The Project Gutenberg eBook, Can You Forgive Her (You)?, by Anthony Trollope

This eBook is for the use of anyone anywhere at no cost and with almost no restrictions whatsoever. You may copy it, give it away or re-use it under the terms of the Project Gutenberg License included with this eBook or online at www.gutenberg.org

Title: Can You Forgive Her (You)?

Author: Anthony Trollope

Release Date: November 16, 2006 -LSB-eBook #19500-RSB- Most recently updated: November 19, 2011

Language: English

***START OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK CAN YOU FORGIVE HER?***

E-text prepared by Joseph E. Loewenstein, M.D.

Editorial note:

_Can You Forgive Her (You)?_ was first published in monthly installments -LRB-one shilling each-RRB- in 1864-1865. The first book edition was published by Chapman and Hall in two volumes -LRB-Volume I in 1864 and Volume II in 1865-RRB-.

Volume I was illustrated by Hablôt Knight Browne, better known as

``Phiz'' (Hablôt Knight Browne)
and a favorite of Dickens. Trollope was not pleased with Browne's work, and the illustrations for Volume II were drawn by a Miss E. Taylor of St. Leonards. These original illustrations are referred to in this text file version of the e-book and can be seen by the reader by viewing the HTML version. See 19500-h.htm or 19500-h.zip -LRB-http://www.gutenberg.org/files/19500/19500-h/19500-h.htm-RRB- or -LRB-http://www.gutenberg.org/files/19500/19500-h.zip-RRB-

CAN YOU FORGIVE HER?

by

ANTHONY TROLLOPE

Author of

``Orley Farm,'' (ANTHONY TROLLOPE Author)
``Doctor Thorne,'' (ANTHONY TROLLOPE Author)
``Framley Parsonage,'' (ANTHONY TROLLOPE Author)
etc..

With Illustrations.

In Two Volumes

Alice Is Taught to Grow Upwards, Towards the Light. XXII. Dandy and Flirt. XXIII. Dinner at Matching Priory. XXIV. Three Politicians. XXV. In Which Much of the History of the Pallisers Is Told. XXVI. VOLUME I.

CHAPTER I.

Mr. Vavasor and His (Vavasor) Daughter.

Whether or no, she (Daughter), whom you are to forgive, if you can, did or did not belong to the Upper Ten Thousand of this our English world, I am not prepared to say with any strength of affirmation. By blood she (Daughter) was connected with big people,--distantly connected with some very big people indeed, people who belonged to the Upper Ten Hundred if there be any such division; but of these very big relations she (Daughter) had known and seen little, and they had cared as little for her (Daughter). Her (Daughter) grandfather, Squire Vavasor of Vavasor Hall, in Westmoreland, was a country gentleman, possessing some thousand a year at the outside, and he (gentleman) therefore never came up to London, and had no ambition to have himself numbered as one in any exclusive set. A hot-headed, ignorant, honest old gentleman, he (gentleman) lived ever at Vavasor Hall, declaring to any who would listen to him (gentleman), that the country was going to the mischief, and congratulating himself that at any rate, in his (gentleman) county, parliamentary reform had been powerless to alter the old political arrangements. Alice Vavasor, whose offence against the world I am to tell you, and if possible to excuse, was the daughter of his (gentleman) younger son; and as her (daughter) father, John Vavasor, had done nothing to raise the family name to eminence, Alice could not lay claim to any high position from her (Alice) birth as a Vavasor. John Vavasor had come up to London early in life as a barrister, and had failed. He (Vavasor) had failed at least in attaining either much wealth or much repute, though he (Vavasor) had succeeded in earning, or perhaps I might better say, in obtaining, a livelihood. He (Vavasor) had married a lady somewhat older than himself, who was in possession of four hundred a year, and who was related to those big people to whom I have alluded. Who these were and the special nature of the relationship, I shall be called upon to explain hereafter, but at present it will suffice to say that Alice Macleod gave great offence to all her (Alice) friends by her (Alice) marriage. She (Alice) did not, however, give them much time for the indulgence of their anger. Having given birth to a daughter within twelve months of her (daughter) marriage, she (daughter) died, leaving in abeyance that question as to whether the fault of her (daughter) marriage should or should not be pardoned by her (daughter) family.

When a man marries an heiress for her (daughter) money, if that money be within her (daughter) own control, as was the case with Miss Macleod's fortune, it is generally well for the speculating lover that the lady's friends should quarrel with him (lover) and with her (lady). She (lady) is thereby driven to throw herself entirely into the gentleman's arms, and he (gentleman) thus becomes possessed of the wife and the money without the abominable nuisance of stringent settlements. But the Macleods, though they quarrelled with Alice, did not quarrel with her (Alice) _à l'outrance_. They snubbed herself and her (Alice) chosen husband; but they did not so far separate themselves from her (Alice) and her (Alice) affairs as to give up the charge of her (Alice) possessions. Her (Alice) four hundred a year was settled very closely on herself and on her (Alice) children, without even a life interest having been given to Mr. Vavasor, and therefore when she (Alice) died the mother's fortune became the property of the little baby. But, under these circumstances, the big people did not refuse to interest themselves to some extent on behalf of the father. I do not suppose that any actual agreement or compact was made between Mr. Vavasor and the Macleods; but it came to be understood between them that if he (Vavasor) made no demand upon them for his (Vavasor) daughter's money, and allowed them to have charge of her (daughter) education, they would do something for him (Vavasor). He (Vavasor) was a practising barrister, though his (Vavasor) practice had never amounted to much; and a practising barrister is always supposed to be capable of filling any situation which may come his (barrister) way. Two years after his (barrister) wife's death Mr. Vavasor was appointed assistant commissioner in some office which had to do with insolvents, and which was abolished three years after his (Vavasor) appointment. It was at first thought that he (Vavasor) would keep his (Vavasor) eight hundred a year for life and be required to do nothing for it; but a wretched cheeseparing Whig government, as John Vavasor called it when describing the circumstances of the arrangement to his (Vavasor) father, down in Westmoreland, would not permit this; it gave him (Vavasor) the option of taking four hundred a year for doing nothing, or of keeping his (Vavasor) whole income and attending three days a week for three hours a day during term time, at a miserable dingy little office near Chancery Lane, where his (Vavasor) duty would consist in signing his (Vavasor) name to accounts which he (Vavasor) never read, and at which he (Vavasor) was never supposed even to look. He (Vavasor) had sulkily elected to keep the money, and this signing had been now for nearly twenty years the business of his (Vavasor) life. Of course he (Vavasor) considered himself to be a very hardly-used man. One Lord Chancellor after another he (Chancellor) petitioned, begging that he (Chancellor) might be relieved from the cruelty of his (Chancellor) position, and allowed to take his (Chancellor) salary without doing anything in return for it. The amount of work which he (Chancellor) did perform was certainly a minimum of labour. Term time, as terms were counted in Mr. Vavasor's office, hardly comprised half the year, and the hours of weekly attendance did not do more than make one day's work a week for a working man; but Mr. Vavasor had been appointed an assistant commissioner, and with every Lord Chancellor he (Chancellor) argued that all Westminster Hall, and Lincoln's Inn to boot, had no right to call upon him (Chancellor) to degrade himself by signing his (Chancellor) name to accounts. In answer to every memorial he (Chancellor) was offered the alternative of freedom with half his (Chancellor) income; and so the thing went on.

There can, however, be no doubt that Mr. Vavasor was better off and happier with his (Vavasor) almost nominal employment than he (Vavasor) would have been without it. He (Vavasor) always argued that it kept him (Vavasor) in London; but he (Vavasor) would undoubtedly have lived in London with or without his (Vavasor) official occupation. He (Vavasor) had become so habituated to London life in a small way, before the choice of leaving London was open to him (Vavasor), that nothing would have kept him (Vavasor) long away from it. After his (Vavasor) wife's death he (Vavasor) dined at his (Vavasor) club every day on which a dinner was not given to him (Vavasor) by some friend elsewhere, and was rarely happy except when so dining. They who have seen him (Vavasor) scanning the steward's list of dishes, and giving the necessary orders for his (Vavasor) own and his (Vavasor) friend's dinner, at about half past four in the afternoon, have seen John Vavasor at the only moment of the day at which he (Vavasor) is ever much in earnest. All other things are light and easy to him (Vavasor),--to be taken easily and to be dismissed easily. Even the eating of the dinner calls forth from him (Vavasor) no special sign of energy. Sometimes a frown will gather on his (Vavasor) brow as he (Vavasor) tastes the first half glass from his (Vavasor) bottle of claret; but as a rule that which he (Vavasor) has prepared for himself with so much elaborate care, is consumed with only pleasant enjoyment. Now and again it will happen that the cook is treacherous even to him (cook), and then he (cook) can hit hard; but in hitting he (cook) is quiet, and strikes with a smile on his (cook) face.

Such had been Mr. Vavasor's pursuits and pleasures in life up to the time at which my story commences. But I must not allow the reader to suppose that he (reader) was a man without good qualities. Had he (reader) when young possessed the gift of industry I think that he (reader) might have shone in his (reader) profession, and have been well spoken of and esteemed in the world. As it was he (reader) was a discontented man, but nevertheless he (reader) was popular, and to some extent esteemed. He (reader) was liberal as far as his (reader) means would permit; he (reader) was a man of his (reader) word; and he (reader) understood well that code of by-laws which was presumed to constitute the character of a gentleman in his (gentleman) circle. He (gentleman) knew how to carry himself well among men, and understood thoroughly what might be said, and what might not; what might be done among those with whom he (gentleman) lived, and what should be left undone. By nature, too, he (gentleman) was kindly disposed, loving many persons a little if he (gentleman) loved few or none passionately. Moreover, at the age of fifty, he (gentleman) was a handsome man, with a fine forehead, round which the hair and beard was only beginning to show itself to be grey. He (gentleman) stood well, with a large person, only now beginning to become corpulent. His (gentleman) eyes were bright and grey, and his (gentleman) mouth and chin were sharply cut, and told of gentle birth. Most men who knew John Vavasor well, declared it to be a pity that he (Vavasor) should spend his (Vavasor) time in signing accounts in Chancery Lane.

I have said that Alice Vavasor's big relatives cared but little for her (Vavasor) in her (Vavasor) early years; but I have also said that they were careful to undertake the charge of her (Vavasor) education, and I must explain away this little discrepancy. The biggest of these big people had hardly heard of her (Vavasor); but there was a certain Lady Macleod, not very big herself, but, as it were, hanging on to the skirts of those who were so, who cared very much for Alice. She (Alice) was the widow of a Sir Archibald Macleod, K.C.B., who had been a soldier, she (Alice) herself having also been a Macleod by birth; and for very many years past--from a time previous to the birth of Alice Vavasor--she (Vavasor) had lived at Cheltenham, making short sojourns in London during the spring, when the contents of her (Vavasor) limited purse would admit of her (Vavasor) doing so. Of old Lady Macleod I think I may say that she (Macleod) was a good woman;--that she (Macleod) was a good woman, though subject to two of the most serious drawbacks to goodness which can afflict a lady. She (lady) was a Calvinistic Sabbatarian in religion, and in worldly matters she (lady) was a devout believer in the high rank of her (lady) noble relatives. She (lady) could almost worship a youthful marquis, though he (marquis) lived a life that would disgrace a heathen among heathens; and she (lady) could and did, in her (lady) own mind, condemn crowds of commonplace men and women to all eternal torments of which her (lady) imagination could conceive, because they listened to profane music in a park on Sunday. Yet she (lady) was a good woman. Out of her (lady) small means she (lady) gave much away. She (lady) owed no man anything. She (lady) strove to love her (lady) neighbours. She (lady) bore much pain with calm unspeaking endurance, and she (lady) lived in trust of a better world. Alice Vavasor, who was after all only her (Vavasor) cousin, she (Vavasor) loved with an exceeding love, and yet Alice had done very much to extinguish such love. Alice, in the years of her (Alice) childhood, had been brought up by Lady Macleod; at the age of twelve she (Macleod) had been sent to a school at Aix-la-Chapelle,--a comitatus of her (Macleod) relatives having agreed that such was to be her (Macleod) fate, much in opposition to Lady Macleod's judgement; at nineteen she (Macleod) had returned to Cheltenham, and after remaining there for little more than a year, had expressed her (Macleod) unwillingness to remain longer with her (Macleod) cousin. She (Macleod) could sympathize neither with her (Macleod) relative's faults or virtues. She (Macleod) made an arrangement, therefore, with her (Macleod) father, that they two would keep house together in London, and so they had lived for the last five years;--for Alice Vavasor when she (Vavasor) will be introduced to the reader had already passed her (Vavasor) twenty-fourth birthday.

Their mode of life had been singular and certainly not in all respects satisfactory. Alice when she (Alice) was twenty-one had the full command of her (Alice) own fortune; and when she (Alice) induced her (Alice) father, who for the last fifteen years had lived in lodgings, to take a small house in Queen Anne Street, of course she (Anne) offered to incur a portion of the expense. He (father) had warned her (Anne) that his (father) habits were not those of a domestic man, but he (father) had been content simply so to warn her (Anne). He (father) had not felt it to be his (father) duty to decline the arrangement because he (father) knew himself to be unable to give to his (father) child all that attention which a widowed father under such circumstances should pay to an only daughter. The house had been taken, and Alice and he (father) had lived together, but their lives had been quite apart. For a short time, for a month or two, he (father) had striven to dine at home and even to remain at home through the evening; but the work had been too hard for him (father) and he (father) had utterly broken down. He (father) had said to her (Alice) and to himself that his (father) health would fail him (father) under the effects of so great a change made so late in life, and I am not sure that he (father) had not spoken truly. At any rate the effort had been abandoned, and Mr. Vavasor now never dined at home. Nor did he (Vavasor) and his (Vavasor) daughter ever dine out together. Their joint means did not admit of their giving dinners, and therefore they could not make their joint way in the same circle. It thus came to pass that they lived apart,--quite apart. They saw each other, probably daily; but they did little more than see each other. They did not even breakfast together, and after three o'clock in the day Mr. Vavasor was never to be found in his (Vavasor) own house.

Miss Vavasor had made for herself a certain footing in society, though I am disposed to doubt her (Vavasor) right to be considered as holding a place among the Upper Ten Thousand. Two classes of people she (Vavasor) had chosen to avoid, having been driven to such avoidings by her (Vavasor) aunt's preferences; marquises and such-like, whether wicked or otherwise, she (Vavasor) had eschewed, and had eschewed likewise all Low Church tendencies. The eschewing of marquises is not generally very difficult. Young ladies living with their fathers on very moderate incomes in or about Queen Anne Street are not usually much troubled on that matter. Nor can I say that Miss Vavasor was so troubled. But with her (Queen) there was a certain definite thing to be done towards such eschewal. Lady Macleod by no means avoided her (Macleod) noble relatives, nor did she (Macleod) at all avoid Alice Vavasor. When in London she (Vavasor) was persevering in her (Vavasor) visits to Queen Anne Street, though she (Vavasor) considered herself, nobody knew why, not to be on speaking terms with Mr. Vavasor. And she (Vavasor) strove hard to produce an intimacy between Alice and her (Alice) noble relatives--such an intimacy as that which she (Alice) herself enjoyed;--an intimacy which gave her (Alice) a footing in their houses but no footing in their hearts, or even in their habits. But all this Alice declined with as much consistency as she (Alice) did those other struggles which her (Alice) old cousin made on her (Alice) behalf,--strong, never-flagging, but ever-failing efforts to induce the girl to go to such places of worship as Lady Macleod herself frequented.

A few words must be said as to Alice Vavasor's person; one fact also must be told, and then, I believe, I may start upon my story. As regards her (Vavasor) character, I will leave it to be read in the story itself. The reader already knows that she (Vavasor) appears upon the scene at no very early age, and the mode of her (Vavasor) life had perhaps given to her (Vavasor) an appearance of more years than those which she (Vavasor) really possessed. It was not that her (Vavasor) face was old, but that there was nothing that was girlish in her (Vavasor) manners. Her (Vavasor) demeanour was as staid, and her (Vavasor) voice as self-possessed as though she (Vavasor) had already been ten years married. In person she (Vavasor) was tall and well made, rather large in her (Vavasor) neck and shoulders, as were all the Vavasors, but by no means fat. Her (Vavasor) hair was brown, but very dark, and she (Vavasor) wore it rather lower upon her (Vavasor) forehead than is customary at the present day. Her (Vavasor) eyes, too, were dark, though they were not black, and her (Vavasor) complexion, though not quite that of a brunette, was far away from being fair. Her (Vavasor) nose was somewhat broad, and _retroussé_ too, but to my thinking it was a charming nose, full of character, and giving to her (Vavasor) face at times a look of pleasant humour, which it would otherwise have lacked. Her (Vavasor) mouth was large, and full of character, and her (Vavasor) chin oval, dimpled, and finely chiselled, like her (Vavasor) father's. I beg you, in taking her (Vavasor) for all in all, to admit that she (Vavasor) was a fine, handsome, high-spirited young woman.

And now for my fact. At the time of which I am writing she (Vavasor) was already engaged to be married.

CHAPTER II.

Lady Macleod.

I cannot say that the house in Queen Anne Street was a pleasant house. I am now speaking of the material house, made up of the walls and furniture, and not of any pleasantness or unpleasantness supplied by the inmates. It was a small house on the south side of the street, squeezed in between two large mansions which seemed to crush it, and by which its fair proportion of doorstep and area was in truth curtailed. The stairs were narrow; the dining-room was dark, and possessed none of those appearances of plenteous hospitality which a dining-room should have. But all this would have been as nothing if the drawing-room had been pretty as it is the bounden duty of all drawing-rooms to be. But Alice Vavasor's drawing-room was not pretty. Her (Vavasor) father had had the care of furnishing the house, and he (father) had intrusted the duty to a tradesman who had chosen green paper, a green carpet, green curtains, and green damask chairs. There was a green damask sofa, and two green arm-chairs opposite to each other at the two sides of the fireplace. The room was altogether green, and was not enticing. In shape it was nearly square, the very small back room on the same floor not having been, as is usual, added to it. This had been fitted up as a

``study'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
for Mr. Vavasor, and was very rarely used for any purpose.

Most of us know when we enter a drawing-room whether it is a pretty room or no; but how few of us know how to make a drawing-room pretty! There has come up in London in these latter days a form of room so monstrously ugly that I will venture to say that no other people on earth but Londoners would put up with it. Londoners, as a rule, take their houses as they can get them, looking only to situation, size, and price. What Grecian, what Roman, what Turk, what Italian would endure, or would ever have endured, to use a room with a monstrous cantle in the form of a parallelogram cut sheerly out of one corner of it? This is the shape of room we have now adopted,--or rather which the builders have adopted for us,--in order to throw the whole first floor into one apartment which may be presumed to have noble dimensions,--with such drawback from it as the necessities of the staircase may require. A sharp unadorned corner projects itself into these would-be noble dimensions, and as ugly a form of chamber is produced as any upon which the eye can look. I would say more on the subject if I dared to do so here, but I am bound now to confine myself to Miss Vavasor's room. The monstrous deformity of which I have spoken was not known when that house in Queen Anne Street was built. There is to be found no such abomination of shape in the buildings of our ancestors,--not even in the days of George the Second. But yet the drawing-room of which I speak was ugly, and Alice knew that it was so. She (Alice) knew that it was ugly, and she (Alice) would greatly have liked to banish the green sofa, to have re-papered the wall, and to have hung up curtains with a dash of pink through them. With the green carpet she (Alice) would have been contented. But her (Alice) father was an extravagant man; and from the day on which she (Alice) had come of age she (Alice) had determined that it was her (Alice) special duty to avoid extravagance.

``It's the ugliest room I ever saw in my life,'' (father)
her (Alice) father once said to her (Alice).

``It is not very pretty,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice replied.

``I'll go halves with you in the expense of redoing it,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said Mr. Vavasor.

``Wouldn't that be extravagant, papa? The things have not been here quite four years yet.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

Then Mr. Vavasor had shrugged his (Vavasor) shoulders and said nothing more about it. It was little to him (Vavasor) whether the drawing-room in Queen Anne Street was ugly or pretty. He (Vavasor) was on the committee of his (Vavasor) club, and he (Vavasor) took care that the furniture there should be in all respects comfortable.

It was now June; and that month Lady Macleod was in the habit of spending among her (Macleod) noble relatives in London when she (Macleod) had succeeded in making both ends so far overlap each other at Cheltenham as to give her (Macleod) the fifty pounds necessary for this purpose. For though she (Macleod) spent her (Macleod) month in London among her (Macleod) noble friends, it must not be supposed that her (Macleod) noble friends gave her (Macleod) bed or board. They sometimes gave her (Macleod) tea, such as it was, and once or twice in the month they gave the old lady a second-rate dinner. On these occasions she (lady) hired a little parlour and bedroom behind it in King Street, Saint James's, and lived a hot, uncomfortable life, going about at nights to gatherings of fashionable people of which she (lady) in her (lady) heart disapproved, seeking for smiles which seldom came to her (lady), and which she (lady) excused herself for desiring because they were the smiles of her (lady) kith and her (lady) kin, telling herself always that she (lady) made this vain journey to the modern Babylon for the good of Alice Vavasor, and telling herself as often that she (Vavasor) now made it for the last time. On the occasion of her (Vavasor) preceding visit she (Vavasor) had reminded herself that she (Vavasor) was then seventy-five years old, and had sworn to herself that she (Vavasor) would come to London no more; but here she (Vavasor) was again in London, having justified the journey to herself on the plea that there were circumstances in Alice's engagement which made it desirable that she (Alice) should for a while be near her (Alice) niece. Her (Alice) niece, as she (Alice) thought, was hardly managing her (Alice) own affairs discreetly.

``Well, aunt,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, as the old lady walked into the drawing-room one morning at eleven o'clock. Alice always called Lady Macleod her (Alice) aunt, though, as has been before explained, there was no such close connexion between them. During Lady Macleod's sojourn in London these morning visits were made almost every day. Alice never denied herself, and even made a point of remaining at home to receive them unless she (Alice) had previously explained that she (Alice) would be out; but I am not prepared to say that they were, of their own nature, agreeable to her (Alice).

``Would you mind shutting the window, my dear?'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)
said Lady Macleod, seating herself stiffly on one of the small ugly green chairs. She (Macleod) had been educated at a time when easy-chairs were considered vicious, and among people who regarded all easy postures as being so; and she (Macleod) could still boast, at seventy-six, that she (Macleod) never leaned back.
``Would you mind shutting the window? I'm so warm that I'm afraid of the draught.'' (unknown)

-LSB-Illustration:

``Would you mind shutting the window?'' (unknown)
-RSB-

``You don't mean to say that you've walked from King Street,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, doing as she (Alice) was desired.

``Indeed I do,--every step of the way. Cabs are so ruinous. It's a most unfortunate thing; they always say it's just over the two miles here. I don't believe a word of it, because I'm only a little more than the half-hour walking it; and those men will say anything. But how can I prove it, you know?'' (unknown)

``I really think it's too far for you to walk when it's so warm.'' (unknown)

``But what can I do, my dear? I must come, when I've specially come up to London to see you. I shall have a cab back again, because it'll be hotter then, and dear Lady Midlothian has promised to send her (Midlothian) carriage at three to take me to the concert. I do so wish you'd go, Alice.'' (unknown)

``It's out of the question, aunt. The idea of my going in that way at the last moment, without any invitation!'' (unknown)

``It wouldn't be without an invitation, Alice. The marchioness has said to me over and over again how glad she (Alice) would be to see you, if I would bring you.'' (unknown)

``Why doesn't she (Alice) come and call if she (Alice) is so anxious to know me?'' (unknown)

``My dear, you've no right to expect it; you haven't indeed. She (Alice) never calls even on me.'' (unknown)

``I know I've no right, and I don't expect it, and I don't want it. But neither has she (Alice) a right to suppose that, under such circumstances, I shall go to her (Alice) house. You might as well give it up, aunt. Cart ropes wouldn't drag me there.'' (unknown)

``I think you are very wrong,--particularly under your present circumstances. A young woman that is going to be married, as you are--'' (unknown)

``As I am,--perhaps.'' (unknown)

``That's nonsense, Alice. Of course you are; and for his (Alice) sake you are bound to cultivate any advantages that naturally belong to you. As to Lady Midlothian or the marchioness coming to call on you here in your father's house, after all that has passed, you really have no right to look for it.'' (unknown)

``And I don't look for it.'' (unknown)

``That sort of people are not expected to call. If you'll think of it, how could they do it with all the demands they have on their time?'' (unknown)

``My dear aunt, I wouldn't interfere with their time for worlds.'' (unknown)

``Nobody can say of me, I'm sure, that I run after great people or rich people. It does happen that some of the nearest relations I have,--indeed I may say the nearest relations,--are people of high rank; and I do not see that I'm bound to turn away from my own flesh and blood because of that, particularly when they are always so anxious to keep up the connexion.'' (unknown)

``I was only speaking of myself, aunt. It is very different with you. You have known them all your life.'' (unknown)

``And how are you to know them if you won't begin? Lady Midlothian said to me only yesterday that she (Midlothian) was glad to hear that you were going to be married so respectably, and then--'' (unknown)

``Upon my word I'm very much obliged to her (Midlothian) ladyship. I wonder whether she (Midlothian) considered that she (Midlothian) married respectably when she (Midlothian) took Lord Midlothian?'' (Lady)

Now Lady Midlothian had been unfortunate in her (Alice) marriage, having united herself to a man of bad character, who had used her (Alice) ill, and from whom she (Alice) had now been for some years separated. Alice might have spared her (Alice) allusion to this misfortune when speaking of the countess to the cousin who was so fond of her (Alice), but she (Alice) was angered by the application of that odious word respectable to her (Alice) own prospects; and perhaps the more angered as she (Alice) was somewhat inclined to feel that the epithet did suit her (Alice) own position. Her (Alice) engagement, she (Alice) had sometimes told herself, was very respectable, and had as often told herself that it lacked other attractions which it should have possessed. She (Alice) was not quite pleased with herself in having accepted John Grey,--or rather perhaps was not satisfied with herself in having loved him (Grey). In her (Alice) many thoughts on the subject, she (Alice) always admitted to herself that she (Alice) had accepted him (Grey) simply because she (Alice) loved him (Grey);--that she (Alice) had given her (Alice) quick assent to his (Grey) quick proposal simply because he (Grey) had won her (Alice) heart. But she (Alice) was sometimes almost angry with herself that she (Alice) had permitted her (Alice) heart to be thus easily taken from her (Alice), and had rebuked herself for her (Alice) girlish facility. But the marriage would be at any rate respectable. Mr. Grey was a man of high character, of good though moderate means; he (Grey) was, too, well educated, of good birth, a gentleman, and a man of talent. No one could deny that the marriage would be highly respectable, and her (Alice) father had been more than satisfied. Why Miss Vavasor herself was not quite satisfied will, I hope, in time make itself appear. In the meanwhile it can be understood that Lady Midlothian's praise would gall her (Midlothian).

``Alice, don't be uncharitable,'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)
said Lady Macleod severely.
``Whatever may have been Lady Midlothian's misfortunes no one can say they have resulted from her (Lady) own fault.'' (unknown)

``Yes they can, aunt, if she (Lady) married a man whom she (Lady) knew to be a scapegrace because he (man) was very rich and an earl.'' (unknown)

``She (Lady) was the daughter of a nobleman herself, and only married in her (Lady) own degree. But I don't want to discuss that. She (Lady) meant to be good-natured when she (Lady) mentioned your marriage, and you should take it as it was meant. After all she (Lady) was only your mother's second cousin--'' (unknown)

``Dear aunt, I make no claim on her (aunt) cousinship.'' (unknown)

``But she (aunt) admits the claim, and is quite anxious that you should know her (aunt). She (aunt) has been at the trouble to find out everything about Mr. Grey, and told me that nothing could be more satisfactory.'' (unknown)

``Upon my word I am very much obliged to her (aunt).'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)

Lady Macleod was a woman of much patience, and possessed also of considerable perseverance. For another half-hour she (Macleod) went on expatiating on the advantages which would accrue to Alice as a married woman from an acquaintance with her (Alice) noble relatives, and endeavouring to persuade her (Alice) that no better opportunity than the present would present itself. There would be a place in Lady Midlothian's carriage, as none other of the daughters were going but Lady Jane. Lady Midlothian would take it quite as a compliment, and a concert was not like a ball or any customary party. An unmarried girl might very properly go to a concert under such circumstances as now existed without any special invitation. Lady Macleod ought to have known her (Macleod) adopted niece better. Alice was immoveable. As a matter of course she (Alice) was immoveable. Lady Macleod had seldom been able to persuade her (Macleod) to anything, and ought to have been well sure that, of all things, she (Macleod) could not have persuaded her (Macleod) to this.

Then, at last, they came to another subject, as to which Lady Macleod declared that she (Macleod) had specially come on this special morning, forgetting, probably, that she (Macleod) had already made the same assertion with reference to the concert. But in truth the last assertion was the correct one, and on that other subject she (Macleod) had been hurried on to say more than she (Macleod) meant by the eagerness of the moment. All the morning she (Macleod) had been full of the matter on which she (Macleod) was now about to speak. She (Macleod) had discussed it quite at length with Lady Midlothian;--though she (Lady) was by no means prepared to tell Alice Vavasor that any such discussion had taken place. From the concert, and the effect which Lady Midlothian's countenance might have upon Mr. Grey's future welfare, she (Lady) got herself by degrees round to a projected Swiss tour which Alice was about to make. Of this Swiss tour she (Alice) had heard before, but had not heard who were to be Miss Vavasor's companions until Lady Midlothian had told her (Midlothian). How it had come to pass that Lady Midlothian had interested herself so much in the concerns of a person whom she (Midlothian) did not know, and on whom she (Midlothian) in her (Midlothian) greatness could not be expected to call, I cannot say; but from some quarter she (Midlothian) had learned who were the proposed companions of Alice Vavasor's tour, and she (Vavasor) had told Lady Macleod that she (Macleod) did not at all approve of the arrangement.

``And when do you go, Alice?'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)
said Lady Macleod.

``Early in July, I believe. It will be very hot, but Kate must be back by the middle of August.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Kate Vavasor was Alice's first cousin.

``Oh! Kate is to go with you?'' (unknown)

``Of course she (Kate) is. I could not go alone, or with no one but George. Indeed it was Kate who made up the party.'' (unknown)

``Of course you could not go alone with George,'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)
said Lady Macleod, very grimly. Now George Vavasor was Kate's brother, and was therefore also first cousin to Alice. He (Vavasor) was heir to the old squire down in Westmoreland, with whom Kate lived, their father being dead. Nothing, it would seem, could be more rational than that Alice should go to Switzerland with her (Alice) cousins; but Lady Macleod was clearly not of this opinion; she (Macleod) looked very grim as she (Macleod) made this allusion to cousin George, and seemed to be preparing herself for a fight.

``That is exactly what I say,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
answered Alice.
``But, indeed, he (George) is simply going as an escort to me and Kate, as we don't like the rôle of unprotected females. It is very good-natured of him (George), seeing how much his (George) time is taken up.'' (unknown)

``I thought he (George) never did anything.'' (unknown)

``That's because you don't know him (George), aunt.'' (unknown)

``No; certainly I don't know him (George).'' (She)
She (Alice) did not add that she (Alice) had no wish to know Mr. George Vavasor, but she (Alice) looked it.
``And has your father been told that he (father) is going?'' (unknown)

``Of course he (father) has.'' (unknown)

``And does--'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)
Lady Macleod hesitated a little before she (Macleod) went on, and then finished her (Macleod) question with a little spasmodic assumption of courage.
``And does Mr. Grey know that he (Grey) is going?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice remained silent for a full minute before she (Alice) answered this question, during which Lady Macleod sat watching her (Macleod) grimly, with her (Macleod) eyes very intent upon her (Macleod) niece's face. If she (Macleod) supposed such silence to have been in any degree produced by shame in answering the question, she (Macleod) was much mistaken. But it may be doubted whether she (Macleod) understood the character of the girl whom she (Macleod) thought she (Macleod) knew so well, and it is probable that she (Macleod) did make such mistake.

``I might tell you simply that he (Grey) does,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice at last,
``seeing that I wrote to him (Grey) yesterday, letting him (Grey) know that such were our arrangements; but I feel that I should not thus answer the question you mean to ask. You want to know whether Mr. Grey will approve of it. As I only wrote yesterday of course I have not heard, and therefore cannot say. But I can say this, aunt, that much as I might regret his (Grey) disapproval, it would make no change in my plans.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``Would it not? Then I must tell you, you are very wrong. It ought to make a change. What! the disapproval of the man you are going to marry make no change in your plans?'' (unknown)

``Not in that matter. Come, aunt, if we must discuss this matter let us do it at any rate fairly. In an ordinary way, if Mr. Grey had asked me to give up for any reason my trip altogether, I should have given it up certainly, as I would give up any other indifferent project at the request of so dear a friend,--a friend with whom I am so--so--so closely connected. But if he (friend) asked me not to travel with my cousin George, I should refuse him (George) absolutely, without a word of parley on the subject, simply because of the nature and closeness of my connection with him (George). I suppose you understand what I mean, aunt?'' (unknown)

``I suppose I do. You mean that you would refuse to obey him (George) on the very subject on which he (George) has a right to claim your obedience.'' (unknown)

``He (George) has no right to claim my obedience on any subject,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice; and as she (Alice) spoke Aunt Macleod jumped up with a little start at the vehemence of the words, and of the tone in which they were expressed. She (Macleod) had heard that tone before, and might have been used to it; but, nevertheless, the little jump was involuntary.
``At present he (George) has no right to my obedience on any subject, but least of all on that,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``His (George) advice he (George) may give me, but I am quite sure he (George) will not ask for obedience.'' (unknown)

``And if he (George) advises you you will slight his (George) advice.'' (unknown)

``If he (George) tells me that I had better not travel with my cousin George I shall certainly not take his (George) advice. Moreover, I should be careful to let him (George) know how much I was offended by any such counsel from him (George). It would show a littleness on his (George) part, and a suspicion of which I cannot suppose him (George) to be capable.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice, as she (Alice) said this, got up from her (Alice) seat and walked about the room. When she (Alice) had finished she (Alice) stood at one of the windows with her (Alice) back to her (Alice) visitor. There was silence between them for a minute or two, during which Lady Macleod was deeply considering how best she (Macleod) might speak the terrible words, which, as Alice's nearest female relative, she (Alice) felt herself bound to utter. At last she (Alice) collected her (Alice) thoughts and her (Alice) courage, and spoke out.

``My dear Alice, I need hardly say that if you had a mother living, or any person with you filling the place of a mother, I should not interfere in this matter.'' (unknown)

``Of course, Aunt Macleod, if you think I am wrong you have quite a right to say so.'' (unknown)

``I do think you are wrong,--very wrong, indeed; and if you persist in this I am afraid I must say that I shall think you wicked. Of course Mr. Grey cannot like you to travel with George Vavasor.'' (unknown)

``And why not, aunt?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice, as she (Alice) asked this question, turned round and confronted Lady Macleod boldly. She (Macleod) spoke with a steady voice, and fixed her (Macleod) eyes upon the old lady's face, as though determined to show that she (Macleod) had no fear of what might be said to her (Macleod).

``Why not, Alice? Surely you do not wish me to say why not.'' (unknown)

``But I do wish you to say why not. How can I defend myself till the accusation is made?'' (unknown)

``You are now engaged to marry Mr. Grey, with the consent and approbation of all your friends. Two years ago you had--had--'' (unknown)

``Had what, aunt? If you mean to say that two years ago I was engaged to my cousin George you are mistaken. Three years ago I told him (George) that under certain conditions I would become engaged to him (George). But my conditions did not suit him (George), nor his (George) me, and no engagement was ever made. Mr. Grey knows the history of the whole thing. As far as it was possible I have told him (Grey) everything that took place.'' (unknown)

``The fact was, Alice, that George Vavasor's mode of life was such that an engagement with him (Vavasor) would have been absolute madness.'' (unknown)

``Dear aunt, you must excuse me if I say that I cannot discuss George Vavasor's mode of life. If I were thinking of becoming his (Vavasor) wife you would have a perfect right to discuss it, because of your constant kindness to me. But as matters are he (Vavasor) is simply a cousin; and as I like him (Vavasor) and you do not, we had better say nothing about him (Vavasor).'' (unknown)

``I must say this--that after what has passed, and at the present crisis of your life--'' (unknown)

``Dear aunt, I'm not in any crisis.'' (unknown)

``Yes you are, Alice; in the most special crisis of a girl's life. You are still a girl, but you are the promised wife of a very worthy man, who will look to you for all his (man) domestic happiness. George Vavasor has the name, at least, of being very wild.'' (unknown)

``The worthy man and the wild man must fight it out between them. If I were going away with George by himself, there might be something in what you say.'' (unknown)

``That would be monstrous.'' (unknown)

``Monstrous or not, it isn't what I'm about to do. Kate and I have put our purses together, and are going to have an outing for our special fun and gratification. As we should be poor travellers alone, George has promised to go with his (George) sister. Papa knows all about it, and never thought of making any objection.'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)

Lady Macleod shook her (Macleod) head. She (Macleod) did not like to say anything against Mr. Vavasor before his (Vavasor) daughter; but the shaking of her (Macleod) head was intended to signify that Mr. Vavasor's assent in such a matter was worth nothing.

``I can only say again,'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)
said Lady Macleod,
``that I think Mr. Grey will be displeased,--and that he (Grey) will have very great cause for displeasure. And I think, moreover, that his (Grey) approbation ought to be your chief study. I believe, my dear, I'll ask you to let Jane get me a cab. I shan't have a bit too much time to dress for the concert.'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)

Alice simply rang the bell, and said no further word on the subject which they had been discussing. When Lady Macleod got up to go away, Alice kissed her (Alice), as was customary with them, and the old lady as she (lady) went uttered her (lady) customary valediction.

``God bless you, my dear. Good-bye! I'll come to-morrow if I can.'' (unknown)
There was therefore no quarrel between them. But both of them felt that words had been spoken which must probably lead to some diminution of their past intimacy.

When Lady Macleod had gone Alice sat alone for an hour thinking of what had passed between them,--thinking rather of those two men, the worthy man and the wild man, whose names had been mentioned in close connection with herself. John Grey was a worthy man, a man worthy at all points, as far as she (Alice) knew him (man). She (Alice) told herself it was so. And she (Alice) told herself, also, that her (Alice) cousin George was wild,--very wild. And yet her (Alice) thoughts were, I fear, on the whole more kindly towards her (Alice) cousin than towards her (Alice) lover. She (Alice) had declared to her (Alice) aunt that John Grey would be incapable of such suspicion as would be shown by any objection on his (Grey) part to the arrangements made for the tour. She (Alice) had said so, and had so believed; and yet she (Alice) continued to brood over the position which her (Alice) affairs would take, if he (Grey) did make the objection which Lady Macleod anticipated. She (Macleod) told herself over and over again, that under such circumstances she (Macleod) would not give way an inch.

``He (God) is free to go,'' (she)
she (Macleod) said to herself.
``If he (God) does not trust me he (God) is quite free to go.'' (she)
It may almost be said that she (Macleod) came at last to anticipate from her (Macleod) lover that very answer to her (Macleod) own letter which she (Macleod) had declared him (lover) to be incapable of making.

CHAPTER III.

John Grey, the Worthy Man.

Mr. Grey's answer to Alice Vavasor's letter, which was duly sent by return of post and duly received on the morning after Lady Macleod's visit, may perhaps be taken as giving a sample of his (Grey) worthiness. It was dated from Nethercoats, a small country-house in Cambridgeshire which belonged to him (Grey), at which he (Grey) already spent much of his (Grey) time, and at which he (Grey) intended to live altogether after his (Grey) marriage.

Nethercoats, June, 186--.

DEAREST ALICE,

I am glad you have settled your affairs,--foreign affairs, I mean,--so much to your mind. As to your home affairs they are not, to my thinking, quite so satisfactorily arranged. But as I am a party interested in the latter my opinion may perhaps have an undue bias. Touching the tour, I quite agree with you that you and Kate would have been uncomfortable alone. It's a very fine theory, that of women being able to get along without men as well as with them; but, like other fine theories, it will be found very troublesome by those who first put it in practice. Gloved hands, petticoats, feminine softness, and the general homage paid to beauty, all stand in the way of success. These things may perhaps some day be got rid of, and possibly with advantage; but while young ladies are still encumbered with them a male companion will always be found to be a comfort. I don't quite know whether your cousin George is the best possible knight you might have chosen. I should consider myself to be infinitely preferable, had my going been upon the cards. Were you in danger of meeting Paynim foes, he (George), no doubt, would kill them off much quicker than I could do, and would be much more serviceable in liberating you from the dungeons of oppressors, or even from stray tigers in the Swiss forests. But I doubt his (George) being punctual with the luggage. He (George) will want you or Kate to keep the accounts, if any are kept. He (George) will be slow in getting you glasses of water at the railway stations, and will always keep you waiting at breakfast. I hold that a man with two ladies on a tour should be an absolute slave to them, or they will not fully enjoy themselves. He (slave) should simply be an upper servant, with the privilege of sitting at the same table with his (slave) mistresses. I have my doubts as to whether your cousin is fit for the place; but, as to myself, it is just the thing that I was made for. Luckily, however, neither you nor Kate are without wills of your own, and perhaps you may be able to reduce Mr. Vavasor to obedience.

As to the home affairs I have very little to say here,--in this letter. I shall of course run up and see you before you start, and shall probably stay a week in town. I know I ought not to do so, as it will be a week of idleness, and yet not a week of happiness. I'd sooner have an hour with you in the country than a whole day in London. And I always feel in town that I've too much to do to allow of my doing anything. If it were sheer idleness I could enjoy it, but it is a feverish idleness, in which one is driven here and there, expecting some gratification which not only never comes, but which never even begins to come. I will, however, undergo a week of it,--say the last seven days of this month, and shall trust to you to recompense me by as much of yourself as your town doings will permit.

And now again as to those home affairs. If I say nothing now I believe you will understand why I refrain. You have cunningly just left me to imply, from what you say, that all my arguments have been of no avail; but you do not answer them, or even tell me that you have decided. I shall therefore imply nothing, and still trust to my personal eloquence for success. Or rather not trust,--not trust, but hope.

The garden is going on very well. We are rather short of water, and therefore not quite as bright as I had hoped; but we are preparing with untiring industry for future brightness. Your commands have been obeyed in all things, and Morrison always says

``The mistress didn't mean this,'' (Morrison)
or
``The mistress did intend that.'' (Morrison)
God bless the mistress is what I now say, and send her (mistress) home, to her (mistress) own home, to her (mistress) flowers, and her (mistress) fruit, and her (mistress) house, and her (mistress) husband, as soon as may be, with no more of these delays which are to me so grievous, and which seem to me to be so unnecessary. That is my prayer.

Yours ever and always,

J. G.

``I didn't give commands,'' (J. G.)
Alice said to herself, as she (Alice) sat with the letter at her (Alice) solitary breakfast-table.
``He (God) asked me how I liked the things, and of course I was obliged to say. I was obliged to seem to care, even if I didn't care.'' (she)
Such were her (Alice) first thoughts as she (Alice) put the letter back into its envelope, after reading it the second time. When she (Alice) opened it, which she (Alice) did quickly, not pausing a moment lest she (Alice) should suspect herself of fearing to see what might be its contents, her (Alice) mind was full of that rebuke which her (Alice) aunt had anticipated, and which she (Alice) had almost taught herself to expect. She (Alice) had torn the letter open rapidly, and had dashed at its contents with quick eyes. In half a moment she (Alice) had seen what was the nature of the reply respecting the proposed companion of her (Alice) tour, and then she (Alice) had completed her (Alice) reading slowly enough.
``No; I gave no commands,'' (she)
she (Alice) repeated to herself, as though she (Alice) might thereby absolve herself from blame in reference to some possible future accusations, which might perhaps be brought against her (Alice) under certain circumstances which she (Alice) was contemplating.

Then she (Alice) considered the letter bit by bit, taking it backwards, and sipping her (Alice) tea every now and then amidst her (Alice) thoughts. No; she (Alice) had no home, no house, there. She (Alice) had no husband;--not as yet. He (husband) spoke of their engagement as though it were a betrothal, as betrothals used to be of yore; as though they were already in some sort married. Such betrothals were not made now-a-days. There still remained, both to him (husband) and to her (Alice), a certain liberty of extricating themselves from this engagement. Should he (husband) come to her (Alice) and say that he (husband) found that their contemplated marriage would not make him (husband) happy, would not she (Alice) release him (husband) without a word of reproach? Would not she (Alice) regard him (husband) as much more honourable in doing so than in adhering to a marriage which was distasteful to him (husband)? And if she (Alice) would so judge him (husband),--judge him (judge) and certainly acquit him (judge), was it not reasonable that she (Alice) under similar circumstances should expect a similar acquittal? Then she (Alice) declared to herself that she (Alice) carried on this argument within her (Alice) own breast simply as an argument, induced to do so by that assertion on his (judge) part that he (judge) was already her (Alice) husband,--that his (judge) house was even now her (Alice) home. She (Alice) had no intention of using that power which was still hers. She (Alice) had no wish to go back from her (Alice) pledged word. She (Alice) thought that she (Alice) had no such wish. She (Alice) loved him (judge) much, and admired him (judge) even more than she (Alice) loved him (judge). He (judge) was noble, generous, clever, good,--so good as to be almost perfect; nay, for aught she (Alice) knew he (judge) was perfect. Would that he (judge) had some faults! Would that he (judge) had! Would that he (judge) had! How could she (Alice), full of faults as she (Alice) knew herself to be,--how could she (Alice) hope to make happy a man perfect as he (man) was! But then there would be no doubt as to her (Alice) present duty. She (Alice) loved him (man), and that was everything. Having told him (man) that she (Alice) loved him (man), and having on that score accepted his (man) love, nothing but a change in her (Alice) heart towards him (man) could justify her (Alice) in seeking to break the bond which bound them together. She (Alice) did love him (man), and she (Alice) loved him (man) only.

But she (Alice) had once loved her (Alice) cousin. Yes, truly it was so. In her (Alice) thoughts she (Alice) did not now deny it. She (Alice) had loved him (cousin), and was tormented by a feeling that she (Alice) had had a more full delight in that love than in this other that had sprung up subsequently. She (Alice) had told herself that this had come of her (Alice) youth;--that love at twenty was sweeter than it could be afterwards. There had been a something of rapture in that earlier dream which could never be repeated,--which could never live, indeed, except in a dream. Now, now that she (Alice) was older and perhaps wiser, love meant a partnership, in which each partner would be honest to the other, in which each would wish and strive for the other's welfare, so that thus their joint welfare might be insured. Then, in those early girlish days, it had meant a total abnegation of self. The one was of earth, and therefore possible. The other had been a ray from heaven,--and impossible, except in a dream.

And she (Alice) had been mistaken in her (Alice) first love. She (Alice) admitted that frankly. He (Alice) whom she (Alice) had worshipped had been an idol of clay, and she (Alice) knew that it was well for her (Alice) to have abandoned that idolatry. He (Alice) had not only been untrue to her (Alice), but, worse than that, had been false in excusing his (Alice) untruth. He (Alice) had not only promised falsely, but had made such promises with a deliberate, premeditated falsehood. And he (Alice) had been selfish, coldly selfish, weighing the value of his (Alice) own low lusts against that of her (Alice) holy love. She (Alice) had known this, and had parted from him (Alice) with an oath to herself that no promised contrition on his (Alice) part should ever bring them again together. But she (Alice) had pardoned him (Alice) as a man, though never as a lover, and had bade him (lover) welcome again as a cousin and as her (Alice) friend's brother. She (Alice) had again become very anxious as to his (lover) career, not hiding her (Alice) regard, but professing that anxiety aloud. She (Alice) knew him (lover) to be clever, ambitious, bold,--and she (Alice) believed even yet, in spite of her (Alice) own experience, that he (lover) might not be bad at heart. Now, as she (Alice) told herself that in truth she (Alice) loved the man to whom her (Alice) troth was plighted, I fear that she (Alice) almost thought more of that other man from whom she (Alice) had torn herself asunder.

``Why should he (God) find himself unhappy in London?'' (she)
she (Alice) said, as she (Alice) went back to the letter.
``Why should he (God) pretend to condemn the very place which most men find the fittest for all their energies? Were I a man, no earthly consideration should induce me to live elsewhere. It is odd how we differ in all things. However brilliant might be his (man) own light, he (man) would be contented to hide it under a bushel!'' (she)

And at last she (Alice) recurred to that matter as to which she (Alice) had been so anxious when she (Alice) first opened her (Alice) lover's letter. It will be remembered how assured she (Alice) had expressed herself that Mr. Grey would not condescend to object to her (Alice) travelling with her (Alice) cousin. He (Grey) had not so condescended. He (Grey) had written on the matter with a pleasant joke, like a gentleman as he (gentleman) was, disdaining to allude to the past passages in the life of her (Alice) whom he (gentleman) loved, abstaining even from expressing anything that might be taken as a permission on his (gentleman) part. There had been in Alice's words, as she (Alice) told him (gentleman) of their proposed plan, a something that had betrayed a tremor in her (Alice) thoughts. She (Alice) had studiously striven so to frame her (Alice) phrases that her (Alice) tale might be told as any other simple statement,--as though there had been no trembling in her (Alice) mind as she (Alice) wrote. But she (Alice) had failed, and she (Alice) knew that she (Alice) had failed. She (Alice) had failed; and he (gentleman) had read all her (Alice) effort and all her (Alice) failure. She (Alice) was quite conscious of this; she (Alice) felt it thoroughly; and she (Alice) knew that he (gentleman) was noble and a gentleman to the last drop of his (gentleman) blood. And yet--yet--yet there was almost a feeling of disappointment in that he (gentleman) had not written such a letter as Lady Macleod had anticipated.

During the next week Lady Macleod still came almost daily to Queen Anne Street, but nothing further was said between her (Queen) and Miss Vavasor as to the Swiss tour; nor were any questions asked about Mr. Grey's opinion on the subject. The old lady of course discovered that there was no quarrel, or, as she (lady) believed, any probability of a quarrel; and with that she (lady) was obliged to be contented. Nor did she (lady) again on this occasion attempt to take Alice to Lady Midlothian's. Indeed, their usual subjects of conversation were almost abandoned, and Lady Macleod's visits, though they were as constant as heretofore, were not so long. She (Macleod) did not dare to talk about Mr. Grey, and because she (Macleod) did not so dare, was determined to regard herself as in a degree ill-used. So she (Macleod) was silent, reserved, and fretful. At length came the last day of her (Macleod) London season, and her (Macleod) last visit to her (Macleod) niece.

``I would come because it's my last day,'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)
said Lady Macleod;
``but really I'm so hurried, and have so many things to do, that I hardly know how to manage it.'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)

``It's very kind,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, giving her (Alice) aunt an affectionate squeeze of the hand.

``I'm keeping the cab, so I can just stay twenty-five minutes. I've marked the time accurately, but I know the man will swear it's over the half-hour.'' (unknown)

``You'll have no more trouble about cabs, aunt, when you are back in Cheltenham.'' (unknown)

``The flies are worse, my dear. I really think they're worse. I pay the bill every month, but they've always one down that I didn't have. It's the regular practice, for I've had them from all the men in the place.'' (unknown)

``It's hard enough to find honest men anywhere, I suppose.'' (unknown)

``Or honest women either. What do you think of Mrs. Green wanting to charge me for an extra week, because she (Green) says I didn't give her (Green) notice till Tuesday morning? I won't pay her (Green), and she (Green) may stop my things if she (Green) dares. However, it's the last time. I shall never come up to London again, my dear.'' (unknown)

``Oh, aunt, don't say that!'' (unknown)

``But I do say it, my dear. What should an old woman like me do, trailing up to town every year, merely because it's what people choose to call the season.'' (unknown)

``To see your friends, of course. Age doesn't matter when a person's health is so good as yours.'' (unknown)

``If you knew what I suffer from lumbago,--though I must say coming to London always does cure that for the time. But as for friends--! Well, I suppose one has no right to complain when one gets to be as old as I am; but I declare I believe that those I love best would sooner be without me than with me.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean me, aunt?'' (unknown)

``No, my dear, I don't mean you. Of course my life would have been very different if you could have consented to remain with me till you were married. But I didn't mean you. I don't know that I meant any one. You shouldn't mind what an old woman like me says.'' (unknown)

``You're a little melancholy because you're going away.'' (unknown)

``No, indeed. I don't know why I stayed the last week. I did say to Lady Midlothian that I thought I should go on the 20th; and, though I know that she (Lady) knew that I really didn't go, she (Lady) has not once sent to me since. To be sure they've been out every night; but I thought she (Lady) might have asked me to come and lunch. It's so very lonely dining by myself in lodgings in London.'' (unknown)

``And yet you never will come and dine with me.'' (unknown)

``No, my dear; no. But we won't talk about that. I've just one word more to say. Let me see. I've just six minutes to stay. I've made up my mind that I'll never come up to town again,--except for one thing.'' (unknown)

``And what's that, aunt?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice, as she (Alice) asked the question, well knew what that one thing was.

``I'll come for your marriage, my dear. I do hope you will not keep me long waiting.'' (unknown)

``Ah! I can't make any promise. There's no knowing when that may be.'' (unknown)

``And why should there be no knowing? I always think that when a girl is once engaged the sooner she (girl)'s married the better. There may be reasons for delay on the gentleman's part.'' (unknown)

``There very often are, you know,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``But, Alice, you don't mean to say that Mr. Grey is putting it off?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice was silent for a moment, during which Lady Macleod's face assumed a look of almost tragic horror. Was there something wrong on Mr. Grey's side of which she (Alice) was altogether unaware? Alice, though for a second or two she (Alice) had been guilty of a slight playful deceit, was too honest to allow the impression to remain.

``No, aunt,'' (she)
she (Alice) said;
``Mr. Grey is not putting it off. It has been left to me to fix the time.'' (she)

``And why don't you fix it?'' (unknown)

``It is such a serious thing! After all it is not more than four months yet since I--I accepted him (Grey). I don't know that there has been any delay.'' (unknown)

``But you might fix the time now, if he (Grey) wishes it.'' (unknown)

``Well, perhaps I shall,--some day, aunt. I'm going to think about it, and you mustn't drive me.'' (unknown)

``But you should have some one to advise you, Alice.'' (unknown)

``Ah! that's just it. People always do seem to think it so terrible that a girl should have her (girl) own way in anything. She (girl) mustn't like any one at first; and then, when she (girl) does like some one, she (girl) must marry him (Grey) directly she (girl)'s bidden. I haven't much of my own way at present; but you see, when I'm married I shan't have it at all. You can't wonder that I shouldn't be in a hurry.'' (unknown)

``I am not advocating anything like hurry, my dear. But, goodness gracious me! I've been here twenty-eight minutes, and that horrid man will impose upon me. Good-bye; God bless you! Mind you write.'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)
And Lady Macleod hurried out of the room more intent at the present moment upon saving her (Macleod) sixpence than she (Macleod) was on any other matter whatsoever.

And then John Grey came up to town, arriving a day or two after the time that he (Grey) had fixed. It is not, perhaps, improbable that Alice had used some diplomatic skill in preventing a meeting between Lady Macleod and her (Macleod) lover. They both were very anxious to obtain the same object, and Alice was to some extent opposed to their views. Had Lady Macleod and John Grey put their forces together she (Macleod) might have found herself unable to resist their joint endeavours. She (Macleod) was resolved that she (Macleod) would not at any rate name any day for her (Macleod) marriage before her (Macleod) return from Switzerland; and she (Macleod) may therefore have thought it wise to keep Mr. Grey in the country till after Lady Macleod had gone, even though she (Macleod) thereby cut down the time of his (Grey) sojourn in London to four days. On the occasion of that visit Mr. Vavasor did a very memorable thing. He (Vavasor) dined at home with the view of welcoming his (Vavasor) future son-in-law. He (Vavasor) dined at home, and asked, or rather assented to Alice's asking, George and Kate Vavasor to join the dinner-party.

``What an auspicious omen for the future nuptials!'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, with her (Kate) little sarcastic smile.
``Uncle John dines at home, and Mr. Grey joins in the dissipation of a dinner-party. We shall all be changed soon, I suppose, and George and I will take to keeping a little cottage in the country.'' (unknown)

``Kate,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, angrily,
``I think you are about the most unjust person I ever met. I would forgive your raillery, however painful it might be, if it were only fair.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``And to whom is it unfair on the present occasion;--to your father?'' (unknown)

``It was not intended for him (father).'' (unknown)

``To yourself?'' (unknown)

``I care nothing as to myself; you know that very well.'' (unknown)

``Then it must have been unfair to Mr. Grey.'' (unknown)

``Yes; it was Mr. Grey whom you meant to attack. If I can forgive him (Grey) for not caring for society, surely you might do so.'' (unknown)

``Exactly; but that's just what you can't do, my dear. You don't forgive him (Grey). If you did you might be quite sure that I should say nothing. And if you choose to bid me hold my tongue I will say nothing. But when you tell me all your own thoughts about this thing you can hardly expect but that I should let you know mine in return. I'm not particular; and if you are ready for a little good, wholesome, useful hypocrisy, I won't balk you. I mayn't be quite so dishonest as you call me, but I'm not so wedded to truth but what I can look, and act, and speak a few falsehoods if you wish it. Only let us understand each other.'' (unknown)

``You know I wish for no falsehood, Kate.'' (unknown)

``I know it's very hard to understand what you do wish. I know that for the last year or two I have been trying to find out your wishes, and, upon my word, my success has been very indifferent. I suppose you wish to marry Mr. Grey, but I'm by no means certain. I suppose the last thing on earth you'd wish would be to marry George?'' (unknown)

``The very last. You're right there at any rate.'' (unknown)

``Alice--! sometimes you drive me too hard; you do, indeed. You make me doubt whether I hate or love you most. Knowing what my feelings are about George, I cannot understand how you can bring yourself to speak of him (George) to me with such contempt!'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Kate Vavasor, as she (Alice) spoke these words, left the room with a quick step, and hurried up to her (Alice) own chamber. There Alice found her (Alice) in tears, and was driven by her (Alice) friend's real grief into the expression of an apology, which she (Alice) knew was not properly due from her (Alice). Kate was acquainted with all the circumstances of that old affair between her (Kate) brother and Alice. She (Kate) had given in her (Kate) adhesion to the propriety of what Alice had done. She (Alice) had allowed that her (Alice) brother George's behaviour had been such as to make any engagement between them impossible. The fault, therefore, had been hers in making any reference to the question of such a marriage. Nor had it been by any means her (Alice) first fault of the same kind. Till Alice had become engaged to Mr. Grey she (Alice) had spoken of George only as her (Alice) brother, or as her (Alice) friend's cousin, but now she (Alice) was constantly making allusion to those past occurrences, which all of them should have striven to forget. Under these circumstances was not Lady Macleod right in saying that George Vavasor should not have been accepted as a companion for the Swiss tour?

-LSB-Illustration:

``Sometimes you drive me too hard.'' (unknown)
-RSB-

The little dinner-party went off very quietly; and if no other ground existed for charging Mr. Grey with London dissipation than what that afforded, he (Grey) was accused most unjustly. The two young men had never before met each other; and Vavasor had gone to his (Grey) uncle's house, prepared not only to dislike but to despise his (Grey) successor in Alice's favour. But in this he (Grey) was either disappointed or gratified, as the case may be.

``He (George) has plenty to say for himself,'' (he)
he (Grey) said to Kate on his (Grey) way home.

``Oh yes; he (George) can talk.'' (unknown)

``And he (George) doesn't talk like a prig either, which was what I expected. He (George)'s uncommonly handsome.'' (unknown)

``I thought men never saw that in each other. I never see it in any man.'' (unknown)

``I see it in every animal--in men, women, horses, dogs, and even pigs. I like to look on handsome things. I think people always do who are ugly themselves.'' (unknown)

``And so you're going into raptures in favour of John Grey.'' (unknown)

``No, I'm not. I very seldom go into raptures about anything. But he (Grey) talks in the way I like a man to talk. How he (Grey) bowled my uncle over about those actors; and yet if my uncle knows anything about anything it is about the stage twenty years ago.'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
There was nothing more said then about John Grey; but Kate understood her (Kate) brother well enough to be aware that this praise meant very little. George Vavasor spoke sometimes from his (Vavasor) heart, and did so more frequently to his (Vavasor) sister than to any one else; but his (Vavasor) words came generally from his (Vavasor) head.

On the day after the little dinner in Queen Anne Street, John Grey came to say good-bye to his (Grey) betrothed;--for his (Grey) betrothed she (Queen) certainly was, in spite of those very poor arguments which she (Queen) had used in trying to convince herself that she (Queen) was still free if she (Queen) wished to claim her (Queen) freedom. Though he (Grey) had been constantly with Alice during the last three days, he (Grey) had not hitherto said anything as to the day of their marriage. He (Grey) had been constantly with her (Alice) alone, sitting for hours in that ugly green drawing-room, but he (Grey) had never touched the subject. He (Grey) had told her (Alice) much of Switzerland, which she (Alice) had never yet seen but which he (Grey) knew well. He (Grey) had told her (Alice) much of his (Grey) garden and house, whither she (Alice) had once gone with her (Alice) father, whilst paying a visit nominally to the colleges at Cambridge. And he (Grey) had talked of various matters, matters bearing in no immediate way upon his (Grey) own or her (Alice) affairs; for Mr. Grey was a man who knew well how to make words pleasant; but previous to this last moment he (Grey) had said nothing on that subject on which he (Grey) was so intent.

``Well, Alice,'' (he)
he (Grey) said, when the last hour had come,
``and about that question of home affairs?'' (he)

``Let us finish off the foreign affairs first.'' (unknown)

``We have finished them; haven't we?'' (unknown)

``Finished them! why we haven't started yet.'' (unknown)

``No; you haven't started. But we've had the discussion. Is there any reason why you'd rather not have this thing settled.'' (unknown)

``No; no special reason.'' (unknown)

``Then why not let it be fixed? Do you fear coming to me as my wife?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``I cannot think that you repent your goodness to me.'' (unknown)

``No; I don't repent it;--what you call my goodness? I love you too entirely for that.'' (unknown)

``My darling!'' (he)
And now he (Grey) passed his (Grey) arm round her (Alice) waist as they stood near the empty fireplace.
``And if you love me--'' (unknown)

``I do love you.'' (unknown)

``Then why should you not wish to come to me?'' (unknown)

``I do wish it. I think I wish it.'' (unknown)

``But, Alice, you must have wished it altogether when you consented to be my wife.'' (unknown)

``A person may wish for a thing altogether, and yet not wish for it instantly.'' (unknown)

``Instantly! Come; I have not been hard on you. This is still June. Will you say the middle of September, and we shall still be in time for warm pleasant days among the lakes? Is that asking for too much?'' (unknown)

``It is not asking for anything.'' (unknown)

``Nay, but it is, love. Grant it, and I will swear that you have granted me everything.'' (She)

She (Alice) was silent, having things to say but not knowing in what words to put them. Now that he (Grey) was with her (Alice) she (Alice) could not say the things which she (Alice) had told herself that she (Alice) would utter to him (Grey). She (Alice) could not bring herself to hint to him (Grey) that his (Grey) views of life were so unlike her (Alice) own, that there could be no chance of happiness between them, unless each could strive to lean somewhat towards the other. No man could be more gracious in word and manner than John Grey; no man more chivalrous in his (Grey) carriage towards a woman; but he (Grey) always spoke and acted as though there could be no question that his (Grey) manner of life was to be adopted, without a word or thought of doubting, by his (Grey) wife. When two came together, why should not each yield something, and each claim something? This she (wife) had meant to say to him (Grey) on this day; but now that he (Grey) was with her (wife) she (wife) could not say it.

``John,'' (she)
she (wife) said at last,
``do not press me about this till I return.'' (she)

``But then you will say the time is short. It would be short then.'' (unknown)

``I cannot answer you now;--indeed, I cannot. That is I cannot answer in the affirmative. It is such a solemn thing.'' (unknown)

``Will it ever be less solemn, dearest?'' (unknown)

``Never, I hope never.'' (He)

He (Grey) did not press her (wife) further then, but kissed her (wife) and bade her (wife) farewell.

CHAPTER IV.

George Vavasor, the Wild Man.

It will no doubt be understood that George Vavasor did not roam about in the woods unshorn, or wear leathern trappings and sandals, like Robinson Crusoe, instead of coats and trousers. His (Robinson) wildness was of another kind. Indeed, I don't know that he (Robinson) was in truth at all wild, though Lady Macleod had called him (Robinson) so, and Alice had assented to her (Alice) use of the word.

George Vavasor had lived in London since he (Vavasor) was twenty, and now, at the time of the beginning of my story, he (Vavasor) was a year or two over thirty. He (Vavasor) was and ever had been the heir to his (Vavasor) grandfather's estate; but that estate was small, and when George first came to London his (George) father was a strong man of forty, with as much promise of life in him (George) as his (George) son had. A profession had therefore been absolutely necessary to him (George); and he (George) had, at his (George) uncle John's instance, been placed in the office of a parliamentary land agent. With this parliamentary land agent he (agent) had quarrelled to the knife, but not before he (agent) had by his (agent) talents made himself so useful that he (agent) had before him (agent) the prospects of a lucrative partnership in the business. George Vavasor had many faults, but idleness--absolute idleness--was not one of them. He (Vavasor) would occasionally postpone his (Vavasor) work to pleasure. He (Vavasor) would be at Newmarket when he (Vavasor) should have been at Whitehall. But it was not usual with him (Vavasor) to be in bed when he (Vavasor) should be at his (Vavasor) desk, and when he (Vavasor) was at his (Vavasor) desk he (Vavasor) did not whittle his (Vavasor) ruler, or pick his (Vavasor) teeth, or clip his (Vavasor) nails. Upon the whole his (Vavasor) friends were pleased with the first five years of his (Vavasor) life in London--in spite of his (Vavasor) having been found to be in debt on more than one occasion. But his (Vavasor) debts had been paid; and all was going on swimmingly, when one day he (Vavasor) knocked down the parliamentary agent with a blow between the eyes, and then there was an end of that. He (Vavasor) himself was wont to say that he (Vavasor) had known very well what he (Vavasor) was about, that it had behoved him (Vavasor) to knock down the man who was to have been his (man) partner, and that he (man) regretted nothing in the matter.
