At any rate the deed was looked upon with approving eyes by many men of good standing,--or, at any rate, sufficient standing to help George to another position; and within six weeks of the time of his (George) leaving the office at Whitehall, he (George) had become a partner in an established firm of wine merchants. A great-aunt had just then left him (George) a couple of thousand pounds, which no doubt assisted him (George) in his (George) views with the wine merchants.

In this employment he (George) remained for another period of five years, and was supposed by all his (George) friends to be doing very well. And indeed he (George) did not do badly, only that he (George) did not do well enough to satisfy himself. He (George) was ambitious of making the house to which he (George) belonged the first house in the trade in London, and scared his (George) partners by the boldness and extent of his (George) views. He (George) himself declared that if they would only have gone along with him (George) he (George) would have made them princes in the wine market. But they were men either of more prudence or of less audacity than he (George), and they declined to walk in his (George) courses. At the end of the five years Vavasor left the house, not having knocked any one down on this occasion, and taking with him (George) a very nice sum of money.

The two last of these five years had certainly been the best period of his (George) life, for he (George) had really worked very hard, like a man, giving up all pleasure that took time from him (George),--and giving up also most pleasures which were dangerous on account of their costliness. He (George) went to no races, played no billiards, and spoke of Cremorne as a childish thing, which he (George) had abandoned now that he (George) was no longer a child. It was during these two years that he (George) had had his (George) love passages with his (George) cousin; and it must be presumed that he (George) had, at any rate, intended at one time to settle himself respectably as a married man. He (man) had, however, behaved very badly to Alice, and the match had been broken off.

He (man) had also during the last two years quarrelled with his (man) grandfather. He (man) had wished to raise a sum of money on the Vavasor estate, which, as it was unentailed, he (man) could only do with his (man) grandfather's concurrence. The old gentleman would not hear of it,--would listen with no patience to the proposition. It was in vain that George attempted to make the squire understand that the wine business was going on very well, that he (George) himself owed no man anything, that everything with him (George) was flourishing;--but that his (George) trade might be extended indefinitely by the use of a few thousand pounds at moderate interest. Old Mr. Vavasor was furious. No documents and no assurances could make him (Vavasor) lay aside a belief that the wine merchants, and the business, and his (Vavasor) grandson were all ruined and ruinous together. No one but a ruined man would attempt to raise money on the family estate! So they had quarrelled, and had never spoken or seen each other since.

``He (John) shall have the estate for his (John) life,'' (the squire)
the squire said to his (squire) son John.
``I don't think I have a right to leave it away from him (John). It never has been left away from the heir. But I'll tie it up so that he (heir) shan't cut a tree on it.'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
John Vavasor perhaps thought that the old rule of primogeniture might under such circumstances have been judiciously abandoned--in this one instance, in his (Vavasor) own favour. But he (Vavasor) did not say so. Nor would he (Vavasor) have said it had there been a chance of his (Vavasor) doing so with success. He (Vavasor) was a man from whom no very noble deed could be expected; but he (Vavasor) was also one who would do no ignoble deed.

After that George Vavasor had become a stockbroker, and a stockbroker he (Vavasor) was now. In the first twelve months after his (Vavasor) leaving the wine business,--the same being the first year after his (Vavasor) breach with Alice,--he (Vavasor) had gone back greatly in the estimation of men. He (Vavasor) had lived in open defiance of decency. He (Vavasor) had spent much money and had apparently made none, and had been, as all his (Vavasor) friends declared, on the high road to ruin. Aunt Macleod had taken her (Macleod) judgement from this period of his (Vavasor) life when she (Macleod) had spoken of him (Vavasor) as a man who never did anything. But he (man) had come forth again suddenly as a working man; and now they who professed to know, declared that he (man) was by no means poor. He (man) was in the City every day; and during the last two years had earned the character of a shrewd fellow who knew what he (fellow) was about, who might not perhaps be very mealy-mouthed in affairs of business, but who was fairly and decently honourable in his (fellow) money transactions. In fact, he (fellow) stood well on ``Change.

And during these two years he (heir) had stood a contest for a seat in Parliament, having striven to represent the metropolitan borough of Chelsea, on the extremely Radical interest. It is true that he (Radical) had failed, and that he (Radical) had spent a considerable sum of money in the contest.

``Where on earth does your nephew get his (nephew) money?'' (men)
men said to John Vavasor at his (Vavasor) club.
``Upon my word I don't know,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor.
``He (nephew) doesn't get it from me, and I'm sure he (nephew) doesn't get it from my father.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
But George Vavasor, though he (Vavasor) failed at Chelsea, did not spend his (Vavasor) money altogether fruitlessly. He (Vavasor) gained reputation by the struggle, and men came to speak of him (Vavasor) as though he (Vavasor) were one who would do something. He (Vavasor) was a stockbroker, a thorough-going Radical, and yet he (Radical) was the heir to a fine estate, which had come down from father to son for four hundred years! There was something captivating about his (son) history and adventures, especially as just at the time of the election he (son) became engaged to an heiress, who died a month before the marriage should have taken place. She (heiress) died without a will, and her (heiress) money all went to some third cousins.

George Vavasor bore this last disappointment like a man, and it was at this time that he (Vavasor) again became fully reconciled to his (Vavasor) cousin. Previous to this they had met; and Alice, at her (Alice) cousin Kate's instigation, had induced her (Alice) father to meet him (father). But at first there had been no renewal of real friendship. Alice had given her (Alice) cordial assent to her (Alice) cousin's marriage with the heiress, Miss Grant, telling Kate that such an engagement was the very thing to put him (cousin) thoroughly on his (cousin) feet. And then she (Kate) had been much pleased by his (cousin) spirit at that Chelsea election.

``It was grand of him (nephew), wasn't it?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, her (Kate) eyes brimming full of tears.
``It was very spirited,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``If you knew all, you would say so. They could get no one else to stand but that Mr. Travers, and he (Travers) wouldn't come forward, unless they would guarantee all his (Travers) expenses.'' (unknown)
``I hope it didn't cost George much,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``It did, though; nearly all he (George) had got. But what matters? Money's nothing to him (George), except for its uses. My own little mite is my own now, and he (George) shall have every farthing of it for the next election, even though I should go out as a housemaid the next day.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
There must have been something great about George Vavasor, or he (Vavasor) would not have been so idolized by such a girl as his (Vavasor) sister Kate.

Early in the present spring, before the arrangements for the Swiss journey were made, George Vavasor had spoken to Alice about that intended marriage which had been broken off by the lady's death. He (Vavasor) was sitting one evening with his (Vavasor) cousin in the drawing-room in Queen Anne Street, waiting for Kate, who was to join him (Vavasor) there before going to some party. I wonder whether Kate had had a hint from her (Kate) brother to be late! At any rate, the two were together for an hour, and the talk had been all about himself. He (brother) had congratulated her (Kate) on her (Kate) engagement with Mr. Grey, which had just become known to him (Grey), and had then spoken of his (Grey) own last intended marriage.

``I grieved for her (housemaid),'' (he)
he (Grey) said,
``greatly.'' (he)

``I'm sure you did, George.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I did;--for her (housemaid), herself. Of course the world has given me credit for lamenting the loss of her (housemaid) money. But the truth is, that as regards both herself and her (housemaid) money, it is much better for me that we were never married.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean even though she (housemaid) should have lived?'' (unknown)

``Yes;--even had she (housemaid) lived.'' (unknown)

``And why so? If you liked her (housemaid), her (housemaid) money was surely no drawback.'' (unknown)

``No; not if I had liked her (housemaid).'' (unknown)

``And did you not like her (housemaid)?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``Oh, George!'' (unknown)

``I did not love her (housemaid) as a man should love his (man) wife, if you mean that. As for my liking her (wife), I did like her (wife). I liked her (wife) very much.'' (unknown)

``But you would have loved her (wife)?'' (unknown)

``I don't know. I don't find that task of loving so very easy. It might have been that I should have learned to hate her (wife).'' (unknown)

``If so, it is better for you, and better for her (wife), that she (wife) has gone.'' (unknown)

``It is better. I am sure of it. And yet I grieve for her (wife), and in thinking of her (wife) I almost feel as though I were guilty of her (wife) death.'' (unknown)

``But she (wife) never suspected that you did not love her (wife)?'' (unknown)

``Oh no. But she (wife) was not given to think much of such things. She (wife) took all that for granted. Poor girl! she (wife) is at rest now, and her (wife) money has gone, where it should go, among her (wife) own relatives.'' (unknown)

``Yes; with such feelings as yours are about her (wife), her (wife) money would have been a burden to you.'' (unknown)

``I would not have taken it. I hope, at least, that I would not have taken it. Money is a sore temptation, especially to a poor man like me. It is well for me that the trial did not come in my way.'' (unknown)

``But you are not such a very poor man now, are you, George? I thought your business was a good one.'' (unknown)

``It is, and I have no right to be a poor man. But a man will be poor who does such mad things as I do. I had three or four thousand pounds clear, and I spent every shilling of it on the Chelsea election. Goodness knows whether I shall have a shilling at all when another chance comes round; but if I have I shall certainly spend it, and if I have not, I shall go in debt wherever I can raise a hundred pounds.'' (unknown)

``I hope you will be successful at last.'' (unknown)

``I feel sure that I shall. But, in the mean time, I cannot but know that my career is perfectly reckless. No woman ought to join her (woman) lot to mine unless she (woman) has within her (woman) courage to be as reckless as I am. You know what men do when they toss up for shillings?'' (unknown)

``Yes, I suppose I do.'' (unknown)

``I am tossing up every day of my life for every shilling that I have.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean that you're--gambling?'' (unknown)

``No. I have given that up altogether. I used to gamble, but I never do that now, and never shall again. What I mean is this,--that I hold myself in readiness to risk everything at any moment, in order to gain any object that may serve my turn. I am always ready to lead a forlorn hope. That's what I mean by tossing up every day for every shilling that I have.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice did not quite understand him (Grey), and perhaps he (Grey) did not intend that she (Alice) should. Perhaps his (Grey) object was to mystify her (Alice) imagination. She (Alice) did not understand him (Grey), but I fear that she (Alice) admired the kind of courage which he (Grey) professed. And he (Grey) had not only professed it: in that matter of the past election he (Grey) had certainly practised it.

In talking of beauty to his (Grey) sister he (Grey) had spoken of himself as being ugly. He (Grey) would not generally have been called ugly by women, had not one side of his (Grey) face been dreadfully scarred by a cicatrice, which in healing, had left a dark indented line down from his (Grey) left eye to his (Grey) lower jaw. That black ravine running through his (Grey) cheek was certainly ugly. On some occasions, when he (Grey) was angry or disappointed, it was very hideous; for he (Grey) would so contort his (Grey) face that the scar would, as it were, stretch itself out, revealing all its horrors, and his (Grey) countenance would become all scar.

``He (I) looked at me like the devil himself--making the hole in his (devil) face gape at me,'' (the squire)
the old squire had said to John Vavasor in describing the interview in which the grandson had tried to bully his (grandson) grandfather into assenting to his (grandson) own views about the mortgage. But in other respects George's face was not ugly, and might have been thought handsome by many women. His (George) hair was black, and was parted in the front. His (George) forehead, though low, was broad. His (George) eyes were dark and bright, and his (George) eyebrows were very full, and perfectly black. At those periods of his (George) anger, all his (George) face which was not scar, was eye and eyebrow. He (George) wore a thick black moustache, which covered his (George) mouth, but no whiskers. People said of him (George) that he (George) was so proud of his (George) wound that he (George) would not grow a hair to cover it. The fact, however, was that no whisker could be made to come sufficiently forward to be of service, and therefore he (George) wore none.

The story of that wound should be told. When he (George) was yet hardly more than a boy, before he (George) had come up to London, he (George) was living in a house in the country which his (George) father then occupied. At the time his (George) father was absent, and he (George) and his (George) sister only were in the house with the maid-servants. His (George) sister had a few jewels in her (sister) room, and an exaggerated report of them having come to the ears of certain enterprising burglars, a little plan was arranged for obtaining them. A small boy was hidden in the house, a window was opened, and at the proper witching hour of night a stout individual crept up-stairs in his (boy) stocking-feet, and was already at Kate Vavasor's door,--when, in the dark, dressed only in his (boy) nightshirt, wholly unarmed, George Vavasor flew at the fellow's throat. Two hours elapsed before the horror-stricken women of the house could bring men to the place. George's face had then been ripped open from the eye downwards, with some chisel, or house-breaking instrument. But the man was dead. George had wrenched from him (George) his (George) own tool, and having first jabbed him (George) all over with insufficient wounds, had at last driven the steel through his (George) windpipe. The small boy escaped, carrying with him (boy) two shillings and threepence which Kate had left upon the drawing-room mantelpiece.

George Vavasor was rather low in stature, but well made, with small hands and feet, but broad in the chest and strong in the loins. He (Vavasor) was a fine horseman and a hard rider; and men who had known him (Vavasor) well said that he (Vavasor) could fence and shoot with a pistol as few men care to do in these peaceable days. Since volunteering had come up, he (Vavasor) had become a captain of Volunteers, and had won prizes with his (Vavasor) rifle at Wimbledon.

Such had been the life of George Vavasor, and such was his (Vavasor) character, and such his (Vavasor) appearance. He (Vavasor) had always lived alone in London, and did so at present; but just now his (Vavasor) sister was much with him (Vavasor), as she (sister) was staying up in town with an aunt, another Vavasor by birth, with whom the reader will, if he (reader) persevere, become acquainted in course of time. I hope he (reader) will persevere a little, for of all the Vavasors Mrs. Greenow was perhaps the best worth knowing. But Kate Vavasor's home was understood to be in her (Vavasor) grandfather's house in Westmoreland.

On the evening before they started for Switzerland, George and Kate walked from Queen Anne Street, where they had been dining with Alice, to Mrs. Greenow's house. Everything had been settled about luggage, hours of starting, and routes as regarded their few first days; and the common purse had been made over to George. That portion of Mr. Grey's letter had been read which alluded to the Paynims and the glasses of water, and everything had passed in the best of good-humour.

``I'll endeavour to get the cold water for you,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
George had said;
``but as to the breakfasts, I can only hope you won't put me to severe trials by any very early hours. When people go out for pleasure it should be pleasure.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

The brother and sister walked through two or three streets in silence, and then Kate asked a question.

``George, I wonder what your wishes really are about Alice?'' (unknown)

``That she (Alice) shouldn't want her (Alice) breakfast too early while we are away.'' (unknown)

``That means that I'm to hold my tongue, of course.'' (unknown)

``No, it doesn't.'' (unknown)

``Then it means that you intend to hold yours.'' (unknown)

``No; not that either.'' (unknown)

``Then what does it mean?'' (unknown)

``That I have no fixed wishes on the subject. Of course she (Alice)'ll marry this man John Grey, and then no one will hear another word about her (Alice).'' (unknown)

``She (Alice) will no doubt, if you don't interfere. Probably she (Alice) will whether you interfere or not. But if you wish to interfere--'' (unknown)

``She (Alice)'s got four hundred a year, and is not so good-looking as she (Alice) was.'' (unknown)

``Yes; she (Alice) has got four hundred a year, and she (Alice) is more handsome now than ever she (Alice) was. I know that you think so;--and that you love her (Alice) and love no one else--unless you have a sneaking fondness for me.'' (unknown)

``I'll leave you to judge of that last.'' (unknown)

``And as for me,--I only love two people in the world; her (Alice) and you. If ever you mean to try, you should try now.'' (unknown)

CHAPTER V.

The Balcony at Basle.

I am not going to describe the Vavasors' Swiss tour. It would not be fair on my readers.

``Six Weeks in the Bernese Oberland, by party of three,'' (I)
would have but very small chance of success in the literary world at present, and I should consider myself to be dishonest if I attempt to palm off such matter on the public in the pages of a novel. It is true that I have just returned from Switzerland, and should find such a course of writing very convenient. But I dismiss the temptation, strong as it is. _Retro age, Satanas._ No living man or woman any longer wants to be told anything of the Grimsell or of the Gemmi. Ludgate Hill is now-a-days more interesting than the Jungfrau.

The Vavasors were not very energetic on their tour. As George had said, they had gone out for pleasure and not for work. They went direct to Interlaken and then hung about between that place and Grindelwald and Lauterbrunnen, It delighted him (George) to sit still on some outer bench, looking at the mountains, with a cigar in his (George) mouth, and it seemed to delight them to be with him (George). Much that Mr. Grey prophesied had come true. The two girls were ministers to him (Grey), instead of having him (Grey) as their slave.

``What fine fellows those Alpine club men think themselves,'' (he)
he (Grey) said on one of these occasions,
``and how thoroughly they despise the sort of enjoyment I get from mountains. But they're mistaken.'' (he)

``I don't see why either need be mistaken,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``But they are mistaken,'' (he)
he (Grey) continued.
``They rob the mountains of their poetry, which is or should be their greatest charm. Mont Blanc can have no mystery for a man who has been up it half a dozen times. It's like getting behind the scenes at a ballet, or making a conjuror explain his (Blanc) tricks.'' (unknown)

``But is the exercise nothing?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

``Yes; the exercise is very fine;--but that avoids the question.'' (unknown)

``And they all botanize,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``I don't believe it. I believe that the most of them simply walk up the mountain and down again. But if they did, that avoids the question also. The poetry and mystery of the mountains are lost to those who make themselves familiar with their details, not the less because such familiarity may have useful results. In this world things are beautiful only because they are not quite seen, or not perfectly understood. Poetry is precious chiefly because it suggests more than it declares. Look in there, through that valley, where you just see the distant little peak at the end. Are you not dreaming of the unknown beautiful world that exists up there;--beautiful, as heaven is beautiful, because you know nothing of the reality? If you make your way up there and back to-morrow, and find out all about it, do you mean to say that it will be as beautiful to you when you come back?'' (unknown)

``Yes;--I think it would,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Then you've no poetry in you. Now I'm made up of poetry.'' (him)
After that they began to laugh at him (Grey) and were very happy.

I think that Mr. Grey was right in answering Alice's letter as he (Grey) did; but I think that Lady Macleod was also right in saying that Alice should not have gone to Switzerland in company with George Vavasor. A peculiar familiarity sprang up, which, had all its circumstances been known to Mr. Grey, would not have entirely satisfied him (Grey), even though no word was said which might in itself have displeased him (Grey). During the first weeks of their travelling no word was said which would have displeased him (Grey); but at last, when the time for their return was drawing nigh, when their happiness was nearly over, and that feeling of melancholy was coming on them which always pervades the last hours of any period that has been pleasant,--then words became softer than they had been, and references were made to old days,--allusions which never should have been permitted between them.

Alice had been very happy,--more happy perhaps in that she (Alice) had been a joint minister with Kate to her (Kate) cousin George's idle fantasies, than she (Kate) would have been hurrying about with him (George) as her (Kate) slave. They had tacitly agreed to spoil him (George) with comforts; and girls are always happier in spoiling some man than in being spoiled by men. And he (man) had taken it all well, doing his (man) despotism pleasantly, exacting much, but exacting nothing that was disagreeable. And he (man) had been amusing always, as Alice thought without any effort. But men and women, when they show themselves at their best, seldom do so without an effort. If the object be near the heart the effort will be pleasant to him (man) who makes it, and if it be made well, it will be hidden; but, not the less, will the effort be there. George Vavasor had on the present occasion done his (Vavasor) very best to please his (Vavasor) cousin.

They were sitting at Basle one evening in the balcony of the big hotel which overlooks the Rhine. The balcony runs the length of the house, and is open to all the company; but it is spacious, and little parties can be formed there with perfect privacy. The swift broad Rhine runs underneath, rushing through from the bridge which here spans the river; and every now and then on summer evenings loud shouts come up from strong swimmers in the water, who are glorying in the swiftness of the current. The three were sitting there, by themselves, at the end of the balcony. Coffee was before them on a little table, and George's cigar, as usual, was in his (George) mouth.

``It's nearly all over,'' (he)
said he (George), after they had remained silent for some minutes.

``And I do think it has been a success,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``Always excepting about the money. I'm ruined for ever.'' (unknown)

``I'll make your money all straight,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``Indeed you'll do nothing of the kind,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``I'm ruined, but you are ruineder. But what signifies? It is such a great thing ever to have had six weeks' happiness, that the ruin is, in point of fact, a good speculation. What do you say, Alice? Won't you vote, too, that we've done it well?'' (unknown)

``I think we've done it very well. I have enjoyed myself thoroughly.'' (unknown)

``And now you've got to go home to John Grey and Cambridgeshire! It's no wonder you should be melancholy.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
That was the thought in Kate's mind, but she (Kate) did not speak it out on this occasion.

``That's good of you, Alice,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``Is it not, George? I like a person who will give a hearty meed of approbation.'' (unknown)

``But I am giving the meed of approbation to myself.'' (unknown)

``I like a person even to do that heartily,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``Not that George and I are thankful for the compliment. We are prepared to admit that we owe almost everything to you,--are we not, George?'' (unknown)

``I'm not; by any means,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``Well, I am, and I expect to have something pretty said to me in return. Have I been cross once, Alice?'' (unknown)

``No; I don't think you have. You are never cross, though you are often ferocious.'' (unknown)

``But I haven't been once ferocious,--nor has George.'' (unknown)

``He (George) would have been the most ungrateful man alive if he (George) had,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice. ``We've done nothing since we've started but realize from him (George) that picture in
``Punch' of the young gentleman at Jeddo who had a dozen ladies to wait upon him (gentleman).'' (unknown)

``And now he (gentleman) has got to go home to his (gentleman) lodgings, and wait upon himself again. Poor fellow! I do pity you, George.'' (unknown)

``No, you don't;--nor does Alice. I believe girls always think that a bachelor in London has the happiest of all lives. It's because they think so that they generally want to put an end to the man's condition.'' (unknown)

``It's envy that makes us want to get married,--not love,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

``It's the devil in some shape, as often as not,'' (he)
said he (George).
``With a man, marriage always seems to him (man) to be an evil at the instant.'' (unknown)

``Not always,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Almost always;--but he (man) does it, as he (man) takes physic, because something worse will come if he (man) don't. A man never likes having his (man) tooth pulled out, but all men do have their teeth pulled out,--and they who delay it too long suffer the very mischief.'' (unknown)

``I do like George's philosophy,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, getting up from her (Kate) chair as she (Kate) spoke;
``it is so sharp, and has such a pleasant acid taste about it; and then we all know that it means nothing. Alice, I'm going up-stairs to begin the final packing.'' (she)

``I'll come with you, dear.'' (unknown)

``No, don't. To tell the truth I'm only going into that man's room because he (man) won't put up a single thing of his (man) own decently. We'll do ours, of course, when we go up to bed. Whatever you disarrange to-night, Master George, you must rearrange for yourself to-morrow morning, for I promise I won't go into your room at five o'clock.'' (unknown)

``How I do hate that early work,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``I'll be down again very soon,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``Then we'll take one turn on the bridge and go to bed.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice and George were left together sitting in the balcony. They had been alone together before many times since their travels had commenced; but they both of them felt that there was something to them in the present moment different from any other period of their journey. There was something that each felt to be sweet, undefinable, and dangerous. Alice had known that it would be better for her (Alice) to go up-stairs with Kate; but Kate's answer had been of such a nature that had she (Kate) gone she (Kate) would have shown that she (Kate) had some special reason for going. Why should she (Kate) show such a need? Or why, indeed, should she (Kate) entertain it?

Alice was seated quite at the end of the gallery, and Kate's chair was at her (Kate) feet in the corner. When Alice and Kate had seated themselves, the waiter had brought a small table for the coffee-cups, and George had placed his (George) chair on the other side of that. So that Alice was, as it were, a prisoner. She (Alice) could not slip away without some special preparation for going, and Kate had so placed her (Kate) chair in leaving, that she (Kate) must actually have asked George to move it before she (Kate) could escape. But why should she (Kate) wish to escape? Nothing could be more lovely and enticing than the scene before her (Kate). The night had come on, with quick but still unperceived approach, as it does in those parts; for the twilight there is not prolonged as it is with us more northern folk. The night had come on, but there was a rising moon, which just sufficed to give a sheen to the water beneath her (Kate). The air was deliciously soft;--of that softness which produces no sensation either of warmth or cold, but which just seems to touch one with loving tenderness, as though the unseen spirits of the air kissed one's forehead as they passed on their wings. The Rhine was running at her (Kate) feet, so near, that in the soft half light it seemed as though she (Kate) might step into its ripple. The Rhine was running by with that delicious sound of rapidly moving waters, that fresh refreshing gurgle of the river, which is so delicious to the ear at all times. If you be talking, it wraps up your speech, keeping it for yourselves, making it difficult neither to her (Kate) who listens nor to him (Kate) who speaks. If you would sleep, it is of all lullabies the sweetest. If you are alone and would think, it aids all your thoughts. If you are alone, and, alas! would not think,--if thinking be too painful,--it will dispel your sorrow, and give the comfort which music alone can give. Alice felt that the air kissed her (Alice), that the river sang for her (Alice) its sweetest song, that the moon shone for her (Alice) with its softest light,--that light which lends the poetry of half-developed beauty to everything that it touches. Why should she (Alice) leave it?

Nothing was said for some minutes after Kate's departure, and Alice was beginning to shake from her (Alice) that half feeling of danger which had come over her (Alice). Vavasor had sat back in his (your) chair, leaning against the house, with his (your) feet raised upon a stool; his (your) arms were folded across his (your) breast, and he (your) seemed to have divided himself between his (your) thoughts and his (your) cigar. Alice was looking full upon the river, and her (Alice) thoughts had strayed away to her (Alice) future home among John Grey's flower-beds and shrubs; but the river, though it sang to her (Alice) pleasantly, seemed to sing a song of other things than such a home as that,--a song full of mystery, as are all river songs when one tries to understand their words.

``When are you to be married, Alice?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George at last.

``Oh, George!'' (she)
said she (Alice).
``You ask me a question as though you were putting a pistol to my ear.'' (unknown)

``I'm sorry the question was so unpleasant.'' (unknown)

``I didn't say that it was unpleasant; but you asked it so suddenly! The truth is, I didn't expect you to speak at all just then. I suppose I was thinking of something.'' (unknown)

``But if it be not unpleasant,--when are you to be married?'' (unknown)

``I do not know. It is not fixed.'' (unknown)

``But about when, I mean? This summer?'' (unknown)

``Certainly not this summer, for the summer will be over when we reach home.'' (unknown)

``This winter? Next spring? Next year?--or in ten years' time?'' (unknown)

``Before the expiration of the ten years, I suppose. Anything more exact than that I can't say.'' (unknown)

``I suppose you like it?'' (he)
he (George) then said.

``What, being married? You see I've never tried yet.'' (unknown)

``The idea of it,--the anticipation, You look forward with satisfaction to the kind of life you will lead at Nethercoats? Don't suppose I am saying anything against it, for I have no conception what sort of a place Nethercoats is. On the whole I don't know that there is any kind of life better than that of an English country gentleman in his (gentleman) own place;--that is, if he (gentleman) can keep it up, and not live as the old squire does, in a state of chronic poverty.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Grey's place doesn't entitle him (Grey) to be called a country gentleman.'' (unknown)

``But you like the prospect of it?'' (unknown)

``Oh, George, how you do cross-question one! Of course I like it, or I shouldn't have accepted it.'' (unknown)

``That does not follow. But I quite acknowledge that I have no right to cross-question you. If I ever had such right on the score of cousinship, I have lost it on the score of--; but we won't mind that, will we, Alice?'' (she)
To this she (Alice) at first made no answer, but he (George) repeated the question.
``Will we, Alice?'' (unknown)

``Will we what?'' (unknown)

``Recur to the old days.'' (unknown)

``Why should we recur to them? They are passed, and as we are again friends and dear cousins the sting of them is gone.'' (unknown)

``Ah, yes! The sting of them is gone. It is for that reason, because it is so, that we may at last recur to them without danger. If we regret nothing,--if neither of us has anything to regret, why not recur to them, and talk of them freely?'' (unknown)

``No, George; that would not do.'' (unknown)

``By heavens, no! It would drive me mad; and if I know aught of you, it would hardly leave you as calm as you are at present.'' (unknown)

``As I would wish to be left calm--'' (unknown)

``Would you? Then I suppose I ought to hold my tongue. But, Alice, I shall never have the power of speaking to you again as I speak now. Since we have been out together, we have been dear friends; is it not so?'' (unknown)

``And shall we not always be dear friends?'' (unknown)

``No, certainly not. How will it be possible? Think of it. How can I really be your friend when you are the mistress of that man's house in Cambridgeshire?'' (unknown)

``George!'' (unknown)

``I mean nothing disrespectful. I truly beg your pardon if it has seemed so. Let me say that gentleman's house;--for he (gentleman) is a gentleman.'' (unknown)

``That he (gentleman) certainly is.'' (unknown)

``You could not have accepted him (gentleman) were he (gentleman) not so. But how can I be your friend when you are his (friend) wife? I may still call you cousin Alice, and pat your children on the head if I chance to see them; and shall stop in the streets and shake hands with him (friend) if I meet him (friend);--that is if my untoward fate does not induce him (friend) to cut my acquaintance;--but as for friendship, that will be over when you and I shall have parted next Thursday evening at London Bridge.'' (unknown)

``Oh, George, don't say so!'' (unknown)

``But I do.'' (unknown)

``And why on Thursday? Do you mean that you won't come to Queen Anne Street any more?'' (unknown)

``Yes, that is what I do mean. This trip of ours has been very successful, Kate says. Perhaps Kate knows nothing about it.'' (unknown)

``It has been very pleasant,--at least to me.'' (unknown)

``And the pleasure has had no drawback?'' (unknown)

``None to me.'' (unknown)

``It has been very pleasant to me, also;--but the pleasure has had its alloy. Alice, I have nothing to ask from you,--nothing.'' (unknown)

``Anything that you should ask, I would do for you.'' (unknown)

``I have nothing to ask;--nothing. But I have one word to say.'' (unknown)

``George, do not say it. Let me go up-stairs. Let me go to Kate.'' (unknown)

``Certainly; if you wish it you shall go.'' (He)
He (George) still held his (George) foot against the chair which barred her (Alice) passage, and did not attempt to rise as he (George) must have done to make way for her (Alice) passage out.
``Certainly you shall go to Kate, if you refuse to hear me. But after all that has passed between us, after these six weeks of intimate companionship, I think you ought to listen to me. I tell you that I have nothing to ask. I am not going to make love to you.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice had commenced some attempt to rise, but she (Alice) had again settled herself in her (Alice) chair. And now, when he (George) paused for a moment, she (Alice) made no further sign that she (Alice) wished to escape, nor did she (Alice) say a word to intimate her (Alice) further wish that he (George) should be silent.

``I am not going to make love to you,'' (he)
he (George) said again.
``As for making love, as the word goes, that must be over between you and me. It has been made and marred, and cannot be remade. It may exist, or it may have been expelled; but where it does not exist, it will never be brought back again.'' (unknown)

``It should not be spoken of between you and me.'' (unknown)

``So, no doubt, any proper-going duenna would say, and so, too, little children should be told; but between you and me there can be no necessity for falsehood. We have grown beyond our sugar-toothed ages, and are now men and women. I perfectly understood your breaking away from me. I understood you, and in spite of my sorrow knew that you were right. I am not going to accuse or to defend myself; but I knew that you were right.'' (unknown)

``Then let there be no more about it.'' (unknown)

``Yes; there must be more about it. I did not understand you when you accepted Mr. Grey. Against him (Grey) I have not a whisper to make. He (Grey) may be perfect for aught I know. But, knowing you as I thought I did, I could not understand your loving such a man as him (man). It was as though one who had lived on brandy should take himself suddenly to a milk diet,--and enjoy the change! A milk diet is no doubt the best. But men who have lived on brandy can't make those changes very suddenly. They perish in the attempt.'' (unknown)

``Not always, George.'' (unknown)

``It may be done with months of agony;--but there was no such agony with you.'' (unknown)

``Who can tell?'' (unknown)

``But you will tell me the cure was made. I thought so, and therefore thought that I should find you changed. I thought that you, who had been all fire, would now have turned yourself into soft-flowing milk and honey, and have become fit for the life in store for you. With such a one I might have travelled from Moscow to Malta without danger. The woman fit to be John Grey's wife would certainly do me no harm,--could not touch my happiness. I might have loved her (wife) once,--might still love the memory of what she (wife) had been; but her (wife), in her (wife) new form, after her (wife) new birth,--such a one as that, Alice, could be nothing to me. Don't mistake me. I have enough of wisdom in me to know how much better, ay, and happier a woman she (woman) might be. It was not that I thought you had descended in the scale; but I gave you credit for virtues which you have not acquired. Alice, that wholesome diet of which I spoke is not your diet. You would starve on it, and perish.'' (He)

He (George) had spoken with great energy, but still in a low voice, having turned full round upon the table, with both his (George) arms upon it, and his (George) face stretched out far over towards her (Alice). She (Alice) was looking full at him (George); and, as I have said before, that scar and his (George) gloomy eyes and thick eyebrows seemed to make up the whole of his (George) face. But the scar had never been ugly to her (Alice). She (Alice) knew the story, and when he (George) was her (Alice) lover she (Alice) had taken pride in the mark of the wound. She (Alice) looked at him (George), but though he (George) paused she (Alice) did not speak. The music of the river was still in her (Alice) ears, and there came upon her (Alice) a struggle as though she (Alice) were striving to understand its song. Were the waters also telling her (Alice) of the mistake she (Alice) had made in accepting Mr. Grey as her (Alice) husband? What her (Alice) cousin was now telling her (Alice),--was it not a repetition of words which she (Alice) had spoken to herself hundreds of times during the last two months? Was she (Alice) not telling herself daily,--hourly,--always,--in every thought of her (Alice) life, that in accepting Mr. Grey she (Alice) had assumed herself to be mistress of virtues which she (Alice) did not possess? Had she (Alice) not, in truth, rioted upon brandy, till the innocence of milk was unfitted for her (Alice)? This man now came and rudely told her (Alice) all this,--but did he (man) not tell her (Alice) the truth? She (Alice) sat silent and convicted; only gazing into his (man) face when his (man) speech was done.

``I have learned this since we have been again together, Alice; and finding you, not the angel I had supposed, finding you to be the same woman I had once loved,--the safety that I anticipated has not fallen to my lot. That's all. Here's Kate, and now we'll go for our walk.'' (unknown)

CHAPTER VI.

The Bridge over the Rhine.

``George,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, speaking before she (Kate) quite got up to them,
``will you tell me whether you have been preparing all your things for an open sale by auction?'' (she)
Then she (Kate) stole a look at Alice, and having learned from that glance that something had occurred which prevented Alice from joining her (Alice) in her (Alice) raillery, she (Alice) went on with it herself rapidly, as though to cover Alice's confusion, and give her (Alice) time to rally before they should all move.
``Would you believe it? he (George) had three razors laid out on his (George) table--'' (unknown)

``A man must shave,--even at Basle.'' (unknown)

``But not with three razors at once; and three hair-brushes, and half a dozen toothbrushes, and a small collection of combs, and four or five little glass bottles, looking as though they contained poison,--all with silver tops. I can only suppose you desired to startle the weak mind of the chambermaid. I have put them all up; but remember this, if they are taken out again you are responsible. And I will not put up your boots, George. What can you have wanted with three pairs of boots at Basle?'' (unknown)

``When you have completed the list of my wardrobe we'll go out upon the bridge. That is, if Alice likes it.'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes; I shall like it.'' (unknown)

``Come along then,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate. And so they moved away. When they got upon the bridge Alice and Kate were together, while George strolled behind them, close to them, but not taking any part in their conversation,--as though he (George) had merely gone with them as an escort. Kate seemed to be perfectly content with this arrangement, chattering to Alice, so that she (Alice) might show that there was nothing serious on the minds of any of them. It need hardly be said that Alice at this time made no appeal to George to join them. He (George) followed them at their heels, with his (George) hands behind his (George) back, looking down upon the pavement and simply waiting upon their pleasure.

``Do you know,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate,
``I have a very great mind to run away.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

``Where do you want to run to?'' (unknown)

``Well;--that wouldn't much signify. Perhaps I'd go to the little inn at Handek. It's a lonely place, where nobody would hear of me,--and I should have the waterfall. I'm afraid they'd want to have their bill paid. That would be the worst of it.'' (unknown)

``But why run away just now?'' (unknown)

``I won't, because you wouldn't like going home with George alone,--and I suppose he (George)'d be bound to look after me, as he (George)'s doing now. I wonder what he (George) thinks of having to walk over the bridge after us girls. I suppose he (George)'d be in that place down there drinking beer, if we weren't here.'' (unknown)

``If he (George) wanted to go, I dare say he (George) would, in spite of us.'' (unknown)

``That's ungrateful of you, for I'm sure we've never been kept in a moment by his (George) failing us. But as I was saying, I do dread going home. You are going to John Grey, which may be pleasant enough; but I'm going--to Aunt Greenow.'' (unknown)

``It's your own choice.'' (unknown)

``No, it's not. I haven't any choice in the matter. Of course I might refuse to speak to Aunt Greenow, and nobody could make me;--but practically I haven't any choice in the matter. Fancy a month at Yarmouth with no companion but such a woman as that!'' (unknown)

``I shouldn't mind it. Aunt Greenow always seems to me to be a very good sort of woman.'' (unknown)

``She (woman) may be a good woman, but I must say I think she (woman)'s of a bad sort. You've never heard her (woman) talk about her (woman) husband?'' (unknown)

``No, never; I think she (woman) did cry a little the first day she (woman) came to Queen Anne Street, but that wasn't unnatural.'' (unknown)

``He (husband) was thirty years older than herself.'' (unknown)

``But still he (husband) was her (woman) husband. And even if her (woman) tears are assumed, what of that? What's a woman to do? Of course she (woman) was wrong to marry him (husband). She (woman) was thirty-five, and had nothing, while he (husband) was sixty-five, and was very rich. According to all accounts she (woman) made him (husband) a very good wife, and now that she (woman)'s got all his (husband) money, you wouldn't have her (woman) go about laughing within three months of his (husband) death.'' (unknown)

``No; I wouldn't have her (woman) laugh; but neither would I have her (woman) cry. And she (woman)'s quite right to wear weeds; but she (woman) needn't be so very outrageous in the depth of her (woman) hems, or so very careful that her (woman) caps are becoming. Her (woman) eyes will be worn out by their double service. They are always red with weeping, and yet she (woman) is ready every minute with a full battery of execution for any man that she (woman) sees.'' (unknown)

``Then why have you consented to go to Yarmouth with her (woman)?'' (unknown)

``Just because she (woman)'s got forty thousand pounds. If Mr. Greenow had left her (woman) with a bare maintenance I don't suppose I should ever have held out my hand to her (woman).'' (unknown)

``Then you're as bad as she (woman) is.'' (unknown)

``Quite as bad;--and that's what makes me want to run away. But it isn't my own fault altogether. It's the fault of the world at large. Does anybody ever drop their rich relatives? When she (woman) proposed to take me to Yarmouth, wasn't it natural that the squire should ask me to go? When I told George, wasn't it natural that he (George) should say, ``Oh, go by all means. She (woman)'s got forty thousand pounds!

'' One can't pretend to be wiser or better than one's relatives. And after all what can I expect from her (Kate) money?'' (She)

``Nothing, I should say.'' (unknown)

``Not a halfpenny. I'm nearly thirty and she (woman)'s only forty, and of course she (woman)'ll marry again. I will say of myself, too, that no person living cares less for money.'' (unknown)

``I should think no one.'' (unknown)

``Yet one sticks to one's rich relatives. It's the way of the world.'' (she)
Then she (Kate) paused a moment.
``But shall I tell you, Alice, why I do stick to her (Alice)? Perhaps you'll think the object as mean as though I wanted her (Alice) money myself.'' (unknown)

``Why is it?'' (unknown)

``Because it is on the cards that she (Alice) may help George in his (George) career. I do not want money, but he (George) may. And for such purposes as his (George), I think it fair that all the family should contribute. I feel sure that he (George) would make a name for himself in Parliament; and if I had my way I would spend every shilling of Vavasor money in putting him (George) there. When I told the squire so I thought he (squire) would have eaten me. I really did think he (squire) would have turned me out of the house.'' (unknown)

``And serve you right too after what had happened.'' (unknown)

``I didn't care. Let him (squire) turn me out. I was determined he (squire) should know what I thought. He (squire) swore at me; and then he (squire) was so unhappy at what he (squire) had done that he (squire) came and kissed me that night in my bedroom, and gave me a ten-pound note. What do you think I did with it? I sent it as a contribution to the next election and George has it now locked up in a box. Don't you tell him (George) that I told you.'' (unknown)

Then they stopped and leaned for a while over the parapet of the bridge.

``Come here, George,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate; and she (Kate) made room for him (George) between herself and Alice.
``Wouldn't you like to be swimming down there as those boys were doing when we went out into the balcony? The water looks so enticing.'' (unknown)

``I can't say I should;--unless it might be a pleasant way of swimming into the next world.'' (unknown)

``I should so like to feel myself going with the stream,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate;
``particularly by this light. I can't fancy in the least that I should be drowned.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

``I can't fancy anything else,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``It would be so pleasant to feel the water gliding along one's limbs, and to be carried away headlong,--knowing that you were on the direct road to Rotterdam.'' (unknown)

``And so arrive there without your clothes,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``They would be brought after in a boat. Didn't you see that those boys had a boat with them? But if I lived here, I'd never do it except by moonlight. The water looks so clear and bright now, and the rushing sound of it is so soft! The sea at Yarmouth won't be anything like that I suppose.'' (her)

Neither of them any longer answered her (Alice), and yet she (Alice) went on talking about the river, and their aunt, and her (Alice) prospects at Yarmouth. Neither of them answered her (Alice), and yet it seemed that they had not a word to say to each other. But still they stood there looking down upon the river, and every now and then Kate's voice was to be heard, preventing the feeling which might otherwise have arisen that their hearts were too full for speech.

At last Alice seemed to shiver. There was a slight trembling in her (Alice) arms, which George felt rather than saw.

``You are cold,'' (he)
he (George) said.

``No indeed.'' (unknown)

``If you are let us go in. I thought you shivered with the night air.'' (unknown)

``It wasn't that. I was thinking of something. Don't you ever think of things that make you shiver?'' (unknown)

``Indeed I do, very often;--so often that I have to do my shiverings inwardly. Otherwise people would think I had the palsy.'' (unknown)

``I don't mean things of moment,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``Little bits of things make me do it;--perhaps a word that I said and ought not to have said ten years ago;--the most ordinary little mistakes, even my own past thoughts to myself about the merest trifles. They are always making me shiver.'' (unknown)

``It's not because you have committed any murder then.'' (unknown)

``No; but it's my conscience all the same, I suppose.'' (unknown)

``Ah! I'm not so good as you. I doubt it's not my conscience at all. When I think of a chance I've let go by, as I have thousands, then it is that I shiver. But, as I tell you, I shiver inwardly. I've been in one long shiver ever since we came out because of one chance that I let go by. Come, we'll go in. We've to be up at five o'clock, and now it's eleven. I'll do the rest of my shivering in bed.'' (unknown)

``Are you tired of being out?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, when the other two began to move.

``Not tired of being out, but George reminds me that we have to be up at five.'' (unknown)

``I wish George would hold his (George) tongue. We can't come to the bridge at Basle every night in our lives. If one found oneself at the top of Sinai I'm afraid the first feeling would be one of fear lest one wouldn't be down in time to dress for dinner. Are you aware, George, that the king of rivers is running beneath your feet, and that the moon is shining with a brilliance you never see at home?'' (unknown)

``I'll stay here all night if you'll put off going to-morrow,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``Our money wouldn't hold out,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

``Don't talk about Sinai any more after that,'' (he)
said he (George),
``but let's go in to bed.'' (he)

They walked across the bridge back to the hotel in the same manner as before, the two girls going together with the young man after them, and so they went up the front steps of the hotel, through the hall, and on to the stairs. Here George handed Alice her (Alice) candle, and as he (George) did so he (George) whispered a few words to her (Alice).

``My shivering fit has to come yet,'' (he)
said he (George),
``and will last me the whole night.'' (he)
She (Alice) would have given much to be able to answer him (George) lightly, as though what he (George) had said had meant nothing;--but she (Alice) couldn't do it; the light speech would not come to her (Alice). She (Alice) was conscious of all this, and went away to her (Alice) own room without answering him (George) at all. Here she (Alice) sat down at the window looking out upon the river till Kate should join her (Kate). Their rooms opened through from one to the other, and she (Kate) would not begin her (Kate) packing till her (Kate) cousin should come.

But Kate had gone with her (Kate) brother, promising, as she (Kate) did so, that she (Kate) would be back in half a minute. That half minute was protracted beyond half an hour.

``If you'll take my advice,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, at last, standing up with her (Kate) candle in her (Kate) hand,
``you'll ask her (I) in plain words to give you another chance. Do it to-morrow at Strasbourg; you'll never have a better opportunity.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

``And bid her (I) throw John Grey over!'' (unknown)

``Don't say anything about John Grey; leave her (I) to settle that matter with herself. Believe me that she (I) has quite courage enough to dispose of John Grey, if she (I) has courage enough to accept your offer.'' (unknown)

``Kate, you women never understand each other. If I were to do that, all her (Kate) most powerful feelings would be arrayed in arms against me. I must leave her (Kate) to find out first that she (Kate) wishes to be rid of her (Kate) engagement.'' (unknown)

``She (Kate) has found that out long ago. Do you think I don't know what she (Kate) wishes? But if you can't bring yourself to speak to her (Kate), she (Kate)'ll marry him (Grey) in spite of her (Kate) wishes.'' (unknown)

``Bring myself! I've never been very slow in bringing myself to speak to any one when there was need. It isn't very pleasant sometimes, but I do it, if I find occasion.'' (unknown)

``But surely it must be pleasant with her (Kate). You must be glad to find that she (Kate) still loves you. You still love her (Kate), I suppose?'' (unknown)

``Upon my word I don't know.'' (unknown)

``Don't provoke me, George. I'm moving heaven and earth to bring you two together; but if I didn't think you loved her (Kate), I'd go to her (Kate) at once and bid her (Kate) never see you again.'' (unknown)

``Upon my word, Kate, I sometimes think it would be better if you'd leave heaven and earth alone.'' (unknown)

``Then I will. But of all human beings, surely you're the most ungrateful.'' (unknown)

``Why shouldn't she (Kate) marry John Grey if she (Kate) likes him (Grey)?'' (unknown)

``But she (Kate) doesn't like him (Grey). And I hate him (Grey). I hate the sound of his (Grey) voice, and the turn of his (Grey) eye, and that slow, steady movement of his (Grey),--as though he (Grey) was always bethinking himself that he (Grey) wouldn't wear out his (Grey) clothes.'' (unknown)

``I don't see that your hating him (Grey) ought to have anything to do with it.'' (unknown)

``If you're going to preach morals, I'll leave you. It's the darling wish of my heart that she (Kate) should be your wife. If you ever loved anybody,--and I sometimes doubt whether you ever did,--but if you did, you loved her (Kate).'' (unknown)

``Did and do are different things.'' (unknown)

``Very well, George; then I have done. It has been the same in every twist and turn of my life. In everything that I have striven to do for you, you have thrown yourself over, in order that I might be thrown over too. But I believe you say this merely to vex me.'' (unknown)

``Upon my word, Kate, I think you'd better go to bed.'' (unknown)

``But not till I've told her (Kate) everything. I won't leave her (Kate) to be deceived and ill-used again.'' (unknown)

``Who is ill-using her (Kate) now? Is it not the worst of ill-usage, trying to separate her (Kate) from that man?'' (unknown)

``No;--if I thought so, I would have no hand in doing it. She (Kate) would be miserable with him (man), and make him (man) miserable as well. She (Kate) does not really love him (man). He (man) loves her (Kate), but I've nothing to do with that. It's nothing to me if he (man) breaks his (man) heart.'' (unknown)

``I shall break mine if you don't let me go to bed.'' (she)

With that she (Kate) went away and hurried along the corridor, till she (Kate) came to her (Kate) cousin's room. She (Kate) found Alice still seated at the window, or rather kneeling on the chair, with her (Alice) head out through the lattice.

``Why, you lazy creature,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate;
``I declare you haven't touched a thing.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

``You said we'd do it together.'' (unknown)

``But he (man) has kept me. Oh, what a man he (man) is! If he (man) ever does get married, what will his (man) wife do with him (man)?'' (unknown)

``I don't think he (man) ever will,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Don't you? I dare say you understand him (man) better than I do. Sometimes I think that the only thing wanting to make him (man) thoroughly good, is a wife. But it isn't every woman that would do for him (man). And the woman who marries him (man) should have high courage. There are moments with him (man) when he (man) is very wild; but he (man) never is cruel and never hard. Is Mr. Grey ever hard?'' (unknown)

``Never; nor yet wild.'' (unknown)

``Oh, certainly not that. I'm quite sure he (Grey)'s never wild.'' (unknown)

``When you say that, Kate, I know that you mean to abuse him (Grey).'' (unknown)

``No; upon my word. What's the good of abusing him (Grey) to you? I like a man to be wild,--wild in my sense. You knew that before.'' (unknown)

``I wonder whether you'd like a wild man for yourself?'' (unknown)

``Ah! that's a question I've never asked myself. I've been often curious to consider what sort of husband would suit you, but I've had very few thoughts about a husband for myself. The truth is, I'm married to George. Ever since--'' (unknown)

``Ever since what?'' (unknown)

``Since you and he (George) were parted, I've had nothing to do in life but to stick to him (George). And I shall do so to the end,--unless one thing should happen.'' (unknown)

``And what's that?'' (unknown)

``Unless you should become his (George) wife after all. He (George) will never marry anybody else.'' (unknown)

``Kate, you shouldn't allude to such a thing now. You know that it's impossible.'' (unknown)

``Well, perhaps so. As far as I'm concerned, it is all the better for me. If George ever married, I should have nothing to do in the world;--literally nothing--nothing--nothing--nothing!'' (unknown)

``Kate, don't talk in that way,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
and Alice came up to her (Alice) and embraced her (Alice).

``Go away,'' (she)
said she (Alice).
``Go, Alice; you and I must part. I cannot bear it any longer. You must know it all. When you are married to John Grey, our friendship must be over. If you became George's wife I should become nobody. I've nothing else in the world. You and he (George) would be so all-sufficient for each other, that I should drop away from you like an old garment. But I'd give up all, everything, every hope I have, to see you become George's wife. I know myself not to be good. I know myself to be very bad, and yet I care nothing for myself. Don't Alice, don't; I don't want your caresses. Caress him (George), and I'll kneel at your feet and cover them with kisses.'' (She)
She (Alice) had now thrown herself upon a sofa, and had turned her (Alice) face away to the wall.

``Kate, you shouldn't speak in that way.'' (unknown)

``Of course I shouldn't,--but I do.'' (unknown)

``You, who know everything, must know that I cannot marry your brother,--even if he (brother) wished it.'' (unknown)

``He (brother) does wish it.'' (unknown)

``Not though I were under no other engagement.'' (unknown)

``And why not?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, again starting up.
``What is there to separate you from George now, but that unfortunate affair, that will end in the misery of you all. Do you think I can't see? Don't I know which of the two men you like best?'' (unknown)

``You are making me sorry, Kate, that I have ventured to come here in your brother's company. It is not only unkind of you to talk to me in this way, but worse than that--it is indelicate.'' (unknown)

``Oh, indelicate! How I do hate that word. If any word in the language reminds me of a whited sepulchre it is that;--all clean and polished outside with filth and rottenness within. Are your thoughts delicate? that's the thing. You are engaged to marry John Grey. That may be delicate enough if you love him (Grey) truly, and feel yourself fitted to be his (Grey) wife; but it's about the most indelicate thing you can do, if you love any one better than him (Grey). Delicacy with many women is like their cleanliness. Nothing can be nicer than the whole outside get-up, but you wouldn't wish to answer for anything beneath.'' (unknown)

``If you think ill of me like that--'' (unknown)

``No; I don't think ill of you. How can I think ill of you when I know that all your difficulties have come from him (Grey)? It hasn't been your fault; it has been his (Grey) throughout. It is he (Grey) who has driven you to sacrifice yourself on this altar. If we can, both of us, manage to lay aside all delicacy and pretence, and dare to speak the truth, we shall acknowledge that it is so. Had Mr. Grey come to you while things were smooth between you and George, would you have thought it possible that he (George) could be George's rival in your estimation? It is Hyperion to Satyr.'' (unknown)

``And which is the Satyr?'' (unknown)

``I'll leave your heart to tell you. You know what is the darling wish of my heart. But, Alice, if I thought that Mr. Grey was to you Hyperion,--if I thought that you could marry him (Grey) with that sort of worshipping, idolatrous love which makes a girl proud as well as happy in her (girl) marriage, I wouldn't raise a little finger to prevent it.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

To this Alice made no answer, and then Kate allowed the matter to drop. Alice made no answer, though she (Alice) felt that she (Alice) was allowing judgement to go against her (Alice) by default in not doing so. She (Alice) had intended to fight bravely, and to have maintained the excellence of her (Alice) present position as the affianced bride of Mr. Grey, but she (Alice) felt that she (Alice) had failed. She (Alice) felt that she (Alice) had, in some sort, acknowledged that the match was one to be deplored;--that her (Alice) words in her (Alice) own defence would by no means have satisfied Mr. Grey, if Mr. Grey could have heard them;--that they would have induced him (Grey) to offer her (Alice) back her (Alice) troth rather than have made him (Grey) happy as a lover. But she (Alice) had nothing further to say. She (Alice) could do something. She (Alice) would hurry home and bid him (Grey) name the earliest day he (Grey) pleased. After that her (Alice) cousin would cease to disturb her (Alice) in her (Alice) career.

It was nearly one o'clock before the two girls began to prepare for their morning start, and Alice, when they had finished their packing, seemed to be worn out with fatigue.

``If you are tired, dear, we'll put it off,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``Not for worlds,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``For half a word we'll do it,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
continued Kate.
``I'll slip out to George and tell him (George), and there's nothing he (George)'d like so much.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
But Alice would not consent.

About two they got into bed, and punctually at six they were at the railway station.

``Don't speak to me,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George, when he (George) met them at their door in the passage.
``I shall only yawn in your face.'' (unknown)
However, they were in time,--which means abroad that they were at the station half an hour before their train started,--and they went on upon their journey to Strasbourg.

There is nothing further to be told of their tour. They were but two days and nights on the road from Basle to London; and during those two days and nights neither George nor Kate spoke a word to Alice of her (Alice) marriage, nor was any allusion made to the balcony at the inn, or to the bridge over the river.

CHAPTER VII.

Aunt Greenow.

Kate Vavasor remained only three days in London before she (Vavasor) started for Yarmouth; and during those three days she (Vavasor) was not much with her (Vavasor) cousin.

``I'm my aunt's, body and soul, for the next six weeks,'' (she)
she (Vavasor) said to Alice, when she (Alice) did come to Queen Anne Street on the morning after her (Alice) arrival.
``And she (aunt) is exigeant in a manner I can't at all explain to you. You mustn't be surprised if I don't even write a line. I've escaped by stealth now. She (aunt) went up-stairs to try on some new weeds for the seaside, and then I bolted.'' (She)
She (Alice) did not say a word about George; nor during those three days, nor for some days afterwards, did George show himself. As it turned out afterwards, he (George) had gone off to Scotland, and had remained a week among the grouse. Thus, at least, he (George) had accounted for himself and his (George) movements; but all George Vavasor's friends knew that his (George) goings out and comings in were seldom accounted for openly like those of other men.

It will perhaps be as well to say a few words about Mrs. Greenow before we go with her (Greenow) to Yarmouth. Mrs. Greenow was the only daughter and the youngest child of the old squire at Vavasor Hall. She (Greenow) was just ten years younger than her (Greenow) brother John, and I am inclined to think that she (Greenow) was almost justified in her (Greenow) repeated assertion that the difference was much greater than ten years, by the freshness of her (Greenow) colour, and by the general juvenility of her (Greenow) appearance. She (Greenow) certainly did not look forty, and who can expect a woman to proclaim herself to be older than her (woman) looks? In early life she (woman) had been taken from her (woman) father's house, and had lived with relatives in one of the large towns in the north of England. It is certain she (woman) had not been quite successful as a girl. Though she (woman) had enjoyed the name of being a beauty, she (woman) had not the usual success which comes from such repute. At thirty-four she (woman) was still unmarried. She (woman) had, moreover, acquired the character of being a flirt; and I fear that the stories which were told of her (woman), though doubtless more than half false, had in them sufficient of truth to justify the character. Now this was very sad, seeing that Arabella Vavasor had no fortune, and that she (woman) had offended her (woman) father and brothers by declining to comply with their advice at certain periods of her (woman) career. There was, indeed, considerable trouble in the minds of the various male Vavasors with reference to Arabella, when tidings suddenly reached the Hall that she (woman) was going to be married to an old man.

She (woman) was married to the old man; and the marriage fortunately turned out satisfactorily, at any rate for the old man and for her (woman) family. The Vavasors were relieved from all further trouble, and were as much surprised as gratified when they heard that she (woman) did her (woman) duty well in her (woman) new position. Arabella had long been a thorn in their side, never having really done anything which they could pronounce to be absolutely wrong, but always giving them cause for fear. Now they feared no longer. Her (woman) husband was a retired merchant, very rich, not very strong in health, and devoted to his (husband) bride. Rumours soon made their way to Vavasor Hall, and to Queen Anne Street, that Mrs. Greenow was quite a pattern wife, and that Mr. Greenow considered himself to be the happiest old man in Lancashire. And now in her (Greenow) prosperity she (Greenow) quite forgave the former slights which had been put upon her (Greenow) by her (Greenow) relatives. She (Greenow) wrote to her (Greenow) dear niece Alice, and to her (Greenow) dearest niece Kate, and sent little presents to her (Greenow) father. On one occasion she (Greenow) took her (Greenow) husband to Vavasor Hall, and there was a regular renewal of all the old family feelings. Arabella's husband was an old man, and was very old for his (man) age; but the whole thing was quite respectable, and there was, at any rate, no doubt about the money. Then Mr. Greenow died; and the widow, having proved the will, came up to London and claimed the commiseration of her (widow) nieces.

``Why not go to Yarmouth with her (aunt) for a month?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
George had said to Kate.
``Of course it will be a bore. But an aunt with forty thousand pounds has a right to claim attention.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Kate acknowledged the truth of the argument and agreed to go to Yarmouth for a month.
``Your aunt Arabella has shown herself to be a very sensible woman,'' (the squire)
the old squire had written;
``much more sensible than anybody thought her (woman) before her (woman) marriage. Of course you should go with her (woman) if she (woman) asks you.'' (the squire)
What aunt, uncle, or cousin, in the uncontrolled possession of forty thousand pounds was ever unpopular in the family?

Yarmouth is not a very prepossessing place to the eye. To my eye, at any rate, it is not so. There is an old town with which summer visitors have little or nothing to do; and there are the new houses down by the sea-side, to which, at any rate, belongs the full advantage of sea air. A kind of esplanade runs for nearly a mile along the sands, and there are built, or in the course of building, rows of houses appropriated to summer visitors all looking out upon the sea. There is no beauty unless the yellow sandy sea can be called beautiful. The coast is low and straight, and the east wind blows full upon it. But the place is healthy; and Mrs. Greenow was probably right in thinking that she (Greenow) might there revive some portion of the health which she (Greenow) had lost in watching beside the couch of her (Greenow) departing lord.

``Omnibus;--no, indeed. Jeannette, get me a fly.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
These were the first words Mrs. Greenow spoke as she (Greenow) put her (Greenow) foot upon the platform at the Yarmouth station. Her (Greenow) maid's name was Jenny; but Kate had already found, somewhat to her (Kate) dismay, that orders had been issued before they left London that the girl was henceforth to be called Jeannette. Kate had also already found that her (Kate) aunt could be imperious; but this taste for masterdom had not shown itself so plainly in London as it did from the moment that the train had left the station at Shoreditch. In London Mrs. Greenow had been among Londoners, and her (Greenow) career had hitherto been provincial. Her (Greenow) spirit, no doubt, had been somewhat cowed by the novelty of her (Greenow) position. But when she (Greenow) felt herself to be once beyond the stones as the saying used to be, she (Greenow) was herself again; and at Ipswich she (Greenow) had ordered Jeannette to get her (Greenow) a glass of sherry with an air which had created a good deal of attention among the guards and porters.

The fly was procured; and with considerable exertion all Mrs. Greenow's boxes, together with the more moderate belongings of her (Greenow) niece and maid, were stowed on the top of it, round upon the driver's body on the coach box, on the maid's lap, and I fear in Kate's also, and upon the vacant seat.

``The large house in Montpelier Parade,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.

``They is all large, ma'am,'' (the driver)
said the driver.

``The largest,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.

``They're much of a muchness,'' (the driver)
said the driver.

``Then Mrs. Jones's,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.
``But I was particularly told it was the largest in the row.'' (unknown)

``I know Mrs. Jones's well,'' (the driver)
said the driver, and away they went.

Mrs. Jones's house was handsome and comfortable; but I fear Mrs. Greenow's satisfaction in this respect was impaired by her (Greenow) disappointment in finding that it was not perceptibly bigger than those to the right and left of her (Greenow). Her (Greenow) ambition in this and in other similar matters would have amused Kate greatly had she (Kate) been a bystander, and not one of her (Kate) aunt's party. Mrs. Greenow was good-natured, liberal, and not by nature selfish; but she (Greenow) was determined not to waste the good things which fortune had given, and desired that all the world should see that she (Greenow) had forty thousand pounds of her (Greenow) own. And in doing this she (Greenow) was repressed by no feeling of false shame. She (Greenow) never hesitated in her (Greenow) demands through bashfulness. She (Greenow) called aloud for such comfort and grandeur as Yarmouth could afford her (Greenow), and was well pleased that all around should hear her (Greenow) calling. Joined to all this was her (Greenow) uncontrolled grief for her (Greenow) husband's death.

``Dear Greenow! sweet lamb! Oh, Kate, if you'd only known that man!'' (she)
When she (Greenow) said this she (Greenow) was sitting in the best of Mrs. Jones's sitting-rooms, waiting to have dinner announced. She (Jones) had taken a drawing-room and dining-room,
``because,'' (She)
as she (Jones) had said,
``she (Kate) didn't see why people should be stuffy when they went to the seaside;--not if they had means to make themselves comfortable.'' (she)

``Oh, Kate, I do wish you'd known him (man)!'' (unknown)

``I wish I had,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate,--very untruly.
``I was unfortunately away when he (man) went to Vavasor Hall.'' (unknown)

``Ah, yes; but it was at home, in the domestic circle, that Greenow should have been seen to be appreciated. I was a happy woman, Kate, while that lasted.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
And Kate was surprised to see that real tears--one or two on each side--were making their way down her (Kate) aunt's cheeks. But they were soon checked with a handkerchief of the broadest hem and of the finest cambric.

``Dinner, ma'am,'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette, opening the door.

``Jeannette, I told you always to say that dinner was served.'' (unknown)

``Dinner's served then,'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette in a tone of anger.

``Come, Kate,'' (aunt)
said her (Jeannette) aunt.
``I've but little appetite myself, but there's no reason you shouldn't eat your dinner. I specially wrote to Mrs. Jones to have some sweetbread. I do hope she (Jones)'s got a decent cook. It's very little I eat myself, but I do like to see things nice.'' (unknown)

The next day was Sunday; and it was beautiful to see how Mrs. Greenow went to church in all the glory of widowhood. There had been a great unpacking after that banquet on the sweetbread, and all her (Greenow) funereal millinery had been displayed before Kate's wondering eyes. The charm of the woman was in this,--that she (Kate) was not in the least ashamed of anything that she (Kate) did. She (Kate) turned over all her (Kate) wardrobe of mourning, showing the richness of each article, the stiffness of the crape, the fineness of the cambric, the breadth of the frills,--telling the price of each to a shilling, while she (Kate) explained how the whole had been amassed without any consideration of expense. This she (Kate) did with all the pride of a young bride when she (Kate) shows the glories of her (Kate) trousseau to the friend of her (Kate) bosom. Jeannette stood by the while, removing one thing and exhibiting another. Now and again through the performance, Mrs. Greenow would rest a while from her (Greenow) employment, and address the shade of the departed one in terms of most endearing affection. In the midst of this Mrs. Jones came in; but the widow was not a whit abashed by the presence of the stranger.

``Peace be to his (cook) manes!'' (she)
she (widow) said at last, as she (widow) carefully folded up a huge black crape mantilla. She (widow) made, however, but one syllable of the classical word, and Mrs. Jones thought that her (Jones) lodger had addressed herself to the mortal
``remains'' (lodger)
of her (Jones) deceased lord.

-LSB-Illustration:

``Peace be to his (cook) manes.'' (unknown)
-RSB-

``He (cook) is left her (Jones) uncommon well off, I suppose,'' (Mrs. Jones/Jones)
said Mrs. Jones to Jeannette.

``You may say that, ma'am. It's more nor a hundred thousand of pounds!'' (unknown)

``No!'' (unknown)
