``Pounds of sterling, ma'am! Indeed it is;--to my knowledge.'' (unknown)

``Why don't she (Jones) have a carriage?'' (unknown)

``So she (Jones) do;--but a lady can't bring her (Jones) carriage down to the sea when she (Jones)'s only just buried her (Jones) husband as one may say. What'd folks say if they saw her (Jones) in her (Jones) own carriage? But it ain't because she (Jones) can't afford it, Mrs. Jones. And now we're talking of it you must order a fly for church to-morrow, that'll look private, you know. She (Jones) said I was to get a man that had a livery coat and gloves.'' (The man)

The man with the coat and gloves was procured; and Mrs. Greenow's entry into church made quite a sensation. There was a thoughtfulness about her (Greenow) which alone showed that she (Greenow) was a woman of no ordinary power. She (Greenow) foresaw all necessities, and made provision for all emergencies. Another would not have secured an eligible sitting, and been at home in Yarmouth church, till half the period of her (Greenow) sojourn there was over. But Mrs. Greenow had done it all. She (Greenow) walked up the middle aisle with as much self-possession as though the chancel had belonged to her (Greenow) family for years; and the respectable pew-opener absolutely deserted two or three old ladies whom she (Greenow) was attending, to show Mrs. Greenow into her (Greenow) seat. When seated, she (Greenow) was the cynosure of all eyes. Kate Vavasor became immediately aware that a great sensation had been occasioned by their entrance, and equally aware that none of it was due to her (Vavasor). I regret to say that this feeling continued to show itself throughout the whole service. How many ladies of forty go to church without attracting the least attention! But it is hardly too much to say that every person in that church had looked at Mrs. Greenow. I doubt if there was present there a single married lady who, on leaving the building, did not speak to her (lady) husband of the widow. There had prevailed during the whole two hours a general though unexpressed conviction that something worthy of remark had happened that morning. It had an effect even upon the curate's reading; and the incumbent, while preaching his (husband) sermon, could not keep his (husband) eyes off that wonderful bonnet and veil.

On the next morning, before eleven, Mrs. Greenow's name was put down at the Assembly Room.

``I need hardly say that in my present condition I care nothing for these things. Of course I would sooner be alone. But, my dear Kate, I know what I owe to you.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

Kate, with less intelligence than might have been expected from one so clever, began to assure her (Kate) aunt that she (Kate) required no society; and that, coming thus with her (Kate) to the seaside in the early days of her (Kate) widowhood, she (Kate) had been well aware that they would live retired. But Mrs. Greenow soon put her (Greenow) down, and did so without the slightest feeling of shame or annoyance on her (Greenow) own part.

``My dear,'' (she)
she (Greenow) said,
``in this matter you must let me do what I know to be right. I should consider myself to be very selfish if I allowed my grief to interfere with your amusements.'' (she)

``But, aunt, I don't care for such amusements.'' (unknown)

``That's nonsense, my dear. You ought to care for them. How are you to settle yourself in life if you don't care for them?'' (unknown)

``My dear aunt, I am settled.'' (unknown)

``Settled!'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, astounded, as though there must have been some hidden marriage of which she (Greenow) had not heard.
``But that's nonsense. Of course you're not settled; and how are you to be, if I allow you to shut yourself up in such a place as this,--just where a girl has a chance?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

It was in vain that Kate tried to stop her (Kate). It was not easy to stop Mrs. Greenow when she (Greenow) was supported by the full assurance of being mistress of the place and of the occasion.

``No, my dear; I know very well what I owe to you, and I shall do my duty. As I said before, society can have no charms now for such a one as I am. All that social intercourse could ever do for me lies buried in my darling's grave. My heart is desolate, and must remain so. But I'm not going to immolate you on the altars of my grief. I shall force myself to go out for your sake, Kate.'' (unknown)

``But, dear aunt, the world will think it so odd, just at present.'' (unknown)

``I don't care twopence for the world. What can the world do to me? I'm not dependent on the world,--thanks to the care of that sainted lamb. I can hold my own; and as long as I can do that the world won't hurt me. No, Kate, if I think a thing's right I shall do it. I mean to make the place pleasant for you if I can, and the world may object if it likes.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

Mrs. Greenow was probably right in her (Greenow) appreciation of the value of her (Greenow) independence. Remarks may perhaps have been made by the world of Yarmouth as to her (Greenow) early return to society. People, no doubt, did remind each other that old Greenow was hardly yet four months buried. Mrs. Jones and Jeannette probably had their little jokes down-stairs. But this did not hurt Mrs. Greenow. What was said, was not said in her (Greenow) hearing, Mrs. Jones's bills were paid every Saturday with admirable punctuality; and as long as this was done everybody about the house treated the lady with that deference which was due to the respectability of her (lady) possessions. When a recently bereaved widow attempts to enjoy her (lady) freedom without money, then it behoves the world to speak aloud;--and the world does its duty.

Numerous people came to call at Montpelier Parade, and Kate was astonished to find that her (Kate) aunt had so many friends. She (Kate) was indeed so bewildered by these strangers that she (Kate) could hardly ascertain whom her (Kate) aunt had really known before, and whom she (Kate) now saw for the first time. Somebody had known somebody who had known somebody else, and that was allowed to be a sufficient introduction,--always presuming that the existing somebody was backed by some known advantages of money or position. Mrs. Greenow could smile from beneath her (Greenow) widow's cap in a most bewitching way.

``Upon my word then she (Kate) is really handsome,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Kate wrote one day to Alice. But she (Kate) could also frown, and knew well how to put aside, or, if need be, to reprobate any attempt at familiarity from those whose worldly circumstances were supposed to be disadvantageous.

``My dear aunt,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate one morning after their walk upon the pier,
``how you did snub that Captain Bellfield!'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

``Captain Bellfield, indeed! I don't believe he (Captain)'s a captain at all. At any rate he (Captain) has sold out, and the tradesmen have had a scramble for the money. He (Captain) was only a lieutenant when the 97th were in Manchester, and I'm sure he (Captain)'s never had a shilling to purchase since that.'' (unknown)

``But everybody here seems to know him (Captain).'' (unknown)

``Perhaps they do not know so much of him (Captain) as I do. The idea of his (Captain) having the impudence to tell me I was looking very well! Nothing can be so mean as men who go about in that way when they haven't money enough in their pockets to pay their washerwomen.'' (unknown)

``But how do you know, aunt, that Captain Bellfield hasn't paid his (Captain) washerwoman?'' (unknown)

``I know more than you think, my dear. It's my business. How could I tell whose attentions you should receive and whose you shouldn't, if I didn't inquire into these things?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

It was in vain that Kate rebelled, or attempted to rebel against this more than maternal care. She (Kate) told her (Kate) aunt that she (Kate) was now nearly thirty, and that she (Kate) had managed her (Kate) own affairs, at any rate with safety, for the last ten years;--but it was to no purpose. Kate would get angry; but Mrs. Greenow never became angry. Kate would be quite in earnest; but Mrs. Greenow would push aside all that her (Greenow) niece said as though it were worth nothing. Kate was an unmarried woman with a very small fortune, and therefore, of course, was desirous of being married with as little delay as possible. It was natural that she (Kate) should deny that it was so, especially at this early date in their mutual acquaintance. When the niece came to know her (niece) aunt more intimately, there might be confidence between them, and then they would do better. But Mrs. Greenow would spare neither herself nor her (Greenow) purse on Kate's behalf, and she (Kate) would be a dragon of watchfulness in protecting her (Kate) from the evil desires of such useless men as Captain Bellfield.

``I declare, Kate, I don't understand you,'' (she)
she (Bellfield) said one morning to her (Bellfield) niece as they sat together over a late breakfast. They had fallen into luxurious habits, and I am afraid it was past eleven o'clock, although the breakfast things were still on the table. Kate would usually bathe before breakfast, but Mrs. Greenow was never out of her (Greenow) room till half-past ten.
``I like the morning for contemplation,'' (she)
she (Greenow) once said.
``When a woman has gone through all that I have suffered she (woman) has a great deal to think of.'' (unknown)
``And it is so much more comfortable to be a-thinking when one's in bed,'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette, who was present at the time.
``Child, hold your tongue,'' (the widow)
said the widow.
``Yes, ma'am,'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette. But we'll return to the scene at the breakfast-table.

``What don't you understand, aunt?'' (unknown)

``You only danced twice last night, and once you stood up with Captain Bellfield.'' (unknown)

``On purpose to ask after that poor woman who washes his (Captain) clothes without getting paid for it.'' (unknown)

``Nonsense, Kate; you didn't ask him (Captain) anything of the kind, I'm sure. It's very provoking. It is indeed.'' (unknown)

``But what harm can Captain Bellfield do me?'' (unknown)

``What good can he (Captain) do you? That's the question. You see, my dear, years will go by. I don't mean to say you ain't quite as young as ever you were, and nothing can be nicer and fresher than you are;--especially since you took to bathing.'' (unknown)

``Oh, aunt, don't!'' (unknown)

``My dear, the truth must be spoken. I declare I don't think I ever saw a young woman so improvident as you are. When are you to begin to think about getting married if you don't do it now?'' (unknown)

``I shall never begin to think about it, till I buy my wedding clothes.'' (unknown)

``That's nonsense,--sheer nonsense. How are you to get wedding clothes if you have never thought about getting a husband? Didn't I see Mr. Cheesacre ask you for a dance last night?'' (unknown)

``Yes, he (Cheesacre) did; while you were talking to Captain Bellfield yourself, aunt.'' (unknown)

``Captain Bellfield can't hurt me, my dear. And why didn't you dance with Mr. Cheesacre?'' (unknown)

``He (Cheesacre)'s a fat Norfolk farmer, with not an idea beyond the virtues of stall-feeding.'' (unknown)

``My dear, every acre of it is his (Cheesacre) own land,--every acre! And he (Cheesacre) bought another farm for thirteen thousand pounds only last autumn. They're better than the squires,--some of those gentlemen farmers; they are indeed. And of all men in the world they're the easiest managed.'' (unknown)

``That's a recommendation, no doubt.'' (unknown)

``Of course it is;--a great recommendation.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

Mrs. Greenow had no idea of joking when her (Greenow) mind was intent on serious things.

``He (Cheesacre)'s to take us to the picnic to-morrow, and I do hope you'll manage to let him (Cheesacre) sit beside you. It'll be the place of honour, because he (Cheesacre) gives all the wine. He (Cheesacre)'s picked up with that man Bellfield, and he (Cheesacre)'s to be there; but if you allow your name to be once mixed up with his (Cheesacre), it will be all over with you as far as Yarmouth is concerned.'' (unknown)

``I don't at all want to be mixed up with Captain Bellfield, as you call it,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate. Then she (Kate) subsided into her (Kate) novel, while Mrs. Greenow busied herself about the good things for the picnic. In truth, the aunt did not understand the niece. Whatsoever might be the faults of Kate Vavasor, an unmaidenly desire of catching a husband for herself was certainly not one of them.

CHAPTER VIII.

Mr. Cheesacre.

Yarmouth is not a happy place for a picnic. A picnic should be held among green things. Green turf is absolutely an essential. There should be trees, broken ground, small paths, thickets, and hidden recesses. There should, if possible, be rocks, old timber, moss, and brambles. There should certainly be hills and dales,--on a small scale; and above all, there should be running water. There should be no expanse. Jones should not be able to see all Greene's movements, nor should Augusta always have her (Jones) eye upon her (Jones) sister Jane. But the spot chosen for Mr. Cheesacre's picnic at Yarmouth had none of the virtues above described. It was on the seashore. Nothing was visible from the site but sand and sea. There were no trees there and nothing green;--neither was there any running water. But there was a long, dry, flat strand; there was an old boat half turned over, under which it was proposed to dine; and in addition to this, benches, boards, and some amount of canvas for shelter were provided by the liberality of Mr. Cheesacre. Therefore it was called Mr. Cheesacre's picnic.

But it was to be a marine picnic, and therefore the essential attributes of other picnics were not required. The idea had come from some boating expeditions, in which mackerel had been caught, and during which food had been eaten, not altogether comfortably, in the boats. Then a thought had suggested itself to Captain Bellfield that they might land and eat their food, and his (Captain) friend Mr. Cheesacre had promised his (Cheesacre) substantial aid. A lady had surmised that Ormesby sands would be the very place for dancing in the cool of the evening. They might

``Dance on the sand,'' (she)
she (lady) said,
``and yet no footing seen.'' (she)
And so the thing had progressed, and the picnic been inaugurated.

It was Mr. Cheesacre's picnic undoubtedly. Mr. Cheesacre was to supply the boats, the wine, the cigars, the music, and the carpenter's work necessary for the turning of the old boat into a banqueting saloon. But Mrs. Greenow had promised to provide the eatables, and enjoyed as much of the _éclat_ as the master of the festival. She (Greenow) had known Mr. Cheesacre now for ten days and was quite intimate with him (Cheesacre). He (Cheesacre) was a stout, florid man, of about forty-five, a bachelor, apparently much attached to ladies' society, bearing no sign of age except that he (bachelor) was rather bald, and that grey hairs had mixed themselves with his (bachelor) whiskers, very fond of his (bachelor) farming, and yet somewhat ashamed of it when he (bachelor) found himself in what he (bachelor) considered to be polite circles. And he (bachelor) was, moreover, a little inclined to seek the honour which comes from a well-filled and liberally-opened purse. He (bachelor) liked to give a man a dinner and then to boast of the dinner he (bachelor) had given. He (bachelor) was very proud when he (bachelor) could talk of having mounted, for a day's hunting, any man who might be supposed to be of higher rank than himself.

``I had Grimsby with me the other day,--the son of old Grimsby of Hatherwick, you know. Blessed if he (son) didn't stake my bay mare. But what matters? I mounted him (son) again the next day just the same.'' (Some people)
Some people thought he (man) was soft, for it was very well known throughout Norfolk that young Grimsby would take a mount wherever he (man) could get it. In these days Mrs. Greenow had become intimate with Mr. Cheesacre, and had already learned that he (Cheesacre) was the undoubted owner of his (Cheesacre) own acres.

``It wouldn't do for me,'' (she)
she (Greenow) had said to him (Cheesacre),
``to be putting myself forward, as if I were giving a party myself, or anything of that sort;--would it now?'' (him)

``Well, perhaps not. But you might come with us.'' (unknown)

``So I will, Mr. Cheesacre, for that dear girl's sake. I should never forgive myself if I debarred her (girl) from all the pleasures of youth, because of my sorrows. I need hardly say that at such a time as this nothing of that sort can give me any pleasure.'' (unknown)

``I suppose not,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre, with solemn look.

``Quite out of the question.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
And Mrs. Greenow wiped away her (Greenow) tears.
``For though as regards age I might dance on the sands as merrily as the best of them--'' (unknown)

``That I'm sure you could, Mrs. Greenow.'' (unknown)

``How's a woman to enjoy herself if her (Greenow) heart lies buried?'' (unknown)

``But it won't be so always, Mrs. Greenow.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

Mrs. Greenow shook her (Greenow) head to show that she (Greenow) hardly knew how to answer such a question. Probably it would be so always;--but she (Greenow) did not wish to put a damper on the present occasion by making so sad a declaration.

``But as I was saying,'' (she)
continued she (Greenow)--
``if you and I do it between us won't that be the surest way of having it come off nicely?'' (she)

Mr. Cheesacre thought that it would be the best way.

``Exactly so;--I'll do the meat and pastry and fruit, and you shall do the boats and the wine.'' (unknown)

``And the music,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre,
``and the expenses at the place.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
He (Cheesacre) did not choose that any part of his (Cheesacre) outlay should go unnoticed.

``I'll go halves in all that if you like,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow. But Mr. Cheesacre had declined this. He (Cheesacre) did not begrudge the expense, but only wished that it should be recognised.

``And, Mr. Cheesacre,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
continued Mrs. Greenow.
``I did mean to send the music; I did, indeed.'' (unknown)

``I couldn't hear of it, Mrs. Greenow.'' (unknown)

``But I mention it now, because I was thinking of getting Blowehard to come. That other man, Flutey, wouldn't do at all out in the open air.'' (unknown)

``It shall be Blowehard,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre; and it was Blowehard. Mrs. Greenow liked to have her (Greenow) own way in these little things, though her (Greenow) heart did lie buried.

On the morning of the picnic Mr. Cheesacre came down to Montpelier Parade with Captain Bellfield, whose linen on that occasion certainly gave no outward sign of any quarrel between him (Cheesacre) and his (Cheesacre) washerwoman. He (Cheesacre) was got up wonderfully, and was prepared at all points for the day's work. He (Cheesacre) had on a pseudo-sailor's jacket, very liberally ornamented with brass buttons, which displayed with great judgement the exquisite shapes of his (Cheesacre) pseudo-sailor's duck trousers. Beneath them there was a pair of very shiny patent-leather shoes, well adapted for dancing on the sand, presuming him (Cheesacre) to be anxious of doing so, as Venus offered to do, without leaving any footmarks. His (Cheesacre) waistcoat was of a delicate white fabric, ornamented with very many gilt buttons. He (Cheesacre) had bejewelled studs in his (Cheesacre) shirt, and yellow kid gloves on his (Cheesacre) hands; having, of course, another pair in his (Cheesacre) pocket for the necessities of the evening. His (Cheesacre) array was quite perfect, and had stricken dismay into the heart of his (Cheesacre) friend Cheesacre, when he (Cheesacre) joined that gentleman. He (Cheesacre) was a well-made man, nearly six feet high, with dark hair, dark whiskers, and dark moustache, nearly black, but of that suspicious hue which to the observant beholder seems always to tell a tale of the hairdresser's shop. He (Cheesacre) was handsome, too, with well-arranged features,--but carrying, perhaps, in his (Cheesacre) nose some first symptoms of the effects of midnight amusements. Upon the whole, however, he (Cheesacre) was a nice man to look at--for those who like to look on nice men of that kind.

Cheesacre, too, had adopted something of a sailor's garb. He (Cheesacre) had on a jacket of a rougher sort, coming down much lower than that of the captain, being much looser, and perhaps somewhat more like a garment which a possible seaman might possibly wear. But he (seaman) was disgusted with himself the moment that he (seaman) saw Bellfield. His (seaman) heart had been faint, and he (seaman) had not dared to ornament himself boldly as his (seaman) friend had done.

``I say, Guss, you are a swell,'' (he)
he (seaman) exclaimed. It may be explained that Captain Bellfield had been christened Gustavus.

``I don't know much about that,'' (the captain)
said the captain;
``my fellow sent me this toggery, and said that it was the sort of thing. I'll change with you if you like it.'' (the captain)
But Cheesacre could not have worn that jacket, and he (Cheesacre) walked on, hating himself.

It will be remembered that Mrs. Greenow had spoken with considerable severity of Captain Bellfield's pretensions when discussing his (Captain) character with her (Bellfield) niece; but, nevertheless, on the present occasion she (Bellfield) received him (Captain) with most gracious smiles. It may be that her (Bellfield) estimate of his (Captain) character had been altered, or that she (Bellfield) was making sacrifice of her (Bellfield) own feelings in consideration of Mr. Cheesacre, who was known to be the captain's intimate friend. But she (Bellfield) had smiles for both of them. She (Bellfield) had a wondrous power of smiling; and could, upon occasion, give signs of peculiar favour to half a dozen different gentlemen in as many minutes. They found her (Bellfield) in the midst of hampers which were not yet wholly packed, while Mrs. Jones, Jeannette, and the cook of the household moved around her (Jones), on the outside of the circle, ministering to her (Jones) wants. She (Jones) had in her (Jones) hand an outspread clean napkin, and she (Jones) wore fastened round her (Jones) dress a huge coarse apron, that she (Jones) might thus be protected from some possible ebullition of gravy, or escape of salad mixture, or cream; but in other respects she (Jones) was clothed in the fullest honours of widowhood. She (Jones) had not mitigated her (Jones) weeds by half an inch. She (Jones) had scorned to make any compromise between the world of pleasure and the world of woe. There she (Jones) was, a widow, declared by herself to be of four months' standing, with a buried heart, making ready a dainty banquet with skill and liberality. She (Jones) was ready on the instant to sit down upon the baskets in which the grouse pie had been just carefully inhumed, and talked about her (Jones) sainted lamb with a deluge of tears. If anybody didn't like it, that person--might do the other thing. Mr. Cheesacre and Captain Bellfield thought that they did like it.

``Oh, Mr. Cheesacre, if you haven't caught me before I've half done! Captain Bellfield, I hope you think my apron becoming.'' (unknown)

``Everything that you wear, Mrs. Greenow, is always becoming.'' (unknown)

``Don't talk in that way when you know--; but never mind--we will think of nothing sad to-day if we can help it. Will we, Mr. Cheesacre?'' (unknown)

``Oh dear no; I should think not;--unless it should come on to rain.'' (unknown)

``It won't rain--we won't think of such a thing. But, by the by, Captain Bellfield, I and my niece do mean to send out a few things, just in a bag you know, so that we may tidy ourselves up a little after the sea. I don't want it mentioned, because if it gets about among the other ladies, they'd think we wanted to make a dressing of it;--and there wouldn't be room for them all; would there?'' (unknown)

``No; there wouldn't,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre, who had been out on the previous evening, inspecting, and perhaps limiting, the carpenters in their work.

``That's just it,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.
``But there won't be any harm, will there, Mr. Cheesacre, in Jeanette's going out with our things? She (Jeanette)'ll ride in the cart, you know, with the eatables. I know Jeannette's a friend of yours.'' (unknown)

``We shall be delighted to have Jeanette,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre.

``Thank ye, sir,'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette, with a curtsey.

``Jeannette, don't you let Mr. Cheesacre turn your head; and mind you behave yourself and be useful. Well; let me see;--what else is there? Mrs. Jones, you might as well give me that ham now. Captain Bellfield, hand it over. Don't you put it into the basket, because you'd turn it the wrong side down. There now, if you haven't nearly made me upset the apricot pie.'' (the captain widow)
Then, in the transfer of the dishes between the captain and the widow, there occurred some little innocent by-play, which seemed to give offence to Mr. Cheesacre; so that that gentleman turned his (Cheesacre) back upon the hampers and took a step away towards the door.

Mrs. Greenow saw the thing at a glance, and immediately applied herself to cure the wound.

``What do you think, Mr. Cheesacre,'' (she)
said she (Greenow),
``Kate wouldn't come down because she (Kate) didn't choose that you should see her (Kate) with an apron on over her (Kate) frock!'' (she)

``I'm sure I don't know why Miss Vavasor should care about my seeing her (Kate).'' (unknown)

``Nor I either. That's just what I said. Do step up into the drawing-room; you'll find her (Kate) there, and you can make her (Kate) answer for herself.'' (unknown)

``She (Kate) wouldn't come down for me,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre. But he (Cheesacre) didn't stir. Perhaps he (Cheesacre) wasn't willing to leave his (Cheesacre) friend with the widow.

At length the last of the dishes was packed and Mrs. Greenow went up-stairs with the two gentlemen. There they found Kate and two or three other ladies who had promised to embark under the protection of Mrs. Greenow's wings. There were the two Miss Fairstairs, whom Mrs. Greenow had especially patronized, and who repaid that lady for her (Greenow) kindness by an amount of outspoken eulogy which startled Kate by its audacity.

``Your dear aunt!'' (Fanny Fairstairs/Fanny)
Fanny Fairstairs had said on coming into the room.
``I don't think I ever came across a woman with such genuine milk of human kindness!'' (unknown)

``Nor with so much true wit,'' (sister)
said her (Fairstairs) sister Charlotte,--who had been called Charlie on the sands of Yarmouth for the last twelve years.

When the widow came into the room, they flew at her (widow) and devoured her (widow) with kisses, and swore that they had never seen her (widow) looking so well. But as the bright new gloves which both the girls wore had been presents from Mrs. Greenow, they certainly did owe her (Greenow) some affection. There are not many ladies who would venture to bestow such gifts upon their friends after so very short an acquaintance; but Mrs. Greenow had a power that was quite her (Greenow) own in such matters. She (Greenow) was already on a very confidential footing with the Miss Fairstairs, and had given them much useful advice as to their future prospects.

And then was there a Mrs. Green, whose husband was first-lieutenant on board a man-of-war on the West Indian Station. Mrs. Green was a quiet, ladylike little woman, rather pretty, very silent, and, as one would have thought, hardly adapted for the special intimacy of Mrs. Greenow. But Mrs. Greenow had found out that she (Greenow) was alone, not very rich, and in want of the solace of society. Therefore she (Greenow) had, from sheer good-nature, forced herself upon Mrs. Green, and Mrs. Green, with much trepidation, had consented to be taken to the picnic.

``I know your husband would like it,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
Mrs. Greenow had said,
``and I hope I may live to tell him (husband) that I made you go.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

There came in also a brother of the Fairstairs girls, Joe Fairstairs, a lanky, useless, idle young man, younger than them, who was supposed to earn his (Fairstairs) bread in an attorney's office at Norwich, or rather to be preparing to earn it at some future time, and who was a heavy burden upon all his (Fairstairs) friends.

``We told Joe to come to the house,'' (Fanny Fairstairs/Fanny)
said Fanny to the widow, apologetically,
``because we thought he (Joe) might be useful in carrying down the cloaks.'' (the widow)
Mrs. Greenow smiled graciously upon Joe, and assured him (Joe) that she (Greenow) was charmed to see him (Joe), without any reference to such services as those mentioned.

And then they started. When they got to the door both Cheesacre and the captain made an attempt to get possession of the widow's arm. But she (widow) had it all arranged. Captain Bellfield found himself constrained to attend to Mrs. Green, while Mr. Cheesacre walked down to the beach beside Kate Vavasor.

``I'll take your arm, Mr. Joe,'' (the widow)
said the widow,
``and the girls shall come with us.'' (the widow)
But when they got to the boats, round which the other comers to the picnic were already assembled, Mr. Cheesacre,--although both the boats were for the day his (Cheesacre) own,--found himself separated from the widow. He (Cheesacre) got into that which contained Kate Vavasor, and was shoved off from the beach while he (Cheesacre) saw Captain Bellfield arranging Mrs. Greenow's drapery. He (Cheesacre) had declared to himself that it should be otherwise; and that as he (Cheesacre) had to pay the piper, the piper should play as he (piper) liked it. But Mrs. Greenow with a word or two had settled it all, and Mr. Cheesacre had found himself to be powerless.
``How absurd Bellfield looks in that jacket, doesn't he (Joe)?'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) said to Kate, as he (Cheesacre) took his (Cheesacre) seat in the boat.

``Do you think so? I thought it was so very pretty and becoming for the occasion.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)

Mr. Cheesacre hated Captain Bellfield, and regretted more than ever that he (Cheesacre) had not done something for his (Cheesacre) own personal adornment. He (Cheesacre) could not endure to think that his (Cheesacre) friend, who paid for nothing, should carry away the honours of the morning and defraud him (Cheesacre) of the delights which should justly belong to him (Cheesacre),

``It may be becoming,'' (him)
said Cheesacre;
``but don't you think it's awfully extravagant?'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)

``As to that I can't tell. You see I don't at all know what is the price of a jacket covered all over with little brass buttons.'' (unknown)

``And the waistcoat, Miss Vavasor!'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre, almost solemnly.

``The waistcoat I should think must have been expensive.'' (unknown)

``Oh, dreadful! and he (Joe)'s got nothing, Miss Vavasor; literally nothing. Do you know,'' (he)
--and he (Cheesacre) reduced his (Cheesacre) voice to a whisper as he (Cheesacre) made this communication,--
``I lent him (Joe) twenty pounds the day before yesterday; I did indeed. You won't mention it again, of course. I tell you, because, as you are seeing a good deal of him (Joe) just now, I think it right that you should know on what sort of a footing he (Joe) stands.'' (he)
It's all fair, they say, in love and war, and this small breach of confidence was, we must presume, a love stratagem on the part of Mr. Cheesacre. He (Cheesacre) was at this time smitten with the charms both of the widow and of the niece, and he (Cheesacre) constantly found that the captain was interfering with him (captain) on whichever side he (captain) turned himself. On the present occasion he (captain) had desired to take the widow for his (captain) share, and was, upon the whole, inclined to think that the widow was the more worthy of his (captain) attentions. He (captain) had made certain little inquiries within the last day or two, the answers to which had been satisfactory. These he (captain) had by no means communicated to his (captain) friend, to whom, indeed, he (captain) had expressed an opinion that Mrs. Greenow was after all only a flash in the pan.
``She (you) does very well pour passer le temps,'' (the captain)
the captain had answered. Mr. Cheesacre had not quite understood the exact gist of the captain's meaning, but had felt certain that his (Cheesacre) friend was playing him (Cheesacre) false.

``I don't want it to be mentioned again, Miss Vavasor,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) continued.

``Such things should not be mentioned at all,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Kate replied, having been angered at the insinuation that the nature of Captain Bellfield's footing could be a matter of any moment to her (Bellfield).

``No, they shouldn't; and therefore I know that I'm quite safe with you, Miss Vavasor. He (Joe)'s a very pleasant fellow, very; and has seen the world,--uncommon; but he (Joe)'s better for eating and drinking with than he (Joe) is for buying and selling with, as we say in Norfolk. Do you like Norfolk, Miss Vavasor?'' (unknown)

``I never was in it before, and now I've only seen Yarmouth.'' (unknown)

``A nice place, Yarmouth, very; but you should come up and see our lands. I suppose you don't know that we feed one-third of England during the winter months.'' (unknown)

``Dear me!'' (unknown)

``We do, though; nobody knows what a county Norfolk is. Taking it altogether, including the game you know, and Lord Nelson, and its watering-places and the rest of it, I don't think there's a county in England to beat it. Fancy feeding one-third of all England and Wales!'' (unknown)

``With bread and cheese, do you mean, and those sort of things?'' (unknown)

``Beef!'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre, and in his (Cheesacre) patriotic energy he (Cheesacre) repeated the word aloud.
``Beef! Yes indeed; but if you were to tell them that in London they wouldn't believe you. Ah! you should certainly come down and see our lands. The 7.45 A.M. train would take you through Norwich to my door, as one may say, and you would be back by the 6.22 P.M.'' (he)
In this way he (Cheesacre) brought himself back again into good-humour, feeling, that in the absence of the widow, he (Cheesacre) could not do better than make progress with the niece.

In the mean time Mrs. Greenow and the captain were getting on very comfortably in the other boat.

``Take an oar, Captain,'' (the men)
one of the men had said to him (captain) as soon as he (captain) had placed the ladies.
``Not to-day, Jack,'' (he)
he (captain) had answered.
``I'll content myself with being bo`san this morning.'' (unknown)
``The best thing as the bo`san does is to pipe all hands to grog,'' (the man)
said the man.
``I won't be behind in that either,'' (the captain)
said the captain; and so they all went on swimmingly.

``What a fine generous fellow your friend, Mr. Cheesacre, is!'' (the widow)
said the widow.

``Yes, he (Cheesacre) is; he (Cheesacre)'s a capital fellow in his (Cheesacre) way. Some of these Norfolk farmers are no end of good fellows.'' (unknown)

``And I suppose he (Cheesacre)'s something more than a common farmer. He (Cheesacre)'s visited by the people about where he (Cheesacre) lives, isn't he (Cheesacre)?'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes, in a sort of a way. The county people, you know, keep themselves very much to themselves.'' (unknown)

``That's of course. But his (Cheesacre) house;--he (Cheesacre) has a good sort of place, hasn't he (Cheesacre)?'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes;--a very good house;--a little too near to the horse-pond for my taste. But when a man gets his (man) money out of the till, he (man) mustn't be ashamed of the counter;--must he (man), Mrs. Greenow?'' (unknown)

``But he (man) could live like a gentleman if he (man) let his (man) own land, couldn't he (man)?'' (unknown)

``That depends upon how a gentleman wishes to live.'' (a lady)
Here the privacy of their conversation was interrupted by an exclamation from a young lady to the effect that Charlie Fairstairs was becoming sick. This Charlie stoutly denied, and proved the truth of her (lady) assertion by her (lady) behaviour. Soon after this they completed their marine adventures, and prepared to land close to the spot at which the banquet was prepared.

CHAPTER IX.

The Rivals.

There had been a pretence of fishing, but no fish had been caught. It was soon found that such an amusement would interfere with the ladies' dresses, and the affairs had become too serious to allow of any trivial interruption.

``I really think, Mr. Cheesacre,'' (an mother)
an anxious mother had said,
``that you'd better give it up. The water off the nasty cord has got all over Maria's dress, already.'' (an mother)
Maria made a faint protest that it did not signify in the least; but the fishing was given up,--not without an inward feeling on the part of Mr. Cheesacre that if Maria chose to come out with him (Cheesacre) in his (Cheesacre) boat, having been invited especially to fish, she (Maria) ought to have put up with the natural results.
``There are people who like to take everything and never like to give anything,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) said to Kate afterwards, as he (Cheesacre) was walking up with her (Kate) to the picnic dinner. But he (Cheesacre) was unreasonable and unjust. The girls had graced his (Cheesacre) party with their best hats and freshest muslins, not that they might see him (Cheesacre) catch a mackerel, but that they might flirt and dance to the best advantage.
``You can't suppose that any girl will like to be drenched with sea-water when she (girl) has taken so much trouble with her (girl) starch,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``Then she (girl) shouldn't come fishing,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre.
``I hate such airs.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

But when they arrived at the old boat, Mrs. Greenow shone forth pre-eminently as the mistress of the occasion, altogether overshadowing Mr. Cheesacre by the extent of her (Greenow) authority. There was a little contest for supremacy between them, invisible to the eyes of the multitude; but Mr. Cheesacre in such a matter had not a chance against Mrs. Greenow. I am disposed to think that she (Greenow) would have reigned even though she (Greenow) had not contributed to the eatables; but with that point in her (Greenow) favour, she (Greenow) was able to make herself supreme. Jeannette, too, was her (Jeannette) servant, which was a great thing. Mr. Cheesacre soon gave way; and though he (Cheesacre) bustled about and was conspicuous, he (Cheesacre) bustled about in obedience to orders received, and became a head servant. Captain Bellfield also made himself useful, but he (Captain) drove Mr. Cheesacre into paroxysms of suppressed anger by giving directions, and by having those directions obeyed. A man to whom he (man) had lent twenty pounds the day before yesterday, and who had not contributed so much as a bottle of champagne!

``We're to dine at four, and now it's half-past three,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, addressing herself to the multitude.

``And to begin to dance at six,'' (an lady)
said an eager young lady.

``Maria, hold your tongue,'' (the lady)
said the young lady's mother.

``Yes, we'll dine at four,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre.
``And as for the music, I've ordered it to be here punctual at half-past five. We're to have three horns, cymbals, triangle, and a drum.'' (unknown)

``How very nice; isn't it, Mrs. Greenow?'' (Charlie/Charlie Fairstairs)
said Charlie Fairstairs.

``And now suppose we begin to unpack,'' (Captain)
said Captain Bellfield.
``Half the fun is in arranging the things.'' (unknown)

``Oh, dear, yes; more than half,'' (Fanny Fairstairs/Fanny)
said Fanny Fairstairs.

``Bellfield, don't mind about the hampers,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre.
``Wine is a ticklish thing to handle, and there's my man there to manage it.'' (unknown)

``It's odd if I don't know more about wine than the boots from the hotel,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
said Bellfield. This allusion to the boots almost cowed Mr. Cheesacre, and made him (Cheesacre) turn away, leaving Bellfield with the widow.

There was a great unpacking, during which Captain Bellfield and Mrs. Greenow constantly had their heads in the same hamper. I by no means intend to insinuate that there was anything wrong in this. People engaged together in unpacking pies and cold chickens must have their heads in the same hamper. But a great intimacy was thereby produced, and the widow seemed to have laid aside altogether that prejudice of hers with reference to the washerwoman. There was a long table placed on the sand, sheltered by the upturned boat from the land side, but open towards the sea, and over this, supported on poles, there was an awning. Upon the whole the arrangement was not an uncomfortable one for people who had selected so very uncomfortable a dining-room as the sand of the sea-shore. Much was certainly due to Mr. Cheesacre for the expenditure he (Cheesacre) had incurred,--and something perhaps to Captain Bellfield for his (Captain) ingenuity in having suggested it.

Now came the placing of the guests for dinner, and Mr. Cheesacre made another great effort.

``I'll tell you what,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) said, aloud,
``Bellfield and I will take the two ends of the table, and Mrs. Greenow shall sit at my right hand.'' (he)
This was not only boldly done, but there was a propriety in it which at first sight seemed to be irresistible. Much as he (Cheesacre) had hated and did hate the captain, he (Cheesacre) had skilfully made the proposition in such a way as to flatter him (Cheesacre), and it seemed for a few moments as though he (Cheesacre) were going to have it all his (Cheesacre) own way. But Captain Bellfield was not a man to submit to defeat in such a matter as this without an effort.
``I don't think that will do,'' (he)
said he (Captain).
``Mrs. Greenow gives the dinner, and Cheesacre gives the wine. We must have them at the two ends of the table. I am sure Mrs. Greenow won't refuse to allow me to hand her (Greenow) to the place which belongs to her (Greenow). I will sit at her (Greenow) right hand and be her (Greenow) minister.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
Mrs. Greenow did not refuse,--and so the matter was adjusted.

Mr. Cheesacre took his (Cheesacre) seat in despair. It was nothing to him (Cheesacre) that he (Cheesacre) had Kate Vavasor at his (Cheesacre) left hand. He (Cheesacre) liked talking to Kate very well, but he (Cheesacre) could not enjoy that pleasure while Captain Bellfield was in the very act of making progress with the widow.

``One would think that he (minister) had given it himself; wouldn't you?'' (he)
he (Captain) said to Maria's mother, who sat at his (Captain) right hand.

The lady did not in the least understand him (Captain).

``Given what?'' (she)
said she (lady).

``Why, the music and the wine and all the rest of it. There are some people full of that kind of impudence. How they manage to carry it on without ever paying a shilling, I never could tell. I know I have to pay my way, and something over and beyond generally.'' (Maria)

Maria's mother said,

``Yes, indeed.'' (Maria mother)
She (lady) had other daughters there besides Maria, and was looking down the table to see whether they were judiciously placed. Her (Maria) beauty, her (Maria) youngest one, Ophelia, was sitting next to that ne'er-do-well Joe Fairstairs, and this made her (Maria) unhappy.
``Ophelia, my dear, you are dreadfully in the draught; there's a seat up here, just opposite, where you'll be more comfortable.'' (unknown)

``There's no draught here, mamma,'' (Ophelia)
said Ophelia, without the slightest sign of moving. Perhaps Ophelia liked the society of that lanky, idle, useless young man.

The mirth of the table certainly came from Mrs. Greenow's end. The widow had hardly taken her (widow) place before she (widow) got up again and changed with the captain. It was found that the captain could better carve the great grouse pie from the end than from the side. Cheesacre, when he (Cheesacre) saw this, absolutely threw down his (Cheesacre) knife and fork violently upon the table.

``Is anything the matter?'' (Maria)
said Maria's mother.

``Matter!'' (he)
said he (Cheesacre). Then he (Cheesacre) shook his (Cheesacre) head in grief of heart and vexation of spirit, and resumed his (Cheesacre) knife and fork. Kate watched it all, and was greatly amused.
``I never saw a man so nearly broken-hearted,'' (she)
she (Kate) said, in her (Kate) letter to Alice the next day.
``Eleven, thirteen, eighteen, twenty-one,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre to himself, reckoning up in his (Cheesacre) misery the number of pounds sterling which he (Cheesacre) would have to pay for being ill-treated in this way.

``Ladies and gentlemen,'' (Captain)
said Captain Bellfield, as soon as the eating was over,
``if I may be permitted to get upon my legs for two minutes, I am going to propose a toast to you.'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
The real patron of the feast had actually not yet swallowed his (patron) last bit of cheese. The thing was indecent in the violence of its injustice.

-LSB-Illustration: Captain Bellfield proposes a toast.-RSB-

``If you please, Captain Bellfield,'' (the patron)
said the patron, indifferent to the cheese in his (patron) throat,
``I'll propose the toast.'' (the patron)

``Nothing on earth could be better, my dear fellow,'' (the captain)
said the captain,
``and I'm sure I should be the last man in the world to take the job out of the hands of one who would do it so much better than I can; but as it's your health that we're going to drink, I really don't see how you are to do it.'' (the captain)

Cheesacre grunted and sat down. He (Cheesacre) certainly could not propose his (Cheesacre) own health, nor did he (Cheesacre) complain of the honour that was to be done him (Cheesacre). It was very proper that his (Cheesacre) health should be drunk, and he (Cheesacre) had now to think of the words in which he (Cheesacre) would return thanks. But the extent of his (Cheesacre) horror may be imagined when Bellfield got up and made a most brilliant speech in praise of Mrs. Greenow. For full five minutes he (Cheesacre) went on without mentioning the name of Cheesacre. Yarmouth, he (Cheesacre) said, had never in his (Cheesacre) days been so blessed as it had been this year by the presence of the lady who was now with them. She (lady) had come among them, he (Cheesacre) declared, forgetful of herself and of her (lady) great sorrows, with the sole desire of adding something to the happiness of others. Then Mrs. Greenow had taken out her (Greenow) pocket-handkerchief, sweeping back the broad ribbons of her (Greenow) cap over her (Greenow) shoulders. Altogether the scene was very affecting, and Cheesacre was driven to madness. They were the very words that he (Cheesacre) had intended to speak himself.

``I hate all this kind of thing,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) said to Kate.
``It's so fulsome.'' (unknown)

``After-dinner speeches never mean anything,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

At last, when Bellfield had come to an end of praising Mrs. Greenow, he (Cheesacre) told the guests that he (Cheesacre) wished to join his (Cheesacre) friend Mr. Cheesacre in the toast, the more so as it could hardly be hoped that Mrs. Greenow would herself rise to return thanks. There was no better fellow than his (Cheesacre) friend Cheesacre, whom he (Cheesacre) had known for he (Cheesacre) would not say how many years. He (Cheesacre) was quite sure they would all have the most sincere pleasure in joining the health of Mr. Cheesacre with that of Mrs. Greenow. Then there was a clattering of glasses and a murmuring of healths, and Mr. Cheesacre slowly got upon his (Cheesacre) legs.

``I'm very much obliged to this company,'' (he)
said he (Cheesacre),
``and to my friend Bellfield, who really is,--but perhaps that doesn't signify now. I've had the greatest pleasure in getting up this little thing, and I'd made up my mind to propose Mrs. Greenow's health; but, h'm, ha, no doubt it has been in better hands. Perhaps, considering all things, Bellfield might have waited.'' (he)

``With such a subject on my hands, I couldn't wait a moment.'' (unknown)

``I didn't interrupt you, Captain Bellfield, and perhaps you'll let me go on without interrupting me. We've all drunk Mrs. Greenow's health, and I'm sure she (Greenow)'s very much obliged. So am I for the honour you've done me. I have taken some trouble in getting up this little thing, and I hope you like it. I think somebody said something about liberality. I beg to assure you that I don't think of that for a moment. Somebody must pay for these sort of things, and I'm always very glad to take my turn. I dare say Bellfield will give us the next picnic, and if he (my)'ll appoint a day before the end of the month, I shall be happy to be one of the party.'' (he)
Then he (Cheesacre) sat down with some inward satisfaction, fully convinced that he (Cheesacre) had given his (Cheesacre) enemy a fatal blow.

``Nothing on earth would give me so much pleasure,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
said Bellfield. After that he (Cheesacre) turned again to Mrs. Greenow and went on with his (Cheesacre) private conversation.

There was no more speaking, nor was there much time for other after-dinner ceremonies. The three horns, the cymbals, the triangle, and the drum were soon heard tuning-up behind the banqueting-hall, and the ladies went to the further end of the old boat to make their preparations for the dance. Then it was that the thoughtful care of Mrs. Greenow, in having sent Jeannette with brushes, combs, clean handkerchiefs, and other little knick-knackeries, became so apparent. It was said that the widow herself actually changed her (widow) cap,--which was considered by some to be very unfair, as there had been an understanding that there should be no dressing. On such occasions ladies are generally willing to forego the advantage of dressing on the condition that other ladies shall forego the same advantage; but when this compact is broken by any special lady, the treason is thought to be very treacherous. It is as though a fencer should remove the button from the end of his (fencer) foil. But Mrs. Greenow was so good-natured in tendering the services of Jeannette to all the young ladies, and was so willing to share with others those good things of the toilet which her (Greenow) care had provided, that her (Greenow) cap was forgiven her (Greenow) by the most of those present.

When ladies have made up their minds to dance they will dance let the circumstances of the moment be ever so antagonistic to that exercise. A ploughed field in February would not be too wet, nor the side of a house too uneven. In honest truth the sands of the seashore are not adapted for the exercise. It was all very well for Venus to make the promise, but when making it she (Venus) knew that Adonis would not keep her (Venus) to her (Venus) word. Let any lightest-limbed nymph try it, and she (Venus) will find that she (Venus) leaves most palpable footing. The sands in question were doubtless compact, firm, and sufficiently moist to make walking on them comfortable; but they ruffled themselves most uncomfortably under the unwonted pressure to which they were subjected. Nevertheless our friends did dance on the sands; finding, however, that quadrilles and Sir Roger de Coverley suited them better than polkas and waltzes.

``No, my friend, no,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
Mrs. Greenow said to Mr. Cheesacre when that gentleman endeavoured to persuade her (Greenow) to stand up;
``Kate will be delighted I am sure to join you,--but as for me, you must excuse me.'' (her)

But Mr. Cheesacre was not inclined at that moment to ask Kate Vavasor to dance with him (Cheesacre). He (Cheesacre) was possessed by an undefined idea that Kate had snubbed him (Cheesacre), and as Kate's fortune was, as he (Cheesacre) said, literally nothing, he (Cheesacre) was not at all disposed to court her (Kate) favour at the expense of such suffering to himself.

``I'm not quite sure that I'll dance myself,'' (he)
said he (Cheesacre), seating himself in a corner of the tent by Mrs. Greenow's side. Captain Bellfield at that moment was seen leading Miss Vavasor away to a new place on the sands, whither he (Captain) was followed by a score of dancers; and Mr. Cheesacre saw that now at last he (Cheesacre) might reap the reward for which he (Cheesacre) had laboured. He (Cheesacre) was alone with the widow, and having been made bold by wine, had an opportunity of fighting his (Cheesacre) battle, than which none better could ever be found. He (Cheesacre) was himself by no means a poor man, and he (Cheesacre) despised poverty in others. It was well that there should be poor gentry, in order that they might act as satellites to those who, like himself, had money. As to Mrs. Greenow's money, there was no doubt. He (gentry) knew it all to a fraction. She (Greenow) had spread for herself, or some one else had spread for her (Greenow), a report that her (Greenow) wealth was almost unlimited; but the forty thousand pounds was a fact, and any such innocent fault as that little fiction might well be forgiven to a woman endorsed with such substantial virtues. And she (woman) was handsome too. Mr. Cheesacre, as he (Cheesacre) regarded her (woman) matured charms, sometimes felt that he (Cheesacre) should have been smitten even without the forty thousand pounds.
``By George! there's flesh and blood,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) had once said to his (Cheesacre) friend Bellfield before he (Cheesacre) had begun to suspect that man's treachery. His (Cheesacre) admiration must then have been sincere, for at that time the forty thousand pounds was not an ascertained fact. Looking at the matter in all its bearings Mr. Cheesacre thought that he (Cheesacre) couldn't do better. His (Cheesacre) wooing should be fair, honest, and above board. He (Cheesacre) was a thriving man, and what might not they two do in Norfolk if they put their wealth together?

``Oh, Mr. Cheesacre, you should join them,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow;
``they'll not half enjoy themselves without you. Kate will think that you mean to neglect her (Kate).'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

``I shan't dance, Mrs. Greenow, unless you like to stand up for a set.'' (unknown)

``No, my friend, no; I shall not do that. I fear you forget how recent has been my bereavement. Your asking me is the bitterest reproach to me for having ventured to join your festive board.'' (unknown)

``Upon my honour I didn't mean it, Mrs. Greenow. I didn't mean it, indeed.'' (unknown)

``I do not suspect you. It would have been unmanly.'' (unknown)

``And nobody can say that of me. There isn't a man or woman in Norfolk that wouldn't say I was manly.'' (unknown)

``I'm quite sure of that.'' (unknown)

``I have my faults, I'm aware.'' (unknown)

``And what are your faults, Mr. Cheesacre?'' (unknown)

``Well; perhaps I'm extravagant. But it's only in these kind of things you know, when I spend a little money for the sake of making my friends happy. When I'm about, on the lands at home, I ain't extravagant, I can tell you.'' (unknown)

``Extravagance is a great vice.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I ain't extravagant in that sense;--not a bit in the world. But when a man's enamoured, and perhaps looking out for a wife, he (man) does like to be a little free, you know.'' (unknown)

``And are you looking out for a wife, Mr. Cheesacre?'' (unknown)

``If I told you I suppose you'd only laugh at me.'' (unknown)

``No; indeed I would not. I am not given to joking when any one that I regard speaks to me seriously.'' (unknown)

``Ain't you though? I'm so glad of that. When one has really got a serious thing to say, one doesn't like to have fun poked at one.'' (unknown)

``And, besides, how could I laugh at marriages, seeing how happy I have been in that condition?--so--very--happy,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
and Mrs. Greenow put up her (Greenow) handkerchief to her (Greenow) eyes.

``So happy that you'll try it again some day; won't you?'' (unknown)

``Never, Mr. Cheesacre; never. Is that the way you talk of serious things without joking? Anything like love--love of that sort--is over for me. It lies buried under the sod with my poor dear departed saint.'' (unknown)

``But, Mrs. Greenow,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
--and Cheesacre, as he (Cheesacre) prepared to argue the question with her (Greenow), got nearer to her (Greenow) in the corner behind the table,--
``But, Mrs. Greenow, care killed a cat, you know.'' (her)

``And sometimes I think that care will kill me.'' (unknown)

``No, by George; not if I can prevent it.'' (unknown)

``You're very kind, Mr. Cheesacre; but there's no preventing such care as mine.'' (unknown)

``Isn't there though? I'll tell you what, Mrs. Greenow; I'm in earnest, I am indeed. If you'll inquire, you'll find there isn't a fellow in Norfolk pays his (fellow) way better than I do, or is better able to do it. I don't pay a sixpence of rent, and I sit upon seven hundred acres of as good land as there is in the county. There's not an acre that won't do me a bullock and a half. Just put that and that together, and see what it comes to. And, mind you, some of these fellows that farm their own land are worse off than if they'd rent to pay. They've borrowed so much to carry on with, that the interest is more than rent. I don't owe a sixpence to ere a man or ere a company in the world. I can walk into every bank in Norwich without seeing my master. There ain't any of my paper flying about, Mrs. Greenow. I'm Samuel Cheesacre of Oileymead, and it's all my own.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
Mr. Cheesacre, as he (Cheesacre) thus spoke of his (Cheesacre) good fortunes and firm standing in the world, became impetuous in the energy of the moment, and brought down his (Cheesacre) fist powerfully on the slight table before them. The whole fabric rattled, and the boat resounded, but the noise he (Cheesacre) had made seemed to assist him (Cheesacre).
``It's all my own, Mrs. Greenow, and the half of it shall be yours if you'll please to take it;'' (he)
then he (Cheesacre) stretched out his (Cheesacre) hand to her (Greenow), not as though he (Cheesacre) intended to grasp hers in a grasp of love, but as if he (Cheesacre) expected some hand-pledge from her (Greenow) as a token that she (Greenow) accepted the bargain.

``If you'd known Greenow, Mr. Cheesacre--'' (unknown)

``I've no doubt he (Cheesacre) was a very good sort of man.'' (unknown)

``If you'd known him (Cheesacre), you would not have addressed me in this way.'' (unknown)

``What difference would that make? My idea is that care killed a cat, as I said before. I never knew what was the good of being unhappy. If I find early mangels don't do on a bit of land, then I sow late turnips; and never cry after spilt milk. Greenow was the early mangels; I'll be the late turnips. Come then, say the word. There ain't a bedroom in my house,--not one of the front ones,--that isn't mahogany furnished!'' (unknown)

``What's furniture to me?'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, with her (Greenow) handkerchief to her (Greenow) eyes.

Just at this moment Maria's mother stepped in under the canvas. It was most inopportune. Mr. Cheesacre felt that he (Cheesacre) was progressing well, and was conscious that he (Cheesacre) had got safely over those fences in the race which his (Cheesacre) bashfulness would naturally make difficult to him (Cheesacre). He (Cheesacre) knew that he (Cheesacre) had done this under the influence of the champagne, and was aware that it might not be easy to procure again a combination of circumstances that would be so beneficial to him (Cheesacre). But now he (Cheesacre) was interrupted just as he (Cheesacre) was expecting success. He (Cheesacre) was interrupted, and felt himself to be looking like a guilty creature under the eye of the strange lady. He (Cheesacre) had not a word to say; but drawing himself suddenly a foot and half away from the widow's side, sat there confessing his (Cheesacre) guilt in his (Cheesacre) face.

Mrs. Greenow felt no guilt, and was afraid of no strange eyes.

``Mr. Cheesacre and I are talking about farming,'' (she)
she (Greenow) said.

``Oh; farming!'' (Maria)
answered Maria's mother.

``Mr. Cheesacre thinks that turnips are better than early mangels,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.

``Yes, I do,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre,

``I prefer the early mangels,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mrs. Greenow.
``I don't think nature ever intended those late crops. What do you say, Mrs. Walker?'' (unknown)

``I daresay Mr. Cheesacre understands what he (Cheesacre)'s about when he (Cheesacre)'s at home,'' (the lady)
said the lady.

``I know what a bit of land can do as well as any man in Norfolk,'' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman.

``It may be very well in Norfolk,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, rising from her (Greenow) seat;
``but the practice isn't thought much of in the other counties with which I am better acquainted.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

``I'd just come in to say that I thought we might be getting to the boats,'' (Mrs. Walker/Walker)
said Mrs. Walker.
``My Ophelia is so delicate.'' (Ophelia)
At this moment the delicate Ophelia was to be seen, under the influence of the music, taking a distant range upon the sands with Joe Fairstairs' arm round her (Ophelia) waist. The attitude was justified by the tune that was in progress, and there is no reason why a galop on the sands should have any special termination in distance, as it must have in a room. But, under such circumstances, Mrs. Walker's solicitude was not unreasonable.

The erratic steps of the distant dancers were recalled and preparations were made for the return journey. Others had strayed besides the delicate Ophelia and the idle Joe, and some little time was taken up in collecting the party. The boats had to be drawn down, and the boatmen fetched from their cans and tobacco-pipes.

``I hope they're sober,'' (Mrs. Walker/Walker)
said Mrs. Walker, with a look of great dismay.

``Sober as judges,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
said Bellfield, who had himself been looking after the remains of Mr. Cheesacre's hampers, while that gentleman had been so much better engaged in the tent.

``Because,'' (Mrs. Walker/Walker)
continued Mrs. Walker,
``I know that they play all manner of tricks when they're--in liquor. They'd think nothing of taking us out to sea, Mrs. Greenow.'' (Mrs. Walker/Walker)

``Oh, I do wish they would,'' (Ophelia)
said Ophelia.

``Ophelia, mind you come in the boat with me,'' (mother)
said her (Ophelia) mother, and she (Ophelia) looked very savage when she (Ophelia) gave the order. It was Mrs. Walker's intention that that boat should not carry Joe Fairstairs. But Joe and her (Walker) daughter together were too clever for her (Walker). When the boats went off she (Walker) found herself to be in that one over which Mr. Cheesacre presided, while the sinning Ophelia with her (Ophelia) good-for-nothing admirer were under the more mirthful protection of Captain Bellfield.

``Mamma will be so angry,'' (Ophelia)
said Ophelia,
``and it was all your fault. I did mean to go into the other boat. Don't, Mr. Fairstairs.'' (Ophelia)
Then they got settled down in their seats, to the satisfaction, let us hope, of them both.

Mr. Cheesacre had vainly endeavoured to arrange that Mrs. Greenow should return with him (Cheesacre). But not only was Captain Bellfield opposed to such a change in their positions, but so also was Mrs. Greenow.

``I think we'd better go back as we came,'' (she)
she (Greenow) said, giving her (Greenow) hand to the Captain.

``Oh, certainly,'' (Captain)
said Captain Bellfield.
``Why should there be any change? Cheesacre, old fellow, mind you look after Mrs. Walker. Come along, my hearty.'' (Captain)
It really almost appeared that Captain Bellfield was addressing Mrs. Greenow as
``his (Cheesacre) hearty,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
but it must be presumed that the term of genial endearment was intended for the whole boat's load. Mrs. Greenow took her (Greenow) place on the comfortable broad bench in the stern, and Bellfield seated himself beside her (Bellfield), with the tiller in his (Captain) hand.

``If you're going to steer, Captain Bellfield, I beg that you'll be careful.'' (unknown)

``Careful,--and with you on board!'' (the Captain)
said the Captain.
``Don't you know that I would sooner perish beneath the waves than that a drop of water should touch you roughly?'' (unknown)

``But you see, we might perish beneath the waves together.'' (unknown)

``Together! What a sweet word that is;--perish together! If it were not that there might be something better even than that, I would wish to perish in such company.'' (unknown)

``But I should not wish anything of the kind, Captain Bellfield, and therefore pray be careful.'' (unknown)

There was no perishing by water on that occasion. Mr. Cheesacre's boat reached the pier at Yarmouth first, and gave up its load without accident. Very shortly afterwards Captain Bellfield's crew reached the same place in the same state of preservation.

``There,'' (he)
said he (Captain), as he (Captain) handed out Mrs. Greenow.
``I have brought you to no harm, at any rate as yet.'' (unknown)

``And, as I hope, will not do so hereafter.'' (unknown)

``May the heavens forbid it, Mrs. Greenow! Whatever may be our lots hereafter,--yours I mean and mine,--I trust that yours may be free from all disaster. Oh, that I might venture to hope that, at some future day, the privilege might be mine of protecting you from all danger!'' (unknown)

``I can protect myself very well, I can assure you. Good night, Captain Bellfield. We won't take you and Mr. Cheesacre out of your way;--will we, Kate? We have had a most pleasant day.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

They were now upon the esplanade, and Mrs. Greenow's house was to the right, whereas the lodgings of both the gentlemen were to the left. Each of them fought hard for the privilege of accompanying the widow to her (widow) door; but Mrs. Greenow was self-willed, and upon this occasion would have neither of them.

``Mr. Joe Fairstairs must pass the house,'' (she)
said she (Greenow),
``and he (Mr.) will see us home. Mr. Cheesacre, good night. Indeed you shall not;--not a step.'' (she)
There was that in her (Greenow) voice which induced Mr. Cheesacre to obey her (Greenow), and which made Captain Bellfield aware that he (Captain) would only injure his (Captain) cause if he (Captain) endeavoured to make further progress in it on the present occasion.

``Well, Kate, what do you think of the day?'' (the aunt)
the aunt said when she (aunt) was alone with her (aunt) niece.

``I never think much about such days, aunt. It was all very well, but I fear I have not the temperament fitted for enjoying the fun. I envied Ophelia Walker because she (Ophelia) made herself thoroughly happy.'' (unknown)

``I do like to see girls enjoy themselves,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow,
``I do, indeed;--and young men too. It seems so natural; why shouldn't young people flirt?'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

``Or old people either for the matter of that?'' (unknown)

``Or old people either,--if they don't do any harm to anybody. I'll tell you what it is, Kate; people have become so very virtuous, that they're driven into all manner of abominable resources for amusement and occupation. If I had sons and daughters I should think a little flirting the very best thing for them as a safety valve. When people get to be old, there's a difficulty. They want to flirt with the young people and the young people don't want them. If the old people would be content to flirt together, I don't see why they should ever give it up;--till they're obliged to give up every thing, and go away.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

That was Mrs. Greenow's doctrine on the subject of flirtation.

CHAPTER X.

Nethercoats.

We will leave Mrs. Greenow with her (Greenow) niece and two sisters at Yarmouth, and returning by stages to London, will call upon Mr. Grey at his (Grey) place in Cambridgeshire as we pass by. I believe it is conceded by all the other counties, that Cambridgeshire possesses fewer rural beauties than any other county in England. It is very flat; it is not well timbered; the rivers are merely dikes; and in a very large portion of the county the farms and fields are divided simply by ditches--not by hedgerows. Such arrangements are, no doubt, well adapted for agricultural purposes, but are not conducive to rural beauty. Mr. Grey's residence was situated in a part of Cambridgeshire in which the above-named characteristics are very much marked. It was in the Isle of Ely, some few miles distant from the Cathedral town, on the side of a long straight road, which ran through the fields for miles without even a bush to cheer it. The name of his (Grey) place was Nethercoats, and here he (Grey) lived generally throughout the year, and here he (Grey) intended to live throughout his (Grey) life.

His (Grey) father had held a prebendal stall at Ely in times when prebendal stalls were worth more than they are at present, and having also been possessed of a living in the neighbourhood, had amassed a considerable sum of money. With this he (Grey) had during his (Grey) life purchased the property of Nethercoats, and had built on it the house in which his (Grey) son now lived. He (Grey) had married late in life, and had lost his (Grey) wife soon after the birth of an only child. The house had been built in his (Grey) own parish, and his (Grey) wife had lived there for a few months and had died there. But after that event the old clergyman had gone back to his (clergyman) residence in the Close at Ely, and there John Grey had had the home of his (Grey) youth. He (Grey) had been brought up under his (Grey) father's eye, having been sent to no public school. But he (Grey) had gone to Cambridge, had taken college honours, and had then, his (Grey) father dying exactly at this time, declined to accept a fellowship. His (Grey) father had left to him (Grey) an income of some fifteen hundred a year, and with this he (Grey) sat himself down, near to his (Grey) college friends, near also to the old cathedral which he (Grey) loved, in the house which his (Grey) father had built.

But though Nethercoats possessed no beauty of scenery, though the country around it was in truth as uninteresting as any country could be, it had many delights of its own. The house itself was as excellent a residence for a country gentleman of small means as taste and skill together could construct. I doubt whether prettier rooms were ever seen than the drawing-room, the library, and the dining-room at Nethercoats. They were all on the ground-floor, and all opened out on to the garden and lawn. The library, which was the largest of the three, was a handsome chamber, and so filled as to make it well known in the University as one of the best private collections in that part of England. But perhaps the gardens of Nethercoats constituted its greatest glory. They were spacious and excellently kept up, and had been originally laid out with that knowledge of gardening without which no garden, merely as a garden, can be effective. And such, of necessity, was the garden of Nethercoats. Fine single forest trees there were none there, nor was it possible that there should have been any such. Nor could there be a clear rippling stream with steep green banks, and broken rocks lying about its bed. Such beauties are beauties of landscape, and do not of their nature belong to a garden. But the shrubs of Nethercoats were of the rarest kind, and had been long enough in their present places to have reached the period of their beauty. Nothing had been spared that a garden could want. The fruit-trees were perfect in their kind, and the glass-houses were so good and so extensive that John Grey in his (Grey) prudence was some times tempted to think that he (Grey) had too much of them.

It must be understood that there were no grounds, according to the meaning usually given to that word, belonging to the house at Nethercoats. Between the garden and the public road there was a paddock belonging to the house, along the side of which, but divided from it by a hedge and shrubbery, ran the private carriageway up to the house. This swept through the small front flower-garden, dividing it equally; but the lawns and indeed the whole of that which made the beauty of the place lay on the back of the house, on which side opened the windows from the three sitting-rooms. Down on the public road there stood a lodge at which lived one of the gardeners. There was another field of some six or seven acres, to which there was a gate from the corner of the front paddock, and which went round two sides of the garden. This was Nethercoats, and the whole estate covered about twelve acres.

It was not a place for much bachelor enjoyment of that sort generally popular with bachelors; nevertheless Mr. Grey had been constant in his (Grey) residence there for the seven years which had now elapsed since he (Grey) had left his (Grey) college. His (Grey) easy access to Cambridge had probably done much to mitigate what might otherwise have been the too great tedium of his (Grey) life; and he (Grey) had, prompted thereto by early associations, found most of his (Grey) society in the Close of Ely Cathedral. But, with all the delight he (Grey) could derive from these two sources, there had still been many solitary hours in his (Grey) life, and he (Grey) had gradually learned to feel that he (Grey) of all men wanted a companion in his (Grey) home.

His (Grey) visits to London had generally been short and far between, occasioned probably by some need in the library, or by the necessity of some slight literary transaction with the editor or publisher of a periodical. In one of these visits he (editor) had met Alice Vavasor, and had remained in Town,--I will not say till Alice had promised to share his (editor) home in Cambridgeshire, but so long that he (editor) had resolved before he (editor) went that he (editor) would ask her (Alice) to do so. He (editor) had asked her (Alice), and we know that he (editor) had been successful. He (editor) had obtained her (Alice) promise, and from that moment all his (editor) life had been changed for him (editor). Hitherto at Nethercoats his (editor) little smoking-room, his (editor) books, and his (editor) plants had been everything to him (editor). Now he (editor) began to surround himself with an infinity of feminine belongings, and to promise himself an infinity of feminine blessings, wondering much that he (editor) should have been content to pass so long a portion of his (editor) life in the dull seclusion which he (editor) had endured. He (editor) was not by nature an impatient man; but now he (editor) became impatient, longing for the fruition of his (editor) new idea of happiness,--longing to have that as his (editor) own which he (editor) certainly loved beyond all else in the world, and which, perhaps, was all he (editor) had ever loved with the perfect love of equality. But though impatient, and fully aware of his (editor) own impatience, he (editor) acknowledged to himself that Alice could not be expected to share it. He (editor) could plan nothing now,--could have no pleasure in life that she (Alice) was not expected to share. But as yet it could not be so with her (Alice). She (Alice) had her (Alice) house in London, her (Alice) town society, and her (Alice) father. And, inasmuch as the change for her (Alice) would be much greater than it would be for him (father), it was natural that she (Alice) should require some small delay. He (father) had not pressed her (Alice). At least he (father) had not pressed her (Alice) with that eager pressure which a girl must resist with something of the opposition of a contest, if she (Alice) resist it at all. But in truth his (father) impatience was now waxing strong, and during the absence in Switzerland of which we have spoken, he (father) resolved that a marriage very late in the autumn,--that a marriage even in winter, would be better than a marriage postponed till the following year. It was not yet late in August when the party returned from their tour. Would not a further delay of two months suffice for his (father) bride?

Alice had written to him (father) occasionally from Switzerland, and her (Alice) first two letters had been very charming. They had referred almost exclusively to the tour, and had been made pleasant with some slightly coloured account of George Vavasor's idleness, and of Kate's obedience to her (Kate) brother's behests. Alice had never written much of love in her (Alice) love-letters, and Grey was well enough contented with her (Alice) style, though it was not impassioned. As for doubting her (Alice) love, it was not in the heart of the man to do so after it had been once assured to him (man) by her (Alice) word. He (man) could not so slightly respect himself or her (Alice) as to leave room for such a doubt in his (man) bosom. He (man) was a man who could never have suggested to himself that a woman loved him (man) till the fact was there before him (man); but who having ascertained, as he (man) might think, the fact, could never suggest to himself that her (woman) love would fail him (man). Her (woman) first two letters from Switzerland had been very pleasant; but after that there had seemed to have crept over her (woman) a melancholy which she (woman) unconsciously transferred to her (woman) words, and which he (man) could not but taste in them,--at first unconsciously, also, but soon with so plain a flavour that he (man) recognised it, and made it a matter of mental inquiry. During the three or four last days of the journey, while they were at Basle and on their way home, she (woman) had not written. But she (woman) did write on the day after her (woman) arrival, having then received from Mr. Grey a letter, in which he (Grey) told her (woman) how very much she (woman) would add to his (Grey) happiness if she (woman) would now agree that their marriage should not be postponed beyond the end of October. This letter she (woman) found in her (woman) room on her (woman) return, and this she (woman) answered at once. And she (woman) answered it in such words that Mr. Grey resolved that he (Grey) would at once go to her (woman) in London. I will give her (woman) letter at length, as I shall then be best able to proceed with my story quickly.

Queen Anne Street, -- August, 186--.

DEAREST JOHN,--

We reached home yesterday tired enough, as we came through from Paris without stopping. I may indeed say that we came through from Strasbourg, as we only slept in Paris. I don't like Strasbourg. A steeple, after all, is not everything, and putting the steeple aside, I don't think the style is good. But the hotel was uncomfortable, which goes for so much;--and then we were saturated with beauty of a better kind.
