I got your letter directly I came in last night, and I suppose I had better dash at it at once. I would so willingly delay doing so, saying nice little things the while, did I not know that this would be mere cowardice. Whatever happens I won't be a coward, and therefore I will tell you at once that I cannot let you hope that we should be married this year. Of course you will ask me why, as you have a right to do, and of course I am bound to answer. I do not know that I can give any answer with which you will not have a right to complain. If it be so, I can only ask your pardon for the injury I am doing you.

Marriage is a great change in life,--much greater to me than to you, who will remain in your old house, will keep your old pursuits, will still be your own master, and will change in nothing,--except in this, that you will have a companion who probably may not be all that you expect. But I must change everything. It will be to me as though I were passing through a grave to a new world. I shall see nothing that I have been accustomed to see, and must abandon all the ways of life that I have hitherto adopted. Of course I should have thought of this before I accepted you; and I did think of it. I made up my mind that, as I truly loved you, I would risk the change;--that I would risk it for your sake and for mine, hoping that I might add something to your happiness, and that I might secure my own. Dear John, do not suppose that I despair that it may be so; but, indeed, you must not hurry me. I must tune myself to the change that I have to make. What if I should wake some morning after six months living with you, and tell you that the quiet of your home was making me mad?

You must not ask me again till the winter shall have passed away. If in the meantime I shall find that I have been wrong, I will humbly confess that I have wronged you, and ask you to forgive me. And I will freely admit this. If the delay which I now purpose is so contrary to your own plans as to make your marriage, under such circumstances, not that which you had expected, I know that you are free to tell me so, and to say that our engagement shall be over. I am well aware that I can have no right to bind you to a marriage at one period which you had only contemplated as to take place at another period. I think I may promise that I will obey any wish you may express in anything,--except in that one thing which you urged in your last letter.

Kate is going down to Yarmouth with Mrs. Greenow, and I shall see no more of her (Greenow) probably till next year, as she (Greenow) will be due in Westmoreland after that. George left me at the door when he (George) brought me home, and declared that he (George) intended to vanish out of London. Whether in town or out, he (George) is never to be seen at this period of the year. Papa offers to go to Ramsgate for a fortnight, but he (Papa) looks so wretched when he (Papa) makes the offer, that I shall not have the heart to hold him (Papa) to it. Lady Macleod very much wants me to go to Cheltenham. I very much want not to go, simply because I can never agree with her (Macleod) about anything; but it will probably end in my going there for a week or two. Over and beyond that, I have no prospects before Christmas which are not purely domestic. There is a project that we shall all eat our Christmas dinner at Vavasor Hall,--of course not including George,--but this project is quite in the clouds, and, as far as I am concerned, will remain there.

Dear John, let me hear that this letter does not make you unhappy.

Most affectionately yours,

ALICE VAVASOR.

At Nethercoats, the post was brought in at breakfast-time, and Mr. Grey was sitting with his (Grey) tea and eggs before him (Grey), when he (Grey) read Alice's letter. He (Grey) read it twice before he (Grey) began to think what he (Grey) would do in regard to it, and then referred to one or two others which he (Grey) had received from Switzerland,--reading them also very carefully. After that, he (Grey) took up the slouch hat which he (Grey) had been wearing in the garden before he (Grey) was called to his (Grey) breakfast, and, with the letters in his (Grey) hand, sauntered down among the shrubs and lawns.

He (Grey) knew, he (Grey) thought he (Grey) knew, that there was more in Alice's mind than a mere wish for delay. There was more in it than that hesitation to take at once a step which she (Alice) really desired to take, if not now, then after some short interval. He (Grey) felt that she (Alice) was unhappy, and unhappy because she (Alice) distrusted the results of her (Alice) marriage; but it never for a moment occurred to him (Grey) that, therefore, the engagement between them should be broken. In the first place he (Grey) loved her (Alice) too well to allow of his (Grey) admitting such an idea without terrible sorrow to himself. He (Grey) was a constant, firm man, somewhat reserved, and unwilling to make new acquaintances, and, therefore, specially unwilling to break away from those which he (Grey) had made. Undoubtedly, had he (Grey) satisfied himself that Alice's happiness demanded such a sacrifice of himself, he (Grey) would have made it, and made it without a word of complaint. The blow would not have prostrated him (Grey), but the bruise would have remained on his (Grey) heart, indelible, not to be healed but by death. He (Grey) would have submitted, and no man would have seen that he (Grey) had been injured. But it did not once occur to him (Grey) that such a proceeding on his (Grey) part would be beneficial to Alice. Without being aware of it, he (Grey) reckoned himself to be the nobler creature of the two, and now thought of her (Alice) as of one wounded, and wanting a cure. Some weakness had fallen on her (Alice), and strength must be given to her (Alice) from another. He (Grey) did not in the least doubt her (Alice) love, but he (Grey) knew that she (Alice) had been associated, for a few weeks past, with two persons whose daily conversation would be prone to weaken the tone of her (Alice) mind. He (Grey) no more thought of giving her (Alice) up than a man thinks of having his (man) leg cut off because he (man) has sprained his (man) sinews. He (man) would go up to town and see her (Alice), and would not even yet abandon all hope that she (Alice) might be found sitting at his (man) board when Christmas should come. By that day's post he (man) wrote a short note to her (Alice).

``Dearest Alice,'' (he)
he (man) said, ``I have resolved to go to London at once. I will be with you in the evening at eight, the day after to-morrow.

``Yours, J. G.'' (unknown)

There was no more in the letter than that.

``And now,'' (she)
she (Alice) said, when she (Alice) received it,
``I must dare to tell him (J.) the whole truth.'' (she)

CHAPTER XI.

John Grey Goes to London.

And what was the whole truth? Alice Vavasor, when she (Vavasor) declared to herself that she (Vavasor) must tell her (Vavasor) lover the whole truth, was expressing to herself her (Vavasor) intention of putting an end to her (Vavasor) engagement with Mr. Grey. She (Vavasor) was acknowledging that that which had to be told was not compatible with the love and perfect faith which she (Vavasor) owed to the man who was her (Vavasor) affianced husband. And yet, why should it be so? She (Vavasor) did not intend to tell him (husband) that she (Vavasor) had been false in her (Vavasor) love to him (husband). It was not that her (Vavasor) heart had again veered itself round and given itself to that wild cousin of hers. Though she (Vavasor) might feel herself constrained to part from John Grey, George Vavasor could never be her (Vavasor) husband. Of that she (Vavasor) assured herself fifty times during the two days' grace which had been allowed her (Vavasor). Nay, she (Vavasor) went farther than that with herself, and pronounced a verdict against any marriage as possible to her (Vavasor) if she (Vavasor) now decided against this marriage which had for some months past been regarded as fixed by herself and all her (Vavasor) friends.

People often say that marriage is an important thing, and should be much thought of in advance, and marrying people are cautioned that there are many who marry in haste and repent at leisure. I am not sure, however, that marriage may not be pondered over too much; nor do I feel certain that the leisurely repentance does not as often follow the leisurely marriages as it does the rapid ones. That some repent no one can doubt; but I am inclined to believe that most men and women take their lots as they find them, marrying as the birds do by force of nature, and going on with their mates with a general, though not perhaps an undisturbed satisfaction, feeling inwardly assured that Providence, if it have not done the very best for them, has done for them as well as they could do for themselves with all the thought in the world. I do not know that a woman can assure to herself, by her (woman) own prudence and taste, a good husband any more than she (woman) can add two cubits to her (woman) stature; but husbands have been made to be decently good,--and wives too, for the most part, in our country,--so that the thing does not require quite so much thinking as some people say.

That Alice Vavasor had thought too much about it, I feel quite sure. She (Vavasor) had gone on thinking of it till she (Vavasor) had filled herself with a cloud of doubts which even the sunshine of love was unable to drive from her (Vavasor) heavens. That a girl should really love the man she (Vavasor) intends to marry,--that, at any rate, may be admitted. But love generally comes easily enough. With all her (Vavasor) doubts Alice never doubted her (Alice) love for Mr. Grey. Nor did she (Alice) doubt his (Grey) character, nor his (Grey) temper, nor his (Grey) means. But she (Alice) had gone on thinking of the matter till her (Alice) mind had become filled with some undefined idea of the importance to her (Alice) of her (Alice) own life. What should a woman do with her (woman) life? There had arisen round her (woman) a flock of learned ladies asking that question, to whom it seems that the proper answer has never yet occurred. Fall in love, marry the man, have two children, and live happy ever afterwards. I maintain that answer has as much wisdom in it as any other that can be given;--or perhaps more. The advice contained in it cannot, perhaps, always be followed to the letter; but neither can the advice of the other kind, which is given by the flock of learned ladies who ask the question.

A woman's life is important to her (woman),--as is that of a man to him (man),--not chiefly in regard to that which she (woman) shall do with it. The chief thing for her (woman) to look to is the manner in which that something shall be done. It is of moment to a young man when entering life to decide whether he (man) shall make hats or shoes; but not of half the moment that will be that other decision, whether he (man) shall make good shoes or bad. And so with a woman;--if she (woman) shall have recognised the necessity of truth and honesty for the purposes of her (woman) life, I do not know that she (woman) need ask herself many questions as to what she (woman) will do with it.

Alice Vavasor was ever asking herself that question, and had by degrees filled herself with a vague idea that there was a something to be done; a something over and beyond, or perhaps altogether beside that marrying and having two children;--if she (Vavasor) only knew what it was. She (Vavasor) had filled herself, or had been filled by her (Vavasor) cousins, with an undefined ambition that made her (Vavasor) restless without giving her (Vavasor) any real food for her (Vavasor) mind. When she (Vavasor) told herself that she (Vavasor) would have no scope for action in that life in Cambridgeshire which Mr. Grey was preparing for her (Vavasor), she (Vavasor) did not herself know what she (Vavasor) meant by action. Had any one accused her (Vavasor) of being afraid to separate herself from London society, she (Vavasor) would have declared that she (Vavasor) went very little into society and disliked that little. Had it been whispered to her (Vavasor) that she (Vavasor) loved the neighbourhood of the shops, she (Vavasor) would have scorned the whisperer. Had it been suggested that the continued rattle of the big city was necessary to her (Vavasor) happiness, she (Vavasor) would have declared that she (Vavasor) and her (Vavasor) father had picked out for their residence the quietest street in London because she (Vavasor) could not bear noise;--and yet she (Vavasor) told herself that she (Vavasor) feared to be taken into the desolate calmness of Cambridgeshire.

When she (Vavasor) did contrive to find any answer to that question as to what she (Vavasor) should do with her (Vavasor) life,--or rather what she (Vavasor) would wish to do with it if she (Vavasor) were a free agent, it was generally of a political nature. She (Vavasor) was not so far advanced as to think that women should be lawyers and doctors, or to wish that she (Vavasor) might have the privilege of the franchise for herself; but she (Vavasor) had undoubtedly a hankering after some second-hand political manoeuvering. She (Vavasor) would have liked, I think, to have been the wife of the leader of a Radical opposition, in the time when such men were put into prison, and to have kept up for him (Radical) his (Radical) seditious correspondence while he (Radical) lay in the Tower. She (Vavasor) would have carried the answers to him (Radical) inside her (Vavasor) stays,--and have made long journeys down into northern parts without any money, if the cause required it. She (Vavasor) would have liked to have around her (Vavasor) ardent spirits, male or female, who would have talked of

``the cause,'' (spirits)
and have kept alive in her (Vavasor) some flame of political fire. As it was, she (Vavasor) had no cause. Her (Vavasor) father's political views were very mild. Lady Macleod's were deadly conservative. Kate Vavasor was an aspiring Radical just now, because her (Vavasor) brother was in the same line; but during the year of the love-passages between George and Alice, George Vavasor's politics had been as conservative as you please. He (Vavasor) did not become a Radical till he (Radical) had quarrelled with his (Radical) grandfather. Now, indeed, he (Radical) was possessed of very advanced views,--views with which Alice felt that she (Alice) could sympathize. But what would be the use of sympathizing down in Cambridgeshire? John Grey had, so to speak, no politics. He (Grey) had decided views as to the treatment which the Roman Senate received from Augustus, and had even discussed with Alice the conduct of the Girondists at the time of Robespierre's triumph; but for Manchester and its cares he (Roman) had no apparent solicitude, and had declared to Alice that he (Roman) would not accept a seat in the British House of Commons if it were offered to him (Roman) free of expense. What political enthusiasm could she (Alice) indulge with such a companion down in Cambridgeshire?

She (Alice) thought too much of all this,--and was, if I may say, over-prudent in calculating the chances of her (Alice) happiness and of his (companion). For, to give her (Alice) credit for what was her (Alice) due, she (Alice) was quite as anxious on the latter head as on the former.

``I don't care for the Roman Senate,'' (she)
she (Alice) would say to herself.
``I don't care much for the Girondists. How am I to talk to him (Roman) day after day, night after night, when we shall be alone together?'' (cousin)

No doubt her (Alice) tour in Switzerland with her (Alice) cousin had had some effect in making such thoughts stronger now than they had ever been. She (Alice) had not again learned to love her (Alice) cousin. She (Alice) was as firmly sure as ever that she (Alice) could never love him (cousin) more. He (cousin) had insulted her (Alice) love; and though she (Alice) had forgiven him (cousin) and again enrolled him (cousin) among her (Alice) dearest friends, she (Alice) could never again feel for him (cousin) that passion which a woman means when she (woman) acknowledges that she (woman) is in love. That, as regarded her (woman) and George Vavasor, was over. But, nevertheless, there had been a something of romance during those days in Switzerland which she (woman) feared she (woman) would regret when she (woman) found herself settled at Nethercoats. She (woman) envied Kate. Kate could, as his (Vavasor) sister, attach herself on to George's political career, and obtain from it all that excitement of life which Alice desired for herself. Alice could not love her (Alice) cousin and marry him (cousin); but she (Alice) felt that if she (Alice) could do so without impropriety she (Alice) would like to stick close to him (cousin) like another sister, to spend her (Alice) money in aiding his (cousin) career in Parliament as Kate would do, and trust herself and her (Kate) career into the boat which he (cousin) was to command. She (Kate) did not love her (Kate) cousin; but she (Kate) still believed in him (cousin),--with a faith which he (cousin) certainly did not deserve.

As the two days passed over her (Kate), her (Kate) mind grew more and more fixed as to its purpose. She (Kate) would tell Mr. Grey that she (Kate) was not fit to be his (Grey) wife--and she (Kate) would beg him (Grey) to pardon her (Kate) and to leave her (Kate). It never occurred to her (Kate) that perhaps he (Grey) might refuse to let her (Kate) go. She (Kate) felt quite sure that she (Kate) would be free as soon as she (Kate) had spoken the word which she (Kate) intended to speak. If she (Kate) could speak it with decision she (Kate) would be free, and to attain that decision she (Kate) would school herself with her (Kate) utmost strength. At one moment she (Kate) thought of telling all to her (Kate) father and of begging him (father) to break the matter to Mr. Grey; but she (Kate) knew that her (Kate) father would not understand her (Kate), and that he (father) would be very hostile to her (Kate),--saying hard, uncomfortable words, which would probably be spared if the thing were done before he (father) was informed. Nor would she (Kate) write to Kate, whose letters to her (Kate) at this time were full of wit at the expense of Mrs. Greenow. She (Greenow) would tell Kate as soon as the thing was done, but not before. That Kate would sympathize with her (Kate), she (Kate) was quite certain.

So the two days passed by and the time came at which John Grey was to be there. As the minute hand on the drawing-room clock came round to the full hour, she (Kate) felt that her (Kate) heart was beating with a violence which she (Kate) could not repress. The thing seemed to her (Kate) to assume bigger dimensions than it had hitherto done. She (Kate) began to be aware that she (Kate) was about to be guilty of a great iniquity, when it was too late for her (Kate) to change her (Kate) mind. She (Kate) could not bring herself to resolve that she (Kate) would, on the moment, change her (Kate) mind. She (Kate) believed that she (Kate) could never pardon herself such weakness. But yet she (Kate) felt herself to be aware that her (Kate) purpose was wicked. When the knock at the door was at last heard she (Kate) trembled and feared that she (Kate) would almost be unable to speak to him (Kate). Might it be possible that there should yet be a reprieve for her (Kate)? No; it was his (Kate) step on the stairs, and there he (Kate) was in the room with her (Kate).

``My dearest,'' (he)
he (Kate) said, coming to her (Kate). His (Kate) smile was sweet and loving as it ever was, and his (Kate) voice had its usual manly, genial, loving tone. As he (Kate) walked across the room Alice felt that he (Kate) was a man of whom a wife might be very proud. He (Kate) was tall and very handsome, with brown hair, with bright blue eyes, and a mouth like a god. It was the beauty of his (god) mouth,--beauty which comprised firmness within itself, that made Alice afraid of him (god). He (god) was still dressed in his (god) morning clothes; but he (god) was a man who always seemed to be well dressed.
``My dearest,'' (he)
he (god) said, advancing across the room, and before she (Alice) knew how to stop herself or him (god), he (god) had taken her (Alice) in his (god) arms and kissed her (Alice).

He (god) did not immediately begin about the letter, but placed her (Alice) upon the sofa, seating himself by her (Alice) side, and looked into her (Alice) face with loving eyes,--not as though to scrutinize what might be amiss there, but as though determined to enjoy to the full his (god) privilege as a lover. There was no reproach at any rate in his (god) countenance;--none as yet; nor did it seem that he (god) thought that he (god) had any cause for fear. They sat in this way for a moment or two in silence, and during those moments Alice was summoning up her (Alice) courage to speak. The palpitation at her (Alice) heart was already gone, and she (Alice) was determined that she (Alice) would speak.

``Though I am very glad to see you,'' (she)
she (Alice) said, at last,
``I am sorry that my letter should have given you the trouble of this journey.'' (she)

``Trouble!'' (he)
he (god) said.
``Nay, you ought to know that it is no trouble. I have not enough to do down at Nethercoats to make the running up to you at any time an unpleasant excitement. So your Swiss journey went off pleasantly?'' (unknown)

``Yes; it went off very pleasantly.'' (she)
This she (Alice) said in that tone of voice which clearly implies that the speaker is not thinking of the words spoken.

``And Kate has now left you?'' (unknown)

``Yes; she (Kate) is with her (Kate) aunt, at the seaside.'' (unknown)

``So I understand;--and your cousin George?'' (unknown)

``I never know much of George's movements. He (George) may be in Town, but I have not seen him (George) since I came back.'' (unknown)

``Ah! that is the way with friends living in London. Unless circumstances bring them together, they are in fact further apart than if they lived fifty miles asunder in the country. And he (George) managed to get through all the trouble without losing your luggage for you very often?'' (unknown)

``If you were to say that we did not lose his (George), that would be nearer the mark. But, John, you have come up to London in this sudden way to speak to me about my letter to you. Is it not so?'' (unknown)

``Certainly it is so. Certainly I have.'' (unknown)

``I have thought much, since, of what I then wrote, very much,--very much, indeed; and I have learned to feel sure that we had better--'' (unknown)

``Stop, Alice; stop a moment, love. Do not speak hurriedly. Shall I tell you what I learned from your letter?'' (unknown)

``Yes; tell me, if you think it better that you should do so.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps it may be better. I learned, love, that something had been said or done during your journey,--or perhaps only something thought, that had made you melancholy, and filled your mind for a while with those unsubstantial and indefinable regrets for the past which we are all apt to feel at certain moments of our life. There are few of us who do not encounter, now and again, some of that irrational spirit of sadness which, when over-indulged, drives men to madness and self-destruction. I used to know well what it was before I knew you; but since I have had the hope of having you in my house, I have banished it utterly. In that I think I have been stronger than you. Do not speak under the influence of that spirit till you have thought whether you, too, cannot banish it.'' (unknown)

``I have tried, and it will not be banished.'' (unknown)

``Try again, Alice. It is a damned spirit, and belongs neither to heaven nor to earth. Do not say to me the words that you were about to say till you have wrestled with it manfully. I think I know what those words were to be. If you love me, those words should not be spoken. If you do not--'' (unknown)

``If I do not love you, I love no one upon earth.'' (unknown)

``I believe it. I believe it as I believe in my own love for you. I trust your love implicitly, Alice. I know that you love me. I think I can read your mind. Tell me that I may return to Cambridgeshire, and again plead my cause for an early marriage from thence. I will not take such speech from you to mean more than it says!'' (She)

She (Alice) sat quiet, looking at him (speaker)--looking full into his (speaker) face. She (Alice) had in nowise changed her (Alice) mind, but after such words from him (speaker), she (Alice) did not know how to declare to him (speaker) her (Alice) resolution. There was something in his (speaker) manner that awed her (Alice),--and something also that softened her (Alice).

``Tell me,'' (he)
said he (speaker),
``that I may see you again to-morrow morning in our usual quiet, loving way, and that I may return home to-morrow evening. Pronounce a yea to that speech from me, and I will ask for nothing further.'' (he)

``No; I cannot do so,'' (she)
she (Alice) said. And the tone of her (Alice) voice, as she (Alice) spoke, was different to any tone that he (speaker) had heard before from her (Alice) mouth.

``Is that melancholy fiend too strong for you?'' (He)
He (speaker) smiled as he (speaker) said this, and as he (speaker) smiled, he (speaker) took her (Alice) hand. She (Alice) did not attempt to withdraw it, but sat by him (speaker) in a strange calmness, looking straight before her (Alice) into the middle of the room.
``You have not struggled with it. You know, as I do, that it is a bad fiend and a wicked one,--a fiend that is prompting you to the worst cruelty in the world. Alice! Alice! Alice! Try to think of all this as though some other person were concerned. If it were your friend, what advice would you give her (Alice)?'' (unknown)

-LSB-Illustration:

``If it were your friend, what advice would you give her (Alice)?'' (unknown)
-RSB-

``I would bid her (Alice) tell the man who had loved her (Alice),--that is, if he (man) were noble, good, and great,--that she (Alice) found herself to be unfit to be his (man) wife; and then I would bid her (Alice) ask his (man) pardon humbly on her (Alice) knees.'' (she)
As she (Alice) said this, she (Alice) sank before him (speaker) on to the floor, and looked up into his (speaker) face with an expression of sad contrition which almost drew him (speaker) from his (speaker) purposed firmness.

He (speaker) had purposed to be firm,--to yield to her (Alice) in nothing, resolving to treat all that she (Alice) might say as the hallucination of a sickened imagination,--as the effect of absolute want of health, for which some change in her (Alice) mode of life would be the best cure. She (Alice) might bid him (speaker) begone in what language she (Alice) would. He (speaker) knew well that such was her (Alice) intention. But he (speaker) would not allow a word coming from her (Alice) in such a way to disturb arrangements made for the happiness of their joint lives. As a loving husband would treat a wife, who, in some exceptionable moment of a melancholy malady, should declare herself unable to remain longer in her (wife) home, so would he (husband) treat her (wife). As for accepting what she (wife) might say as his (husband) dismissal, he (husband) would as soon think of taking the fruit-trees from the southern wall because the sun sometimes shines from the north. He (husband) could not treat either his (husband) interests or hers so lightly as that.

``But what if he (man) granted no such pardon, Alice? I will grant none such. You are my wife, my own, my dearest, my chosen one. You are all that I value in the world, my treasure and my comfort, my earthly happiness and my gleam of something better that is to come hereafter. Do you think that I shall let you go from me in that way? No, love. If you are ill I will wait till your illness is gone by; and, if you will let me, I will be your nurse.'' (unknown)

``I am not ill.'' (unknown)

``Not ill with any defined sickness. You do not shake with ague, nor does your head rack you with aching; but yet you may be ill. Think of what has passed between us. Must you not be ill when you seek to put an end to all that without any cause assigned.'' (unknown)

``You will not hear my reasons,'' (she)
--she (wife) was still kneeling before him (husband) and looking up into his (husband) face.

``I will hear them if you will tell me that they refer to any supposed faults of my own.'' (unknown)

``No, no, no!'' (unknown)

``Then I will not hear them. It is for me to find out your faults, and when I have found out any that require complaint, I will come and make it. Dear Alice, I wish you knew how I long for you.'' (he)
Then he (husband) put his (husband) hand upon her (wife) hair, as though he (husband) would caress her (wife).

But this she (wife) would not suffer, so she (wife) rose slowly, and stood with her (wife) hand upon the table in the middle of the room.

``Mr. Grey--'' (she)
she (wife) said.

``If you will call me so, I shall think it only a part of your malady.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Grey,'' (she)
she (wife) continued,
``I can only hope that you will take me at my word.'' (she)

``Oh, but I will not; certainly I will not, if that would be adverse to my own interests.'' (unknown)

``I am thinking of your interests; I am, indeed;--at any rate as much as of my own. I feel quite sure that I should not make you happy as your wife,--quite sure; and feeling that, I think that I am right, even after all that has passed, to ask your forgiveness, and to beg that our engagement may be over.'' (unknown)

``No, Alice, no; never with my consent. I cannot tell you with what contentment I would marry you to-morrow,--to-morrow, or next month, or the month after. But if it cannot be so, then I will wait. Nothing but your marriage with some one else would convince me.'' (unknown)

``I cannot convince you in that way,'' (she)
she (wife) said, smiling.

``You will convince me in no other. You have not spoken to your father of this as yet?'' (unknown)

``Not as yet.'' (unknown)

``Do not do so, at any rate for the present. You will own that it might be possible that you would have to unsay what you had said.'' (unknown)

``No; it is not possible.'' (unknown)

``Give yourself and me the chance. It can do no harm. And, Alice, I ask you now for no reasons. I will not ask your reasons, or even listen to them, because I do not believe that they will long have effect even on yourself. Do you still think of going to Cheltenham?'' (unknown)

``I have decided nothing as yet.'' (unknown)

``If I were you, I would go. I think a change of air would be good for you.'' (unknown)

``Yes; you treat me as though I were partly silly, and partly insane; but it is not so. The change you speak of should be in my nature, and in yours.'' (He)

He (husband) shook his (husband) head and still smiled. There was something in the imperturbed security of his (husband) manner which almost made her (wife) angry with him (husband). It seemed as though he (husband) assumed so great a superiority that he (husband) felt himself able to treat any resolve of hers as the petulance of a child. And though he (husband) spoke in strong language of his (husband) love, and of his (husband) longing that she (wife) should come to him (husband), yet he (husband) was so well able to command his (husband) feelings, that he (husband) showed no sign of grief at the communication she (wife) had made to him (husband). She (wife) did not doubt his (husband) love, but she (wife) believed him (husband) to be so much the master of his (husband) love,--as he (husband) was the master of everything else, that her (wife) separation from him (husband) would cause him (husband) no uncontrollable grief. In that she (wife) utterly failed to understand his (husband) character. Had she (wife) known him (husband) better, she (wife) might have been sure that such a separation now would with him (husband) have carried its mark to the grave. Should he (husband) submit to her (wife) decision, he (husband) would go home and settle himself to his (husband) books the next day; but on no following day would he (husband) be again capable of walking forth among his (husband) flowers with an easy heart. He (husband) was a strong, constant man, perhaps over-conscious of his (husband) own strength; but then his (husband) strength was great.

``He (you) is perfect!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice had said to herself often.
``Oh that he (you) were less perfect!'' (He)

He (husband) did not stay with her (Alice) long after the last word that has been recorded.

``Perhaps,'' (he)
he (husband) said, as for a moment he (husband) held her (Alice) hand at parting,
``I had better not come to-morrow.'' (he)

``No, no; it is better not.'' (unknown)

``I advise you not to tell your father of this, and doubtless you will think of it before you do so. But if you do tell him (father), let me know that you have done so.'' (unknown)

``Why that?'' (unknown)

``Because in such case I also must see him (father). God bless you, Alice! God bless you, dearest, dearest Alice!'' (he)
Then he (husband) went, and she (Alice) sat there on the sofa without moving, till she (Alice) heard her (Alice) father's feet as he (father) came up the stairs.

``What, Alice, are you not in bed yet?'' (unknown)

``Not yet, papa.'' (unknown)

``And so John Grey has been here. He (Grey) has left his (Grey) stick in the hall. I should know it among a thousand.'' (unknown)

``Yes; he (Grey) has been here.'' (unknown)

``Is anything the matter, Alice?'' (unknown)

``No, papa, nothing is the matter.'' (unknown)

``He (papa) has not made himself disagreeable, has he (papa)?'' (unknown)

``Not in the least. He (papa) never does anything wrong. He (papa) may defy man or woman to find fault with him (papa).'' (unknown)

``So that is it, is it? He (papa) is just a shade too good. Well, I have always thought that myself. But it's a fault on the right side.'' (unknown)

``It's no fault, Papa. If there be any fault, it is not with him (Papa). But I am yawning and tired, and I will go to bed.'' (unknown)

``Is he (Papa) to be here to-morrow?'' (unknown)

``No; he (Papa) returns to Nethercoats early. Good night, papa.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

Mr. Vavasor, as he (Vavasor) went up to his (Vavasor) bedroom, felt sure that there had been something wrong between his (Vavasor) daughter and her (daughter) lover.

``I don't know how she (Papa)'ll ever put up with him (papa),'' (he)
he (Vavasor) said to himself,
``he (papa) is so terribly conceited. I shall never forget how he (papa) went on about Charles Kemble, and what a fool he (papa) made of himself.'' (he)

Alice, before she (Alice) went to bed, sat down and wrote a letter to her (Alice) cousin Kate.

CHAPTER XII.

Mr. George Vavasor at Home.

It cannot perhaps fairly be said that George Vavasor was an unhospitable man, seeing that it was his (Vavasor) custom to entertain his (Vavasor) friends occasionally at Greenwich, Richmond, or such places; and he (Vavasor) would now and again have a friend to dine with him (Vavasor) at his (Vavasor) club. But he (Vavasor) never gave breakfasts, dinners, or suppers under his (Vavasor) own roof. During a short period of his (Vavasor) wine-selling career, at which time he (Vavasor) had occupied handsome rooms over his (Vavasor) place of business in New Burlington Street, he (Vavasor) had presided at certain feasts given to customers or expectant customers by the firm; but he (Vavasor) had not found this employment to his (Vavasor) taste, and had soon relinquished it to one of the other partners. Since that he (Vavasor) had lived in lodgings in Cecil Street,--down at the bottom of that retired nook, near to the river and away from the Strand. Here he (Vavasor) had simply two rooms on the first floor, and hither his (Vavasor) friends came to him (Vavasor) very rarely. They came very rarely on any account. A stray man might now and then pass an hour with him (man) here; but on such occasions the chances were that the visit had some reference, near or distant, to affairs of business. Eating or drinking there was never any to be found here by the most intimate of his (man) allies. His (man) lodgings were his (man) private retreat, and they were so private that but few of his (man) friends knew where he (man) lived.

And had it been possible he (man) would have wished that no one should have known his (man) whereabouts. I am not aware that he (man) had any special reason for this peculiarity, or that there was anything about his (man) mode of life that required hiding; but he (man) was a man who had always lived as though secrecy in certain matters might at any time become useful to him (man). He (man) had a mode of dressing himself when he (man) went out at night that made it almost impossible that any one should recognise him (man). The people at his (man) lodgings did not even know that he (man) had relatives, and his (man) nearest relatives hardly knew that he (man) had lodgings. Even Kate had never been at the rooms in Cecil Street, and addressed all her (Kate) letters to his (Cecil) place of business or his (Cecil) club. He (Cecil) was a man who would bear no inquiry into himself. If he (Cecil) had been out of view for a month, and his (Cecil) friends asked him (Cecil) where he (Cecil) had been, he (Cecil) always answered the question falsely, or left it unanswered. There are many men of whom everybody knows all about all their belongings;--as to whom everybody knows where they live, whither they go, what is their means, and how they spend it. But there are others of whom no man knows anything, and George Vavasor was such a one. For myself I like the open babbler the best. Babbling may be a weakness, but to my thinking mystery is a vice.

Vavasor also maintained another little establishment, down in Oxfordshire; but the two establishments did not even know of each other's existence. There was a third, too, very closely hidden from the world's eye, which shall be nameless; but of the establishment in Oxfordshire he (Vavasor) did sometimes speak, in very humble words, among his (Vavasor) friends. When he (Vavasor) found himself among hunting men, he (Vavasor) would speak of his (Vavasor) two nags at Roebury, saying that he (Vavasor) had never yet been able to mount a regular hunting stable, and that he (Vavasor) supposed he (Vavasor) never would; but that there were at Roebury two indifferent beasts of his (Vavasor) if any one chose to buy them. And men very often did buy Vavasor's horses. When he (Vavasor) was on them they always went well and sold themselves readily. And though he (Vavasor) thus spoke of two, and perhaps did not keep more during the summer, he (Vavasor) always seemed to have horses enough when he (Vavasor) was down in the country. No one even knew George Vavasor not to hunt because he (Vavasor) was short of stuff. And here, at Roebury, he (Vavasor) kept a trusty servant, an ancient groom with two little bushy grey eyes which looked as though they could see through a stable door. Many were the long whisperings which George and Bat Smithers carried on at the stable door, in the very back depth of the yard attached to the hunting inn at Roebury. Bat regarded his (George) master as a man wholly devoted to horses, but often wondered why he (George) was not more regular in his (George) sojournings in Oxfordshire. Of any other portion of his (George) master's life Bat knew nothing. Bat could give the address of his (George) master's club in London, but he (George) could give no other address.

But though Vavasor's private lodgings were so very private, he (George) had, nevertheless, taken some trouble in adorning them. The furniture in the sitting-room was very neat, and the book-shelves were filled with volumes that shone with gilding on their backs. The inkstand, the paper-weight, the envelope case on his (George) writing-table were all handsome. He (George) had a single good portrait of a woman's head hanging on one of his (George) walls. He (George) had a special place adapted for his (George) pistols, others for his (George) foils, and again another for his (George) whips. The room was as pretty a bachelor's room as you would wish to enter, but you might see, by the position of the single easy-chair that was brought forward, that it was seldom appropriated to the comfort of more than one person. Here he (George) sat lounging over his (George) breakfast, late on a Sunday morning in September, when all the world was out of town. He (George) was reading a letter which had just been brought down to him (George) from his (George) club. Though the writer of it was his (George) sister Kate, she (Kate) had not been privileged to address it to his (George) private lodgings. He (George) read it very quickly, running rapidly over its contents, and then threw it aside from him (George) as though it were of no moment, keeping, however, an enclosure in his (George) hand. And yet the letter was of much moment, and made him (George) think deeply.

``If I did it at all,'' (he)
said he (George),
``it would be more with the object of cutting him (papa) out than with any other.'' (he)

The reader will hardly require to be told that the him (reader) in question was John Grey, and that Kate's letter was one instigating her (Kate) brother to renew his (brother) love affair with Alice. And Vavasor was in truth well inclined to renew it, and would have begun the renewing it at once, had he (brother) not doubted his (brother) power with his (brother) cousin. Indeed it has been seen that he (brother) had already attempted some commencement of such renewal at Basle. He (brother) had told Kate more than once that Alice's fortune was not much, and that her (Alice) beauty was past its prime; and he (brother) would no doubt repeat the same objections to his (brother) sister with some pretence of disinclination. It was not his (brother) custom to show his (brother) hand to the players at any game that he (brother) played. But he (brother) was, in truth, very anxious to obtain from Alice a second promise of her (Alice) hand. How soon after that he (brother) might marry her (Alice), would be another question.

Perhaps it was not Alice's beauty that he (brother) coveted, nor yet her (Alice) money exclusively. Nevertheless he (brother) thought her (Alice) very beautiful, and was fully aware that her (Alice) money would be of great service to him (brother). But I believe that he (brother) was true in that word that he (brother) spoke to himself, and that his (brother) chief attraction was the delight which he (brother) would have in robbing Mr. Grey of his (Grey) wife. Alice had once been his (Grey) love, had clung to his (Grey) side, had whispered love to him (Grey), and he (Grey) had enough of the weakness of humanity in him (Grey) to feel the soreness arising from her (Alice) affection for another. When she (Alice) broke away from him (Grey) he (Grey) had acknowledged that he (Grey) had been wrong, and when, since her (Alice) engagement with Mr. Grey, he (Grey) had congratulated her (Alice), he (Grey) had told her (Alice) in his (Grey) quiet, half-whispered, impressive words how right she (Alice) was; but not the less, therefore, did he (Grey) feel himself hurt that John Grey should be her (Alice) lover. And when he (Grey) had met this man he (Grey) had spoken well of him (Grey) to his (Grey) sister, saying that he (Grey) was a gentleman, a scholar, and a man of parts; but not the less had he (Grey) hated him (Grey) from the first moment of his (Grey) seeing him (Grey). Such hatred under such circumstances was almost pardonable. But George Vavasor, when he (Vavasor) hated, was apt to follow up his (Vavasor) hatred with injury. He (Vavasor) could not violently dislike a man and yet not wish to do him (Vavasor) any harm. At present, as he (Vavasor) sat lounging in his (Vavasor) chair, he (Vavasor) thought that he (Vavasor) would like to marry his (Vavasor) cousin Alice; but he (Vavasor) was quite sure that he (Vavasor) would like to be the means of putting a stop to the proposed marriage between Alice and John Grey.

Kate had been very false to her (Kate) friend, and had sent up to her (Kate) brother the very letter which Alice had written to her (Alice) after that meeting in Queen Anne Street which was described in the last chapter,--or rather a portion of it, for with the reserve common to women she (Alice) had kept back the other half. Alice had declared to herself that she (Alice) would be sure of her (Alice) cousin's sympathy, and had written out all her (Alice) heart on the matter, as was her (Alice) wont when writing to Kate.

``But you must understand,'' (she)
she (Alice) wrote,
``that all that I said to him (papa) went with him (papa) for nothing. I had determined to make him (papa) know that everything between us must be over, but I failed. I found that I had no words at command, but that he (papa) was able to talk to me as though I were a child. He (papa) told me that I was sick and full of phantasies, and bade me change the air. As he (papa) spoke in this way, I could not help feeling how right he (papa) was to use me so; but I felt also that he (papa), in his (papa) mighty superiority, could never be a fitting husband for a creature so inferior to him (papa) as I am. Though I altogether failed to make him (papa) understand that it was so, every moment that we were together made me more fixed in my resolution.'' (she)

This letter from Alice to Kate, Vavasor read over and over again, though Kate's letter to himself, which was the longer one, he (cousin) had thrown aside after the first glance. There was nothing that he (cousin) could learn from that. He (cousin) was as good a judge of the manner in which he (cousin) would play his (cousin) own game as Kate could be; but in this matter he (cousin) was to learn how he (cousin) would play his (cousin) game from a knowledge of the other girl's mind.

``She (papa)'ll never marry him (papa), at any rate,'' (he)
he (cousin) said to himself,
``and she (papa) is right. He (papa)'d make an upper servant of her (papa); very respectable, no doubt, but still only an upper servant. Now with me;--well, I hardly know what I should make of her (papa). I cannot think of myself as a man married.'' (he)
Then he (cousin) threw her (girl) letter after Kate's, and betook himself to his (cousin) newspaper and his (cousin) cigar.

It was two hours after this, and he (cousin) still wore his (cousin) dressing-gown, and he (cousin) was still lounging in his (cousin) easy-chair, when the waiting-maid at the lodgings brought him (cousin) up word that a gentleman wished to see him (gentleman). Vavasor kept no servant of his (servant) own except that confidential groom down at Bicester. It was a rule with him (servant) that people could be better served and cheaper served by other people's servants than by their own. Even in the stables at Bicester the innkeeper had to find what assistance was wanted, and charge for it in the bill. And George Vavasor was no Sybarite. He (Vavasor) did not deem it impracticable to put on his (Vavasor) own trousers without having a man standing at his (Vavasor) foot to hold up the leg of the garment. A valet about a man knows a great deal of a man's ways, and therefore George had no valet.

``A gentleman!'' (he)
said he (George) to the girl.
``Does the gentleman look like a public-house keeper?'' (unknown)

``Well, I think he (gentleman) do,'' (the girl)
said the girl.

``Then show him (gentleman) up,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

And the gentleman was a public-house keeper. Vavasor was pretty sure of his (George) visitor before he (George) desired the servant to give him (George) entrance. It was Mr. Grimes from the

``Handsome Man'' (Mr. Grimes/Grimes)
public-house and tavern, in the Brompton Road, and he (Grimes) had come by appointment to have a little conversation with Mr. Vavasor on matters political. Mr. Grimes was a man who knew that business was business, and as such had some considerable weight in his (Grimes) own neighbourhood. With him (Grimes) politics was business, as well as beer, and omnibus-horses, and foreign wines;--in the fabrication of which latter article Mr. Grimes was supposed to have an extended experience. To such as him (Grimes), when intent on business, Mr. Vavasor was not averse to make known the secrets of his (Vavasor) lodging-house; and now, when the idle of London world was either at morning church or still in bed, Mr. Grimes had come out by appointment to do a little political business with the lately-rejected member for the Chelsea Districts.

Vavasor had been, as I have said, lately rejected, and the new member who had beaten him (member) at the hustings had sat now for one session in parliament. Under his (member) present reign he (member) was destined to the honour of one other session, and then the period of his (member) existing glory,--for which he (member) was said to have paid nearly six thousand pounds,--would be over. But he (member) might be elected again, perhaps for a full period of six sessions; and it might be hoped that this second election would be conducted on more economical principles. To this, the economical view of the matter, Mr. Grimes was very much opposed, and was now waiting upon George Vavasor in Cecil Street, chiefly with the object of opposing the new member's wishes on this head. No doubt Mr. Grimes was personally an advocate for the return of Mr. Vavasor, and would do all in his (Vavasor) power to prevent the re-election of the young Lord Kilfenora, whose father, the Marquis of Bunratty, had scattered that six thousand pounds among the electors and non-electors of Chelsea; but his (Marquis) main object was that money should be spent.

''`Tain't altogether for myself,'' (the electors non-electors)
he (Marquis) said to a confidential friend in the same way of business;
``I don't get so much on it. Perhaps sometimes not none. May be I've a bill agin some of those gents not paid this werry moment. But it's the game I looks to. If the game dies away, it'll never be got up again;--never. Who'll care about elections then? Anybody'd go and get hisself elected if we was to let the game go by!'' (a friend)
And so, that the game might not go by, Mr. Grimes was now present in Mr. George Vavasor's rooms.

``Well Mr. Grimes,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George,
``how are you this morning? Sit down, Mr. Grimes. If every man were as punctual as you are, the world would go like clock-work; wouldn't it?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

``Business is business, Mr. Vavasor,'' (the publican)
said the publican, after having made his (publican) salute, and having taken his (publican) chair with some little show of mock modesty.
``That's my maxim. If I didn't stick to that, nothing wouldn't ever stick to me; and nothing doesn't much as it is. Times is very bad, Mr. Vavasor.'' (unknown)

``Of course they are. They're always bad. What was the Devil made for, except that they should be bad? But I should have thought you publicans were the last men who ought to complain.'' (unknown)

``Lord love you, Mr. Vavasor; why, I suppose of all the men as is put upon, we're put upon the worst. What's the good of drawing of beer, if the more you draw the more you don't make. Yesterday as ever was was Saturday, and we drawed three pound ten and nine. What'll that come to, Mr. Vavasor, when you reckons it up with the brewer? Why, it's a next to nothing. You knows that well enough.'' (unknown)

``Upon my word I don't. But I know you don't sell a pint of beer without getting a profit out of it.'' (unknown)

``Lord love you, Mr. Vavasor. If I hadn't nothink to look to but beer I couldn't keep a house over my head; no I couldn't. That house of mine belongs to Meux's people; and very good people they are too;--have made a sight of money; haven't they, Mr. Vavasor? I has to get my beer from them in course. Why not, when it's their house? But if I sells their stuff as I gets it, there ain't a halfpenny coming to me out of a gallon. Look at that, now.'' (unknown)

``But then you don't sell it as you get it. You stretch it.'' (unknown)

``That's in course. I'm not going to tell you a lie, Mr. Vavasor. You know what's what as well as I do, and a sight better, I expect. There's a dozen different ways of handling beer, Mr. Vavasor. But what's the use of that, when they can take four or five pounds a day over the counter for their rot-gut stuff at the ``Cadogan Arms,

'' and I can't do no better nor yet perhaps so well, for a real honest glass of beer. Stretch it! It's my belief the more you poison their liquor, the more the people likes it!'' (Mr. Grimes/Grimes)

Mr. Grimes was a stout man, not very tall, with a mottled red face, and large protruding eyes. As regards his (Grimes) own person, Mr. Grimes might have been taken as a fair sample of the English innkeeper, as described for many years past. But in his (Grimes) outer garments he (Grimes) was very unlike that description. He (Grimes) wore a black, swallow-tailed coat, made, however, to set very loose upon his (Grimes) back, a black waistcoat, and black pantaloons. He (Grimes) carried, moreover, in his (Grimes) hands a black chimney-pot hat. Not only have the top-boots and breeches vanished from the costume of innkeepers, but also the long, particoloured waistcoat, and the birds'-eye fogle round their necks. They get themselves up to look like Dissenting ministers or undertakers, except that there is still a something about their rosy gills which tells a tale of the spigot and corkscrew.

Mr. Grimes had only just finished the tale of his (Grimes) own hard ways as a publican, when the door-bell was again rung.

``There's Scruby,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George Vavasor,
``and now we can go to business.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

CHAPTER XIII.

Mr. Grimes Gets His (Grimes) Odd Money.

The handmaiden at George Vavasor's lodgings announced

``another gent,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
and then Mr. Scruby entered the room in which were seated George, and Mr. Grimes the publican from the
``Handsome Man'' (the publican)
on the Brompton Road. Mr. Scruby was an attorney from Great Marlborough Street, supposed to be very knowing in the ways of metropolitan elections; and he (Scruby) had now stepped round, as he (Scruby) called it, with the object of saying a few words to Mr. Grimes, partly on the subject of the forthcoming contest at Chelsea, and partly on that of the contest last past. These words were to be said in the presence of Mr. Vavasor, the person interested. That some other words had been spoken between Mr. Scruby and Mr. Grimes on the same subjects behind Mr. Vavasor's back I think very probable. But even though this might have been so I am not prepared to say that Mr. Vavasor had been deceived by their combinations.

The two men were very civil to each other in their salutations, the attorney assuming an air of patronizing condescension, always calling the other Grimes; whereas Mr. Scruby was treated with considerable deference by the publican, and was always called Mr. Scruby.

``Business is business,'' (the publican)
said the publican as soon as these salutations were over;
``isn't it now, Mr. Scruby?'' (the publican)

``And I suppose Grimes thinks Sunday morning a particularly good time for business,'' (the attorney)
said the attorney, laughing.

``It's quiet, you know,'' (Mr. Grimes/Grimes)
said Grimes.
``But it warn't me as named Sunday morning. It was Mr. Vavasor here. But it is quiet; ain't it, Mr. Scruby?'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)

Mr. Scruby acknowledged that it was quiet, especially looking out over the river, and then they proceeded to business.

``We must pull the governor through better next time than we did last,'' (the attorney)
said the attorney.

``Of course we must, Mr. Scruby; but, Lord love you, Mr. Vavasor, whose fault was it? What notice did I get,--just tell me that? Why, Travers's name was up on the liberal interest ever so long before the governor had ever thought about it.'' (unknown)

``Nobody is blaming you, Mr. Grimes,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``And nobody can't, Mr. Vavasor. I done my work true as steel, and there ain't another man about the place as could have done half as much. You ask Mr. Scruby else. Mr. Scruby knows, if ere a man in London does. I tell you what it is, Mr. Vavasor, them Chelsea fellows, who lives mostly down by the river, ain't like your Maryboners or Finsburyites. It wants something of a man to manage them. Don't it Mr. Scruby?'' (unknown)

``It wants something of a man to manage any of them as far as my experience goes,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby.

``Of course it do; and there ain't one in London knows so much about it as you do, Mr. Scruby. I will say that for you. But the long and the short of it is this;--business is business, and money is money.'' (unknown)

``Money is money, certainly,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby.
``There's no doubt in the world about that, Grimes;--and a deal of it you had out of the last election.'' (unknown)

``No, I hadn't; begging your pardon, Mr. Scruby, for making so free. What I had to my own cheek wasn't nothing to speak of. I wasn't paid for my time; that's what I wasn't. You look how a publican's business gets cut up at them elections;--and then the state of the house afterwards! What would the governor say to me if I was to put down painting inside and out in my little bill?'' (unknown)

``It doesn't seem to make much difference how you put it down,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor.
``The total is what I look at.'' (unknown)

``Just so, Mr. Vavasor; just so. The total is what I looks at too. And I has to look at it a deuced long time before I gets it. I ain't a got it yet; have I, Mr. Vavasor?'' (unknown)

``Well; if you ask me I should say you had,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.
``I know I paid Mr. Scruby three hundred pounds on your account.'' (unknown)

``And I got every shilling of it, Mr. Vavasor. I'm not a going to deny the money, Mr. Vavasor. You'll never find me doing that. I'm as round as your hat, and as square as your elbow,--I am. Mr. Scruby knows me; don't you, Mr. Scruby?'' (unknown)

``Perhaps I know you too well, Grimes.'' (unknown)

``No you don't, Mr. Scruby; not a bit too well. Nor I don't know you too well, either. I respect you, Mr. Scruby, because you're a man as understands your business. But as I was saying, what's three hundred pounds when a man's bill is three hundred and ninety-two thirteen and fourpence?'' (unknown)

``I thought that was all settled, Mr. Scruby,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor.

``Why you see, Mr. Vavasor, it's very hard to settle these things. If you ask me whether Mr. Grimes here can sue you for the balance, I tell you very plainly that he (Grimes) can't. We were a little short of money when we came to a settlement, as is generally the case at such times, and so we took Mr. Grimes' receipt for three hundred pounds.'' (unknown)

``Of course you did, Mr. Scruby.'' (unknown)

``Not on account, but in full of all demands.'' (unknown)

``Now Mr. Scruby!'' (the publican)
and the publican as he (Scruby) made this appeal looked at the attorney with an expression of countenance which was absolutely eloquent.
``Are you going to put me off with such an excuse as that?'' (unknown)
so the look spoke plainly enough.
``Are you going to bring up my own signature against me, when you know very well that I shouldn't have got a shilling at all for the next twelve months if I hadn't given it? Oh Mr. Scruby!'' (Mr. Grimes/Grimes)
That's what Mr. Grimes' look said, and both Mr. Scruby and Mr. Vavasor understood it perfectly.

``In full of all demands,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby, with a slight tone of triumph in his (Scruby) voice, as though to show that Grimes' appeal had no effect at all upon his (Grimes) conscience.
``If you were to go into a court of law, Grimes, you wouldn't have a leg to stand upon.'' (unknown)

``A court of law? Who's a going to law with the governor, I should like to know? not I; not if he (governor) didn't pay me them ninety-two pounds thirteen and fourpence for the next five years.'' (unknown)

``Five years or fifteen would make no difference,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Scruby.
``You couldn't do it.'' (unknown)

``And I ain't a going to try. That's not the ticket I've come here about, Mr. Vavasor, this blessed Sunday morning. Going to law, indeed! But Mr. Scruby, I've got a family.'' (unknown)

``Not in the vale of Taunton, I hope,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``They is at the

``Handsome Man' in the Brompton Road, Mr. Vavasor; and I always feels that I owes my first duty to them. If a man don't work for his (man) family, what do he (man) work for?'' (unknown)

``Come, come, Grimes,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby.
``What is it you're at? Out with it, and don't keep us here all day.'' (unknown)

``What is it I'm at, Mr. Scruby? As if you didn't know very well what I'm at. There's my house;--in all them Chelsea districts it's the most convenientest of any public as is open for all manner of election purposes. That's given up to it.'' (unknown)

``And what next?'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Scruby.

``The next is, I myself. There isn't one of the lot of 'em can work them Chelsea fellows down along the river unless it is me. Mr. Scruby knows that. Why I've been a getting of them up with a view to this very job ever since;--why ever since they was a talking of the Chelsea districts. When Lord Robert was a coming in for the county on the religious dodge, he (Robert) couldn't have worked them fellows anyhow, only for me. Mr. Scruby knows that.'' (unknown)

``Let's take it all for granted, Mr. Grimes,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor.
``What comes next?'' (unknown)

``Well;--them Bunratty people; it is they as has come next. They know which side their bread is likely to be buttered; they do. They're a bidding for the

``Handsome Man' already; they are.'' (unknown)

``And you'd let your house to the Tory party, Grimes!'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby, in a tone in which disgust and anger were blended.

``Who said anything of my letting my house to the Tory party, Mr. Scruby? I'm as round as your hat, Mr. Scruby, and as square as your elbow; I am. But suppose as all the liberal gents as employs you, Mr. Scruby, was to turn again you and not pay you your little bills, wouldn't you have your eyes open for customers of another kind? Come now, Mr. Scruby?'' (unknown)

-LSB-Illustration:

``I'm as round as your hat, and as square as your elbow; I am.'' (unknown)
-RSB-

``You won't make much of that game, Grimes.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps not; perhaps not. There's a risk in all these things; isn't there, Mr. Vavasor? I should like to see you a Parliament gent; I should indeed. You'd be a credit to the districts; I really think you would.'' (unknown)

``I'm much obliged by your good opinion, Mr. Grimes,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``When I sees a gent coming forward I knows whether he (Grimes)'s fit for Parliament, or whether he (Grimes) ain't. I says you are fit. But Lord love you, Mr. Vavasor; it's a thing a gentleman always has to pay for.'' (unknown)

``That's true enough; a deal more than it's worth, generally.'' (unknown)

``A thing's worth what it fetches. I'm worth what I'll fetch; that's the long and the short of it. I want to have my balance, that's the truth. It's the odd money in a man's bill as always carries the profit. You ask Mr. Scruby else;--only with a lawyer it's all profit I believe.'' (unknown)

``That's what you know about it,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Scruby.

``If you cut off a man's odd money,'' (the publican)
continued the publican,
``you break his (man) heart. He (man)'d almost sooner have that and leave the other standing. He (man)'d call the hundreds capital, and if he (man) lost them at last, why he (man)'d put it down as being in the way of trade. But the odd money;--he (man) looks at that, Mr. Vavasor, as in a manner the very sweat of his (Vavasor) brow, the work of his (Vavasor) own hand; that's what goes to his (Vavasor) family, and keeps the pot a boiling down-stairs. Never stop a man's odd money, Mr. Vavasor; that is, unless he (Vavasor) comes it very strong indeed.'' (the publican)

``And what is it you want now?'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Scruby.

``I wants ninety-two pounds thirteen and fourpence, Mr. Scruby, and then we'll go to work for the new fight with contented hearts. If we're to begin at all, it's quite time; it is indeed, Mr. Vavasor.'' (unknown)

``And what you mean us to understand is, that you won't begin at all without your money,'' (the lawyer)
said the lawyer.

``That's about it, Mr. Scruby.'' (unknown)

``Take a fifty-pound note, Grimes,'' (the lawyer)
said the lawyer.

``Fifty-pound notes are not so ready,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``Oh, he (Grimes)'ll be only too happy to have your acceptance; won't you, Grimes.'' (unknown)

``Not for fifty pounds, Mr. Scruby. It's the odd money that I wants. I don't mind the thirteen and four, because that's neither here nor there among friends, but if I didn't get all them ninety-two pounds I should be a broken-hearted man; I should indeed, Mr. Vavasor. I couldn't go about your work for next year so as to do you justice among the electors. I couldn't indeed.'' (unknown)

``You'd better give him (Vavasor) a bill for ninety pounds at three months, Mr. Vavasor. I have no doubt he (Vavasor) has got a stamp in his (Vavasor) pocket.'' (unknown)

``That I have, Mr. Scruby; there ain't no mistake about that. A bill stamp is a thing that often turns up convenient with gents as mean business like Mr. Vavasor and you. But you must make it ninety-two; you must indeed, Mr. Vavasor. And do make it two months if you can, Mr. Vavasor; they do charge so unconscionable on ninety days at them branch banks; they do indeed.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

George Vavasor and Mr. Scruby, between them, yielded at last, so far as to allow the bill to be drawn for ninety-two pounds, but they were stanch as to the time.

``If it must be, it must,'' (the publican)
said the publican, with a deep sigh, as he (publican) folded up the paper and put it into the pocket of a huge case which he (publican) carried. ``And now, gents, I'll tell you what it is. We'll make safe work of this here next election. We know what's to be our little game in time, and if we don't go in and win, my name ain't Jacob Grimes, and I ain't the landlord of the ``Handsome Man.
'' As you gents has perhaps got something to say among yourselves, I'll make so bold as to wish you good morning.'' (the Man)
So, with that, Mr. Grimes lifted his (Grimes) hat from the floor, and bowed himself out of the room.

``You couldn't have done it cheaper; you couldn't, indeed,'' (the lawyer)
said the lawyer, as soon as the sound of the closing front door had been heard.

``Perhaps not; but what a thief the man is! I remember your telling me that the bill was about the most preposterous you had ever seen.'' (unknown)

``So it was, and if we hadn't wanted him (man) again of course we shouldn't have paid him (man). But we'll have it all off his (man) next account, Mr. Vavasor,--every shilling of it, It's only lent; that's all;--it's only lent.'' (unknown)

``But one doesn't want to lend such a man money, if one could help it.'' (unknown)

``That's true. If you look at it in that light, it's quite true. But you see we cannot do without him (man). If he (man) hadn't got your bill, he (man)'d have gone over to the other fellows before the week was over; and the worst of it would have been that he (man) knows our hand. Looking at it all round you've got him (man) cheap, Mr. Vavasor;--you have, indeed.'' (unknown)

``Looking at it all round is just what I don't like, Mr. Scruby, But if a man will have a whistle, he (man) must pay for it.'' (unknown)

``You can't do it cheap for any of these metropolitan seats; you can't, indeed, Mr. Vavasor. That is, a new man can't. When you've been in four or five times, like old Duncombe, why then, of course, you may snap your fingers at such men as Grimes. But the Chelsea districts ain't dear. I don't call them by any means dear. Now Marylebone is dear,--and so is Southwark. It's dear, and nasty; that's what the borough is. Only that I never tell tales, I could tell you a tale, Mr. Vavasor, that'd make your hair stand on end; I could indeed.'' (unknown)

``Ah! the game is hardly worth the candle, I believe.'' (unknown)

``That depends on what way you choose to look at it. A seat in Parliament is a great thing to a man who wants to make his (man) way;--a very great thing;--specially when a man's young, like you, Mr. Vavasor.'' (unknown)

``Young!'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.
``Sometimes it seems to me as though I've been living for a hundred years. But I won't trouble you with that, Mr. Scruby, and I believe I needn't keep you any longer.'' (he)
With that, he (George) got up and bowed the attorney out of the room, with just a little more ceremony than he (George) had shown to the publican.

``Young!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor to himself, when he (George) was left alone.
``There's my uncle, or the old squire,--they're both younger men than I am. One cares for his (uncle) dinner, and the other for his (uncle) bullocks and his (uncle) trees. But what is there that I care for, unless it is not getting among the sheriff's officers for debt?'' (he)
Then he (George) took out a little memorandum-book from his (George) breast-pocket, and having made in it an entry as to the amount and date of that bill which he (George) had just accepted on the publican's behalf, he (George) conned over the particulars of its pages.
``Very blue; very blue, indeed,'' (he)
he (George) said to himself when he (George) had completed the study.
``But nobody shall say I hadn't the courage to play the game out, and that old fellow must die some day, one supposes. If I were not a fool, I should make it up with him (fool) before he (fool) went; but I am a fool, and shall remain so to the last.'' (he)
Soon after that he (George) dressed himself slowly, reading a little every now and then as he (George) did so. When his (George) toilet was completed, and his (George) Sunday newspapers sufficiently perused, he (George) took up his (George) hat and umbrella and sauntered out.

CHAPTER XIV.

Alice Vavasor Becomes Troubled.

Kate Vavasor had sent to her (Vavasor) brother only the first half of her (Vavasor) cousin's letter, that half in which Alice had attempted to describe what had taken place between her (Alice) and Mr. Grey. In doing this, Kate had been a wicked traitor,--a traitor to that feminine faith against which treason on the part of one woman is always unpardonable in the eyes of other women. But her (woman) treason would have been of a deeper die had she (woman) sent the latter portion, for in that Alice had spoken of George Vavasor himself. But even of this treason, Kate would, I think, have been guilty, had the words which Alice wrote been of a nature to serve her (Alice) own purpose if read by her (Alice) brother. But they had not been of this nature. They had spoken of George as a man with whom any closer connection than that which existed at present was impossible, and had been written with the view of begging Kate to desist from making futile attempts in that direction.

``I feel myself driven,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice had said,
``to write all this, as otherwise,--if I were simply to tell you that I have resolved to part from Mr. Grey,--you would think that the other thing might follow. The other thing cannot follow. I should think myself untrue in my friendship to you if I did not tell you about Mr. Grey; and you will be untrue in your friendship to me if you take advantage of my confidence by saying more about your brother.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
This part of Alice's letter Kate had not sent to George Vavasor;--
``But the other thing shall follow,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
Kate had said, as she (Kate) read the words for the second time, and then put the papers into her (Kate) desk.
``It shall follow.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

To give Kate Vavasor her (Vavasor) due, she (Vavasor) was, at any rate, unselfish in her (Vavasor) intrigues. She (Vavasor) was obstinately persistent, and she (Vavasor) was moreover unscrupulous, but she (Vavasor) was not selfish. Many years ago she (Vavasor) had made up her (Vavasor) mind that George and Alice should be man and wife, feeling that such a marriage would be good at any rate for her (Alice) brother. It had been almost brought about, and had then been hindered altogether through a fault on her (Alice) brother's part. But she (Alice) had forgiven him (brother) this sin as she (Alice) had forgiven many others, and she (Alice) was now at work in his (brother) behalf again, determined that they two should be married, even though neither of them might be now anxious that it should be so. The intrigue itself was dear to her (Alice), and success in it was necessary to her (Alice) self-respect.

She (Alice) answered Alice's letter with a pleasant, gossiping epistle, which shall be recorded, as it will tell us something of Mrs. Greenow's proceedings at Yarmouth. Kate had promised to stay at Yarmouth for a month, but she (Kate) had already been there six weeks, and was still under her (Kate) aunt's wing.

Yarmouth, October, 186--.

DEAREST ALICE,

Of course I am delighted. It is no good saying that I am not. I know how difficult it is to deal with you, and therefore I sit down to answer your letter with fear and trembling, lest I should say a word too much, and thereby drive you back, or not say quite enough and thereby fail to encourage you on. Of course I am glad. I have long thought that Mr. Grey could not make you happy, and as I have thought so, how can I not be glad? It is no use saying that he (Grey) is good and noble, and all that sort of thing. I have never denied it. But he (Grey) was not suited to you, and his (Grey) life would have made you wretched. Ergo, I rejoice. And as you are the dearest friend I have, of course I rejoice mightily.

I can understand accurately the sort of way in which the interview went. Of course he (friend) had the best of it. I can see him (friend) so plainly as he (friend) stood up in unruffled self-possession, ignoring all that you said, suggesting that you were feverish or perhaps bilious, waving his (friend) hand over you a little, as though that might possibly do you some small good, and then taking his (friend) leave with an assurance that it would be all right as soon as the wind changed. I suppose it's very noble in him (friend), not taking you at your word, and giving you, as it were, another chance; but there is a kind of nobility which is almost too great for this world. I think very well of you, my dear, as women go, but I do not think well enough of you to believe that you are fit to be Mr. John Grey's wife.

Of course I'm very glad. You have known my mind from the first to the last, and, therefore, what would be the good of my mincing matters? No woman wishes her (woman) dearest friend to marry a man to whom she (woman) herself is antipathetic. You would have been as much lost to me, had you become Mrs. Grey of Nethercoats, Cambridgeshire, as though you had gone to heaven. I don't say but what Nethercoats may be a kind of heaven,--but then one doesn't wish one's friend that distant sort of happiness. A flat Eden I can fancy it, hemmed in by broad dykes, in which cream and eggs are very plentiful, where an Adam and an Eve might drink the choicest tea out of the finest china, with toast buttered to perfection, from year's end to year's end; into which no money troubles would ever find their way, nor yet any naughty novels. But such an Eden is not tempting to me, nor, as I think, to you. I can fancy you stretching your poor neck over the dyke, longing to fly away that you might cease to be at rest, but knowing that the matrimonial dragon was too strong for any such flight. If ever bird banged his (you) wings to pieces against gilded bars, you would have banged yours to pieces in that cage.

You say that you have failed to make him (you) understand that the matter is settled. I need not say that of course it is settled, and that he (you) must be made to understand it. You owe it to him (you) now to put him (you) out of all doubt. He (you) is, I suppose, accessible to the words of a mortal, god though he (god) be. But I do not fear about this, for, after all, you have as much firmness about you as most people;--perhaps as much as he (god) has at bottom, though you may not have so many occasions to show it.

As to that other matter I can only say that you shall be obliged, as far as it is in my power to obey you. For what may come out from me by word of mouth when we are together, I will not answer with certainty. But my pen is under better control, and it shall not write the offending name.

And now I must tell you a little about myself;--or rather, I am inclined to spin a yarn, and tell you a great deal. I have got such a lover! But I did describe him (lover) before. Of course it's Mr. Cheesacre. If I were to say he (Cheesacre) hasn't declared himself, I should hardly give you a fair idea of my success. And yet he (Cheesacre) has not declared himself,--and, which is worse, is very anxious to marry a rival. But it's a strong point in my favour that my rival wants him (Cheesacre) to take me, and that he (Cheesacre) will assuredly be driven to make me an offer sooner or later, in obedience to her (Cheesacre) orders. My aunt is my rival, and I do not feel the least doubt as to his (Cheesacre) having offered to her (Cheesacre) half a dozen times. But then she (Cheesacre) has another lover, Captain Bellfield, and I see that she (Bellfield) prefers him (Captain). He (Captain) is a penniless scamp and looks as though he (Captain) drank. He (Captain) paints his (Captain) whiskers too, which I don't like; and, being forty, tries to look like twenty-five. Otherwise he (Captain) is agreeable enough, and I rather approve of my aunt's taste in preferring him (Captain).

But my lover has solid attractions, and allures me on by a description of the fat cattle which he (lover) sends to market. He (lover) is a man of substance, and should I ever become Mrs. Cheesacre, I have reason to think that I shall not be left in want. We went up to his (lover) place on a visit the other day. Oileymead is the name of my future home;--not so pretty as Nethercoats, is it? And we had such a time there! We reached the place at ten and left it at four, and he (lover) managed to give us three meals. I'm sure we had before our eyes at different times every bit of china, delf, glass, and plate in the establishment. He (lover) made us go into the cellar, and told us how much wine he (lover) had got there, and how much beer.

``It's all paid for, Mrs. Greenow, every bottle of it,'' (he)
he (lover) said, turning round to my aunt, with a pathetic earnestness, for which I had hardly given him (lover) credit.
