``Everything in this house is my own; it's all paid for. I don't call anything a man's own till it's paid for. Now that jacket that Bellfield swells about with on the sands at Yarmouth,--that's not his (man) own,--and it's not like to be either.'' (he)
And then he (lover) winked his (lover) eye as though bidding my aunt to think of that before she (aunt) encouraged such a lover as Bellfield. He (lover) took us into every bedroom, and disclosed to us all the glories of his (lover) upper chambers. It would have done you good to see him (lover) lifting the counterpanes, and bidding my aunt feel the texture of the blankets! And then to see her (aunt) turn round to me and say:--
``Kate, it's simply the best-furnished house I ever went over in my life!'' (me)
--
``It does seem very comfortable,'' (I.)
said I.
``Comfortable!'' (I.)
said he (lover).
``Yes, I don't think there's anybody can say that Oileymead isn't comfortable.'' (I)
I did so think of you and Nethercoats. The attractions are the same;--only in the one place you would have a god for your keeper, and in the other a brute. For myself, if ever I'm to have a keeper at all, I shall prefer a man. But when we got to the farmyard his (man) eloquence reached the highest pitch.
``Mrs. Greenow,'' (he)
said he (man),
``look at that,'' (he)
and he (man) pointed to heaps of manure raised like the streets of a little city.
``Look at that!'' (unknown)
``There's a great deal,'' (aunt)
said my aunt.
``I believe you,'' (he)
said he (man).
``I've more muck upon this place here than any farmer in Norfolk, gentle or simple; I don't care who the other is.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Only fancy, Alice; it may all be mine; the blankets, the wine, the muck, and the rest of it. So my aunt assured me when we got home that evening. When I remarked that the wealth had been exhibited to her (aunt) and not to me, she (aunt) did not affect to deny it, but treated that as a matter of no moment.
``He (farmer) wants a wife, my dear,'' (she)
she (aunt) said,
``and you may pick him (farmer) up to-morrow by putting out your hand.'' (she)
When I remarked that his (man) mind seemed to be intent on low things, and specially named the muck, she (aunt) only laughed at me.
``Money's never dirty,'' (she)
she (aunt) said,
``nor yet what makes money.'' (she)
She (aunt) talks of taking lodgings in Norwich for the winter, saying that in her (aunt) widowed state she (aunt) will be as well there as anywhere else, and she (aunt) wants me to stay with her (aunt) up to Christmas. Indeed she (aunt) first proposed the Norwich plan on the ground that it might be useful to me,--with a view to Mr. Cheesacre, of course; but I fancy that she (aunt) is unwilling to tear herself away from Captain Bellfield. At any rate to Norwich she (Bellfield) will go, and I have promised not to leave her (Bellfield) before the second week in November. With all her (Bellfield) absurdities I like her (Bellfield). Her (Bellfield) faults are terrible faults, but she (Bellfield) has not the fault of hiding them by falsehood. She (Bellfield) is never stupid, and she (Bellfield) is very good-natured. She (Bellfield) would have allowed me to equip myself from head to foot at her (Bellfield) expense, if I would have accepted her (Bellfield) liberality, and absolutely offered to give me my trousseau if I would marry Mr. Cheesacre.

I live in the hope that you will come down to the old place at Christmas. I won't offend you more than I can help. At any rate he (Cheesacre) won't be there. And if I don't see you there, where am I to see you? If I were you I would certainly not go to Cheltenham. You are never happy there.

Do you ever dream of the river at Basle? I do;--so often.

Most affectionately yours,

KATE VAVASOR.

-LSB-Illustration:

``Mrs. Greenow, look at that.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
-RSB-

Alice had almost lost the sensation created by the former portion of Kate's letter by the fun of the latter, before she (Kate) had quite made that sensation her (Kate) own. The picture of the Cambridgeshire Eden would have displeased her (Kate) had she (Kate) dwelt upon it, and the allusion to the cream and toast would have had the very opposite effect to that which Kate had intended. Perhaps Kate had felt this, and had therefore merged it all in her (Kate) stories about Mr. Cheesacre.

``I will go to Cheltenham,'' (she)
she (Kate) said to herself.
``He (farmer) has recommended it. I shall never be his (farmer) wife;--but, till we have parted altogether, I will show him (farmer) that I think well of his (farmer) advice.'' (she)
That same afternoon she (Kate) told her (Kate) father that she (Kate) would go to Lady Macleod's at Cheltenham before the end of the month. She (Kate) was, in truth, prompted to this by a resolution, of which she (Kate) was herself hardly conscious, that she (Kate) would not at this period of her (Kate) life be in any way guided by her (Kate) cousin. Having made up her (Kate) mind about Mr. Grey, it was right that she (Kate) should let her (Kate) cousin know her (Kate) purpose; but she (Kate) would never be driven to confess to herself that Kate had influenced her (Kate) in the matter. She (Kate) would go to Cheltenham. Lady Macleod would no doubt vex her (Macleod) by hourly solicitations that the match might be renewed; but, if she (Macleod) knew herself, she (Macleod) had strength to withstand Lady Macleod.

She (Macleod) received one letter from Mr. Grey before the time came for her (Macleod) departure, and she (Macleod) answered it, telling him (Grey) of her (Macleod) intention;--telling him (Grey) also that she (Macleod) now felt herself bound to explain to her (Macleod) father her (Macleod) present position.

``I tell you this,'' (she)
she (Macleod) said,
``in consequence of what you said to me on the matter. My father will know it to-morrow, and on the following morning I shall start for Cheltenham. I have heard from Lady Macleod and she (Macleod) expects me.'' (she)

On the following morning she (Macleod) did tell her (Macleod) father, standing by him (father) as he (father) sat at his (father) breakfast.

``What!'' (he)
said he (father), putting down his (father) tea-cup and looking up into her (Macleod) face;
``What! not marry John Grey!'' (he)

``No, papa; I know how strange you must think it.'' (unknown)

``And you say that there has been no quarrel.'' (unknown)

``No;--there has been no quarrel. By degrees I have learned to feel that I should not make him (Grey) happy as his (Grey) wife.'' (unknown)

``It's d--d nonsense,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said Mr. Vavasor. Now such an expression as this from him (Vavasor), addressed to his (Vavasor) daughter, showed that he (Vavasor) was very deeply moved.

``Oh, papa! don't talk to me in that way.'' (unknown)

``But it is. I never heard such trash in my life. If he (papa) comes to me I shall tell him (papa) so. Not make him (papa) happy! Why can't you make him (papa) happy?'' (unknown)

``We are not suited to each other.'' (unknown)

``But what's the matter with him (papa)? He (papa)'s a gentleman.'' (unknown)

``Yes; he (papa)'s a gentleman.'' (unknown)

``And a man of honour, and with good means, and with all that knowledge and reading which you profess to like. Look here, Alice; I am not going to interfere, nor shall I attempt to make you marry anyone. You are your own mistress as far as that is concerned. But I do hope, for your sake and for mine,--I do hope that there is nothing again between you and your cousin.'' (unknown)

``There is nothing, papa.'' (unknown)

``I did not like your going abroad with him (papa), though I didn't choose to interrupt your plan by saying so. But if there were anything of that kind going on, I should be bound to tell you that your cousin's position at present is not a good one. Men do not speak well of him (cousin).'' (unknown)

``There is nothing between us, papa; but if there were, men speaking ill of him (papa) would not deter me.'' (unknown)

``And men speaking well of Mr. Grey will not do the other thing. I know very well that women can be obstinate.'' (unknown)

``I haven't come to this resolution without thinking much about it, papa.'' (unknown)

``I suppose not. Well;--I can't say anything more. You are your own mistress, and your fortune is in your own keeping. I can't make you marry John Grey. I think you very foolish, and if he (Grey) comes to me I shall tell him (Grey) so. You are going down to Cheltenham, are you?'' (unknown)

``Yes, papa; I have promised Lady Macleod.'' (unknown)

``Very well. I'd sooner it should be you than me; that's all I can say.'' (he)
Then he (Vavasor) took up his (Vavasor) newspaper, thereby showing that he (Vavasor) had nothing further to say on the matter, and Alice left him (Vavasor) alone.

The whole thing was so vexatious that even Mr. Vavasor was disturbed by it. As it was not term time he (Vavasor) had no signing to do in Chancery Lane, and could not, therefore, bury his (Vavasor) unhappiness in his (Vavasor) daily labour,--or rather in his (Vavasor) labour that was by no means daily. So he (Vavasor) sat at home till four o'clock, expressing to himself in various phrases his (Vavasor) wonder that

``any man alive should ever rear a daughter.'' (he)
And when he (Vavasor) got to his (Vavasor) club the waiters found him (Vavasor) quite unmanageable about his (Vavasor) dinner, which he (Vavasor) ate alone, rejecting all proposition of companionship. But later in the evening he (Vavasor) regained his (Vavasor) composure over a glass of whiskey-toddy and a cigar.
``She (daughter)'s got her (daughter) own money,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) said to himself,
``and what does it matter? I don't suppose she (daughter)'ll marry her (daughter) cousin. I don't think she (daughter)'s fool enough for that. And after all she (daughter)'ll probably make it up again with John Grey.'' (he)
And in this way he (Vavasor) determined that he (Vavasor) might let this annoyance run off him (Vavasor), and that he (Vavasor) need not as a father take the trouble of any interference.

But while he (Vavasor) was at his (Vavasor) club there came a visitor to Queen Anne Street, and that visitor was the dangerous cousin of whom, according to his (visitor) uncle's testimony, men at present did not speak well. Alice had not seen him (visitor) since they had parted on the day of their arrival in London,--nor, indeed, had heard of his (visitor) whereabouts. In the consternation of her (Alice) mind at this step which she (Alice) was taking,--a step which she (Alice) had taught herself to regard as essentially her (Alice) duty before it was taken, but which seemed to herself to be false and treacherous the moment she (Alice) had taken it,--she (Alice) had become aware that she (Alice) had been wrong to travel with her (Alice) cousin. She (Alice) felt sure,--she (Alice) thought that she (Alice) was sure,--that her (Alice) doing so had in nowise affected her (Alice) dealings with Mr. Grey. She (Alice) was very certain,--she (Alice) thought that she (Alice) was certain,--that she (Alice) would have rejected him (Grey) just the same had she (Alice) never gone to Switzerland. But every one would say of her (Alice) that her (Alice) journey to Switzerland with such companions had produced that result. It had been unlucky and she (Alice) was sorry for it, and she (Alice) now wished to avoid all communication with her (Alice) cousin till this affair should be altogether over. She (Alice) was especially unwilling to see him (cousin); but she (Alice) had not felt it necessary to give any special injunctions as to his (cousin) admittance; and now, before she (Alice) had time to think of it,--on the eve of her (Alice) departure for Cheltenham,--he (cousin) was in the room with her (Alice), just as the dusk of the October evening was coming on. She (Alice) was sitting away from the fire, almost behind the window-curtains, thinking of John Grey and very unhappy in her (Alice) thoughts, when George Vavasor was announced. It will of course be understood that Vavasor had at this time received his (Vavasor) sister's letter. He (Vavasor) had received it, and had had time to consider the matter since the Sunday morning on which we saw him (Vavasor) in his (Vavasor) own rooms in Cecil Street.

``She (daughter) can turn it all into capital to-morrow, if she (daughter) pleases,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) had said to himself when thinking of her (Vavasor) income. But he (Vavasor) had also reminded himself that her (Vavasor) grandfather would probably enable him (grandfather) to settle an income out of the property upon Alice, in the event of their being married. And then he (grandfather) had also felt that he (grandfather) could have no greater triumph than
``walking atop of John Grey,'' (he)
as he (grandfather) called it. His (grandfather) return for the Chelsea Districts would hardly be sweeter to him (grandfather) than that.

``You must have thought I had vanished out of the world,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George, coming up to her (Alice) with his (George) extended hand.

Alice was confused, and hardly knew how to address him (George).

``Somebody told me that you were shooting,'' (she)
she (Alice) said after a pause.

``So I was, but my shooting is not like the shooting of your great Nimrods,--men who are hunters upon the earth. Two days among the grouse and two more among the partridges are about the extent of it. Capel Court is the preserve in which I am usually to be found.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice knew nothing of Capel Court, and said,

``Oh, indeed.'' (Capel Court)

``Have you heard from Kate?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
George asked.

``Yes, once or twice; she (Kate) is still at Yarmouth with Aunt Greenow.'' (unknown)

``And is going to Norwich, as she (Kate) says. Kate seems to have made a league with Aunt Greenow. I, who don't pretend to be very disinterested in money matters, think that she (Greenow) is quite right. No doubt Aunt Greenow may marry again, but friends with forty thousand pounds are always agreeable.'' (unknown)

``I don't believe that Kate thinks much of that,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Not so much as she (Kate) ought, I dare say. Poor Kate is not a rich woman, or, I fear, likely to become one. She (Kate) doesn't seem to dream of getting married, and her (Kate) own fortune is less than a hundred a year.'' (unknown)

``Girls who never dream of getting married are just those who make the best marriages at last,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Perhaps so, but I wish I was easier about Kate. She (Kate) is the best sister a man ever had.'' (unknown)

``Indeed she (Kate) is.'' (unknown)

``And I have done nothing for her (Kate) as yet. I did think, while I was in that wine business, that I could have done anything I pleased for her (Kate). But my grandfather's obstinacy put me out of that; and now I'm beginning the world again,--that is, comparatively. I wonder whether you think I'm wrong in trying to get into Parliament?'' (unknown)

``No; quite right. I admire you for it. It is just what I would do in your place. You are unmarried, and have a right to run the risk.'' (unknown)

``I am so glad to hear you speak like that,'' (he)
said he (George). He (George) had now managed to take up that friendly, confidential, almost affectionate tone of talking which he (George) had so often used when abroad with her (Alice), and which he (George) had failed to assume when first entering the room.

``I have always thought so.'' (unknown)

``But you have never said it.'' (unknown)

``Haven't I? I thought I had.'' (unknown)

``Not heartily like that. I know that people abuse me;--my own people, my grandfather, and probably your father,--saying that I am reckless and the rest of it. I do risk everything for my object; but I do not know that any one can blame me,--unless it be Kate. To whom else do I owe anything?'' (unknown)

``Kate does not blame you.'' (unknown)

``No; she (Kate) sympathizes with me; she (Kate), and she (Kate) only, unless it be you.'' (he)
Then he (George) paused for an answer, but she (Alice) made him (George) none.
``She (Kate) is brave enough to give me her (Kate) hearty sympathy. But perhaps for that very reason I ought to be the more chary in endangering the only support that she (Kate) is like to have. What is ninety pounds a year for the maintenance of a single lady?'' (unknown)

``I hope that Kate will always live with me,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice;
``that is, as soon as she (Kate) has lost her (Kate) home at Vavasor Hall.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

He (George) had been very crafty and had laid a trap for her (Alice). He (George) had laid a trap for her (Alice), and she (Alice) had fallen into it. She (Alice) had determined not to be induced to talk of herself; but he (George) had brought the thing round so cunningly that the words were out of her (Alice) mouth before she (Alice) remembered whither they would lead her (Alice). She (Alice) did remember this as she (Alice) was speaking them, but then it was too late.

``What;--at Nethercoats?'' (he)
said he (George).
``Neither she (Kate) nor I doubt your love, but few men would like such an intruder as that into their household, and of all men Mr. Grey, whose nature is retiring, would like it the least.'' (unknown)

``I was not thinking of Nethercoats,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Ah, no; that is it, you see. Kate says so often to me that when you are married she (Kate) will be alone in the world.'' (unknown)

``I don't think she (Kate) will ever find that I shall separate myself from her (Kate).'' (unknown)

``No; not by any will of your own. Poor Kate! You cannot be surprised that she (Kate) should think of your marriage with dread. How much of her (Kate) life has been made up of her (Kate) companionship with you;--and all the best of it too! You ought not to be angry with her (Kate) for regarding your withdrawal into Cambridgeshire with dismay.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice could not act the lie which now seemed to be incumbent on her (Alice). She (Alice) could not let him (George) talk of Nethercoats as though it were to be her (Alice) future home. She (Alice) made the struggle, and she (Alice) found that she (Alice) could not do it. She (Alice) was unable to find the words which should tell no lie to the ear, and which should yet deceive him (George).

``Kate may still live with me,'' (she)
she (Alice) said slowly.
``Everything is over between me and Mr. Grey.'' (unknown)

``Alice!--is that true?'' (unknown)

``Yes, George; it is true. If you will allow me to say so, I would rather not talk about it;--not just at present.'' (unknown)

``And does Kate know it?'' (unknown)

``Yes, Kate knows it.'' (unknown)

``And my uncle?'' (unknown)

``Yes, papa knows it also.'' (unknown)

``Alice, how can I help speaking of it? How can I not tell you that I am rejoiced that you are saved from a thraldom which I have long felt sure would break your heart?'' (unknown)

``Pray do not talk of it further.'' (unknown)

``Well; if I am forbidden I shall of course obey. But I own it is hard to me. How can I not congratulate you?'' (she)
To this she (Alice) answered nothing, but beat with her (Alice) foot upon the floor as though she (Alice) were impatient of his (George) words.
``Yes, Alice, I understand. You are angry with me,'' (he)
he (George) continued.
``And yet you have no right to be surprised that when you tell me this I should think of all that passed between us in Switzerland. Surely the cousin who was with you then has a right to say what he (cousin) thinks of this change in your life; at any rate he (cousin) may do so, if as in this case he (cousin) approves altogether of what you are doing.'' (unknown)

``I am glad of your approval, George; but pray let that be an end to it.'' (unknown)

After that the two sat silent for a minute or two. She (Alice) was waiting for him (George) to go, but she (Alice) could not bid him (George) leave the house. She (Alice) was angry with herself, in that she (Alice) had allowed herself to tell him (George) of her (Alice) altered plans, and she (Alice) was angry with him (George) because he (George) would not understand that she (Alice) ought to be spared all conversation on the subject. So she (Alice) sat looking through the window at the row of gaslights as they were being lit, and he (George) remained in his (George) chair with his (George) elbow on the table and his (George) head resting on his (George) hand.

``Do you remember asking me whether I ever shivered,'' (he)
he (George) said at last;
''--whether I ever thought of things that made me shiver? Don't you remember; on the bridge at Basle?'' (he)

``Yes; I remember.'' (unknown)

``Well, Alice;--one cause for my shivering is over. I won't say more than that now. Shall you remain long at Cheltenham?'' (unknown)

``Just a month.'' (unknown)

``And then you come back here?'' (unknown)

``I suppose so. Papa and I will probably go down to Vavasor Hall before Christmas. How much before I cannot say.'' (unknown)

``I shall see you at any rate after your return from Cheltenham? Of course Kate will know, and she (Kate) will tell me.'' (unknown)

``Yes; Kate will know. I suppose she (Kate) will stay here when she (Kate) comes up from Norfolk. Good-bye.'' (unknown)

``Good-bye, Alice. I shall have fewer fits of that inward shivering that you spoke of,--many less, on account of what I have now heard. God bless you, Alice; good-bye.'' (unknown)

``Good-bye, George.'' (he)

As he (George) went he (George) took her (Alice) hand and pressed it closely between his (George) own. In those days when they were lovers,--engaged lovers, a close, long-continued pressure of her (Alice) hand had been his (George) most eloquent speech of love. He (George) had not been given to many kisses,--not even to many words of love. But he (George) would take her (Alice) hand and hold it, even as he (George) looked away from her (Alice), and she (Alice) remembered well the touch of his (George) palm. It was ever cool,--cool, and with a surface smooth as a woman's,--a small hand that had a firm grip. There had been days when she (woman) had loved to feel that her (woman) own was within it, when she (woman) trusted in it, and intended that it should be her (woman) staff through life. Now she (woman) distrusted it; and as the thoughts of the old days came upon her (woman), and the remembrance of that touch was recalled, she (woman) drew her (woman) hand away rapidly. Not for that had she (woman) driven from her (woman) as honest a man as had ever wished to mate with a woman. He (man), George Vavasor, had never so held her (woman) hand since the day when they had parted, and now on this first occasion of her (woman) freedom she (woman) felt it again. What did he (Vavasor) think of her (woman)? Did he (Vavasor) suppose that she (woman) could transfer her (woman) love in that way, as a flower may be taken from one buttonhole and placed in another? He (Vavasor) read it all, and knew that he (Vavasor) was hurrying on too quickly.

``I can understand well,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) said in a whisper,
``what your present feelings are; but I do not think you will be really angry with me because I have been unable to repress my joy at what I cannot but regard as your release from a great misfortune.'' (he)
Then he (Vavasor) went.

``My release!'' (she)
she (woman) said, seating herself on the chair from which he (Vavasor) had risen.
``My release from a misfortune! No;--but my fall from heaven! Oh, what a man he (man) is! That he (man) should have loved me, and that I should have driven him (man) away from me!'' (that master hers)
Her (woman) thoughts travelled off to the sweetness of that home at Nethercoats, to the excellence of that master who might have been hers; and then in an agony of despair she (woman) told herself that she (woman) had been an idiot and a fool, as well as a traitor. What had she (woman) wanted in life that she (woman) should have thus quarrelled with as happy a lot as ever had been offered to a woman? Had she (woman) not been mad, when she (woman) sent from her (woman) side the only man that she (woman) loved,--the only man that she (woman) had ever truly respected? For hours she (woman) sat there, all alone, putting out the candles which the servant had lighted for her (woman), and leaving untasted the tea that was brought to her (woman).

Poor Alice! I hope that she (Alice) may be forgiven. It was her (Alice) special fault, that when at Rome she (Alice) longed for Tibur, and when at Tibur she (Alice) regretted Rome. Not that her (Alice) cousin George is to be taken as representing the joys of the great capital, though Mr. Grey may be presumed to form no inconsiderable part of the promised delights of the country. Now that she (Alice) had sacrificed her (Alice) Tibur, because it had seemed to her (Alice) that the sunny quiet of its pastures lacked the excitement necessary for the happiness of life, she (Alice) was again prepared to quarrel with the heartlessness of Rome, and already was again sighing for the tranquillity of the country.

Sitting there, full of these regrets, she (Alice) declared to herself that she (Alice) would wait for her (Alice) father's return, and then, throwing herself upon his (father) love and upon his (father) mercy, would beg him (father) to go to Mr. Grey and ask for pardon for her (Alice).

``I should be very humble to him (man),'' (she)
she (Alice) said;
``but he (man) is so good, that I may dare to be humble before him (man).'' (she)
So she (Alice) waited for her (Alice) father. She (Alice) waited till twelve, till one, till two;--but still he (father) did not come. Later than that she (Alice) did not dare to wait for him (father). She (Alice) feared to trust him (father) on such business returning so late as that,--after so many cigars; after, perhaps, some superfluous beakers of club nectar. His (father) temper at such a moment would not be fit for such work as hers. But if he (father) was late in coming home, who had sent him (father) away from his (father) home in unhappiness? Between two and three she (Alice) went to bed, and on the following morning she (Alice) left Queen Anne Street for the Great Western Station before her (Alice) father was up.

CHAPTER XV.

Paramount Crescent.

Lady Macleod lived at No. 3, Paramount Crescent, in Cheltenham, where she (Macleod) occupied a very handsome first-floor drawing-room, with a bedroom behind it, looking over a stable-yard, and a small room which would have been the dressing-room had the late Sir Archibald been alive, but which was at present called the dining-room: and in it Lady Macleod did dine whenever her (Macleod) larger room was to be used for any purposes of evening company. The vicinity of the stable-yard was not regarded by the tenant as among the attractions of the house; but it had the effect of lowering the rent, and Lady Macleod was a woman who regarded such matters. Her (Macleod) income, though small, would have sufficed to enable her (Macleod) to live removed from such discomforts; but she (Macleod) was one of those women who regard it as a duty to leave something behind them,--even though it be left to those who do not at all want it; and Lady Macleod was a woman who wilfully neglected no duty. So she (Macleod) pinched herself, and inhaled the effluvia of the stables, and squabbled with the cabmen, in order that she (Macleod) might bequeath a thousand pounds or two to some Lady Midlothian, who cared, perhaps, little for her (Lady), and would hardly thank her (Lady) memory for the money.

Had Alice consented to live with her (Alice), she (Alice) would have merged that duty of leaving money behind her (Alice) in that other duty of finding a home for her (Alice) adopted niece. But Alice had gone away, and therefore the money was due to Lady Midlothian rather than to her (Lady). The saving, however, was postponed whenever Alice would consent to visit Cheltenham; and a bedroom was secured for her (Alice) which did not look out over the stables. Accommodation was also found for her (Alice) maid much better than that provided for Lady Macleod's own maid. She (Macleod) was a hospitable, good old woman, painfully struggling to do the best she (Macleod) could in the world. It was a pity that she (Macleod) was such a bore, a pity that she (Macleod) was so hard to cabmen and others, a pity that she (Macleod) suspected all tradesmen, servants, and people generally of a rank of life inferior to her (Macleod) own, a pity that she (Macleod) was disposed to condemn for ever and ever so many of her (Macleod) own rank because they played cards on week days, and did not go to church on Sundays,--and a pity, as I think above all, that while she (Macleod) was so suspicious of the poor she (Macleod) was so lenient to the vices of earls, earl's sons, and such like.

Alice, having fully considered the matter, had thought it most prudent to tell Lady Macleod by letter what she (Macleod) had done in regard to Mr. Grey. There had been many objections to the writing of such a letter, but there appeared to be stronger objection to that telling it face to face which would have been forced upon her (Macleod) had she (Macleod) not written. There would in such case have arisen on Lady Macleod's countenance a sternness of rebuke which Alice did not choose to encounter. The same sternness of rebuke would come upon the countenance on receipt of the written information; but it would come in its most aggravated form on the immediate receipt of the letter, and some of its bitterness would have passed away before Alice's arrival. I think that Alice was right. It is better for both parties that any great offence should be confessed by letter.

But Alice trembled as the cab drew up at No. 3, Paramount Crescent. She (Alice) met her (Alice) aunt, as was usual, just inside the drawing-room door, and she (Alice) saw at once that if any bitterness had passed away from that face, the original bitterness must indeed have been bitter. She (Alice) had so timed her (Alice) letter that Lady Macleod should have no opportunity of answering it. The answer was written there in the mingled anger and sorrow of those austere features.

``Alice!'' (she)
she (Macleod) said, as she (Macleod) took her (Macleod) niece in her (Macleod) arms and kissed her (Macleod);
``oh, Alice, what is this?'' (niece)

``Yes, aunt; it is very bad, I know,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
and poor Alice tried to make a jest of it.
``Young ladies are very wicked when they don't know their own minds. But if they haven't known them and have been wicked, what can they do but repent?'' (unknown)

``Repent!'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)
said Lady Macleod.
``Yes; I hope you will repent. Poor Mr. Grey;--what must he (Grey) think of it?'' (unknown)

``I can only hope, aunt, that he (Grey) won't think of it at all for very long.'' (unknown)

``That's nonsense, my dear, Of course he (Grey)'ll think of it, and of course you'll marry him (Grey).'' (unknown)

``Shall I, aunt?'' (unknown)

``Of course you will. Why, Alice, hasn't it been all settled among families? Lady Midlothian knew all the particulars of it just as well as I did. And is not your word pledged to him (Grey)? I really don't understand what you mean. I don't see how it is possible you should go back. Gentlemen when they do that kind of thing are put out of society;--but I really think it is worse in a woman.'' (unknown)

``Then they may if they please put me out of society;--only that I don't know that I'm particularly in it.'' (unknown)

``And the wickedness of the thing, Alice! I'm obliged to say so.'' (unknown)

``When you talk to me about society, aunt, and about Lady Midlothian, I give up to you, willingly;--the more willingly, perhaps, because I don't care much for one or the other.'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)
Here Lady Macleod tried to say a word; but she (Macleod) failed, and Alice went on, boldly looking up into her (Alice) aunt's face, which became a shade more bitter than ever.
``But when you tell me about wickedness and my conscience, then I must be my own judge. It is my conscience, and the fear of committing wickedness, that has made me do this.'' (unknown)

``You should submit to be guided by your elders, Alice.'' (unknown)

``No; my elders in such a matter as this cannot teach me. It cannot be right that I should go to a man's house and be his (man) wife, if I do not think that I can make him (man) happy.'' (unknown)

``Then why did you accept him (man)?'' (unknown)

``Because I was mistaken. I am not going to defend that. If you choose to scold me for that, you may do so, aunt, and I will not answer you. But as to marrying him (man) or not marrying him (man) now,--as to that, I must judge for myself.'' (unknown)

``It was a pity you did not know your own mind earlier.'' (unknown)

``It was a pity,--a great pity. I have done myself an injury that is quite irretrievable;--I know that, and am prepared to bear it. I have done him (man), too, an injustice which I regret with my whole heart. I can only excuse myself by saying that I might have done him (man) a worse injustice.'' (unknown)

All this was said at the very moment of her (Alice) arrival, and the greeting did not seem to promise much for the happiness of the next month; but perhaps it was better for them both that the attack and the defence should thus be made suddenly, at their first meeting. It is better to pull the string at once when you are in the shower-bath, and not to stand shivering, thinking of the inevitable shock which you can only postpone for a few minutes. Lady Macleod in this case had pulled the string, and thus reaped the advantage of her (Macleod) alacrity.

``Well, my dear,'' (ladyship)
said her (Macleod) ladyship,
``I suppose you will like to go up-stairs and take off your bonnet. Mary shall bring you some tea when you come down.'' (ladyship)
So Alice escaped, and when she (Alice) returned to the comfort of her (Alice) cup of tea in the drawing-room, the fury of the storm had passed away. She (Alice) sat talking of other things till dinner; and though Lady Macleod did during the evening make one allusion to
``poor Mr. Grey,'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)
the subject was allowed to drop. Alice was very tender as to her (Alice) aunt's ailments, was more than ordinarily attentive to the long list of Cheltenham iniquities which was displayed to her (Alice), and refrained from combating any of her (Alice) aunt's religious views. After a while they got upon the subject of Aunt Greenow, for whose name Lady Macleod had a special aversion,--as indeed she (Macleod) had for all the Vavasor side of Alice's family; and then Alice offered to read, and did read to her (Alice) aunt many pages out of one of those terrible books of wrath, which from time to time come forth and tell us that there is no hope for us. Lady Macleod liked to be so told; and as she (Macleod) now, poor woman, could not read at nights herself, she (Macleod) enjoyed her (Macleod) evening.

Lady Macleod no doubt did enjoy her (Macleod) niece's sojourn at Cheltenham, but I do not think it could have been pleasant to Alice. On the second day nothing was said about Mr. Grey, and Alice hoped that by her (Alice) continual readings in the book of wrath her (Alice) aunt's heart might be softened towards her (Alice). But it seemed that Lady Macleod measured the periods of respite, for on the third day and on the fifth she (Macleod) returned to the attack.

``Did John Grey still wish that the match should go on?'' (she)
she (Macleod) asked, categorically. It was in vain that Alice tried to put aside the question, and begged that the matter might not be discussed. Lady Macleod insisted on her (Macleod) right to carry on the examination, and Alice was driven to acknowledge that she (Alice) believed he (Grey) did wish it. She (Alice) could hardly say otherwise, seeing that she (Alice) had at that moment a letter from him (Grey) in her (Alice) pocket, in which he (Grey) still spoke of his (Grey) engagement as being absolutely binding on him (Grey), and expressed a hope that this change from London to Cheltenham would bring her (Alice) round and set everything to rights. He (Grey) certainly did, in a fashion, wave his (Grey) hand over her (Alice), as Kate had said of him (Grey). This letter Alice had resolved that she (Alice) would not answer. He (Grey) would probably write again, and she (Alice) would beg him (Grey) to desist. Instead of Cheltenham bringing her (Alice) round, Cheltenham had made her (Alice) firmer than ever in her (Alice) resolution. I am inclined to think that the best mode of bringing her (Alice) round at this moment would have been a course of visits from her (Alice) cousin George, and a series of letters from her (Alice) cousin Kate. Lady Macleod's injunctions would certainly not bring her (Macleod) round.

After ten days, ten terrible days, devoted to discussions on matrimony in the morning, and to the book of wrath in the evening,--relieved by two tea-parties, in which the sins of Cheltenham were discussed at length,--Lady Macleod herself got a letter from Mr. Grey. Mr. Grey's kindest compliments to Lady Macleod. He (Grey) believed that Lady Macleod was aware of the circumstances of his (Grey) engagement with Miss Vavasor. Might he (Grey) call on Miss Vavasor at Lady Macleod's house in Cheltenham? and might he (Grey) also hope to have the pleasure of making Lady Macleod's acquaintance? Alice had been in the room when her (Alice) aunt received this letter, but her (Alice) aunt had said nothing, and Alice had not known from whom the letter had come. When her (Alice) aunt crept away with it after breakfast she (Alice) had suspected nothing, and had never imagined that Lady Macleod, in the privacy of her (Macleod) own room looking out upon the stables, had addressed a letter to Nethercoats. But such a letter had been addressed to Nethercoats, and Mr. Grey had been informed that he (Grey) would be received in Paramount Crescent with great pleasure.

Mr. Grey had even indicated the day on which he (Grey) would come, and on the morning of that day Lady Macleod had presided over the two teacups in a state of nervous excitement which was quite visible to Alice. More than once Alice asked little questions, not supposing that she (Alice) was specially concerned in the matter which had caused her (Alice) aunt's fidgety restlessness, but observing it so plainly that it was almost impossible not to allude to it.

``There's nothing the matter, my dear, at all,'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)
at last Lady Macleod said; but as she (Macleod) said so she (Macleod) was making up her (Macleod) mind that the moment had not come in which she (Macleod) must apprise Alice of Mr. Grey's intended visit. As Alice had questioned her (Alice) at the breakfast table she (Alice) would say nothing about it then, but waited till the teacups were withdrawn, and till the maid had given her (maid) last officious poke to the fire. Then she (maid) began. She (maid) had Mr. Grey's letter in her (maid) pocket, and as she (maid) prepared herself to speak, she (maid) pulled it out and held it on the little table before her (maid).

``Alice,'' (she)
she (maid) said,
``I expect a visitor here to-day.'' (she)

Alice knew instantly who was the expected visitor. Probably any girl under such circumstances would have known equally well.

``A visitor, aunt,'' (she)
she (Alice) said, and managed to hide her (Alice) knowledge admirably.

``Yes, Alice a visitor. I should have told you before, only I thought,--I thought I had better not. It is Mr.--Mr. Grey.'' (unknown)

``Indeed, aunt! Is he (Grey) coming to see you?'' (unknown)

``Well;--he (Grey) is desirous no doubt of seeing you more especially; but he (Grey) has expressed a wish to make my acquaintance, which I cannot, under the circumstances, think is unnatural. Of course, Alice, he (Grey) must want to talk over this affair with your friends.'' (unknown)

``I wish I could have spared them,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice,--
``I wish I could.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``I have brought his (Grey) letter here, and you can see it if you please. It is very nicely written, and as far as I am concerned I should not think of refusing to see him (Grey). And now comes the question. What are we to do with him (Grey)? Am I to ask him (Grey) to dinner? I take it for granted that he (Grey) will not expect me to offer him (Grey) a bed, as he (Grey) knows that I live in lodgings.'' (unknown)

``Oh no, aunt; he (Grey) certainly will not expect that.'' (unknown)

``But ought I to ask him (Grey) to dinner? I should be most happy to entertain him (Grey), though you know how very scanty my means of doing so are;--but I really do not know how it might be,--between you and him (Grey), I mean.'' (unknown)

``We should not fight, aunt.'' (unknown)

``No, I suppose not;--but if you cannot be affectionate in your manner to him (Grey)--'' (unknown)

``I will not answer for my manners, aunt; but you may be sure of this,--that I should be affectionate in my heart. I shall always regard him (Grey) as a dearly loved friend; though for many years, no doubt, I shall be unable to express my friendship.'' (unknown)

``That may be all very well, Alice, but it will not be what he (Grey) will want. I think upon the whole that I had better not ask him (Grey) to dinner.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps not, aunt.'' (unknown)

``It is a period of the day in which any special constraint among people is more disagreeable than at any other time, and then at dinner the servants must see it. I think there might be some awkwardness if he (Grey) were to dine here.'' (unknown)

``I really think there would,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, anxious to have the subject dropped.

``I hope he (Grey) won't think that I am inhospitable. I should be so happy to do the best I could for him (Grey), for I regard him (Grey), Alice, quite as though he (Grey) were to be your husband. And when anybody at all connected with me has come to Cheltenham I always have asked them to dine, and then I have Gubbins's man to come and wait at table,--as you know.'' (unknown)

``Of all men in the world Mr. Grey is the last to think about it.'' (unknown)

``That should only make me the more careful. But I think it would perhaps be more comfortable if he (Grey) were to come in the evening.'' (unknown)

``Much more comfortable, aunt.'' (unknown)

``I suppose he (Grey) will be here in the afternoon, before dinner, and we had better wait at home for him (Grey). I dare say he (Grey)'ll want to see you alone, and therefore I'll retire to my own rooms,'' (unknown)
--looking over the stables! Dear old lady.
``But if you wish it, I will receive him (Grey) first--and then Martha,'' (Martha)
--Martha was Alice's maid--
``can fetch you down.'' (Martha Alice maid)

This discussion as to the propriety or impropriety of giving her (Alice) lover a dinner had not been pleasant to Alice, but, nevertheless, when it was over she (Alice) felt grateful to Lady Macleod. There was an attempt in the arrangement to make Mr. Grey's visit as little painful as possible; and though such a discussion at such a time might as well have been avoided, the decision to which her (Alice) ladyship had at last come with reference both to the dinner and the management of the visit was, no doubt, the right one.

Lady Macleod had been quite correct in all her (Macleod) anticipations. At three o'clock Mr. Grey was announced, and Lady Macleod, alone, received him (Grey) in her (Macleod) drawing-room. She (Macleod) had intended to give him (Grey) a great deal of good advice, to bid him (Grey) still keep up his (Grey) heart and as it were hold up his (Grey) head, to confess to him (Grey) how very badly Alice was behaving, and to express her (Alice) entire concurrence with that theory of bodily ailment as the cause and origin of her (Alice) conduct. But she (Alice) found that Mr. Grey was a man to whom she (Alice) could not give much advice. It was he (Grey) who did the speaking at this conference, and not she (Alice). She (Alice) was overawed by him (Grey) after the first three minutes. Indeed her (Alice) first glance at him (Grey) had awed her (Alice). He (Grey) was so handsome,--and then, in his (Grey) beauty, he (Grey) had so quiet and almost saddened an air! Strange to say that after she (Alice) had seen him (Grey), Lady Macleod entertained for him (Grey) an infinitely higher admiration than before, and yet she (Macleod) was less surprised than she (Macleod) had been at Alice's refusal of him (Grey). The conference was very short; and Mr. Grey had not been a quarter of an hour in the house before Martha attended upon her (Martha) mistress with her (Martha) summons.

Alice was ready and came down instantly. She (Alice) found Mr. Grey standing in the middle of the room waiting to receive her (Alice), and the look of majesty which had cowed Lady Macleod had gone from his (Grey) countenance. He (Grey) could not have received her (Macleod) with a kinder smile, had she (Macleod) come to him (Grey) with a promise that she (Macleod) would at this meeting name the day for their marriage.

``At any rate it does not make him (Grey) unhappy,'' (she)
she (Macleod) said to herself.

``You are not angry,'' (he)
he (Grey) said,
``that I should have followed you all the way here, to see you.'' (he)

``No, certainly; not angry, Mr. Grey. All anger that there may be between us must be on your side. I feel that thoroughly.'' (unknown)

``Then there shall be none on either side. Whatever may be done, I will not be angry with you. Your father advised me to come down here to you.'' (unknown)

``You have seen him (father), then?'' (unknown)

``Yes, I have seen him (father). I was in London the day you left.'' (unknown)

``It is so terrible to think that I should have brought upon you all this trouble.'' (unknown)

``You will bring upon me much worse trouble than that unless--. But I have not now come down here to tell you that. I believe that according to rule in such matters I should not have come to you at all, but I don't know that I care much about such rules.'' (unknown)

``It is I that have broken all rules.'' (unknown)

``When a lady tells a gentleman that she (lady) does not wish to see more of him (gentleman)--'' (unknown)

``Oh, Mr. Grey, I have not told you that.'' (unknown)

``Have you not? I am glad at any rate to hear you deny it. But you will understand what I mean. When a gentleman gets his (gentleman) dismissal from a lady he (gentleman) should accept it,--that is, his (gentleman) dismissal under such circumstances as I have received mine. But I cannot lay down my love in that way; nor, maintaining my love, can I give up the battle. It seems to me that I have a right at any rate to know something of your comings and goings as long as,--unless, Alice, you should take another name than mine.'' (unknown)

``My intention is to keep my own.'' (she)
This she (Macleod) said in the lowest possible tone,--almost in a whisper,--with her (Macleod) eyes fixed upon the ground.

``And you will not deny me that right?'' (unknown)

``I cannot hinder you. Whatever you may do, I myself have sinned so against you that I can have no right to blame you.'' (unknown)

``There shall be no question between us of injury from one to the other. In any conversation that we may have, or in any correspondence--'' (unknown)

``Oh, Mr. Grey, do not ask me to write.'' (unknown)

``Listen to me. Should there be any on either side, there shall be no idea of any wrong done.'' (unknown)

``But I have done you wrong;--great wrong.'' (unknown)

``No, Alice; I will not have it so. When I asked you to accept my hand,--begging the greatest boon which it could ever come to my lot to ask from a fellow-mortal,--I knew well how great was your goodness to me when you told me that it should be mine. Now that you refuse it, I know also that you are good, thinking that in doing so you are acting for my welfare,--thinking more of my welfare than of your own.'' (unknown)

``Oh yes, yes; it is so, Mr. Grey; indeed it is so.'' (unknown)

``Believing that, how can I talk of wrong? That you are wrong in your thinking on this subject,--that your mind has become twisted by false impressions,--that I believe. But I cannot therefore love you less,--nor, so believing, can I consider myself to be injured. Nor am I even so little selfish as you are. I think if you were my wife that I could make you happy; but I feel sure that my happiness depends on your being my wife.'' (She)

She (Macleod) looked up into his (Grey) face, but it was still serene in all its manly beauty. Her (Macleod) cousin George, if he (George) were moved to strong feeling, showed it at once in his (George) eyes,--in his (George) mouth, in the whole visage of his (George) countenance. He (George) glared in his (George) anger, and was impassioned in his (George) love. But Mr. Grey when speaking of the happiness of his (Grey) entire life, when confessing that it was now at stake with a decision against him (Grey) that would be ruinous to it, spoke without a quiver in his (Grey) voice, and had no more sign of passion in his (Grey) face than if he (Grey) were telling his (Grey) gardener to move a rose tree.

``I hope--and believe that you will find your happiness elsewhere, Mr. Grey.'' (unknown)

``Well; we can but differ, Alice. In that we do differ. And now I will say one word to explain why I have come here. If I were to write to you against your will, it would seem that I were persecuting you. I cannot bring myself to do that, even though I had the right. But if I were to let you go from me, taking what you have said to me and doing nothing, it would seem that I had accepted your decision as final. I do not do so. I will not do so. I come simply to tell you that I am still your suitor. If you will let me, I will see you again early in January,--as soon as you have returned to town. You will hardly refuse to see me.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (she)
she (Grey) said;
``I cannot refuse to see you.'' (she)

``Then it shall be so,'' (he)
he (Grey) said,
``and I will not trouble you with letters, nor will I trouble you longer now with words. Tell your aunt that I have said what I came to say, and that I give her (aunt) my kindest thanks.'' (he)
Then he (Grey) took her (Grey) hand and pressed it,--not as George Vavasor had pressed it,--and was gone. When Lady Macleod returned, she (Macleod) found that the question of the evening's tea arrangements had settled itself.

CHAPTER XVI.

The Roebury Club.

It has been said that George Vavasor had a little establishment at Roebury, down in Oxfordshire, and thither he (Vavasor) betook himself about the middle of November. He (Vavasor) had been long known in this county, and whether or no men spoke well of him (Vavasor) as a man of business in London, men spoke well of him (Vavasor) down there, as one who knew how to ride to hounds. Not that Vavasor was popular among fellow-sportsmen. It was quite otherwise. He (Vavasor) was not a man that made himself really popular in any social meetings of men. He (Vavasor) did not himself care for the loose little talkings, half flat and half sharp, of men when they meet together in idleness. He (Vavasor) was not open enough in his (Vavasor) nature for such popularity. Some men were afraid of him (Vavasor), and some suspected him (Vavasor). There were others who made up to him (Vavasor), seeking his (Vavasor) intimacy, but these he (Vavasor) usually snubbed, and always kept at a distance. Though he (Vavasor) had indulged in all the ordinary pleasures of young men, he (Vavasor) had never been a jovial man. In his (Vavasor) conversations with men he (Vavasor) always seemed to think that he (Vavasor) should use his (Vavasor) time towards serving some purpose of business. With women he (Vavasor) was quite the reverse. With women he (Vavasor) could be happy. With women he (Vavasor) could really associate. A woman he (Vavasor) could really love;--but I doubt whether for all that he (Vavasor) could treat a woman well.

But he (Vavasor) was known in the Oxfordshire country as a man who knew what he (Vavasor) was about, and such men are always welcome. It is the man who does not know how to ride that is made uncomfortable in the hunting field by cold looks or expressed censure. And yet it is very rarely that such men do any real harm. Such a one may now and then get among the hounds or override the hunt, but it is not often so. Many such complaints are made; but in truth the too forward man, who presses the dogs, is generally one who can ride, but is too eager or too selfish to keep in his (man) proper place. The bad rider, like the bad whist player, pays highly for what he (man) does not enjoy, and should be thanked. But at both games he (man) gets cruelly snubbed. At both games George Vavasor was great and he (Vavasor) never got snubbed.

There were men who lived together at Roebury in a kind of club,--four or five of them, who came thither from London, running backwards and forwards as hunting arrangements enabled them to do so,--a brewer or two and a banker, with a would-be fast attorney, a sporting literary gentleman, and a young unmarried Member of Parliament who had no particular home of his (Member) own in the country. These men formed the Roebury Club, and a jolly life they had of it. They had their own wine closet at the King's Head,--or Roebury Inn as the house had come to be popularly called,--and supplied their own game. The landlord found everything else; and as they were not very particular about their bills, they were allowed to do pretty much as they liked in the house. They were rather imperious, very late in their hours, sometimes, though not often, noisy, and once there had been a hasty quarrel which had made the landlord in his (King) anger say that the club should be turned out of his (King) house. But they paid well, chaffed the servants much oftener than they bullied them, and on the whole were very popular.

To this club Vavasor did not belong, alleging that he (King) could not afford to live at their pace, and alleging, also, that his (King) stays at Roebury were not long enough to make him (King) a desirable member. The invitation to him (King) was not repeated and he (King) lodged elsewhere in the little town. But he (King) occasionally went in of an evening, and would make up with the members a table at whist.

He (King) had come down to Roebury by mail train, ready for hunting the next morning, and walked into the club-room just at midnight. There he (King) found Maxwell the banker, Grindley the would-be fast attorney, and Calder Jones the Member of Parliament, playing dummy. Neither of the brewers were there, nor was the sporting literary gentleman.

``Here's Vavasor,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell,
``and now we won't play this blackguard game any longer. Somebody told me, Vavasor, that you were gone away.'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)

``Gone away;--what, like a fox?'' (unknown)

``I don't know what it was; that something had happened to you since last season; that you were married, or dead, or gone abroad. By George, I've lost the trick after all! I hate dummy like the devil. I never hold a card in dummy's hand. Yes, I know; that's seven points on each side. Vavasor, come and cut. Upon my word if any one had asked me, I should have said you were dead.'' (unknown)

``But you see, nobody ever does think of asking you anything.'' (unknown)

``What you probably mean,'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)
said Grindley,
``is that Vavasor was not returned for Chelsea last February; but you've seen him (devil) since that. Are you going to try it again, Vavasor?'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)

``If you'll lend me the money I will.'' (unknown)

``I don't see what on earth a man gains by going into the house,'' (Calder Jones/Jones)
said Calder Jones.
``I couldn't help myself as it happened, but, upon my word it's a deuce of a bore. A fellow thinks he (man) can do as he (man) likes about going,--but he (man) can't. It wouldn't do for me to give it up, because--'' (unknown)

``Oh no, of course not; where should we all be?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor.

``It's you and me, Grindems,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell.
``D-- parliament, and now let's have a rubber.'' (Mr.)

They played till three and Mr. Calder Jones lost a good deal of money,--a good deal of money in a little way, for they never played above ten-shilling points, and no bet was made for more than a pound or two. But Vavasor was the winner, and when he (winner) left the room he (winner) became the subject of some ill-natured remarks.

``I wonder he (man) likes coming in here,'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)
said Grindley, who had himself been the man to invite him (Grindley) to belong to the club, and who had at one time indulged the ambition of an intimacy with George Vavasor.

``I can't understand it,'' (Calder Jones/Jones)
said Calder Jones, who was a little bitter about his (Jones) money.
``Last year he (man) seemed to walk in just when he (man) liked, as though he (man) were one of us.'' (unknown)

``He (man)'s a bad sort of fellow,'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)
said Grindley;
``he (man)'s so uncommonly dark. I don't know where on earth he (man) gets his (man) money from, He (man) was heir to some small property in the north, but he (man) lost every shilling of that when he (man) was in the wine trade.'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)

``You're wrong there, Grindems,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell,--making use of a playful nickname which he (Grindley) had invented for his (Grindley) friend.
``He (man) made a pot of money at the wine business, and had he (man) stuck to it he (man) would have been a rich man.'' (unknown)

``He (man)'s lost it all since then, and that place in the north into the bargain.'' (unknown)

``Wrong again, Grindems, my boy. If old Vavasor were to die to-morrow, Vavasor Hall would go just as he (Hall) might choose to leave it. George may be a ruined man for aught I know--'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)

``There's no doubt about that, I believe,'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)
said Grindley.

``Perhaps not, Grindems; but he (George) can't have lost Vavasor Hall because he (George) has never as yet had an interest in it. He (George)'s the natural heir, and will probably get it some day.'' (unknown)

``All the same,'' (Calder Jones/Jones)
said Calder Jones,
``isn't it rather odd he (George) should come in here?'' (Calder Jones/Jones)

``We've asked him (George) often enough,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell;
``not because we like him (George), but because we want him (George) so often to make up a rubber. I don't like George Vavasor, and I don't know who does; but I like him (Vavasor) better than dummy. And I'd sooner play whist with men I don't like, Grindems, than I'd not play at all.'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
A bystander might have thought from the tone of Mr. Maxwell's voice that he (Maxwell) was alluding to Mr. Grindley himself, but Mr. Grindley didn't seem to take it in that light.

``That's true, of course,'' (he)
said he (Grindley).
``We can't pick men just as we please. But I certainly didn't think that he (Vavasor)'d make it out for another season.'' (unknown)

The club breakfasted the next morning at nine o'clock, in order that they might start at half-past for the meet at Edgehill. Edgehill is twelve miles from Roebury, and the hacks would do it in an hour and a half,--or perhaps a little less.

``Does anybody know anything about that brown horse of Vavasor's?'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell.
``I saw him (Vavasor) coming into the yard yesterday with that old groom of his (Vavasor).'' (unknown)

``He (Vavasor) had a brown horse last season,'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)
said Grindley;--
``a little thing that went very fast, but wasn't quite sound on the road.'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)

``That was a mare,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell,
``and he (Vavasor) sold her (mare) to Cinquebars.'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
*

-LSB-*Ah, my friend, from whom I have borrowed this scion of the nobility! Had he (Maxwell) been left with us he (Maxwell) would have forgiven me my little theft, and now that he (Maxwell) has gone I will not change the name.-RSB-

``For a hundred and fifty,'' (Calder Jones/Jones)
said Calder Jones,
``and she (mare) wasn't worth the odd fifty.'' (Calder Jones/Jones)

``He (Vavasor) won seventy with her (mare) at Leamington,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell,
``and I doubt whether he (Vavasor)'d take his (Vavasor) money now.'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)

``Is Cinquebars coming down here this year?'' (unknown)

``I don't know,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell.
``I hope not. He (Vavasor)'s the best fellow in the world, but he (Vavasor) can't ride, and he (Vavasor) don't care for hunting, and he (Vavasor) makes more row than any fellow I ever met. I wish some fellow could tell me something about that fellow's brown horse.'' (unknown)

``I'd never buy a horse of Vavasor's if I were you,'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)
said Grindley.
``He (fellow) never has anything that's all right all round.'' (unknown)

``And who has?'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell, as he (Maxwell) took into his (Maxwell) plate a second mutton chop, which had just been brought up hot into the room especially for him (Maxwell).
``That's the mistake men make about horses, and that's why there's so much cheating. I never ask for a warranty with a horse, and don't very often have a horse examined. Yet I do as well as others. You can't have perfect horses any more than you can perfect men, or perfect women. You put up with red hair, or bad teeth, or big feet,--or sometimes with the devil of a voice. But a man when he (man) wants a horse won't put up with anything! Therefore those who've got horses to sell must lie. When I go into the market with three hundred pounds I expect a perfect animal. As I never do that now I never expect a perfect animal. I like 'em to see; I like 'em to have four legs; and I like 'em to have a little wind. I don't much mind anything else.'' (unknown)

``By Jove you're about right,'' (Calder Jones/Jones)
said Calder Jones. The reader will therefore readily see that Mr. Maxwell the banker reigned as king in that club.

Vavasor had sent two horses on in charge of Bat Smithers, and followed on a pony about fourteen hands high, which he (Smithers) had ridden as a cover hack for the last four years. He (Smithers) did not start till near ten, but he (Smithers) was able to catch Bat with his (Smithers) two horses about a mile and a half on that side of Edgehill.

``Have you managed to come along pretty clean?'' (the master)
the master asked as he (master) came up with his (master) servant.

``They be the most beastly roads in all England,'' (he)
said Bat, who always found fault with any county in which he (master) happened to be located.
``But I'll warrant I'm cleaner than most on 'em. What for any county should make such roads as them I never could tell.'' (unknown)

``The roads about there are bad, certainly;--very bad. But I suppose they would have been better had Providence sent better materials. And what do you think of the brown horse, Bat?'' (unknown)

``Well, sir.'' (He)
He (master) said no more, and that he (master) said with a drawl.

``He (them)'s as fine an animal to look at as ever I put my eye on,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``He (them)'s all that,'' (unknown)
said Bat.

``He (them)'s got lots of pace too.'' (unknown)

``I'm sure he (them) has, sir.'' (unknown)

``And they tell me you can't beat him (them) at jumping.'' (unknown)

``They can mostly do that, sir, if they're well handled.'' (unknown)

``You see he (them)'s a deal over my weight.'' (unknown)

``Yes, he (them) is, Mr. Vavasor. He (Vavasor) is a fourteen stoner.'' (unknown)

``Or fifteen,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor.

``Perhaps he (Vavasor) may, sir. There's no knowing what a `orse can carry till he (Vavasor)'s tried.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

George asked his (George) groom no more questions, but felt sure that he (George) had better sell his (George) brown horse if he (George) could. Now I here protest that there was nothing specially amiss with the brown horse. Towards the end of the preceding season he (George) had overreached himself and had been lame, and had been sold by some owner with more money than brains who had not cared to wait for a cure. Then there had gone with him (owner) a bad character, and a vague suspicion had attached itself to him (owner), as there does to hundreds of horses which are very good animals in their way. He (owner) had come thus to Tattersall's, and Vavasor had bought him (owner) cheap, thinking that he (owner) might make money of him (owner), from his (owner) form and action. He (owner) had found nothing amiss with him (owner),--nor, indeed, had Bat Smithers. But his (Smithers) character went with him (Smithers), and therefore Bat Smithers thought it well to be knowing. George Vavasor knew as much of horses as most men can,--as, perhaps, as any man can who is not a dealer, or a veterinary surgeon; but he (surgeon), like all men, doubted his (surgeon) own knowledge, though on that subject he (surgeon) would never admit that he (surgeon) doubted it. Therefore he (surgeon) took Bat's word and felt sure that the horse was wrong.

``We shall have a run from the big wood,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``If they make un break, you will, sir,'' (unknown)
said Bat.

``At any rate I'll ride the brown horse,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George. Then, as soon as that was settled between them, the Roebury Club overtook them.

There was now a rush of horses on the road altogether, and they were within a quarter of a mile of Edgehill church, close to which was the meet. Bat with his (George) two hunters fell a little behind, and the others trotted on together. The other grooms with their animals were on in advance, and were by this time employed in combing out forelocks, and rubbing stirrup leathers and horses' legs free from the dirt of the roads;--but Bat Smithers was like his (Smithers) master, and did not congregate much with other men, and Vavasor was sure to give orders to his (Smithers) servant different from the orders given by others.

``Are you well mounted this year?'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
Maxwell asked of George Vavasor.

``No, indeed; I never was what I call well mounted yet. I generally have one horse and three or four cripples. That brown horse behind there is pretty good, I believe.'' (unknown)

``I see your man has got the old chestnut mare with him (man).'' (unknown)

``She (mare)'s one of the cripples,--not but what she (mare)'s as sound as a bell, and as good a hunter as ever I wish to ride; but she (mare) makes a little noise when she (mare)'s going.'' (unknown)

``So that you can hear her (mare) three fields off,'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)
said Grindley.

``Five if the fields are small enough and your ears are sharp enough,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor.
``All the same I wouldn't change her (mare) for the best horse I ever saw under you.'' (unknown)

``Had you there, Grindems,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell.

``No, he (hunter) didn't,'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)
said Grindley.
``He (hunter) didn't have me at all.'' (unknown)

``Your horses, Grindley, are always up to all the work they have to do,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George;
``and I don't know what any man wants more than that.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

``Had you again, Grindems,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell.

``I can ride against him (man) any day,'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)
said Grindley.

``Yes; or against a brick wall either, if your horse didn't know any better,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``Had you again, Grindems,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell. Whereupon Mr. Grindley trotted on, round the corner by the church, and into the field in which the hounds were assembled. The fire had become too hot for him (Grindley), and he (Grindley) thought it best to escape. Had it been Vavasor alone he (Grindley) would have turned upon him (Grindley) and snarled, but he (Grindley) could not afford to exhibit any ill temper to the king of the club. Mr. Grindley was not popular, and were Maxwell to turn openly against him (Maxwell) his (Maxwell) sporting life down at Roebury would decidedly be a failure.

The lives of such men as Mr. Grindley,--men who are tolerated in the daily society of others who are accounted their superiors, do not seem to have many attractions. And yet how many such men does one see in almost every set? Why Mr. Grindley should have been inferior to Mr. Maxwell the banker, or to Stone, or to Prettyman who were brewers, or even to Mr. Pollock the heavy-weight literary gentleman, I can hardly say. An attorney by his (attorney) trade is at any rate as good as a brewer, and there are many attorneys who hold their heads high anywhere. Grindley was a rich man,--or at any rate rich enough for the life he (Grindley) led. I don't know much about his (Grindley) birth, but I believe it was as good as Maxwell's. He (Maxwell) was not ignorant, or a fool;--whereas I rather think Maxwell was a fool. Grindley had made his (Grindley) own way in the world, but Maxwell would certainly not have made himself a banker if his (Maxwell) father had not been a banker before him (Maxwell); nor could the bank have gone on and prospered had there not been partners there who were better men of business than our friend. Grindley knew that he (Grindley) had a better intellect than Maxwell; and yet he (Grindley) allowed Maxwell to snub him (Maxwell), and he (Maxwell) toadied Maxwell in return. It was not on the score of riding that Maxwell claimed and held his (Maxwell) superiority, for Grindley did not want pluck, and every one knew that Maxwell had lived freely and that his (Maxwell) nerves were not what they had been. I think it had come from the outward look of the men, from the form of each, from the gait and visage which in one was good and in the other insignificant. The nature of such dominion of man over man is very singular, but this is certain that when once obtained in manhood it may be easily held.

Among boys at school the same thing is even more conspicuous, because boys have less of conscience than men, are more addicted to tyranny, and when weak are less prone to feel the misery and disgrace of succumbing. Who has been through a large school and does not remember the Maxwells and Grindleys,--the tyrants and the slaves,--those who domineered and those who submitted? Nor was it, even then, personal strength, nor always superior courage, that gave the power of command. Nor was it intellect, or thoughtfulness, nor by any means such qualities as make men and boys lovable. It is said by many who have had to deal with boys, that certain among them claim and obtain ascendancy by the spirit within them; but I doubt whether the ascendancy is not rather thrust on them than claimed by them. Here again I think the outward gait of the boy goes far towards obtaining for him (boy) the submission of his (boy) fellows.

But the tyrant boy does not become the tyrant man, or the slave boy the slave man, because the outward visage, that has been noble or mean in the one, changes and becomes so often mean or noble in the other.

``By George, there's Pollock!'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell, as he (Maxwell) rode into the field by the church.
``I'll bet half a crown that he (Pollock)'s come down from London this morning, that he (Pollock) was up all night last night, and that he (Pollock) tells us so three times before the hounds go out of the paddock.'' (Pollock/Mr. Pollock)
Mr. Pollock was the heavy-weight sporting literary gentleman.

CHAPTER XVII.

Edgehill.

Of all sights in the world there is, I think, none more beautiful than that of a pack of fox-hounds seated, on a winter morning, round the huntsman, if the place of meeting has been chosen with anything of artistic skill. It should be in a grassy field, and the field should be small. It should not be absolutely away from all buildings, and the hedgerows should not have been clipped and pared, and made straight with reference to modern agricultural economy. There should be trees near, and the ground should be a little uneven, so as to mark some certain small space as the exact spot where the dogs and servants of the hunt should congregate.

There are well-known grand meets in England, in the parks of noblemen, before their houses, or even on what are called their lawns; but these magnificent affairs have but little of the beauty of which I speak. Such assemblies are too grand and too ornate, and, moreover, much too far removed from true sporting proprieties. At them, equipages are shining, and ladies' dresses are gorgeous, and crowds of tradesmen from the neighbouring town have come there to look at the grand folk. To my eye there is nothing beautiful in that. The meet I speak of is arranged with a view to sport, but the accident of the locality may make it the prettiest thing in the world.

Such, in a special degree, was the case at Edgehill. At Edgehill the whole village consisted of three or four cottages; but there was a small old church, with an old grey tower, and a narrow, green, almost dark, churchyard, surrounded by elm-trees. The road from Roebury to the meet passed by the church stile, and turning just beyond it came upon the gate which led into the little field in which the hounds felt themselves as much at home as in their kennels. There might be six or seven acres in the field, which was long and narrow, so that the huntsman had space to walk leisurely up and down with the pack clustering round him (huntsman), when he (huntsman) considered that longer sitting might chill them. The church tower was close at hand, visible through the trees, and the field itself was green and soft, though never splashing with mud or heavy with holes.

Edgehill was a favourite meet in that country, partly because foxes were very abundant in the great wood adjacent, partly because the whole country around is grass-land, and partly, no doubt, from the sporting propensities of the neighbouring population. As regards my own taste, I do not know that I do like beginning a day with a great wood,--and if not beginning it, certainly not ending it. It is hard to come upon the cream of hunting, as it is upon the cream of any other delight. Who can always drink Lafitte of the finest, can always talk to a woman who is both beautiful and witty, or can always find the right spirit in the poetry he (cream) reads? A man has usually to work through much mud before he (cream) gets his (cream) nugget. It is so certainly in hunting, and a big wood too frequently afflicts the sportsman, as the mud does the miner. The small gorse cover is the happy, much-envied bit of ground in which the gold is sure to show itself readily. But without the woods the gorse would not hold the foxes, and without the mud the gold would not have found its resting-place.

But, as I have said, Edgehill was a popular meet, and, as regarded the meet itself, was eminently picturesque. On the present occasion the little field was full of horsemen, moving about slowly, chatting together, smoking cigars, getting off from their hacks and mounting their hunters, giving orders to their servants, and preparing for the day. There were old country gentlemen there, greeting each other from far sides of the county; sporting farmers who love to find themselves alongside their landlords, and to feel that the pleasures of the country are common to both; men down from town, like our friends of the Roebury club, who made hunting their chosen pleasure, and who formed, in number, perhaps the largest portion of the field; officers from garrisons round about; a cloud of servants, and a few nondescript stragglers who had picked up horses, hither and thither, round the country. Outside the gate on the road were drawn up a variety of vehicles, open carriages, dog-carts, gigs, and waggonettes, in some few of which were seated ladies who had come over to see the meet. But Edgehill was, essentially, not a ladies' meet. The distances to it were long, and the rides in Cranby Wood--the big wood--were not adapted for wheels. There were one or two ladies on horseback, as is always the case; but Edgehill was not a place popular, even with hunting ladies. One carriage, that of the old master of the hounds, had entered the sacred precincts of the field, and from this the old baronet was just descending, as Maxwell, Calder Jones, and Vavasor rode into the field.

-LSB-Illustration: Edgehill.-RSB-

``I hope I see you well, Sir William,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell, greeting the master. Calder Jones also made his (Jones) little speech, and so did Vavasor.

``Humph--well, yes, I'm pretty well, thank`ee. Just move on, will you? My mare can't stir here.'' (him)
Then some one else spoke to him (Jones), and he (Jones) only grunted in answer. Having slowly been assisted up on to his (Jones) horse,--for he (Jones) was over seventy years of age,--he (Jones) trotted off to the hounds, while all the farmers round him (Jones) touched their hats to him (Jones). But his (Jones) mind was laden with affairs of import, and he (Jones) noticed no one. In a whispered voice he (Jones) gave his (Jones) instructions to his (Jones) huntsman, who said,
``Yes, Sir William,'' (huntsman)
``No, Sir William,'' (huntsman)
``No doubt, Sir William.'' (huntsman)
One long-eared, long-legged fellow, in a hunting-cap and scarlet coat, hung listening by, anxious to catch something of the orders for the morning.
``Who the devil's that fellow, that's all breeches and boots?'' (William)
said Sir William aloud to some one near him (William), as the huntsman moved off with the hounds. Sir William knew the man well enough, but was minded to punish him (William) for his (William) discourtesy.
``Where shall we find first, Sir William?'' (Calder Jones/Jones)
said Calder Jones, in a voice that was really very humble.
``How the mischief am I to know where the foxes are?'' (William)
said Sir William, with an oath; and Calder Jones retired unhappy, and for the moment altogether silenced.

And yet Sir William was the most popular man in the county, and no more courteous gentleman ever sat at the bottom of his (William) own table. A mild man he (William) was, too, when out of his (William) saddle, and one by no means disposed to assume special supremacy. But a master of hounds, if he (master) have long held the country,--and Sir William had held his (William) for more than thirty years,--obtains a power which that of no other potentate can equal. He (William) may say and do what he (William) pleases, and his (William) tyranny is always respected. No conspiracy against him (William) has a chance of success; no sedition will meet with sympathy;--that is, if he (William) be successful in showing sport. If a man be sworn at, abused, and put down without cause, let him (man) bear it and think that he (man) has been a victim for the public good. And let him (man) never be angry with the master. That rough tongue is the necessity of the master's position. They used to say that no captain could manage a ship without swearing at his (captain) men. But what are the captain's troubles in comparison with those of the master of hounds? The captain's men are under discipline, and can be locked up, flogged, or have their grog stopped.
