The master of hounds cannot stop the grog of any offender, and he (master) can only stop the tongue, or horse, of such an one by very sharp words.

``Well, Pollock, when did you come?'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell.

``By George,'' (the gentleman)
said the literary gentleman,
``just down from London by the 8.30 from Euston Square, and got over here from Winslow in a trap, with two fellows I never saw in my life before. We came tandem in a fly, and did the nineteen miles in an hour.'' (the gentleman)

``Come, Athenian, draw it mild,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell.

``We did, indeed. I wonder whether they'll pay me their share of the fly. I had to leave Onslow Crescent at a quarter before eight, and I did three hours' work before I started.'' (unknown)

``Then you did it by candle-light,'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)
said Grindley.

``Of course I did; and why shouldn't I? Do you suppose no one can work by candle-light except a lawyer? I suppose you fellows were playing whist, and drinking hard. I'm uncommon glad I wasn't with you, for I shall be able to ride.'' (unknown)

``I bet you a pound,'' (Mrs. Jones/Jones)
said Jones,
``if there's a run, I see more of it than you.'' (Mrs. Jones/Jones)

``I'll take that bet with Jones,'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)
said Grindley,
``and Vavasor shall be the judge.'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)

``Gentlemen, the hounds can't get out, if you will stop up the gate,'' (William)
said Sir William. Then the pack passed through, and they all trotted on for four miles, to Cranby Wood.

Vavasor, as he (Wood) rode on to the wood, was alone, or speaking, from time to time, a few words to his (Wood) servant.

``I'll ride the chestnut mare in the wood,'' (he)
he (Wood) said,
``and do you keep near me.'' (he)

``I bean't to be galloping up and down them rides, I suppose,'' (unknown)
said Bat, almost contemptuously.

``I shan't gallop up and down the rides, myself; but do you mark me, to know where I am, so that I can change if a fox should go away.'' (unknown)

``You'll be here all day, sir. That's my belief.'' (unknown)

``If so, I won't ride the brown horse at all. But do you take care to let me have him (fox) if there's a chance. Do you understand?'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes, I understand, sir. There ain't no difficulty in my understanding;--only I don't think, sir, you'll ever get a fox out of that wood to-day. Why, it stands to reason. The wind's from the north-east.'' (Cranby Wood)

Cranby Wood is very large,--there being, in truth, two or three woods together. It was nearly twelve before they found; and then for an hour there was great excitement among the men, who rode up and down the rides as the hounds drove the fox from one end to another of the enclosure. Once or twice the poor animal did try to go away, and then there was great hallooing, galloping, and jumping over unnecessary fences; but he (fox) was headed back again, or changed his (fox) mind, not liking the north-east wind of which Bat Smithers had predicted such bad things. After one the crowd of men became rather more indifferent, and clustered together in broad spots, eating their lunch, smoking cigars, and chaffing each other. It was singular to observe the amazing quantity of ham sandwiches and of sherry that had been carried into Cranby Wood on that day. Grooms appeared to have been laden with cases, and men were as well armed with flasks at their saddle-bows as they used to be with pistols. Maxwell and Pollock formed the centre of one of these crowds, and chaffed each other with the utmost industry, till, tired of having inflicted no wounds, they turned upon Grindley and drove him (Grindley) out of the circle.

``You'll make that man cut his (man) throat, if you go on at that,'' (Pollock/Mr. Pollock)
said Pollock.
``Shall I?'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell.
``Then I'll certainly stick to him (man) for the sake of humanity in general.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
During all this time Vavasor sat apart, quite alone, and Bat Smithers grimly kept his (Smithers) place, about three hundred yards from him (Smithers).

``We shan't do any good to-day,'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)
said Grindley, coming up to Vavasor.

``I'm sure I don't know,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor.

``That old fellow has got to be so stupid, he (fellow) doesn't know what he (fellow)'s about,'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)
said Grindley, meaning Sir William.

``How can he (fellow) make the fox break?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor; and as his (Grindley) voice was by no means encouraging Grindley rode away.

Lunch and cigars lasted till two, during which hour the hounds, the huntsmen, the whips, and old Sir William were hard at work, as also were some few others who persistently followed every chance of the game. From that till three there were two or three flashes in the pan, and false reports as to foxes which had gone away, which first set men galloping, and then made them very angry. After three, men began to say naughty things, to abuse Cranby Wood, to wish violently that they had remained at home or gone elsewhere, and to speak irreverently of their ancient master.

``It's the cussidest place in all creation,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell.
``I often said I'd not come here any more, and now I say it again.'' (unknown)

``And yet you'll be here the next meet,'' (Grindley/Mr. Grindley)
said Grindley, who had sneaked back to his (Grindley) old companions in weariness of spirit.

``Grindems, you know a sight too much,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell;
``you do indeed. An ordinary fellow has no chance with you.'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)

Grindley was again going to catch it, but was on this time saved by the appearance of the huntsman, who came galloping up one of the rides, with a lot of the hounds at his (Grindley) heels.

``He (fellow) isn't away, Tom, surely?'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell.

``He (fellow)'s out of the wood somewheres,'' (Tom)
said Tom;--and off they all went. Vavasor changed his (Maxwell) horse, getting on to the brown one, and giving up his (Maxwell) chestnut mare to Bat Smithers, who suggested that he (Maxwell) might as well go home to Roebury now. Vavasor gave him (Maxwell) no answer, but, trotting on to the point where the rides met, stopped a moment and listened carefully. Then he (Maxwell) took a path diverging away from that by which the huntsmen and the crowd of horsemen had gone, and made the best of his (Maxwell) way through the wood. At the end of this he (Maxwell) came upon Sir William, who, with no one near him (William) but his (William) servant, was standing in the pathway of a little hunting-gate.

``Hold hard,'' (William)
said Sir William.
``The hounds are not out of the wood yet.'' (unknown)

``Is the fox away, sir?'' (unknown)

``What's the good of that if we can't get the hounds out?--Yes, he (fox)'s away. He (fox) passed out where I'm standing.'' (he)
And then he (William) began to blow his (William) horn lustily, and by degrees other men and a few hounds came down the ride. Then Tom, with his (Tom) horse almost blown, made his (Tom) appearance outside the wood, and soon there came a rush of men, nearly on the top of one another, pushing on, not knowing whither, but keenly alive to the fact that the fox had at last consented to move his (fox) quarters.

Tom touched his (Tom) hat, and looked at his (Tom) master, inquiringly.

``He (fox)'s gone for Claydon's,'' (the master)
said the master.
``Try them up that hedgerow.'' (Tom)
Tom did try them up the hedgerow, and in half a minute the hounds came upon the scent. Then you might see men settling their hats on their heads, and feeling their feet in the stirrups. The moment for which they had so long waited had come, and yet there were many who would now have preferred that the fox should be headed back into cover. Some had but little confidence in their half-blown horses;--with many the waiting, though so abused and anathematized, was in truth more to their taste than the run itself;--with others the excitement had gone by, and a gallop over a field or two was necessary before it would be restored. With most men at such a moment there is a little nervousness, some fear of making a bad start, a dread lest others should have more of the success of the hunt than falls to them. But there was a great rush and a mighty bustle as the hounds made out their game, and Sir William felt himself called upon to use the rough side of his (William) tongue to more than one delinquent.

And then certain sly old stagers might be seen turning off to the left, instead of following the course of the game as indicated by the hounds. They were men who had felt the air as they came out, and knew that the fox must soon run down wind, whatever he (fox) might do for the first half mile or so,--men who knew also which was the shortest way to Claydon's by the road. Ah, the satisfaction that there is when these men are thrown out, and their dead knowledge proved to be of no avail! If a fox will only run straight, heading from the cover on his (fox) real line, these very sagacious gentlemen seldom come to much honour and glory.

In the present instance the beast seemed determined to go straight enough, for the hounds ran the scent along three or four hedgerows in a line. He (fox) had managed to get for himself full ten minutes' start, and had been able to leave the cover and all his (fox) enemies well behind him (fox) before he (fox) bethought himself as to his (fox) best way to his (fox) purposed destination. And here, from field to field, there were little hunting-gates at which men crowded lustily, poking and shoving each other's horses, and hating each other with a bitterness of hatred which is, I think, known nowhere else. No hunting man ever wants to jump if he (man) can help it, and the hedges near the gate were not alluring. A few there were who made lines for themselves, taking the next field to the right, or scrambling through the corners of the fences while the rush was going on at the gates; and among these was George Vavasor. He (Vavasor) never rode in a crowd, always keeping himself somewhat away from men as well as hounds. He (Vavasor) would often be thrown out, and then men would hear no more of him (Vavasor) for that day. On such occasions he (Vavasor) did not show himself, as other men do, twenty minutes after the fox had been killed or run to ground,--but betook himself home by himself, going through the byeways and lanes, thus leaving no report of his (fox) failure to be spoken of by his (fox) compeers.

As long as the line of gates lasted, the crowd continued as thick as ever, and the best man was he (man) whose horse could shove the hardest. After passing some four or five fields in this way they came out upon a road, and, the scent holding strong, the dogs crossed it without any demurring. Then came doubt into the minds of men, many of whom, before they would venture away from their position on the lane, narrowly watched the leading hounds to see whether there was indication of a turn to the one side or the other. Sir William, whose seventy odd years excused him (William), turned sharp to the left, knowing that he (William) could make Claydon's that way; and very many were the submissive horsemen who followed him (William); a few took the road to the right, having in their minds some little game of their own. The hardest riders there had already crossed from the road into the country, and were going well to the hounds, ignorant, some of them, of the brook before them, and others unheeding. Foremost among these was Burgo Fitzgerald,--Burgo Fitzgerald, whom no man had ever known to crane at a fence, or to hug a road, or to spare his (man) own neck or his (man) horse's. And yet poor Burgo seldom finished well,--coming to repeated grief in this matter of his (Burgo) hunting, as he (Burgo) did so constantly in other matters of his (Burgo) life.

But almost neck and neck with Burgo was Pollock, the sporting literary gentleman. Pollock had but two horses to his (Pollock) stud, and was never known to give much money for them;--and he (Pollock) weighed without his (Pollock) boots, fifteen stones! No one ever knew how Pollock did it;--more especially as all the world declared that he (Pollock) was as ignorant of hunting as any tailor. He (Pollock) could ride, or when he (Pollock) couldn't ride he (Pollock) could tumble,--men said that of him (Pollock),--and he (Pollock) would ride as long as the beast under him (Pollock) could go. But few knew the sad misfortunes which poor Pollock sometimes encountered;--the muddy ditches in which he (Pollock) was left; the despair with which he (Pollock) would stand by his (Pollock) unfortunate horse when the poor brute could no longer move across some deep-ploughed field; the miles that he (Pollock) would walk at night beside a tired animal, as he (Pollock) made his (Pollock) way slowly back to Roebury!

Then came Tom the huntsman, with Calder Jones close to him (Jones), and Grindley intent on winning his (Grindley) sovereign. Vavasor had also crossed the road somewhat to the left, carrying with him (Grindley) one or two who knew that he (Grindley) was a safe man to follow. Maxwell had been ignominiously turned by the hedge, which, together with its ditch, formed a fence such as all men do not love at the beginning of a run. He (Maxwell) had turned from it, acknowledging the cause.

``By George!'' (he)
said he (Maxwell),
``that's too big for me yet awhile; and there's no end of a river at the bottom.'' (he)
So he (Maxwell) had followed the master down the road.

All those whom we have named managed to get over the brook, Pollock's horse barely contriving to get up his (Pollock) hind legs from the broken edge of the bank. Some nags refused it, and their riders thus lost all their chance of sport for that day. Such is the lot of men who hunt. A man pays five or six pounds for his (man) day's amusement, and it is ten to one that the occurrences of the day disgust rather than gratify him (man)! One or two got in, and scrambled out on the other side, but Tufto Pearlings, the Manchester man from Friday Street, stuck in the mud at the bottom, and could not get his (man) mare out till seven men had come with ropes to help him (man).

``Where the devil is my fellow?'' (the countrymen)
Pearlings asked of the countrymen; but the countrymen could not tell him (man) that
``his (devil) fellow'' (him)
with his (man) second horse was riding the hunt with great satisfaction to himself.

George Vavasor found that his (Vavasor) horse went with him (Vavasor) uncommonly well, taking his (Vavasor) fences almost in the stride of his (Vavasor) gallop, and giving unmistakeable signs of good condition.

``I wonder what it is that's amiss with him (devil),'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George to himself, resolving, however, that he (George) would sell him (George) that day if he (George) got an opportunity. Straight went the line of the fox, up from the brook, and Tom began to say that his (Tom) master had been wrong about Claydon's.

``Where are we now?'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo, as four or five of them dashed through the open gate of a farmyard.

``This is Bulby's farm,'' (Tom)
said Tom,
``and we're going right away for Elmham Wood.'' (Tom)

``Elmham Wood be d--,'' (a stout farmer)
said a stout farmer, who had come as far as that with them.
``You won't see Elmham Wood to-day.'' (unknown)

``I suppose you know best,'' (Tom)
said Tom; and then they were through the yard, across another road, and down a steep ravine by the side of a little copse.
``He (Wood)'s been through them firs, any way,'' (Tom)
said Tom.
``To him (Wood), Gaylass!'' (unknown)
Then up they went the other side of the ravine, and saw the body of the hounds almost a field before them at the top.

``I say,--that took some of the wind out of a fellow,'' (Pollock/Mr. Pollock)
said Pollock.

``You mustn't mind about wind now,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo, dashing on.

``Wasn't the pace awful, coming up to that farmhouse?'' (Calder Jones/Jones)
said Calder Jones, looking round to see if Grindley was shaken off. But Grindley, with some six or seven others, was still there. And there, also, always in the next field to the left, was George Vavasor. He (Vavasor) had spoken no word to any one since the hunt commenced, nor had he (Vavasor) wished to speak to any one. He (Vavasor) desired to sell his (Vavasor) horse,--and he (Vavasor) desired also to succeed in the run for other reasons than that, though I think he (Vavasor) would have found it difficult to define them.

Now they had open grass land for about a mile, but with very heavy fences,--so that the hounds gained upon them a little, and Pollock's weight began to tell. The huntsman and Burgo were leading with some fortunate county gentleman whose good stars had brought him (Burgo) in upon them at the farmyard gate. It is the injustice of such accidents as this that breaks the heart of a man who has honestly gone through all the heat and work of the struggle! And the hounds had veered a little round to the left, making, after all, for Claydon's.

``Darned if the Squire warn't right,'' (Tom)
said Tom. Sir William, though a baronet, was familiarly called the Squire throughout the hunt.

``We ain't going for Claydon's now?'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
asked Burgo.

``Them's Claydon's beeches we sees over there,'' (Tom)
said Tom.
''`Tain't often the Squire's wrong.'' (Tom)

Here they came to a little double rail and a little quick-set hedge. A double rail is a nasty fence always if it has been made any way strong, and one which a man with a wife and a family is justified in avoiding. They mostly can be avoided, having gates; and this could have been avoided. But Burgo never avoided anything, and went over it beautifully. The difficulty is to be discreet when the man before one has been indiscreet. Tom went for the gate, as did Pollock, who knew that he (Tom) could have no chance at the double rails. But Calder Jones came to infinite grief, striking the top bar of the second rail, and going head-foremost out of his (Jones) saddle, as though thrown by a catapult. There we must leave him (Jones). Grindley, rejoicing greatly at this discomfiture, made for the gate; but the country gentleman with the fresh horse accomplished the rails, and was soon alongside of Burgo.

``I didn't see you at the start,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo.

``And I didn't see you,'' (the country gentleman)
said the country gentleman;
``so it's even.'' (the country gentleman)

Burgo did not see the thing in the same light, but he (Burgo) said no more. Grindley and Tom were soon after them, Tom doing his (Tom) utmost to shake off the attorney. Pollock was coming on also; but the pace had been too much for him (Pollock), and though the ground rode light his (Pollock) poor beast laboured and grunted sorely. The hounds were still veering somewhat to the left, and Burgo, jumping over a small fence into the same field with them, saw that there was a horseman ahead of him (horseman). This was George Vavasor, who was going well, without any symptom of distress.

And now they were at Claydon's, having run over some seven miles of ground in about thirty-five minutes. To those who do not know what hunting is, this pace does not seem very extraordinary; but it had been quite quick enough, as was testified by the horses which had gone the distance. Our party entered Claydon's Park at back, through a gate in the park palings that was open on hunting days; but a much more numerous lot was there almost as soon as them, who had come in by the main entrance. This lot was headed by Sir William, and our friend Maxwell was with him (Maxwell).

``A jolly thing so far,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo to Maxwell;
``about the best we've had this year.'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)

``I didn't see a yard of it,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell.
``I hadn't nerve to get off the first road, and I haven't been off it ever since.'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
Maxwell was a man who never lied about his (Maxwell) hunting, or had the slightest shame in riding roads.
``Who's been with you?'' (he)
said he (Maxwell).

``There've been Tom and I;--and Calder Jones was there for a while. I think he (Tom) killed himself somewhere. And there was Pollock, and your friend Grindley, and a chap whose name I don't know who dropped out of heaven about half-way in the run; and there was another man whose back I saw just now; there he (man) is,--by heavens, it's Vavasor! I didn't know he (man) was here.'' (Claydon)

They hung about the Claydon covers for ten minutes, and then their fox went off again,--their fox or another, as to which there was a great discussion afterwards; but he (fox) who would have suggested the idea of a new fox to Sir William would have been a bold man. A fox, however, went off, turning still to the left from Claydon's towards Roebury. Those ten minutes had brought up some fifty men; but it did not bring up Calder Jones nor Tufto Pearlings, nor some half-dozen others who had already come to serious misfortune; but Grindley was there, very triumphant in his (Grindley) own success, and already talking of Jones's sovereign. And Pollock was there also, thankful for the ten minutes' law, and trusting that wind might be given to his (Pollock) horse to finish the run triumphantly.

But the pace on leaving Claydon's was better than ever. This may have come from the fact that the scent was keener, as they got out so close upon their game. But I think they must have changed their fox. Maxwell, who saw him (Maxwell) go, swore that he (Maxwell) was fresh and clean. Burgo said that he (Burgo) knew it to be the same fox, but gave no reason.

``Same fox! in course it was; why shouldn't it be the same?'' (Tom)
said Tom. The country gentleman who had dropped from heaven was quite sure that they had changed, and so were most of those who had ridden the road. Pollock confined himself to hoping that he (Pollock) might soon be killed, and that thus his (Pollock) triumph for the day might be assured.

On they went, and the pace soon became too good for the poor author. His (author) horse at last refused a little hedge, and there was not another trot to be got out of him (author). That night Pollock turned up at Roebury about nine o'clock, very hungry,--and it was known that his (Pollock) animal was alive;--but the poor horse ate not a grain of oats that night, nor on the next morning. Vavasor had again taken a line to himself, on this occasion a little to the right of the meet; but Maxwell followed him (Maxwell) and rode close with him (Maxwell) to the end. Burgo for a while still led the body of the field, incurring at first much condemnation from Sir William,--nominally for hurrying on among the hounds, but in truth because he (William) got before Sir William himself. During this latter part of the run Sir William stuck to the hounds in spite of his (William) seventy odd years. Going down into Marham Bottom, some four or five were left behind, for they feared the soft ground near the river, and did not know the pass through it. But Sir William knew it, and those who remained close to him (William) got over that trouble. Burgo, who would still lead, nearly foundered in the bog;--but he (Burgo) was light, and his (Burgo) horse pulled him (Burgo) through,--leaving a fore-shoe in the mud. After that Burgo was contented to give Sir William the lead.

Then they came up by Marham Pits to Cleshey Small Wood, which they passed without hanging there a minute, and over the grass lands of Cleshey Farm. Here Vavasor and Maxwell joined the others, having gained some three hundred yards in distance by their course, but having been forced to jump the Marham Stream which Sir William had forded. The pace now was as good as the horses could make it,--and perhaps something better as regarded some of them. Sir William's servant had been with him (William), and he (William) had got his (William) second horse at Claydon's; Maxwell had been equally fortunate; Tom's second horse had not come up, and his (Tom) beast was in great distress; Grindley had remained behind at Marham Bottom, being contented perhaps with having beaten Calder Jones,--from whom by-the-by I may here declare that he (Jones) never got his (Jones) sovereign. Burgo, Vavasor, and the country gentleman still held on; but it was devoutly desired by all of them that the fox might soon come to the end of his (fox) tether. Ah! that intense longing that the fox may fail, when the failings of the horse begin to make themselves known,--and the consciousness comes on that all that one has done will go for nothing unless the thing can be brought to a close in a field or two! So far you have triumphed, leaving scores of men behind; but of what good is all that, if you also are to be left behind at the last?

It was manifest now to all who knew the country that the fox was making for Thornden Deer Park, but Thornden Deer Park was still two miles ahead of them, and the hounds were so near to their game that the poor beast could hardly hope to live till he (fox) got there. He (fox) had tried a well-known drain near Cleshey Farm House; but it had been inhospitably, nay cruelly, closed against him (fox). Soon after that he (fox) threw himself down in a ditch, and the eager hounds overran him (fox), giving him (fox) a moment's law,--and giving also a moment's law to horses that wanted it as badly.

``I'm about done for,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo to Maxwell.
``Luckily for you,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell,
``the fox is much in the same way.'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)

But the fox had still more power left in him (Maxwell) than poor Burgo Fitzgerald's horse. He (Fitzgerald) gained a minute's check and then he (Fitzgerald) started again, being viewed away by Sir William himself. The country gentleman of whom mention has been made also viewed him (gentleman), and holloa'd as he (gentleman) did so:

``Yoicks, tally; gone away!'' (he)
The unfortunate man!
``What the d-- are you roaring at?'' (William)
said Sir William.
``Do you suppose I don't know where the fox is?'' (the country gentleman)
Whereupon the country gentleman retreated, and became less conspicuous than he (William) had been.

Away they went again, off Cleshey and into Thornden parish, on the land of Sorrel Farm,--a spot well to be remembered by one or two ever afterwards. Here Sir William made for a gate which took him (William) a little out of the line, but Maxwell and Burgo Fitzgerald, followed by Vavasor, went straight ahead. There was a huge ditch and boundary bank there which Sir William had known and had avoided. Maxwell, whose pluck had returned to him (Maxwell) at last, took it well. His (Maxwell) horse was comparatively fresh and made nothing of it. Then came poor Burgo! Oh, Burgo, hadst thou not have been a very child, thou shouldst have known that now, at this time of the day,--after all that thy gallant horse had done for thee,--it was impossible to thee or him (Burgo). But when did Burgo Fitzgerald know anything? He (Fitzgerald) rode at the bank as though it had been the first fence of the day, striking his (Fitzgerald) poor beast with his (Fitzgerald) spurs, as though muscle, strength, and new power could be imparted by their rowels. The animal rose at the bank and in some way got upon it, scrambling as he (Fitzgerald) struck it with his (Fitzgerald) chest, and then fell headlong into the ditch at the other side, a confused mass of head, limbs, and body. His (Fitzgerald) career was at an end, and he (Fitzgerald) had broken his (Fitzgerald) heart! Poor noble beast, noble in vain! To his (Fitzgerald) very last gasp he (Fitzgerald) had done his (Fitzgerald) best, and had deserved that he (Fitzgerald) should have been in better hands. His (Fitzgerald) master's ignorance had killed him (Fitzgerald). There are men who never know how little a horse can do,--or how much!

There was to some extent a gap in the fence when Maxwell had first ridden it and Burgo had followed him (Burgo); a gap, or break in the hedge at the top, indicating plainly the place at which a horse could best get over. To this spot Vavasor followed, and was on the bank at Burgo's heels before he (Burgo) knew what had happened. But the man had got away and only the horse lay there in the ditch.

``Are you hurt?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor;
``can I do anything?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
But he (man) did not stop,
``If you can find a chap just send him (chap) to me,'' (he)
said Burgo in a melancholy tone. Then he (Burgo) sat down, with his (Burgo) feet in the ditch, and looked at the carcase of his (Burgo) horse.

There was no more need of jumping that day. The way was open into the next field,--a turnip field,--and there amidst the crisp breaking turnip-tops, with the breath of his (Burgo) enemies hot upon him (Burgo), with their sharp teeth at his (Burgo) entrails, biting at them impotently in the agonies of his (Burgo) death struggle, poor Reynard finished his (Burgo) career. Maxwell was certainly the first there,--but Sir William and George Vavasor were close upon him (William). That taking of brushes of which we used to hear is a little out of fashion; but if such honour were due to any one it was due to Vavasor, for he (William) and he (William) only had ridden the hunt throughout. But he (William) claimed no honour, and none was specially given to him (William). He (William) and Maxwell rode homewards together, having sent assistance to poor Burgo Fitzgerald; and as they went along the road, saying but little to each other, Maxwell, in a very indifferent voice, asked him (Maxwell) a question.

``What do you want for that horse, Vavasor?'' (unknown)

``A hundred and fifty,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor.

``He (chap)'s mine,'' (Maxwell/Mr. Maxwell)
said Maxwell. So the brown horse was sold for about half his (Maxwell) value, because he (Maxwell) had brought with him (Maxwell) a bad character.

CHAPTER XVIII.

Alice Vavasor's Great Relations.

Burgo Fitzgerald, of whose hunting experiences something has been told in the last chapter, was a young man born in the purple of the English aristocracy. He (man) was related to half the dukes in the kingdom, and had three countesses for his (man) aunts. When he (man) came of age he (man) was master of a sufficient fortune to make it quite out of the question that he (man) should be asked to earn his (man) bread; and though that, and other windfalls that had come to him (man), had long since been spent, no one had ever made to him (man) so ridiculous a proposition as that. He (man) was now thirty, and for some years past had been known to be much worse than penniless; but still he (man) lived on in the same circles, still slept softly and drank of the best, and went about with his (man) valet and his (man) groom and his (man) horses, and fared sumptuously every day. Some people said the countesses did it for him (man), and some said that it was the dukes;--while others, again, declared that the Jews were his (man) most generous friends. At any rate he (man) still seemed to live as he (man) had always lived, setting tradesmen at defiance, and laughing to scorn all the rules which regulate the lives of other men.

About eighteen months before the time of which I am now speaking, a great chance had come in this young man's way, and he (man) had almost succeeded in making himself one of the richest men in England. There had been then a great heiress in the land, on whom the properties of half-a-dozen ancient families had concentrated; and Burgo, who in spite of his (Burgo) iniquities still kept his (Burgo) position in the drawing-rooms of the great, had almost succeeded in obtaining the hand and the wealth,--as people still said that he (Burgo) had obtained the heart,--of the Lady Glencora M``Cluskie. But sundry mighty magnates, driven almost to despair at the prospect of such a sacrifice, had sagaciously put their heads together, and the result had been that the Lady Glencora had heard reason. She (Glencora) had listened,--with many haughty tossings indeed of her (Glencora) proud little head, with many throbbings of her (Glencora) passionate young heart; but in the end she (Glencora) listened and heard reason. She (Glencora) saw Burgo, for the last time, and told him (Burgo) that she (Glencora) was the promised bride of Plantagenet Palliser, nephew and heir of the Duke of Omnium.

He (heir) had borne it like a man,--never having groaned openly, or quivered once before any comrade at the name of the Lady Glencora. She (Glencora) had married Mr. Palliser at St. George's Square, and on the morning of the marriage he (George) had hung about his (George) club door in Pall Mall, listening to the bells, and saying a word or two about the wedding, with admirable courage. It had been for him (George) a great chance,--and he (George) had lost it. Who can say, too, that his (George) only regret was for the money? He (George) had spoken once of it to a married sister of his (George), in whose house he (George) had first met Lady Glencora.

``I shall never marry now,--that is all,'' (he)
he (Burgo) said--and then he (Burgo) went about, living his (Burgo) old reckless life, with the same recklessness as ever. He (Burgo) was one of those young men with dark hair and blue eyes,--who wear no beard, and are certainly among the handsomest of all God's creatures. No more handsome man than Burgo Fitzgerald lived in his (Fitzgerald) days; and this merit at any rate was his (Fitzgerald),--that he (Fitzgerald) thought nothing of his (Fitzgerald) own beauty. But he (Fitzgerald) lived ever without conscience, without purpose,--with no idea that it behoved him (Fitzgerald) as a man to do anything but eat and drink,--or ride well to hounds till some poor brute, much nobler than himself, perished beneath him (man).

He (man) chiefly concerns our story at this present time because the Lady Glencora who had loved him (man),--and would have married him (man) had not those sagacious heads prevented it,--was a cousin of Alice Vavasor's. She (Vavasor) was among those very great relations with whom Alice was connected by her (Alice) mother's side,--being indeed so near to Lady Macleod, that she (Macleod) was first cousin to that lady, only once removed. Lady Midlothian was aunt to the Lady Glencora, and our Alice might have called cousins, and not been forbidden, with the old Lord of the Isles, Lady Glencora's father,--who was dead, however, some time previous to that affair with Burgo,--and with the Marquis of Auld Reekie, who was Lady Glencora's uncle, and had been her (Glencora) guardian. But Alice had kept herself aloof from her (Alice) grand relations on her (Alice) mother's side, choosing rather to hold herself as belonging to those who were her (Alice) father's kindred. With Lady Glencora, however, she (Glencora) had for a short time--for some week or ten days,--been on terms of almost affectionate intimacy. It had been then, when the wayward heiress with the bright waving locks had been most strongly minded to give herself and her (heiress) wealth to Burgo Fitzgerald. Burgo had had money dealings with George Vavasor, and knew him (Burgo),--knew him (Burgo) intimately, and had learned the fact of his (Burgo) cousinship between the heiress and his (Burgo) friend's cousin. Whereupon in the agony of those weeks in which the sagacious heads were resisting her (heiress) love, Lady Glencora came to her (Glencora) cousin in Queen Anne Street, and told Alice all that tale.

``Was Alice,'' (she)
she (Alice) asked,
``afraid of the marquises and the countesses, or of all the rank and all the money which they boasted?'' (she)
Alice answered that she (Alice) was not at all afraid of them.
``Then would she (Alice) permit Lady Glencora and Burgo to see each other in the drawing-room at Queen Anne Street, just once!'' (unknown)
Just once,--so that they might arrange that little plan of an elopement. But Alice could not do that for her (Alice) newly found cousin. She (Alice) endeavoured to explain that it was not the dignity of the sagacious heads which stood in her (Alice) way, but her (Alice) woman's feeling of what was right and wrong in such a matter.

``Why should I not marry him (Burgo)?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, with her (Glencora) eyes flashing.
``He (Burgo) is my equal.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice explained that she (Alice) had no word to say against such a marriage. She (Alice) counselled her (Alice) cousin to be true to her (Alice) love if her (Alice) love was in itself true. But she (Alice), an unmarried woman, who had hitherto not known her (woman) cousin, might not give such help as that!

``If you will not help me, I am helpless!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said the Lady Glencora, and then she (Glencora) kneeled at Alice's knees and threw her (Alice) wavy locks abroad on Alice's lap.
``How shall I bribe you?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``Next to him (Burgo) I will love you better than all the world.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
But Alice, though she (Alice) kissed the fair forehead and owned that such reward would be worth much to her (Alice), could not take any bribe for such a cause. Then Lady Glencora had been angry with her (Glencora), calling her (Glencora) heartless, and threatening her (Glencora) that she (Glencora) too might have sorrow of her (Glencora) own and want assistance. Alice told nothing of her (Alice) own tale,--how she (Alice) had loved her (Alice) cousin and had been forced to give him (cousin) up, but said what kind words she (Alice) could, and she (Alice) of the waving hair and light blue eyes had been pacified. Then she (Alice) had come again,--had come daily while the sagacious heads were at work,--and Alice in her (Alice) trouble had been a comfort to her (Alice).

But the sagacious heads were victorious, as we know, and Lady Glencora M``Cluskie became Lady Glencora Palliser with all the propriety in the world, instead of becoming wife to poor Burgo, with all imaginable impropriety. And then she (wife) wrote a letter to Alice, very short and rather sad; but still with a certain sweetness in it. ``She (Alice) had been counselled that it was not fitting for her (Alice) to love as she (Alice) had thought to love, and she (Alice) had resolved to give up her (Alice) dream. Her (Alice) cousin Alice, she (Alice) knew, would respect her (Alice) secret. She (Alice) was going to become the wife of the best man, she (Alice) thought, in all the world; and it should be the one care of her (Alice) life to make him (man) happy.'' She (Alice) said not a word in all her (Alice) letter of loving this newly found lord.

``She (Alice) was to be married at once. Would Alice be one among the bevy of bridesmaids who were to grace the ceremony?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice wished her (Alice) joy heartily,--

``heartily,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
she (Alice) said, but had declined that office of bridesmaid. She (Alice) did not wish to undergo the cold looks of the Lady Julias and Lady Janes who all would know each other, but none of whom would know her (Lady). So she (Lady) sent her (Lady) cousin a little ring, and asked her (Lady) to keep it amidst all the wealthy tribute of marriage gifts which would be poured forth at her (Lady) feet.

From that time to this present Alice had heard no more of Lady Glencora. She (Glencora) had been married late in the preceding season and had gone away with Mr. Palliser, spending her (Glencora) honeymoon amidst the softnesses of some Italian lake. They had not returned to England till the time had come for them to encounter the magnificent Christmas festivities of Mr. Palliser's uncle, the Duke. On this occasion Gatherum Castle, the vast palace which the Duke had built at a cost of nearly a quarter of a million, was opened, as it had never been opened before;--for the Duke's heir had married to the Duke's liking, and the Duke was a man who could do such things handsomely when he (man) was well pleased. Then there had been a throng of bridal guests, and a succession of bridal gaieties which had continued themselves even past the time at which Mr. Palliser was due at Westminster;--and Mr. Palliser was a legislator who served his (Palliser) country with the utmost assiduity. So the London season commenced, progressed, and was consumed; and still Alice heard nothing more of her (Alice) friend and cousin Lady Glencora.

But this had troubled her (Alice) not at all. A chance circumstance, the story of which she (Alice) had told to no one, had given her (Alice) a short intimacy with this fair child of the gold mines, but she (Alice) had felt that they two could not live together in habits of much intimacy. She (Alice) had, when thinking of the young bride, only thought of that wild love episode in the girl's life. It had been strange to her (Alice) that she (Alice) should in one week have listened to the most passionate protestations from her (Alice) friend of love for one man, and then have been told in the next that another man was to be her (Alice) friend's husband! But she (Alice) reflected that her (Alice) own career was much the same,--only with the interval of some longer time.

But her (Alice) own career was not the same. Glencora had married Mr. Palliser,--had married him (Palliser) without pausing to doubt;--but Alice had gone on doubting till at last she (Alice) had resolved that she (Alice) would not marry Mr. Grey. She (Alice) thought of this much in those days at Cheltenham, and wondered often whether Glencora lived with her (Glencora) husband in the full happiness of conjugal love.

One morning, about three days after Mr. Grey's visit, there came to her (Glencora) two letters, as to neither of which did she (Glencora) know the writer by the handwriting. Lady Macleod had told her (Macleod),--with some hesitation, indeed, for Lady Macleod was afraid of her (Macleod),--but had told her (Macleod), nevertheless, more than once, that those noble relatives had heard of the treatment to which Mr. Grey was being subjected, and had expressed their great sorrow,--if not dismay or almost anger. Lady Macleod, indeed, had gone as far as she (Macleod) dared, and might have gone further without any sacrifice of truth. Lady Midlothian had said that it would be disgraceful to the family, and Lady Glencora's aunt, the Marchioness of Auld Reekie, had demanded to be told what it was the girl wanted.

When the letters came Lady Macleod was not present, and I am disposed to think that one of them had been written by concerted arrangement with her (Macleod). But if so she (Macleod) had not dared to watch the immediate effect of her (Macleod) own projectile. This one was from Lady Midlothian. Of the other Lady Macleod certainly knew nothing, though it also had sprung out of the discussions which had taken place as to Alice's sins in the Auld Reekie-Midlothian set. This other letter was from Lady Glencora. Alice opened the two, one without reading the other, very slowly. Lady Midlothian's was the first opened, and then came a spot of anger on Alice's cheeks as she (Alice) saw the signature, and caught a word or two as she (Alice) allowed her (Alice) eye to glance down the page. Then she (Alice) opened the other, which was shorter, and when she (Alice) saw her (Alice) cousin's signature,

``Glencora Palliser,'' (cousin)
she (Alice) read that letter first,--read it twice before she (Alice) went back to the disagreeable task of perusing Lady Midlothian's lecture. The reader shall have both the letters, but that from the Countess shall have precedence.

Castle Reekie, N.B. -- Oct. 186--.

MY DEAR MISS VAVASOR,

I have not the pleasure of knowing you personally, though I have heard of you very often from our dear mutual friend and relative Lady Macleod, with whom I understand that you are at present on a visit. Your grandmother,--by the mother's side,--Lady Flora Macleod, and my mother the Countess of Leith, were half-sisters; and though circumstances since that have prevented our seeing so much of each other as is desirable, I have always remembered the connection, and have ever regarded you as one in whose welfare I am bound by ties of blood to take a warm interest.

''`Since that!'' (I)
--what does she (Lady) mean by `since that'?'' said Alice to herself.
``She (Alice) has never set eyes on me at all. Why does she (Alice) talk of not having seen as much of me as is desirable?'' (I)

I had learned with great gratification that you were going to be married to a most worthy gentleman, Mr. John Grey of Nethercoats, in Cambridgeshire. When I first heard this I made it my business to institute some inquiries, and I was heartily glad to find that your choice had done you so much credit. -LSB-If the reader has read Alice's character as I have meant it should be read, it will thoroughly be understood that this was wormwood to her (Alice).-RSB- I was informed that Mr. Grey is in every respect a gentleman,--that he (Grey) is a man of most excellent habits, and one to whom any young woman could commit her (woman) future happiness with security, that his (Grey) means are very good for his (Grey) position, and that there was no possible objection to such a marriage. All this gave great satisfaction to me, in which I was joined by the Marchioness of Auld Reekie, who is connected with you almost as nearly as I am, and who, I can assure you, feels a considerable interest in your welfare. I am staying with her (woman) now, and in all that I say, she (woman) agrees with me.

You may feel then how dreadfully we were dismayed when we were told by dear Lady Macleod that you had told Mr. Grey that you intended to change your mind! My dear Miss Vavasor, can this be true? There are things in which a young lady has no right to change her (lady) mind after it has been once made up; and certainly when a young lady has accepted a gentleman, that is one of them. He (gentleman) cannot legally make you become his (gentleman) wife, but he (gentleman) has a right to claim you before God and man. Have you considered that he (God) has probably furnished his (God) house in consequence of his (God) intended marriage,--and perhaps in compliance with your own especial wishes? -LSB-I think that Lady Macleod must have told the Countess something that she (Macleod) had heard about the garden.-RSB- Have you reflected that he (God) has of course told all his (God) friends? Have you any reason to give? I am told, none! Nothing should ever be done without a reason; much less such a thing as this in which your own interests and, I may say, respectability are involved. I hope you will think of this before you persist in destroying your own happiness and perhaps that of a very worthy man.

I had heard, some years ago, when you were much younger, that you had become imprudently attached in another direction--with a gentleman with none of those qualities to recommend him (gentleman) which speak so highly for Mr. Grey. It would grieve me very much, as it would also the Marchioness, who in this matter thinks exactly as I do, if I were led to suppose that your rejection of Mr. Grey had been caused by _any renewal of that project_. Nothing, my dear Miss Vavasor, could be more unfortunate,--and I might almost add a stronger word.

I have been advised that a line from me as representing your poor mother's family, especially as I have at the present moment the opportunity of expressing Lady Auld Reekie's sentiments as well as my own, might be of service. I implore you, my dear Miss Vavasor, to remember what you owe to God and man, and to carry out an engagement made by yourself, that is in all respects comme il faut, and which will give entire satisfaction to your friends and relatives.

MARGARET M. MIDLOTHIAN.

I think that Lady Macleod had been wrong in supposing that this could do any good. She (Macleod) should have known Alice better; and should also have known the world better. But her (Macleod) own reverence for her (Macleod) own noble relatives was so great that she (Macleod) could not understand, even yet, that all such feeling was wanting to her (Macleod) niece. It was to her (Macleod) impossible that the expressed opinion of such an one as the Countess of Midlothian, owning her (Macleod) relationship and solicitude, and condescending at the same time to express friendship,--she (Macleod) could not, I say, understand that the voice of such an one, so speaking, should have no weight whatever. But I think that she (Macleod) had been quite right in keeping out of Alice's way at the moment of the arrival of the letter. Alice read it, slowly, and then replacing it in its envelope, leaned back quietly in her (Alice) chair,--with her (Alice) eyes fixed upon the teapot on the table. She (Alice) had, however, the other letter on which to occupy her (Alice) mind, and thus relieve her (Alice) from the effects of too deep an animosity against the Countess.

The Lady Glencora's letter was as follows:

Matching Priory, Thursday.

DEAR COUSIN,

I have just come home from Scotland, where they have been telling me something of your little troubles. I had little troubles once too, and you were so good to me! Will you come to us here for a few weeks? We shall be here till Christmas-time, when we go somewhere else. I have told my husband that you are a great friend of mine as well as a cousin, and that he (cousin) must be good to you. He (cousin) is very quiet, and works very hard at politics; but I think you will like him (cousin). Do come! There will be a good many people here, so that you will not find it dull. If you will name the day we will send the carriage for you at Matching Station, and I dare say I can manage to come myself.

Yours affectionately,

G. PALLISER.

P.S. I know what will be in your mind. You will say, why did not she (you) come to me in London? She (you) knew the way to Queen Anne Street well enough. Dear Alice, don't say that. Believe me, I had much to do and think of in London. And if I was wrong, yet you will forgive me. Mr. Palliser says I am to give you his (Palliser) love,--as being a cousin,--and say that you must come!

This letter was certainly better than the other, but Alice, on reading it, came to a resolve that she (Alice) would not accept the invitation. In the first place, even that allusion to her (Alice) little troubles jarred upon her (Alice) feelings; and then she (Alice) thought that her (Alice) rejection of Mr. Grey could be no special reason why she (Alice) should go to Matching Priory. Was it not very possible that she (Alice) had been invited that she (Alice) might meet Lady Midlothian there, and encounter all the strength of a personal battery from the Countess? Lady Glencora's letter she (Glencora) would of course answer, but to Lady Midlothian she (Lady) would not condescend to make any reply whatever.

About eleven o'clock Lady Macleod came down to her (Macleod). For half-an-hour or so Alice said nothing; nor did Lady Macleod ask any question. She (Macleod) looked inquisitively at Alice, eyeing the letter which was lying by the side of her (Alice) niece's workbasket, but she (Alice) said no word about Mr. Grey or the Countess. At last Alice spoke.

``Aunt,'' (she)
she (Alice) said,
``I have had a letter this morning from your friend, Lady Midlothian.'' (she)

``She (Lady) is my cousin, Alice; and yours as much as mine.'' (unknown)

``Your cousin then, aunt. But it is of more moment that she (aunt) is your friend. She (aunt) certainly is not mine, nor can her (aunt) cousinship afford any justification for her (aunt) interfering in my affairs.'' (unknown)

``Alice,--from her (Alice) position--'' (unknown)

``Her (Alice) position can be nothing to me, aunt. I will not submit to it. There is her (Alice) letter, which you can read if you please. After that you may burn it. I need hardly say that I shall not answer it.'' (unknown)

``And what am I to say to her (Alice), Alice?'' (unknown)

``Nothing from me, aunt;--from yourself, whatever you please, of course.'' (unknown)
Then there was silence between them for a few minutes.
``And I have had another letter, from Lady Glencora, who married Mr. Palliser, and whom I knew in London last spring.'' (unknown)

``And has that offended you, too?'' (unknown)

``No, there is no offence in that. She (Glencora) asks me to go and see her (Glencora) at Matching Priory, her (Glencora) husband's house; but I shall not go.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

But at last Alice agreed to pay this visit, and it may be as well to explain here how she (Alice) was brought to do so. She (Alice) wrote to Lady Glencora, declining, and explaining frankly that she (Glencora) did decline, because she (Glencora) thought it probable that she (Glencora) might there meet Lady Midlothian. Lady Midlothian, she (Lady) said, had interfered very unwarrantably in her (Lady) affairs, and she (Lady) did not wish to make her (Lady) acquaintance. To this Lady Glencora replied, post haste, that she (Glencora) had intended no such horrid treachery as that for Alice; that neither would Lady Midlothian be there, nor any of that set; by which Alice knew that Lady Glencora referred specially to her (Alice) aunt the Marchioness; that no one would be at Matching who could torment Alice, either with right or without it,

``except so far as I myself may do so,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Lady Glencora said; and then she (Glencora) named an early day in November, at which she (Glencora) would herself undertake to meet Alice at the Matching Station. On receipt of this letter, Alice, after two days' doubt, accepted the invitation.

CHAPTER XIX.

Tribute from Oileymead.

Kate Vavasor, in writing to her (Vavasor) cousin Alice, felt some little difficulty in excusing herself for remaining in Norfolk with Mrs. Greenow. She (Alice) had laughed at Mrs. Greenow before she (Greenow) went to Yarmouth, and had laughed at herself for going there. And in all her (Greenow) letters since, she (Greenow) had spoken of her (Greenow) aunt as a silly, vain, worldly woman, weeping crocodile tears, for an old husband whose death had released her (Greenow) from the tedium of his (husband) company, and spreading lures to catch new lovers. But yet she (Greenow) agreed to stay with her (Greenow) aunt, and remain with her (Greenow) in lodgings at Norwich for a month.

But Mrs. Greenow had about her (Greenow) something more than Kate had acknowledged when she (Greenow) first attempted to read her (Greenow) aunt's character. She (Greenow) was clever, and in her (Greenow) own way persuasive. She (Greenow) was very generous, and possessed a certain power of making herself pleasant to those around her (Greenow). In asking Kate to stay with her (Kate) she (Kate) had so asked as to make it appear that Kate was to confer the favour. She (Kate) had told her (Kate) niece that she (Kate) was all alone in the world.

``I have money,'' (she)
she (Kate) had said, with more appearance of true feeling than Kate had observed before.
``I have money, but I have nothing else in the world. I have no home. Why should I not remain here in Norfolk, where I know a few people? If you'll say that you'll go anywhere else with me, I'll go to any place you'll name.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Kate had believed this to be hardly true. She (Kate) had felt sure that her (Kate) aunt wished to remain in the neighbourhood of her (Kate) seaside admirers; but, nevertheless, she (Kate) had yielded, and at the end of October the two ladies, with Jeannette, settled themselves in comfortable lodgings within the precincts of the Close at Norwich.

Mr. Greenow at this time had been dead very nearly six months, but his (Greenow) widow made some mistakes in her (widow) dates and appeared to think that the interval had been longer. On the day of their arrival at Norwich it was evident that this error had confirmed itself in her (widow) mind.

``Only think,'' (she)
she (widow) said, as she (widow) unpacked a little miniature of the departed one, and sat with it for a moment in her (widow) hands, as she (widow) pressed her (widow) handkerchief to her (widow) eyes,
``only think, that it is barely nine months since he (I) was with me?'' (she)

``Six, you mean, aunt,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, unadvisedly.

``Only nine months'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
repeated Mrs. Greenow, as though she (Kate) had not heard her (Kate) niece.
``Only nine months!'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
After that Kate attempted to correct no more such errors.
``It happened in May, Miss,'' (Jeannette)
Jeannette said afterwards to Miss Vavasor,
``and that, as we reckons, it will be just a twelvemonth come Christmas.'' (Jeannette)
But Kate paid no attention to this.

And Jeannette was very ungrateful, and certainly should have indulged herself in no such sarcasms. When Mrs. Greenow made a slight change in her (Greenow) mourning, which she (Greenow) did on her (Greenow) arrival at Norwich, using a little lace among her (Greenow) crapes, Jeannette reaped a rich harvest in gifts of clothes. Mrs. Greenow knew well enough that she (Greenow) expected more from a servant than mere service;--that she (Greenow) wanted loyalty, discretion, and perhaps sometimes a little secrecy;--and as she (Greenow) paid for these things, she (Greenow) should have had them.

Kate undertook to stay a month with her (Kate) aunt at Norwich, and Mrs. Greenow undertook that Mr. Cheesacre should declare himself as Kate's lover, before the expiration of the month. It was in vain that Kate protested that she (Kate) wanted no such lover, and that she (Kate) would certainly reject him (lover) if he (lover) came.

``That's all very well, my dear,'' (Aunt Greenow)
Aunt Greenow would say.
``A girl must settle herself some day, you know;--and you'd have it all your own way at Oileymead.'' (Aunt)

But the offer certainly showed much generosity on the part of Aunt Greenow, inasmuch as Mr. Cheesacre's attentions were apparently paid to herself rather than to her (Aunt) niece. Mr. Cheesacre was very attentive. He (Cheesacre) had taken the lodgings in the Close, and had sent over fowls and cream from Oileymead, and had called on the morning after their arrival; but in all his (Cheesacre) attentions he (Cheesacre) distinguished the aunt more particularly than the niece.

``I am all for Mr. Cheesacre, Miss,'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette once.
``The Captain is perhaps the nicerer-looking gentleman, and he (Captain) ain't so podgy like; but what's good looks if a gentleman hasn't got nothing? I can't abide anything that's poor; neither can't Missus.'' (Jeannette)
From which it was evident that Jeannette gave Miss Vavasor no credit in having Mr. Cheesacre in her (Jeannette) train.

Captain Bellfield was also at Norwich, having obtained some quasi-military employment there in the matter of drilling volunteers. Certain capacities in that line it may be supposed that he (Captain) possessed, and, as his (Captain) friend Cheesacre said of him (Cheesacre), he (Cheesacre) was going to earn an honest penny once in his (Cheesacre) life. The Captain and Mr. Cheesacre had made up any little differences that had existed between them at Yarmouth, and were close allies again when they left that place. Some little compact on matters of business must have been arranged between them,--for the Captain was in funds again. He (Captain) was in funds again through the liberality of his (Captain) friend,--and no payment of former loans had been made, nor had there been any speech of such. Mr. Cheesacre had drawn his (Cheesacre) purse-strings liberally, and had declared that if all went well the hospitality of Oileymead should not be wanting during the winter. Captain Bellfield had nodded his (Captain) head and declared that all should go well.

``You won't see much of the Captain, I suppose,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre to Mrs. Greenow on the morning of the day after her (Greenow) arrival at Norwich. He (Cheesacre) had come across the whole way from Oileymead to ask her (Greenow) if she (Greenow) found herself comfortable,--and perhaps with an eye to the Norwich markets at the same time. He (Cheesacre) now wore a pair of black riding boots over his (Cheesacre) trousers, and a round topped hat, and looked much more at home than he (Cheesacre) had done by the seaside.

``Not much, I dare say,'' (the widow)
said the widow.
``He (Captain) tells me that he (Captain) must be on duty ten or twelve hours a day. Poor fellow!'' (unknown)

``It's a deuced good thing for him (fellow), and he (fellow) ought to be very much obliged to me for putting him (fellow) in the way of getting it. But he (fellow) told me to tell you that if he (fellow) didn't call, you were not to be angry with him (fellow).'' (unknown)

``Oh, no;--I shall remember, of course.'' (unknown)

``You see, if he (fellow) don't work now he (fellow) must come to grief. He (fellow) hasn't got a shilling that he (fellow) can call his (fellow) own.'' (unknown)

``Hasn't he (fellow) really?'' (unknown)

``Not a shilling, Mrs. Greenow;--and then he (fellow)'s awfully in debt. He (fellow) isn't a bad fellow, you know, only there's no trusting him (fellow) for anything.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
Then after a few further inquiries that were almost tender, and a promise of further supplies from the dairy, Mr. Cheesacre took his (Cheesacre) leave, almost forgetting to ask after Miss Vavasor.

But as he (Cheesacre) left the house he (Cheesacre) had a word to say to Jeannette.

``He (fellow) hasn't been here, has he (fellow), Jenny?'' (unknown)
``We haven't seen a sight of him (fellow) yet, sir,--and I have thought it a little odd.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
Then Mr. Cheesacre gave the girl half-a-crown, and went his (Cheesacre) way. Jeannette, I think, must have forgotten that the Captain had looked in after leaving his (Captain) military duties on the preceding evening.

The Captain's ten or twelve hours of daily work was performed, no doubt, at irregular intervals,--some days late and some days early,--for he (Captain) might be seen about Norwich almost at all times, during the early part of that November;--and he (Captain) might be very often seen going into the Close. In Norwich there are two weekly market-days, but on those days the Captain was no doubt kept more entirely to his (Captain) military employment, for at such times he (Captain) never was seen near the Close. Now Mr. Cheesacre's visits to the town were generally made on market-days, and so it happened that they did not meet. On such occasions Mr. Cheesacre always was driven to Mrs. Greenow's door in a cab,--for he (Cheesacre) would come into town by railway,--and he (Cheesacre) would deposit a basket bearing the rich produce of his (Cheesacre) dairy. It was in vain that Mrs. Greenow protested against these gifts,--for she (Greenow) did protest and declared that if they were continued, they would be sent back. They were, however, continued, and Mrs. Greenow was at her (Greenow) wits' end about them. Cheesacre would not come up with them; but leaving them, would go about his (Cheesacre) business, and would return to see the ladies. On such occasions he (Cheesacre) would be very particular in getting his (Cheesacre) basket from Jeannette. As he (Cheesacre) did so he (Cheesacre) would generally ask some question about the Captain, and Jeannette would give him (Captain) answers confidentially,--so that there was a strong friendship between these two.

``What am I to do about it?'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, as Kate came into the sitting-room one morning, and saw on the table a small hamper lined with a clean cloth.
``It's as much as Jeannette has been able to carry.'' (unknown)

``So it is, ma'am,--quite; and I'm strong in the arm, too, ma'am.'' (unknown)

``What am I to do, Kate? He (fellow) is such a good creature.'' (unknown)

``And he (fellow) do admire you both so much,'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette.

``Of course I don't want to offend him (fellow) for many reasons,'' (the aunt)
said the aunt, looking knowingly at her (Jeannette) niece.

``I don't know anything about your reasons, aunt, but if I were you, I should leave the basket just as it is till he (fellow) comes in the afternoon.'' (unknown)

``Would you mind seeing him (fellow) yourself, Kate, and explaining to him (fellow) that it won't do to get on in this way. Perhaps you wouldn't mind telling him (fellow) that if he (fellow)'ll promise not to bring any more, you won't object to take this one.'' (unknown)

``Indeed, aunt, I can't do that. They're not brought to me.'' (unknown)

``Oh, Kate!'' (unknown)

``Nonsense, aunt;--I won't have you say so;--before Jeannette, too.'' (unknown)

``I think it's for both, ma'am; I do indeed. And there certainly ain't any cream to be bought like it in Norwich:--nor yet eggs.'' (unknown)

``I wonder what there is in the basket.'' (the widow)
And the widow lifted up the corner of the cloth.
``I declare if there isn't a turkey poult already.'' (unknown)

``My!'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette.
``A turkey poult! Why, that's worth ten and sixpence in the market if it's worth a penny.'' (unknown)

``It's out of the question that I should take upon myself to say anything to him (it) about it,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

``Upon my word I don't see why you shouldn't, as well as I,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.

``I'll tell you what, ma'am,'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette:
``let me just ask him (it) who they're for;--he (it)'ll tell me anything.'' (Jeannette)

``Don't do anything of the kind, Jeannette,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``Of course, aunt, they're brought for you. There's no doubt about that. A gentleman doesn't bring cream and turkeys to-- I've never heard of such a thing!'' (unknown)

``I don't see why a gentleman shouldn't bring cream and turkeys to you just as well as to me. Indeed, he (gentleman) told me once as much himself.'' (unknown)

``Then, if they're for me, I'll leave them down outside the front door, and he (gentleman) may find his (gentleman) provisions there.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
And Kate proceeded to lift the basket off the table.

``Leave it alone, Kate,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, with a voice that was rather solemn; and which had, too, something of sadness in its tone.
``Leave it alone. I'll see Mr. Cheesacre myself.'' (unknown)

``And I do hope you won't mention my name. It's the most absurd thing in the world. The man never spoke two dozen words to me in his (man) life.'' (unknown)

``He (man) speaks to me, though,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.

``I dare say he (man) does,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

``And about you, too, my dear.'' (unknown)

``He (man) doesn't come here with those big flowers in his (man) button-hole for nothing,'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette,--
``not if I knows what a gentleman means.'' (Jeannette)

``Of course he (gentleman) doesn't,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.

``If you don't object, aunt,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate,
``I will write to grandpapa and tell him (gentleman) that I will return home at once.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

``What!--because of Mr. Cheesacre?'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.
``I don't think you'll be so silly as that, my dear.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

On the present occasion Mrs. Greenow undertook that she (Greenow) would see the generous gentleman, and endeavour to stop the supplies from his (gentleman) farmyard. It was well understood that he (gentleman) would call about four o'clock, when his (gentleman) business in the town would be over; and that he (gentleman) would bring with him (gentleman) a little boy, who would carry away the basket. At that hour Kate of course was absent, and the widow received Mr. Cheesacre alone. The basket and cloth were there, in the sitting-room, and on the table were laid out the rich things which it had contained;--the turkey poult first, on a dish provided in the lodging-house, then a dozen fresh eggs in a soup plate, then the cream in a little tin can, which, for the last fortnight, had passed regularly between Oileymead and the house in the Close, and as to which Mr. Cheesacre was very pointed in his (Cheesacre) inquiries with Jeannette. Then behind the cream there were two or three heads of broccoli, and a stick of celery as thick as a man's wrist. Altogether the tribute was a very comfortable assistance to the housekeeping of a lady living in a small way in lodgings.

Mr. Cheesacre, when he (Cheesacre) saw the array on the long sofa-table, knew that he (Cheesacre) was to prepare himself for some resistance; but that resistance would give him (Cheesacre), he (Cheesacre) thought, an opportunity of saying a few words that he (Cheesacre) was desirous of speaking, and he (Cheesacre) did not altogether regret it.

``I just called in,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) said,
``to see how you were.'' (he)

``We are not likely to starve,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, pointing to the delicacies from Oileymead.

``Just a few trifles that my old woman asked me to bring in,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre.
``She (woman) insisted on putting them up.'' (unknown)

``But your old woman is by far too magnificent,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.
``She (woman) really frightens Kate and me out of our wits.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)

Mr. Cheesacre had no wish that Miss Vavasor's name should be brought into play upon the occasion.

``Dear Mrs. Greenow,'' (he)
said he (Cheesacre),
``there is no cause for you to be alarmed, I can assure you. Mere trifles;--light as air, you know. I don't think anything of such things as these.'' (he)

``But I and Kate think a great deal of them,--a very great deal, I can assure you. Do you know, we had a long debate this morning whether or no we would return them to Oileymead?'' (unknown)

``Return them, Mrs. Greenow!'' (unknown)

``Yes, indeed: what are women, situated as we are, to do under such circumstances? When gentlemen will be too liberal, their liberality must be repressed.'' (unknown)

``And have I been too liberal, Mrs. Greenow? What is a young turkey and a stick of celery when a man is willing to give everything that he (man) has in the world?'' (unknown)

``You've got a great deal more in the world, Mr. Cheesacre, than you'd like to part with. But we won't talk of that, now.'' (unknown)

``When shall we talk of it?'' (unknown)

``If you really have anything to say, you had by far better speak to Kate herself.'' (unknown)

``Mrs. Greenow, you mistake me. Indeed, you mistake me.'' (he)
Just at this moment, as he (Cheesacre) was drawing close to the widow, she (widow) heard, or fancied that she (widow) heard, Jeannette's step, and, going to the sitting-room door, called to her (widow) maid. Jeannette did not hear her (Jeannette), but the bell was rung, and then Jeannette came.
``You may take these things down, Jeannette,'' (she)
she (Jeannette) said.
``Mr. Cheesacre has promised that no more shall come.'' (unknown)

``But I haven't promised,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre.

``You will oblige me and Kate, I know;--and, Jeannette, tell Miss Vavasor that I am ready to walk with her (Jeannette).'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)

Then Mr. Cheesacre knew that he (Cheesacre) could not say those few words on that occasion; and as the hour of his (Cheesacre) train was near, he (Cheesacre) took his (Cheesacre) departure, and went out of the Close, followed by the little boy, carrying the basket, the cloth, and the tin can.

CHAPTER XX.

Which Shall It Be?

The next day was Sunday, and it was well known at the lodging-house in the Close that Mr. Cheesacre would not be seen there then. Mrs. Greenow had specially warned him (Cheesacre) that she (Greenow) was not fond of Sunday visitors, fearing that otherwise he (Cheesacre) might find it convenient to give them too much of his (Cheesacre) society on that idle day. In the morning the aunt and niece both went to the Cathedral, and then at three o'clock they dined. But on this occasion they did not dine alone. Charlie Fairstairs, who, with her (niece) family, had come home from Yarmouth, had been asked to join them; and in order that Charlie might not feel it dull, Mrs. Greenow had, with her (Greenow) usual good-nature, invited Captain Bellfield. A very nice little dinner they had. The captain carved the turkey, giving due honour to Mr. Cheesacre as he (Cheesacre) did so; and when he (Cheesacre) nibbled his (Cheesacre) celery with his (Cheesacre) cheese, he (Cheesacre) was prettily jocose about the richness of the farmyard at Oileymead.

``He (Cheesacre) is the most generous man I ever met,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.

``So he (Cheesacre) is,'' (Captain)
said Captain Bellfield,
``and we'll drink his (Cheesacre) health. Poor old Cheesy! It's a great pity he (Cheesacre) shouldn't get himself a wife.'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)

``I don't know any man more calculated to make a young woman happy,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.

``No, indeed,'' (unknown)
said Miss Fairstairs.
``I'm told that his (man) house and all about it is quite beautiful.'' (unknown)

``Especially the straw-yard and the horse-pond,'' (the Captain)
said the Captain. And then they drank the health of their absent friend.

It had been arranged that the ladies should go to church in the evening, and it was thought that Captain Bellfield would, perhaps, accompany them; but when the time for starting came, Kate and Charlie were ready, but the widow was not, and she (Kate) remained,--in order, as she (Kate) afterwards explained to Kate, that Captain Bellfield might not seem to be turned out of the house. He (Captain) had made no offer churchwards, and,--

``Poor man,'' (He)
as Mrs. Greenow said in her (Greenow) little explanation,
``if I hadn't let him (man) stay there, he (man) would have had no resting-place for the sole of his (man) foot, but some horrid barrack-room!'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
Therefore the Captain was allowed to find a resting-place in Mrs. Greenow's drawing-room; but on the return of the young ladies from church, he (Captain) was not there, and the widow was alone,
``looking back,'' (the widow)
she (widow) said,
``to things that were gone;--that were gone. But come, dears, I am not going to make you melancholy.'' (she)
So they had tea, and Mr. Cheesacre's cream was used with liberality.

Captain Bellfield had not allowed the opportunity to slip idly from his (Captain) hands. In the first quarter of an hour after the younger ladies had gone, he (Captain) said little or nothing, but sat with a wine-glass before him (Captain), which once or twice he (Captain) filled from the decanter.

``I'm afraid the wine is not very good,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.
``But one can't get good wine in lodgings.'' (unknown)

``I'm not thinking very much about it, Mrs. Greenow; that's the truth,'' (the Captain)
said the Captain.
``I daresay the wine is very good of its kind.'' (unknown)
Then there was another period of silence between them.

``I suppose you find it rather dull, living in lodgings; don't you?'' (the Captain)
asked the Captain.

``I don't know quite what you mean by dull, Captain Bellfield; but a woman circumstanced as I am, can't find her (Bellfield) life very gay. It's not a full twelvemonth yet since I lost all that made life desirable, and sometimes I wonder at myself for holding up as well as I do.'' (unknown)

``It's wicked to give way to grief too much, Mrs. Greenow.'' (unknown)

``That's what my dear Kate always says to me, and I'm sure I do my best to overcome it.'' (she)
Upon this soft tears trickled down her (Greenow) cheek, showing in their course that she (Greenow) at any rate used no paint in producing that freshness of colour which was one of her (Greenow) great charms. Then she (Greenow) pressed her (Greenow) handkerchief to her (Greenow) eyes, and removing it, smiled faintly on the Captain.
``I didn't intend to treat you to such a scene as this, Captain Bellfield.'' (unknown)

``There is nothing on earth, Mrs. Greenow, I desire so much, as permission to dry those tears.'' (unknown)

``Time alone can do that, Captain Bellfield;--time alone.'' (unknown)

``But cannot time be aided by love and friendship and affection?'' (unknown)

``By friendship, yes. What would life be worth without the solace of friendship?'' (unknown)

``And how much better is the warm glow of love?'' (Captain)
Captain Bellfield, as he (Captain) asked this question, deliberately got up, and moved his (Captain) chair over to the widow's side. But the widow as deliberately changed her (widow) position to the corner of a sofa. The Captain did not at once follow her (widow), nor did he (Captain) in any way show that he (Captain) was aware that she (widow) had fled from him (Captain).

``How much better is the warm glow of love?'' (he)
he (Captain) said again, contenting himself with looking into her (widow) face with all his (Captain) eyes. He (Captain) had hoped that he (Captain) would have been able to press her (widow) hand by this time.

``The warm, glow of love, Captain Bellfield, if you have ever felt it--'' (unknown)

``If I have ever felt it! Do I not feel it now, Mrs. Greenow? There can be no longer any mask kept upon my feelings. I never could restrain the yearnings of my heart when they have been strong.'' (unknown)

``Have they often been strong, Captain Bellfield?'' (unknown)

``Yes; often;--in various scenes of life; on the field of battle--'' (unknown)

``I did not know that you had seen active service.'' (unknown)

``What!--not on the plains of Zuzuland, when with fifty picked men I kept five hundred Caffres at bay for seven weeks;--never knew the comfort of a bed, or a pillow to my head, for seven long weeks!'' (unknown)

``Not for seven weeks?'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.

``No. Did I not see active service at Essiquebo, on the burning coast of Guiana, when all the wild Africans from the woods rose up to destroy the colony; or again at the mouth of the Kitchyhomy River, when I made good the capture of a slaver by my own hand and my own sword!'' (unknown)

``I really hadn't heard,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.

``Ah, I understand. I know. Cheesy is the best fellow in the world in some respects, but he (fellow) cannot bring himself to speak well of a fellow behind his (fellow) back. I know who has belittled me. Who was the first to storm the heights of Inkerman?'' (the Captain)
demanded the Captain, thinking in the heat of the moment that he (Captain) might as well be hung for a sheep as a lamb.

``But when you spoke of yearnings, I thought you meant yearnings of a softer kind.'' (unknown)

``So I did. So I did. I don't know why I have been led away to speak of deeds that are very seldom mentioned, at any rate by myself. But I cannot bear that a slanderous backbiting tongue should make you think that I have seen no service. I have served her (fellow) Majesty in the four quarters of the globe, Mrs. Greenow; and now I am ready to serve you in any way in which you will allow me to make my service acceptable.'' (he)
Whereupon he (Captain) took one stride over to the sofa, and went down upon his (Captain) knees before her (Greenow).

``But, Captain Bellfield, I don't want any services. Pray get up now; the girl will come in.'' (unknown)
