``I care nothing for any girl. I am planted here till some answer shall have been made to me; till some word shall have been said that may give me a little hope.'' (he)
Then he (Captain) attempted to get hold of her (Greenow) hand, but she (Greenow) put them behind her (Greenow) back and shook her (Greenow) head.
``Arabella,'' (he)
he (Captain) said,
``will you not speak a word to me?'' (he)

``Not a word, Captain Bellfield, till you get up; and I won't have you call me Arabella. I am the widow of Samuel Greenow, than whom no man was more respected where he (man) was known, and it is not fitting that I should be addressed in that way.'' (unknown)

``But I want you to become my wife,--and then--'' (unknown)

``Ah, then indeed! But that then isn't likely to come. Get up, Captain Bellfield, or I'll push you over and then ring the bell. A man never looks so much like a fool as when he (man)'s kneeling down,--unless he (man)'s saying his (man) prayers, as you ought to be doing now. Get up, I tell you. It's just half past seven, and I told Jeannette to come to me then.'' (the widow)

There was that in the widow's voice which made him (Captain) get up, and he (Captain) rose slowly to his (Captain) feet.

``You've pushed all the chairs about, you stupid man,'' (she)
she (Greenow) said. Then in one minute she (Greenow) had restored the scattered furniture to their proper places, and had rung the bell. When Jeannette came she (Jeannette) desired that tea might be ready by the time that the young ladies returned, and asked Captain Bellfield if a cup should be set for him (Captain). This he (Captain) declined, and bade her (Bellfield) farewell while Jeannette was still in the room. She (Jeannette) shook hands with him (Captain) without any sign of anger, and even expressed a hope that they might see him (Captain) again before long.

``He (man)'s a very handsome man, is the Captain,'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette, as the hero of the Kitchyhomy River descended the stairs.

``You shouldn't think about handsome men, child,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.

``And I'm sure I don't,'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette.
``Not no more than anybody else; but if a man is handsome, ma'am, why it stands to reason that he (man) is handsome.'' (unknown)

``I suppose Captain Bellfield has given you a kiss and a pair of gloves.'' (unknown)

``As for gloves and such like, Mr. Cheesacre is much better for giving than the Captain; as we all know; don't we, ma'am? But in regard to kisses, they're presents as I never takes from anybody. Let everybody pay his (Captain) debts. If the Captain ever gets a wife, let him (Captain) kiss her (wife).'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)

On the following Tuesday morning Mr. Cheesacre as usual called in the Close, but he (Cheesacre) brought with him (Cheesacre) no basket. He (Cheesacre) merely left a winter nosegay made of green leaves and laurestinus flowers, and sent up a message to say that he (Cheesacre) should call at half past three, and hoped that he (Cheesacre) might then be able to see Mrs. Greenow--on particular business.

``That means you, Kate,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.

``No, it doesn't; it doesn't mean me at all. At any rate he (Captain) won't see me.'' (unknown)

``I dare say it's me he (Captain) wishes to see. It seems to be the fashionable plan now for gentlemen to make offers by deputy. If he (deputy) says anything, I can only refer him (deputy) to you, you know.'' (unknown)

``Yes, you can; you can tell him (deputy) simply that I won't have him (deputy). But he (deputy) is no more thinking of me than--'' (unknown)

``Than he (deputy) is of me, you were going to say.'' (unknown)

``No, aunt; I wasn't going to say that at all.'' (unknown)

``Well, we shall see. If he (deputy) does mean anything, of course you can please yourself; but I really think you might do worse.'' (unknown)

``But if I don't want to do at all?'' (unknown)

``Very well; you must have your own way. I can only tell you what I think.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)

At half past three o'clock punctually Mr. Cheesacre came to the door, and was shown up-stairs. He (Cheesacre) was told by Jeannette that Captain Bellfield had looked in on the Sunday afternoon, but that Miss Fairstairs and Miss Vavasor had been there the whole time. He (Captain) had not got on his (Captain) black boots nor yet had his (Captain) round topped hat. And as he (Captain) did wear a new frock coat, and had his (Captain) left hand thrust into a kid glove, Jeannette was quite sure that he (Captain) intended business of some kind. With new boots, creaking loudly, he (Captain) walked up into the drawing-room, and there he (Captain) found the widow alone.

``Thanks for the flowers,'' (she)
she (widow) said at once.
``It was so good of you to bring something that we could accept.'' (unknown)

``As for that,'' (he)
said he (Captain),
``I don't see why you should scruple about a trifle of cream, but I hope that any such feeling as that will be over before long.'' (he)
To this the widow made no answer, but she (widow) looked very sweetly on him (Captain) as she (widow) bade him (Captain) sit down.

He (Captain) did sit down; but first he (Captain) put his (Captain) hat and stick carefully away in one corner, and then he (Captain) pulled off his (Captain) glove--somewhat laboriously, for his (Captain) hand was warm. He (Captain) was clearly prepared for great things. As he (Captain) pushed up his (Captain) hair with his (Captain) hands there came from his (Captain) locks an ambrosial perfume,--as of marrow-oil, and there was a fixed propriety of position of every hair of his (Captain) whiskers, which indicated very plainly that he (Captain) had been at a hairdresser's shop since he (Captain) left the market. Nor do I believe that he (Captain) had worn that coat when he (Captain) came to the door earlier in the morning. If I were to say that he (Captain) had called at his (Captain) tailor's also, I do not think that I should be wrong.

``How goes everything at Oileymead?'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, seeing that her (Greenow) guest wanted some little assistance in leading off the conversation.

``Pretty well, Mrs. Greenow; pretty well. Everything will go very well if I am successful in the object which I have on hand to-day.'' (unknown)

``I'm sure I hope you'll be successful in all your undertakings.'' (unknown)

``In all my business undertakings I am, Mrs. Greenow. There isn't a shilling due on my land to e'er a bank in Norwich; and I haven't thrashed out a quarter of last year's corn yet, which is more than many of them can say. But there ain't many of them who don't have to pay rent, and so perhaps I oughtn't to boast.'' (unknown)

``I know that Providence has been very good to you, Mr. Cheesacre, as regards worldly matters.'' (unknown)

``And I haven't left it all to Providence, either. Those who do, generally go to the wall, as far as I can see. I'm always at work late and early, and I know when I get a profit out of a man's labour and when I don't, as well as though it was my only chance of bread and cheese.'' (unknown)

``I always thought you understood farming business, Mr. Cheesacre.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I do. I like a bit of fun well enough, when the time for it comes, as you saw at Yarmouth. And I keep my three or four hunters, as I think a country gentleman should; and I shoot over my own ground. But I always stick to my work. There are men, like Bellfield, who won't work. What do they come to? They're always borrowing.'' (unknown)

``But he (gentleman) has fought his (gentleman) country's battles, Mr. Cheesacre.'' (unknown)

``He (Cheesacre) fight! I suppose he (Cheesacre)'s been telling you some of his (Cheesacre) old stories. He (Cheesacre) was ten years in the West Indies, and all his (Cheesacre) fighting was with the mosquitoes.'' (unknown)

``But he (Cheesacre) was in the Crimea. At Inkerman, for instance--'' (unknown)

``He (Cheesacre) in the Crimea! Well, never mind. But do you inquire before you believe that story. But as I was saying, Mrs. Greenow, you have seen my little place at Oileymead.'' (unknown)

``A charming house. All you want is a mistress for it.'' (unknown)

``That's it; that's just it. All I want is a mistress for it. And there's only one woman on earth that I would wish to see in that position. Arabella Greenow, will you be that woman?'' (he)
As he (guest) made the offer he (guest) got up and stood before her (Greenow), placing his (guest) right hand upon his (guest) heart.

-LSB-Illustration:

``Arabella Greenow, will you be that woman?'' (unknown)
-RSB-

``I, Mr. Cheesacre!'' (she)
she (Greenow) said.

``Yes, you. Who else? Since I saw you what other woman has been anything to me; or, indeed, I may say before? Since the first day I saw you I felt that there my happiness depended.'' (unknown)

``Oh, Mr. Cheesacre, I thought you were looking elsewhere.'' (unknown)

``No, no, no. There never was such a mistake as that. I have the highest regard and esteem for Miss Vavasor, but really--'' (unknown)

``Mr. Cheesacre, what am I to say to you?'' (unknown)

``What are you to say to me? Say that you'll be mine. Say that I shall be yours. Say that all I have at Oileymead shall be yours. Say that the open carriage for a pair of ponies to be driven by a lady which I have been looking at this morning shall be yours. Yes, indeed; the sweetest thing you ever saw in your life,--just like one that the lady of the Lord Lieutenant drives about in always. That's what you must say. Come, Mrs. Greenow!'' (unknown)

``Ah, Mr. Cheesacre, you don't know what it is to have buried the pride of your youth hardly yet twelve months.'' (unknown)

``But you have buried him (Cheesacre), and there let there be an end of it. Your sitting here all alone, morning, noon, and night, won't bring him (Cheesacre) back. I'm sorry for him (Cheesacre); I am indeed. Poor Greenow! But what more can I do?'' (unknown)

``I can do more, Mr. Cheesacre. I can mourn for him (Cheesacre) in solitude and in silence.'' (unknown)

``No, no, no. What's the use of it,--breaking your heart for nothing,--and my heart too. You never think of that.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
And Mr. Cheesacre spoke in a tone that was full of reproach.

``It cannot be, Mr. Cheesacre.'' (unknown)

``Ah, but it can be. Come, Mrs. Greenow. We understand each other well enough now, surely. Come, dearest.'' (he)
And he (Cheesacre) approached her (Greenow) as though to put his (Cheesacre) arm round her (Greenow) waist. But at that moment there came a knock at the door, and Jeannette, entering the room, told her (Jeannette) mistress that Captain Bellfield was below and wanted to know whether he (Captain) could see her (Bellfield) for a minute on particular business.

``Show Captain Bellfield up, certainly,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.

``D-- Captain Bellfield!'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre.

CHAPTER XXI.

Alice Is Taught to Grow Upwards, Towards the Light.

Before the day came on which Alice was to go to Matching Priory, she (Alice) had often regretted that she (Alice) had been induced to make the promise, and yet she (Alice) had as often resolved that there was no possible reason why she (Alice) should not go to Matching Priory. But she (Alice) feared this commencement of a closer connection with her (Alice) great relations. She (Alice) had told herself so often that she (Alice) was quite separated from them, that the slight accident of blood in no way tied her (Alice) to them or them to her (Alice),--this lesson had been so thoroughly taught to her (Alice) by the injudicious attempts of Lady Macleod to teach an opposite lesson, that she (Alice) did not like the idea of putting aside the effect of that teaching. And perhaps she (Alice) was a little afraid of the great folk whom she (Alice) might probably meet at her (Alice) cousin's house. Lady Glencora herself she (Glencora) had liked,--and had loved too with that momentary love which certain circumstances of our life will sometimes produce, a love which is strong while it lasts, but which can be laid down when the need of it is passed. She (Glencora) had liked and loved Lady Glencora, and had in no degree been afraid of her (Glencora) during those strange visitings in Queen Anne Street;--but she (Glencora) was by no means sure that she (Glencora) should like Lady Glencora in the midst of her (Glencora) grandeur and surrounded by the pomp of her (Glencora) rank. She (Glencora) would have no other friend or acquaintance in that house, and feared that she (Glencora) might find herself desolate, cold, and wounded in her (Glencora) pride. She (Glencora) had been tricked into the visit, too, or rather had tricked herself into it. She (Glencora) had been sure that there had been a joint scheme between her (Glencora) cousin and Lady Midlothian, and could not resist the temptation of repudiating it in her (Glencora) letter to Lady Glencora. But there had been no such scheme; she (Glencora) had wronged Lady Glencora, and had therefore been unable to resist her (Glencora) second request. But she (Glencora) felt unhappy, fearing that she (Glencora) would be out of her (Glencora) element, and more than once half made up her (Glencora) mind to excuse herself.

Her (Glencora) aunt had, from the first, thought well of her (Glencora) going, believing that it might probably be the means of reconciling her (Glencora) to Mr. Grey. Moreover, it was a step altogether in the right direction. Lady Glencora would, if she (Glencora) lived, become a Duchess, and as she (Glencora) was decidedly Alice's cousin, of course Alice should go to her (Alice) house when invited. It must be acknowledged that Lady Macleod was not selfish in her (Macleod) worship of rank. She (Macleod) had played out her (Macleod) game in life, and there was no probability that she (Macleod) would live to be called cousin by a Duchess of Omnium. She (Duchess) bade Alice go to Matching Priory, simply because she (Alice) loved her (Alice) niece, and therefore wished her (Alice) to live in the best and most eligible way within her (Alice) reach.

``I think you owe it as a duty to your family to go,'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)
said Lady Macleod.

What further correspondence about her (Macleod) affairs had passed between Lady Macleod and Lady Midlothian Alice never knew. She (Lady) steadily refused all entreaty made that she (Lady) would answer the Countess's letter, and at last threatened her (Lady) aunt that if the request were further urged she (Lady) would answer it,--telling Lady Midlothian that she (Midlothian) had been very impertinent.

``I am becoming a very old woman, Alice,'' (the lady)
the poor lady said, piteously,
``and I suppose I had better not interfere any further. Whatever I have said I have always meant to be for your good.'' (the lady)
Then Alice got up, and kissing her (Alice) aunt, tried to explain to her (Alice) that she (Alice) resented no interference from her (Alice), and felt grateful for all that she (Alice) both said and did; but that she (Alice) could not endure meddling from people whom she (Alice) did not know, and who thought themselves entitled to meddle by their rank.

``And because they are cousins as well,'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)
said Lady Macleod, in a softly sad, apologetic voice.

Alice left Cheltenham about the middle of November on her (Alice) road to Matching Priory. She (Alice) was to sleep in London one night, and go down to Matching in Yorkshire with her (Alice) maid on the following day. Her (Alice) father undertook to meet her (Alice) at the Great Western Station, and to take her (Alice) on the following morning to the Great Northern. He (Great) said nothing in his (Great) letter about dining with her (Alice), but when he (Great) met her (Alice), muttered something about an engagement, and taking her (Alice) home graciously promised that he (Great) would breakfast with her (Alice) on the following morning.

``I'm very glad you are going, Alice,'' (he)
he (Great) said when they were in the cab together.

``Why, papa?'' (unknown)

``Why?--because I think it's the proper thing to do. You know I've never said much to you about these people. They're not connected with me, and I know that they hate the name of Vavasor;--not but what the name is a deal older than any of theirs, and the family too.'' (unknown)

``And therefore I don't understand why you think I'm specially right. If you were to say I was specially wrong, I should be less surprised, and of course I shouldn't go.'' (unknown)

``You should go by all means. Rank and wealth are advantages, let anybody say what they will to the contrary. Why else does everybody want to get them?'' (unknown)

``But I shan't get them by going to Matching Priory.'' (unknown)

``You'll get part of their value. Take them as a whole, the nobility of England are pleasant acquaintances to have. I haven't run after them very much myself, though I married, as I may say, among them. That very thing rather stood in my way than otherwise. But you may be sure of this, that men and women ought to grow, like plants, upwards. Everybody should endeavour to stand as well as he (acquaintances) can in the world, and if I had a choice of acquaintance between a sugar-baker and a peer, I should prefer the peer,--unless, indeed, the sugar-baker had something very strong on his (acquaintance) side to offer. I don't call that tuft-hunting, and it does not necessitate toadying. It's simply growing up, towards the light, as the trees do.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice listened to her (Alice) father's worldly wisdom with a smile, but she (Alice) did not attempt to answer him (father). It was very seldom, indeed, that he (father) took upon himself the labour of lecturing her (Alice), or that he (father) gave her (Alice) even as much counsel as he (father) had given now.

``Well, papa, I hope I shall find myself growing towards the light,'' (she)
she (Alice) said as she (Alice) got out of the cab. Then he (father) had not entered the house, but had taken the cab on with him (father) to his (father) club.

On her (Alice) table Alice found a note from her (Alice) cousin George.

``I hear you are going down to the Pallisers at Matching Priory to-morrow, and as I shall be glad to say one word to you before you go, will you let me see you this evening,--say at nine?--G. V.'' (She)
She (Alice) felt immediately that she (Alice) could not help seeing him (George), but she (Alice) greatly regretted the necessity. She (Alice) wished that she (Alice) had gone directly from Cheltenham to the North,--regardless even of those changes of wardrobe which her (Alice) purposed visit required. Then she (Alice) set herself to considering. How had George heard of her (Alice) visit to the Priory, and how had he (George) learned the precise evening which she (Alice) would pass in London? Why should he (George) be so intent on watching all her (Alice) movements as it seemed that he (George) was? As to seeing him (George) she (Alice) had no alternative, so she (Alice) completed her (Alice) arrangements for her (Alice) journey before nine, and then awaited him (George) in the drawing-room.

``I'm so glad you're going to Matching Priory,'' (he)
were the first words he (George) said. He (George), too, might have taught her (Alice) to grow towards the light, if she (Alice) had asked him (George) for his (George) reasons;--but this she (Alice) did not do just then.

``How did you learn that I was going?'' (she)
she (Alice) said.

``I heard it from a friend of mine. Well;--from Burgo Fitzgerald, if you must know.'' (unknown)

``From Mr. Fitzgerald?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, in profound astonishment:
``How could Mr. Fitzgerald have heard of it?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``That's more than I know, Alice. Not directly from Lady Glencora, I should say.'' (unknown)

``That would be impossible.'' (unknown)

``Yes; quite so, no doubt. I think she (Glencora) keeps up her (Glencora) intimacy with Burgo's sister, and perhaps it got round to him (Burgo) in that way.'' (unknown)

``And did he (Burgo) tell you also that I was going to-morrow? He (Burgo) must have known all about it very accurately.'' (unknown)

``No; then I asked Kate, and Kate told me when you were going. Yes; I know. Kate has been wrong, hasn't she (Kate)? Kate was cautioned, no doubt, to say nothing about your comings and goings to so inconsiderable a person as myself. But you must not be down upon Kate. She (Kate) never mentioned it till I showed by my question to her (Kate) that I knew all about your journey to Matching. I own I do not understand why it should be necessary to keep me so much in the dark.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice felt that she (Alice) was blushing. The caution had been given to Kate because Kate still transgressed in her (Kate) letters, by saying little words about her (Kate) brother. And Alice did not even now believe Kate to have been false to her (Kate); but she (Kate) saw that she (Kate) herself had been imprudent.

``I cannot understand it,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
continued George, speaking without looking at her (Kate).
``It was but the other day that we were such dear friends! Do you remember the balcony at Basle? and now it seems that we are quite estranged;--nay, worse than estranged; that I am, as it were, under some ban. Have I done anything to offend you, Alice? If so, speak out, like a woman of spirit as you are.'' (unknown)

``Nothing,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Then why am I tabooed? Why was I told the other day that I might not congratulate you on your happy emancipation? I say boldly, that had you resolved on that while we were together in Switzerland, you would have permitted me, as a friend, almost as a brother, to discuss it with you.'' (unknown)

``I think not, George.'' (unknown)

``I am sure you would. And why has Kate been warned not to tell me of this visit to the Pallisers? I know she (Kate) has been warned though she (Kate) has not confessed it.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice sat silent, not knowing what to say in answer to this charge brought against her (Alice),--thinking, perhaps, that the questioner would allow his (questioner) question to pass without an answer. But Vavasor was not so complaisant.

``If there be any reason, Alice, I think that I have a right to ask it.'' (she)

For a few seconds she (Vavasor) did not speak a word, but sat considering. He (questioner) also remained silent with his (questioner) eyes fixed upon her (Vavasor). She (Vavasor) looked at him (questioner) and saw nothing but his (questioner) scar,--nothing but his (questioner) scar and the brightness of his (questioner) eyes, which was almost fierce. She (Vavasor) knew that he (questioner) was in earnest, and therefore resolved that she (Vavasor) would be in earnest also.

``I think that you have such a right,'' (she)
she (Vavasor) said at last.

``Then let me exercise it.'' (unknown)

``I think that you have such a right, but I think also that you are ungenerous to exercise it.'' (unknown)

``I cannot understand that. By heavens, Alice, I cannot be left in this suspense! If I have done anything to offend you, perhaps I can remove the offence by apology.'' (unknown)

``You have done nothing to offend me.'' (unknown)

``Or if there be any cause why our friendship should be dropped,--why we should be on a different footing to each other in London than we were in Switzerland, I may acknowledge it, if it be explained to me. But I cannot put up with the doubt, when I am told that I have a right to demand its solution.'' (unknown)

``Then I will be frank with you, George, though my being so will, as you may guess, be very painful.'' (She)
She (Vavasor) paused again, looking at him (questioner) to see if yet he (questioner) would spare her (Vavasor); but he (questioner) was all scar and eyes as before, and there was no mercy in his (questioner) face.

``Your sister, George, has thought that my parting with Mr. Grey might lead to a renewal of a purpose of marriage between you and me. You know her (sister) eagerness, and will understand that it may have been necessary that I should require silence from her (sister) on that head. You ought now to understand it all.'' (unknown)

``I then am being punished for her (sister) sins,'' (he)
he (questioner) said; and suddenly the scar on his (questioner) face was healed up again, and there was something of the old pleasantness in his (questioner) eyes.

``I have said nothing about any sins, George, but I have found it necessary to be on my guard.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (he)
he (questioner) said, after a short pause,
``You are an honest woman, Alice,--the honestest I ever knew. I will bring Kate to order,--and, now, we may be friends again; may we not?'' (he)
And he (questioner) extended his (questioner) hand to her (Vavasor) across the table.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Vavasor) said,
``certainly, if you wish it.'' (she)
She (Vavasor) spoke doubtingly, with indecision in her (Vavasor) voice, as though remembering at the moment that he (questioner) had given her (Vavasor) no pledge.
``I certainly do wish it very much,'' (he)
said he (questioner); and then she (Vavasor) gave him (questioner) her (Vavasor) hand.

``And I may now talk about your new freedom?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (she)
said she (Vavasor);
``no. Do not speak of that. A woman does not do what I have done in that affair without great suffering. I have to think of it daily; but do not make me speak of it.'' (she)

``But this other subject, this visit to Matching; surely I may speak of that?'' (she)
There was something now in his (questioner) voice so bright, that she (Vavasor) felt the influence of it, and answered him (questioner) cheerfully,
``I don't see what you can have to say about it.'' (him)

``But I have a great deal. I am so glad you are going. Mind you cement a close intimacy with Mr. Palliser.'' (unknown)

``With Mr. Palliser?'' (unknown)

``Yes; with Mr. Palliser. You must read all the blue books about finance. I'll send them to you if you like it.'' (unknown)

``Oh, George!'' (unknown)

``I'm quite in earnest. That is, not in earnest about the blue books, as you would not have time; but about Mr. Palliser. He (Palliser) will be the new Chancellor of the Exchequer without a doubt.'' (unknown)

``Will he (Palliser) indeed? But why should I make a bosom friend of the Chancellor of the Exchequer. I don't want any public money.'' (unknown)

``But I do, my girl. Don't you see?'' (unknown)

``No; I don't.'' (unknown)

``I think I shall get returned at this next election.'' (unknown)

``I'm sure I hope you will.'' (unknown)

``And if I do, of course it will be my game to support the ministry;--or rather the new ministry; for of course there will be changes.'' (unknown)

``I hope they will be on the right side.'' (unknown)

``Not a doubt of that, Alice.'' (unknown)

``I wish they might be changed altogether.'' (unknown)

``Ah! that's impossible. It's very well as a dream; but there are no such men as you want to see,--men really from the people,--strong enough to take high office. A man can't drive four horses because he (man)'s a philanthropist,--or rather a philhorseophist, and is desirous that the team should be driven without any hurt to them. A man can't govern well, simply because he (man) is genuinely anxious that men should be well governed.'' (unknown)

``And will there never be any such men?'' (unknown)

``I won't say that. I don't mind confessing to you that it is my ambition to be such a one myself. But a child must crawl before he (man) can walk. Such a one as I, hoping to do something in politics, must spare no chance. It would be something to me that Mr. Palliser should become the friend of any dear friend of mine,--especially of a dear friend bearing the same name.'' (unknown)

``I'm afraid, George, you'll find me a bad hand at making any such friendship.'' (unknown)

``They say he (George) is led immensely by his (George) wife, and that she (wife) is very clever. But I mean this chiefly, Alice, that I do hope I shall have all your sympathy in any political career that I may make, and all your assistance also.'' (unknown)

``My sympathy I think I can promise you. My assistance, I fear, would be worthless.'' (unknown)

``By no means worthless, Alice; not if I see you take that place in the world which I hope to see you fill. Do you think women nowadays have no bearing upon the politics of the times? Almost as much as men have.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
In answer to which Alice shook her (Alice) head; but, nevertheless, she (Alice) felt in some way pleased and flattered.

George left her (Alice) without saying a word more about her (Alice) marriage prospects past or future, and Alice as she (Alice) went to bed felt glad that this explanation between them had been made.

CHAPTER XXII.

Dandy and Flirt.

Alice reached the Matching Road Station about three o'clock in the afternoon without adventure, and immediately on the stopping of the train became aware that all trouble was off her (Alice) own hands. A servant in livery came to the open window, and touching his (servant) hat to her (Alice), inquired if she (Alice) were Miss Vavasor. Then her (Alice) dressing-bag and shawls and cloaks were taken from her (Alice), and she (Alice) was conveyed through the station by the station-master on one side of her (Alice), the footman on the other, and by the railway porter behind. She (Alice) instantly perceived that she (Alice) had become possessed of great privileges by belonging even for a time to Matching Priory, and that she (Alice) was essentially growing upwards towards the light.

Outside, on the broad drive before the little station, she (Alice) saw an omnibus that was going to the small town of Matching, intended for people who had not grown upwards as had been her (Alice) lot; and she (Alice) saw also a light stylish-looking cart which she (Alice) would have called a Whitechapel had she (Alice) been properly instructed in such matters, and a little low open carriage with two beautiful small horses, in which was sitting a lady enveloped in furs. Of course this was Lady Glencora. Another servant was standing on the ground, holding the horses of the carriage and the cart.

``Dear Alice, I'm so glad you've come,'' (unknown)
said a voice from the furs.
``Look here, dear; your maid can go in the dog-cart with your things,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
--it wasn't a dog-cart, but Lady Glencora knew no better;--
``she (maid)'ll be quite comfortable there; and do you get in here. Are you very cold?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``Oh, no; not cold at all.'' (unknown)

``But it is awfully cold. You've been in the stuffy carriage, but you'll find it cold enough out here, I can tell you.'' (unknown)

``Oh! Lady Glencora, I am so sorry that I've brought you out on such a morning,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, getting in and taking the place assigned her (Alice) next to the charioteer.

``What nonsense! Sorry! Why I've looked forward to meeting you all alone, ever since I knew you were coming. If it had snowed all the morning I should have come just the same. I drive out almost every day when I'm down here,--that is, when the house is not too crowded, or I can make an excuse. Wrap these things over you; there are plenty of them. You shall drive if you like.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice, however, declined the driving, expressing her (Alice) gratitude in what prettiest words she (Alice) could find.

``I like driving better than anything, I think. Mr. Palliser doesn't like ladies to hunt, and of course it wouldn't do as he (Palliser) does not hunt himself. I do ride, but he (Palliser) never gets on horseback. I almost fancy I should like to drive four-in-hand,--only I know I should be afraid.'' (unknown)

``It would look very terrible,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Yes; wouldn't it? The look would be the worst of it; as it is all the world over. Sometimes I wish there were no such things as looks. I don't mean anything improper, you know; only one does get so hampered, right and left, for fear of Mrs. Grundy. I endeavour to go straight, and get along pretty well on the whole, I suppose. Baker, you must put Dandy in the bar; he (Baker) pulls so, going home, that I can't hold him (Baker) in the check.'' (She)
She (Alice) stopped the horses, and Baker, a very completely-got-up groom of some forty years of age, who sat behind, got down and put the impetuous Dandy
``in the bar,'' (Dandy)
thereby changing the rein, so that the curb was brought to bear on him (Dandy).
``They're called Dandy and Flirt,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
continued Lady Glencora, speaking to Alice.
``Ain't they a beautiful match? The Duke gave them to me and named them himself. Did you ever see the Duke?'' (unknown)

-LSB-Illustration:

``Baker, you must put Dandy in the bar.'' (unknown)
-RSB-

``Never,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``He (Baker) won't be here before Christmas, but you shall be introduced some day in London. He (Baker)'s an excellent creature and I'm a great pet of his (Baker); though, after all, I never speak half a dozen words to him (Baker) when I see him (Baker). He (Baker)'s one of those people who never talk. I'm one of those who like talking, as you'll find out. I think it runs in families; and the Pallisers are non-talkers. That doesn't mean that they are not speakers, for Mr. Palliser has plenty to say in the House, and they declare that he (Palliser)'s one of the few public men who've got lungs enough to make a financial statement without breaking down.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice was aware that she (Alice) had as yet hardly spoken herself, and began to bethink herself that she (Alice) didn't know what to say. Had Lady Glencora paused on the subject of Dandy and Flirt, she (Glencora) might have managed to be enthusiastic about the horses, but she (Glencora) could not discuss freely the general silence of the Palliser family, nor the excellent lungs, as regarded public purposes, of the one who was the husband of her (Glencora) present friend. So she (Glencora) asked how far it was to Matching Priory.

``You're not tired of me already, I hope,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``I didn't mean that,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``I delight in the drive. But somehow one expects Matching Station to be near Matching.'' (unknown)

``Ah, yes; that's a great cheat. It's not Matching Station at all but Matching Road Station, and it's eight miles. It is a great bore, for though the omnibus brings our parcels, we have to be constantly sending over, and it's very expensive, I can assure you. I want Mr. Palliser to have a branch, but he (Palliser) says he (Palliser) would have to take all the shares himself, and that would cost more, I suppose.'' (unknown)

``Is there a town at Matching?'' (unknown)

``Oh, a little bit of a place. I'll go round by it if you like, and in at the further gate.'' (unknown)

``Oh, no!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Ah, but I should like. It was a borough once, and belonged to the Duke; but they put it out at the Reform Bill. They made some kind of bargain;--he (Palliser) was to keep either Silverbridge or Matching, but not both. Mr. Palliser sits for Silverbridge, you know. The Duke chose Silverbridge,--or rather his (Palliser) father did, as he (Palliser) was then going to build his (Palliser) great place in Barsetshire;--that's near Silverbridge. But the Matching people haven't forgiven him (Palliser) yet. He (Palliser) was sitting for Matching himself when the Reform Bill passed. Then his (Bill) father died, and he (Bill) hasn't lived there much since. It's a great deal nicer place than Gatherum Castle, only not half so grand. I hate grandeur; don't you?'' (unknown)

``I never tried much of it, as you have.'' (unknown)

``Come now; that's not fair. There's no one in the world less grand than I am.'' (unknown)

``I mean that I've not had grand people about me.'' (unknown)

``Having cut all your cousins,--and Lady Midlothian in particular, like a naughty girl as you are. I was so angry with you when you accused me of selling you about that. You ought to have known that I was the last person in the world to have done such a thing.'' (unknown)

``I did not think you meant to sell me, but I thought--'' (unknown)

``Yes, you did, Alice. I know what you thought; you thought that Lady Midlothian was making a tool of me that I might bring you under her (Midlothian) thumb, so that she (Midlothian) might bully you into Mr. Grey's arms. That's what you thought. I don't know that I was at all entitled to your good opinion, but I was not entitled to that special bad opinion.'' (unknown)

``I had no bad opinion;--but it was so necessary that I should guard myself.'' (unknown)

``You shall be guarded. I'll take you under my shield. Mr. Grey shan't be named to you, except that I shall expect you to tell me all about it; and you must tell me all about that dangerous cousin, too, of whom they were saying such terrible things down in Scotland. I had heard of him (cousin) before.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
These last words Lady Glencora spoke in a lower voice and in an altered tone,--slowly, as though she (Glencora) were thinking of something that pained her (Glencora). It was from Burgo Fitzgerald that she (Glencora) had heard of George Vavasor.

Alice did not know what to say. She (Alice) found it impossible to discuss all the most secret and deepest of her (Alice) feelings out in that open carriage, perhaps in the hearing of the servant behind, on this her (Alice) first meeting with her (Alice) cousin,--of whom, in fact, she (Alice) knew very little. She (Alice) had not intended to discuss these things at all, and certainly not in such a manner as this. So she (Alice) remained silent.

``This is the beginning of the park,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, pointing to a grand old ruin of an oak tree, which stood on the wide margin of the road, outside the rounded corner of the park palings, propped up with a skeleton of supporting sticks all round it.
``And that is Matching oak, under which Coeur de Lion or Edward the Third, I forget which, was met by Sir Guy de Palisere as he (Guy) came from the war, or from hunting, or something of that kind. It was the king, you know, who had been fighting or whatever it was, and Sir Guy entertained him (Guy) when he (Guy) was very tired. Jeffrey Palliser, who is my husband's cousin, says that old Sir Guy luckily pulled out his (Guy) brandy-flask. But the king immediately gave him (Guy) all the lands of Matching,--only there was a priory then and a lot of monks, and I don't quite understand how that was. But I know one of the younger brothers always used to be abbot and sit in the House of Lords. And the king gave him (king) Littlebury at the same time, which is about seven miles away from here. As Jeffrey Palliser says, it was a great deal of money for a pull at his (Palliser) flask. Jeffrey Palliser is here now, and I hope you'll like him (Palliser). If I have no child, and Mr. Palliser were not to marry again, Jeffrey would be the heir.'' (unknown)
And here again her (Glencora) voice was low and slow, and altogether changed in its tone.

``I suppose that's the way most of the old families got their estates.'' (unknown)

``Either so, or by robbery. Many of them were terrible thieves, my dear, and I dare say Sir Guy was no better than he (Guy) should be. But since that they have always called some of the Pallisers Plantagenet. My husband's name is Plantagenet. The Duke is called George Plantagenet, and the king was his (king) godfather. The queen is my godmother, I believe, but I don't know that I'm much the better for it. There's no use in godfathers and godmothers;--do you think there is?'' (unknown)

``Not much as it's managed now.'' (unknown)

``If I had a child,-- Oh, Alice, it's a dreadful thing not to have a child when so much depends on it!'' (unknown)

``But you're such a short time married yet.'' (unknown)

``Ah, well; I can see it in his (I) eyes when he (I) asks me questions; but I don't think he (I)'d say an unkind word, not if his (I) own position depended on it. Ah, well; this is Matching. That other gate we passed, where Dandy wanted to turn in,--that's where we usually go up, but I've brought you round to show you the town. That's the inn,--whoever can possibly come to stay there I don't know; I never saw anybody go in or out. That's the baker who bakes our bread,--we baked it at the house at first, but nobody could eat it; and I know that that man there mends Mr. Palliser's shoes. He (Palliser)'s very particular about his (Palliser) shoes. We shall see the church as we go in at the other gate. It is in the park, and is very pretty,--but not half so pretty as the priory ruins close to the house. The ruins are our great lion. I do so love to wander about them at moonlight. I often think of you when I do; I don't know why.--But I do know why, and I'll tell you some day. Come, Miss Flirt!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

As they drove up through the park, Lady Glencora pointed out first the church and then the ruins, through the midst of which the road ran, and then they were at once before the front door. The corner of the modern house came within two hundred yards of the gateway of the old priory. It was a large building, very pretty, with two long fronts; but it was no more than a house. It was not a palace, nor a castle, nor was it hardly to be called a mansion. It was built with gabled roofs, four of which formed the side from which the windows of the drawing-rooms opened out upon a lawn which separated the house from the old ruins, and which indeed surrounded the ruins, and went inside them, forming the present flooring of the old chapel, and the old refectory, and the old cloisters. Much of the cloisters indeed was standing, and there the stone pavement remained; but the square of the cloisters was all turfed, and in the middle of it stood a large modern stone vase, out of the broad basin of which hung flowering creepers and green tendrils.

As Lady Glencora drove up to the door, a gentleman, who had heard the sound of the wheels, came forth to meet them.

``There's Mr. Palliser,'' (she)
said she (Glencora);
``that shows that you are an honoured guest, for you may be sure that he (guest) is hard at work and would not have come out for anybody else. Plantagenet, here is Miss Vavasor, perished. Alice, my husband.'' (she)
Then Mr. Palliser put forth his (Palliser) hand and helped her (Glencora) out of the carriage.

``I hope you've not found it very cold,'' (he)
said he (Palliser).
``The winter has come upon us quite suddenly.'' (He)

He (Palliser) said nothing more to her (Glencora) than this, till he (Palliser) met her (Glencora) again before dinner. He (Palliser) was a tall thin man, apparently not more than thirty years of age, looking in all respects like a gentleman, but with nothing in his (gentleman) appearance that was remarkable. It was a face that you might see and forget, and see again and forget again; and yet when you looked at it and pulled it to pieces, you found that it was a fairly good face, showing intellect in the forehead, and much character in the mouth. The eyes too, though not to be called bright, had always something to say for themselves, looking as though they had a real meaning. But the outline of the face was almost insignificant, being too thin; and he (character) wore no beard to give it character. But, indeed, Mr. Palliser was a man who had never thought of assisting his (Palliser) position in the world by his (Palliser) outward appearance. Not to be looked at, but to be read about in the newspapers, was his (Palliser) ambition. Men said that he (Palliser) was to be Chancellor of the Exchequer, and no one thought of suggesting that the insignificance of his (Palliser) face would stand in his (Palliser) way.

``Are the people all out?'' (wife)
his (Palliser) wife asked him (Palliser).

``The men have not come in from shooting;--at least I think not;--and some of the ladies are driving, I suppose. But I haven't seen anybody since you went.'' (unknown)

``Of course you haven't. He (husband) never has time, Alice, to see any one. But we'll go up-stairs, dear. I told them to let us have tea in my dressing-room, as I thought you'd like that better than going into the drawing-room before you had taken off your things. You must be famished, I know. Then you can come down, or if you want to avoid two dressings you can sit over the fire up-stairs till dinner-time.'' (she)
So saying she (wife) skipped up-stairs and Alice followed her (Alice).
``Here's my dressing-room, and here's your room all but opposite. You look out into the park. It's pretty, isn't it? But come into my dressing-room, and see the ruins out of the window.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice followed Lady Glencora across the passage into what she (Alice) called her (Alice) dressing-room, and there found herself surrounded by an infinitude of feminine luxuries. The prettiest of tables were there;--the easiest of chairs;--the most costly of cabinets;--the quaintest of old china ornaments. It was bright with the gayest colours,--made pleasant to the eye with the binding of many books, having nymphs painted on the ceiling and little Cupids on the doors.

``Isn't it pretty?'' (she)
she (Alice) said, turning quickly on Alice.
``I call it my dressing-room because in that way I can keep people out of it, but I have my brushes and soap in a little closet there, and my clothes,--my clothes are everywhere I suppose, only there are none of them here. Isn't it pretty?'' (unknown)

``Very pretty.'' (unknown)

``The Duke did it all. He (it) understands such things thoroughly. Now to Mr. Palliser a dressing-room is a dressing-room, and a bedroom a bedroom. He (Palliser) cares for nothing being pretty; not even his (Palliser) wife, or he (Palliser) wouldn't have married me.'' (unknown)

``You wouldn't say that if you meant it.'' (unknown)

``Well, I don't know. Sometimes when I look at myself, when I simply am myself, with no making up or grimacing, you know, I think I'm the ugliest young woman the sun ever shone on. And in ten years' time I shall be the ugliest old woman. Only think,--my hair is beginning to get grey, and I'm not twenty-one yet. Look at it;'' (she)
and she (Alice) lifted up the wavy locks just above her (Alice) ear.
``But there's one comfort; he (I) doesn't care about beauty. How old are you?'' (unknown)

``Over five-and-twenty,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Nonsense;--then I oughtn't to have asked you. I am so sorry.'' (unknown)

``That's nonsense at any rate. Why should you think I should be ashamed of my age?'' (unknown)

``I don't know why, only somehow, people are; and I didn't think you were so old. Five-and-twenty seems so old to me. It would be nothing if you were married; only, you see, you won't get married.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps I may yet; some day.'' (unknown)

``Of course you will. You'll have to give way. You'll find that they'll get the better of you. Your father will storm at you, and Lady Macleod will preach at you, and Lady Midlothian will jump upon you.'' (unknown)

``I'm not a bit afraid of Lady Midlothian.'' (unknown)

``I know what it is, my dear, to be jumped upon. We talked with such horror of the French people giving their daughters in marriage, just as they might sell a house or a field, but we do exactly the same thing ourselves. When they all come upon you in earnest how are you to stand against them? How can any girl do it?'' (unknown)

``I think I shall be able.'' (unknown)

``To be sure you're older,--and you are not so heavily weighted. But never mind; I didn't mean to talk about that;--not yet at any rate. Well, now, my dear, I must go down. The Duchess of St. Bungay is here, and Mr. Palliser will be angry if I don't do pretty to her (Duchess). The Duke is to be the new President of the Council, or rather, I believe he (President) is President now. I try to remember it all, but it is so hard when one doesn't really care two pence how it goes. Not but what I'm very anxious that Mr. Palliser should be Chancellor of the Exchequer. And now, will you remain here, or will you come down with me, or will you go to your own room, and I'll call for you when I go down to dinner? We dine at eight.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice decided that she (Alice) would stay in her (Alice) own room till dinner time, and was taken there by Lady Glencora. She (Glencora) found her (Glencora) maid unpacking her (Glencora) clothes, and for a while employed herself in assisting at the work; but that was soon done, and then she (Glencora) was left alone.

``I shall feel so strange, ma'am, among all those people down-stairs,'' (the girl)
said the girl.
``They all seem to look at me as though they didn't know who I was.'' (unknown)

``You'll get over that soon, Jane.'' (unknown)

``I suppose I shall; but you see, they're all like knowing each other, miss.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice, when she (Alice) sat down alone, felt herself to be very much in the same condition as her (Alice) maid. What would the Duchess of St. Bungay or Mr. Jeffrey Palliser,--who himself might live to be a duke if things went well for him (Palliser),--care for her (Alice)? As to Mr. Palliser, the master of the house, it was already evident to her (Alice) that he (Palliser) would not put himself out of his (Palliser) way for her (Alice). Had she (Alice) not done wrong to come there? If it were possible for her (Alice) to fly away, back to the dullness of Queen Anne Street, or even to the preachings of Lady Macleod, would she (Macleod) not do so immediately? What business had she (Macleod),--she (Macleod) asked herself,--to come to such a house as that? Lady Glencora was very kind to her (Glencora), but frightened her (Glencora) even by her (Glencora) kindness. Moreover, she (Glencora) was aware that Lady Glencora could not devote herself especially to any such guest as she (Glencora) was. Lady Glencora must of course look after her (Glencora) duchesses, and do pretty, as she (Glencora) called it, to her (Glencora) husband's important political alliances.

And then she (Glencora) began to think about Lady Glencora herself. What a strange, weird nature she (Glencora) was,--with her (Glencora) round blue eyes and wavy hair, looking sometimes like a child and sometimes almost like an old woman! And how she (woman) talked! What things she (woman) said, and what terrible forebodings she (woman) uttered of stranger things that she (woman) meant to say! Why had she (woman) at their first meeting made that allusion to the mode of her (woman) own betrothal,--and then, checking herself for speaking of it so soon, almost declare that she (woman) meant to speak more of it hereafter?

``She (Jane) should never mention it to any one,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice to herself.
``If her (Jane) lot in life has not satisfied her (Jane), there is so much the more reason why she (Jane) should not mention it.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Then Alice protested to herself that no father, no aunt, no Lady Midlothian should persuade her (Lady) into a marriage of which she (Lady) feared the consequences. But Lady Glencora had made for herself excuses which were not altogether untrue. She (Glencora) had been very young, and had been terribly weighted with her (Glencora) wealth.

And it seemed to Alice that her (Alice) cousin had told her (Alice) everything in that hour and a half that they had been together. She (Alice) had given a whole history of her (Alice) husband and of herself. She (Alice) had said how indifferent he (husband) was to her (Alice) pleasures, and how vainly she (Alice) strove to interest herself in his (husband) pursuits. And then, as yet, she (Alice) was childless and without prospect of a child, when, as she (Alice) herself had said,--

``so much depended on it.'' (she)
It was very strange to Alice that all this should have been already told to her (Alice). And why should Lady Glencora think of Alice when she (Glencora) walked out among the priory ruins by moonlight?

The two hours seemed to her (Glencora) very long,--as though she (Glencora) were passing her (Glencora) time in absolute seclusion at Matching. Of course she (Glencora) did not dare to go down-stairs. But at last her (Glencora) maid came to dress her (Glencora).

``How do you get on below, Jane?'' (mistress)
her (Glencora) mistress asked her (Glencora).

``Why, miss, they are uncommon civil, and I don't think after all it will be so bad. We had our teas very comfortable in the housekeeper's room. There are five or six of us altogether, all ladies'-maids, miss; and there's nothing on earth to do all the day long, only sit and do a little needlework over the fire.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

A few minutes before eight Lady Glencora knocked at Alice's door, and took her (Glencora) arm to lead her (Glencora) to the drawing-room. Alice saw that she (Alice) was magnificently dressed, with an enormous expanse of robe, and that her (Alice) locks had been so managed that no one could suspect the presence of a grey hair. Indeed, with all her (Alice) magnificence, she (Alice) looked almost a child.

``Let me see,'' (she)
she (Alice) said, as they went down-stairs together.
``I'll tell Jeffrey to take you in to dinner. He (Jeffrey)'s about the easiest young man we have here. He (Jeffrey) rather turns up his (Jeffrey) nose at everything, but that doesn't make him (Jeffrey) the less agreeable; does it, dear?--unless he (Jeffrey) turns up his (Jeffrey) nose at you, you know.'' (unknown)

``But perhaps he (Jeffrey) will.'' (unknown)

``No; he (Jeffrey) won't do that. That would be uncourteous,--and he (Jeffrey)'s the most courteous man in the world. There's nobody here, you see,'' (she)
she (Alice) said as they entered the room,
``and I didn't suppose there would be. It's always proper to be first in one's own house. I do so try to be proper,--and it is such trouble. Talking of people earning their bread, Alice;--I'm sure I earn mine. Oh dear!--what fun it would be to be sitting somewhere in Asia, eating a chicken with one's fingers, and lighting a big fire outside one's tent to keep off the lions and tigers. Fancy your being on one side of the fire and the lions and tigers on the other, grinning at you through the flames!'' (she)
Then Lady Glencora strove to look like a lion, and grinned at herself in the glass.

``That sort of grin wouldn't frighten me,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``I dare say not. I have been reading about it in that woman's travels. Oh, here they are, and I mustn't make any more faces. Duchess, do come to the fire. I hope you've got warm again. This is my cousin, Miss Vavasor.'' (The Duchess)

The Duchess made a stiff little bow of condescension, and then declared that she (Alice) was charmingly warm.

``I don't know how you manage in your house, but the staircases are so comfortable. Now at Longroyston we've taken all the trouble in the world,--put down hot-water pipes all over the house, and everything else that could be thought of, and yet, you can't move about the place without meeting with draughts at every corner of the passages.'' (The Duchess)
The Duchess spoke with an enormous emphasis on every other word, sometimes putting so great a stress on some special syllable, as almost to bring her (Duchess) voice to a whistle. This she (Duchess) had done with the word
``pipes'' (she)
to a great degree,--so that Alice never afterwards forgot the hot-water pipes of Longroyston.
``I was telling Lady Glencora, Miss Palliser, that I never knew a house so warm as this,--or, I'm sorry to say,'' (unknown)
--and here the emphasis was very strong on the word sorry,--
``so cold as Longroyston.'' (a audience)
And the tone in which Longroyston was uttered would almost have drawn tears from a critical audience in the pit of a playhouse. The Duchess was a woman of about forty, very handsome, but with no meaning in her (Duchess) beauty, carrying a good fixed colour in her (Duchess) face, which did not look like paint, but which probably had received some little assistance from art. She (Duchess) was a well-built, sizeable woman, with good proportions and fine health,--but a fool. She (Duchess) had addressed herself to one Miss Palliser; but two Miss Pallisers, cousins of Plantagenet Palliser, had entered the room at the same time, of whom I may say, whatever other traits of character they may have possessed, that at any rate they were not fools.

``It's always easy to warm a small house like this,'' (Miss Palliser)
said Miss Palliser, whose Christian names, unfortunately for her (Palliser), were Iphigenia Theodata, and who by her (Palliser) cousin and sister was called Iphy--
``and I suppose equally difficult to warm a large one such as Longroyston.'' (sister)
The other Miss Palliser had been christened Euphemia.

``We've got no pipes, Duchess, at any rate,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora; and Alice, as she (Glencora) sat listening, thought she (Glencora) discerned in Lady Glencora's pronunciation of the word pipes an almost hidden imitation of the Duchess's whistle. It must have been so, for at the moment Lady Glencora's eye met Alice's for an instant, and was then withdrawn, so that Alice was compelled to think that her (Alice) friend and cousin was not always quite successful in those struggles she (Alice) made to be proper.

Then the gentlemen came in one after another, and other ladies, till about thirty people were assembled. Mr. Palliser came up and spoke another word to Alice in a kind voice,--meant to express some sense of connection if not cousinship.

``My wife has been thinking so much of your coming. I hope we shall be able to amuse you.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice, who had already begun to feel desolate, was grateful, and made up her (Alice) mind that she (Alice) would try to like Mr. Palliser.

Jeffrey Palliser was almost the last in the room, but directly he (Palliser) entered Lady Glencora got up from her (Glencora) seat, and met him (Palliser) as he (Palliser) was coming into the crowd.

``You must take my cousin, Alice Vavasor, in to dinner,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said,
``and;--will you oblige me to-day?'' (she)

``Yes;--as you ask me like that.'' (unknown)

``Then try to make her (Vavasor) comfortable.'' (she)
After that she (Glencora) introduced them, and Jeffrey Palliser stood opposite to Alice, talking to her (Alice), till dinner was announced.

CHAPTER XXIII.

Dinner at Matching Priory.

Alice found herself seated near to Lady Glencora's end of the table, and, in spite of her (Alice) resolution to like Mr. Palliser, she (Alice) was not sorry that such an arrangement had been made. Mr. Palliser had taken the Duchess out to dinner, and Alice wished to be as far removed as possible from her (Alice) Grace. She (Alice) found herself seated between her (Alice) bespoken friend Jeffrey Palliser and the Duke, and as soon as she (Alice) was seated Lady Glencora introduced her (Glencora) to her (Glencora) second neighbour.

``My cousin, Duke,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora said,
``and a terrible Radical.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``Oh, indeed; I'm glad of that. We're sadly in want of a few leading Radicals, and perhaps I may be able to gain one now.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice thought of her (Alice) cousin George, and wished that he (George), instead of herself, was sitting next to the Duke of St. Bungay.

``But I'm afraid I never shall be a leading Radical,'' (she)
she (Alice) said.

``You shall lead me at any rate, if you will,'' (he)
said he (George).

``As the little dogs lead the blind men,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``No, Lady Glencora, not so. But as the pretty women lead the men who have eyes in their head. There is nothing I want so much, Miss Vavasor, as to become a Radical;--if I only knew how.'' (unknown)

``I think it's very easy to know how,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Do you? I don't. I've voted for every liberal measure that has come seriously before Parliament since I had a seat in either House, and I've not been able to get beyond Whiggery yet.'' (unknown)

``Have you voted for the ballot?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
asked Alice, almost trembling at her (Alice) own audacity as she (Alice) put the question.

``Well; no, I've not. And I suppose that is the crux. But the ballot has never been seriously brought before any House in which I have sat. I hate it with so keen a private hatred, that I doubt whether I could vote for it.'' (unknown)

``But the Radicals love it,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Palliser,'' (Duke)
said the Duke, speaking loudly from his (George) end of the table,
``I'm told you can never be entitled to call yourself a Radical till you've voted for the ballot.'' (Duke)

``I don't want to be called a Radical,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser,--
``or to be called anything at all.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

``Except Chancellor of the Exchequer,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora in a low voice.

``And that's about the finest ambition by which a man can be moved,'' (the Duke)
said the Duke.
``The man who can manage the purse-strings of this country can manage anything.'' (Duke)
Then that conversation dropped and the Duke ate his (Palliser) dinner.

``I was especially commissioned to amuse you,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Jeffrey Palliser to Alice.
``But when I undertook the task I had no conception that you would be calling Cabinet Ministers over the coals about their politics.'' (unknown)

``I did nothing of the kind, surely, Mr. Palliser. I suppose all Radicals do vote for the ballot, and that's why I said it.'' (unknown)

``Your definition was perfectly just, I dare say, only--'' (unknown)

``Only what?'' (unknown)

``Lady Glencora need not have been so anxious to provide specially for your amusement. Not but what I'm very much obliged to her (Glencora),--of course. But Miss Vavasor, unfortunately I'm not a politician. I haven't a chance of a seat in the House, and so I despise politics.'' (unknown)

``Women are not allowed to be politicians in this country.'' (unknown)

``Thank God, they can't do much in that way;--not directly, I mean. Only think where we should be if we had a feminine House of Commons, with feminine debates, carried on, of course, with feminine courtesy. My cousins Iphy and Phemy there would of course be members. You don't know them yet?'' (unknown)

``No; not yet. Are they politicians?'' (unknown)

``Not especially. They have their tendencies, which are decidedly liberal. There has never been a Tory Palliser known, you know. But they are too clever to give themselves up to anything in which they can do nothing. Being women they live a depressed life, devoting themselves to literature, fine arts, social economy, and the abstract sciences. They write wonderful letters; but I believe their correspondence lists are quite full, so that you have no chance at present of getting on either of them.'' (unknown)

``I haven't the slightest pretension to ask for such an honour.'' (unknown)

``Oh! if you mean because you don't know them, that has nothing to do with it.'' (unknown)

``But I have no claim either private or public.'' (unknown)

``That has nothing to do with it either. They don't at all seek people of note as their correspondents. Free communication with all the world is their motto, and Rowland Hill is the god they worship. Only they have been forced to guard themselves against too great an accession of paper and ink. Are you fond of writing letters, Miss Vavasor?'' (unknown)

``Yes, to my friends; but I like getting them better.'' (unknown)

``I shrewdly suspect they don't read half what they get. Is it possible any one should go through two sheets of paper filled by our friend the Duchess there? No; their delight is in writing. They sit each at her (Duchess) desk after breakfast, and go on till lunch. There is a little rivalry between them, not expressed to each other, but visible to their friends. Iphy certainly does get off the greater number, and I'm told crosses quite as often as Phemy, but then she (Duchess) has the advantage of a bolder and larger hand.'' (unknown)

``Do they write to you?'' (unknown)

``Oh, dear no. I don't think they ever write to any relative. They don't discuss family affairs and such topics as that. Architecture goes a long way with them, and whether women ought to be clerks in public offices. Iphy has certain American correspondents that take up much of her (Duchess) time, but she (Duchess) acknowledges she (Duchess) does not read their letters.'' (unknown)

``Then I certainly shall not write to her (Duchess).'' (unknown)

``But you are not American, I hope. I do hate the Americans. It's the only strong political feeling I have. I went there once, and found I couldn't live with them on any terms.'' (unknown)

``But they please themselves. I don't see they are to be hated because they don't live after our fashion.'' (unknown)

``Oh; it's jealousy of course. I know that. I didn't come across a cab-driver who wasn't a much better educated man than I am. And as for their women, they know everything. But I hated them, and I intend to hate them. You haven't been there?'' (unknown)

``Oh no.'' (unknown)

``Then I will make bold to say that any English lady who spent a month with them and didn't hate them would have very singular tastes. I begin to think they'll eat each other up, and then there'll come an entirely new set of people of a different sort. I always regarded the States as a Sodom and Gomorrah, prospering in wickedness, on which fire and brimstone were sure to fall sooner or later.'' (unknown)

``I think that's wicked.'' (unknown)

``I am wicked, as Topsy used to say. Do you hunt?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``Do you shoot?'' (unknown)

``Shoot! What; with a gun?'' (unknown)

``Yes. I was staying in a house last week with a lady who shot a good deal.'' (unknown)

``No; I don't shoot.'' (unknown)

``Do you ride?'' (unknown)

``No; I wish I did. I have never ridden because I've no one to ride with me.'' (unknown)

``Do you drive?'' (unknown)

``No; I don't drive either.'' (unknown)

``Then what do you do?'' (unknown)

``I sit at home, and--'' (unknown)

``Mend your stockings?'' (unknown)

``No; I don't do that, because it's disagreeable; but I do work a good deal. Sometimes I have amused myself by reading.'' (unknown)

``Ah; they never do that here. I have heard that there is a library, but the clue to it has been lost, and nobody now knows the way. I don't believe in libraries. Nobody ever goes into a library to read, any more than you would into a larder to eat. But there is this difference;--the food you consume does come out of the larders, but the books you read never come out of the libraries.'' (unknown)

``Except Mudie's,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Ah, yes; he (you) is the great librarian. And you mean to read all the time you are here, Miss Vavasor?'' (unknown)

``I mean to walk about the priory ruins sometimes.'' (unknown)

``Then you must go by moonlight, and I'll go with you. Only isn't it rather late in the year for that?'' (unknown)

``I should think it is,--for you, Mr. Palliser.'' (the Duke)

Then the Duke spoke to her (Alice) again, and she (Alice) found that she (Alice) got on very well during dinner. But she (Alice) could not but feel angry with herself in that she (Alice) had any fear on the subject;--and yet she (Alice) could not divest herself of that fear. She (Alice) acknowledged to herself that she (Alice) was conscious of a certain inferiority to Lady Glencora and to Mr. Jeffrey Palliser, which almost made her (Glencora) unhappy. As regarded the Duke on the other side of her (Glencora), she (Glencora) had no such feeling. He (Palliser) was old enough to be her (Glencora) father, and was a Cabinet Minister; therefore he (Minister) was entitled to her (Glencora) reverence. But how was it that she (Glencora) could not help accepting the other people round her (Glencora) as being indeed superior to herself? Was she (Glencora) really learning to believe that she (Glencora) could grow upwards by their sunlight?

``Jeffrey is a pleasant fellow, is he (Jeffrey) not?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora to her (Glencora) as they passed back through the billiard-room to the drawing-room.

``Very pleasant;--a little sarcastic, perhaps.'' (unknown)

``I should think you would soon find yourself able to get the better of that if he (Jeffrey) tries it upon you,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora; and then the ladies were all in the drawing-room together.

``It is quite deliciously warm, coming from one room to another,'' (the Duchess)
said the Duchess, putting her (Duchess) emphasis on the
``one'' (the Duchess)
and the
``other.'' (the Duchess)

``Then we had better keep continually moving,'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)
said a certain Mrs. Conway Sparkes, a literary lady, who had been very handsome, who was still very clever, who was not perhaps very good-natured, and of whom the Duchess of St. Bungay was rather afraid.

``I hope we may be warm here too,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``But not deliciously warm,'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)
said Mrs. Conway Sparkes.

``It makes me tremble in every limb when Mrs. Sparkes attacks her (Sparkes),'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora said to Alice in Alice's own room that night,
``for I know she (Sparkes)'ll tell the Duke; and he (Jeffrey)'ll tell that tall man with red hair whom you see standing about, and the tall man with red hair will tell Mr. Palliser, and then I shall catch it.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``And who is the tall man with red hair?'' (unknown)

``He (man)'s a political link between the Duke and Mr. Palliser. His (Palliser) name is Bott, and he (Palliser)'s a Member of Parliament.'' (unknown)

``But why should he (Palliser) interfere?'' (unknown)

``I suppose it's his (Palliser) business. I don't quite understand all the ins and outs of it. I believe he (Palliser)'s to be one of Mr. Palliser's private secretaries if he (Palliser) becomes Chancellor of the Exchequer. Perhaps he (Palliser) doesn't tell;--only I think he (Palliser) does all the same. He (Palliser) always calls me Lady Glen-cowrer. He (Palliser) comes out of Lancashire, and made calico as long as he (Palliser) could get any cotton.'' (unknown)
But this happened in the bedroom, and we must go back for a while to the drawing-room.

The Duchess had made no answer to Mrs. Sparkes, and so nothing further was said about the warmth. Nor, indeed, was there any conversation that was comfortably general. The number of ladies in the room was too great for that, and ladies do not divide themselves nicely into small parties, as men and women do when they are mixed. Lady Glencora behaved pretty by telling the Duchess all about her (Glencora) pet pheasants; Mrs. Conway Sparkes told ill-natured tales of some one to Miss Euphemia Palliser; one of the Duchess's daughters walked off to a distant piano with an admiring friend and touched a few notes; while Iphigenia Palliser boldly took up a book, and placed herself at a table. Alice, who was sitting opposite to Lady Glencora, began to speculate whether she (Glencora) might do the same; but her (Glencora) courage failed her (Glencora), and she (Glencora) sat on, telling herself that she (Glencora) was out of her (Glencora) element.

``Alice Vavasor,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora after a while, suddenly, and in a somewhat loud voice,
``can you play billiards?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``No,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, rather startled.

``Then you shall learn to-night, and if nobody else will teach you, you shall be my pupil.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Whereupon Lady Glencora rang the bell and ordered that the billiard-table might be got ready.
``You'll play, Duchess, of course,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``It is so nice and warm, that I think I will,'' (the Duchess)
said the Duchess; but as she (Duchess) spoke she (Duchess) looked suspiciously to that part of the room where Mrs. Conway Sparkes was sitting.

``Let us all play,'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)
said Mrs. Conway Sparkes,
``and then it will be nicer,--and perhaps warmer, too.'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)

The gentlemen joined them just as they were settling themselves round the table, and as many of them stayed there, the billiard-room became full. Alice had first a cue put into her (Alice) hand, and making nothing of that was permitted to play with a mace. The duty of instructing her (Alice) devolved on Jeffrey Palliser, and the next hour passed pleasantly;--not so pleasantly, she (Alice) thought afterwards, as did some of those hours in Switzerland when her (Alice) cousins were with her (Alice). After all, she (Alice) could get more out of her (Alice) life with such associates as them, than she (Alice) could with any of these people at Matching. She (Alice) felt quite sure of that;--though Jeffrey Palliser did take great trouble to teach her (Alice) the game, and once or twice made her (Alice) laugh heartily by quizzing the Duchess's attitude as she (Duchess) stood up to make her (Duchess) stroke.

``I wish I could play billiards,'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)
said Mrs. Sparkes, on one of these occasions;
``I do indeed.'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)

``I thought you said you were coming to play,'' (the Duchess)
said the Duchess, almost majestically, and with a tone of triumph evidently produced by her (Duchess) own successes.

``Only to see your Grace,'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)
said Mrs. Sparkes.

``I don't know that there is anything more to see in me than in anybody else,'' (the Duchess)
said the Duchess.
``Mr. Palliser, that was a cannon. Will you mark that for our side?'' (unknown)

-LSB-Illustration:

``Mr. Palliser, that was a cannon.'' (unknown)
-RSB-

``Oh no, Duchess, you hit the same ball twice.'' (unknown)

``Very well;--then I suppose Miss Vavasor plays now. That was a miss. Will you mark that, if you please?'' (she)
This latter demand was made with great stress, as though she (Duchess) had been defrauded in the matter of the cannon, and was obeyed. Before long, the Duchess, with her (Duchess) partner, Lady Glencora, won the game,--which fact, however, was, I think, owing rather to Alice's ignorance than to her (Alice) Grace's skill. The Duchess, however, was very triumphant, and made her (Duchess) way back into the drawing-room with a step which seemed to declare loudly that she (Duchess) had trumped Mrs. Sparkes at last.

Not long after this the ladies went up-stairs on their way to bed. Many of them, perhaps, did not go to their pillows at once, as it was as yet not eleven o'clock, and it was past ten when they all came down to breakfast. At any rate, Alice, who had been up at seven, did not go to bed then, nor for the next two hours.

``I'll come into your room just for one minute,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora said as she (Glencora) passed on from the door to her (Glencora) own room; and in about five minutes she (Glencora) was back with her (Glencora) cousin.
``Would you mind going into my room--it's just there, and sitting with Ellen for a minute?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
This Lady Glencora said in the sweetest possible tone to the girl who was waiting on Alice; and then, when they were alone together, she (Alice) got into a little chair by the fireside and prepared herself for conversation.

``I must keep you up for a quarter of an hour while I tell you something. But first of all, how do you like the people? Will you be able to be comfortable with them?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice of course said that she (Alice) thought she (Alice) would; and then there came that little discussion in which the duties of Mr. Bott, the man with the red hair, were described.

``But I've got something to tell you,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, when they had already been there some twenty minutes.
``Sit down opposite to me, and look at the fire while I look at you.'' (unknown)

``Is it anything terrible?'' (unknown)

``It's nothing wrong.'' (unknown)

``Oh, Lady Glencora, if it's--'' (unknown)

``I won't have you call me Lady Glencora. Don't I call you Alice? Why are you so unkind to me? I have not come to you now asking you to do for me anything that you ought not to do.'' (unknown)

``But you are going to tell me something.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice felt sure that the thing to be told would have some reference to Mr. Fitzgerald, and she (Alice) did not wish to hear Mr. Fitzgerald's name from her (Alice) cousin's lips.

``Tell you something;--of course I am. I'm going to tell you that,--that in writing to you the other day I wrote a fib. But it wasn't that I wished to deceive you;--only I couldn't say it all in a letter.'' (unknown)

``Say all what?'' (unknown)

``You know I confessed that I had been very bad in not coming to you in London last year.'' (unknown)

``I never thought of it for a moment.'' (unknown)

``You did not care whether I came or not: was that it? But never mind. Why should you have cared? But I cared. I told you in my letter that I didn't come because I had so many things on hand. Of course that was a fib.'' (unknown)

``Everybody makes excuses of that kind,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``But they don't make them to the very people of all others whom they want to know and love. I was longing to come to you every day. But I feared I could not come without speaking of him (my);--and I had determined never to speak of him (my) again.'' (she)
This she (Alice) said in that peculiar low voice which she (Alice) assumed at times.

``Then why do it now, Lady Glencora?'' (unknown)

``I won't be called Lady Glencora. Call me Cora. I had a sister once, older than I, and she (Glencora) used to call me Cora. If she (Glencora) had lived--. But never mind that now. She (Glencora) didn't live. I'll tell you why I do it now. Because I cannot help it. Besides, I've met him (Cora). I've been in the same room with him (Cora), and have spoken to him (Cora). What's the good of any such resolution now?'' (unknown)

``And you have met him (Cora)?'' (unknown)

``Yes; he (Cora)--Mr. Palliser--knew all about it. When he (Palliser) talked of taking me to the house, I whispered to him (Palliser) that I thought Burgo would be there.'' (unknown)

``Do not call him (Burgo) by his (Burgo) Christian name,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, almost with a shudder.
