``Why not?--why not his (Burgo) Christian name? I did when I told my husband. Or perhaps I said Burgo Fitzgerald.'' (unknown)

``Well.'' (unknown)

``And he (Fitzgerald) bade me go. He (Fitzgerald) said it didn't signify, and that I had better learn to bear it. Bear it, indeed! If I am to meet him (Fitzgerald), and speak to him (Fitzgerald), and look at him (Fitzgerald), surely I may mention his (Fitzgerald) name.'' (she)
And then she (Alice) paused for an answer.
``May I not?'' (unknown)

``What am I to say?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
exclaimed Alice.

``Anything you please, that's not a falsehood. But I've got you here because I don't think you will tell a falsehood. Oh, Alice, I do so want to go right, and it is so hard!'' (creature)

Hard, indeed, poor creature, for one so weighted as she (Alice) had been, and sent out into the world with so small advantages of previous training or of present friendship! Alice began to feel now that she (Alice) had been enticed to Matching Priory because her (Alice) cousin wanted a friend, and of course she (Alice) could not refuse to give the friendship that was asked from her (Alice). She (Alice) got up from her (Alice) chair, and kneeling down at the other's feet put up her (Alice) face and kissed her (Alice).

``I knew you would be good to me,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``I knew you would. And you may say whatever you like. But I could not bear that you should not know the real reason why I neither came to you nor sent for you after we went to London. You'll come to me now; won't you, dear?'' (unknown)

``Yes;--and you'll come to me,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, making in her (Alice) mind a sort of bargain that she (Alice) was not to be received into Mr. Palliser's house after the fashion in which Lady Midlothian had proposed to receive her (Lady). But it struck her (Lady) at once that this was unworthy of her (Lady), and ungenerous.
``But I'll come to you,'' (she)
she (Lady) added,
``whether you come to me or not.'' (she)

``I will go to you,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora,
``of course,--why shouldn't I? But you know what I mean. We shall have dinners and parties and lots of people.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``And we shall have none,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, smiling.

``And therefore there is so much more excuse for your coming to me;--or rather I mean so much more reason, for I don't want excuses. Well, dear, I'm so glad I've told you. I was afraid to see you in London. I should hardly have known how to look at you then. But I've got over that now.'' (she)
Then she (Alice) smiled and returned the kiss which Alice had given her (Alice). It was singular to see her (Alice) standing on the bedroom rug with all her (Alice) magnificence of dress, but with her (Alice) hair pushed back behind her (Alice) ears, and her (Alice) eyes red with tears,--as though the burden of the magnificence remained to her (Alice) after its purpose was over.

``I declare it's ever so much past twelve. Good night, now, dear. I wonder whether he (I)'s come up. But I should have heard his (I) step if he (I) had. He (I) never treads lightly. He (I) seldom gives over work till after one, and sometimes goes on till three. It's the only thing he (I) likes, I believe. God bless you! good night. I've such a deal more to say to you; and Alice, you must tell me something about yourself, too; won't you, dear?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Then without waiting for an answer Lady Glencora went, leaving Alice in a maze of bewilderment. She (Glencora) could hardly believe that all she (Glencora) had heard, and all she (Glencora) had done, had happened since she (Glencora) left Queen Anne Street that morning.

CHAPTER XXIV.

Three Politicians.

Mr. Palliser was one of those politicians in possessing whom England has perhaps more reason to be proud than of any other of her (Glencora) resources, and who, as a body, give to her (Glencora) that exquisite combination of conservatism and progress which is her (Glencora) present strength and best security for the future. He (Palliser) could afford to learn to be a statesman, and had the industry wanted for such training. He (Palliser) was born in the purple, noble himself, and heir to the highest rank as well as one of the greatest fortunes of the country, already very rich, surrounded by all the temptations of luxury and pleasure; and yet he (Palliser) devoted himself to work with the grinding energy of a young penniless barrister labouring for a penniless wife, and did so without any motive more selfish than that of being counted in the roll of the public servants of England. He (barrister) was not a brilliant man, and understood well that such was the case. He (barrister) was now listened to in the House, as the phrase goes; but he (barrister) was listened to as a laborious man, who was in earnest in what he (barrister) did, who got up his (barrister) facts with accuracy, and who, dull though he (barrister) be, was worthy of confidence. And he (barrister) was very dull. He (barrister) rather prided himself on being dull, and on conquering in spite of his (barrister) dullness. He (barrister) never allowed himself a joke in his (barrister) speeches, nor attempted even the smallest flourish of rhetoric. He (barrister) was very careful in his (barrister) language, labouring night and day to learn to express himself with accuracy, with no needless repetition of words, perspicuously with regard to the special object he (barrister) might have in view. He (barrister) had taught himself to believe that oratory, as oratory, was a sin against that honesty in politics by which he (barrister) strove to guide himself. He (barrister) desired to use words for the purpose of teaching things which he (barrister) knew and which others did not know; and he (barrister) desired also to be honoured for his (barrister) knowledge. But he (barrister) had no desire to be honoured for the language in which his (barrister) knowledge was conveyed. He (barrister) was an upright, thin, laborious man; who by his (barrister) parts alone could have served no political party materially, but whose parts were sufficient to make his (barrister) education, integrity, and industry useful in the highest degree. It is the trust which such men inspire which makes them so serviceable;--trust not only in their labour,--for any man rising from the mass of the people may be equally laborious; nor yet simply in their honesty and patriotism. The confidence is given to their labour, honesty, and patriotism joined to such a personal stake in the country as gives them a weight and ballast which no politician in England can possess without it.

If he (politician) was dull as a statesman he (politician) was more dull in private life, and it may be imagined that such a woman as his (politician) wife would find some difficulty in making his (politician) society the source of her (woman) happiness. Their marriage, in a point of view regarding business, had been a complete success,--and a success, too, when on the one side, that of Lady Glencora, there had been terrible dangers of shipwreck, and when on his (politician) side also there had been some little fears of a mishap. As regards her (Glencora) it has been told how near she (Glencora) went to throwing herself, with all her (Glencora) vast wealth, into the arms of a young man, whom no father, no guardian could have regarded as a well-chosen husband for any girl;--one who as yet had shown no good qualities, who had been a spendthrift, unprincipled, and debauched. Alas, she (girl) had loved him (husband)! It is possible that her (girl) love and her (girl) wealth might have turned him (husband) from evil to good. But who would have ventured to risk her (girl),--I will not say her (girl) and her (girl) vast inheritances,--on such a chance? That evil, however, had been prevented, and those about her (girl) had managed to marry her (girl) to a young man, very steady by nature, with worldly prospects as brilliant as her (girl) own, and with a station than which the world offers nothing higher. His (man) little threatened mischance,--a passing fancy for a married lady who was too wise to receive vows which were proffered not in the most ardent manner,--had, from special reasons, given some little alarm to his (man) uncle, which had just sufficed at the time to make so very judicious a marriage doubly pleasant to that noble duke, So that all things and all people had conspired to shower substantial comforts on the heads of this couple, when they were joined together, and men and women had not yet ceased to declare how happy were both in the accumulated gifts of fortune.

And as regards Mr. Palliser, I think that his (Palliser) married life, and the wife, whom he (Palliser) certainly had not chosen, but who had dropped upon him (Palliser), suited him (Palliser) admirably. He (Palliser) wanted great wealth for that position at which he (Palliser) aimed. He (Palliser) had been rich before his (Palliser) marriage with his (Palliser) own wealth,--so rich that he (Palliser) could throw thousands away if he (Palliser) wished it; but for him (Palliser) and his (Palliser) career was needed that colossal wealth which would make men talk about it,--which would necessitate an expansive expenditure, reaching far and wide, doing nothing, or less than nothing, for his (Palliser) own personal comfort, but giving to him (Palliser) at once that rock-like solidity which is so necessary to our great aristocratic politicians. And his (Palliser) wife was, as far as he (Palliser) knew, all that he (Palliser) desired. He (Palliser) had not dabbled much in the fountains of Venus, though he (Palliser) had forgotten himself once, and sinned in coveting another man's wife. But his (Palliser) sin then had hardly polluted his (Palliser) natural character, and his (Palliser) desire had been of a kind which was almost more gratified in its disappointment than it would have been in its fruition. On the morning after the lady had frowned on him (Palliser) he (Palliser) had told himself that he (Palliser) was very well out of that trouble. He (Palliser) knew that it would never be for him (Palliser) to hang up on the walls of a temple a well-worn lute as a votive offering when leaving the pursuits of love. _Idoneus puellis_ he (Palliser) never could have been. So he (Palliser) married Lady Glencora and was satisfied. The story of Burgo Fitzgerald was told to him (Fitzgerald), and he (Fitzgerald) supposed that most girls had some such story to tell. He (Fitzgerald) thought little about it, and by no means understood her (Glencora) when she (Glencora) said to him (Fitzgerald), with all the impressiveness which she (Glencora) could throw into the words,

``You must know that I have really loved him (God).'' (she)
``You must love me now,'' (he)
he (Fitzgerald) had replied with a smile; and then as regarded his (Fitzgerald) mind, the thing was over. And since his (Fitzgerald) marriage he (Fitzgerald) had thought that things matrimonial had gone well with him (Fitzgerald), and with her (Glencora) too. He (Fitzgerald) gave her (Glencora) almost unlimited power of enjoying her (Glencora) money, and interfered but little in her (Glencora) way of life. Sometimes he (Fitzgerald) would say a word of caution to her (Glencora) with reference to those childish ways which hardly became the dull dignity of his (Fitzgerald) position; and his (Fitzgerald) words then would have in them something of unintentional severity,--whether instigated or not by the red-haired Radical Member of Parliament, I will not pretend to say;--but on the whole he (Member) was contented and loved his (Member) wife, as he (Member) thought, very heartily, and at least better than he (Member) loved any one else. One cause of unhappiness, or rather one doubt as to his (Member) entire good fortune, was beginning to make itself felt, as his (Member) wife had to her (wife) sorrow already discovered. He (Member) had hoped that before this he (Member) might have heard that she (wife) would give him (Member) a child. But the days were young yet for that trouble, and the care had not become a sorrow.

But this judicious arrangement as to properties, this well-ordered alliance between families, had not perhaps suited her (wife) as well as it had suited him (Member). I think that she (wife) might have learned to forget her (wife) early lover, or to look back upon it with a soft melancholy hardly amounting to regret, had her (wife) new lord been more tender in his (lord) ways with her (wife). I do not know that Lady Glencora's heart was made of that stern stuff which refuses to change its impressions; but it was a heart, and it required food. To love and fondle someone,--to be loved and fondled, were absolutely necessary to her (Glencora) happiness. She (Glencora) wanted the little daily assurance of her (Glencora) supremacy in the man's feelings, the constant touch of love, half accidental half contrived, the passing glance of the eye telling perhaps of some little joke understood only between them two rather than of love, the softness of an occasional kiss given here and there when chance might bring them together, some half-pretended interest in her (Glencora) little doings, a nod, a wink, a shake of the head, or even a pout. It should have been given to her (Glencora) to feed upon such food as this daily, and then she (Glencora) would have forgotten Burgo Fitzgerald. But Mr. Palliser understood none of these things; and therefore the image of Burgo Fitzgerald in all his (Fitzgerald) beauty was ever before her (Glencora) eyes.

But not the less was Mr. Palliser a prosperous man, as to the success of whose career few who knew him (Palliser) had much doubt. It might be written in the book of his (Palliser) destiny that he (Palliser) would have to pass through some violent domestic trouble, some ruin in the hopes of his (Palliser) home, of a nature to destroy then and for ever the worldly prospects of other men. But he (Palliser) was one who would pass through such violence, should it come upon him (Palliser), without much scathe. To lose his (Palliser) influence with his (Palliser) party would be worse to him (Palliser) than to lose his (Palliser) wife, and public disgrace would hit him (Palliser) harder than private dishonour.

And the present was the very moment in which success was, as was said, coming to him (Palliser). He (Palliser) had already held laborious office under the Crown, but had never sat in the Cabinet. He (Palliser) had worked much harder than Cabinet Ministers generally work,--but hitherto had worked without any reward that was worth his (Palliser) having. For the stipend which he (Palliser) had received had been nothing to him (Palliser),--as the great stipend which he (Palliser) would receive, if his (Palliser) hopes were true, would also be nothing to him (Palliser). To have ascendancy over other men, to be known by his (Palliser) countrymen as one of their real rulers, to have an actual and acknowledged voice in the management of nations,--those were the rewards for which he (Palliser) looked; and now in truth it seemed as though they were coming to him (Palliser). It was all but known that the existing Chancellor of the Exchequer would separate himself from the Government, carrying various others with him (Chancellor), either before or immediately consequent on the meeting of Parliament;--and it was all but known, also, that Mr. Palliser would fill his (Palliser) place, taking that high office at once, although he (Palliser) had never hitherto sat in that august assembly which men call the Cabinet. He (Palliser) could thus afford to put up with the small everyday calamity of having a wife who loved another man better than she (wife) loved him (man).

The presence of the Duke of St. Bungay at Matching was assumed to be a sure sign of Mr. Palliser's coming triumph. The Duke was a statesman of a very different class, but he (statesman) also had been eminently successful as an aristocratic pillar of the British Constitutional Republic. He (statesman) was a minister of very many years' standing, being as used to cabinet sittings as other men are to their own armchairs; but he (statesman) had never been a hard-working man. Though a constant politician, he (statesman) had ever taken politics easy whether in office or out. The world had said before now that the Duke might be Premier, only that he (Premier) would not take the trouble. He (Premier) had been consulted by a very distinguished person,--so the papers had said more than once,--as to the making of Prime Ministers. His (Premier) voice in council was esteemed to be very great. He (Premier) was regarded as a strong rock of support to the liberal cause, and yet nobody ever knew what he (Premier) did; nor was there much record of what he (Premier) said. The offices which he (Premier) held, or had held, were generally those to which no very arduous duties were attached. In severe debates he (Premier) never took upon himself the brunt of opposition oratory. What he (Premier) said in the House was generally short and pleasant,--with some slight, drolling, undercurrent of uninjurious satire running through it. But he (Premier) was a walking miracle of the wisdom of common sense. He (Premier) never lost his (Premier) temper. He (Premier) never made mistakes. He (Premier) never grew either hot or cold in a cause. He (Premier) was never reckless in politics, and never cowardly. He (Premier) snubbed no man, and took snubbings from no man. He (man) was a Knight of the Garter, a Lord Lieutenant of his (Lieutenant) county, and at sixty-two had his (Lieutenant) digestion unimpaired and his (Lieutenant) estate in excellent order. He (Lieutenant) was a great buyer of pictures, which, perhaps, he (Lieutenant) did not understand, and a great collector of books which certainly he (Lieutenant) never read. All the world respected him (Lieutenant), and he (Lieutenant) was a man to whom the respect of all the world was as the breath of his (Lieutenant) nostrils.

But even he (Lieutenant) was not without his (Lieutenant) peacock on the wall, his (Lieutenant) skeleton in the closet, his (Lieutenant) thorn in his (Lieutenant) side; though the peacock did not scream loud, the skeleton was not very terrible in his (Lieutenant) anatomical arrangement, nor was the thorn likely to fester to a gangrene. The Duke was always in awe about his (Lieutenant) wife.

He (Lieutenant) was ever uneasy about his (Lieutenant) wife, but it must not be supposed that he (Lieutenant) feared the machinations of any Burgo Fitzgerald as being destructive of his (Fitzgerald) domestic comfort. The Duchess was and always had been all that is proper. Ladies in high rank, when gifted with excelling beauty, have often been made the marks of undeserved calumny;--but no breath of slander had ever touched her (Duchess) name. I doubt if any man alive had ever had the courage even to wink at her (Duchess) since the Duke had first called her (Duchess) his (man) own. Nor was she (Duchess) a spendthrift, or a gambler. She (Duchess) was not fast in her (Duchess) tastes, or given to any pursuit that was objectionable. She (Duchess) was simply a fool, and as a fool was ever fearing that she (Duchess) was the mark of ridicule. In all such miseries she (Duchess) would complain sorrowfully, piteously, and occasionally very angrily, to her (Duchess) dear Duke and protector; till sometimes her (Duchess) dear Duke did not quite know what to do with her (Duchess) or how to protect her (Duchess). It did not suit him (fool), a Knight of the Garter and a Duke of St. Bungay, to beg mercy for that poor wife of his (Knight) from such a one as Mrs. Conway Sparkes; nor would it be more in his (Knight) way to lodge a formal complaint against that lady before his (Knight) host or hostess,--as one boy at school may sometimes do as regards another.

``If you don't like the people, my dear, we will go away,'' (he)
he (Knight) said to her (hostess) late on that evening of which we have spoken.
``No,'' (she)
she (hostess) replied,
``I do not wish to go away. I have said that we would stay till December, and Longroyston won't be ready before that. But I think that something ought to be done to silence that woman.'' (she)
And the accent came strong upon
``something,'' (unknown)
and then again with terrific violence upon
``woman.'' (Duke)

The Duke did not know how to silence Mrs. Conway Sparkes. It was a great principle of his (Knight) life never to be angry with any one. How could he (Knight) get at Mrs. Conway Sparkes?

``I don't think she (woman) is worth your attention,'' (the husband)
said the husband.
``That's all very well, Duke,'' (the wife)
said the wife,
``and perhaps she (woman) is not. But I find her (woman) in this house, and I don't like to be laughed at. I think Lady Glencora should make her (Glencora) know her (Glencora) place.'' (the wife)

``Lady Glencora is very young, my dear.'' (unknown)

``I don't know about being so very young,'' (the Duchess)
said the Duchess, whose ear had perhaps caught some little hint of poor Lady Glencora's almost unintentional mimicry. Now as appeals of this kind were being made frequently to the Duke, and as he (husband) was often driven to say some word, of which he (husband) himself hardly approved, to some one in protection of his (husband) Duchess, he (husband) was aware that the matter was an annoyance, and at times almost wished that her (Duchess) Grace was at--Longroyston.

And there was a third politician staying at Matching Priory who had never yet risen to the rank of a statesman, but who had his (statesman) hopes. This was Mr. Bott, the member for St. Helens, whom Lady Glencora had described as a man who stood about, with red hair,--and perhaps told tales of her (Glencora) to her (Glencora) husband. Mr. Bott was a person who certainly had had some success in life and who had won it for himself. He (Bott) was not very young, being at this time only just on the right side of fifty. He (Bott) was now enjoying his (Bott) second session in Parliament, having been returned as a pledged disciple of the Manchester school. Nor had he (Bott) apparently been false to his (Bott) pledges. At St. Helens he (Bott) was still held to be a good man and true. But they who sat on the same side with him (Bott) in the House and watched his (Bott) political manoeuvres, knew that he (Bott) was striving hard to get his (Bott) finger into the public pie. He (Bott) was not a rich man, though he (Bott) had made calico and had got into Parliament. And though he (Bott) claimed to be a thoroughgoing Radical, he (Radical) was a man who liked to live with aristocrats, and was fond of listening to the whispers of such as the Duke of St. Bungay or Mr. Palliser. It was supposed that he (Palliser) did understand something of finance. He (Palliser) was at any rate great in figures; and as he (Palliser) was possessed of much industry, and was obedient withal, he (Palliser) was a man who might make himself useful to a Chancellor of the Exchequer ambitious of changes.

There are men who get into such houses as Matching Priory and whose presence there is a mystery to many;--as to whom the ladies of the house never quite understand why they are entertaining such a guest.

``And Mr. Bott is coming,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Mr. Palliser had said to his (Palliser) wife.
``Mr. Bott!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora had answered.
``Goodness me! who is Mr. Bott?'' (unknown)
``He (Bott) is member for St. Helens,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.
``A very serviceable man in his (man) way.'' (unknown)
``And what am I to do with him (man)?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
asked Lady Glencora.
``I don't know that you can do anything with him (man). He (man) is a man who has a great deal of business, and I dare say he (man) will spend most of his (man) time in the library.'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
So Mr. Bott arrived. But though a huge pile of letters and papers came to him (Bott) every morning by post, he (Bott) unfortunately did not seem to spend much of his (Bott) time in the library. Perhaps he (Bott) had not found the clue to that lost apartment. Twice he (Bott) went out shooting, but as on the first day he (Bott) shot the keeper, and on the second very nearly shot the Duke, he (Bott) gave that up. Hunting he (Bott) declined, though much pressed to make an essay in that art by Jeffrey Palliser. He (Palliser) seemed to spend his (Palliser) time, as Lady Glencora said, in standing about,--except at certain times when he (Palliser) was closeted with Mr. Palliser, and when, it may be presumed, he (Palliser) made himself useful. On such days he (Palliser) would be seen at the hour of lunch with fingers much stained with ink, and it was generally supposed that on those occasions he (Palliser) had been counting up taxes and calculating the effect of great financial changes. He (Palliser) was a tall, wiry, strong man, with a bald head and bristly red beard, which, however, was cut off from his (man) upper and under lip. This was unfortunate, as had he (man) hidden his (man) mouth he (man) would not have been in so marked a degree an ugly man. His (man) upper lip was very long, and his (man) mouth was mean. But he (man) had found that without the help of a razor to these parts he (man) could not manage his (man) soup to his (man) satisfaction, and preferring cleanliness to beauty had shaved himself accordingly.

``I shouldn't dislike Mr. Bott so much,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora said to her (Glencora) husband,
``if he (Bott) didn't rub his (Bott) hands and smile so often, and seem to be going to say something when he (Bott) really is not going to say anything.'' (husband)

``I don't think you need trouble yourself about him (Bott), my dear,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Mr. Palliser had answered.

``But when he (Bott) looks at me in that way, I can't help stopping, as I think he (Bott) is going to speak; and then he (Bott) always says,

``Can I do anything for you, Lady Glen-cowrer?''' (She)

She (Glencora) instantly saw that her (Glencora) husband did not like this.

``Don't be angry with me, dear,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said.
``You must admit that he (Bott) is rather a bore.'' (unknown)

``I am not at all angry, Glencora,'' (the husband)
said the husband;
``and if you insist upon it, I will see that he (Bott) leaves;--and in such case will of course never ask him (Bott) again. But that might be prejudicial to me, as he (Bott) is a man whom I trust in politics, and who may perhaps be serviceable to me.'' (the husband)

Of course Lady Glencora declared that Mr. Bott might remain as long as he (Bott) and her (Glencora) husband desired, and of course she (Glencora) mentioned his (Bott) name no more to Mr. Palliser; but from that time forth she (Glencora) regarded Mr. Bott as an enemy, and felt also that Mr. Bott regarded her (Glencora) in the same light.

When it was known among outside politicians that the Duke of St. Bungay was staying at Matching Priory, outside politicians became more sure than ever that Mr. Palliser would be the new Chancellor of the Exchequer. The old minister and the young minister were of course arranging matters together. But I doubt whether Mr. Palliser and the Duke ever spoke on any such topic during the entire visit. Though Mr. Bott was occasionally closeted with Mr. Palliser, the Duke never troubled himself with such closetings. He (Bott) went out shooting--on his (Bott) pony, read his (Bott) newspaper, wrote his (Bott) notes, and looked with the eye of a connoisseur over all Mr. Palliser's farming apparatus.

``You seem to have a good man, I should say,'' (the Duke)
said the Duke.
``What! Hubbings? Yes;--he (man) was a legacy from my uncle when he (man) gave me up the Priory.'' (unknown)
``A very good man, I should say. Of course he (man) won't make it pay; but he (man)'ll make it look as though it did;--which is the next best thing. I could never get rent out of land that I farmed myself,--never.'' (unknown)
``I suppose not,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, who did not care much about it. The Duke would have talked to him (Palliser) by the hour together about farming had Mr. Palliser been so minded; but he (Palliser) talked to him (Palliser) very little about politics. Nor during the whole time of his (Palliser) stay at Matching did the Duke make any other allusion to Mr. Palliser's hopes as regarded the ministry, than that in which he (Palliser) had told Lady Glencora at the dinner-table that her (Glencora) husband's ambition was the highest by which any man could be moved.

But Mr. Bott was sometimes honoured by a few words with the Duke.

``We shall muster pretty strong, your Grace,'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
Mr. Bott had said to him (Bott) one day before dinner.

``That depends on how the changes go,'' (the Duke)
said the Duke.

``I suppose there will be a change?'' (unknown)

``Oh yes; there'll be a change,--certainly, I should say. And it will be in your direction.'' (unknown)

``And in Palliser's?'' (unknown)

``Yes; I should think so;--that is, if it suits him (We). By-the-by, Mr. Bott--'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
Then there was a little whispered communication, in which perhaps Mr. Bott was undertaking some commission of that nature which Lady Glencora had called
``telling.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

CHAPTER XXV.

In Which Much of the History of the Pallisers Is Told.

At the end of ten days Alice found herself quite comfortable at Matching Priory. She (Alice) had now promised to remain there till the second week of December, at which time she (Alice) was to go to Vavasor Hall,--there to meet her (Alice) father and Kate. The Pallisers were to pass their Christmas with the Duke of Omnium in Barsetshire.

``We always are to do that,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora.
``It is the state occasion at Gatherum Castle, but it only lasts for one week. Then we go somewhere else. Oh dear!'' (unknown)

``Why do you say `oh dear'?'' (unknown)

``Because--; I don't think I mean to tell you.'' (unknown)

``Then I'm sure I won't ask.'' (unknown)

``That's so like you, Alice. But I can be as firm as you, and I'm sure I won't tell you unless you do ask.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
But Alice did not ask, and it was not long before Lady Glencora's firmness gave way.

But, as I have said, Alice had become quite comfortable at Matching Priory. Perhaps she (Alice) was already growing upwards towards the light. At any rate she (Alice) could listen with pleasure to the few words the Duke would say to her (Alice). She (Alice) could even chat a little to the Duchess,--so that her (Duchess) Grace had observed to Lady Glencora that

``her (Alice) cousin was a very nice person,--a very nice person indeed. What a pity it was that she (Alice) had been so ill-treated by that gentleman in Oxfordshire!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora had to explain that the gentleman lived in Cambridgeshire, and that he (gentleman), at any rate, had not treated anybody ill.
``Do you mean that she (Alice)--jilted him (gentleman)?'' (the Duchess)
said the Duchess, almost whistling, and opening her (Duchess) eyes very wide.
``Dear me, I'm sorry for that. I shouldn't have thought it.'' (she)
And when she (Duchess) next spoke to Alice she (Alice) assumed rather a severe tone of emphasis;--but this was soon abandoned when Alice listened to her (Alice) with complacency.

Alice also had learned to ride,--or rather had resumed her (Alice) riding, which for years had been abandoned. Jeffrey Palliser had been her (Alice) squire, and she (Alice) had become intimate with him (Palliser) so as to learn to quarrel with him (Palliser) and to like him (Palliser),--to such an extent that Lady Glencora had laughingly told her (Glencora) that she (Glencora) was going to do more.

``I rather think not,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``But what has thinking to do with it? Who ever thinks about it?'' (unknown)

``I don't just at present,--at any rate.'' (unknown)

``Upon my word it would be very nice;--and then perhaps some day you'd be the Duchess.'' (unknown)

``Glencora, don't talk such nonsense.'' (unknown)

``Those are the speculations which people make. Only I should spite you by killing myself, so that he (I) might marry again.'' (unknown)

``How can you say such horrid things?'' (unknown)

``I think I shall,--some day. What right have I to stand in his (I) way? He (I) spoke to me the other day about Jeffrey's altered position, and I knew what he (Jeffrey) meant;--or rather what he (Jeffrey) didn't mean to say, but what he (Jeffrey) thought. But I shan't kill myself.'' (unknown)

``I should think not.'' (unknown)

``I only know one other way,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``You are thinking of things which should never be in your thoughts,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice vehemently.
``Have you no trust in God's providence? Cannot you accept what has been done for you?'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)

Mr. Bott had gone away, much to Lady Glencora's delight, but had unfortunately come back again. On his (Bott) return Alice heard more of the feud between the Duchess and Mrs. Conway Sparkes.

``I did not tell you,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora to her (Glencora) friend;--
``I did not tell you before he (God) went that I was right about his (God) tale-bearing.'' (friend)

``And did he (God) bear tales?'' (unknown)

``Yes; I did get the scolding, and I know very well that it came through him (God), though Mr. Palliser did not say so. But he (Palliser) told me that the Duchess had felt herself hurt by that other woman's way of talking.'' (unknown)

``But it was not your fault.'' (unknown)

``No; that's what I said. It was he (Palliser) who desired me to ask Mrs. Conway Sparkes to come here. I didn't want her (Sparkes). She (Sparkes) goes everywhere, and it is thought a catch to get her (Sparkes); but if she (Sparkes) had been drowned in the Red Sea I shouldn't have minded. When I told him (Palliser) that, he (Palliser) said it was nonsense,--which of course it was; and then he (Palliser) said I ought to make her (Sparkes) hold her (Sparkes) tongue. Of course I said I couldn't. Mrs. Conway Sparkes wouldn't care for me. If she (Sparkes) quizzed me, myself, I told him (Palliser) that I could take care of myself, though she (Sparkes) were ten times Mrs. Conway Sparkes, and had written finer poetry than Tennyson.'' (unknown)

``It is fine;--some of it,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Oh, I dare say! I know a great deal of it by heart, only I wouldn't give her (Sparkes) the pleasure of supposing that I had ever thought so much about her (Sparkes) poetry. And then I told him (Tennyson) that I couldn't take care of the Duchess,--and he (Tennyson) told me that I was a child.'' (unknown)

``He (Tennyson) only meant that in love.'' (unknown)

``I am a child; I know that. Why didn't he (Tennyson) marry some strong-minded, ferocious woman that could keep his (Tennyson) house in order, and frown Mrs. Sparkes out of her (Sparkes) impudence? It wasn't my fault.'' (unknown)

``You didn't tell him (Tennyson) that.'' (unknown)

``But I did. Then he (Tennyson) kissed me, and said it was all right, and told me that I should grow older. ``And Mrs. Sparkes will grow more impudent,

'' I said, `and the Duchess more silly.'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)
And after that I went away. Now this horrid Mr. Bott has come back again, and only that it would be mean in me to condescend so far, I would punish him (Bott). He (Bott) grins and smiles at me, and rubs his (Bott) big hands more than ever, because he (Bott) feels that he (Bott) has behaved badly. Is it not horrid to have to live in the house with such people?''

``I don't think you need mind him (Tennyson) much.'' (unknown)

``Yes; but I am the mistress here, and am told that I am to entertain the people. Fancy entertaining the Duchess of St. Bungay and Mr. Bott!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice had now become so intimate with Lady Glencora that she (Alice) did not scruple to read her (Alice) wise lectures,--telling her (Alice) that she (Alice) allowed herself to think too much of little things,--and too much also of some big things.

``As regards Mr. Bott,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice,
``I think you should bear it as though there were no such person.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``But that would be pretence,--especially to you.'' (unknown)

``No; it would not be pretence; it would be the reticence which all women should practise,--and you, in your position, more almost than any other woman.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Then Lady Glencora pouted, told Alice that it was a pity she (Glencora) had not married Mr. Palliser, and left her (Glencora).

That evening,--the evening of Mr. Bott's return to Matching, that gentleman found a place near to Alice in the drawing-room. He (gentleman) had often come up to her (Alice), rubbing his (gentleman) hands together, and saying little words, as though there was some reason from their positions that they two should be friends. Alice had perceived this, and had endeavoured with all her (Alice) force to shake him (gentleman) off; but he (gentleman) was a man, who if he (gentleman) understood a hint, never took it. A cold shoulder was nothing to him (gentleman), if he (gentleman) wanted to gain the person who showed it him (gentleman). His (gentleman) code of perseverance taught him (gentleman) that it was a virtue to overcome cold shoulders. The man or woman who received his (man) first overtures with grace would probably be one on whom it would be better that he (man) should look down and waste no further time; whereas he (man) or she (woman) who could afford to treat him (man) with disdain would no doubt be worth gaining. Such men as Mr. Bott are ever gracious to cold shoulders. The colder the shoulders, the more gracious are the Mr. Botts.

``What a delightful person is our dear friend, Lady Glencora!'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Mr. Bott, having caught Alice in a position from which she (Alice) could not readily escape.

Alice had half a mind to differ, or to make any remark that might rid her (Alice) from Mr. Bott. But she (Alice) did not dare to say a word that might seem to have been said playfully.

``Yes, indeed,'' (she)
she (Alice) replied.
``How very cold it is to-night!'' (She)
She (Alice) was angry with herself for her (Alice) own stupidity as soon as the phrase was out of her (Alice) mouth, and then she (Alice) almost laughed as she (Alice) thought of the Duchess and the hot-water pipes at Longroyston.

``Yes, it is cold. You and her (Glencora) ladyship are great friends, I believe, Miss Vavasor.'' (unknown)

``She (Glencora) is my cousin,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Ah! yes; that is so pleasant. I have reason to know that Mr. Palliser is very much gratified that you should be so much with her (Glencora).'' (unknown)

This was unbearable. Alice could not quite assume sufficient courage to get up from her (Alice) chair and walk away from him (Bott), and yet she (Alice) felt that she (Alice) must escape further conversation.

``I don't know that I am very much with her (Glencora), and if I were I can't think it would make any difference to Mr. Palliser.'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)

But Mr. Bott was not a man to be put down when he (Bott) had a purpose in hand.

``I can assure you that those are his (Palliser) sentiments. Of course we all know that dear Lady Glencora is young. She (Glencora) is very young.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Bott, I really would rather not talk about my cousin.'' (unknown)

``But, dear Miss Vavasor;--when we both have her (Glencora) welfare in view--?'' (unknown)

``I haven't her (Glencora) welfare in view, Mr. Bott; not in the least. There is no reason why I should. You must excuse me if I say I cannot talk about her (Glencora) welfare with a perfect stranger.'' (she)
Then she (Alice) did get up, and went away from the Member of Parliament, leaving him (Member) rather astonished at her (Alice) audacity. But he (Member) was a constant man, and his (Member) inner resolve was simply to the effect that he (Member) would try it again.

I wonder whether Jeffrey Palliser did think much of the difference between his (Palliser) present position and that which would have been his (Palliser) had Lady Glencora been the happy possessor of a cradle up-stairs with a boy in it. I suppose he (Palliser) must have done so. It is hardly possible that any man should not be alive to the importance of such a chance. His (man) own present position was one of the most unfortunate which can fall to the lot of a man. His (man) father, the Duke's youngest brother, had left him (man) about six hundred a year, and had left him (man) also a taste for living with people of six thousand. The propriety of earning his (man) bread had never been put before him (man). His (man) father had been in Parliament, and had been the most favoured son of the old Duke, who for some years before his (man) death had never spoken to him (man) who now reigned over the house of the Pallisers. Jeffrey's father had been brought up at Matching Priory as scions of ducal houses are brought up, and on the old man's death had been possessed of means sufficient to go on in the same path, though with difficulty. His (man) brother had done something for him (man), and at various times he (man) had held some place near the throne. But on his (man) death, when the property left behind him (man) was divided between his (man) son and three daughters, Jeffrey Palliser became possessed of the income above stated. Of course he (Palliser) could live on it,--and as during the winter months of the year a home was found for him (Palliser) free of cost, he (Palliser) could keep hunters, and live as rich men live. But he (Palliser) was a poor, embarrassed man, without prospects,--until this fine ducal prospect became opened to him (man) by the want of that cradle at Matching Priory.

But the prospect was no doubt very distant. Lady Glencora might yet have as many sons as Hecuba. Or she (Glencora) might die, and some other more fortunate lady might become the mother of his (man) cousin's heir. Or the Duke might marry and have a son. And, moreover, his (son) cousin was only one year older than himself, and the great prize, if it came his (son) way, might not come for forty years as yet. Nevertheless his (son) hand might now be acceptable in quarters where it would certainly be rejected had Lady Glencora possessed that cradle up-stairs. We cannot but suppose that he (son) must have made some calculations of this nature.

``It is a pity you should do nothing all your life,'' (cousin)
his (son) cousin Plantagenet said to him (son) one morning just at this time. Jeffrey had sought the interview in his (Jeffrey) cousin's room, and I fear had done so with some slight request for ready money.

``What am I to do?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Jeffrey.

``At any rate you might marry.'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes;--I could marry. There's no man so poor but what he (man) can do that. The question would be how I might like the subsequent starvation.'' (unknown)

``I don't see that you need starve. Though your own fortune is small, it is something,--and many girls have fortunes of their own.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

Jeffrey thought of Lady Glencora, but he (Jeffrey) made no allusion to her (Glencora) in speech.

``I don't think I'm very good at that kind of thing,'' (he)
he (Jeffrey) said.
``When the father and mother came to ask of my house and my home I should break down. I don't say it as praising myself;--indeed, quite the reverse; but I fear I have not a mercenary tendency.'' (unknown)

``That's nonsense.'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes; quite so. I admit that.'' (unknown)

``Men must have mercenary tendencies or they would not have bread. The man who ploughs that he (man) may live does so because he (man), luckily, has a mercenary tendency.'' (unknown)

``Just so. But you see I am less lucky than the ploughman.'' (unknown)

``There is no vulgar error so vulgar,--that is to say, common or erroneous, as that by which men have been taught to say that mercenary tendencies are bad. A desire for wealth is the source of all progress. Civilization comes from what men call greed. Let your mercenary tendencies be combined with honesty and they cannot take you astray.'' (the Chancellor)
This the future Chancellor of the Exchequer said with much of that air and tone of wisdom which a Chancellor of the Exchequer ought to possess.

``But I haven't got any such tendencies,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Jeffrey.

``Would you like to occupy a farm in Scotland?'' (Plantagenet/Plantagenet Palliser)
said Plantagenet Palliser.

``And pay rent?'' (unknown)

``You would have to pay rent of course.'' (unknown)

``Thank you, no. It would be dishonest, as I know I should never pay it.'' (unknown)

``You are too old, I fear, for the public service.'' (unknown)

``You mean a desk in the Treasury,--with a hundred a year. Yes; I think I am too old.'' (unknown)

``But have you no plan of your own?'' (unknown)

``Not much of one. Sometimes I have thought I would go to New Zealand.'' (unknown)

``You would have to be a farmer there.'' (unknown)

``No;--I shouldn't do that. I should get up an opposition to the Government and that sort of thing, and then they would buy me off and give me a place.'' (unknown)

``That does very well here, Jeffrey, if a man can get into Parliament and has capital enough to wait; but I don't think it would do out there. Would you like to go into Parliament?'' (unknown)

``What; here? Of course I should. Only I should be sure to get terribly into debt. I don't owe very much, now,--not to speak of,--except what I owe you.'' (unknown)

``You owe nothing to me,'' (Plantagenet/Plantagenet Palliser)
said Plantagenet, with some little touch of magniloquence in his (Jeffrey) tone.
``No; don't speak of it. I have no brother, and between you and me it means nothing. You see, Jeffrey, it may be that I shall have to look to you as my--my--my heir, in short.'' (Hereupon Jeffrey)
Hereupon Jeffrey muttered something as to the small probability of such necessity, and as to the great remoteness of any result even if it were so.

``That's all true,'' (the heir)
said the elder heir of the Pallisers,
``but still--. In short, I wish you would do something. Do you think about it; and then some day speak to me again.'' (the heir)

Jeffrey, as he (Jeffrey) left his (Jeffrey) cousin with a cheque for #500 in his (Jeffrey) waist-coat pocket, thought that the interview which had at one time taken important dimensions, had not been concluded altogether satisfactorily. A seat in Parliament! Yes, indeed! If his (Jeffrey) cousin would so far use his (Jeffrey) political, monetary, or ducal interest as to do that for him (Jeffrey);--as to give him (Jeffrey) something of the status properly belonging to the younger son of the House, then indeed life would have some charms for him (son)! But as for the farm in Scotland, or a desk at an office in London,--his (son) own New Zealand plan would be better than those. And then as he (son) went along of course he (son) bethought himself that it might be his (son) lot yet to die, and at least to be buried, in the purple, as a Duke of Omnium. If so, certainly it would be his (son) duty to prepare another heir, and leave a duke behind him (son),--if it were possible.

``Are you going to ride with us after lunch?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora to him (son) as he (son) strolled into the drawing-room.

``No,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Jeffrey;
``I'm going to study.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

``To do what?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``To study;--or rather I shall spend to-day in sitting down and considering what I will study. My cousin has just been telling me that I ought to do something.'' (unknown)

``So you ought,'' (Iphigenia)
said Iphigenia energetically from her (Glencora) writing-desk.

``But he (cousin) didn't seem to have any clear opinion what it ought to be. You see there can't be two Chancellors of the Exchequer at the same time. Mrs. Sparkes, what ought a young man like me to set about doing?'' (unknown)

``Go into Parliament, I should say,'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)
said Mrs. Sparkes.

``Ah, yes; exactly. He (man) had some notion of that kind, too, but he (man) didn't name any particular place. I think I'll try the City of London. They've four there, and of course the chance of getting in would thereby be doubled.'' (unknown)

``I thought that commercial men were generally preferred in the City,'' (the Duchess)
said the Duchess, taking a strong and good-natured interest in the matter.

``Mr. Palliser means to make a fortune in trade as a preliminary,'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)
said Mrs. Sparkes.

``I don't think he (Palliser) meant anything of the kind,'' (the Duchess)
said the Duchess.

``At any rate I have got to do something, so I can't go and ride,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Jeffrey.

``And you ought to do something,'' (Iphigenia)
said Iphigenia from her (Duchess) desk.

Twice during this little conversation Lady Glencora had looked up, catching Alice's eye, and Alice had well known what she (Alice) had meant.

``You see,'' (unknown)
the glance had said,
``Plantagenet is beginning to take an interest in his (Palliser) cousin, and you know why. The man who is to be the father of the future dukes must not be allowed to fritter away his (father) time in obscurity. Had I that cradle up-stairs Jeffrey might be as idle as he (Jeffrey) pleased.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice understood it well.

Of course Jeffrey did join the riding party.

``What is a man like me to do who wants to do something?'' (he)
he (Jeffrey) said to Alice. Alice was quite aware that Lady Glencora had contrived some little scheme that Mr. Palliser should be riding next to her (Glencora). She (Glencora) liked Mr. Palliser, and therefore had no objection; but she (Glencora) declared to herself that her (Glencora) cousin was a goose for her (Glencora) pains.

``Mrs. Sparkes says you ought to go into Parliament.'' (unknown)

``Yes;--and the dear Duchess would perhaps suggest a house in Belgrave Square. I want to hear your advice now.'' (unknown)

``I can only say ditto to Miss Palliser.'' (unknown)

``What! Iphy? About procrastination? But you see the more of my time he (Jeffrey) steals the better it is for me.'' (unknown)

``That's the evil you have got to cure.'' (unknown)

``My cousin Plantagenet suggested--marriage.'' (unknown)

``A very good thing too, I'm sure,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice;
``only it depends something on the sort of wife you get.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``You mean, of course, how much money she (wife) has.'' (unknown)

``Not altogether.'' (unknown)

``Looking at it from my cousin's point of view, I suppose that it is the only important point. Who are there coming up this year,--in the way of heiresses?'' (unknown)

``Upon my word I don't know. In the first place, how much money makes an heiress?'' (unknown)

``For such a fellow as me, I suppose ten thousand pounds ought to do.'' (unknown)

``That's not much,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, who had exactly that amount of her (Alice) own.

``No--; perhaps that's too moderate. But the lower one went in the money speculation, the greater would be the number to choose from, and the better the chance of getting something decent in the woman herself. I have something of my own,--not much you know; so with the lady's ten thousand pounds we might be able to live,--in some second-rate French town perhaps.'' (unknown)

``But I don't see what you would gain by that.'' (unknown)

``My people here would have got rid of me. That seems to be the great thing. If you hear of any girl with about that sum, moderately good-looking, not too young so that she (girl) might know something of the world, decently born, and able to read and write, perhaps you will bear me in mind.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I will,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, who was quite aware that he (cousin) had made an accurate picture of her (Alice) own position.
``When I meet such a one, I will send for you at once.'' (unknown)

``You know no such person now?'' (unknown)

``Well, no; not just at present.'' (unknown)

``I declare I don't think he (girl) could do anything better,'' (cousin)
her (Alice) cousin said to her (Alice) that night. Lady Glencora was now in the habit of having Alice with her (Alice) in what she (Alice) called her (Alice) dressing-room every evening, and then they would sit till the small hours came upon them. Mr. Palliser always burnt the midnight oil and came to bed with the owls. They would often talk of him (Palliser) and his (Palliser) prospects till Alice had perhaps inspired his (Palliser) wife with more of interest in him (Palliser) and them than she (Alice) had before felt. And Alice had managed generally to drive her (Alice) friend away from those topics which were so dangerous,--those allusions to her (Alice) childlessness, and those hints that Burgo Fitzgerald was still in her (Alice) thoughts. And sometimes, of course, they had spoken of Alice's own prospects, till she (Alice) got into a way of telling her (Alice) cousin freely all that she (Alice) felt. On such occasions Lady Glencora would always tell her (Glencora) that she (Glencora) had been right,--if she (Glencora) did not love the man.
``Though your finger were put out for the ring,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora on one such occasion,
``you should go back, if you did not love him (girl).'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``But I did love him (girl),'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Then I don't understand it,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora; and, in truth, close as was their intimacy, they did not perfectly understand each other.

But on this occasion they were speaking of Jeffrey Palliser.

``I declare I don't think he (girl) could do any better,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``If you talk such nonsense, I will not stay,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``But why should it be nonsense? You would be very comfortable with your joint incomes. He (girl) is one of the best fellows in the world. It is clear that he (girl) likes you; and then we should be so near to each other. I am sure Mr. Palliser would do something for him (Palliser) if he (Palliser) married,--and especially if I asked him (Palliser).'' (unknown)

``I only know of two things against it.'' (unknown)

``And what are they?'' (unknown)

``That he (Palliser) would not take me for his (Palliser) wife, and that I would not take him (Palliser) for my husband.'' (unknown)

``Why not? What do you dislike in him (Palliser)?'' (unknown)

``I don't dislike him (Palliser) at all. I like him (Palliser) very much indeed. But one can't marry all the people one likes.'' (unknown)

``But what reason is there why you shouldn't marry him (Palliser)?'' (unknown)

``This chiefly,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, after a pause;
``that I have just separated myself from a man whom I certainly did love truly, and that I cannot transfer my affections quite so quickly as that.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

As soon as the words were out of her (Alice) mouth she (Alice) knew that they should not have been spoken. It was exactly what Glencora had done. She (Glencora) had loved a man and had separated herself from him (man) and had married another all within a month or two. Lady Glencora first became red as fire over her (Glencora) whole face and shoulders, and Alice afterwards did the same as she (Alice) looked up, as though searching in her (Alice) cousin's eyes for pardon.

``It is an unmaidenly thing to do, certainly,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora very slowly, and in her (Glencora) lowest voice.
``Nay, it is unwomanly; but one may be driven. One may be so driven that all gentleness of womanhood is driven out of one.'' (unknown)

``Oh, Glencora!'' (unknown)

``I did not propose that you should do it as a sudden thing.'' (unknown)

``Glencora!'' (unknown)

``I did do it suddenly. I know it. I did it like a beast that is driven as its owner chooses. I know it. I was a beast. Oh, Alice, if you know how I hate myself!'' (unknown)

``But I love you with all my heart,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``Glencora, I have learned to love you so dearly!'' (unknown)

``Then you are the only being that does. He (owner) can't love me. How is it possible? You,--and perhaps another.'' (unknown)

``There are many who love you. He (owner) loves you. Mr. Palliser loves you.'' (unknown)

``It is impossible. I have never said a word to him (Palliser) that could make him (Palliser) love me. I have never done a thing for him (Palliser) that can make him (Palliser) love me. The mother of his (Palliser) child he (Palliser) might have loved, because of that. Why should he (Palliser) love me? We were told to marry each other and did it. When could he (Palliser) have learned to love me? But, Alice, he (Palliser) requires no loving, either to take it or to give it. I wish it were so with me.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice said what she (Alice) could to comfort her (Alice), but her (Alice) words were but of little avail as regarded those marriage sorrows.

``Forgive you!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
at last Glencora said.
``What have I to forgive? You don't suppose I do not know it all, and think of it all without the chance of some stray word like that! Forgive you! I am so grateful that you love me! Some one's love I must have found,--or I could not have remained here.'' (unknown)

CHAPTER XXVI.

Lady Midlothian.

A week or ten days after this, Alice, when she (Alice) came down to the breakfast-parlour one morning, found herself alone with Mr. Bott. It was the fashion at Matching Priory for people to assemble rather late in the day. The nominal hour for breakfast was ten, and none of the ladies of the party were ever seen before that. Some of the gentlemen would breakfast earlier, especially on hunting mornings; and on some occasions the ladies, when they came together, would find themselves altogether deserted by their husbands and brothers. On this day it was fated that Mr. Bott alone should represent the sterner sex, and when Alice entered the room he (Bott) was standing on the rug with his (Bott) back to the fire, waiting till the appearance of some other guest should give him (Bott) the sanction necessary for the commencement of his (Bott) morning meal. Alice, when she (Alice) saw him (Bott), would have retreated had it been possible, for she (Alice) had learned to dislike him (Bott) greatly, and was, indeed, almost afraid of him (Bott); but she (Alice) could not do so without making her (Alice) flight too conspicuous.

``Do you intend to prolong your stay here, Miss Vavasor?'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Mr. Bott, taking advantage of the first moment at which she (Alice) looked up from a letter which she (Alice) was reading.

``For a few more days, I think,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Ah--I'm glad of that. Mr. Palliser has pressed me so much to remain till he (Palliser) goes to the Duke's, that I cannot get away sooner. As I am an unmarried man myself, I can employ my time as well in one place as in another;--at this time of the year at least.'' (unknown)

``You must find that very convenient,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Yes, it is convenient. You see in my position,--Parliamentary position, I mean,--I am obliged, as a public man, to act in concert with others. A public man can be of no service unless he (man) is prepared to do that. We must give and take, you know, Miss Vavasor.'' (Miss Vavasor)

As Miss Vavasor made no remark in answer to this, Mr. Bott continued--

``I always say to the men of my party,--of course I regard myself as belonging to the extreme Radicals.'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)

``Oh, indeed!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Yes. I came into Parliament on that understanding; and I have never seen any occasion as yet to change any political opinion that I have expressed. But I always say to the gentlemen with whom I act, that nothing can be done if we don't give and take. I don't mind saying to you, Miss Vavasor, that I look upon our friend, Mr. Palliser, as the most rising public man in the country. I do, indeed.'' (unknown)

``I am happy to hear you say so,'' (victim)
said his (Bott) victim, who found herself driven to make some remark.

``And I, as an extreme Radical, do not think I can serve my party better than by keeping in the same boat with him (Radical), as long as it will hold the two. ``He (Radical)'ll make a Government hack of you,'' a friend of mine said to me the other day. ``And I'll make a Manchester school Prime Minister of him (Minister),

'' I replied. I rather think I know what I'm about, Miss Vavasor.'' (him)

``No doubt,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``And so does he (Minister);--and so does he (Minister). Mr. Palliser is not the man to be led by the nose by any one. But it's a fair system of give and take. You can't get on in politics without it. What a charming woman is your relative, Lady Glencowrer! I remember well what you said to me the other evening.'' (unknown)

``Do you?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``And I quite agree with you that confidential intercourse regarding dear friends should not be lightly made.'' (unknown)

``Certainly not,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``But there are occasions, Miss Vavasor; there are occasions when the ordinary laws by which we govern our social conduct must be made somewhat elastic.'' (unknown)

``I don't think this one of them, Mr. Bott.'' (unknown)

``Is it not? Just listen to me for one moment, Miss Vavasor. Our friend, Mr. Palliser, I am proud to say, relies much upon my humble friendship. Our first connection has, of course, been political; but it has extended beyond that, and has become pleasantly social;--I may say, very pleasantly social.'' (unknown)

``What a taste Mr. Palliser must have!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice thought to herself.

``But I need not tell you that Lady Glencowrer is--very young; we may say, very young indeed.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Bott, I will not talk to you about Lady Glencora Palliser.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

This Alice said in a determined voice, and with all the power of resistance at her (Alice) command. She (Alice) frowned too, and looked savagely at Mr. Bott. But he (Bott) was a man of considerable courage, and knew how to bear such opposition without flinching.

``When I tell you, Miss Vavasor, that I speak solely with a view to her (Vavasor) domestic happiness!'' (unknown)

``I don't think that she (Vavasor) wishes to have any such guardian of her (Vavasor) happiness.'' (unknown)

``But if he (Bott) wishes it, Miss Vavasor! Now I have the means of knowing that he (Bott) has the greatest reliance on your judgement.'' (Hereupon Alice)

Hereupon Alice got up with the intention of leaving the room, but she (Alice) was met at the door by Mrs. Conway Sparkes.

``Are you running from your breakfast, Miss Vavasor?'' (she)
said she (Sparkes).

``No, Mrs. Sparkes; I am running from Mr. Bott,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, who was almost beside herself with anger.

``Mr. Bott, what is this?'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)
said Mrs. Sparkes.
``Ha, ha, ha,'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
laughed Mr. Bott.

Alice returned to the room, and Mrs. Sparkes immediately saw that she (Sparkes) had in truth been running from Mr. Bott.

``I hope I shall be able to keep the peace,'' (she)
said she (Sparkes).
``I trust his (Bott) offence was not one that requires special punishment.'' (unknown)

``Ha, ha, ha,'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
again laughed Mr. Bott, who rather liked his (Bott) position.

Alice was very angry with herself, feeling that she (Alice) had told more of the truth to Mrs. Sparkes than she (Sparkes) should have done, unless she (Sparkes) was prepared to tell the whole. As it was, she (Sparkes) wanted to say something, and did not know what to say; but her (Sparkes) confusion was at once stopped by the entrance of Lady Glencora.

``Mrs. Sparkes, good morning,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``I hope nobody has waited breakfast. Good morning, Mr. Bott. Oh, Alice!'' (unknown)

``What is the matter?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, going up to her (Alice).

``Oh, Alice, such a blow!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
But Alice could see that her (Alice) cousin was not quite in earnest;--that the new trouble, though it might be vexatious, was no great calamity.
``Come here,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora; and they both went into an embrasure of the window.
``Now I shall have to put your confidence in me to the test. This letter is from,--whom do you think?'' (unknown)

``How can I guess?'' (unknown)

``From Lady Midlothian! and she (Lady)'s coming here on Monday, on her (Lady) road to London. Unless you tell me that you are quite sure this is as unexpected by me as by you, I will never speak to you again.'' (unknown)

``I am quite sure of that.'' (unknown)

``Ah! then we can consult. But first we'll go and have some breakfast.'' (ladies)
Then more ladies swarmed into the room,--the Duchess and her (Duchess) daughter, and the two Miss Pallisers, and others; and Mr. Bott had his (Bott) hands full in attending,--or rather in offering to attend, to their little wants.

The morning was nearly gone before Alice and her (Alice) cousin had any further opportunity of discussing in private the approach of Lady Midlothian; but Mr. Palliser had come in among them, and had been told of the good thing which was in store for him (Palliser).

``We shall be delighted to see Lady Midlothian,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

``But there is somebody here who will not be at all delighted to see her (Lady),'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora to her (Glencora) husband.

``Is there, indeed?'' (he)
said he (Palliser).
``Who is that?'' (unknown)

``Her (Lady) most undutiful cousin, Alice Vavasor. But, Alice, Mr. Palliser knows nothing about it, and it is too long to explain.'' (unknown)

``I am extremely sorry--'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
began Mr. Palliser.

``I can assure you it does not signify in the least,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``It will only be taking me away three days earlier.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

Upon hearing this Mr. Palliser looked very serious. What quarrel could Miss Vavasor have had with Lady Midlothian which should make it impossible for them to be visitors at the same house?

``It will do no such thing,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``Do you mean to say that you are coward enough to run away from her (Alice)?'' (unknown)

``I'm afraid, Miss Vavasor, that we can hardly bid her (Alice) not come,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser. In answer to this, Alice protested that she (Alice) would not for worlds have been the means of keeping Lady Midlothian away from Matching.
``I should tell you, Mr. Palliser, that I have never seen Lady Midlothian, though she (Lady) is my far-away cousin. Nor have I ever quarrelled with her (Lady). But she (Lady) has given me advice by letter, and I did not answer her (Lady) because I thought she (Lady) had no business to interfere. I shall go away, not because I am afraid of her (Lady), but because, after what has passed, our meeting would be unpleasant to her (Lady).'' (unknown)

``You could tell her (Lady) that Miss Vavasor is here,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.
``And then she (Lady) need not come unless she (Lady) pleased.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

The matter was so managed at last that Alice found herself unable to leave Matching without making more of Lady Midlothian's coming than it was worth. It would undoubtedly be very disagreeable,--this unexpected meeting with her (Lady) relative; but, as Lady Glencora said, Lady Midlothian would not eat her (Midlothian). In truth, she (Midlothian) felt ashamed of herself in that she (Midlothian) was afraid of her (Midlothian) relative. No doubt she (Midlothian) was afraid of her (Midlothian). So much she (Midlothian) was forced to admit to herself. But she (Midlothian) resolved at last that she (Midlothian) would not let her (Midlothian) drive her (Midlothian) out of the house.

``Is Mr. Bott an admirer of your cousin?'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)
Mrs. Sparkes said that evening to Lady Glencora.

``A very distant one I should think,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``Goodness gracious!'' (an lady)
exclaimed an old lady who had been rather awed by Alice's intimacy and cousinship with Lady Glencora;
``it's the very last thing I should have dreamt of.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``But I didn't dream it, first or last,'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)
said Mrs. Sparkes.

``Why do you ask?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``Don't suppose that I am asking whether Miss Vavasor is an admirer of his (admirer),'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)
said Mrs. Sparkes.
``I have no suspicion of that nature. I rather think that when he (admirer) plays Bacchus she (Lady) plays Ariadne, with full intention of flying from him (admirer) in earnest.'' (unknown)

``Is Mr. Bott inclined to play Bacchus?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
asked Lady Glencora.

``I rather thought he (Bott) was this morning. If you observe, he (Bott) has something of a godlike and triumphant air about him (Bott).'' (unknown)

``I don't think his (Bott) godship will triumph there,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``I really think she (Lady) would be throwing herself very much away,'' (the lady)
said the old lady.

``Miss Vavasor is not at all disposed to do that,'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)
said Mrs. Sparkes. Then that conversation was allowed to drop.

On the following Monday, Lady Midlothian arrived. The carriage was sent to meet her (Lady) at the station about three o'clock in the afternoon, and Alice had to choose whether she (Alice) would undergo her (Alice) first introduction immediately on her (Alice) relative's arrival, or whether she (Alice) would keep herself out of the way till she (Alice) should meet her (Alice) in the drawing-room before dinner.

``I shall receive her (Lady) when she (Lady) comes,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora,
``and of course will tell her (Lady) that you are here.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``Yes, that will be best; and--; dear me, I declare I don't know how to manage it.'' (unknown)

``I'll bring her (Lady) to you in my room if you like it.'' (unknown)

``No; that would be too solemn,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``That would make her (Lady) understand that I thought a great deal about her (Lady).'' (unknown)

``Then we'll let things take their chance, and you shall come across her (Lady) just as you would any other stranger.'' (Lady Midlothian)
It was settled at last that this would be the better course, but that Lady Midlothian was to be informed of Alice's presence at the Priory as soon as she (Alice) should arrive.

Alice was in her (Alice) own room when the carriage in which sat the unwelcome old lady was driven up to the hall-door. She (lady) heard the wheels plainly, and knew well that her (lady) enemy was within the house. She (lady) had striven hard all the morning to make herself feel indifferent to this arrival, but had not succeeded; and was angry with herself at finding that she (lady) sat up-stairs with an anxious heart, because she (lady) knew that her (lady) cousin was in the room down-stairs. What was Lady Midlothian to her (Midlothian) that she (Midlothian) should be afraid of her (Midlothian)? And yet she (Midlothian) was very much afraid of Lady Midlothian. She (Lady) questioned herself on the subject over and over again, and found herself bound to admit that such was the fact. At last, about five o'clock, having reasoned much with herself, and rebuked herself for her (Lady) own timidity, she (Lady) descended into the drawing-room,--Lady Glencora having promised that she (Glencora) would at that hour be there,--and on opening the door became immediately conscious that she (Glencora) was in the presence of her (Glencora) august relative. There sat Lady Midlothian in a great chair opposite the fire, and Lady Glencora sat near to her (Glencora) on a stool. One of the Miss Pallisers was reading in a further part of the room, and there was no one else present in the chamber.

The Countess of Midlothian was a very little woman, between sixty and seventy years of age, who must have been very pretty in her (Countess) youth. At present she (Countess) made no pretension either to youth or beauty,--as some ladies above sixty will still do,--but sat confessedly an old woman in all her (woman) external relations. She (woman) wore a round bonnet which came much over her (woman) face,--being accustomed to continue the use of her (woman) bonnet till dinner time when once she (woman) had been forced by circumstances to put it on. She (woman) wore a short cloak which fitted close to her (woman) person, and, though she (woman) occupied a great arm-chair, sat perfectly upright, looking at the fire. Very small she (woman) was, but she (woman) carried in her (woman) grey eyes and sharp-cut features a certain look of importance which saved her (woman) from being considered as small in importance. Alice, as soon as she (Alice) saw her (Alice), knew that she (Alice) was a lady over whom no easy victory could be obtained.

``Here is Alice,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, rising as her (Glencora) cousin entered the room.
``Alice, let me introduce you to Lady Midlothian.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice, as she (Alice) came forward, was able to assume an easy demeanour, even though her (Alice) heart within was failing her (Alice). She (Alice) put out her (Alice) hand, leaving it to the elder lady to speak the first words of greeting.

``I am glad at last to be able to make your acquaintance, my dear,'' (Lady Midlothian)
said Lady Midlothian;
``very glad.'' (Lady Midlothian)
But still Alice did not speak.
``Your aunt, Lady Macleod, is one of my oldest friends, and I have heard her (Macleod) speak of you very often.'' (unknown)

``And Lady Macleod has often spoken to me of your ladyship,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Then we know each other's names,'' (the Countess)
said the Countess;
``and it will be well that we should be acquainted with each other's persons. I am becoming an old woman, and if I did not learn to know you now, or very shortly, I might never do so.'' (the Countess)

Alice could not help thinking that even under those circumstances neither might have had, so far as that was concerned, much cause of sorrow, but she (Alice) did not say so. She (Alice) was thinking altogether of Lady Midlothian's letter to her (Midlothian), and trying to calculate whether or no it would be well for her (Midlothian) to rush away at once to the subject. That Lady Midlothian would mention the letter, Alice felt well assured; and when could it be better mentioned than now, in Glencora's presence,--when no other person was near them to listen to her (Alice)?

``You are very kind,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``I would wish to be so,'' (Lady)
said Lady Midlothian.
``Blood is thicker than water, my dear; and I know no earthly ties that can bind people together if those of family connection will not do so. Your mother, when she (mother) and I were young, was my dearest friend.'' (unknown)

``I never knew my mother,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice,--feeling, however, as she (Alice) spoke, that the strength of her (Alice) resistance to the old woman was beginning to give way.

``No, my dear, you never did; and that is to my thinking another reason why they who loved her (mother) should love you. But Lady Macleod is your nearest relative,--on your mother's side, I mean,--and she (Macleod) has done her (Macleod) duty by you well.'' (unknown)

``Indeed she (Macleod) has, Lady Midlothian.'' (unknown)

``She (Lady) has, and others, therefore, have been the less called upon to interfere. I only say this, my dear, in my own vindication,--feeling, perhaps, that my conduct needs some excuse.'' (unknown)

``I'm sure Alice does not think that,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``It is what I think rather than what Alice thinks that concerns my own shortcomings,'' (Lady)
said Lady Midlothian, with a smile which was intended to be pleasant.
``But I have wished to make up for former lost opportunities.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice knew that she (Alice) was about to refer to her (Alice) letter, and trembled.
``I am very anxious now to be reckoned one of Alice Vavasor's friends, if she (Vavasor) will allow me to become so.'' (unknown)

``I can only be too proud,--if--'' (unknown)

``If what, my dear?'' (the lady)
said the old lady. I believe that she (lady) meant to be gracious, but there was something in her (lady) manner, or, perhaps, rather in her (lady) voice, so repellant, that Alice felt that they could hardly become true friends.
``If what, my dear?'' (unknown)

``Alice means--'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
began Lady Glencora.

``Let Alice say what she (Alice) means herself,'' (Lady)
said Lady Midlothian.

``I hardly know how to say what I do mean,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, whose spirit within her (Alice) was rising higher as the occasion for using it came upon her (Alice).
``I am assured that you and I, Lady Midlothian, differ very much as to a certain matter; and as it is one in which I must be guided by my own opinion, and not that of any other person, perhaps--'' (unknown)

``You mean about Mr. Grey?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice;
``I mean about Mr. Grey.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``I think so much about that matter, and your happiness as therein concerned, that when I heard that you were here I was determined to take Matching in my way to London, so that I might have an opportunity of speaking to you.'' (unknown)

``Then you knew that Alice was here,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
