``Of course I did. I suppose you have heard all the history, Glencora?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

Lady Glencora was forced to acknowledge that she (Alice) had heard the history,--

``the history'' (she)
being poor Alice's treatment of Mr. Grey.

``And what do you think of it?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Both Alice and her (Alice) hostess looked round to the further end of the room in which Miss Palliser was reading, intending thus to indicate that the lady knew as yet none of the circumstances, and that there could be no good reason why she (lady) should be instructed in them at this moment.
``Perhaps another time and another place may be better,'' (Lady Midlothian)
said Lady Midlothian;
``but I must go the day after to-morrow,--indeed, I thought of going to-morrow.'' (Lady Midlothian)

``Oh, Lady Midlothian!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
exclaimed Lady Glencora.

``You must regard this as merely a passing visit, made upon business. But, as I was saying, when shall I get an opportunity of speaking to Alice where we need not be interrupted?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

Lady Glencora suggested her (Glencora) room up-stairs, and offered the use of it then, or on that night when the world should be about to go to bed. But the idea of this premeditated lecture was terrible to Alice, and she (Alice) determined that she (Alice) would not endure it.

``Lady Midlothian, it would really be of no use.'' (unknown)

``Of no use, my dear!'' (unknown)

``No, indeed. I did get your letter, you know.'' (unknown)

``And as you have not answered it, I have come all this way to see you.'' (unknown)

``I shall be so sorry if I give offence, but it is a subject which I cannot bring myself to discuss'' (she)
--she (Alice) was going to say with a stranger, but she (Alice) was able to check herself before the offensive word was uttered,--
``which I cannot bring myself to discuss with any one.'' (she)

``But you don't mean to say that you won't see me?'' (unknown)

``I will not talk upon that matter,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``I will not do it even with Lady Macleod.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Lady)
said Lady Midlothian, and her (Lady) sharp grey eyes now began to kindle with anger;
``and therefore it is so very necessary that other friends should interfere.'' (Lady)

``But I will endure no interference,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice,
``either from persons who are friends or who are not friends.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
And as she (Alice) spoke she (Alice) rose from her (Alice) chair.
``You must forgive me, Lady Midlothian, if I say that I can have no conversation with you on this matter.'' (she)
Then she (Alice) walked out of the room, leaving the Countess and Lady Glencora together. As she (Glencora) went Miss Palliser lifted her (Palliser) eyes from her (Palliser) book, and knew that there had been a quarrel, but I doubt if she (Palliser) had heard any of the words which had been spoken.

``The most self-willed young woman I ever met in my life,'' (Lady Midlothian)
said Lady Midlothian, as soon as Alice was gone.

-LSB-Illustration:

``The most self-willed young woman I ever met in my life.'' (unknown)
-RSB-

``I knew very well how it would be,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``But it is quite frightful, my dear. She (woman) has been engaged, with the consent of all her (woman) friends, to this young man.'' (unknown)

``I know all about it.'' (unknown)

``But you must think she (woman) is very wrong.'' (unknown)

``I don't quite understand her (woman), but I suppose she (woman) fears they would not be happy together.'' (unknown)

``Understand her (woman)! I should think not; nobody can understand her (woman). A young woman to become engaged to a gentleman in that way,--before all the world, as one may say;--to go to his (gentleman) house, as I am told, and talk to the servants, and give orders about the furniture and then turn round and simply say that she (woman) has changed her (woman) mind! She (woman) hasn't given the slightest reason to my knowledge.'' (Lady)
And Lady Midlothian, as she (Lady) insisted on the absolute iniquity of Alice's proceedings, almost startled Lady Glencora by the eagerness of her (Glencora) countenance. Lady Midlothian had been one of those who, even now not quite two years ago, had assisted in obtaining the submission of Lady Glencora herself. Lady Midlothian seemed on the present occasion to remember nothing of this, but Lady Glencora remembered it very exactly.
``I shall not give it up,'' (Lady)
continued Lady Midlothian.
``I have the greatest possible objection to her (woman) father, who contrived to connect himself with our family in a most shameful manner, without the slightest encouragement. I don't think I have spoken to him (father) since, but I shall see him (father) now and tell him (father) my opinion.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice held her (Lady) ground, and avoided all further conversation with Lady Midlothian. A message came to her (Lady) through Lady Glencora imploring her (Glencora) to give way, but she (Glencora) was quite firm.

``Good-bye to you,'' (Lady Midlothian)
Lady Midlothian said to her (Midlothian) as she (Midlothian) went.
``Even yet I hope that things may go right, and if so you will find that I can forget and forgive.'' (unknown)

``If perseverance merits success,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora to Alice,
``she (woman) ought to succeed.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
``But she (woman) won't succeed,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

CHAPTER XXVII.

The Priory Ruins.

Lady Midlothian went away on her (Lady) road to London on the Wednesday morning, and Alice was to follow her (Alice) on the next day. It was now December, and the weather was very clear and frosty, but at night there was bright moonlight. On this special night the moon would be full, and Lady Glencora had declared that she (Glencora) and Alice would go out amidst the ruins. It was no secret engagement, having been canvassed in public, and having been met with considerable discouragement by some of the party. Mr. Palliser had remarked that the night air would be very cold, and Mr. Bott had suggested all manner of evil consequences. Had Mr. Palliser alone objected, Lady Glencora might have given way, but Mr. Bott's word riveted her (Glencora) purpose.

``We are not going to be frightened,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora said.

``People do not generally walk out at night in December,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Mr. Palliser observed.

``That's just the reason why we want to do it,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``But we shall wrap ourselves up, and nobody need be afraid. Jeffrey, we shall expect you to stand sentinel at the old gate, and guard us from the ghosts.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

Jeffrey Palliser, bargaining that he (Palliser) might be allowed a cigar, promised that he (Palliser) would do as he (Palliser) was bidden.

The party at Matching Priory had by this time become very small. There were indeed no guests left, not counting those of the Palliser family, excepting Miss Vavasor, Mr. Bott, and an old lady who had been a great friend of Mr. Palliser's mother. It was past ten in the evening when Lady Glencora declared that the time had arrived for them to carry out their purpose. She (Glencora) invited the two Miss Pallisers to join her (Glencora), but they declined, urging their fear of the night air, and showing by their manner that they thought the proposition a very imprudent one. Mr. Bott offered to accompany them, but Lady Glencora declined his (Bott) attendance very stoutly.

``No, indeed, Mr. Bott; you were one of those who preached a sermon against my dissipation in the morning, and I'm not going to allow you to join it, now the time for its enjoyment has come.'' (unknown)

``My dear Lady Glencora, if I were you, indeed I wouldn't,'' (the lady)
said the old lady, looking round towards Mr. Palliser.

``My dear Mrs. Marsham, if you were me, indeed you would,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
and Lady Glencora also looked at her (Glencora) husband.

``I think it a foolish thing to do,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, sternly.

``If you forbid it, of course we won't go,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``Forbid it:--no; I shall not forbid it.'' (unknown)

``Allons donc,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

She (Glencora) and Alice were already muffled in cloaks and thick shawls, and Alice now followed her (Alice) out of the room. There was a door which opened from the billiard-room out on to the grand terrace, which ran in front of the house, and here they found Jeffrey Palliser already armed with his (Palliser) cigar. Alice, to tell the truth, would much have preferred to abandon the expedition, but she (Alice) had felt that it would be cowardly in her (Alice) to desert Lady Glencora. There had not arisen any very close intimacy between her (Glencora) and Mr. Palliser, but she (Glencora) entertained a certain feeling that Mr. Palliser trusted her (Glencora), and liked her (Glencora) to be with his (Palliser) wife. She (Glencora) would have wished to justify this supposed confidence, and was almost sure that Mr. Palliser expected her (Glencora) to do so in this instance. She (Glencora) did say a word or two to her (Glencora) cousin up-stairs, urging that perhaps her (Glencora) husband would not like it.

``Let him (I) say so plainly,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora,
``and I'll give it up instantly. But I'm not going to be lectured out of my purposes secondhand by Mr. Bott or old Mother Marsham. I understand all these people, my dear. And if you throw me over, Alice, I'll never forgive you,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora added.

After this Alice resolved that she (Glencora) would not throw her (Glencora) friend over. She (Glencora) was afraid to do so. But she (Glencora) was also becoming a little afraid of her (Glencora) friend,--afraid that she (Glencora) would be driven some day either to throw her (Glencora) over, or to say words to her (Glencora) that would be very unpalatable.

``Now, Jeffrey,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora as they walked abreast along the broad terrace towards the ruins,
``when we get under the old gateway you must let me and Alice go round the dormitory and the chapel alone. Then we'll come back by the cloisters, and we'll take another turn outside with you. The outside is the finest by this light,--only I want to show Alice something by ourselves.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``You're not afraid, I know, and if Miss Vavasor is not--'' (unknown)

``Miss Vavasor,--who, I think, would have allowed you to call her (Alice) by her (Alice) other name on such an occasion as this,--is never afraid.'' (unknown)

``Glencora, how dare you say so?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``I really think we had better go back.'' (She)

She (Alice) felt herself to be very angry with her (Alice) cousin. She (Alice) almost began to fear that she (Alice) had mistaken her (Alice), and had thought better of her (Alice) than she (Alice) had deserved. What she (Alice) had now said struck Alice as being vulgar,--as being premeditated vulgarity, and her (Alice) annoyance was excessive. Of course Mr. Palliser would think that she (Alice) was a consenting party to the proposition made to him (Palliser).

``Go back!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora.
``No, indeed. We'll go on, and leave him (you) here. Then he (you) can call nobody anything. Don't be angry with me,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said, as soon as they were out of hearing.
``The truth is this;--if you choose to have him (you) for your husband, you may.'' (unknown)

``But if I do not choose.'' (unknown)

``Then there can be no harm done, and I will tell him (you) so. But, Alice,--think of this. Whom will you meet that would suit you better? And you need not decide now. You need not say a word, but leave me to tell him (you), that if it is to be thought of at all, it cannot be thought of till he (you) meets you in London. Trust me, you will be safe with me.'' (unknown)

``You shall tell him (you) nothing of the kind,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``I believe you to be joking throughout, and I think the joke is a bad one.'' (unknown)

``No; there you wrong me. Indeed I am not joking. I know that in what I am saying I am telling you the simple truth. He (you) has said enough to me to justify me in saying so. Alice, think of it all. It would reconcile me to much, and it would be something to be the mother of the future Duke of Omnium.'' (unknown)

``To me it would be nothing,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice;
``less than nothing. I mean to say that the temptation is one so easily resisted that it acts in the other way. Don't say anything more about it, Glencora.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``If you don't wish it, I will not.'' (unknown)

``No;--I do not wish it. I don't think I ever saw moonlight so bright as this. Look at the lines of that window against the light. They are clearer than you ever see them in the day.'' (unknown)

They were now standing just within the gateway of the old cruciform chapel, having entered the transept from a ruined passage which was supposed to have connected the church with the dormitory. The church was altogether roofless, but the entire walls were standing. The small clerestory windows of the nave were perfect, and the large windows of the two transepts and of the west end were nearly so. Of the opposite window, which had formed the back of the choir, very little remained. The top of it, with all its tracery, was gone, and three broken upright mullions of uneven heights alone remained. This was all that remained of the old window, but a transom or cross-bar of stone had been added to protect the carved stone-work of the sides, and save the form of the aperture from further ruin. That this transom was modern was to be seen from the magnificent height and light grace of the workmanship in the other windows, in which the long slender mullions rose from the lower stage or foundation of the whole up into the middle tracery of the arch without protection or support, and then lost themselves among the curves, not running up into the roof or soffit, and there holding on as though unable to stand alone. Such weakness as that had not as yet shown itself in English church architecture when Matching Priory was built.

-LSB-Illustration: The Priory Ruins.-RSB-

``Is it not beautiful!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora.
``I do love it so! And there is a peculiar feeling of cold about the chill of the moon, different from any other cold. It makes you wrap yourself up tight, but it does not make your teeth chatter; and it seems to go into your senses rather than into your bones. But I suppose that's nonsense,'' (she)
she (Glencora) added, after a pause.

``Not more so than what people are supposed to talk by moonlight.'' (unknown)

``That's unkind. I'd like what I say on such an occasion to be more poetical or else more nonsensical than what other people say under the same circumstances. And now I'll tell you why I always think of you when I come here by moonlight.'' (unknown)

``But I suppose you don't often come.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I do; that is to say, I did come very often when we had the full moon in August. The weather wasn't like this, and I used to run out through the open windows and nobody knew where I was gone. I made him (I) come once, but he (I) didn't seem to care about it. I told him (I) that part of the refectory wall was falling; so he (I) looked at that, and had a mason sent the next day. If anything is out of order he (mason) has it put to rights at once. There would have been no ruins if all the Pallisers had been like him (mason).'' (unknown)

``So much the better for the world.'' (unknown)

``No;--I say no. Things may live too long. But now I'm going to tell you. Do you remember that night I brought you home from the play to Queen Anne Street?'' (unknown)

``Indeed I do,--very well.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice had occasion to remember it, for it had been in the carriage on that evening that she (Alice) had positively refused to give any aid to her (Alice) cousin in that matter relating to Burgo Fitzgerald.

``And do you remember how the moon shone then?'' (unknown)

``Yes, I think I do.'' (unknown)

``I know I do. As we came round the corner out of Cavendish Square he (mason) was standing there,--and a friend of yours was standing with him (friend).'' (unknown)

``What friend of mine?'' (unknown)

``Never mind that; it does not matter now.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean my cousin George?'' (unknown)

``Yes, I do mean your cousin; and oh, Alice! dear Alice! I don't know why I should love you, for if you had not been hardhearted that night,--stony cruel in your hard propriety, I should have gone with him (cousin) then, and all this icy coldness would have been prevented.'' (She)

She (Alice) was standing quite close to Alice, and as she (Alice) spake she (Alice) shook with shivering and wrapped her (Alice) furs closer and still closer about her (Alice).

``You are very cold,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``We had better go in.'' (unknown)

``No, I am not cold,--not in that way. I won't go in yet. Jeffrey will come to us directly. Yes;--we should have escaped that night if you would have allowed him (Jeffrey) to come into your house. Ah, well! we didn't, and there's an end of it.'' (unknown)

``But Glencora,--you cannot regret it.'' (unknown)

``Not regret it! Alice, where can your heart be? Or have you a heart? Not regret it! I would give everything I have in the world to have been true to him (Jeffrey). They told me that he (Jeffrey) would spend my money. Though he (Jeffrey) should have spent every farthing of it, I regret it; though he (Jeffrey) should have made me a beggar, I regret it. They told me that he (Jeffrey) would ill-use me, and desert me,--perhaps beat me. I do not believe it; but even though that should have been so, I regret it. It is better to have a false husband than to be a false wife.'' (unknown)

``Glencora, do not speak like that. Do not try to make me think that anything could tempt you to be false to your vows.'' (unknown)

``Tempt me to be false! Why, child, it has been all false throughout. I never loved him (husband). How can you talk in that way, when you know that I never loved him (husband)? They browbeat me and frightened me till I did as I was told;--and now;--what am I now?'' (unknown)

``You are his (husband) honest wife. Glencora, listen to me.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
And Alice took hold of her (Alice) arm.

``No,'' (she)
she (Alice) said,
``no; I am not honest. By law I am his (husband) wife; but the laws are liars! I am not his (husband) wife. I will not say the thing that I am. When I went to him (husband) at the altar, I knew that I did not love the man that was to be my husband. But him (husband),--Burgo,--I love him (husband) with all my heart and soul. I could stoop at his (husband) feet and clean his (husband) shoes for him (husband), and think it no disgrace!'' (she)

``Oh, Cora, my friend, do not say such words as those! Remember what you owe your husband and yourself, and come away.'' (unknown)

``I do know what I owe him (husband), and I will pay it him (husband). Alice, if I had a child I think I would be true to him (husband). Think! I know I would;--though I had no hour of happiness left to me in my life. But what now is the only honest thing that I can do? Why, leave him (husband);--so leave him (husband) that he (husband) may have another wife and be the father of a child. What injury shall I do him (husband) by leaving him (husband)? He (husband) does not love me; you know yourself that he (husband) does not love me.'' (unknown)

``I know that he (husband) does.'' (unknown)

``Alice, that is untrue. He (husband) does not; and you have seen clearly that it is so. It may be that he (husband) can love no woman. But another woman would give him (husband) a son, and he (husband) would be happy. I tell you that every day and every night,--every hour of every day and of every night,--I am thinking of the man I love. I have nothing else to think of. I have no occupation,--no friends,--no one to whom I care to say a word. But I am always talking to Burgo in my thoughts; and he (Burgo) listens to me. I dream that his (Burgo) arm is round me--'' (unknown)

``Oh, Glencora!'' (unknown)

``Well!--Do you begrudge me that I should tell you the truth? You have said that you would be my friend, and you must bear the burden of my friendship. And now,--this is what I want to tell you.--Immediately after Christmas, we are to go to Monkshade, and he (friend) will be there. Lady Monk is his (friend) aunt.'' (unknown)

``You must not go. No power should take you there.'' (unknown)

``That is easily said, child; but all the same I must go. I told Mr. Palliser that he (Palliser) would be there, and he (Palliser) said it did not signify. He (Palliser) actually said that it did not signify. I wonder whether he (Palliser) understands what it is for people to love each other;--whether he (Palliser) has ever thought about it.'' (unknown)

``You must tell him (Palliser) plainly that you will not go.'' (unknown)

``I did. I told him (Palliser) plainly as words could tell him (Palliser). ``Glencora,'' he (Fitzgerald) said,--and you know the way he (Fitzgerald) looks when he (Fitzgerald) means to be lord and master, and put on the very husband indeed,--``This is an annoyance which you must bear and overcome. It suits me that we should go to Monkshade, and it does not suit me that there should be any one whom you are afraid to meet.

'' Could I tell him (husband) that he (husband) would lose his (husband) wife if I did go? Could I threaten him (husband) that I would throw myself into Burgo's arms if that opportunity were given to me? You are very wise, and very prudent. What would you have had me say?'' (me)

``I would have you now tell him (Palliser) everything, rather than go to that house.'' (unknown)

``Alice, look here. I know what I am, and what I am like to become. I loathe myself, and I loathe the thing that I am thinking of. I could have clung to the outside of a man's body, to his (man) very trappings, and loved him (man) ten times better than myself!--ay, even though he (man) had ill-treated me,--if I had been allowed to choose a husband for myself. Burgo would have spent my money,--all that it would have been possible for me to give him (Burgo). But there would have been something left, and I think that by that time I could have won even him (Burgo) to care for me. But with that man--! Alice you are very wise. What am I to do?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice had no doubt as to what her (Alice) cousin should do. She (Alice) should be true to her (Alice) marriage-vow, whether that vow when made were true or false. She (Alice) should be true to it as far as truth would now carry her (Alice). And in order that she (Alice) might be true, she (Alice) should tell her (Alice) husband as much as might be necessary to induce him (husband) to spare her (Alice) the threatened visit to Monkshade. All that she (Alice) said to Lady Glencora, as they walked slowly across the chapel. But Lady Glencora was more occupied with her (Glencora) own thoughts than with her (Glencora) friend's advice.

``Here's Jeffrey!'' (she)
she (Glencora) said.
``What an unconscionable time we have kept him (Jeffrey)!'' (unknown)

``Don't mention it,'' (he)
he (friend) said.
``And I shouldn't have come to you now, only that I thought I should find you both freezing into marble.'' (unknown)

``We are not such cold-blooded creatures as that,--are we, Alice?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``And now we'll go round the outside; only we must not stay long, or we shall frighten those two delicious old duennas, Mrs. Marsham and Mr. Bott.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

These last words were said as it were in a whisper to Alice; but they were so whispered that there was no real attempt to keep them from the ears of Mr. Jeffrey Palliser. Glencora, Alice thought, should not have allowed the word duenna to have passed her (Alice) lips in speaking to any one; but, above all, she (Alice) should not have done so in the hearing of Mr. Palliser's cousin.

They walked all round the ruin, on a raised gravel-path which had been made there; and Alice, who could hardly bring herself to speak,--so full was her (Alice) mind of that which had just been said to her (Alice),--was surprised to find that Glencora could go on, in her (Glencora) usual light humour, chatting as though there were no weight within her (Glencora) to depress her (Glencora) spirits.

CHAPTER XXVIII.

Alice Leaves the Priory.

As they came in at the billiard-room door, Mr. Palliser was there to meet them.

``You must be very cold,'' (he)
he (Palliser) said to Glencora, who entered first.
``No, indeed,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora;--but her (Glencora) teeth were chattering, and her (Glencora) whole appearance gave the lie to her (Glencora) words.
``Jeffrey,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, turning to his (Palliser) cousin,
``I am angry with you. You, at least, should have known better than to have allowed her (Marsham) to remain so long.'' (cousin)
Then Mr. Palliser turned away, and walked his (Palliser) wife off, taking no notice whatsoever of Miss Vavasor.

Alice felt the slight, and understood it all. He (Palliser) had told her (Alice) plainly enough, though not in words, that he (Palliser) had trusted his (Palliser) wife with her (Alice), and that she (Alice) had betrayed the trust. She (Alice) might have brought Glencora in within five or six minutes, instead of allowing her (Glencora) to remain out there in the freezing night air for nearly three-quarters of an hour. That was the accusation which Mr. Palliser made against her (Glencora), and he (Palliser) made it with the utmost severity. He (Palliser) asked no question of her (Glencora) whether she (Glencora) were cold. He (Palliser) spoke no word to her (Glencora), nor did he (Palliser) even look at her (Glencora). She (Glencora) might get herself away to her (Glencora) bedroom as she (Glencora) pleased. Alice understood all this completely, and though she (Alice) knew that she (Alice) had not deserved such severity, she (Alice) was not inclined to resent it. There was so much in Mr. Palliser's position that was to be pitied, that Alice could not find it in her (Alice) heart to be angry with him (Palliser).

``He (Jeffrey) is provoked with us, now,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Jeffrey Palliser, standing with her (Alice) for a moment in the billiard-room, as he (Palliser) handed her (Alice) a candle.

``He (Jeffrey) is afraid that she (Marsham) will have caught cold.'' (unknown)

``Yes; and he (Jeffrey) thinks it wrong that she (Marsham) should remain out at night so long. You can easily understand, Miss Vavasor, that he (Jeffrey) has not much sympathy for romance.'' (unknown)

``I dare say he (Jeffrey) is right,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, not exactly knowing what to say, and not being able to forget what had been said about herself and Jeffrey Palliser when they first left the house.
``Romance usually means nonsense, I believe.'' (unknown)

``That is not Glencora's doctrine.'' (unknown)

``No; but she (Glencora) is younger than I am. My feet are very cold, Mr. Palliser, and I think I will go up to my room.'' (unknown)

``Good night,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Jeffrey, offering her (Alice) his (Jeffrey) hand.
``I think it so hard that you should have incurred his (Palliser) displeasure.'' (unknown)

``It will not hurt me,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, smiling.

``No;--but he (Palliser) does not forget.'' (unknown)

``Even that will not hurt me. Good night, Mr. Palliser.'' (unknown)

``As it is the last night, may I say good night, Alice? I shall be away to-morrow before you are up.'' (He)

He (Jeffrey) still held her (Alice) hand; but it had not been in his (Jeffrey) for half a minute, and she (Alice) had thought nothing of that, nor did she (Alice) draw it away even now suddenly.

``No,'' (she)
said she (Alice),
``Glencora was very wrong there,--doing an injury without meaning it to both of us. There can be no possible reason why you should call me otherwise than is customary.'' (she)

``Can there never be a reason?'' (unknown)

``No, Mr. Palliser. Good night;--and if I am not to see you to-morrow morning, good-bye.'' (unknown)

``You will certainly not see me to-morrow morning.'' (unknown)

``Good-bye. Had it not been for this folly of Glencora's, our acquaintance would have been very pleasant.'' (unknown)

``To me it has been very pleasant. Good night.'' (she)

Then she (Alice) left him (Jeffrey), and went up alone to her (Alice) own room. Whether or no other guests were still left in the drawing-room she (Alice) did not know; but she (Alice) had seen that Mr. Palliser took his (Palliser) wife up-stairs, and therefore she (Alice) considered herself right in presuming that the party was broken up for the night. Mr. Palliser,--Plantagenet Palliser, according to all rules of courtesy should have said a word to her (Alice) as he (Palliser) went; but, as I have said before, Alice was disposed to overlook his (Palliser) want of civility on this occasion. So she (Alice) went up alone to her (Alice) room, and was very glad to find herself able to get close to a good fire. She (Alice) was, in truth, very cold--cold to her (Alice) bones, in spite of what Lady Glencora had said on behalf of the moonlight. They two had been standing all but still during the greater part of the time that they had been talking, and Alice, as she (Alice) sat herself down, found that her (Alice) feet were numbed with the damp that had penetrated through her (Alice) boots. Certainly Mr. Palliser had reason to be angry that his (Palliser) wife should have remained out in the night air so long,--though perhaps not with Alice.

And then she (Alice) began to think of what had been told her (Alice); and to try to think of what, under such circumstances, it behoved her (Alice) to do. She (Alice) could not doubt that Lady Glencora had intended to declare that, if opportunity offered itself, she (Glencora) would leave her (Glencora) husband, and put herself under the protection of Mr. Fitzgerald; and Alice, moreover, had become painfully conscious that the poor deluded unreasoning creature had taught herself to think that she (Alice) might excuse herself for this sin to her (Alice) own conscience by the fact that she (Alice) was childless, and that she (Alice) might thus give to the man who had married her (Alice) an opportunity of seeking another wife who might give him (man) an heir. Alice well knew how insufficient such an excuse would be even to the wretched woman who had framed it for herself. But still it would operate,--manifestly had already operated, on her (Alice) mind, teaching her (Alice) to hope that good might come out of evil. Alice, who was perfectly clearsighted as regarded her (Alice) cousin, however much impaired her (Alice) vision might have been with reference to herself, saw nothing but absolute ruin, ruin of the worst and most intolerable description, in the plan which Lady Glencora seemed to have formed. To her (Glencora) it was black in the depths of hell; and she (Glencora) knew that to Glencora also it was black.

``I loathe myself,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Glencora had said,
``and the thing that I am thinking of.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

What was Alice to do under these circumstances? Mr. Palliser, she (Alice) was aware, had quarrelled with her (Alice); for in his (Palliser) silent way he (Palliser) had first shown that he (Palliser) had trusted her (Alice) as his (Palliser) wife's friend; and then, on this evening, he (Palliser) had shown that he (Palliser) had ceased to trust her (Alice). But she (Alice) cared little for this. If she (Alice) told him (Palliser) that she (Alice) wished to speak to him (Palliser), he (Palliser) would listen, let his (Palliser) opinion of her (Alice) be what it might; and having listened he (Palliser) would surely act in some way that would serve to save his (Palliser) wife. What Mr. Palliser might think of herself, Alice cared but little.

But then there came to her (Alice) an idea that was in every respect feminine,--that in such a matter she (Alice) had no right to betray her (Alice) friend. When one woman tells the story of her (Alice) love to another woman, the confidant always feels that she (Alice) will be a traitor if she (Alice) reveals the secret. Had Lady Glencora made Alice believe that she (Alice) meditated murder, or robbery, Alice would have had no difficulty in telling the tale, and thus preventing the crime. But now she (Alice) hesitated, feeling that she (Alice) would disgrace herself by betraying her (Alice) friend. And, after all, was it not more than probable that Glencora had no intention of carrying out a threat the very thought of which must be terrible to herself?

As she (Glencora) was thinking of all this, sitting in her (Glencora) dressing-gown close over the fire, there came a loud knock at the door, which, as she (Glencora) had turned the key, she (Glencora) was forced to answer in person. She (Glencora) opened the door, and there was Iphigenia Palliser, Jeffrey's cousin, and Mr. Palliser's cousin.

``Miss Vavasor,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said,
``I know that I am taking a great liberty, but may I come into your room for a few minutes? I so much wish to speak to you!'' (she)
Alice of course bade her (Alice) enter, and placed a chair for her (Alice) by the fire.

Alice Vavasor had made very little intimacy with either of the two Miss Pallisers. It had seemed to herself as though there had been two parties in the house, and that she (Vavasor) had belonged to the one which was headed by the wife, whereas the Miss Pallisers had been naturally attached to that of the husband. These ladies, as she (wife) had already seen, almost idolized their cousin; and though Plantagenet Palliser had till lately treated Alice with the greatest personal courtesy, there had been no intimacy of friendship between them, and consequently none between her (Alice) and his (cousin) special adherents. Nor was either of these ladies prone to sudden friendship with such a one as Alice Vavasor. A sudden friendship, with a snuffy president of a foreign learned society, with some personally unknown lady employed on female emigration, was very much in their way. But Alice had not shown herself to be useful or learned, and her (Alice) special intimacy with Lady Glencora had marked her (Glencora) out as in some sort separated from them and their ways.

``I know that I am intruding,'' (Miss Palliser)
said Miss Palliser, as though she (Palliser) were almost afraid of Alice.

``Oh dear, no,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``If I can do anything for you I shall be very happy.'' (unknown)

``You are going to-morrow, and if I did not speak to you now I should have no other opportunity. Glencora seems to be very much attached to you, and we all thought it so good a thing that she (Glencora) should have such a friend.'' (unknown)

``I hope you have not all changed your minds,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, with a faint smile, thinking as she (Alice) spoke that the
``all'' (she)
must have been specially intended to include the master of the house.

``Oh, no;--by no means. I did not mean that. My cousin, Mr. Palliser, I mean, liked you so much when you came.'' (unknown)

``And he (Palliser) does not like me quite so much now, because I went out in the moonlight with his (Palliser) wife. Isn't that it?'' (unknown)

``Well;--no, Miss Vavasor. I had not intended to mention that at all. I had not indeed. I have seen him (Palliser) certainly since you came in,--just for a minute, and he (Palliser) is vexed. But it is not about that that I would speak to you.'' (unknown)

``I saw plainly enough that he (Palliser) was angry with me.'' (unknown)

``He (Palliser) thought you would have brought her (Vavasor) in earlier.'' (unknown)

``And why should he (Palliser) think that I can manage his (Palliser) wife? She (wife) was the mistress out there as she (wife) is in here. Mr. Palliser has been unreasonable. Not that it signifies.'' (unknown)

``I don't think he (Palliser) has been unreasonable; I don't, indeed, Miss Vavasor. He (Palliser) has certainly been vexed. Sometimes he (Palliser) has much to vex him (Palliser). You see, Glencora is very young.'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)

Mr. Bott also had declared that Lady Glencora was very young. It was probable, therefore, that that special phrase had been used in some discussion among Mr. Palliser's party as to Glencora's foibles. So thought Alice as the remembrance of the word came upon her (Alice).

``She (Glencora) is not younger than when Mr. Palliser married her (Glencora),'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice said.

``You mean that if a man marries a young wife he (Palliser) must put up with the trouble. That is a matter of course. But their ages, in truth, are very suitable. My cousin himself is not yet thirty. When I say that Glencora is young--'' (unknown)

``You mean that she (Glencora) is younger in spirit, and perhaps in conduct, than he (cousin) had expected to find her (Glencora).'' (unknown)

``But you are not to suppose that he (cousin) complains, Miss Vavasor. He (cousin) is much too proud for that.'' (unknown)

``I should hope so,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, thinking of Mr. Bott.

``I hardly know how to explain to you what I wish to say, or how far I may be justified in supposing that you will believe me to be acting solely on Glencora's behalf. I think you have some influence with her (Glencora);--and I know no one else that has any.'' (unknown)

``My friendship with her (Glencora) is not of very long date, Miss Palliser.'' (unknown)

``I know it, but still there is the fact. Am I not right in supposing--'' (unknown)

``In supposing what?'' (unknown)

``In supposing that you had heard the name of Mr. Fitzgerald as connected with Glencora's before her (Glencora) marriage with my cousin?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice paused a moment before she (Alice) answered.

``Yes, I had,'' (she)
she (Alice) then said.

``And I think you were agreed, with her (Glencora) other relations, that such a marriage would have been very dreadful.'' (unknown)

``I never spoke of the matter in the presence of any relatives of Glencora's. You must understand, Miss Palliser, that though I am her (Palliser) far-away cousin, I do not even know her (Palliser) nearest connections. I never saw Lady Midlothian till she (Lady) came here the other day.'' (unknown)

``But you advised her (Lady) to abandon Mr. Fitzgerald.'' (unknown)

``Never!'' (unknown)

``I know she (Lady) was much with you, just at that time.'' (unknown)

``I used to see her (Lady), certainly.'' (unknown)

Then there was a pause, and Miss Palliser, in truth, scarcely knew how to go on. There had been a hardness about Alice which her (Alice) visitor had not expected,--an unwillingness to speak or even to listen, which made Miss Palliser almost wish that she (Alice) were out of the room. She (Alice) had, however, mentioned Burgo Fitzgerald's name, and out of the room now she (Alice) could not go without explaining why she (Alice) had done so. But at this point Alice came suddenly to her (Alice) assistance.

``Just then she (Lady) was often with me,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, continuing her (Alice) reply;
``and there was much talk between us about Mr. Fitzgerald. What was my advice then can be of little matter; but in this we shall be both agreed, Miss Palliser, that Glencora now should certainly not be called upon to be in his (Fitzgerald) company.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``She (Glencora) has told you, then?'' (unknown)

``Yes;--she (Glencora) has told me.'' (unknown)

``That he (Fitzgerald) is to be at Lady Monk's?'' (unknown)

``She (Monk) has told me that Mr. Palliser expects her (Monk) to meet him (Palliser) at the place to which they are going when they leave the Duke's, and that she (Monk) thinks it hard that she (Monk) should be subjected to such a trial.'' (unknown)

``It should be no trial, Miss Vavasor.'' (unknown)

``How can it be otherwise? Come, Miss Palliser; if you are her (Monk) friend, be fair to her (Monk).'' (unknown)

``I am her (Monk) friend;--but I am, above everything, my cousin's friend. He (friend) has told me that she (Monk) has complained of having to meet this man. He (friend) declares that it should be nothing to her (Monk), and that the fear is an idle folly. It should be nothing to her (Monk), but still the fear may not be idle. Is there any reason,--any real reason,--why she (Monk) should not go? Miss Vavasor, I conjure you to tell me,--even though in doing so you must cast so deep reproach upon her (Monk) name! Anything will be better than utter disgrace and sin!'' (unknown)

``I conceive that I cast no reproach upon her (Monk) in saying that there is great reason why she (Monk) should not go to Monkshade.'' (unknown)

``You think there is absolute grounds for interference? I must tell him (you), you know, openly what he (you) would have to fear.'' (unknown)

``I think,--nay, Miss Palliser, I know,--that there is ample reason why you should save her (Palliser) from being taken to Monkshade, if you have the power to do so.'' (unknown)

``I can only do it, or attempt to do it, by telling him (you) just what you tell me.'' (unknown)

``Then tell him (you). You must have thought of that, I suppose, before you came to me.'' (unknown)

``Yes;--yes, Miss Vavasor. I had thought of it. No doubt I had thought of it. But I had believed all through that you would assure me that there was no danger. I believed that you would have said that she (You) was innocent.'' (unknown)

``And she (You) is innocent,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, rising from her (Alice) chair, as though she (Alice) might thus give emphasis to words which she (Alice) hardly dared to speak above a whisper.
``She (You) is innocent. Who accuses her (You) of guilt? You ask me a question on his (you) behalf--'' (unknown)

``On hers--and on his (you), Miss Vavasor.'' (unknown)

``A question which I feel myself bound to answer truly,--to answer with reference to the welfare of them both; but I will not have it said that I accuse her (You). She (You) had been attached to Mr. Fitzgerald when your cousin married her (You). He (cousin) knew that this had been the case. She (You) told him (cousin) the whole truth. In a worldly point of view her (You) marriage with Mr. Fitzgerald would probably have been very imprudent.'' (unknown)

``It would have been utterly ruinous.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps so; I say nothing about that. But as it turned out, she (You) gave up her (You) own wishes and married your cousin.'' (unknown)

``I don't know about her (You) own wishes, Miss Vavasor.'' (unknown)

``It is what she (You) did. She (You) would have married Mr. Fitzgerald, had she (You) not been hindered by the advice of those around her (You). It cannot be supposed that she (You) has forgotten him (Fitzgerald) in so short a time. There can be no guilt in her (You) remembrance.'' (unknown)

``There is guilt in loving any other than her (You) husband.'' (unknown)

``Then, Miss Palliser, it was her (You) marriage that was guilty, and not her (You) love. But all that is done and past. It should be your cousin's object to teach her (You) to forget Mr. Fitzgerald, and he (Fitzgerald) will not do that by taking her (You) to a house where that gentleman is staying.'' (unknown)

``She (You) has said so much to you herself?'' (unknown)

``I do not know that I need declare to you what she (You) has said herself. You have asked me a question, and I have answered it, and I am thankful to you for having asked it. What object can either of us have but to assist her (You) in her (You) position?'' (unknown)

``And to save him (gentleman) from dishonour. I had so hoped that this was simply a childish dread on her (You) part.'' (unknown)

``It is not so. It is no childish dread. If you have the power to prevent her (You) going to Lady Monk's, I implore you to use it. Indeed, I will ask you to promise me that you will do so.'' (unknown)

``After what you have said, I have no alternative.'' (unknown)

``Exactly. There is no alternative. Either for his (gentleman) sake or for hers, there is none.'' (companion)

Thereupon Miss Palliser got up, and wishing her (Alice) companion good night, took her (Alice) departure. Throughout the interview there had been no cordiality of feeling between them. There was no pretence of friendship, even as they were parting. They acknowledged that their objects were different. That of Alice was to save Lady Glencora from ruin. That of Miss Palliser was to save her (Palliser) cousin from disgrace,--with perhaps some further honest desire to prevent sorrow and sin. One loved Lady Glencora, and the other clearly did not love her (Glencora). But, nevertheless, Alice felt that Miss Palliser, in coming to her (Palliser), had acted well, and that to herself this coming had afforded immense relief. Some step would now be taken to prevent that meeting which she (Palliser) had so deprecated, and it would be taken without any great violation of confidence on her (Palliser) part. She (Palliser) had said nothing as to which Lady Glencora could feel herself aggrieved.

On the next morning she (Glencora) was down in the breakfast-room soon after nine, and had not been in the room many minutes before Mr. Palliser entered.

``The carriage is ordered for you at a quarter before ten,'' (he)
he (Palliser) said,
``and I have come down to give you your breakfast.'' (he)
There was a smile on his (Palliser) face as he (Palliser) spoke, and Alice could see that he (Palliser) intended to make himself pleasant.

``Will you allow me to give you yours instead?'' (she)
said she (Alice). But as it happened, no giving on either side was needed, as Alice's breakfast was brought to her (Alice) separately.

``Glencora bids me say that she (I) will be down immediately,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

Alice then made some inquiry with reference to the effects of last night's imprudence, which received only a half-pronounced reply. Mr. Palliser was willing to be gracious, but did not intend to be understood as having forgiven the offence. The Miss Pallisers then came in together, and after them Mr. Bott, closely followed by Mrs. Marsham, and all of them made inquiries after Lady Glencora, as though it was to be supposed that she (Glencora) might probably be in a perilous state after what she (Glencora) had undergone on the previous evening. Mr. Bott was particularly anxious.

``The frost was so uncommonly severe,'' (he)
said he (Bott),
``that any delicate person like Lady Glencora must have suffered in remaining out so long.'' (he)

The insinuation that Alice was not a delicate person and that, as regarded her (Alice), the severity of the frost was of no moment, was very open, and was duly appreciated. Mr. Bott was aware that his (Bott) great patron had in some sort changed his (Bott) opinion about Miss Vavasor, and he (Bott) was of course disposed to change his (Bott) own. A fortnight since Alice might have been as delicate as she (Alice) pleased in Mr. Bott's estimation.

``I hope you do not consider Lady Glencora delicate,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice to Mr. Palliser.

``She (Glencora) is not robust,'' (the husband)
said the husband.

``By no means,'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham.

``Indeed, no,'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Mr. Bott.

Alice knew that she (Alice) was being accused of being robust herself; but she (Alice) bore it in silence. Ploughboys and milkmaids are robust, and the accusation was a heavy one. Alice, however, thought that she (Alice) would not have minded it, if she (Alice) could have allowed herself to reply; but this at the moment of her (Alice) going away she (Alice) could not do.

``I think she (Glencora) is as strong as the rest of us,'' (Iphigenia)
said Iphigenia Palliser, who felt that after last night she (Alice) owed something to Miss Vavasor.

``As some of us,'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Mr. Bott, determined to persevere in his (Bott) accusation.

At this moment Lady Glencora entered, and encountered the eager inquiries of her (Glencora) two duennas. These, however, she (Glencora) quickly put aside, and made her (Glencora) way up to Alice.

``The last morning has come, then,'' (she)
she (Alice) said.

``Yes, indeed,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``Mr. Palliser must have thought that I was never going.'' (unknown)

``On the other hand,'' (he)
said he (Bott),
``I have felt much obliged to you for staying.'' (he)
But he (Bott) said it coldly; and Alice began to wish that she (Alice) had never seen Matching Priory.

``Obliged!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
exclaimed Lady Glencora.
``I can't tell you how much obliged I am. Oh, Alice, I wish you were going to stay with us!'' (unknown)

``We are leaving this in a week's time,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

``Of course we are,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``With all my heart I wish we were not. Dear Alice! I suppose we shall not meet till we are all in town.'' (unknown)

``You will let me know when you come up,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``I will send to you instantly; and, Alice, I will write to you from Gatherum,--or from Monkshade.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice could not help looking around and catching Miss Palliser's eye. Miss Palliser was standing with her (Palliser) foot on the fender, but was so placed that she (Palliser) could see Alice. She (Alice) made a slight sign with her (Alice) head, as much as to say that Lady Glencora must have no opportunity of writing from the latter place; but she (Glencora) said nothing.

Then the carriage was announced, and Mr. Palliser took Alice out on his (Palliser) arm.

``Don't come to the door, Glencora,'' (he)
he (Palliser) said.
``I especially wish you not to do so.'' (The cousins)
The two cousins then kissed each other, and Alice went away to the carriage.

``Good-bye, Miss Vavasor,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser; but he (Palliser) expressed no wish that he (Palliser) might see her (Alice) again as his (Palliser) guest at Matching Priory.

Alice, as she (Alice) was driven in solitary grandeur to the railway station, could not but wish that she (Alice) had never gone there.

CHAPTER XXIX.

Burgo Fitzgerald.

On the night before Christmas Eve two men were sitting together in George Vavasor's rooms in Cecil Street. It was past twelve o'clock, and they were both smoking; there were square bottles on the table containing spirits, with hot water and cold water in jugs, and one of the two men was using, and had been using, these materials for enjoyment. Vavasor had not been drinking, nor did it appear as though he (Cecil) intended to begin. There was a little weak brandy and water in a glass by his (Cecil) side, but there it had remained untouched for the last twenty minutes. His (Cecil) companion, however, had twice in that time replenished his (Cecil) beaker, and was now puffing out the smoke of his (Cecil) pipe with the fury of a steamer's funnel when she (Vavasor) has not yet burned the black off her (Vavasor) last instalment of fresh coals. This man was Burgo Fitzgerald. He (Fitzgerald) was as handsome as ever;--a man whom neither man nor woman could help regarding as a thing beautiful to behold;--but not the less was there in his (man) eyes and cheeks a look of haggard dissipation,--of riotous living, which had become wearisome, by its continuance, even to himself,--that told to all who saw him (man) much of the history of his (man) life. Most men who drink at nights, and are out till cockcrow doing deeds of darkness, become red in their faces, have pimpled cheeks and watery eyes, and are bloated and not comfortable to be seen. It is a kind dispensation of Providence who thus affords to such sinners a visible sign, to be seen day by day, of the injury which is being done. The first approach of a carbuncle on the nose, about the age of thirty, has stopped many a man from drinking. No one likes to have carbuncles on his (man) nose, or to appear before his (man) female friends with eyes which look as though they were swimming in grog. But to Burgo Fitzgerald Providence in her (man) anger had not afforded this protection. He (Fitzgerald) became at times pale, sallow, worn, and haggard. He (Fitzgerald) grew thin, and still thinner. At times he (Fitzgerald) had been ill to death's door. Among his (Fitzgerald) intimate friends there were those who heard him (Fitzgerald) declare frequently that his (Fitzgerald) liver had become useless to him (Fitzgerald); and that, as for gastric juices, he (Fitzgerald) had none left to him (Fitzgerald). But still his (Fitzgerald) beauty remained. The perfect form of his (Fitzgerald) almost god-like face was the same as ever, and the brightness of his (Fitzgerald) bright blue eye was never quenched.

On the present occasion he (Fitzgerald) had come to Vavasor's room with the object of asking from him (Fitzgerald) certain assistance, and perhaps also some amount of advice. But as regarded the latter article he (Fitzgerald) was, I think, in the state of most men when they seek for counsellors who shall counsel them to do evil. Advice administered in accordance with his (counsel) own views would give him (counsel) comfortable encouragement, but advice on the other side he (counsel) was prepared to disregard altogether. These two men had known each other long, and a close intimacy had existed between them in the days past, previous to Lady Glencora's engagement with Mr. Palliser. When Lady Glencora endeavoured, vainly as we know, to obtain aid from Alice Vavasor, Burgo had been instigated to believe that Alice's cousin might assist him (Burgo). Any such assistance George Vavasor would have been quite ready to give. Some pecuniary assistance he (Vavasor) had given, he (Vavasor) at that time having been in good funds. Perhaps he (Vavasor) had for a moment induced Burgo to think that he (Burgo) could obtain for the pair the use of the house in Queen Anne Street as a point at which they might meet, and from whence they might start on their journey of love. All that was over. Those hopes had been frustrated, and Lady Glencora M``Cluskie had become Lady Glencora Palliser and not Lady Glencora Fitzgerald. But now other hopes had sprung up, and Burgo was again looking to his (Burgo) friend for assistance.

``I believe she (Lady) would,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
Burgo said, as he (Burgo) lifted the glass to his (Burgo) mouth.
``It's a thing of that sort that a man can only believe,--perhaps only hope,--till he (man) has tried. I know that she (Lady) is not happy with him (man), and I have made up my mind that I will at least ask her (Lady).'' (unknown)

``But he (man) would have her (Lady) fortune all the same?'' (unknown)

``I don't know how that would be. I haven't inquired, and I don't mean to inquire. Of course I don't expect you or any one else to believe me, but her (Lady) money has no bearing on the question now. Heaven knows I want money bad enough, but I wouldn't take away another man's wife for money.'' (unknown)

``You don't mean to say you think it would be wicked. I supposed you to be above those prejudices.'' (unknown)

``It's all very well for you to chaff.'' (unknown)

``It's no chaff at all. I tell you fairly I wouldn't run away with any man's wife. I have an old-fashioned idea that when a man has got a wife he (man) ought to be allowed to keep her (wife). Public opinion, I know, is against me.'' (unknown)

``I think he (man) ran away with my wife,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo, with emphasis;
``that's the way I look at it. She (wife) was engaged to me first; and she (wife) really loved me, while she (wife) never cared for him (man).'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)

``Nevertheless, marriage is marriage, and the law is against you. But if I did go in for such a troublesome job at all, I certainly should keep an eye upon the money.'' (unknown)

``It can make no difference.'' (unknown)

``It did make a difference, I suppose, when you first thought of marrying her (wife)?'' (unknown)

``Of course it did. My people brought us together because she (wife) had a large fortune and I had none. There's no doubt in the world about that. And I'll tell you what; I believe that old harridan of an aunt of mine is willing to do the same thing now again. Of course she (aunt) doesn't say as much. She (aunt) wouldn't dare do that, but I do believe she (aunt) means it. I wonder where she (aunt) expects to go to!'' (unknown)

``That's grateful on your part.'' (unknown)

``Upon my soul I hate her (aunt). I do indeed. It isn't love for me now so much as downright malice against Palliser, because he (Palliser) baulked her (aunt) project before. She (aunt) is a wicked old woman. Some of us fellows are wicked enough--you and I for instance--'' (unknown)

``Thank you. I don't know, however, that I am qualified to run in a curricle with you.'' (unknown)

``But we are angels to such an old she-devil as that. You may believe me or not, as you like.--I dare say you won't believe me.'' (unknown)

``I'll say I do, at any rate.'' (unknown)

``The truth is, I want to get her (aunt), partly because I love her (aunt); but chiefly because I do believe in my heart that she (aunt) loves me.'' (unknown)

``It's for her (aunt) sake then! You are ready to sacrifice yourself to do her (aunt) a good turn.'' (unknown)

``As for sacrificing myself, that's done. I'm a man utterly ruined and would cut my throat to-morrow for the sake of my relations, if I cared enough about them. I know my own condition pretty well. I have made a shipwreck of everything, and have now only got to go down among the breakers.'' (unknown)

``Only you would like to take Lady Glencora with you.'' (unknown)

``No, by heavens! But sometimes, when I do think about it at all,--which I do as seldom as I can,--it seems to me that I might still become a different fellow if it were possible for me to marry her (Glencora).'' (unknown)

``Had you married her (Glencora) when she (Glencora) was free to marry any one and when her (Glencora) money was her (Glencora) own, it might have been so.'' (unknown)

``I think it would be quite as much so now. I do, indeed. If I could get her (Glencora) once, say to Italy, or perhaps to Greece, I think I could treat her (Glencora) well, and live with her (Glencora) quietly. I know that I would try.'' (unknown)

``Without the assistance of brandy and cigars.'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``And without any money.'' (unknown)

``With only a little. I know you'll laugh at me; but I make pictures to myself of a sort of life which I think would suit us, and be very different from this hideous way of living, with which I have become so sick that I loathe it.'' (unknown)

``Something like Juan and Haidée, with Planty Pall coming after you, like old Lambro.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
By the nickname of Planty Pall George Vavasor intended to designate Lady Glencora's present husband.

``He (Juan)'d get a divorce, of course, and then we should be married. I really don't think he (Juan)'d dislike it, when it was all done. They tell me he (Juan) doesn't care for her (I).'' (unknown)

``You have seen her (I) since her (I) marriage?'' (unknown)

``Yes; twice.'' (unknown)

``And have spoken to her (I)?'' (unknown)

``Once only,--so as to be able to do more than ask her (I) if she (I) were well. Once, for about two minutes, I did speak to her (I).'' (unknown)

``And what did she (I) say?'' (unknown)

``She (I) said it would be better that we should not meet. When she (I) said that, I knew that she (I) was still fond of me. I could have fallen at her (I) feet that moment, only the room was full of people. I do think that she (I) is fond of me.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Vavasor paused a few minutes.

``I dare say she (I) is fond of you,'' (he)
he (Burgo) then said;
``but whether she (I) has pluck for such a thing as this, is more than I can say. Probably she (I) has not. And if she (I) has, probably you would fail in carrying out your plan.'' (he)

``I must get a little money first,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo.

``And that's an operation which no doubt you find more difficult every day, as you grow older.'' (unknown)

``It seems to be much the same sort of thing. I went to Magruin this morning.'' (unknown)

``He (your)'s the fellow that lives out near Gray's Inn Lane?'' (unknown)

``Just beyond the Foundling Hospital. I went to him (Gray), and he (Gray) was quite civil about it. He (Gray) says I owe him (Gray) over three thousand pounds, but that doesn't seem to make any difference.'' (unknown)

``How much did you ever have from him (Gray)?'' (unknown)

``I don't recollect that I ever absolutely had any money. He (Gray) got a bill of mine from a tailor who went to smash, and he (Gray) kept on renewing that till it grew to be ever so many bills. I think he (Gray) did once let me have twenty-four pounds,--but certainly never more than that.'' (unknown)

``And he (Gray) says he (Gray)'ll give you money now? I suppose you told him (Gray) why you wanted it.'' (unknown)

``I didn't name her (Gray),--but I told him (Gray) what would make him (Gray) understand that I hoped to get off with a lady who had a lot of tin. I asked him (Gray) for two hundred and fifty. He (Gray) says he (Gray)'ll let me have one hundred and fifty on a bill at two months for five hundred,--with your name to it.'' (unknown)

``With my name to it! That's kind on his (Gray) part,--and on yours too.'' (unknown)

``Of course I can't take it up at the end of two months.'' (unknown)

``I dare say not,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor.

``But he (Gray) won't come upon you then,--nor for a year or more afterwards. I did pay you what you lent me before.'' (unknown)

``Yes, you did. I always thought that to be a special compliment on your part.'' (unknown)

``And you'll find I'll pull you through now in some way. If I don't succeed in this I shall go off the hooks altogether soon; and if I were dead my people would pay my debts then.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Before the evening was over Vavasor promised the assistance asked of him (Burgo). He (Burgo) knew that he (Burgo) was lending his (Burgo) name to a man who was utterly ruined, and putting it into the hands of another man who was absolutely without conscience in the use he (man) would make of it. He (man) knew that he (man) was creating for himself trouble, and in all probability loss, which he (man) was ill able to bear. But the thing was one which came within the pale of his (man) laws. Such assistance as that he (man) might ask of others, and had asked and received before now. It was a reckless deed on his (man) part, but then all his (man) doings were reckless. It was consonant with his (man) mode of life.

``I thought you would, old fellow,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo, as he (Burgo) got up to go away.
``Perhaps, you know, I shall pull through in this; and perhaps, after all, some part of her (I) fortune will come with her (I). If so you'll be all right.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps I may. But look here, Burgo,--don't you give that fellow up the bill till you've got the money into your fist.'' (unknown)

``You may be quite easy about that. I know their tricks. He (fellow) and I will go to the bank together, and we shall squabble there at the door about four or five odd sovereigns,--and at last I shall have to give him (fellow) up two or three. Beastly old robber! I declare I think he (robber)'s worse than I am myself.'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
Then Burgo Fitzgerald took a little more brandy and water and went away.

He (Fitzgerald) was living at this time in the house of one of his (Fitzgerald) relatives in Cavendish Square, north of Oxford Street. His (Fitzgerald) uncles and his (Fitzgerald) aunts, and all those who were his (Fitzgerald) natural friends, had clung to him (Fitzgerald) with a tenacity that was surprising; for he (Fitzgerald) had never been true to any of them, and did not even pretend to like them. His (Fitzgerald) father, with whom for many years he (Fitzgerald) had not been on speaking terms, was now dead; but he (Fitzgerald) had sisters whose husbands would still open their houses to him (Fitzgerald), either in London or in the country;--would open their houses to him (Fitzgerald), and lend him (Fitzgerald) their horses, and provide him (Fitzgerald) with every luxury which the rich enjoy,--except ready money. When the uttermost stress of pecuniary embarrassment would come upon him (Fitzgerald), they would pay something to stave off the immediate evil. And so Burgo went on. Nobody now thought of saying much to reproach him (Burgo). It was known to be waste of words, and trouble in vain. They were still fond of him (Burgo) because he (Burgo) was beautiful and never vain of his (Burgo) beauty;--because in the midst of his (Burgo) recklessness there was always about him (Burgo) a certain kindliness which made him (Burgo) pleasant to those around him (Burgo). He (Burgo) was soft and gracious with children, and would be very courteous to his (Burgo) lady cousins. They knew that as a man he (Burgo) was worthless, but nevertheless they loved him (Burgo). I think the secret of it was chiefly in this,--that he (Burgo) seemed to think so little of himself.

But now as he (Burgo) walked home in the middle of the night from Cecil Street to Cavendish Square he (Cecil) did think much of himself. Indeed such self-thoughts come naturally to all men, be their outward conduct ever so reckless. Every man to himself is the centre of the whole world;--the axle on which it all turns. All knowledge is but his (man) own perception of the things around him (man). All love, and care for others, and solicitude for the world's welfare, are but his (man) own feelings as to the world's wants and the world's merits.

He (man) had played his (man) part as a centre of all things very badly. Of that he (man) was very well aware. He (man) had sense enough to know that it should be a man's lot to earn his (man) bread after some fashion, and he (man) often told himself that never as yet had he (man) earned so much as a penny roll. He (man) had learned to comprehend that the world's progress depends on the way in which men do their duty by each other,--that the progress of one generation depends on the discharge of such duties by that which preceded it;--and he (man) knew that he (man), in his (man) generation, had done nothing to promote such progress. He (man) thoroughly despised himself,--if there might be any good in that! But on such occasions as these, when the wine he (man) had drunk was sufficient only to drive away from him (man) the numbness of despair, when he (man) was all alone with the cold night air upon his (man) face, when the stars were bright above him (man) and the world around him (man) was almost quiet, he (man) would still ask himself whether there might not yet be, even for him (man), some hope of a redemption, --some chance of a better life in store for him (man). He (man) was still young,--wanting some years of thirty. Could there be, even for him (man), some mode of extrication from his (man) misery?

We know what was the mode which now, at this moment, was suggesting itself to him (man). He (man) was proposing to himself, as the best thing that he (man) could do, to take away another man's wife and make himself happy with her (wife)! What he (man) had said to Vavasor as to disregarding Lady Glencora's money had been perfectly true. That in the event of her (Glencora) going off with him (man), some portion of her (Glencora) enormous wealth would still cling to her (Glencora), he (man) did believe. Seeing that she (Glencora) had no children he (man) could not understand where else it should all go. But he (man) thought of this as it regarded her (Glencora), not as it regarded him (man). When he (man) had before made his (man) suit to her (Glencora),--a suit which was then honourable, however disadvantageous it might have seemed to be to her (Glencora)--he (man) had made in his (man) mind certain calculations as to the good things which would result to him (man) if he (man) were successful He (man) would keep hounds, and have three or four horses every day for his (man) own riding, and he (man) would have no more interviews with Magruin, waiting in that rogue's dingy back parlour for many a weary wretched half-hour, till the rogue should be pleased to show himself. So far he (rogue) had been mercenary; but he (rogue) had learned to love the girl, and to care more for her (girl) than for her (girl) money, and when the day of disappointment came upon him (rogue),--the day on which she (girl) had told him (rogue) that all between them was to be over for ever,--he (rogue) had, for a few hours, felt the loss of his (rogue) love more than the loss of his (rogue) money.

Then he (rogue) had had no further hope. No such idea as that which now filled his (rogue) mind had then come upon him (rogue). The girl had gone from him (rogue) and married another man, and there was an end of it. But by degrees tidings had reached him (rogue) that she (girl) was not happy,--reaching him (rogue) through the mouths of people who were glad to exaggerate all that they had heard. A whole tribe of his (rogue) female relatives had been anxious to promote his (rogue) marriage with Lady Glencora M``Cluskie, declaring that, after all that was come and gone, Burgo would come forth from his (Burgo) troubles as a man of great wealth. So great was the wealth of the heiress that it might withstand even his (Burgo) propensities for spending. That whole tribe had been bitterly disappointed; and when they heard that Mr. Palliser's marriage had given him (Palliser) no child, and that Lady Glencora was unhappy,--they made their remarks in triumph rather than in sorrow. I will not say that they looked forward approvingly to such a step as that which Burgo now wished to take,--though as regarded his (Burgo) aunt, Lady Monk, he (Burgo) himself had accused her (Monk); but they whispered that such things had been done and must be expected, when marriages were made up as had been that marriage between Mr. Palliser and his (Palliser) bride.

As he (Palliser) walked on, thinking of his (Palliser) project, he (Palliser) strove hard to cheat himself into a belief that he (Palliser) would do a good thing in carrying Lady Glencora away from her (Glencora) husband. Bad as had been his (Palliser) life he (Palliser) had never before done aught so bad as that. The more fixed his (Palliser) intention became, the more thoroughly he (Palliser) came to perceive how great and grievous was the crime which he (Palliser) contemplated. To elope with another man's wife no longer appeared to him (Palliser) to be a joke at which such men as he (Palliser) might smile. But he (Palliser) tried to think that in this case there would be special circumstances which would almost justify him (Palliser), and also her (wife). They had loved each other and had sworn to love each other with constancy. There had been no change in the feelings or even in the wishes of either of them. But cold people had come between them with cold calculations, and had separated them. She (wife) had been, he (Palliser) told himself, made to marry a man she (wife) did not love. If they two loved each other truly, would it not still be better that they should come together? Would not the sin be forgiven on account of the injustice which had been done to them? Had Mr. Palliser a right to expect more from a wife who had been made to marry him (Palliser) without loving him (Palliser)? Then he (Palliser) reverted to those dreams of a life of love, in some sunny country, of which he (Palliser) had spoken to Vavasor, and he (Palliser) strove to nourish them. Vavasor had laughed at him (Palliser), talking of Juan and Haidée. But Vavasor, he (Juan) said to himself, was a hard cold man, who had no touch of romance in his (man) character. He (man) would not be laughed out of his (man) plan by such as he (man),--nor would he (man) be frightened by the threat of any Lambro who might come after him (man), whether he (man) might come in the guise of indignant uncle or injured husband.

He (man) had crossed from Regent Street through Hanover Square, and as he (man) came out by the iron gates into Oxford Street, a poor wretched girl, lightly clad in thin raiment, into whose bones the sharp freezing air was penetrating, asked him (man) for money. Would he (man) give her (girl) something to get drink, so that for a moment she (girl) might feel the warmth of her (girl) life renewed? Such midnight petitions were common enough in his (man) ears, and he (man) was passing on without thinking of her (girl). But she (girl) was urgent, and took hold of him (man).

``For love of God,'' (she)
she (girl) said,
``if it's only a penny to get a glass of gin! Feel my hand,--how cold it is.'' (she)
And she (girl) strove to put it up against his (rogue) face.

He (rogue) looked round at her (girl) and saw that she (girl) was very young,--sixteen, perhaps, at the most, and that she (girl) had once,--nay very lately,--been exquisitely pretty. There still lingered about her (girl) eyes some remains of that look of perfect innocency and pure faith which had been hers not more than twelve months since. And now, at midnight, in the middle of the streets, she (girl) was praying for a pennyworth of gin, as the only comfort she (girl) knew, or could expect!

``You are cold!'' (he)
said he (rogue), trying to speak to her (girl) cheerily.

``Cold!'' (she)
said she (girl), repeating the word, and striving to wrap herself closer in her (girl) rags, as she (girl) shivered--
``Oh God! if you knew what it was to be as cold as I am! I have nothing in the world,--not one penny,--not a hole to lie in!'' (she)

``We are alike then,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo, with a slight low laugh.
``I also have nothing. You cannot be poorer than I am.'' (unknown)

``You poor!'' (she)
she (girl) said. And then she (girl) looked up into his (Burgo) face.
``Gracious; how beautiful you are! Such as you are never poor.'' (He)

He (Burgo) laughed again,--in a different tone. He (Burgo) always laughed when any one told him (Burgo) of his (Burgo) beauty.

``I am a deal poorer than you, my girl,'' (he)
he (Burgo) said.
``You have nothing. I have thirty thousand pounds worse than nothing. But come along, and I will get you something to eat.'' (unknown)

``Will you?'' (she)
said she (girl), eagerly. Then looking up at him (Burgo) again, she (girl) exclaimed--
``Oh, you are so handsome!'' (she)

He (Burgo) took her (girl) to a public-house and gave her (girl) bread and meat and beer, and stood by her (girl) while she (girl) ate it. She (girl) was shy with him (Burgo) then, and would fain have taken it to a corner by herself, had he (Burgo) allowed her (girl). He (Burgo) perceived this, and turned his (Burgo) back to her (girl), but still spoke to her (girl) a word or two as she (girl) ate. The woman at the bar who served him (Burgo) looked at him (Burgo) wonderingly, staring into his (Burgo) face; and the pot-boy woke himself thoroughly that he (Burgo) might look at Burgo; and the waterman from the cab-stand stared at him (waterman); and women who came in for gin looked almost lovingly up into his (waterman) eyes. He (waterman) regarded them all not at all, showing no feeling of disgrace at his (waterman) position, and no desire to carry himself as a ruffler. He (waterman) quietly paid what was due when the girl had finished her (girl) meal, and then walked with her (girl) out of the shop.

``And now,'' (he)
said he (waterman),
``what must I do with you? If I give you a shilling can you get a bed?'' (he)
She (girl) told him (waterman) that she (girl) could get a bed for sixpence.
``Then keep the other sixpence for your breakfast,'' (he)
said he (waterman).
``But you must promise me that you will buy no gin to-night.'' (She)
She (girl) promised him (waterman), and then he (waterman) gave her (girl) his (waterman) hand as he (waterman) wished her (girl) good night;--his (waterman) hand, which it had been the dearest wish of Lady Glencora to call her (Glencora) own. She (Glencora) took it and pressed it to her (Glencora) lips.
``I wish I might once see you again,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said,
``because you are so good and so beautiful.'' (she)
He (waterman) laughed again cheerily, and walked on, crossing the street towards Cavendish Square. She (Glencora) stood looking at him (waterman) till he (waterman) was out of sight, and then as she (Glencora) moved away,--let us hope to the bed which his (waterman) bounty had provided, and not to a gin-shop,--she (Glencora) exclaimed to herself again and again--
``Gracious, how beautiful he (I) was!'' (she)
``He (I)'s a good un,'' (the woman)
the woman at the public-house had said as soon as he (waterman) left it;
``but, my! did you ever see a man's face handsome as that fellow's?'' (he)

-LSB-Illustration: Burgo Fitzgerald.-RSB-

Poor Burgo! All who had seen him (Fitzgerald) since life had begun with him (Fitzgerald) had loved him (Fitzgerald) and striven to cherish him (Fitzgerald). And with it all, to what a state had he (Fitzgerald) come! Poor Burgo! had his (Fitzgerald) eyes been less brightly blue, and his (Fitzgerald) face less godlike in form, it may be that things would have gone better with him (Fitzgerald). A sweeter-tempered man than he (Fitzgerald) never lived,--nor one who was of a kinder nature. At this moment he (Fitzgerald) had barely money about him (Fitzgerald) to take him (Fitzgerald) down to his (Fitzgerald) aunt's house at Monkshade, and as he (Fitzgerald) had promised to be there before Christmas Day, he (Fitzgerald) was bound to start on the next morning, before help from Mr. Magruin was possible. Nevertheless, out of his (Magruin) very narrow funds he (Magruin) had given half a crown to comfort the poor creature who had spoken to him (Magruin) in the street.

CHAPTER XXX.

Containing a Love Letter.

Vavasor, as he (Magruin) sat alone in his (Magruin) room, after Fitzgerald had left him (Fitzgerald), began to think of the days in which he (Fitzgerald) had before wished to assist his (Fitzgerald) friend in his (Fitzgerald) views with reference to Lady Glencora;--or rather he (Fitzgerald) began to think of Alice's behaviour then, and of Alice's words.
