Alice had steadfastly refused to give any aid. No less likely assistant for such a purpose could have been selected. But she (Alice) had been very earnest in declaring that it was Glencora's duty to stand by her (Glencora) promise to Burgo.

``He (fellow) is a desperate spendthrift,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Kate Vavasor had said to her (Vavasor).
``Then let her (you) teach him (fellow) to be otherwise,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice had answered.
``That might have been a good reason for refusing his (fellow) offer when he (fellow) first made it; but it can be no excuse for untruth, now that she (you) has told him (fellow) that she (you) loves him (fellow)!'' (unknown)
``If a woman,'' (she)
she (Alice) had said again,
``won't venture her (you) fortune for the man she (you) loves, her (you) love is not worth having.'' (she)
All this George Vavasor remembered now; and as he (Vavasor) remembered it he (Vavasor) asked himself whether the woman that had once loved him (Vavasor) would venture her (woman) fortune for him (Vavasor) still.

Though his (Vavasor) sister had pressed him (Vavasor) on the subject with all the vehemence that she (sister) could use, he (Vavasor) had hardly hitherto made up his (Vavasor) mind that he (Vavasor) really desired to marry Alice. There had grown upon him (Vavasor) lately certain Bohemian propensities,--a love of absolute independence in his (Vavasor) thoughts as well as actions,--which were antagonistic to marriage. He (Vavasor) was almost inclined to think that marriage was an old-fashioned custom, fitted indeed well enough for the usual dull life of the world at large,--as many men both in heathen and in Christian ages have taught themselves to think of religion,--but which was not adapted to his (Vavasor) advanced intelligence. If he (Vavasor) loved any woman he (Vavasor) loved his (Vavasor) cousin Alice. If he (Vavasor) thoroughly respected any woman he (Vavasor) respected her (Alice). But that idea of tying himself down to a household was in itself distasteful to him (Vavasor).

``It is a thing terrible to think of,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) once said to a congenial friend in these days of his (Vavasor) life,
``that a man should give permission to a priest to tie him (man) to another human being like a Siamese twin, so that all power of separate and solitary action should be taken from him (man) for ever! The beasts of the field do not treat each other so badly. They neither drink themselves drunk, nor eat themselves stupid;--nor do they bind themselves together in a union which both would have to hate.'' (a friend)
In this way George Vavasor, trying to imitate the wisdom of the brutes, had taught himself some theories of a peculiar nature. But, nevertheless, as he (Vavasor) thought of Alice Vavasor on this occasion, he (Vavasor) began to feel that if a Siamese twin were necessary for him (Vavasor), she (Vavasor) of all others was the woman to whom he (Vavasor) would wish to be so bound.

And if he (Vavasor) did it at all, he (Vavasor) must do it now. Under the joint instigation of himself and his (Vavasor) sister,--as he (Vavasor) thought, and perhaps not altogether without reason,--she (sister) had broken her (sister) engagement with Mr. Grey. That she (sister) would renew it again if left to herself, he (Grey) believed probable. And then, despite that advanced intelligence which had taught him (Grey) to regard all forms and ceremonies with the eye of a philosopher, he (Grey) had still enough of human frailty about him (Grey) to feel keenly alive to the pleasure of taking from John Grey the prize which John Grey had so nearly taken from him (Grey). If Alice could have been taught to think as he (Grey) did as to the absurdity of those indissoluble ties, that would have been better. But nothing would have been more impossible than the teaching of such a lesson to his (Grey) cousin Alice. George Vavasor was a man of courage, and dared do most things;--but he (Vavasor) would not have dared to commence the teaching of such a lesson to her (Alice).

And now, at this moment, what was his (Vavasor) outlook into life generally? He (Vavasor) had very high ambition, and a fair hope of gratifying it if he (Vavasor) could only provide that things should go well with him (Vavasor) for a year or so. He (Vavasor) was still a poor man, having been once nearly a rich man; but still so much of the result of his (man) nearly acquired riches remained to him (man), that on the strength of them he (man) might probably find his (man) way into Parliament. He (man) had paid the cost of the last attempt, and might, in a great degree, carry on this present attempt on credit. If he (man) succeeded there would be open to him (man) a mode of life, agreeable in itself, and honourable among men. But how was he (man) to bear the cost of this for the next year, or the next two years? His (man) grandfather was still alive, and would probably live over that period. If he (man) married Alice he (man) would do so with no idea of cheating her (Alice) out of her (Alice) money. She (Alice) should learn,--nay, she (Alice) had already learned from his (man) own lips,--how perilous was his (man) enterprise. But he (man) knew her (Alice) to be a woman who would boldly risk all in money, though no consideration would induce her (Alice) to stir a hair's breadth towards danger in reputation. Towards teaching her (Alice) that doctrine at which I have hinted, he (man) would not have dared to make an attempt; but he (man) felt that he (man) should have no repugnance to telling her (Alice) that he (man) wanted to spend all her (Alice) money in the first year or two of their married life!

He (man) was still in his (man) arm-chair, thinking of all this, with that small untasted modicum of brandy and water beside him (man), when he (man) heard some distant Lambeth clock strike three from over the river. Then he (man) rose from his (man) seat, and taking the candles in his (man) hand, sat himself down at a writing-desk on the other side of the room.

``I needn't send it when it's written,'' (he)
he (man) said to himself,
``and the chances are that I won't.'' (he)
Then he (man) took his (man) paper, and wrote as follows:--

DEAR ALICE,

The time was when the privilege was mine of beginning my letters to you with a warmer show of love than the above word contains,--when I might and did call you dearest; but I lost that privilege through my own folly, and since that it has been accorded to another. But you have found,--with a thorough honesty of purpose than which I know nothing greater,--that it has behoved you to withdraw that privilege also. I need hardly say that I should not have written as I now write, had you not found it expedient to do as you have done. I now once again ask you to be my wife. In spite of all that passed in those old days,--of all the selfish folly of which I was then guilty, I think you know, and at the time knew, that I ever loved you. I claim to say for myself that my love to you was true from first to last, and I claim from you belief for that statement. Indeed I do not think that you ever doubted my love.

Nevertheless, when you told me that I might no longer hope to make you my wife, I had no word of remonstrance that I could utter. You acted as any woman would act whom love had not made a fool. Then came the episode of Mr. Grey; and bitter as have been my feelings whilst that engagement lasted, I never made any attempt to come between you and the life you had chosen. In saying this I do not forget the words which I spoke last summer at Basle, when, as far as I knew, you still intended that he (Grey) should be your husband. But what I said then was nothing to that which, with much violence, I refrained from saying. Whether you remember those few words I cannot tell; but certainly you would not have remembered them,--would not even have noticed them,--had your heart been at Nethercoats.

But all this is nothing. You are now again a free woman; and once again I ask you to be my wife. We are both older than we were when we loved before, and will both be prone to think of marriage in a somewhat different light. Then personal love for each other was most in our thoughts. God forbid that it should not be much in our thoughts now! Perhaps I am deceiving myself in saying that it is not even now stronger in mine than any other consideration. But we have both reached that time of life, when it is probable that in any proposition of marriage we should think more of our adaptability to each other than we did before. For myself I know that there is much in my character and disposition to make me unfit to marry a woman of the common stamp. You know my mode of life, and what are my hopes and my chances of success. I run great risk of failing. It may be that I shall encounter ruin where I look for reputation and a career of honour. The chances are perhaps more in favour of ruin than of success. But, whatever may be the chances, I shall go on as long as any means of carrying on the fight are at my disposal. If you were my wife to-morrow I should expect to use your money, if it were needed, in struggling to obtain a seat in Parliament and a hearing there. I will hardly stoop to tell you that I do not ask you to be my wife for the sake of this aid;--but if you were to become my wife I should expect all your cooperation;--with your money, possibly, but certainly with your warmest spirit.

And now, once again, Alice,--dearest Alice, will you be my wife? I have been punished, and I have kissed the rod,--as I never kissed any other rod. You cannot accuse my love. Since the time in which I might sit with my arm round your waist, I have sat with it round no other waist. Since your lips were mine, no other lips have been dear to me. Since you were my counsellor, I have had no other counsellor,--unless it be poor Kate, whose wish that we may at length be married is second in earnestness only to my own. Nor do I think you will doubt my repentance. Such repentance indeed claims no merit, as it has been the natural result of the loss which I have suffered. Providence has hitherto been very good to me in not having made that loss irremediable by your marriage with Mr. Grey. I wish you now to consider the matter well, and to tell me whether you can pardon me and still love me. Do I flatter myself when I feel that I doubt your pardon almost more than I doubt your love?

Think of this thing in all its bearings before you answer me. I am so anxious that you should think of it that I will not expect your reply till this day week. It can hardly be your desire to go through life unmarried. I should say that it must be essential to your ambition that you should join your lot to that of some man the nature of whose aspirations would be like to your own. It is because this was not so as regarded him (man) whose suit you had accepted, that you found yourself at last obliged to part from him (man). May I not say that with us there would be no such difference? It is because I believe that in this respect we are fitted for each other, as man and woman seldom are fitted, that I once again ask you to be my wife.

This will reach you at Vavasor, where you will now be with the old squire and Kate. I have told her (Kate) nothing of my purpose in writing this letter. If it should be that your answer is such as I desire, I should use the opportunity of our re-engagement to endeavour to be reconciled to my grandfather. He (grandfather) has misunderstood me and has ill-used me. But I am ready to forgive that, if he (grandfather) will allow me to do so. In such case you and Kate would arrange that, and I would, if possible, go down to Vavasor while you are there. But I am galloping on a-head foolishly in thinking of this, and am counting up my wealth while the crockery in my basket is so very fragile. One word from you will decide whether or no I shall ever bring it into market.

If that word is to be adverse do not say anything of a meeting between me and the Squire. Under such circumstances it would be impossible. But, oh, Alice! do not let it be adverse. I think you love me. Your woman's pride towards me has been great and good and womanly; but it has had its way; and, if you love me, might now be taught to succumb.

Dear Alice, will you be my wife?

Yours, in any event, most affectionately,

GEORGE VAVASOR.

Vavasor, when he (VAVASOR) had finished his (VAVASOR) letter, went back to his (VAVASOR) seat over the fire, and there he (VAVASOR) sat with it close at his (VAVASOR) hand for nearly an hour. Once or twice he (VAVASOR) took it up with fingers almost itching to throw it into the fire. He (VAVASOR) took it up and held the corners between his (VAVASOR) forefinger and thumb, throwing forward his (VAVASOR) hand towards the flame, as though willing that the letter should escape from him (VAVASOR) and perish if chance should so decide. But chance did not so decide, and the letter was put back upon the table at his (VAVASOR) elbow. Then when the hour was nearly over he (VAVASOR) read it again.

``I'll bet two to one that she (I) gives way,'' (he)
he (VAVASOR) said to himself, as he (VAVASOR) put the sheet of paper back into the envelope.
``Women are such out-and-out fools.'' (he)
Then he (VAVASOR) took his (VAVASOR) candle, and carrying his (VAVASOR) letter with him (VAVASOR), went into his (VAVASOR) bedroom.

The next morning was the morning of Christmas Eve. At about nine o'clock a boy came into his (boy) room who was accustomed to call for orders for the day.

``Jem,'' (he)
he (boy) said to the boy,
``there's half a crown lying there on the looking-glass.'' (the boy)
Jem looked and acknowledged the presence of the half-crown.
``Is it a head or a tail, Jem?'' (the boy)
asked the boy's master. Jem scrutinized the coin, and declared that the uppermost surface showed a tail.
``Then take that letter and post it,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George Vavasor. Whereupon Jem, asking no question and thinking but little of the circumstances under which the command was given, did take the letter and did post it. In due accordance with postal regulations it reached Vavasor Hall and was delivered to Alice on the Christmas morning.

A merry Christmas did not fall to the lot of George Vavasor on the present occasion. An early Christmas-box he (Vavasor) did receive in the shape of a very hurried note from his (Vavasor) friend Burgo.

``This will be brought to you by Stickling,'' (Stickling)
the note said; but who Stickling was Vavasor did not know.
``I send the bill. Couldn't you get the money and send it me, as I don't want to go up to town again before the thing comes off? You're a trump; and will do the best you can. Don't let that rogue off for less than a hundred and twenty.--Yours, B. F.'' (Mr. Magruin/Magruin)
Vavasor, therefore, having nothing better to do, spent his (Vavasor) Christmas morning in calling on Mr. Magruin.

``Oh, Mr. Vavasor,'' (Mr. Magruin/Magruin)
said Magruin;
``really this is no morning for business!'' (Mr. Magruin/Magruin)

``Time and tide wait for no man, Mr. Magruin, and my friend wants his (friend) money to-morrow.'' (unknown)

``Oh, Mr. Vavasor,--to-morrow!'' (unknown)

``Yes, to-morrow. If time and tide won't wait, neither will love. Come, Mr. Magruin, out with your cheque-book, and don't let's have any nonsense.'' (unknown)

``But is the lady sure, Mr. Vavasor?'' (Mr. Magruin/Magruin)
asked Mr. Magruin, anxiously.

``Ladies never are sure,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor;
``hardly more sure than bills made over to money-lenders. I'm not going to wait here all day. Are you going to give him (Vavasor) the money?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``Christmas-day, Mr. Vavasor! There's no getting money in the city to-day.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

But Vavasor before he (Magruin) left did get the money from Mr. Magruin,--#122 10s.--for which an acceptance at two months for #500 was given in exchange,--and carried it off in triumph.

``Do tell him (Vavasor) to be punctual,'' (Mr. Magruin/Magruin)
said Mr. Magruin, when Vavasor took his (Magruin) leave.
``I do so like young men to be punctual. But I really think Mr. Fitzgerald is the most unpunctual young man I ever did know yet.'' (unknown)

``I think he (Fitzgerald) is,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George Vavasor, as he (Vavasor) went away.

He (Vavasor) ate his (Vavasor) Christmas dinner in absolute solitude at an eating-house near his (Vavasor) lodgings. It may be supposed that no man dares to dine at his (man) club on a Christmas Day. He (man) at any rate did not so dare;--and after dinner he (man) wandered about through the streets, wondering within his (man) mind how he (man) would endure the restraints of married life. And the same dull monotony of his (man) days was continued for a week, during which he (man) waited, not impatiently, for an answer to his (man) letter. And before the end of the week the answer came.

CHAPTER XXXI.

Among the Fells.

Alice came down to breakfast on that Christmas morning at Vavasor Hall without making any sign as to the letter she (Alice) had received. The party there consisted of her (Alice) grandfather, her (Alice) father, her (Alice) cousin Kate, and herself. They all made their Christmas salutations as is usual, and Alice received and made hers as did the others, without showing that anything had occurred to disturb her (Alice) tranquillity. Kate remarked that she (Kate) had heard that morning from Aunt Greenow, and promised to show Alice the letter after breakfast. But Alice said no word of her (Alice) own letter.

``Why didn't your aunt come here to eat her (aunt) Christmas dinner?'' (the Squire)
said the Squire.

``Perhaps, sir, because you didn't ask her (aunt),'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, standing close to her (Kate) grandfather,--for the old man was somewhat deaf.

``And why didn't you ask her (aunt);--that is, if she (aunt) stands upon asking to come to her (aunt) old home?'' (unknown)

``Nay, sir, but I couldn't do that without your bidding. We Vavasors are not always fond of meeting each other.'' (unknown)

``Hold your tongue, Kate. I know what you mean, and you should be the last to speak of it. Alice, my dear, come and sit next to me. I am much obliged to you for coming down all this way to see your old grandfather at Christmas. I am indeed. I only wish you had brought better news about your sweetheart.'' (unknown)

``She (sweetheart)'ll think better of it before long, sir,'' (father)
said her (Kate) father.

``Papa, you shouldn't say that. You would not wish me to marry against my own judgement.'' (unknown)

``I don't know much about ladies' judgements,'' (the man)
said the old man.
``It does seem to me that when a lady makes a promise she (lady) ought to keep it.'' (unknown)

``According to that,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate,
``if I were engaged to a man, and found that he (man) was a murderer, I still ought to marry him (man).'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

``But Mr. Grey is not a murderer,'' (the Squire)
said the Squire.

``Pray,--pray, don't talk about it,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``If you do I really cannot sit and hear it.'' (unknown)

``I have given over saying anything on the subject,'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
said John Vavasor, speaking as though he (Vavasor) had already expended upon it a vast amount of paternal eloquence. He (Vavasor) had, however, never said more than has been recorded in these pages. Alice during this conversation, sat with her (Alice) cousin's letter in her (Alice) pocket, and as yet had not even begun to think what should be the nature of her (Alice) reply.

The Squire of Vavasor Hall was a stout old man, with a red face and grey eyes, which looked fiercely at you, and with long grey hair, and a rough grey beard, which gave him (Squire) something of the appearance of an old lion. He (Squire) was passionate, unreasoning, and specially impatient of all opposition; but he (Squire) was affectionate, prone to forgive when asked to do so, unselfish, and hospitable. He (Squire) was, moreover, guided strictly by rules, which he (Squire) believed to be rules of right. His (Squire) grandson George had offended him (George) very deeply,--had offended him (George) and never asked his (George) pardon. He (George) was determined that such pardon should never be given, unless it were asked for with almost bended knees; but, nevertheless, this grandson should be his (grandson) heir. That was his (grandson) present intention. The right of primogeniture could not, in accordance with his (grandson) theory, be abrogated by the fact that it was, in George Vavasor's case, protected by no law. The Squire could leave Vavasor Hall to whom he (Squire) pleased, but he (Squire) could not have hoped to rest quietly in his (Squire) grave should it be found that he (Squire) had left it to any one but the eldest son of his (Squire) own eldest son. Though violent, and even stern, he (Squire) was more prone to love than to anger; and though none of those around him (Squire) dared to speak to him (Squire) of his (Squire) grandson, yet he (Squire) longed in his (Squire) heart for some opportunity of being reconciled to him (Squire).

The whole party went to church on this Christmas morning. The small parish church of Vavasor, an unpretending wooden structure, with a single bell which might be heard tinkling for a mile or two over the fells, stood all alone about half a mile from the Squire's gate. Vavasor was a parish situated on the intermediate ground between the mountains of the lake country and the plains. Its land was unproductive, ill-drained, and poor, and yet it possessed little or none of the beauty which tourists go to see. It was all amidst the fells, and very dreary. There were long skirtings of dark pines around a portion of the Squire's property, and at the back of the house there was a thick wood of firs running up to the top of what was there called the Beacon Hill. Through this there was a wild steep walk which came out upon the moorland, and from thence there was a track across the mountain to Hawes Water and Naddale, and on over many miles to the further beauties of Bowness and Windermere. They who knew the country, and whose legs were of use to them, could find some of the grandest scenery in England within reach of a walk from Vavasor Hall; but to others the place was very desolate. For myself, I can find I know not what of charm in wandering over open, unadorned moorland. It must be more in the softness of the grass to the feet, and the freshness of the air to the lungs, than in anything that meets the eye. You might walk for miles and miles to the north-east, or east, or south-east of Vavasor without meeting any object to arrest the view. The great road from Lancaster to Carlisle crossed the outskirts of the small parish about a mile from the church, and beyond that the fell seemed to be interminable. Towards the north it rose, and towards the south it fell, and it rose and fell very gradually. Here and there some slight appearance of a valley might be traced which had been formed by the action of the waters; but such breakings of ground were inconsiderable, and did not suffice to interrupt the stern sameness of the everlasting moorland.

The daily life at Vavasor was melancholy enough for such a one as the Squire's son, who regarded London as the only place on the earth's surface in which a man could live with comfort. The moors offered no charms to him (man). Nor did he (man) much appreciate the homely comforts of the Hall; for the house, though warm, was old-fashioned and small, and the Squire's cook was nearly as old as the Squire himself. John Vavasor's visits to Vavasor were always visits of duty rather than of pleasure. But it was not so with Alice. She (Alice) could be very happy there with Kate; for, like herself, Kate was a good walker and loved the mountains. Their regard for each other had grown and become strong because they had gone together o'er river and moor, and because they had together disregarded those impediments of mud and wet which frighten so many girls away from the beauties of nature.

On this Christmas Day they all went to church, the Squire being accompanied by Alice in a vehicle which in Ireland is called an inside jaunting-car, and which is perhaps the most uncomfortable kind of vehicle yet invented; while John Vavasor walked with his (Vavasor) niece. But the girls had arranged that immediately after church they would start for a walk up the Beacon Hill, across the fells, towards Hawes Water. They always dined at the Hall at the vexatious hour of five; but as their church service, with the sacrament included, would be completed soon after twelve, and as lunch was a meal which the Squire did not himself attend, they could have full four hours for their excursion. This had all been planned before Alice received her (Alice) letter; but there was nothing in that to make her (Alice) change her (Alice) mind about the walk.

``Alice, my dear,'' (the man)
said the old man to her (Alice) when they were together in the jaunting-car,
``you ought to get married.'' (the man)
The Squire was hard of hearing, and under any circumstances an inside jaunting-car is a bad place for conversation, as your teeth are nearly shaken out of your head by every movement which the horse makes. Alice therefore said nothing, but smiled faintly, in reply to her (Alice) grandfather. On returning from church he (grandfather) insisted that Alice should again accompany him (grandfather), telling her (Alice) specially that he (grandfather) desired to speak to her (Alice).
``My dear child,'' (he)
he (grandfather) said,
``I have been thinking a great deal about you, and you ought to get married.'' (he)

``Well, sir, perhaps I shall some day.'' (unknown)

``Not if you quarrel with all your suitors,'' (the man)
said the old man.
``You quarrelled with your cousin George, and now you have quarrelled with Mr. Grey. You'll never get married, my dear, if you go on in that way.'' (unknown)

``Why should I be married more than Kate?'' (unknown)

``Oh, Kate! I don't know that anybody wants to marry Kate. I wish you'd think of what I say. If you don't get married before long, perhaps you'll never get married at all. Gentlemen won't stand that kind of thing for ever.'' (The girls)

The two girls took a slice of cake each in her (Alice) hand, and started on their walk.

``We shan't be able to get to the lake,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

``No,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice;
``but we can go as far as the big stone on Swindale Fell, where we can sit down and see it.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``Do you remember the last time we sat there?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``It is nearly three years ago, and it was then that you told me that all was to be over between you and George. Do you remember what a fool I was, and how I screamed in my sorrow? I sometimes wonder at myself and my own folly. How is it that I can never get up any interest about my own belongings? And then we got soaking wet through coming home.'' (unknown)

``I remember that very well.'' (unknown)

``And how dark it was! That was in September, but we had dined early. If we go as far as Swindale we shall have it very dark coming home to-day;--but I don't mind that through the Beacon Wood, because I know my way so well. You won't be afraid of half an hour's dark?'' (unknown)

``Oh, no,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Yes; I do remember that day. Well; it's all for the best, I suppose. And now I must read you my aunt's letter.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Then, while they were still in the wood, Kate took out the letter from her (Kate) aunt and read it, while they still walked slowly up the hill. It seemed that hitherto neither of her (Kate) two suitors had brought the widow to terms. Indeed, she (Kate) continued to write of Mr. Cheesacre as though that gentleman were inconsolable for the loss of Kate, and gave her (Kate) niece much serious advice as to the expedience of returning to Norfolk, in order that she (Kate) might secure so eligible a husband.
``You must understand all the time, Alice,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, pausing as she (Kate) read the letter,
``that the dear man has never given me the slightest ground for the faintest hope, and that I know to a certainty that he (man) makes an offer to her (Alice) twice a week,--that is, on every market day. You can't enjoy half the joke if you won't bear that in mind.'' (she)
Alice promised that she (Alice) would bear it all in mind, and then Kate went on with her (Kate) reading. Poor Bellfield was working very hard at his (husband) drill, Mrs. Greenow went on to say; so hard that sometimes she (Greenow) really thought the fatigue would be too much for his (husband) strength. He (husband) would come in sometimes of an evening and just take a cup of tea;--generally on Mondays and Thursdays.
``These are not market days at Norwich,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate;
``and thus unpleasant meetings are avoided.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
``He (man) comes in,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow,
``and takes a little tea; and sometimes I think that he (man) will faint at my feet.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
``That he (man) kneels there on every occasion,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate,
``and repeats his (man) offer also twice a week, I have not the least doubt in the world.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

``And will she (man) accept him (man) at last?'' (unknown)

``Really I don't know what to think of it. Sometimes I fancy that she (man) likes the fun of the thing, but that she (man) is too wide-awake to put herself in any man's power. I have no doubt she (man) lends him (man) money, because he (man) wants it sadly and she (man) is very generous. She (man) gives him (man) money, I feel sure, but takes his (man) receipt on stamped paper for every shilling. That's her (man) character all over.'' (the writer)

The letter then went on to say that the writer had made up her (Kate) mind to remain at Norwich certainly through the winter and spring, and that she (Kate) was anxiously desirous that her (Kate) dear Kate should go back to her (Kate).

``Come and have one other look at Oileymead,'' (unknown)
said the letter,
``and then, if you make up your mind that you don't like it or him (man), I won't ask you to think of them ever again. I believe him (man) to be a very honest fellow.'' (unknown)
``Did you ever know such a woman?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate;
``with all her (woman) faults I believe she (woman) would go through fire and water to serve me. I think she (woman)'d lend me money without any stamped paper.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Then Aunt Greenow's letter was put up, and the two girls had come out upon the open fell.

It was a delicious afternoon for a winter's walk. The air was clear and cold, but not actually frosty. The ground beneath their feet was dry, and the sky, though not bright, had that appearance of enduring weather which gives no foreboding of rain. There is a special winter's light, which is very clear though devoid of all brilliancy,--through which every object strikes upon the eye with well-marked lines, and under which almost all forms of nature seem graceful to the sight if not actually beautiful. But there is a certain melancholy which ever accompanies it. It is the light of the afternoon, and gives token of the speedy coming of the early twilight. It tells of the shortness of the day, and contains even in its clearness a promise of the gloom of night. It is absolute light, but it seems to contain the darkness which is to follow it. I do not know that it is ever to be seen and felt so plainly as on the wide moorland, where the eye stretches away over miles, and sees at the world's end the faint low lines of distant clouds settling themselves upon the horizon. Such was the light of this Christmas afternoon, and both the girls had felt the effects of it before they reached the big stone on Swindale Fell, from which they intended to look down upon the loveliness of Hawes Water. As they went up through the wood there had been some laughter between them over Aunt Greenow's letter; and they had discussed almost with mirth the merits of Oileymead and Mr. Cheesacre; but as they got further on to the fell, and as the half-melancholy wildness of the place struck them, their words became less light, and after a while they almost ceased to speak.

Alice had still her (Alice) letter in her (Alice) pocket. She (Alice) had placed it there when she (Alice) came down to breakfast, and had carried it with her (Alice) since. She (Alice) had come to no resolution as yet as to her (Alice) answer to it, nor had she (Alice) resolved whether or no she (Alice) would show it to Kate. Kate had ever been regarded by her (Kate) as her (Kate) steadfast friend. In all these affairs she (Kate) had spoken openly to Kate. We know that Kate had in part betrayed her (Kate), but Alice suspected no such treason. She (Alice) had often quarrelled with Kate; but she (Kate) had quarrelled with her (Kate) not on account of any sin against the faith of their friendship. She (Kate) believed in her (Kate) cousin perfectly, though she (Kate) found herself often called upon to disagree with her (Kate) almost violently. Why should she (Kate) not show this letter to Kate, and discuss it in all its bearings before she (Kate) replied to it? This was in her (Kate) mind as she (Kate) walked silently along over the fell.

The reader will surmise from this that she (Kate) was already half inclined to give way, and to join her (Kate) lot to that of her (Kate) cousin George. Alas, yes! The reader will be right in his (reader) surmise. And yet it was not her (Kate) love for the man that prompted her (Kate) to run so terrible a risk. Had it been so, I think that it would be easier to forgive her (Kate). She (Kate) was beginning to think that love,--the love of which she (Kate) had once thought so much,--did not matter. Of what use was it, and to what had it led? What had love done for her (Kate) friend Glencora? What had love done for her (Kate)? Had she (Kate) not loved John Grey, and had she (Kate) not felt that with all her (Kate) love life with him (Grey) would have been distasteful to her (Kate)? It would have been impossible for her (Kate) to marry a man whom personally she (Kate) disliked; but she (Kate) liked her (Kate) cousin George,--well enough, as she (Kate) said to herself almost indifferently.

Upon the whole it was a grievous task to her (Kate) in these days,--this having to do something with her (Kate) life. Was it not all vain and futile? As for that girl's dream of the joys of love which she (Kate) had once dreamed,--that had gone from her (Kate) slumbers, never to return. How might she (Kate) best make herself useful,--useful in some sort that might gratify her (Kate) ambition;--that was now the question which seemed to her (Kate) to be of most importance.

Her (Kate) cousin's letter to her (Kate) had been very crafty. He (cousin) had studied the whole of her (Kate) character accurately as he (cousin) wrote it. When he (cousin) had sat down to write it he (cousin) had been indifferent to the result; but he (cousin) had written it with that care to attain success which a man uses when he (man) is anxious not to fail in an attempt. Whether or no he (man) cared to marry his (man) cousin was a point so little interesting to him (man) that chance might decide it for him (man); but when chance had decided that he (man) did wish it, it was necessary for his (man) honour that he (man) should have that for which he (man) condescended to ask.

His (man) letter to her (man) had been clever and very crafty.

``At any rate he (man) does me justice,'' (she)
she (man) said to herself, when she (man) read those words about her (man) money, and the use which he (man) proposed to make of it.
``He (man) is welcome to it all if it will help him (man) in his (man) career, whether he (man) has it as my friend or as my husband.'' (she)
Then she (man) thought of Kate's promise of her (man) little mite, and declared to herself that she (man) would not be less noble than her (man) cousin Kate. And would it not be well that she (man) should be the means of reconciling George to his (George) grandfather? George was the representative of the family,--of a family so old that no one now knew which had first taken the ancient titular name of some old Saxon landowner,--the parish, or the man. There had been in old days some worthy Vavaseurs, as Chaucer calls them, whose rank and bearing had been adopted on the moorland side. Of these things Alice thought much, and felt that it should be her (Alice) duty so to act, that future Vavasors might at any rate not be less in the world than they who had passed away. In a few years at furthest, George Vavasor must be Vavasor of Vavasor. Would it not be right that she (Alice) should help him (Vavasor) to make that position honourable?

They walked on, exchanging now and again a word or two, till the distant Cumberland mountains began to form themselves in groups of beauty before their eyes.

``There's Helvellyn at last,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``I'm always happy when I see that.'' (unknown)
``And isn't that Kidsty Pike?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
asked Alice.
``No; you don't see Kidsty yet. But you will when you get up to the bank there. That's Scaw Fell on the left;--the round distant top. I can distinguish it, though I doubt whether you can.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Then they went on again, and were soon at the bank from whence the sharp top of the mountain which Alice had named was visible.
``And now we are on Swindale, and in five minutes we shall get to the stone.'' (unknown)

In less than five minutes they were there; and then, but not till then, the beauty of the little lake, lying down below them in the quiet bosom of the hills, disclosed itself. A lake should, I think, be small, and should be seen from above, to be seen in all its glory. The distance should be such that the shadows of the mountains on its surface may just be traced, and that some faint idea of the ripple on the waters may be present to the eye. And the form of the lakes should be irregular, curving round from its base among the lower hills, deeper and still deeper into some close nook up among the mountains from which its head waters spring. It is thus that a lake should be seen, and it was thus that Hawes Water was seen by them from the flat stone on the side of Swindale Fell. The basin of the lake has formed itself into the shape of the figure of 3, and the top section of the figure lies embosomed among the very wildest of the Westmoreland mountains. Altogether it is not above three miles long, and every point of it was to be seen from the spot on which the girls sat themselves down. The water beneath was still as death, and as dark,--and looked almost as cold. But the slow clouds were passing over it, and the shades of darkness on its surface changed themselves with gradual changes. And though no movement was visible, there was ever and again in places a slight sheen upon the lake, which indicated the ripple made by the breeze.

``I'm so glad I've come here,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, seating herself.
``I cannot bear the idea of coming to Vavasor without seeing one of the lakes at least.'' (unknown)

``We'll get over to Windermere one day,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

``I don't think we shall. I don't think it possible that I should stay long. Kate, I've got a letter to show you.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
And there was that in the tone of her (Kate) voice which instantly put Kate upon her (Kate) mettle.

Kate seated herself also, and put up her (Kate) hand for the letter.

``Is it from Mr. Grey?'' (she)
she (Kate) asked.

``No,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice;
``it is not from Mr. Grey.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
And she (Alice) gave her (Alice) companion the paper. Kate before she (Kate) had touched it had seen that it was from her (Kate) brother George; and as she (Kate) opened it looked anxiously into Alice's face.
``Has he (Grey) offended you?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Kate asked.

-LSB-Illustration: Swindale Fell.-RSB-

``Read it,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice,
``and then we'll talk of it afterwards,--as we go home.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Then she (Alice) got up from the stone and walked a step or two towards the brow of the fell, and stood there looking down upon the lake, while Kate read the letter.
``Well!'' (she)
she (Kate) said, when she (Kate) returned to her (Kate) place.

``Well,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``Alice, Alice, it will, indeed, be well if you listen to him (Grey). Oh, Alice, may I hope? Alice, my own Alice, my darling, my friend! Say that it shall be so.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
And Kate knelt at her (Kate) friend's feet upon the heather, and looked up into her (Kate) face with eyes full of tears. What shall we say of a woman who could be as false as she (woman) had been, and yet could be so true?

Alice made no immediate answer, but still continued to gaze down over her (Alice) friend upon the lake.

``Alice,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
continued Kate,
``I did not think I should be made so happy this Christmas Day. You could not have the heart to bring me here and show me this letter in this way, and bid me read it so calmly, and then tell me that it is all for nothing. No; you could not do that? Alice, I am so happy. I will so love this place. I hated it before.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
And then she (Kate) put her (Kate) face down upon the boulder-stone and kissed it. Still Alice said nothing, but she (Alice) began to feel that she (Alice) had gone further than she (Alice) had intended. It was almost impossible for her (Alice) now to say that her (Alice) answer to George must be a refusal.

Then Kate again went on speaking.

``But is it not a beautiful letter? Say, Alice,--is it not a letter of which if you were his (me) brother you would feel proud if another girl had shown it to you? I do feel proud of him (me). I know that he (me) is a man with a manly heart and manly courage, who will yet do manly things. Here out on the mountain, with nobody near us, with Nature all round us, I ask you on your solemn word as a woman, do you love him (me)?'' (unknown)

``Love him (me)!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Yes;--love him (me): as a woman should love her (woman) husband. Is not your heart his (husband)? Alice, there need be no lies now. If it be so, it should be your glory to say so, here, to me, as you hold that letter in your hand.'' (unknown)

``I can have no such glory, Kate. I have ever loved my cousin; but not so passionately as you seem to think.'' (unknown)

``Then there can be no passion in you.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps not, Kate. I would sometimes hope that it is so. But come; we shall be late; and you will be cold sitting there.'' (unknown)

``I would sit here all night to be sure that your answer would be as I would have it. But, Alice, at any rate you shall tell me before I move what your answer is to be. I know you will not refuse him (I); but make me happy by saying so with your own lips.'' (unknown)

``I cannot tell you before you move, Kate.'' (unknown)

``And why not?'' (unknown)

``Because I have not as yet resolved.'' (unknown)

``Ah, that is impossible. That is quite impossible. On such a subject and under such circumstances a woman must resolve at the first moment. You had resolved, I know, before you had half read the letter;--though, perhaps, it may not suit you to say so.'' (unknown)

``You are quite mistaken. Come along and let us walk, and I will tell you all.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Then Kate arose, and they turned their back to the lake, and began to make their way homewards.
``I have not made up my mind as to what answer I will give him (You); but I have shown you his (You) letter in order that I might have some one with whom I might speak openly. I knew well how it would be, and that you would strive to hurry me into an immediate promise.'' (unknown)

``No;--no; I want nothing of the kind.'' (unknown)

``But yet I could not deny myself the comfort of your friendship.'' (unknown)

``No, Alice, I will not hurry you. I will do nothing that you do not wish. But you cannot be surprised that I should be very eager. Has it not been the longing of all my life? Have I not passed my time plotting and planning and thinking of it till I have had time to think of nothing else? Do you know what I suffered when, through George's fault, the engagement was broken off? Was it not martyrdom to me,--that horrid time in which your Crichton from Cambridgeshire was in the ascendant? Did I not suffer the tortures of purgatory while that went on;--and yet, on the whole, did I not bear them with patience? And, now, can you be surprised that I am wild with joy when I begin to see that everything will be as I wish;--for it will be as I wish, Alice. It may be that you have not resolved to accept him (Crichton). But you would have resolved to refuse him (Crichton) instantly had that been your destined answer to his (Crichton) letter.'' (the Beacon Wood Kate)
There was but little more said between them on the subject as they were passing over the fell, but when they were going down the path through the Beacon Wood, Kate again spoke:
``You will not answer him (Crichton) without speaking to me first?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

``I will, at any rate, not send my answer without telling you,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``And you will let me see it?'' (unknown)

``Nay,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice;
``I will not promise that. But if it is unfavourable I will show it you.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``Then I shall never see it,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, laughing.
``But that is quite enough for me. I by no means wish to criticise the love-sweet words in which you tell him (Crichton) that his (Crichton) offences are all forgiven. I know how sweet they will be. Oh, heavens! how I envy him (Crichton)!'' (unknown)

Then they were at home; and the old man met them at the front door, glowering at them angrily from out his (man) old leonine eyes, because the roast beef was already roasted. He (man) had his (man) great uncouth silver watch in his (man) hand, which was always a quarter of an hour too fast, and he (man) pointed at it fiercely, showing them the minute hand at ten minutes past the hour.

``But, grandpapa, you are always too fast,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

``And you are always too slow, miss,'' (the squire)
said the hungry old squire.

``Indeed, it is not five yet. Is it, Alice?'' (unknown)

``And how long are you going to be dressing?'' (unknown)

``Not ten minutes;--are we, Alice? And, grandpapa, pray don't wait.'' (unknown)

``Don't wait! That's what they always say,'' (he)
he (squire) muttered, peevishly.
``As if one would be any better waiting for them after the meat is on the table.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
But neither Kate nor Alice heard this, as they were already in their rooms.

Nothing more was said that evening between Alice and Kate about the letter; but Kate, as she (Kate) wished her (Kate) cousin good night inside her (Kate) bedroom door, spoke to her (Kate) just one word--

``Pray for him (it) to-night,'' (cousin)
she (Kate) said,
``as you pray for those you love best.'' (she)
Alice made no answer, but we may believe that she (Alice) did as she (Alice) was desired to do.

CHAPTER XXXII.

Containing an Answer to the Love Letter.

Alice had had a week allowed to her (Alice) to write her (Alice) answer; but she (Alice) sent it off before the full week was past.

``Why should I keep him (it) in suspense?'' (she)
she (Alice) said.
``If it is to be so, there can be no good in not saying so at once.'' (she)
Then she (Alice) thought, also, that if this were to be her (Alice) destiny it might be well for Mr. Grey that all his (Grey) doubts on the matter should be dispelled. She (Alice) had treated him (Grey) badly,--very badly. She (Alice) had so injured him (Grey) that the remembrance of the injury must always be a source of misery to her (Alice); but she (Alice) owed to him (Grey) above everything to let him (Grey) know what were her (Alice) intentions as soon as they were settled. She (Alice) tried to console herself by thinking that the wound to him (Grey) would be easy to cure.
``He (it) also is not passionate,'' (she)
she (Alice) said. But in so saying she (Alice) deceived herself. He (Grey) was a man in whom Love could be very passionate;--and was, moreover, one in whom Love could hardly be renewed.

Each morning Kate asked her (Kate) whether her (Kate) answer was written; and on the third day after Christmas, just before dinner, Alice said that she (Alice) had written it, and that it was gone.

``But it isn't post-day,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate;--for the post illuminated Vavasor but three days a week.

``I have given a boy sixpence to take it to Shap,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, blushing.

``And what have you said?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
asked Kate, taking hold of the other's arm.

``I have kept my promise,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice;
``and do you keep yours by asking no further questions.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``My sister,--my own sister,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate. And then, as Alice met her (Alice) embrace, there was no longer any doubt as to the nature of the reply.

After this there was of course much close discussion between them as to what other steps should now be taken. Kate wanted her (Kate) cousin to write immediately to Mr. Grey, and was somewhat frightened when Alice declined to do so till she (Alice) had received a further letter from George.

``You have not proposed any horrid stipulations to him (boy)?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
exclaimed Kate.

``I don't know what you may call horrid stipulations,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, gravely.
``My conditions have not been very hard, and I do not think you would have disapproved them.'' (unknown)

``But he (boy)!--He (boy) is so impetuous! Will he (boy) disapprove them?'' (unknown)

``I have told him (boy)-- But, Kate, this is just what I did not mean to tell you.'' (unknown)

``Why should there be secrets between us?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

``There shall be none, then. I have told him (boy) that I cannot bring myself to marry him (boy) instantly;--that he (boy) must allow me twelve months to wear off, if I can in that time, much of sadness and of self-reproach which has fallen to my lot.'' (unknown)

``Twelve months, Alice?'' (unknown)

``Listen to me. I have said so. But I have told him (boy) also that if he (boy) wishes it still, I will at once tell papa and grandpapa that I hold myself as engaged to him (boy), so that he (boy) may know that I bind myself to him (boy) as far as it is possible that I should do so. And I have added something else, Kate,'' (she)
she (Kate) continued to say after a slight pause,--
``something else which I can tell you, though I could tell it to no other person. I can tell you because you would do, and will do the same. I have told him (boy) that any portion of my money is at his (boy) service which may be needed for his (boy) purposes before that twelve months is over.'' (she)

``Oh, Alice! No;--no. You shall not do that. It is too generous.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
And Kate perhaps felt at the moment that her (Kate) brother was a man to whom such an offer could hardly be made with safety.

``But I have done it. Mercury, with sixpence in his (boy) pocket, is already posting my generosity at Shap. And, to tell the truth, Kate, it is no more than fair. He (boy) has honestly told me that while the old Squire lives he (Squire) will want my money to assist him (Squire) in a career of which I do much more than approve. It has been my earnest wish to see him (Squire) in Parliament. It will now be the most earnest desire of my heart;--the one thing as to which I shall feel an intense anxiety. How then can I have the face to bid him (Squire) wait twelve months for that which is specially needed in six months' time? It would be like the workhouses which are so long in giving bread, that in the mean time the wretches starve.'' (unknown)

``But the wretch shan't starve,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``My money, small as it is, will carry him (Squire) over this bout. I have told him (Squire) that he (Squire) shall have it, and that I expect him (Squire) to spend it. Moreover, I have no doubt that Aunt Greenow would lend me what he (Squire) wants.'' (unknown)

``But I should not wish him (Squire) to borrow from Aunt Greenow. She (Greenow) would advance him (Squire) the money, as you say, upon stamped paper, and then talk of it.'' (unknown)

``He (Squire) shall have mine,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

``And who are you?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, laughing.
``You are not going to be his (Squire) wife?'' (unknown)

``He (Squire) shall not touch your money till you are his (Squire) wife,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, very seriously.
``I wish you would consent to change your mind about this stupid tedious year, and then you might do as you pleased. I have no doubt such a settlement might be made as to the property here, when my grandfather hears of it, as would make you ultimately safe.'' (unknown)

``And do you think I care to be ultimately safe, as you call it? Kate, my dear, you do not understand me.'' (unknown)

``I suppose not. And yet I thought that I had known something about you.'' (unknown)

``It is because I do not care for the safety of which you speak that I am now going to become your brother's wife. Do you suppose that I do not see that I must run much risk?'' (unknown)

``You prefer the excitement of London to the tranquillity, may I say, of Cambridgeshire.'' (unknown)

``Exactly;--and therefore I have told George that he (George) shall have my money whenever he (George) wants it.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

Kate was very persistent in her (Kate) objection to this scheme till George's answer came. His (George) answer to Alice was accompanied by a letter to his (George) sister, and after that Kate said nothing more about the money question. She (Kate) said no more then; but it must not therefore be supposed that she (Kate) was less determined than she (Kate) had been that no part of Alice's fortune should be sacrificed to her (Alice) brother's wants;--at any rate before Alice should become her (Alice) brother's wife. But her (Alice) brother's letter for the moment stopped her (Alice) mouth. It would be necessary that she (Alice) should speak to him (brother) before she (Alice) again spoke to Alice.

In what words Alice had written her (Alice) assent it will be necessary that the reader should know, in order that something may be understood of the struggle which she (Alice) made upon the occasion; but they shall be given presently, when I come to speak of George Vavasor's position as he (Vavasor) received them. George's reply was very short and apparently very frank. He (George) deprecated the delay of twelve months, and still hoped to be able to induce her (Alice) to be more lenient to him (George). He (George) advised her (Alice) to write to Mr. Grey at once,--and as regarded the Squire he (Squire) gave her (Alice) _carte blanche_ to act as she (Alice) pleased. If the Squire required any kind of apology, expression of sorrow,--and asking for pardon, or such like, he (Squire), George, would, under the circumstances as they now existed, comply with the requisition most willingly. He (George) would regard it as a simple form, made necessary by his (George) coming marriage. As to Alice's money, he (George) thanked her (Alice) heartily for her (Alice) confidence. If the nature of his (George) coming contest at Chelsea should make it necessary, he (George) would use her (Alice) offer as frankly as it had been made. Such was his (George) letter to Alice. What was contained in his (George) letter to Kate, Alice never knew.

Then came the business of telling this new love tale,--the third which poor Alice had been forced to tell her (Alice) father and grandfather;--and a grievous task it was. In this matter she (Alice) feared her (Alice) father much more than her (Alice) grandfather, and therefore she (Alice) resolved to tell her (Alice) grandfather first;--or, rather, she (Alice) determined that she (Alice) would tell the Squire, and that in the mean time Kate should talk to her (Kate) father.

``Grandpapa,'' (she)
she (Kate) said to him (father) the morning after she (Kate) had received her (Kate) cousin's second letter.--The old man was in the habit of breakfasting alone in a closet of his (man) own, which was called his (man) dressing-room, but in which he (man) kept no appurtenances for dressing, but in lieu of them a large collection of old spuds and sticks and horse's-bits. There was a broken spade here, and a hoe or two; and a small table in the corner was covered with the debris of tradesmen's bills from Penrith, and dirty scraps which he (man) was wont to call his (man) farm accounts.--
``Grandpapa,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, rushing away at once into the middle of her (Alice) subject,
``you told me the other day that you thought I ought to be--married.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``Did I, my dear? Well, yes; so I did. And so you ought;--I mean to that Mr. Grey.'' (unknown)

``That is impossible, sir.'' (unknown)

``Then what's the use of your coming and talking to me about it?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

This made Alice's task not very easy; but, nevertheless, she (Alice) persevered.

``I am come, grandpapa, to tell you of another engagement.'' (unknown)

``Another!'' (he)
said he (man). And by the tone of his (man) voice he (man) accused his (man) granddaughter of having a larger number of favoured suitors than ought to fall to the lot of any young lady. It was very hard upon her (lady), but still she (lady) went on.

``You know,'' (she)
said she (lady),
``that some years ago I was to have been married to my cousin George;'' (she)
--and then she (lady) paused.

``Well,'' (the man)
said the old man.

``And I remember you told me then that you were much pleased.'' (unknown)

``So I was. George was doing well then; or,--which is more likely,--had made us believe that he (George) was doing well. Have you made it up with him (George) again?'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir.'' (unknown)

``And that's the meaning of your jilting Mr. Grey, is it?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Poor Alice! It is hard to explain how heavy a blow fell upon her (Alice) from the open utterance of that word! Of all words in the language it was the one which she (Alice) now most dreaded. She (Alice) had called herself a jilt, with that inaudible voice which one uses in making self-accusations;--but hitherto no lips had pronounced the odious word to her (Alice) ears. Poor Alice! She (Alice) was a jilt; and perhaps it may have been well that the old man should tell her (Alice) so.

``Grandpapa!'' (she)
she (Alice) said; and there was that in the tone of her (Alice) voice which somewhat softened the Squire's heart.

``Well, my dear, I don't want to be ill-natured. So you are going at last to marry George, are you? I hope he (George)'ll treat you well; that's all. Does your father approve of it?'' (unknown)

``I have told you first, sir;--because I wish to obtain your consent to seeing George again here as your grandson.'' (unknown)

``Never,'' (the man)
said the old man, snarling;--
``never!'' (the man)

``If he (George) has been wrong, he (George) will beg your pardon.'' (unknown)

``If he (George) has been wrong! Didn't he (George) want to squander every shilling of the property,--property which has never belonged to him (George);--property which I could give to Tom, Dick, or Harry to-morrow, if I liked?--If he (Harry) has been wrong!'' (unknown)

``I am not defending him (Harry), sir;--but I thought that, perhaps, on such an occasion as this--'' (unknown)

``A Tom Fool's occasion! You've got money of your own. He (Tom)'ll spend all that now.'' (unknown)

``He (Tom) will be less likely to do so if you will recognise him (Tom) as your heir. Pray believe, sir, that he (Tom) is not the sort of man that he (Tom) was.'' (unknown)

``He (Tom) must be a very clever sort of man, I think, when he (man) has talked you out of such a husband as John Grey. It's astounding to me,--with that ugly mug of his (Grey)! Well, my dear, if your father approves of it, and if George will ask my pardon,--but I don't think he (George) ever will--'' (unknown)

``He (George) will, sir. I am his (George) messenger for as much as that.'' (unknown)

``Oh, you are, are you? Then you may also be my messenger to him (George), and tell him (George) that, for your sake, I will let him (George) come back here. I know he (George)'ll insult me the first day; but I'll try and put up with it,--for your sake, my dear. Of course I must know what your father thinks about it.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

It may be imagined that Kate's success was even less than that which Alice achieved.

``I knew it would be so,'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
said John Vavasor, when his (Vavasor) niece first told him (Vavasor);--and as he (Vavasor) spoke he (Vavasor) struck his (Vavasor) hand upon the table.
``I knew all along how it would be.'' (unknown)

``And why should it not be so, Uncle John?'' (unknown)

``He (John) is your brother, and I will not tell you why.'' (unknown)

``You think that he (John) is a spendthrift?'' (unknown)

``I think that he (John) is as unsafe a man as ever I knew to be intrusted with the happiness of any young woman. That is all.'' (unknown)

``You are hard upon him (John), uncle.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps so. Tell Alice this from me,--that as I have never yet been able to get her (Alice) to think anything of my opinion, I do not at all expect that I shall be able to induce her (Alice) to do so now. I will not even make the attempt. As my son-in-law I will not receive George Vavasor. Tell Alice that.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice was told her (Alice) father's message; but Kate in telling it felt no deep regret. She (Kate) well knew that Alice would not be turned back from her (Alice) present intention by her (Alice) father's wishes. Nor would it have been very reasonable that she (Alice) should. Her (Alice) father had for many years relieved himself from the burden of a father's cares, and now had hardly the right to claim a father's privileges.

We will now go once again to George Vavasor's room in Cecil Street, in which he (Cecil) received Alice's letter. He (Cecil) was dressing when it was first brought to him (Cecil); and when he (Cecil) recognised the handwriting he (Cecil) put it down on his (Cecil) toilet table unopened. He (Cecil) put it down, and went on brushing his (Cecil) hair, as though he (Cecil) were determined to prove to himself that he (Cecil) was indifferent as to the tidings which it might contain. He (Cecil) went on brushing his (Cecil) hair, and cleaning his (Cecil) teeth, and tying his (Cecil) cravat carefully over his (Cecil) turned-down collar, while the unopened letter lay close to his (Cecil) hand. Of course he (Cecil) was thinking of it,--of course he (Cecil) was anxious,--of course his (Cecil) eye went to it from moment to moment. But he (Cecil) carried it with him (Cecil) into the sitting-room still unopened, and so it remained until after the girl had brought him (Cecil) his (Cecil) tea and his (Cecil) toast.

``And now,'' (he)
said he (Cecil), as he (Cecil) threw himself into his (Cecil) arm-chair,
``let us see what the girl of my heart says to me.'' (he)
The girl of his (Cecil) heart said to him (Cecil) as follows:--

MY DEAR GEORGE,

I feel great difficulty in answering your letter. Could I have my own way, I should make no answer to it at present, but leave it for the next six months, so that then such answer might hereafter be made as circumstances should seem to require. This will be little flattering to you, but it is less flattering to myself. Whatever answer I may make, how can anything in this affair be flattering either to you or to me? We have been like children who have quarrelled over our game of play, till now, at the close of our little day of pleasure, we are fain to meet each other in tears, and acknowledge that we have looked for delights where no delights were to be found.

Kate, who is here, talks to me of passionate love. There is no such passion left to me;--nor, as I think, to you either. It would not now be possible that you and I should come together on such terms as that. We could not stand up together as man and wife with any hope of a happy marriage, unless we had both agreed that such happiness might be had without passionate love.

You will see from all this that I do not refuse your offer. Without passion, I have for you a warm affection, which enables me to take a livelier interest in your career than in any other of the matters which are around me. Of course, if I become your wife that interest will be still closer and dearer, and I do feel that I can take in it that concern which a wife should have in her (wife) husband's affairs.

If it suits you, I will become your wife;--but it cannot be quite at once. I have suffered much from the past conflicts of my life, and there has been very much with which I must reproach myself. I know that I have behaved badly. Sometimes I have to undergo the doubly bitter self-accusation of having behaved in a manner which the world will call unfeminine. You must understand that I have not passed through this unscathed, and I must beg you to allow me some time for a cure. A perfect cure I may never expect, but I think that in twelve months from this time I may so far have recovered my usual spirit and ease of mind as to enable me to devote myself to your happiness. Dear George, if you will accept me under such circumstances, I will be your wife, and will endeavour to do my duty by you faithfully.

I have said that even now, as your cousin, I take a lively interest in your career,--of course I mean your career as a politician,--and especially in your hopes of entering Parliament. I understand, accurately as I think, what you have said about my fortune, and I perfectly appreciate your truth and frankness. If I had nothing of my own you, in your circumstances, could not possibly take me as your wife. I know, moreover, that your need of assistance from my means is immediate rather than prospective. My money may be absolutely necessary to you within this year, during which, as I tell you most truly, I cannot bring myself to become a married woman. But my money shall be less cross-grained than myself. You will take it as frankly as I mean it when I say, that whatever you want for your political purposes shall be forthcoming at your slightest wish. Dear George, let me have the honour and glory of marrying a man who has gained a seat in the Parliament of Great Britain! Of all positions which a man may attain that, to me, is the grandest.

I shall wait for a further letter from you before I speak either to my father or to my grandfather. If you can tell me that you accede to my views, I will at once try to bring about a reconciliation between you and the Squire. I think that that will be almost easier than inducing my father to look with favour upon our marriage. But I need hardly say that should either one or the other oppose it,--or should both do so,--that would not turn me from my purpose.

I also wait for your answer to write a last line to Mr. Grey.

Your affectionate cousin,

ALICE VAVASOR.

George Vavasor when he (Vavasor) had read the letter threw it carelessly from him (Vavasor) on to the breakfast table, and began to munch his (Vavasor) toast. He (Vavasor) threw it carelessly from him (Vavasor), as though taking a certain pride in his (Vavasor) carelessness.

``Very well,'' (he)
said he (Vavasor);
``so be it. It is probably the best thing that I could do, whatever the effect may be on her (girl).'' (he)
Then he (Vavasor) took up his (Vavasor) newspaper. But before the day was over he (Vavasor) had made many plans,--plans made almost unconsciously,--as to the benefit which might accrue to him (Vavasor) from the offer which she (VAVASOR) had made of her (VAVASOR) money. And before night he (Vavasor) had written that reply to her (VAVASOR) of which we have heard the contents; and had written also to his (Vavasor) sister Kate a letter, of which Kate had kept the contents to herself.

CHAPTER XXXIII.

Monkshade.

When the first of the new year came round Lady Glencora was not keeping her (Glencora) appointment at Lady Monk's house. She (Glencora) went to Gatherum Castle, and let us hope that she (Glencora) enjoyed the magnificent Christmas hospitality of the Duke; but when the time came for moving on to Monkshade, she (Glencora) was indisposed, and Mr. Palliser went thither alone. Lady Glencora returned to Matching and remained at home, while her (Glencora) husband was away, in company with the two Miss Pallisers.

When the tidings reached Monkshade that Lady Glencora was not to be expected, Burgo Fitzgerald was already there, armed with such pecuniary assistance as George Vavasor had been able to wrench out of the hands of Mr. Magruin.

``Burgo,'' (aunt)
said his (Magruin) aunt, catching him (Magruin) one morning near his (Magruin) bedroom door as he (Magruin) was about to go down-stairs in hunting trim,
``Burgo, your old flame, Lady Glencora, is not coming here.'' (he)

``Lady Glencora not coming!'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo, betraying by his (Burgo) look and the tone of his (Burgo) voice too clearly that this change in the purpose of a married lady was to him (Burgo) of more importance than it should have been. Such betrayal, however, to Lady Monk was not perhaps matter of much moment.

``No; she (Glencora) is not coming. It can't be matter of any moment to you now.'' (unknown)

``But, by heavens, it is,'' (he)
said he (Burgo), putting his (Burgo) hand up to his (Burgo) forehead, and leaning back against the wall of the passage as though in despair.
``It is matter of moment to me. I am the most unfortunate devil that ever lived.'' (unknown)

``Fie, Burgo, fie! You must not speak in that way of a married woman. I begin to think it is better that she (woman) should not come.'' (another man)
At this moment another man booted and spurred came down the passage, upon whom Lady Monk smiled sweetly, speaking some pretty little word as he (man) passed. Burgo spoke never a word, but still stood leaning against the wall, with his (Burgo) hand to his (Burgo) forehead, showing that he (Burgo) had heard something which had moved him (Burgo) greatly.
``Come back into your room, Burgo,'' (aunt)
said his (Burgo) aunt; and they both went in at the door that was nearest to them, for Lady Monk had been on the look-out for him (Burgo), and had caught him (Burgo) as soon as he (Burgo) appeared in the passage.
``If this does annoy you, you should keep it to yourself! What will people say?'' (unknown)

``How can I help what they say?'' (unknown)

``But you would not wish to injure her (woman), I suppose? I thought it best to tell you, for fear you should show any special sign of surprise if you heard of it first in public. It is very weak in you to allow yourself to feel that sort of regard for a married woman. If you cannot constrain yourself I shall be afraid to let you meet her (woman) in Brook Street.'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)

Burgo looked for a moment into his (Burgo) aunt's face without answering her (aunt), and then turned away towards the door.

``You can do as you please about that,'' (he)
said he (Burgo);
``but you know as well as I do what I have made up my mind to do.'' (he)

``Nonsense, Burgo; I know nothing of the kind. But do you go down-stairs to breakfast, and don't look like that when you go among the people there.'' (Lady Monk)

Lady Monk was a woman now about fifty years of age, who had been a great beauty, and who was still handsome in her (Monk) advanced age. Her (Monk) figure was very good. She (Monk) was tall and of fine proportion, though by no means verging to that state of body which our excellent American friend and critic Mr. Hawthorne has described as beefy and has declared to be the general condition of English ladies of Lady Monk's age. Lady Monk was not beefy. She (Monk) was a comely, handsome, upright, dame,--one of whom, as regards her (Monk) outward appearance, England might be proud,--and of whom Sir Cosmo Monk was very proud. She (Monk) had come of the family of the Worcestershire Fitzgeralds, of whom it used to be said that there never was one who was not beautiful and worthless. Looking at Lady Monk you would hardly think that she (Monk) could be a worthless woman; but there were one or two who professed to know her (Monk), and who declared that she (Monk) was a true scion of the family to which she (Monk) belonged;--that even her (Monk) husband's ample fortune had suffered from her (Monk) extravagance, that she (Monk) had quarrelled with her (Monk) only son, and had succeeded in marrying her (Monk) daughter to the greatest fool in the peerage. She (Monk) had striven very hard to bring about a marriage between her (Monk) nephew and the great heiress, and was a woman not likely to pardon those who had foiled her (woman).

At this moment Burgo felt very certain that his (Burgo) aunt was aware of his (Burgo) purpose, and could not forgive her (aunt) for pretending to be innocent of it. In this he (Burgo) was most ungrateful, as well as unreasonable,--and very indiscreet also. Had he (Burgo) been a man who ever reflected he (Burgo) must have known that such a woman as his (Burgo) aunt could only assist him (Burgo) as long as she (woman) might be presumed to be ignorant of his (Burgo) intention. But Burgo never reflected. The Fitzgeralds never reflected till they were nearer forty than thirty, and then people began to think worse of them than they had thought before.

When Burgo reached the dining-room there were many men there, but no ladies. Sir Cosmo Monk, a fine bald-headed hale man of about sixty, was standing up at the sideboard, cutting a huge game pie. He (Monk) was a man also who did not reflect much, but who contrived to keep straight in his (Monk) course through the world without much reflection.

``Palliser is coming without her (woman),'' (he)
he (Monk) said in his (Monk) loud clear voice, thinking nothing of his (Monk) wife's nephew.
``She (woman)'s ill, she (woman) says.'' (unknown)

``I'm sorry for it,'' (man)
said one man.
``She (woman)'s a deal the better fellow of the two.'' (unknown)

``She (woman) has twice more go in her (woman) than Planty Pall,'' (unknown)
said another.

``Planty is no fool, I can tell you,'' (Cosmo/Cosmo Monk)
said Sir Cosmo, coming to the table with his (Cosmo) plate full of pie.
``We think he (fool)'s about the most rising man we have.'' (Cosmo/Cosmo Monk)
Sir Cosmo was the member for his (Cosmo) county, and was a Liberal. He (Cosmo) had once, when a much younger man, been at the Treasury, and had since always spoken of the Whig Government as though he (man) himself were in some sort a part of it.

``Burgo, do you hear that Palliser is coming without his (Palliser) wife?'' (man man)
said one man,--a very young man, who hardly knew what had been the circumstances of the case. The others, when they saw Burgo enter, had been silent on the subject of Lady Glencora.

``I have heard,--and be d--d to him (Palliser),'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo. Then there was suddenly a silence in the room, and everyone seemed to attend assiduously to his (Burgo) breakfast. It was very terrible, this clear expression of a guilty meaning with reference to the wife of another man! Burgo regarded neither his (Burgo) plate nor his (Burgo) cup, but thrusting his (Burgo) hands into his (Burgo) breeches pockets, sat back in his (Burgo) chair with the blackness as of a thunder cloud upon his (Burgo) brow.

-LSB-Illustration:

``I have heard,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo.-RSB-

``Burgo, you had better eat your breakfast,'' (Cosmo/Cosmo Monk)
said Sir Cosmo.

``I don't want any breakfast.'' (He)
He (Cosmo) took, however, a bit of toast, and crumbling it up in his (Cosmo) hand as he (Cosmo) put a morsel into his (Cosmo) mouth, went away to the sideboard and filled for himself a glass of cherry brandy.

``If you don't eat any breakfast the less of that you take the better,'' (Cosmo/Cosmo Monk)
said Sir Cosmo.

``I'm all right now,'' (he)
said he (Cosmo), and coming back to the table, went through some form of making a meal with a roll and a cup of tea.

They who were then present used afterwards to say that they should never forget that breakfast. There had been something, they declared, in the tone of Burgo's voice when he (Burgo) uttered his (Burgo) curse against Mr. Palliser, which had struck them all with dread. There had, too, they said, been a blackness in his (Burgo) face, so terrible to be seen, that it had taken from them all the power of conversation. Sir Cosmo, when he (Cosmo) had broken the ominous silence, had done so with a manifest struggle. The loud clatter of glasses with which Burgo had swallowed his (Burgo) dram, as though resolved to show that he (Burgo) was regardless who might know that he (Burgo) was drinking, added to the feeling. It may easily be understood that there was no further word spoken at that breakfast-table about Planty Pall or his (Burgo) wife.

On that day Burgo Fitzgerald startled all those who saw him (Fitzgerald) by the mad way in which he (Fitzgerald) rode. Early in the day there was no excuse for any such rashness. The hounds went from wood to wood, and men went in troops along the forest sides as they do on such occasions. But Burgo was seen to cram his (Burgo) horse at impracticable places, and to ride at gates and rails as though resolved to do himself and his (Burgo) uncle's steed a mischief. This was so apparent that some friend spoke to Sir Cosmo Monk about it.

``I can do nothing,'' (Cosmo/Cosmo Monk)
said Sir Cosmo.
``He (Palliser) is a man whom no one's words will control. Something has ruffled him (Palliser) this morning, and he (Palliser) must run his (Palliser) chance till he (Palliser) becomes quiet.'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
In the afternoon there was a good run, and Burgo again rode as hard as he (Burgo) could make his (Burgo) horse carry him (Burgo);--but then there was the usual excuse for hard riding; and such riding in a straight run is not dangerous, as it is when the circumstances of the occasion do not warrant it, But, be that as it may, Burgo went on to the end of the day without accident, and as he (Burgo) went home, assured Sir Cosmo, in a voice which was almost cheery, that his (Cosmo) mare Spinster was by far the best thing in the Monkshade stables. Indeed Spinster made quite a character that day, and was sold at the end of the season for three hundred guineas on the strength of it.
