I am, however, inclined to believe that there was nothing particular about the mare. Horses always catch the temperament of their riders, and when a man wishes to break his (man) neck, he (man) will generally find a horse willing to assist him (man) in appearance, but able to save him (man) in the performance. Burgo, at any rate, did not break his (Burgo) neck, and appeared at the dinner-table in a better humour than that which he (Burgo) had displayed in the morning.

On the day appointed Mr. Palliser reached Monkshade. He (Palliser) was, in a manner, canvassing for the support of the Liberal party, and it would not have suited him (Liberal) to show any indifference to the invitation of so influential a man as Sir Cosmo. Sir Cosmo had a little party of his (Cosmo) own in the House, consisting of four or five other respectable country gentlemen, who troubled themselves little with thinking, and who mostly had bald heads. Sir Cosmo was a man with whom it was quite necessary that such an aspirant as Mr. Palliser should stand well, and therefore Mr. Palliser came to Monkshade, although Lady Glencora was unable to accompany him (Palliser).

``We are so sorry,'' (Lady Monk)
said Lady Monk.
``We have been looking forward to having Lady Glencora with us beyond everything.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

Mr. Palliser declared that Lady Glencora herself was overwhelmed with grief in that she (Glencora) should have been debarred from making this special visit. She (Glencora) had, however, been so unwell at Gatherum, the anxious husband declared, as to make it unsafe for her (Glencora) to go again away from home.

``I hope it is nothing serious,'' (Lady Monk)
said Lady Monk, with a look of grief so well arranged that any stranger would have thought that all the Pallisers must have been very dear to her (Monk) heart. Then Mr. Palliser went on to explain that Lady Glencora had unfortunately been foolish. During one of those nights of hard frost she (Glencora) had gone out among the ruins at Matching, to show them by moonlight to a friend. The friend had thoughtlessly, foolishly, and in a manner which Mr. Palliser declared to be very reprehensible, allowed Lady Glencora to remain among the ruins till she (Glencora) had caught cold.

``How very wrong!'' (Lady Monk)
said Lady Monk with considerable emphasis.

``It was very wrong,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, speaking of poor Alice almost maliciously.
``However, she (Glencora) caught a cold which, unfortunately, has become worse at my uncle's, and so I was obliged to take her (Glencora) home.'' (Lady)

Lady Monk perceived that Mr. Palliser had in truth left his (Palliser) wife behind because he (Palliser) believed her (Lady) to be ill, and not because he (Palliser) was afraid of Burgo Fitzgerald. So accomplished a woman as Lady Monk felt no doubt that the wife's absence was caused by fear of the lover, and not by any cold caught in viewing ruins by moonlight. She (Monk) was not to be deceived in such a matter. But she (Monk) became aware that Mr. Palliser had been deceived. As she (Monk) was right in this we must go back for a moment, and say a word of things as they went on at Matching after Alice Vavasor had left that place.

Alice had told Miss Palliser that steps ought to be taken, whatever might be their cost, to save Lady Glencora from the peril of a visit to Monkshade. To this Miss Palliser had assented, and, when she (Glencora) left Alice, was determined to tell Mr. Palliser the whole story. But when the time for doing so had come, her (Glencora) courage failed her (Glencora). She (Glencora) could not find words in which to warn the husband that his (husband) wife would not be safe in the company of her (wife) old lover. The task with Lady Glencora herself, bad as that would be, might be easier, and this task she (Glencora) at last undertook,--not without success.

``Glencora,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said, when she (Glencora) found a fitting opportunity,
``you won't be angry, I hope, if I say a word to you?'' (she)

``That depends very much upon what the word is,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora. And here it must be acknowledged that Mr. Palliser's wife had not done much to ingratiate herself with Mr. Palliser's cousins;--not perhaps so much as she (wife) should have done, seeing that she (wife) found them in her (wife) husband's house. She (wife) had taught herself to think that they were hard, stiff, and too proud of bearing the name of Palliser. Perhaps some little attempt may have been made by one or both of them to teach her (wife) something, and it need hardly be said that such an attempt on the part of a husband's unmarried female relations would not be forgiven by a young bride. She (bride) had undoubtedly been ungracious, and of this Miss Palliser was well aware.

``Well,--the word shall be as little unpleasant as I can make it,'' (unknown)
said Miss Palliser, already appreciating fully the difficulty of her (Palliser) task.

``But why say anything that is unpleasant? However, if it is to be said, let us have it over at once.'' (unknown)

``You are going to Monkshade, I believe, with Plantagenet.'' (unknown)

``Well;--and what of that?'' (unknown)

``Dear Glencora, I think you had better not go. Do you not think so yourself?'' (unknown)

``Who has been talking to you?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, turning upon her (Glencora) very sharply.

``Nobody has been talking to me;--not in the sense you mean.'' (unknown)

``Plantagenet has spoken to you?'' (unknown)

``Not a word,'' (unknown)
said Miss Palliser.
``You may be sure that he (you) would not utter a word on such a subject to anyone unless it were to yourself. But, dear Glencora, you should not go there;--I mean it in all kindness and love,--I do indeed.'' (she)
Saying this she (Glencora) offered her (Glencora) hand to Glencora, and Glencora took it.

``Perhaps you do,'' (she)
said she (Glencora) in a low voice.

``Indeed I do. The world is so hard and cruel in what it says.'' (unknown)

``I do not care two straws for what the world says.'' (unknown)

``But he (you) might care.'' (unknown)

``It is not my fault. I do not want to go to Monkshade. Lady Monk was my friend once, but I do not care if I never see her (Monk) again. I did not arrange this visit. It was Plantagenet who did it.'' (unknown)

``But he (friend) will not take you there if you say you do not wish it.'' (unknown)

``I have said so, and he (friend) told me that I must go. You will hardly believe me,--but I condescended even to tell him (friend) why I thought it better to remain away. He (friend) told me, in answer, that it was a silly folly which I must live down, and that it did not become me to be afraid of any man.'' (unknown)

``Of course you are not afraid, but--'' (unknown)

``I am afraid. That is just the truth. I am afraid;--but what can I do more than I have done?'' (unknown)

This was very terrible to Miss Palliser. She (Glencora) had not thought that Lady Glencora would say so much, and she (Glencora) felt a true regret in having been made to hear words which so nearly amounted to a confession. But for this there was no help now. There were not many more words between them, and we already know the result of the conversation. Lady Glencora became so ill from the effects of her (Glencora) imprudent lingering among the ruins that she (Glencora) was unable to go to Monkshade.

Mr. Palliser remained three days at Monkshade, and cemented his (Palliser) political alliance with Sir Cosmo much in the same way as he (Palliser) had before done with the Duke of St. Bungay. There was little or nothing said about politics, and certainly not a word that could be taken as any definite party understanding between the men; but they sat at dinner together at the same table, drank a glass of wine or two out of the same decanters, and dropped a chance word now and again about the next session of Parliament. I do not know that anything more had been expected either by Mr. Palliser or by Sir Cosmo; but it seemed to be understood when Mr. Palliser went away that Sir Cosmo was of opinion that that young scion of a ducal house ought to become the future Chancellor of the Exchequer in the Whig Government.

``I can't see that there's so much in him (man),'' (member)
said one young member of Parliament to Sir Cosmo.

``I rather think that there is, all the same,'' (the baronet)
said the baronet.
``There's a good deal in him (man), I believe! I dare say he (man)'s not very bright, but I don't know that we want brightness. A bright financier is the most dangerous man in the world. We've had enough of that already. Give me sound common sense, with just enough of the gab in a man to enable him (man) to say what he (man)'s got to say! We don't want more than that nowadays.'' (Cosmo/Cosmo Monk)
From which it became evident that Sir Cosmo was satisfied with the new political candidate for high place.

Lady Monk took an occasion to introduce Mr. Palliser to Burgo Fitzgerald; with what object it is difficult to say, unless she (Monk) was anxious to make mischief between the men. Burgo scowled at him (Burgo); but Mr. Palliser did not notice the scowl, and put out his (Palliser) hand to his (Palliser) late rival most affably. Burgo was forced to take it, and as he (Burgo) did so made a little speech.

``I'm sorry that we have not the pleasure of seeing Lady Glencora with you,'' (he)
said he (Burgo).

``She (Glencora) is unfortunately indisposed,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

``I am sorry for it,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo--
``very sorry indeed.'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
Then he (Palliser) turned his (Palliser) back and walked away. The few words he (Palliser) had spoken, and the manner in which he (Palliser) had carried himself, had been such as to make all those around them notice it. Each of them knew that Lady Glencora's name should not have been in Burgo's mouth, and all felt a fear not easily to be defined that something terrible would come of it. But Mr. Palliser himself did not seem to notice anything, or to fear anything; and nothing terrible did come of it during that visit of his (Palliser) to Monkshade.

CHAPTER XXXIV.

Mr. Vavasor Speaks to His (Vavasor) Daughter.

Alice Vavasor returned to London with her (Vavasor) father, leaving Kate at Vavasor Hall with her (Vavasor) grandfather. The journey was not a pleasant one. Mr. Vavasor knew that it was his (Vavasor) duty to do something,--to take some steps with the view of preventing the marriage which his (Vavasor) daughter meditated; but he (Vavasor) did not know what that something should be, and he (Vavasor) did know that, whatever it might be, the doing of it would be thoroughly disagreeable. When they started from Vavasor he (Vavasor) had as yet hardly spoken to her (daughter) a word upon the subject.

``I cannot congratulate you,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) had simply said.
``I hope the time may come, papa, when you will,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice had answered; and that had been all.

The squire had promised that he (squire) would consent to a reconciliation with his (squire) grandson, if Alice's father would express himself satisfied with the proposed marriage. John Vavasor had certainly expressed nothing of the kind.

``I think so badly of him (papa),'' (he)
he (Vavasor) had said, speaking to the old man of George,
``that I would rather know that almost any other calamity was to befall her (Glencora), than that she (Glencora) should be united to him (papa).'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
Then the squire, with his (squire) usual obstinacy, had taken up the cudgels on behalf of his (squire) grandson; and had tried to prove that the match after all would not be so bad in its results as his (squire) son seemed to expect.
``It would do very well for the property,'' (he)
he (squire) said.
``I would settle the estate on their eldest son, so that he (son) could not touch it; and I don't see why he (son) shouldn't reform as well as another.'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
John Vavasor had then declared that George was thoroughly bad, that he (Vavasor) was an adventurer; that he (Vavasor) believed him (Vavasor) to be a ruined man, and that he (Vavasor) would never reform. The squire upon this had waxed angry, and in this way George obtained aid and assistance down at the old house, which he (George) certainly had no right to expect. When Alice wished her (Alice) grandfather good-bye the old man gave her (Alice) a message to his (man) grandson.
``You may tell him (son),'' (he)
said he (man),
``that I will never see him (son) again unless he (son) begs my pardon for his (son) personal bad conduct to me, but that if he (son) marries you, I will take care that the property is properly settled upon his (son) child and yours. I shall always be glad to see you, my dear; and for your sake, I will see him (son) if he (son) will humble himself to me.'' (he)
There was no word spoken then about her (Alice) father's consent; and Alice, when she (Alice) left Vavasor, felt that the squire was rather her (Alice) friend than her (Alice) enemy in regard to this thing which she (Alice) contemplated. That her (Alice) father was and would be an uncompromising enemy to her (Alice),--uncompromising though probably not energetical,--she (Alice) was well aware; and, therefore, the journey up to London was not comfortable.

Alice had resolved, with great pain to herself, that in this matter she (Alice) owed her (Alice) father no obedience.

``There cannot be obedience on one side,'' (she)
she (Alice) said to herself,
``without protection and support on the other.'' (she)
Now it was quite true that John Vavasor had done little in the way of supporting or protecting his (Vavasor) daughter. Early in life, before she (daughter) had resided under the same roof with him (Vavasor) in London, he (Vavasor) had, as it were, washed his (Vavasor) hands of all solicitude regarding her (daughter); and having no other ties of family, had fallen into habits of life which made it almost impossible for him (Vavasor) to live with her (daughter) as any other father would live with his (father) child. Then, when there first sprang up between them that manner of sharing the same house without any joining together of their habits of life, he (father) had excused himself to himself by saying that Alice was unlike other girls, and that she (Alice) required no protection. Her (Alice) fortune was her (Alice) own, and at her (Alice) own disposal. Her (Alice) character was such that she (Alice) showed no inclination to throw the burden of such disposal on her (Alice) father's shoulders. She (Alice) was steady, too, and given to no pursuits which made it necessary that he (father) should watch closely over her (Alice). She (Alice) was a girl, he (father) thought, who could do as well without surveillance as with it,--as well, or perhaps better. So it had come to pass that Alice had been the free mistress of her (Alice) own actions, and had been left to make the most she (Alice) could of her (Alice) own hours. It cannot be supposed that she (Alice) had eaten her (Alice) lonely dinners in Queen Anne Street night after night, week after week, month after month, without telling herself that her (Alice) father was neglecting her (Alice). She (Alice) could not perceive that he (father) spent every evening in society, but never an evening in her (Alice) society, without feeling that the tie between her (Alice) and him (father) was not the strong bond which usually binds a father to his (father) child. She (Alice) was well aware that she (Alice) had been ill-used in being thus left desolate in her (Alice) home. She (Alice) had uttered no word of complaint; but she (Alice) had learned, without being aware that she (Alice) was doing so, to entertain a firm resolve that her (Alice) father should not guide her (Alice) in her (Alice) path through life. In that affair of John Grey they had both for a time thought alike, and Mr. Vavasor had believed that his (Vavasor) theory with reference to Alice had been quite correct. She (Alice) had been left to herself, and was going to dispose of herself in a way than which nothing could be more eligible. But evil days were now coming, and Mr. Vavasor, as he (Vavasor) travelled up to London, with his (Vavasor) daughter seated opposite to him (Vavasor) in the railway carriage, felt that now, at last, he (Vavasor) must interfere. In part of the journey they had the carriage to themselves, and Mr. Vavasor thought that he (Vavasor) would begin what he (Vavasor) had to say; but he (Vavasor) put it off till others joined them, and then there was no further opportunity for such conversation as that which would be necessary between them. They reached home about eight in the evening, having dined on the road.
``She (son) will be tired to-night,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) said to himself, as he (Vavasor) went off to his (Vavasor) club,
``and I will speak to her (son) to-morrow.'' (he)
Alice specially felt his (Vavasor) going on this evening. When two persons had together the tedium of such a journey as that from Westmoreland up to London, there should be some feeling between them to bind them together while enjoying the comfort of the evening. Had he (Vavasor) stayed and sat with her (Alice) at her (Alice) tea-table, Alice would at any rate have endeavoured to be soft with him (Vavasor) in any discussion that might have been raised; but he (Vavasor) went away from her (Alice) at once, leaving her (Alice) to think alone over the perils of the life before her (Alice).
``I want to speak to you after breakfast to-morrow,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) said as he (Vavasor) went out. Alice answered that she (Alice) should be there,--as a matter of course. She (Alice) scorned to tell him (Vavasor) that she (Alice) was always there,--always alone at home. She (Alice) had never uttered a word of complaint, and she (Alice) would not begin now.

The discussion after breakfast the next day was commenced with formal and almost ceremonial preparation. The father and daughter breakfasted together, with the knowledge that the discussion was coming. It did not give to either of them a good appetite, and very little was said at table.

``Will you come up-stairs?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, when she (Alice) perceived that her (Alice) father had finished his (father) tea.

``Perhaps that will be best,'' (he)
said he (father). Then he (father) followed her (Alice) into the drawing-room in which the fire had just been lit.

``Alice,'' (he)
said he (father),
``I must speak to you about this engagement of yours.'' (he)

``Won't you sit down, papa? It does look so dreadful, your standing up over one in that way.'' (He)
He (father) had placed himself on the rug with his (father) back to the incipient fire, but now, at her (Alice) request, he (father) sat himself down opposite to her (Alice).

``I was greatly grieved when I heard of this at Vavasor.'' (unknown)

``I am sorry that you should be grieved, papa.'' (unknown)

``I was grieved. I must confess that I never could understand why you treated Mr. Grey as you have done.'' (unknown)

``Oh, papa, that's done and past. Pray let that be among the bygones.'' (unknown)

``Does he (papa) know yet of your engagement with your cousin?'' (unknown)

``He (papa) will know it by this time to-morrow.'' (unknown)

``Then I beg of you, as a great favour, to postpone your letter to him (papa).'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
To this Alice made no answer.
``I have not troubled you with many such requests, Alice. Will you tell me that this one shall be granted?'' (unknown)

``I think that I owe it to him (papa) as an imperative duty to let him (papa) know the truth.'' (unknown)

``But you may change your mind again.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice found that this was hard to bear and hard to answer; but there was a certain amount of truth in the grievous reproach conveyed in her (Alice) father's words, which made her (Alice) bow her (Alice) neck to it.
``I have no right to say that it is impossible,'' (she)
she (Alice) replied, in words that were barely audible.

``No;--exactly so,'' (father)
said her (Alice) father.
``And therefore it will be better that you should postpone any such communication.'' (unknown)

``For how long do you mean?'' (unknown)

``Till you and I shall have agreed together that he (papa) should be told.'' (unknown)

``No, papa; I will not consent to that. I consider myself bound to let him (papa) know the truth without delay. I have done him (papa) a great injury, and I must put an end to that as soon as possible.'' (unknown)

``You have done him (papa) an injury certainly, my dear;--a very great injury,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said Mr. Vavasor, going away from his (Vavasor) object about the proposed letter;
``and I believe he (papa) will feel it as such to the last day of his (papa) life, if this goes on.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

``I hope not. I believe that it will not be so. I feel sure that it will not be so.'' (unknown)

``But of course what I am thinking of now is your welfare,--not his (papa). When you simply told me that you intended to--.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice winced, for she (Alice) feared to hear from her (Alice) father that odious word which her (Alice) grandfather had used to her (Alice); and indeed the word had been on her (Alice) father's lips, but he (father) had refrained and spared her (Alice)--
``that you intended to break your engagement with Mr. Grey,'' (he)
he (father) continued,
``I said little or nothing to you. I would not ask you to marry any man, even though you had yourself promised to marry him (man). But when you tell me that you are engaged to your cousin George, the matter is very different. I do not think well of your cousin. Indeed I think anything but well of him (cousin). It is my duty to tell you that the world speaks very ill of him (cousin).'' (he)
He (father) paused, but Alice remained silent.
``When you were about to travel with him (cousin),'' (he)
he (father) continued,
``I ought perhaps to have told you the same. But I did not wish to pain you or his (cousin) sister; and, moreover, I have heard worse of him (cousin) since then,--much worse than I had heard before.'' (he)

``As you did not tell me before, I think you might spare me now,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``No, my dear; I cannot allow you to sacrifice yourself without telling you that you are doing so. If it were not for your money he (cousin) would never think of marrying you.'' (unknown)

``Of that I am well aware,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``He (cousin) has told me so himself very plainly.'' (unknown)

``And yet you will marry him (cousin)?'' (unknown)

``Certainly I will. It seems to me, papa, that there is a great deal of false feeling about this matter of money in marriage,--or rather, perhaps, a great deal of pretended feeling. Why should I be angry with a man for wishing to get that for which every man is struggling? At this point of George's career the use of money is essential to him (George). He (George) could not marry without it.'' (unknown)

``You had better then give him (George) your money without yourself,'' (father)
said her (Alice) father, speaking in irony.

``That is just what I mean to do, papa,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``What!'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said Mr. Vavasor, jumping up from his (Vavasor) seat.
``You mean to give him (papa) your money before you marry him (papa)?'' (unknown)

``Certainly I do;--if he (papa) should want it;--or, I should rather say, as much as he (papa) may want of it.'' (unknown)

``Heavens and earth!'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
exclaimed Mr. Vavasor.
``Alice, you must be mad.'' (unknown)

``To part with my money to my friend?'' (she)
said she (Alice).
``It is a kind of madness of which I need not at any rate be ashamed.'' (unknown)

``Tell me this, Alice; has he (friend) got any of it as yet?'' (unknown)

``Not a shilling. Papa, pray do not look at me like that. If I had no thought of marrying him (Papa) you would not call me mad because I lent to my cousin what money he (cousin) might need.'' (unknown)

``I should only say that so much of your fortune was thrown away, and if it were not much that would be an end of it. I would sooner see you surrender to him (cousin) the half of all you have, without any engagement to marry him (cousin), than know that he (cousin) had received a shilling from you under such a promise.'' (unknown)

``You are prejudiced against him (cousin), sir.'' (unknown)

``Was it prejudice that made you reject him (cousin) once before? Did you condemn him (cousin) then through prejudice? Had you not ascertained that he (cousin) was altogether unworthy of you?'' (unknown)

``We were both younger, then,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, speaking very softly, but very seriously.
``We were both much younger then, and looked at life with other eyes than those which we now use. For myself I expected much then, which I now seem hardly to regard at all; and as for him (cousin), he (cousin) was then attached to pleasures to which I believe he (cousin) has now learned to be indifferent.'' (unknown)

``Psha!'' (the father)
ejaculated the father.

``I can only speak as I believe,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
continued Alice.
``And I think I may perhaps know more of his (cousin) manner of life than you do, papa. But I am prepared to run risks now which I feared before. Even though he (cousin) were all that you think him (cousin) to be, I would still endeavour to do my duty to him (cousin), and to bring him (cousin) to other things.'' (unknown)

``What is it you expect to get by marrying him (cousin)?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
asked Mr. Vavasor.

``A husband whose mode of thinking is congenial to my own,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
answered Alice.
``A husband who proposes to himself a career in life with which I can sympathize. I think that I may perhaps help my cousin in the career which he (cousin) has chosen, and that alone is a great reason why I should attempt to do so.'' (unknown)

``With your money?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said Mr. Vavasor with a sneer.

``Partly with my money,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, disdaining to answer the sneer.
``Though it were only with my money, even that would be something.'' (unknown)

``Well, Alice, as your father, I can only implore you to pause before you commit yourself to his (father) hands. If he (father) demands money from you, and you are minded to give it to him (father), let him (father) have it in moderation. Anything will be better than marrying him (father). I know that I cannot hinder you; you are as much your own mistress as I am my own master,--or rather a great deal more, as my income depends on my going to that horrid place in Chancery Lane. But yet I suppose you must think something of your father's wishes and your father's opinion. It will not be pleasant for you to stand at the altar without my being there near you.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

To this Alice made no answer; but she (Alice) told herself that it had not been pleasant to her (Alice) to have stood at so many places during the last four years,--and to have found herself so often alone,--without her (Alice) father being near to her (Alice). That had been his (father) fault, and it was not now in her (Alice) power to remedy the ill-effects of it.

``Has any day been fixed between you and him (father)?'' (he)
he (father) asked.

``No, papa.'' (unknown)

``Nothing has been said about that?'' (unknown)

``Yes; something has been said. I have told him (papa) that it cannot be for a year yet. It is because I told him (papa) that, that I told him (papa) also that he (papa) should have my money when he (papa) wanted it.'' (unknown)

``Not all of it?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said Mr. Vavasor.

``I don't suppose he (papa) will need it all. He (papa) intends to stand again for Chelsea, and it is the great expense of the election which makes him (papa) want money. You are not to suppose that he (papa) has asked me for it. When I made him (papa) understand that I did not wish to marry quite yet, I offered him (papa) the use of that which would be ultimately his (papa) own.'' (unknown)

``And he (papa) has accepted it?'' (unknown)

``He (papa) answered me just as I had intended,--that when the need came he (papa) would take me at my word.'' (unknown)

``Then, Alice, I will tell you what is my belief. He (papa) will drain you of every shilling of your money, and when that is gone, there will be no more heard of the marriage. We must take a small house in some cheap part of the town and live on my income as best we may. I shall go and insure my life, so that you may not absolutely starve when I die.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
Having said this, Mr. Vavasor went away, not immediately to the insurance office, as his (Vavasor) words seemed to imply, but to his (Vavasor) club where he (Vavasor) sat alone, reading the newspaper, very gloomily, till the time came for his (Vavasor) afternoon rubber of whist, and the club dinner bill for the day was brought under his (Vavasor) eye.

Alice had no such consolations in her (Alice) solitude. She (Alice) had fought her (Alice) battle with her (Alice) father tolerably well, but she (Alice) was now called upon to fight a battle with herself, which was one much more difficult to win. Was her (Alice) cousin, her (Alice) betrothed as she (Alice) now must regard him (cousin), the worthless, heartless, mercenary rascal which her (Alice) father painted him (father)? There had certainly been a time, and that not very long distant, in which Alice herself had been almost constrained so to regard him (father). Since that any change for the better in her (Alice) opinion of him (father) had been grounded on evidence given either by himself or by his (father) sister Kate. He (father) had done nothing to inspire her (Kate) with any confidence, unless his (father) reckless daring in coming forward to contest a seat in Parliament could be regarded as a doing of something. And he (father) had owned himself to be a man almost penniless; he (father) had spoken of himself as being utterly reckless,--as being one whose standing in the world was and must continue to be a perch on the edge of a precipice, from which any accident might knock him (father) headlong. Alice believed in her (Alice) heart that this last profession or trade to which he (father) had applied himself, was becoming as nothing to him (father),--that he (father) received from it no certain income;--no income that a man could make to appear respectable to fathers or guardians when seeking a girl in marriage. Her (girl) father declared that all men spoke badly of him (father). Alice knew her (Alice) father to be an idle man, a man given to pleasure, to be one who thought by far too much of the good things of the world; but she (Alice) had never found him (father) to be either false or malicious. His (father) unwonted energy in this matter was in itself evidence that he (father) believed himself to be right in what he (father) said.

To tell the truth, Alice was frightened at what she (Alice) had done, and almost repented of it already. Her (Alice) acceptance of her (Alice) cousin's offer had not come of love;--nor had it, in truth, come chiefly of ambition. She (Alice) had not so much asked herself why she (Alice) should do this thing, as why she (Alice) should not do it,--seeing that it was required of her (Alice) by her (Alice) friend. What after all did it matter? That was her (Alice) argument with herself. It cannot be supposed that she (Alice) looked back on the past events of her (Alice) life with any self-satisfaction. There was no self-satisfaction, but in truth there was more self-reproach than she (Alice) deserved. As a girl she (Alice) had loved her (Alice) cousin George passionately, and that love had failed her (Alice). She (Alice) did not tell herself that she (Alice) had been wrong when she (Alice) gave him (George) up, but she (Alice) thought herself to have been most unfortunate in the one necessity. After such an experience as that, would it not have been better for her (Alice) to have remained without further thought of marriage?

Then came that terrible episode in her (Alice) life for which she (Alice) never could forgive herself. She (Alice) had accepted Mr. Grey because she (Alice) liked him (Grey) and honoured him (Grey).

``And I did love him (papa),'' (she)
she (Alice) said to herself, now on this morning. Poor, wretched, heart-wrung woman! As she (woman) sat there thinking of it all in her (woman) solitude she (woman) was to be pitied at any rate, if not to be forgiven. Now, as she (woman) thought of Nethercoats, with its quiet life, its gardens, its books, and the peaceful affectionate ascendancy of him (Grey) who would have been her (woman) lord and master, her (woman) feelings were very different from those which had induced her (woman) to resolve that she (woman) would not stoop to put her (woman) neck beneath that yoke. Would it not have been well for her (woman) to have a master who by his (master) wisdom and strength could save her (woman) from such wretched doubtings as these? But she (woman) had refused to bend, and then she (woman) had found herself desolate and alone in the world.

``If I can do him (papa) good why should I not marry him (papa)?'' (chief)
In that feeling had been the chief argument which had induced her (woman) to return such an answer as she (woman) had sent to her (woman) cousin.
``For myself, what does it matter? As to this life of mine and all that belongs to it, why should I regard it otherwise than to make it of some service to some one who is dear to me?'' (He)
He (cousin) had been ever dear to her (woman) from her (woman) earliest years. She (woman) believed in his (cousin) intellect, even if she (woman) could not believe in his (cousin) conduct. Kate, her (Kate) friend, longed for this thing. As for that dream of love, it meant nothing; and as for those arguments of prudence,--that cold calculation about her (Kate) money, which all people seemed to expect from her (Kate),--she (Kate) would throw it to the winds. What if she (Kate) were ruined! There was always the other chance. She (Kate) might save him (cousin) from ruin, and help him (cousin) to honour and fortune.

But then, when the word was once past her (Kate) lips, there returned to her (Kate) that true woman's feeling which made her (Kate) plead for a long day,--which made her (Kate) feel that that long day would be all too short,--which made her (Kate) already dread the coming of the end of the year. She (Kate) had said that she (Kate) would become George Vavasor's wife, but she (Kate) wished that the saying so might be the end of it. When he (Vavasor) came to her (Kate) to embrace her (Kate) how should she (Kate) receive him (Vavasor)? The memory of John Grey's last kiss still lingered on her (Kate) lips. She (Kate) had told herself that she (Kate) scorned the delights of love; if it were so, was she (Kate) not bound to keep herself far from them; if it were so,--would not her (Kate) cousin's kiss pollute her (Kate)?

``It may be as my father says,'' (she)
she (Kate) thought.
``It may be that he (father) wants my money only; if so, let him (father) have it. Surely when the year is over I shall know.'' (she)
Then a plan formed itself in her (Kate) head, which she (Kate) did not make willingly, with any voluntary action of her (Kate) mind,--but which came upon her (Kate) as plans do come,--and recommended itself to her (Kate) in despite of herself. He (cousin) should have her (Kate) money as he (cousin) might call for it,--all of it excepting some small portion of her (Kate) income, which might suffice to keep her (Kate) from burdening her (Kate) father. Then, if he (father) were contented, he (father) should go free, without reproach, and there should be an end of all question of marriage for her (Kate).

As she (Kate) thought of this, and matured it in her (Kate) mind, the door opened, and the servant announced her (Kate) cousin George.

CHAPTER XXXV.

Passion versus Prudence.

It had not occurred to Alice that her (Alice) accepted lover would come to her (Alice) so soon. She (Alice) had not told him (lover) expressly of the day on which she (Alice) would return, and had not reflected that Kate would certainly inform him (lover). She (Kate) had been thinking so much of the distant perils of this engagement, that this peril, so sure to come upon her (Kate) before many days or hours could pass by, had been forgotten. When the name struck her (Kate) ear, and George's step was heard outside on the landing-place, she (Kate) felt the blood rush violently to her (Kate) heart, and she (Kate) jumped up from her (Kate) seat panic-stricken and in utter dismay. How should she (Kate) receive him (George)? And then again, with what form of affection would she (Kate) be accosted by him (George)? But he (George) was there in the room with her (Kate) before she (Kate) had had a moment allowed to her (Kate) for thought.

She (Kate) hardly ventured to look up at him (George); but, nevertheless, she (Kate) became aware that there was something in his (George) appearance and dress brighter, more lover-like, perhaps newer, than was usual with him (George). This in itself was an affliction to her (Kate). He (George) ought to have understood that such an engagement as theirs not only did not require, but absolutely forbade, any such symptom of young love as this. Even when their marriage came, if it must come, it should come without any customary sign of smartness, without any outward mark of exaltation. It would have been very good in him (George) to have remained away from her (Kate) for weeks and months; but to come upon her (Kate) thus, on the first morning of her (Kate) return, was a cruelty not to be forgiven. These were the feelings with which Alice regarded her (Alice) betrothed when he (George) came to see her (Alice).

``Alice,'' (he)
said he (George), coming up to her (Alice) with his (George) extended hand,--
``Dearest Alice!'' (he)

She (Alice) gave him (George) her (Alice) hand, and muttered some word which was inaudible even to him (George); she (Alice) gave him (George) her (Alice) hand, and immediately endeavoured to resume it, but he (George) held it clenched within his (George) own, and she (Alice) felt that she (Alice) was his (George) prisoner. He (George) was standing close to her (Alice) now, and she (Alice) could not escape from him (George). She (Alice) was trembling with fear lest worse might betide her (Alice) even than this. She (Alice) had promised to marry him (George), and now she (Alice) was covered with dismay as she (Alice) felt rather than thought how very far she (Alice) was from loving the man to whom she (Alice) had given this promise.

``Alice,'' (he)
he (man) said,
``I am a man once again. It is only now that I can tell you what I have suffered during these last few years.'' (he)
He (man) still held her (Alice) hand, but he (man) had not as yet attempted any closer embrace. She (Alice) knew that she (Alice) was standing away from him (man) awkwardly, almost showing her (Alice) repugnance to him (man); but it was altogether beyond her (Alice) power to assume an attitude of ordinary ease.
``Alice,'' (he)
he (man) continued,
``I feel that I am a strong man again, armed to meet the world at all points. Will you not let me thank you for what you have done for me?'' (he)

She (Alice) must speak to him (man)! Though the doing so should be ever so painful to her (Alice), she (Alice) must say some word to him (man) which should have in it a sound of kindness. After all, it was his (man) undoubted right to come to her (Alice), and the footing on which he (man) assumed to stand was simply that which she (Alice) herself had given to him (man). It was not his (man) fault if at this moment he (man) inspired her (Alice) with disgust rather than with love.

``I have done nothing for you, George,'' (she)
she (Alice) said,
``nothing at all.'' (she)
Then she (Alice) got her (Alice) hand away from him (man), and retreated back to a sofa where she (Alice) seated herself, leaving him (man) still standing in the space before the fire.
``That you may do much for yourself is my greatest hope. If I can help you, I will do so most heartily.'' (she)
Then she (Alice) became thoroughly ashamed of her (Alice) words, feeling that she (Alice) was at once offering to him (man) the use of her (Alice) purse.

``Of course you will help me,'' (he)
he (man) said.
``I am full of plans, all of which you must share with me. But now, at this moment, my one great plan is that in which you have already consented to be my partner. Alice, you are my wife now. Tell me that it will make you happy to call me your husband.'' (she)

Not for worlds could she (Alice) have said so at this moment. It was ill-judged in him (man) to press her (Alice) thus. He (man) should already have seen, with half an eye, that no such triumph as that which he (man) now demanded could be his (man) on this occasion. He (man) had had his (man) triumph when, in the solitude of his (man) own room, with quiet sarcasm he (man) had thrown on one side of him (man) the letter in which she (Alice) had accepted him (man), as though the matter had been one almost indifferent to him (man). He (man) had no right to expect the double triumph. Then he (man) had frankly told himself that her (Alice) money would be useful to him (man). He (man) should have been contented with that conviction, and not have required her (Alice) also to speak to him (man) soft winning words of love.

``That must be still distant, George,'' (she)
she (Alice) said.
``I have suffered so much!'' (unknown)

``And it has been my fault that you have suffered; I know that. These years of misery have been my doing.'' (unknown)
It was, however, the year of coming misery that was the most to be dreaded.

``I do not say that,'' (she)
she (Alice) replied,
``nor have I ever thought it. I have myself and myself only to blame.'' (she)
Here he (man) altogether misunderstood her (Alice), believing her (Alice) to mean that the fault for which she (Alice) blamed herself had been committed in separating herself from him (man) on that former occasion.

``Alice, dear, let bygones be bygones.'' (unknown)

``Bygones will not be bygones. It may be well for people to say so, but it is never true. One might as well say so to one's body as to one's heart. But the hairs will grow grey, and the heart will grow cold.'' (unknown)

``I do not see that one follows upon the other,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.
``My hair is growing very grey;'' (he)
--and to show that it was so, he (George) lifted the dark lock from the side of his (George) forehead, and displayed the incipient grizzling of the hair from behind.
``If grey hairs make an old man, Alice, you will marry an old husband; but even you shall not be allowed to say that my heart is old.'' (unknown)

That word

``husband,'' (cousin)
which her (Alice) cousin had twice used, was painful to Alice's ear. She (Alice) shrunk from it with palpable bodily suffering. Marry an old husband! His (husband) age was nothing to the purpose, though he (husband) had been as old as Enoch. But she (Alice) was again obliged to answer him (Enoch).
``I spoke of my own heart,'' (she)
said she (Alice):
``I sometimes feel that it has grown very old.'' (she)

``Alice, that is hardly cheering to me.'' (unknown)

``You have come to me too quickly, George, and do not reflect how much there is that I must remember. You have said that bygones should be bygones. Let them be so, at any rate as far as words are concerned. Give me a few months in which I may learn,--not to forget them, for that will be impossible,--but to abstain from speaking of them.'' (she)

There was something in her (Alice) look as she (Alice) spoke, and in the tone of her (Alice) voice that was very sad. It struck him (Enoch) forcibly, but it struck him (Enoch) with anger rather than with sadness. Doubtless her (Alice) money had been his (Enoch) chief object when he (Enoch) offered to renew his (Enoch) engagement with her (Alice). Doubtless he (Enoch) would have made no such offer had she (Alice) been penniless, or even had his (Enoch) own need been less pressing. But, nevertheless, he (Enoch) desired something more than money. The triumph of being preferred to John Grey,--of having John Grey sent altogether adrift, in order that his (Grey) old love might be recovered, would have been too costly a luxury for him (Grey) to seek, had he (Grey) not in seeking it been able to combine prudence with the luxury. But though his (Grey) prudence had been undoubted, he (Grey) desired the luxury also. It was on a calculation of the combined advantage that he (Grey) had made his (Grey) second offer to his (Grey) cousin. As he (Grey) would by no means have consented to proceed with the arrangement without the benefit of his (Grey) cousin's money, so also did he (Grey) feel unwilling to dispense with some expression of her (Grey) love for him (Grey), which would be to him (Grey) triumphant. Hitherto in their present interview there had certainly been no expression of her (Grey) love.

``Alice,'' (he)
he (Grey) said,
``your greeting to me is hardly all that I had hoped.'' (he)

``Is it not?'' (she)
said she (Grey).
``Indeed, George, I am sorry that you should be disappointed; but what can I say? You would not have me affect a lightness of spirit which I do not feel?'' (unknown)

``If you wish,'' (he)
said he (Grey), very slowly,--
``if you wish to retract your letter to me, you now have my leave to do so.'' (he)

What an opportunity was this of escape! But she (Grey) had not the courage to accept it. What girl, under such circumstances, would have had such courage? How often are offers made to us which we would almost give our eyes to accept, but dare not accept because we fear the countenance of the offerer?

``I do not wish to retract my letter,'' (she)
said she (girl), speaking as slowly as he (Grey) had spoken;
``but I wish to be left awhile, that I may recover my strength of mind. Have you not heard doctors say, that muscles which have been strained, should be allowed rest, or they will never entirely renew their tension? It is so with me now; if I could be quiet for a few months, I think I could learn to face the future with a better courage.'' (he)

``And is that all you can say to me, Alice?'' (unknown)

``What would you have me say?'' (unknown)

``I would fain hear one word of love from you; is that unreasonable? I would wish to know from your own lips that you have satisfaction in the renewed prospect of our union; is that too ambitious? It might have been that I was over-bold in pressing my suit upon you again; but as you accepted it, have I not a right to expect that you should show me that you have been happy in accepting it?'' (she)

But she (girl) had not been happy in accepting it. She (girl) was not happy now that she (girl) had accepted it. She (girl) could not show to him (Grey) any sign of such joy as that which he (Grey) desired to see. And now, at this moment, she (girl) feared with an excessive fear that there would come some demand for an outward demonstration of love, such as he (Grey) in his (Grey) position might have a right to make. She (girl) seemed to be aware that this might be prevented only by such demeanour on her (girl) part as that which she (girl) had practised, and she (girl) could not, therefore, be stirred to the expression of any word of affection. She (girl) listened to his (Grey) appeal, and when it was finished she (girl) made no reply. If he (Grey) chose to take her (girl) in dudgeon, he (Grey) must do so. She (girl) would make for him (Grey) any sacrifice that was possible to her (girl), but this sacrifice was not possible.

``And you have not a word to say to me?'' (he)
he (Grey) asked. She (girl) looked up at him (Grey), and saw that the cicature on his (Grey) face was becoming ominous; his (Grey) eyes were bent upon her (girl) with all their forbidding brilliance, and he (Grey) was assuming that look of angry audacity which was so peculiar to him (Grey), and which had so often cowed those with whom he (Grey) was brought in contact.

``No other word, at present, George; I have told you that I am not at ease. Why do you press me now?'' (He)

He (Grey) had her (girl) letter to him (Grey) in the breast-pocket of his (Grey) coat, and his (Grey) hand was on it, that he (Grey) might fling it back to her (girl), and tell her (girl) that he (Grey) would not hold her (girl) to be his (Grey) promised wife under such circumstances as these. The anger which would have induced him (Grey) to do so was the better part of his (Grey) nature. Three or four years since, this better part would have prevailed, and he (Grey) would have given way to his (Grey) rage. But now, as his (Grey) fingers played upon the paper, he (Grey) remembered that her (girl) money was absolutely essential to him (Grey),--that some of it was needed by him (Grey) almost instantly,--that on this very morning he (Grey) was bound to go where money would be demanded from him (Grey), and that his (Grey) hopes with regard to Chelsea could not be maintained unless he (Grey) was able to make some substantial promise of providing funds. His (Grey) sister Kate's fortune was just two thousand pounds. That, and no more, was now the capital at his (Grey) command, if he (Grey) should abandon this other source of aid. Even that must go, if all other sources should fail him (Grey); but he (Grey) would fain have that untouched, if it were possible. Oh, that that old man in Westmoreland would die and be gathered to his (man) fathers, now that he (man) was full of years and ripe for the sickle! But there was no sign of death about the old man. So his (man) fingers released their hold on the letter, and he (man) stood looking at her (Grey) in his (man) anger.

``You wish me then to go from you?'' (he)
he (man) said.

``Do not be angry with me, George!'' (unknown)

``Angry! I have no right to be angry. But, by heaven, I am wrong there. I have the right, and I am angry. I think you owed it me to give me some warmer welcome. Is it to be thus with us always for the next accursed year?'' (unknown)

``Oh, George!'' (unknown)

``To me it will be accursed. But is it to be thus between us always? Alice, I have loved you above all women. I may say that I have never loved any woman but you; and yet I am sometimes driven to doubt whether you have a heart in you capable of love. After all that has passed, all your old protestations, all my repentance, and your proffer of forgiveness, you should have received me with open arms. I suppose I may go now, and feel that I have been kicked out of your house like a dog.'' (unknown)

``If you speak to me like that, and look at me like that, how can I answer you?'' (unknown)

``I want no answer. I wanted you to put your hand in mine, to kiss me, and to tell me that you are once more my own. Alice, think better of it; kiss me, and let me feel my arm once more round your waist.'' (She)

She (Grey) shuddered as she (Grey) sat, still silent, on her (Grey) seat, and he (man) saw that she (Grey) shuddered. With all his (man) desire for her (Grey) money,--his (man) instant need of it,--this was too much for him (man); and he (man) turned upon his (man) heel, and left the room without another word. She (Grey) heard his (man) quick step as he (man) hurried down the stairs, but she (Grey) did not rise to arrest him (man). She (Grey) heard the door slam as he (man) left the house, but still she (Grey) did not move from her (Grey) seat. Her (Grey) immediate desire had been that he (man) should go,--and now he (man) was gone. There was in that a relief which almost comforted her (Grey). And this was the man from whom, within the last few days, she (Grey) had accepted an offer of marriage.

George, when he (George) left the house, walked hurriedly into Cavendish Square, and down along the east side, till he (George) made his (George) way out along Princes Street, into the Circus in Oxford Street. Close to him (George) there, in Great Marlborough Street, was the house of his (Great) parliamentary attorney, Mr. Scruby, on whom he (Great) was bound to call on that morning. As he (Great) had walked away from Queen Anne Street, he (Great) had thought of nothing but that too visible shudder which his (Great) cousin Alice had been unable to repress. He (Great) had been feeding on his (Great) anger, and indulging it, telling himself at one moment that he (Great) would let her (Alice) and her (Alice) money go from him (Great) whither they list,--and making inward threats in the next that the time should come in which he (Great) would punish her (Alice) for this ill-usage. But there was the necessity of resolving what he (Great) would say to Mr. Scruby. To Mr. Scruby was still due some trifle on the cost of the last election; but even if this were paid, Mr. Scruby would make no heavy advance towards the expense of the next election. Whoever might come out at the end of such affairs without a satisfactory settlement of his (Scruby) little bill, as had for a while been the case with Mr. Grimes, from the

``Handsome Man,'' (Mr. Grimes/Grimes)
--and as, indeed, still was the case with him (Grimes), as that note of hand at three months' date was not yet paid,--Mr. Scruby seldom allowed himself to suffer. It was true that the election would not take place till the summer; but there were preliminary expenses which needed ready money. Metropolitan voters, as Mr. Scruby often declared, required to be kept in good humour,--so that Mr. Scruby wanted the present payment of some five hundred pounds, and a well-grounded assurance that he (Scruby) would be put in full funds by the beginning of next June. Even Mr. Scruby might not be true as perfect steel, if he (Scruby) thought that his (Scruby) candidate at the last moment would not come forth properly prepared. Other candidates, with money in their pockets, might find their way into Mr. Scruby's offices. As George Vavasor crossed Regent Street, he (Vavasor) gulped down his (Vavasor) anger, and applied his (Vavasor) mind to business. Should he (Vavasor) prepare himself to give orders that Kate's little property should be sold out, or would he (Vavasor) resolve to use his (Vavasor) cousin's money? That his (Vavasor) cousin's money would still be at his (Vavasor) disposal, in spite of the stormy mood in which he (Vavasor) had retreated from her (Kate) presence, he (Vavasor) felt sure; but the asking for it on his (Vavasor) part would be unpleasant. That duty he (Vavasor) must entrust to Kate. But as he (Vavasor) reached Mr. Scruby's door, he (Scruby) had decided that for such purposes as those now in hand, it was preferable that he (Scruby) should use his (Scruby) wife's fortune. It was thus that in his (Scruby) own mind he (Scruby) worded the phrase, and made for himself an excuse. Yes;--he (Scruby) would use his (Scruby) wife's fortune, and explain to Mr. Scruby that he (Scruby) would be justified in doing so by the fact that his (Scruby) own heritage would be settled on her (wife) at her (wife) marriage. I do not suppose that he (Scruby) altogether liked it. He (Scruby) was not, at any rate as yet, an altogether heartless swindler. He (swindler) could not take his (swindler) cousin's money without meaning,--without thinking that he (swindler) meant, to repay her (wife) in full all that he (swindler) took. Her (wife) behaviour to him (swindler) this very morning had no doubt made the affair more difficult to his (swindler) mind, and more unpleasant than it would have been had she (wife) smiled on him (swindler); but even as it was, he (swindler) managed to assure himself that he (swindler) was doing her (wife) no wrong, and with this self-assurance he (swindler) entered Mr. Scruby's office.

The clerks in the outer office were very civil to him (Scruby), and undertook to promise him (Scruby) that he (Scruby) should not be kept waiting an instant. There were four gentlemen in the little parlour, they said, waiting to see Mr. Scruby, but there they should remain till Mr. Vavasor's interview was over. One gentleman, as it seemed, was even turned out to make way for him (gentleman); for as George was ushered into the lawyer's room, a little man, looking very meek, was hurried away from it.

``You can wait, Smithers,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby, speaking from within.
``I shan't be very long.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Vavasor apologized to his (Scruby) agent for the injury he (Scruby) was doing Smithers; but Mr. Scruby explained that he (Scruby) was only a poor devil of a printer, looking for payment of his (Scruby) little account. He (Scruby) had printed and posted 30,000 placards for one of the late Marylebone candidates, and found some difficulty in getting his (Scruby) money.
``You see, when they're in a small way of business, it ruins them,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Scruby.
``Now that poor devil,--he (devil) hasn't had a shilling of his (devil) money yet, and the greater part has been paid out of his (devil) pocket to the posters. It is hard.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

It comforted Vavasor when he (Scruby) thus heard that there were others who were more backward in their payments, even than himself, and made him (Scruby) reflect that a longer credit than had yet been achieved by him (Scruby), might perhaps be within his (Scruby) reach.

``It is astonishing how much a man may get done for him (man),'' (he)
said he (Scruby),
``without paying anything for years.'' (he)

``Yes; that's true. So he (man) may, if he (man) knows how to go about it. But when he (man) does pay, Mr. Vavasor, he (Vavasor) does it through the nose;--cent. per cent., and worse, for all his (Vavasor) former shortcomings.'' (unknown)

``How many there are who never pay at all,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``Yes, Mr. Vavasor;--that's true, too. But see what a life they lead. It isn't a pleasant thing to be afraid of coming into your agent's office; not what you would like, Mr. Vavasor;--not if I know you.'' (unknown)

``I never was afraid of meeting anyone yet,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor;
``but I don't know what I may come to.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``Nor never will, I'll go bail. But, Lord love you, I could tell you such tales! I've had Members of Parliament, past, present, and future, almost down on their knees to me in this little room. It's about a month or six weeks before the elections come on when they're at their worst. There is so much you see, Mr. Vavasor, for which a gentleman must pay ready money. It isn't like a business in which a lawyer is supposed to find the capital. If I had money enough to pay out of my own pocket all the cost of all the metropolitan gentlemen for whom I act, why, I could live on the interest without any trouble, and go into Parliament myself like a man.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

George Vavasor perfectly understood that Mr. Scruby was explaining to him (Vavasor), with what best attempt at delicacy he (Vavasor) could make, that funds for the expense of the Chelsea election were not to be forthcoming from the Great Marlborough Street establishment.

``I suppose so,'' (he)
said he (Great).
``But you do do it sometimes.'' (unknown)

``Never, Mr. Vavasor,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby, very solemnly.
``As a rule, never. I may advance the money, on interest, of course, when I receive a guarantee from the candidate's father, or from six or seven among the committee, who must all be very substantial,--very substantial indeed. But in a general way I don't do it. It isn't my place.'' (unknown)

``I thought you did;--but at any rate I don't want you to do it for me.'' (unknown)

``I'm quite sure you don't,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby, with a brighter tone of voice than that he (Scruby) had just been using.
``I never thought you did, Mr. Vavasor. Lord bless you, Mr. Vavasor, I know the difference between gentlemen as soon as I see them.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Then they went to business, and Vavasor became aware that it would be thought convenient that he (Scruby) should lodge with Mr. Scruby, to his (Scruby) own account, a sum not less than six hundred pounds within the next week, and it would be also necessary that he (Scruby) should provide for taking up that bill, amounting to ninety-two pounds, which he (Scruby) had given to the landlord of the

``Handsome Man.'' (he)
In short, it would be well that he (Scruby) should borrow a thousand pounds from Alice, and as he (Scruby) did not wish that the family attorney of the Vavasors should be employed to raise it, he (attorney) communicated to Mr. Scruby as much of his (Scruby) plans as was necessary,--feeling more hesitation in doing it than might have been expected from him (Scruby). When he (Scruby) had done so, he (Scruby) was very intent on explaining also that the money taken from his (Scruby) cousin, and future bride, would be repaid to her (bride) out of the property in Westmoreland, which was,--did he (Scruby) say settled on himself? I am afraid he (Scruby) did.

``Yes, yes;--a family arrangement,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby, as he (Scruby) congratulated him (Scruby) on his (Scruby) proposed marriage. Mr. Scruby did not care a straw from what source the necessary funds might be drawn.

CHAPTER XXXVI.

John Grey Goes a Second Time to London.

Early in that conversation which Mr. Vavasor had with his (Vavasor) daughter, and which was recorded a few pages back, he (Vavasor) implored her (daughter) to pause a while before she (daughter) informed Mr. Grey of her (daughter) engagement with her (daughter) cousin. Nothing, however, on that point had been settled between them. Mr. Vavasor had wished her (daughter) to say that she (daughter) would not write till he (Vavasor) should have assented to her (daughter) doing so. She (daughter) had declined to bind herself in this way, and then they had gone off to other things;--to George Vavasor's character and the disposition of her (daughter) money. Alice, however, had felt herself bound not to write to Mr. Grey quite at once. Indeed, when her (Alice) cousin left her (Alice) she (Alice) had no appetite for writing such a letter as hers was to be. A day or two passed by her (Alice) in this way, and nothing more was said by her (Alice) or her (Alice) father. It was now the middle of January, and the reader may remember that Mr. Grey had promised that he (Grey) would come to her (Alice) in London in that month, as soon as he (Grey) should know that she (Alice) had returned from Westmoreland. She (Alice) must at any rate do something to prevent that visit. Mr. Grey would not come without giving her (Alice) notice. She (Alice) knew enough of the habits of the man to be sure of that. But she (Alice) desired that her (Alice) letter to him (Grey) should be in time to prevent his (Grey) to her (Alice); so when those few days were gone, she (Alice) sat down to write without speaking to her (Alice) father again upon the subject.

It was a terrible job;--perhaps the most difficult of all the difficult tasks which her (Alice) adverse fate had imposed upon her (Alice). She (Alice) found when she (Alice) did attempt it, that she (Alice) could have done it better if she (Alice) had done it at the moment when she (Alice) was writing the other letter to her (Alice) cousin George. Then Kate had been near her (Kate), and she (Kate) had been comforted by Kate's affectionate happiness. She (Kate) had been strengthened at that moment by a feeling that she (Kate) was doing the best in her (Kate) power, if not for herself, at any rate for others. All that comfort and all that strength had left her (Kate) now. The atmosphere of the fells had buoyed her (Kate) up, and now the thick air of London depressed her (Kate). She (Kate) sat for hours with the pen in her (Kate) hand, and could not write the letter. She (Kate) let a day go by and a night, and still it was not written. She (Kate) hardly knew herself in her (Kate) unnatural weakness. As the mental photographs of the two men forced themselves upon her (Kate), she (Kate) could not force herself to forget those words--

``Look here, upon this picture--and on this.'' (she)
How was it that she (Kate) now knew how great was the difference between the two men, how immense the pre-eminence of him (Kate) whom she (Kate) had rejected;--and that she (Kate) had not before been able to see this on any of those many previous occasions on which she (Kate) had compared the two together? As she (Kate) thought of her (Kate) cousin George's face when he (George) left her (Kate) room a few days since, and remembered Mr. Grey's countenance when last he (Grey) held her (Kate) hand at Cheltenham, the quiet dignity of his (Grey) beauty which would submit to show no consciousness of injury, she (Kate) could not but tell herself that when Paradise had been opened to her (Kate), she (Kate) had declared herself to be fit only for Pandemonium. In that was her (Kate) chief misery; that now,--now when it was too late,--she (Kate) could look at it aright.

But the letter must be written, and on the second day she (Kate) declared to herself that she (Kate) would not rise from her (Kate) chair till it was done. The letter was written on that day and was posted. I will now ask the reader to go down with me to Nethercoats that we may be present with John Grey when he (Grey) received it. He (Grey) was sitting at breakfast in his (Grey) study there, and opposite to him (Grey), lounging in an arm-chair, with a _Quarterly_ in his (Grey) hand, was the most intimate of his (Grey) friends, Frank Seward, a fellow of the college to which they had both belonged. Mr. Seward was a clergyman, and the tutor of his (Seward) college, and a man who worked very hard at Cambridge. In the days of his (Seward) leisure he (Seward) spent much of his (Seward) time at Nethercoats, and he (Seward) was the only man to whom Grey had told anything of his (Grey) love for Alice and of his (Grey) disappointment. Even to Seward he (Seward) had not told the whole story. He (Seward) had at first informed his (Seward) friend that he (Seward) was engaged to be married, and as he (Seward) had told this as no secret,--having even said that he (Seward) hated secrets on such matters,--the engagement had been mentioned in the common room of their college, and men at Cambridge knew that Mr. Grey was going to take to himself a wife. Then Mr. Seward had been told that trouble had come, and that it was not improbable that there would be no such marriage. Even when saying this Mr. Grey told none of the particulars, though he (Grey) owned to his (Grey) friend that a heavy blow had struck him (Grey). His (Grey) intimacy with Seward was of that thorough kind which is engendered only out of such young and lasting friendship as had existed between them; but even to such a friend as this Mr. Grey could not open his (Grey) whole heart. It was only to a friend who should also be his (Grey) wife that he (Grey) could do that,--as he (Grey) himself thoroughly understood. He (Grey) had felt that such a friend was wanting to him (friend), and he (friend) had made the attempt.

``Don't speak of this as yet,'' (he)
he (friend) had said to Mr. Seward.
``Of course when the matter is settled, those few people who know me must know it. But perhaps there may be a doubt as yet, and as long as there is a doubt, it is better that it should not be discussed.'' (He)

He (Seward) had said no more than this,--had imputed no blame to Alice,--had told none of the circumstances; but Seward had known that the girl had jilted his (Seward) friend, and had made up his (Seward) mind that she (girl) must be heartless and false. He (Seward) had known also that his (Seward) friend would never look for any other such companion for his (friend) home.

Letters were brought to each of them on this morning, and Seward's attention was of course occupied by those which he (Seward) received. Grey, as soon as the envelopes had touched his (Grey) hand, became aware that one of them was from Alice, and this he (Grey) at once opened. He (Grey) did it very calmly, but without any of that bravado of indifference with which George Vavasor had received Alice's letter from Westmoreland.

``It is right that I should tell you at once,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, rushing into the middle of her (Alice) subject without even the formality of the customary address--
``It is right that I should tell you at once that--.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Oh, the difficulty which she (Alice) had encountered when her (Alice) words had carried her (Alice) as far as this!--
``that my cousin, George Vavasor, has repeated to me his (Vavasor) offer of marriage, and that I have accepted it. I tell you, chiefly in order that I may save you from the trouble which you purposed to take when I last saw you at Cheltenham. I will not tell you any of the circumstances of this engagement, because I have no right to presume that you will care to hear them. I hardly dare to ask you to believe of me that in all that I have done, I have endeavoured to act with truth and honesty. That I have been very ignorant, foolish,--what you will that is bad, I know well; otherwise there could not have been so much in the last few years of my life on which I am utterly ashamed to look back. For the injury that I have done you, I can only express deep contrition. I do not dare to ask you to forgive me.--ALICE VAVASOR.'' (She)
She (Alice) had tormented herself in writing this,--had so nearly driven herself distracted with attempts which she (Alice) had destroyed, that she (Alice) would not even read once to herself these last words.
``He (I)'ll know it, and that is all that is necessary,'' (she)
she (Alice) said to herself as she (Alice) sent the letter away from her (Alice).

Mr. Grey read it twice over, leaving the other letters unnoticed on the table by his (Grey) tea-cup. He (Grey) read it twice over, and the work of reading it was one to him (Grey) of intense agony. Hitherto he (Grey) had fed himself with hope. That Alice should have been brought to think of her (Alice) engagement with him (Grey) in a spirit of doubt and with a mind so troubled, that she (Alice) had been inclined to attempt an escape from it, had been very grievous to him (Grey); but it had been in his (Grey) mind a fantasy, a morbid fear of himself, which might be cured by time. He (Grey), at any rate, would give all his (Grey) energies towards achieving such a cure. There had been one thing, however, which he (Grey) most feared;--which he (Grey) had chiefly feared, though he (Grey) had forbidden himself to think that it could be probable, and this thing had now happened.

He (Grey) had ever disliked and feared George Vavasor;--not from any effect which the man had upon himself, for as we know his (man) acquaintance with Vavasor was of the slightest;--but he (man) had feared and disliked his (man) influence upon Alice. He (man) had also feared the influence of her (Alice) cousin Kate. To have cautioned Alice against her (Alice) cousins would have been to him (man) impossible. It was not his (man) nature to express suspicion to one he (man) loved. Is the tone of that letter remembered in which he (man) had answered Alice when she (Alice) informed him (man) that her (Alice) cousin George was to go with Kate and her (Kate) to Switzerland? He (George) had written, with a pleasant joke, words which Alice had been able to read with some little feeling of triumph to her (Alice) two friends. He (George) had not so written because he (George) liked what he (George) knew of the man. He (George) disliked all that he (George) knew of him (George). But it had not been possible for him (George) to show that he (George) distrusted the prudence of her (Alice), whom, as his (George) future wife, he (George) was prepared to trust in all things.

I have said that he (George) read Alice's letter with an agony of sorrow; as he (George) sat with it in his (George) hand he (George) suffered as, probably, he (George) had never suffered before. But there was nothing in his (George) countenance to show that he (George) was in pain. Seward had received some long epistle, crossed from end to end,--indicative, I should say, of a not far distant termination to that college tutorship,--and was reading it with placid contentment. It did not occur to him (Seward) to look across at Grey, but had he (Grey) done so, I doubt whether he (Grey) would have seen anything to attract his (Grey) attention. But Grey, though he (Grey) was wounded, would not allow himself to be dismayed. There was less hope now than before, but there might still be hope;--hope for her (Grey), even though there might be none for him (Grey). Tidings had reached his (Grey) ears also as to George Vavasor, which had taught him (Vavasor) to believe that the man was needy, reckless, and on the brink of ruin. Such a marriage to Alice Vavasor would be altogether ruinous. Whatever might be his (man) own ultimate fate he (man) would still seek to save her (Vavasor) from that. Her (Vavasor) cousin, doubtless, wanted her (Vavasor) money. Might it not be possible that he (cousin) would be satisfied with her (Vavasor) money, and that thus the woman might be saved?

``Seward,'' (he)
he (cousin) said at last, addressing his (cousin) friend, who had not yet come to the end of the last crossed page.

``Is there anything wrong?'' (Seward/Mr. Seward)
said Seward.

``Well;--yes; there is something a little wrong. I fear I must leave you, and go up to town to-day.'' (unknown)

``Nobody ill, I hope?'' (unknown)

``No;--nobody is ill. But I must go up to London. Mrs. Bole will take care of you, and you must not be angry with me for leaving you.'' (Seward/Mr. Seward)

Seward assured him (Seward) that he (Seward) would not be in the least angry, and that he (Seward) was thoroughly conversant with the capabilities and good intentions of Mrs. Bole the housekeeper; but added, that as he (Seward) was so near his (Seward) own college, he (Seward) would of course go back to Cambridge. He (Seward) longed to say some word as to the purpose of Grey's threatened journey; to make some inquiry as to this new trouble; but he (Grey) knew that Grey was a man who did not well bear close inquiries, and he (Grey) was silent.

``Why not stay here?'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey, after a minute's pause.
``I wish you would, old fellow; I do, indeed.'' (Seward/Mr. Seward)
There was a tone of special affection in his (Grey) voice which struck Seward at once.
``If I can be of the slightest service or comfort to you, I will of course.'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)

Grey again sat silent for a little while.

``I wish you would; I do, indeed.'' (unknown)

``Then I will.'' (unknown)
And again there was a pause.

``I have got a letter here from--Miss Vavasor,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey.

``May I hope that--'' (unknown)

``No;--it does not bring good news to me. I do not know that I can tell it you all. I would if I could, but the whole story is one not to be told in a hurry. I should leave false impressions. There are things which a man cannot tell.'' (unknown)

``Indeed there are,'' (Seward/Mr. Seward)
said Seward.

``I wish with all my heart that you knew it all as I know it; but that is impossible. There are things which happen in a day which it would take a lifetime to explain.'' (unknown)
Then there was another pause.
``I have heard bad news this morning, and I must go up to London at once. I shall go into Ely so as to be there by twelve; and if you will, you shall drive me over. I may be back in a day; certainly in less than a week; but it will be a comfort to me to know that I shall find you here.'' (unknown)

The matter was so arranged, and at eleven they started. During the first two miles not a word was spoken between them.

``Seward,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
Grey said at last,
``if I fail in what I am going to attempt, it is probable that you will never hear Alice Vavasor's name mentioned by me again; but I want you always to bear this in mind;--that at no moment has my opinion of her (Vavasor) ever been changed, nor must you in such case imagine from my silence that it has changed. Do you understand me?'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)

``I think I do.'' (unknown)

``To my thinking she (Vavasor) is the finest of God's creatures that I have known. It may be that in her (Vavasor) future life she (Vavasor) will be severed from me altogether; but I shall not, therefore, think the less well of her (Vavasor); and I wish that you, as my friend, should know that I so esteem her (Vavasor), even though her (Vavasor) name should never be mentioned between us.'' (Seward/Mr. Seward)
Seward, in some few words, assured him (Seward) that it should be so, and then they finished their journey in silence.

From the station at Ely, Grey sent a message by the wires up to John Vavasor, saying that he (Vavasor) would call on him (Vavasor) that afternoon at his (Vavasor) office in Chancery Lane. The chances were always much against finding Mr. Vavasor at his (Vavasor) office; but on this occasion the telegram did reach him (Vavasor) there, and he (Vavasor) remained till the unaccustomed hour of half past four to meet the man who was to have been his (man) son-in-law.

``Have you heard from her (Vavasor)?'' (he)
he (man) asked as soon as Grey entered the dingy little room, not in Chancery Lane, but in its neighbourhood, which was allocated to him (Grey) for his (Grey) signing purposes.

``Yes,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
--said Grey;
``she (Vavasor) has written to me.'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)

``And told you about her (Vavasor) cousin George. I tried to hinder her (Vavasor) from writing, but she (Vavasor) is very wilful.'' (unknown)

``Why should you have hindered her (Vavasor)? If the thing was to be told, it is better that it should be done at once.'' (unknown)

``But I hoped that there might be an escape. I don't know what you think of all this, Grey, but to me it is the bitterest misfortune that I have known. And I've had some bitter things, too,'' (he)
he (Grey) added,--thinking of that period of his (Grey) life, when the work of which he (Grey) was ashamed was first ordained as his (Grey) future task.

``What is the escape that you hoped?'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
asked Grey.

``I hardly know. The whole thing seems to me to be so mad, that I partly trusted that she (Vavasor) would see the madness of it. I am not sure whether you know anything of my nephew George?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
asked Mr. Vavasor.

``Very little,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey.

``I believe him (George) to be utterly an adventurer,--a man without means and without principle,--upon the whole about as bad a man as you may meet. I give you my word, Grey, that I don't think I know a worse man. He (Grey)'s going to marry her (Vavasor) for her (Vavasor) money; then he (Grey) will beggar her (Vavasor), after that he (Grey)'ll ill-treat her (Vavasor), and yet what can I do?'' (unknown)

``Prevent the marriage.'' (unknown)
