``But how, my dear fellow? Prevent it! It's all very well to say that, and it's the very thing I want to do. But how am I to prevent it? She (Vavasor)'s as much her (Vavasor) own master as you are yours. She (Vavasor) can give him (master) every shilling of her (Vavasor) fortune to-morrow. How am I to prevent her (Vavasor) from marrying him (master)?'' (unknown)

``Let her (Vavasor) give him (master) every shilling of her (Vavasor) fortune to-morrow,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey.

``And what is she (Vavasor) to do then?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
asked Mr. Vavasor.

``Then--then,--then,--then let her (Vavasor) come to me,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said John Grey; and as he (Grey) spoke there was the fragment of a tear in his (Grey) eye, and the hint of quiver in his (Grey) voice.

-LSB-Illustration:

``Then--then,--then let her (Vavasor) come to me.'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
-RSB-

Even the worldly, worn-out, unsympathetic nature of John Vavasor was struck, and, as it were, warmed by this.

``God bless you; God bless you, my dear fellow. I heartily wish for her (Vavasor) sake that I could look forward to any such an end to this affair.'' (unknown)

``And why not look forward to it? You say that he (God) merely wants her (Vavasor) money. As he (God) wants it let him (God) have it!'' (unknown)

``But Grey, you do not know Alice; you do not understand my girl. When she (Alice) had lost her (Alice) fortune nothing would induce her (Alice) to become your wife.'' (unknown)

``Leave that to follow as it may,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said John Grey.
``Our first object must be to sever her (Alice) from a man, who is, as you say, himself on the verge of ruin; and who would certainly make her (Alice) wretched. I am here now, not because I wish her (Alice) to be my own wife, but because I wish that she (wife) should not become the wife of such a one as your nephew. If I were you I would let him (nephew) have her (wife) money.'' (unknown)

``If you were I, you would have nothing more to do with it than the man that is as yet unborn. I know that she (wife) will give him (man) her (wife) money because she (wife) has said so; but I have no power as to her (wife) giving it or as to her (wife) withholding it. That's the hardship of my position;--but it is of no use to think of that now.'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)

John Grey certainly did not think about it. He (Grey) knew well that Alice was independent, and that she (Alice) was not inclined to give up that independence to anyone. He (Grey) had not expected that her (Alice) father would be able to do much towards hindering his (Grey) daughter from becoming the wife of George Vavasor, but he (Vavasor) had wished that he (Vavasor) himself and her (wife) father should be in accord in their views, and he (Vavasor) found that this was so. When he (Vavasor) left Mr. Vavasor's room nothing had been said about the period of the marriage. Grey thought it improbable that Alice would find herself able to give herself in marriage to her (Alice) cousin immediately,--so soon after her (Alice) breach with him (Grey); but as to this he (Grey) had no assurance, and he (Grey) determined to have the facts from her (Alice) own lips, if she (Alice) would see him (Grey). So he (Grey) wrote to her (Alice), naming a day on which he (Grey) would call upon her (Alice) early in the morning; and having received from her (Alice) no prohibition, he (Grey) was in Queen Anne Street at the hour appointed.

He (Grey) had conceived a scheme which he (Grey) had not made known to Mr. Vavasor, and as to the practicability of which he (Vavasor) had much doubt; but which, nevertheless, he (Vavasor) was resolved to try if he (Vavasor) should find the attempt possible. He (Vavasor) himself would buy off George Vavasor. He (Vavasor) had ever been a prudent man, and he (Vavasor) had money at command. If Vavasor was such a man as they, who knew him (man) best, represented him (man), such a purchase might be possible. But then, before this was attempted, he (man) must be quite sure that he (man) knew his (man) man, and he (man) must satisfy himself also that in doing so he (man) would not, in truth, add to Alice's misery. He (man) could hardly bring himself to think it possible that she (Alice) did, in truth, love her (Alice) cousin with passionate love. It seemed to him (cousin), as he (cousin) remembered what Alice had been to himself, that this must be impossible. But if it were so, that of course must put an end to his (cousin) interference. He (cousin) thought that if he (cousin) saw her (Alice) he (cousin) might learn all this, and therefore he (cousin) went to Queen Anne Street.

``Of course he (man) must come if he (man) will,'' (she)
she (Queen) said to herself when she (Queen) received his (cousin) note.
``It can make no matter. He (man) will say nothing half so hard to me as what I say to myself all day long.'' (her)
But when the morning came, and the hour came, and the knock at the door for which her (Queen) ears were on the alert, her (Queen) heart misgave her (Queen), and she (Queen) felt that the present moment of her (Queen) punishment, though not the heaviest, would still be hard to bear.

He (cousin) came slowly up-stairs,--his (cousin) step was ever slow,--and gently opened the door for himself. Then, before he (cousin) even looked at her (Queen), he (cousin) closed it again. I do not know how to explain that it was so; but it was this perfect command of himself at all seasons which had in part made Alice afraid of him (cousin), and drove her (Alice) to believe that they were not fitted for each other. She (Alice), when he (cousin) thus turned for a moment from her (Alice), and then walked slowly towards her (Alice), stood with both her (Alice) hands leaning on the centre table of the room, and with her (Alice) eyes fixed upon its surface.

``Alice,'' (he)
he (cousin) said, walking up to her (Alice) very slowly.

Her (Alice) whole frame shuddered as she (Alice) heard the sweetness of his (cousin) voice. Had I not better tell the truth of her (Alice) at once? Oh, if she (Alice) could only have been his (cousin) again! What madness during these last six months had driven her (Alice) to such a plight as this! The old love came back upon her (Alice). Nay; it had never gone. But that trust in his (cousin) love returned to her (Alice),--that trust which told her (Alice) that such love and such worth would have sufficed to make her (Alice) happy. But this confidence in him (cousin) was worthless now! Even though he (cousin) should desire it, she (Alice) could not change again.

``Alice,'' (he)
he (cousin) said again. And then, as slowly she (Alice) looked up at him (cousin), he (cousin) asked her (Alice) for her (Alice) hand.
``You may give it me,'' (he)
he (cousin) said,
``as to an old friend.'' (he)
She (Alice) put her (Alice) hand in his (cousin) hand, and then, withdrawing it, felt that she (Alice) must never trust herself to do so again.

``Alice,'' (he)
he (cousin) continued,
``I do not expect you to say much to me; but there is a question or two which I think you will answer. Has a day been fixed for this marriage?'' (he)

``No,'' (she)
she (Alice) said.

``Will it be in a month?'' (unknown)

``Oh, no;--not for a year,'' (she)
she (Alice) replied hurriedly;--and he (cousin) knew at once by her (Alice) voice that she (Alice) already dreaded this new wedlock. Whatever of anger he (cousin) might before have felt for her (Alice) was banished. She (Alice) had brought herself by her (Alice) ill-judgement,--by her (Alice) ignorance, as she (Alice) had confessed,--to a sad pass; but he (cousin) believed that she (Alice) was still worthy of his (cousin) love.

``And now one other question, Alice;--but if you are silent, I will not ask it again. Can you tell me why you have again accepted your cousin's offer?'' (unknown)

``Because--,'' (she)
she (Alice) said very quickly, looking up as though she (Alice) were about to speak with all her (Alice) old courage.
``But you would never understand me,'' (she)
she (Alice) said,--
``and there can be no reason why I should dare to hope that you should ever think well of me again.'' (she)

He (cousin) knew that there was no love,--no love for that man to whom she (Alice) had pledged her (Alice) hand. He (man) did not know, on the other hand, how strong, how unchanged, how true was her (Alice) love for himself. Indeed, of himself he (man) was thinking not at all. He (man) desired to learn whether she (Alice) would suffer, if by any scheme he (man) might succeed in breaking off this marriage. When he (man) had asked her (Alice) whether she (Alice) were to be married at once, she (Alice) had shuddered at the thought. When he (man) asked her (Alice) why she (Alice) had accepted her (Alice) cousin, she (Alice) had faltered, and hinted at some excuse which he (man) might fail to understand. Had she (Alice) loved George Vavasor, he (Vavasor) could have understood that well enough.

``Alice,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) said, speaking still very slowly,
``nothing has ever yet been done which need to a certainty separate you and me. I am a persistent man, and I do not even yet give up all hope. A year is a long time. As you say yourself, I do not as yet quite understand you. But, Alice,--and I think that the position in which we stood a few months since justifies me in saying so without offence,--I love you now as well as ever, and should things change with you, I cannot tell you with how much joy and eagerness I should take you back to my bosom. My heart is yours now as it has been since I knew you.'' (he)

Then he (Vavasor) again just touched her (Alice) hand, and left her (Alice) before she (Alice) had been able to answer a word.

CHAPTER XXXVII.

Mr. Tombe's Advice.

Alice sat alone for an hour without moving when John Grey had left her (Alice), and the last words which he (Grey) had uttered were sounding in her (Alice) ears all the time,

``My heart is still yours, as it has been since I knew you.'' (he)
There had been something in his (Grey) words which had soothed her (Alice) spirits, and had, for the moment, almost comforted her (Alice). At any rate, he (Grey) did not despise her (Alice). He (Grey) could not have spoken such words as these to her (Alice) had he (Grey) not still held her (Alice) high in his (Grey) esteem. Nay;--had he (Grey) not even declared that he (Grey) would yet take her (Alice) as his (Grey) own if she (Alice) would come to him (Grey)?
``I cannot tell you with how much joy I would take you back to my bosom!'' (unknown)
Ah! that might never be. But yet the assurance had been sweet to her (Alice);--dangerously sweet, as she (Alice) soon told herself. She (Alice) knew that she (Alice) had lost her (Alice) Eden, but it was something to her (Alice) that the master of the garden had not himself driven her (Alice) forth. She (Alice) sat there, thinking of her (Alice) fate, as though it belonged to some other one,--not to herself; as though it were a tale that she (Alice) had read. Herself she (Alice) had shipwrecked altogether; but though she (Alice) might sink, she (Alice) had not been thrust from the ship by hands which she (Alice) loved.

But would it not have been better that he (master) should have scorned her (Alice) and reviled her (Alice)? Had he (master) been able to do so, he (master) at least would have escaped the grief of disappointed love. Had he (master) learned to despise her (Alice), he (master) would have ceased to regret her (Alice). She (Alice) had no right to feel consolation in the fact that his (master) sufferings were equal to her (Alice) own. But when she (Alice) thought of this, she (Alice) told herself that it could not be that it was so. He (master) was a man, she (Alice) said, not passionate by nature. Alas! it was the mistake she (Alice) had ever made when summing up the items of his (master) character! He (master) might be persistent, she (Alice) thought, in still striving to do that upon which he (master) had once resolved. He (master) had said so, and that which he (master) said was always true to the letter. But, nevertheless, when this thing which he (master) still chose to pursue should have been put absolutely beyond his (master) reach, he (master) would not allow his (master) calm bosom to be harassed by a vain regret. He (master) was a man too whole at every point,--so Alice told herself,--to allow his (master) happiness to be marred by such an accident.

But must the accident occur? Was there no chance that he (master) might be saved, even from such trouble as might follow upon such a loss? Could it not be possible that he (master) might be gratified,--since it would gratify him (master),--and that she (Alice) might be saved! Over and over again she (Alice) considered this,--but always as though it were another woman whom she (Alice) would fain save, and not herself.

But she (Alice) knew that her (Alice) own fate was fixed. She (Alice) had been mad when she (Alice) had done the thing, but the thing was not on that account the less done. She (Alice) had been mad when she (Alice) had trusted herself abroad with two persons, both of whom, as she (Alice) had well known, were intent on wrenching her (Alice) happiness from out of her (Alice) grasp. She (Alice) had been mad when she (Alice) had told herself, whilst walking over the Westmoreland fells, that after all she (Alice) might as well marry her (Alice) cousin, since that other marriage was then beyond her (Alice) reach! Her (Alice) two cousins had succeeded in blighting all the hopes of her (Alice) life;--but what could she (Alice) now think of herself in that she (Alice) had been so weak as to submit to such usage from their hands? Alas!--she (Alice) told herself, admitting in her (Alice) misery all her (Alice) weakness,--alas, she (Alice) had no mother. She (Alice) had gloried in her (Alice) independence, and this had come of it! She (Alice) had scorned the prudence of Lady Macleod, and her (Macleod) scorn had brought her (Macleod) to this pass!

Was she (Macleod) to give herself bodily,--body and soul, as she (Macleod) said aloud in her (Macleod) solitary agony,--to a man whom she (Macleod) did not love? Must she (Macleod) submit to his (man) caresses,--lie on his (man) bosom,--turn herself warmly to his (man) kisses?

``No,'' (she)
she (Macleod) said,
``no,'' (she)
--speaking audibly, as she (Macleod) walked about the room;
``no;--it was not in my bargain; I never meant it.'' (she)
But if so what had she (Macleod) meant;--what had been her (Macleod) dream? Of what marriage had she (Macleod) thought, when she (Macleod) was writing that letter back to George Vavasor? How am I to analyse her (Macleod) mind, and make her (Macleod) thoughts and feelings intelligible to those who may care to trouble themselves with the study? Any sacrifice she (Macleod) would make for her (Macleod) cousin which one friend could make for another. She (Macleod) would fight his (friend) battles with her (Macleod) money, with her (Macleod) words, with her (Macleod) sympathy. She (Macleod) would sit with him (friend) if he (friend) needed it, and speak comfort to him (friend) by the hour. His (friend) disgrace should be her (Macleod) disgrace;--his (friend) glory her (Macleod) glory;--his (friend) pursuits her (Macleod) pursuits. Was not that the marriage to which she (Macleod) had consented? But he (friend) had come to her (Macleod) and asked her (Macleod) for a kiss, and she (Macleod) had shuddered before him (friend), when he (friend) made the demand. Then that other one had come and had touched her (Macleod) hand, and the fibres of her (Macleod) body had seemed to melt within her (Macleod) at the touch, so that she (Macleod) could have fallen at his (friend) feet.

She (Macleod) had done very wrong. She (Macleod) knew that she (Macleod) had done wrong. She (Macleod) knew that she (Macleod) had sinned with that sin which specially disgraces a woman. She (Macleod) had said that she (Macleod) would become the wife of a man to whom she (Macleod) could not cleave with a wife's love; and, mad with a vile ambition, she (Macleod) had given up the man for whose modest love her (Macleod) heart was longing. She (Macleod) had thrown off from her (Macleod) that wondrous aroma of precious delicacy, which is the greatest treasure of womanhood. She (Macleod) had sinned against her (Macleod) sex; and, in an agony of despair, as she (Macleod) crouched down upon the floor with her (Macleod) head against her (Macleod) chair, she (Macleod) told herself that there was no pardon for her (Macleod). She (Macleod) understood it now, and knew that she (Macleod) could not forgive herself.

But can you forgive her (Macleod), delicate reader? Or am I asking the question too early in my story? For myself, I have forgiven her (Macleod). The story of the struggle has been present to my mind for many years,--and I have learned to think that even this offence against womanhood may, with deep repentance, be forgiven. And you also must forgive her (Macleod) before we close the book, or else my story will have been told amiss.

But let us own that she (Macleod) had sinned,--almost damnably, almost past forgiveness. What;--think that she (Macleod) knew what love meant, and not know which of two she (Macleod) loved! What;--doubt, of two men for whose arms she (Macleod) longed, of which the kisses would be sweet to bear; on which side lay the modesty of her (Macleod) maiden love! Faugh! She (Macleod) had submitted to pollution of heart and feeling before she (Macleod) had brought herself to such a pass as this. Come;--let us see if it be possible that she (Macleod) may be cleansed by the fire of her (Macleod) sorrow.

``What am I to do?'' (She)
She (Macleod) passed that whole day in asking herself that question. She (Macleod) was herself astounded at the rapidity with which the conviction had forced itself upon her (Macleod) that a marriage with her (Macleod) cousin would be to her (Macleod) almost impossible; and could she (Macleod) permit it to be said of her (Macleod) that she (Macleod) had thrice in her (Macleod) career jilted a promised suitor,--that three times she (Macleod) would go back from her (Macleod) word because her (Macleod) fancy had changed? Where could she (Macleod) find the courage to tell her (Macleod) father, to tell Kate, to tell even George himself, that her (Macleod) purpose was again altered? But she (Macleod) had a year at her (Macleod) disposal. If only during that year he (George) would take her (Macleod) money and squander it, and then require nothing further of her (Macleod) hands, might she (Macleod) not thus escape the doom before her (Macleod)? Might it not be possible that the refusal should this time come from him (George)? But she (Macleod) succeeded in making one resolve. She (Macleod) thought at least that she (Macleod) succeeded. Come what might, she (Macleod) would never stand with him (George) at the altar. While there was a cliff from which she (Macleod) might fall, water that would cover her (Macleod), a death-dealing grain that might be mixed in her (Macleod) cup, she (Macleod) could not submit herself to be George Vavasor's wife. To no ear could she (Macleod) tell of this resolve. To no friend could she (Macleod) hint her (Macleod) purpose. She (Macleod) owed her (Macleod) money to the man after what had passed between them. It was his (man) right to count upon such assistance as that would give him (man), and he (man) should have it. Only as his (man) betrothed she (Macleod) could give it him (man), for she (Macleod) understood well that if there were any breach between them, his (man) accepting of such aid would be impossible. He (man) should have her (Macleod) money, and then, when the day came, some escape should be found.

In the afternoon her (her) father came to her (her), and it may be as well to explain that Mr. Grey had seen him (Grey) again that day. Mr. Grey, when he (Grey) left Queen Anne Street, had gone to his (Grey) lawyer, and from thence had made his (Grey) way to Mr. Vavasor. It was between five and six when Mr. Vavasor came back to his (Vavasor) house, and he (Vavasor) then found his (Vavasor) daughter sitting over the drawing-room fire, without lights, in the gloom of the evening. Mr. Vavasor had returned with Grey to the lawyer's chambers, and had from thence come direct to his (Vavasor) own house. He (Vavasor) had been startled at the precision with which all the circumstances of his (Vavasor) daughter's position had been explained to a mild-eyed old gentleman, with a bald head, who carried on his (Vavasor) business in a narrow, dark, clean street, behind Doctors' Commons. Mr. Tombe was his (Tombe) name.

``No;'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
Mr. Grey had said, when Mr. Vavasor had asked as to the peculiar nature of Mr. Tombe's business;
``he (my) is not specially an ecclesiastical lawyer. He (my) had a partner at Ely, and was always employed by my father, and by most of the clergy there.'' (Mr. Tombe)
Mr. Tombe had evinced no surprise, no dismay, and certainly no mock delicacy, when the whole affair was under discussion. George Vavasor was to get present moneys, but,--if it could be so arranged--from John Grey's stores rather than from those belonging to Alice. Mr. Tombe could probably arrange that with Mr. Vavasor's lawyer, who would no doubt be able to make difficulty as to raising ready money. Mr. Tombe would be able to raise ready money without difficulty. And then, at last, George Vavasor was to be made to surrender his (Vavasor) bride, taking or having taken the price of his (Vavasor) bargain. John Vavasor sat by in silence as the arrangement was being made, not knowing how to speak. He (Vavasor) had no money with which to give assistance.
``I wish you to understand from the lady's father,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
Grey said to the lawyer,
``that the marriage would be regarded by him (father) with as much dismay as by myself.'' (the lawyer)

``Certainly;--it would be ruinous,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
Mr. Vavasor had answered.

``And you see, Mr. Tombe,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
Mr. Grey went on,
``we only wish to try the man. If he (Tombe) be not such as we believe him (Tombe) to be, he (Tombe) can prove it by his (Tombe) conduct. If he (Tombe) is worthy of her (father), he (Tombe) can then take her (father).'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)

``You merely wish to open her (father) eyes, Mr. Grey,'' (the lawyer)
said the mild-eyed lawyer.

``I wish that he (Grey) should have what money he (Grey) wants, and then we shall find what it is he (Grey) really wishes.'' (unknown)

``Yes; we shall know our man,'' (the lawyer)
said the lawyer.
``He (Grey) shall have the money, Mr. Grey,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
and so the interview had been ended.

Mr. Vavasor, when he (Vavasor) entered the drawing-room, addressed his (Vavasor) daughter in a cheery voice.

``What; all in the dark?'' (unknown)

``Yes, papa. Why should I have candles when I am doing nothing? I did not expect you.'' (unknown)

``No; I suppose not. I came here because I want to say a few words to you about business.'' (unknown)

``What business, papa?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice well understood the tone of her (Alice) father's voice. He (Vavasor) was desirous of propitiating her (Alice); but was at the same time desirous of carrying some point in which he (Vavasor) thought it probable that she (Alice) would oppose him (Vavasor).

``Well; my love, if I understood you rightly, your cousin George wants some money.'' (unknown)

``I did not say that he (George) wants it now; but I think he (George) will want it before the time for the election comes.'' (unknown)

``If so, he (George) will want it at once. He (George) has not asked you for it yet?'' (unknown)

``No; he (George) has merely said that should he (George) be in need he (George) would take me at my word.'' (unknown)

``I think there is no doubt that he (George) wants it. Indeed, I believe that he (George) is almost entirely without present means of his (George) own.'' (unknown)

``I can hardly think so; but I have no knowledge about it. I can only say that he (George) has not asked me yet, and that I should wish to oblige him (George) whenever he (George) may do so.'' (unknown)

``To what extent, Alice?'' (unknown)

``I don't know what I have. I get about four hundred a year, but I do not know what it is worth, or how far it can all be turned into money. I should wish to keep a hundred a year and let him (George) have the rest.'' (unknown)

``What; eight thousand pounds!'' (the father)
said the father who in spite of his (father) wish not to oppose her (Alice), could not but express his (father) dismay.

``I do not imagine that he (George) will want so much; but if he (George) should, I wish that he (George) should have it.'' (unknown)

``Heaven and earth!'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
said John Vavasor.
``Of course we should have to give up the house.'' (He)
He (Vavasor) could not suppress his (Vavasor) trouble, or refrain from bursting out in agony at the prospect of such a loss.

``But he (George) has asked me for nothing yet, papa.'' (unknown)

``No, exactly; and perhaps he (papa) may not; but I wish to know what to do when the demand is made. I am not going to oppose you now; your money is your own, and you have a right to do with it as you please;--but would you gratify me in one thing?'' (unknown)

``What is it, papa?'' (unknown)

``When he (papa) does apply, let the amount be raised through me?'' (unknown)

``How through you?'' (unknown)

``Come to me; I mean, so that I may see the lawyer, and have the arrangements made.'' (he)
Then he (Vavasor) explained to her (Alice) that in dealing with large sums of money, it could not be right that she (Alice) should do so without his (Vavasor) knowledge, even though the property was her (Alice) own.
``I will promise you that I will not oppose your wishes,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) said. Then Alice undertook that when such case should arise the money should be raised through his (Vavasor) means.

The day but one following this she (Alice) received a letter from Lady Glencora, who was still at Matching Priory. It was a light-spirited, chatty, amusing letter, intended to be happy in its tone,--intended to have a flavour of happiness, but just failing through the too apparent meaning of a word here and there.

``You will see that I am at Matching,'' (unknown)
the letter said,
``whereas you will remember that I was to have been at Monkshade. I escaped at last by a violent effort, and am now passing my time innocently,--I fear not so profitably as she (I) would induce me to do,--with Iphy Palliser. You remember Iphy. She (I) is a good creature, and would fain turn even me to profit, if it were possible. I own that I am thinking of them all at Monkshade, and am in truth delighted that I am not there. My absence is entirely laid upon your shoulders. That wicked evening amidst the ruins! Poor ruins. I go there alone sometimes and fancy that I hear such voices from the walls, and see such faces through the broken windows! All the old Pallisers come and frown at me, and tell me that I am not good enough to belong to them. There is a particular window to which Sir Guy comes and makes faces at me. I told Iphy the other day, and she (them) answered me very gravely, that I might, if I chose, make myself good enough for the Pallisers. Even for the Pallisers! Isn't that beautiful?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

Then Lady Glencora went on to say, that her (Glencora) husband intended to come up to London early in the session, and that she (Glencora) would accompany him (husband).

``That is,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
added Lady Glencora,
``if I am still good enough for the Pallisers at that time.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

CHAPTER XXXVIII.

The Inn at Shap.

When George Vavasor left Mr. Scruby's office--the attentive reader will remember that he (reader) did call upon Mr. Scruby, the Parliamentary lawyer, and there recognised the necessity of putting himself in possession of a small sum of money with as little delay as possible;--when he (Scruby) left the attorney's office, he (Scruby) was well aware that the work to be done was still before him (Scruby). And he (Scruby) knew also that the job to be undertaken was a very disagreeable job. He (Scruby) did not like the task of borrowing his (Scruby) cousin Alice's money.

We all of us know that swindlers and rogues do very dirty tricks, and we are apt to picture to ourselves a certain amount of gusto and delight on the part of the swindlers in the doing of them. In this, I think we are wrong. The poor, broken, semi-genteel beggar, who borrows half-sovereigns apiece from all his (beggar) old acquaintances, knowing that they know that he (beggar) will never repay them, suffers a separate little agony with each petition that he (beggar) makes. He (beggar) does not enjoy pleasant sailing in this journey which he (beggar) is making. To be refused is painful to him (beggar). To get his (beggar) half sovereign with scorn is painful. To get it with apparent confidence in his (beggar) honour is almost more painful.

``D-- it,'' (he)
he (beggar) says to himself on such rare occasions,
``I will pay that fellow;'' (he)
and yet, as he (beggar) says it, he (beggar) knows that he (beggar) never will pay even that fellow. It is a comfortless unsatisfying trade, that of living upon other people's money.

How was George Vavasor to make his (Vavasor) first step towards getting his (Vavasor) hand into his (Vavasor) cousin's purse? He (Vavasor) had gone to her (it) asking for her (it) love, and she (it) had shuddered when he (Vavasor) asked her (it). That had been the commencement of their life under their new engagement. He (Vavasor) knew very well that the money would be forthcoming when he (Vavasor) demanded it,--but under their present joint circumstances, how was he (Vavasor) to make the demand? If he (Vavasor) wrote to her (it), should he (Vavasor) simply ask for money, and make no allusion to his (Vavasor) love? If he (Vavasor) went to her (it) in person, should he (Vavasor) make his (Vavasor) visit a mere visit of business,--as he (Vavasor) might call on his (Vavasor) banker?

He (Vavasor) resolved at last that Kate should do the work for him (Vavasor). Indeed, he (Vavasor) had felt all along that it would be well that Kate should act as ambassador between him (ambassador) and Alice in money matters, as she (Alice) had long done in other things. He (ambassador) could talk to Kate as he (ambassador) could not talk to Alice;--and then, between the women, those hard money necessities would be softened down by a romantic phraseology which he (ambassador) would not himself know how to use with any effect. He (ambassador) made up his (ambassador) mind to see Kate, and with this view he (ambassador) went down to Westmoreland; and took himself to a small wayside inn at Shap among the fells, which had been known to him (ambassador) of old. He (ambassador) gave his (ambassador) sister notice that he (ambassador) would be there, and begged her (sister) to come over to him (ambassador) as early as she (sister) might find it possible on the morning after his (ambassador) arrival. He (ambassador) himself reached the place late in the evening by train from London. There is a station at Shap, by which the railway company no doubt conceives that it has conferred on that somewhat rough and remote locality all the advantages of a refined civilization; but I doubt whether the Shappites have been thankful for the favour. The landlord at the inn, for one, is not thankful. Shap had been a place owing all such life as it had possessed to coaching and posting. It had been a stage on the high road from Lancaster to Carlisle, and though it lay high and bleak among the fells, and was a cold, windy, thinly-populated place,--filling all travellers with thankfulness that they had not been made Shappites, nevertheless, it had had its glory in its coaching and posting. I have no doubt that there are men and women who look back with a fond regret to the palmy days of Shap.

Vavasor reached the little inn about nine in the evening on a night that was pitchy dark, and in a wind which made it necessary for him (it) to hold his (it) hat on to his (it) head.

``What a beastly country to live in,'' (he)
he (it) said to himself, resolving that he (it) would certainly sell Vavasor Hall in spite of all family associations, if ever the power to do so should be his (it).
``What trash it is,'' (he)
he (it) said,
``hanging on to such a place as that without the means of living like a gentleman, simply because one's ancestors have done so.'' (he)
And then he (it) expressed a doubt to himself whether all the world contained a more ignorant, opinionated, useless old man than his (man) grandfather,--or, in short, a greater fool.

``Well, Mr. George,'' (he)
said the landlord as soon as he (man) saw him (man),
``a sight of you's guid for sair een. It's o'er lang since you've been doon amang the fells.'' (him)
But George did not want to converse with the innkeeper, or to explain how it was that he (George) did not visit Vavasor Hall. The innkeeper, no doubt, knew all about it,--knew that the grandfather had quarrelled with his (grandfather) grandson, and knew the reason why; but George, if he (George) suspected such knowledge, did not choose to refer to it. So he (George) simply grunted something in reply, and getting himself in before a spark of fire which hardly was burning in a public room with a sandy floor, begged that the little sitting-room up-stairs might be got ready for him (George). There he (George) passed the evening in solitude, giving no encouragement to the landlord, who, nevertheless, looked him (George) up three or four times,--till at last George said that his (George) head ached, and that he (George) would wish to be alone.
``He (George) was always one of them cankery chiels as never have a kindly word for man nor beast,'' (unknown)
said the landlord.
``Seems as though that raw slash in his (man) face had gone right through into his (man) heart.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
After that George was left alone, and sat thinking whether it would not be better to ask Alice for two thousand pounds at once,--so as to save him (George) from the disagreeable necessity of a second borrowing before their marriage. He (George) was very uneasy in his (George) mind. He (George) had flattered himself through it all that his (George) cousin had loved him (George). He (George) had felt sure that such was the case while they were together in Switzerland. When she (Alice) had determined to give up John Grey, of course he (Grey) had told himself the same thing. When she (Alice) had at once answered his (Grey) first subsequent overture with an assent, he (Grey) had of course been certain that it was so. Dark, selfish, and even dishonest as he (Grey) was, he (Grey) had, nevertheless, enjoyed something of a lover's true pleasure in believing that Alice had still loved him (Grey) through all their mischances. But his (Grey) joy had in a moment been turned into gall during that interview in Queen Anne Street. He (Grey) had read the truth at a glance. A man must be very vain, or else very little used to such matters, who at George Vavasor's age cannot understand the feelings with which a woman receives him (Vavasor). When Alice contrived as she (Alice) had done to escape the embrace he (Vavasor) was so well justified in asking, he (Vavasor) knew the whole truth. He (Vavasor) was sore at heart, and very angry withal. He (Vavasor) could have readily spurned her (Alice) from him (Vavasor), and rejected her (Alice) who had once rejected him (Vavasor). He (Vavasor) would have done so had not his (Vavasor) need for her (Alice) money restrained him (Vavasor). He (Vavasor) was not a man who could deceive himself in such matters. He (Vavasor) knew that this was so, and he (Vavasor) told himself that he (Vavasor) was a rascal.

Vavasor Hall was, by the road, about five miles from Shap, and it was not altogether an easy task for Kate to get over to the village without informing her (Kate) grandfather that the visit was to be made, and what was its purport. She (Kate) could, indeed, walk, and the walk would not be so long as that she (Kate) had taken with Alice to Swindale fell;--but walking to an inn on a high road, is not the same thing as walking to a point on a hill side over a lake. Had she (Alice) been dirty, draggled, and wet through on Swindale fell, it would have simply been matter for mirth; but her (Alice) brother she (Alice) knew would not have liked to see her (Alice) enter the Lowther Arms at Shap in such a condition. It, therefore, became necessary that she (Alice) should ask her (Alice) grandfather to lend her (Alice) the jaunting car.

``Where do you want to go?'' (he)
he (grandfather) asked sharply. In such establishments as that at Vavasor Hall the family horse is generally used for double duties. Though he (grandfather) draws the lady of the house one day, he (grandfather) is not too proud to draw manure on the next. And it will always be found that the master of the house gives a great preference to the manure over the lady. The squire at Vavasor had come to do so to such an extent that he (squire) regarded any application for the animal's services as an encroachment.

``Only to Shap, grandpapa.'' (unknown)

``To Shap! what on earth can take you to Shap? There are no shops at Shap.'' (unknown)

``I am not going to do shopping. I want to see some one there.'' (unknown)

``Whom can you want to see at Shap?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

Then it occurred to Kate on the spur of the moment that she (Kate) might as well tell her (Kate) grandfather the fact.

``My brother has come down,'' (she)
she (Kate) said;
``and is at the inn there. I had not intended to tell you, as I did not wish to mention his (brother) name till you had consented to receive him (brother) here.'' (she)

``And he (brother) expects to come here now;--does he (brother)?'' (the squire)
said the squire.

``Oh, no, sir. I think he (brother) has no expectation of the kind. He (brother) has come down simply to see me;--about business I believe.'' (unknown)

``Business! what business? I suppose he (brother) wants to get your money from you?'' (unknown)

``I think it is with reference to his (brother) marriage. I think he (brother) wants me to use my influence with Alice that it may not be delayed.'' (unknown)

``Look here, Kate; if ever you lend him (brother) your money, or any of it,--that is, of the principal I mean,--I will never speak to him (principal) again under any circumstance. And more than that! Look here, Kate. In spite of all that has past and gone, the property will become his (principal) for his (principal) life when I die,--unless I change my will. If he (principal) gets your money from you, I will change it, and he (principal) shall not be a shilling richer at my death than he (principal) is now. You can have the horse to go to Shap.'' (the squire)

What unlucky chance had it been which had put this idea into the old squire's head on this especial morning? Kate had resolved that she (Kate) would entreat her (Kate) brother to make use of her (Kate) little fortune. She (Kate) feared that he (brother) was now coming with some reference to his (brother) cousin's money,--that something was to be done to enable him (brother) to avail himself of his (brother) cousin's offer; and Kate, almost blushing in the solitude of her (Kate) chamber at the thought, was determined that her (Kate) brother must be saved from such temptation. She (Kate) knew that money was necessary to him (brother). She (Kate) knew that he (brother) could not stand a second contest without assistance. With all their confidences, he (brother) had never told her (Kate) much of his (brother) pecuniary circumstances in the world, but she (Kate) was almost sure that he (brother) was a poor man. He (brother) had said as much as that to her (Kate), and in his (brother) letter desiring her (Kate) to come to him (brother) at Shap, he (brother) had inserted a word or two purposely intended to prepare her (Kate) mind for monetary considerations.

As she (Kate) was jogged along over the rough road to Shap, she (Kate) made up her (Kate) mind that Aunt Greenow would be the proper person to defray the expense of the coming election. To give Kate her (Kate) due she (Kate) would have given up every shilling of her (Kate) own money without a moment's hesitation, or any feeling that her (Kate) brother would be wrong to accept it. Nor would she (Kate), perhaps, have been unalterably opposed to his (brother) taking Alice's money, had Alice simply been his (brother) cousin. She (Alice) felt that as Vavasors they were bound to stand by the future head of the family in an attempt which was to be made, as she (Alice) felt, for the general Vavasor interest. But she (Alice) could not endure to think that her (Alice) brother should take the money of the girl whom he (brother) was engaged to marry. Aunt Greenow's money she (Greenow) thought was fair game. Aunt Greenow herself had made various liberal offers to herself which Kate had declined, not caring to be under pecuniary obligations even to Aunt Greenow without necessity; but she (Greenow) felt that for such a purpose as her (Greenow) brother's contest, she (Greenow) need not hesitate to ask for assistance, and she (Greenow) thought also that such assistance would be forthcoming.

``Grandpapa knows that you are here, George,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, when their first greeting was over.

``The deuce he (George) does! and why did you tell him (George)?'' (unknown)

``I could not get the car to come in without letting him (George) know why I wanted it.'' (unknown)

``What nonsense! as if you couldn't have made any excuse! I was particularly anxious that he (George) should not guess that I am here.'' (unknown)

``I don't see that it can make any difference, George.'' (unknown)

``But I see that it can,--a very great difference. It may prevent my ever being able to get near him (George) again before he (George) dies. What did he (George) say about my coming?'' (unknown)

``He (George) didn't say much.'' (unknown)

``He (George) made no offer as to my going there?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``I should not have gone if he (George) had. I don't know now that I ever shall go. To be there to do any good,--so as to make him (George) alter his (George) will, and leave me in the position which I have a right to expect, would take more time than the whole property is worth. And he (George) would endeavour to tie me down in some way I could not stand;--perhaps ask me to give up my notion for going into Parliament.'' (unknown)

``He (George) might ask you, but he (George) would not make it ground for another quarrel, if you refused.'' (unknown)

``He (George) is so unreasonable and ignorant that I am better away from him (George). But, Kate, you have not congratulated me on my matrimonial prospects.'' (unknown)

``Indeed I did, George, when I wrote to you.'' (unknown)

``Did you? well; I had forgotten. I don't know that any very strong congratulatory tone is necessary. As things go, perhaps it may be as well for all of us, and that's about the best that can be said for it.'' (unknown)

``Oh, George!'' (unknown)

``You see I'm not romantic, Kate, as you are. Half a dozen children with a small income do not generally present themselves as being desirable to men who wish to push their way in the world.'' (unknown)

``You know you have always longed to make her (Kate) your wife.'' (unknown)

``I don't know anything of the kind. You have always been under a match-making hallucination on that point. But in this case you have been so far successful, and are entitled to your triumph.'' (unknown)

``I don't want any triumph; you ought to know that.'' (unknown)

``But I'll tell you what I do want, Kate. I want some money.'' (he)
Then he (brother) paused, but as she (Kate) did not answer immediately, he (brother) was obliged to go on speaking.
``I'm not at all sure that I have not been wrong in making this attempt to get into Parliament,--that I'm not struggling to pick fruit which is above my reach.'' (unknown)

``Don't say that, George.'' (unknown)

``Ah, but I can't help feeling it. I need hardly tell you that I am ready to risk anything of my own. If I know myself I would toss up to-morrow, or for the matter of that to-day, between the gallows and a seat in the House. But I cannot go on with this contest by risking what is merely my own. Money, for immediate use, I have none left, and my neck, though I were ever so willing to risk it, is of no service.'' (unknown)

``Whatever I have can be yours to-morrow,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, in a hesitating voice, which too plainly pronounced her (Kate) misery as she (Kate) made the offer. She (Kate) could not refrain herself from making it. Though her (Kate) grandfather's threat was ringing in her (Kate) ears,--though she (Kate) knew that she (Kate) might be ruining her (Kate) brother by proposing such a loan, she (Kate) had no alternative. When her (Kate) brother told her (Kate) of his (brother) want of money, she (Kate) could not abstain from tendering to him (brother) the use of what was her (Kate) own.

``No;'' (he)
said he (brother).
``I shall not take your money.'' (unknown)

``You would not scruple, if you knew how welcome you are.'' (unknown)

``At any rate, I shall not take it. I should not think it right. All that you have would only just suffice for my present wants, and I should not choose to make you a beggar. There would, moreover, be a difficulty about readjusting the payment.'' (unknown)

``There would be no difficulty, because no one need be consulted but us two.'' (unknown)

``I should not think it right, and therefore let there be an end of it,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George in a tone of voice which had in it something of magniloquence.

``What is it you wish then?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, who knew too well what he (George) did wish.

``I will explain to you. When Alice and I are married, of course there will be a settlement made on her (Alice), and as we are both the grandchildren of the old squire I shall propose that the Vavasor property shall be hers for life in the event of her (Alice) outliving me.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

``And if this be done, there can be no harm in my forestalling some of her (Alice) property, which, under the circumstances of such a settlement, would of course become mine when we are married.'' (unknown)

``But the squire might leave the property to whom he (squire) pleases.'' (unknown)

``We know very well that he (squire) won't, at any rate, leave it out of the family. In fact, he (squire) would only be too glad to consent to such an agreement as that I have proposed, because he (squire) would thereby rob me of all power in the matter.'' (unknown)

``But that could not be done till you are married.'' (unknown)

``Look here, Kate;--don't you make difficulties.'' (he)
And now, as he (George) looked at her (Kate), the cicature on his (George) face seemed to open and yawn at her (Kate).
``If you mean to say that you won't help me, do say so, and I will go back to London.'' (unknown)

``I would do anything in my power to help you,--that was not wrong!'' (unknown)

``Yes; anybody could say as much as that. That is not much of an offer if you are to keep to yourself the power of deciding what is wrong. Will you write to Alice,--or better still, go to her (Alice), and explain that I want the money.'' (unknown)

``How can I go to London now?'' (unknown)

``You can do it very well, if you choose. But if that be too much, then write to her (Alice). It will come much better from you than from me; write to her (Alice), and explain that I must pay in advance the expenses of this contest, and that I cannot look for success unless I do so. I did not think that the demand would come so quick on me; but they know that I am not a man of capital, and therefore I cannot expect them to carry on the fight for me, unless they know that the money is sure. Scruby has been bitten two or three times by these metropolitan fellows, and he (Scruby) is determined that he (Scruby) will not be bitten again.'' (he)
Then he (George) paused for Kate to speak.

``George,'' (she)
she (Kate) said, slowly.

``Well.'' (unknown)

``I wish you would try any other scheme but that.'' (unknown)

``There is no other scheme! That's so like a woman;--to quarrel with the only plan that is practicable.'' (unknown)

``I do not think you ought to take Alice's money.'' (unknown)

``My dear Kate, you must allow me to be the best judge of what I ought to do, and what I ought not to do. Alice herself understands the matter perfectly. She (Alice) knows that I cannot obtain this position, which is as desirable for her (Alice) as it is for me--'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

``And for me as much as for either,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, interrupting him (George).

``Very well. Alice, I say, knows that I cannot do this without money, and has offered the assistance which I want. I would rather that you should tell her (Alice) how much I want, and that I want it now, than that I should do so. That is all. If you are half the woman that I take you to be, you will understand this well enough.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

Kate did understand it well enough. She (Kate) was quite awake to the fact that her (Kate) brother was ashamed of the thing he (brother) was about to do,--so much ashamed of it that he (brother) was desirous of using her (Kate) voice instead of his (brother) own.

``I want you to write to her (woman) quite at once,'' (he)
he (brother) continued;
``since you seem to think that it is not worth while to take the trouble of a journey to London.'' (he)

``There is no question about the trouble,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``I would walk to London to get the money for you, if that were all.'' (unknown)

``Do you think that Alice will refuse to lend it me?'' (he)
said he (brother), looking into her (Kate) face.

``I am sure that she (Alice) would not, but I think that you ought not to take it from her (Alice). There seems to me to be something sacred about property that belongs to the girl you are going to marry.'' (unknown)

``If there is anything on earth I hate,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George, walking about the room,
``it is romance. If you keep it for reading in your bedroom, it's all very well for those who like it, but when it comes to be mixed up with one's business it plays the devil. If you would only sift what you have said, you would see what nonsense it is. Alice and I are to be man and wife. All our interests, and all our money, and our station in life, whatever it may be, are to be joint property. And yet she (Alice) is the last person in the world to whom I ought to go for money to improve her (Alice) prospects as well as my own. That's what you call delicacy. I call it infernal nonsense.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

``I tell you what I'll do, George. I'll ask Aunt Greenow to lend you the money,--or to lend it to me.'' (unknown)

``I don't believe she (Aunt)'d give me a shilling. Moreover, I want it quite immediately, and the time taken up in letter-writing and negotiations would be fatal to me. If you won't apply to Alice, I must. I want you to tell me whether you will oblige me in this matter.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

Kate was still hesitating as to her (Kate) answer, when there came a knock at the door, and a little crumpled note was brought up to her (Kate). A boy had just come with it across the fell from Vavasor Hall, and Kate, as soon as she (Kate) saw her (Kate) name on the outside, knew that it was from her (Kate) grandfather. It was as follows:--

``If George wishes to come to the Hall, let him (George) come. If he (George) chooses to tell me that he (George) regrets his (George) conduct to me, I will see him (George).'' (unknown)

``What is it?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George. Then Kate put the note into her (Kate) brother's hand.

``I'll do nothing of the kind,'' (he)
he (George) said.
``What good should I get by going to the old man's house?'' (unknown)

``Every good,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``If you don't go now you never can do so.'' (unknown)

``Never till it's my own,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``If you show him (man) that you are determined to be at variance with him (man), it never will be your own;--unless, indeed, it should some day come to you as part of Alice's fortune. Think of it, George; you would not like to receive everything from her (Alice).'' (He)

He (George) walked about the room, muttering maledictions between his (George) teeth and balancing, as best he (George) was able at such a moment, his (George) pride against his (George) profit.

``You haven't answered my question,'' (he)
said he (George).
``If I go to the Hall, will you write to Alice?'' (unknown)

``No, George; I cannot write to Alice asking her (Alice) for the money.'' (unknown)

``You won't?'' (unknown)

``I could not bring myself to do it.'' (unknown)

``Then, Kate, you and my grandfather may work together for the future. You may get him (grandfather) to leave you the place if you have skill enough.'' (unknown)

``That is as undeserved a reproach as any woman ever encountered,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, standing her (Kate) ground boldly before him (George).
``If you have either heart or conscience, you will feel that it is so.'' (unknown)

``I'm not much troubled with either one or the other, I fancy. Things are being brought to such a pass with me that I am better without them.'' (unknown)

``Will you take my money, George; just for the present?'' (unknown)

``No. I haven't much conscience; but I have a little left.'' (unknown)

``Will you let me write to Mrs. Greenow?'' (unknown)

``I have not the slightest objection; but it will be of no use whatsoever.'' (unknown)

``I will do so, at any rate. And now will you come to the Hall?'' (unknown)

``To beg that old fool's pardon? No; I won't. In the mood I am in at present, I couldn't do it. I should only anger him (fool) worse than ever. Tell him (fool) that I've business which calls me back to London at once.'' (unknown)

``It is a thousand pities.'' (unknown)

``It can't be helped.'' (unknown)

``It may make so great a difference to you for your whole life!'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
urged Kate.

``I'll tell you what I'll do,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.
``I'll go to Vavasor and put up with the old squire's insolence, if you'll make this application for me to Alice.'' (I)
I wonder whether it occurred to him (George) that his (George) sister desired his (George) presence at the Hall solely on his (George) own behalf. The same idea certainly did not occur to Kate. She (Kate) hesitated, feeling that she (Kate) would almost do anything to achieve a reconciliation between her (Kate) grandfather and her (Kate) brother.

``But you'll let me write to Aunt Greenow first,'' (she)
said she (Kate).
``It will take only two days,--or at the most three?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

To this George consented as though he (George) were yielding a great deal; and Kate, with a sore conscience, with a full knowledge that she (Kate) was undertaking to do wrong, promised that she (Kate) would apply to Alice for her (Alice) money, if sufficient funds should not be forthcoming from Mrs. Greenow. Thereupon, George graciously consented to proceed to his (George) bedroom, and put together his (George) clothes with a view to his (George) visit to the Hall.

``I thank Providence, Kate, that circumstances make it impossible for me to stay above two days. I have not linen to last me longer.'' (unknown)

``We'll manage that for you at the Hall.'' (unknown)

``Indeed you won't do anything of the kind. And look, Kate, when I make that excuse don't you offer to do so. I will stay there over to-morrow night, and shall go into Kendal early, so as to catch the express train up on Thursday morning. Don't you throw me over by any counter proposition.'' (unknown)

Then they started together in the car, and very few words were said till they reached the old lodge, which stood at the entrance to the place.

``Eh, Mr. George; be that you?'' (the woman)
said the old woman, who came out to swing back for them the broken gate.
``A sight of you is good for sair een.'' (the inn-keeper)
It was the same welcome that the inn-keeper had given him (George), and equally sincere. George had never made himself popular about the place, but he (George) was the heir.

``I suppose you had better go into the drawing-room,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate;
``while I go to my grandfather. You won't find a fire there.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

``Manage it how you please; but don't keep me in the cold very long. Heavens, what a country house! The middle of January, and no fires in the room.'' (unknown)

``And remember, George, when you see him (George) you must say that you regret that you ever displeased him (George). Now that you are here, don't let there be any further misunderstanding.'' (unknown)

``I think it very probable that there will be,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.
``I only hope he (George)'ll let me have the old horse to take me back to Shap if there is. There he (George) is at the front door, so I shan't have to go into the room without a fire.'' (The man)

The old man was standing at the hall steps when the car drove up, as though to welcome his (George) grandson. He (George) put out his (George) hand to help Kate down the steps, keeping his (George) eye all the time on George's face.

``So you've come back,'' (the squire)
the squire said to him (George).

-LSB-Illustration:

``So you've come back, have you?'' (the Squire)
said the Squire.-RSB-

``Yes, sir;--I've come back, like the prodigal son in the parable.'' (unknown)

``The prodigal son was contrite. I hope you are so.'' (unknown)

``Pretty well for that, sir. I'm sorry there has been any quarrel, and all that, you know.'' (unknown)

``Go in,'' (the squire)
said the squire, very angrily.
``Go in. To expect anything gracious from you would be to expect pearls from swine. Go in.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

George went in, shrugging his (George) shoulders as his (George) eyes met his (George) sister's. It was in this fashion that the reconciliation took place between Squire Vavasor and his (Squire) heir.

CHAPTER XXXIX.

Mr. Cheesacre's Hospitality.

As the winter wore itself away, Mr. Cheesacre, happy as he (Cheesacre) was amidst the sports of Norfolk, and prosperous as he (Cheesacre) might be with the augean spoils of Oileymead, fretted himself with an intense anxiety to bring to a close that affair which he (Cheesacre) had on his (Cheesacre) hands with the widow Greenow. There were two special dangers which disturbed him (Cheesacre). She (Greenow) would give herself and all her (Greenow) money to that adventurer, Bellfield; or else she (Greenow) would spend her (Greenow) own money so fast before he (adventurer) got hold upon it, that the prize would be greatly damaged.

``I'm -- if she (you) hasn't been and set up a carriage!'' (he)
he (adventurer) said to himself one day, as standing on the pavement of Tombland, in Norwich, he (adventurer) saw Mrs. Greenow issue forth from the Close in a private brougham, accompanied by one of the Fairstairs girls.
``She (you)'s been and set up her (you) carriage as sure as my name's Cheesacre!'' (he)

Whatever reason he (adventurer) might have to fear the former danger, we may declare that he (adventurer) had none whatever as to the latter. Mrs. Greenow knew what she (Greenow) was doing with her (Greenow) money as well as any lady in England. The private carriage was only a hired brougham taken by the month, and as to that boy in buttons whom she (Greenow) had lately established, why should she (Greenow) not keep a young servant, and call him (servant) a page, if it gave her (Greenow) any comfort to do so? If Mr. Cheesacre had also known that she (Greenow) had lent the Fairstairs family fifty pounds to help them through with some difficulty which Joe had encountered with the Norwich tradespeople, he (Joe) would have been beside himself with dismay. He (Joe) desired to obtain the prize unmutilated,--in all its fair proportions. Any such clippings he (Joe) regarded as robberies against himself.

But he (Joe) feared Bellfield more than he (Joe) feared the brougham. That all is fair in love and war was no doubt, at this period, Captain Bellfield's maxim, and we can only trust that he (Captain) found in it some consolation, or ease to his (Captain) conscience, in regard to the monstrous lies which he (Captain) told his (Captain) friend. In war, no doubt, all stratagems are fair. The one general is quite justified in making the other believe that he (general) is far to the right, when in truth he (general) is turning his (general) enemy's left flank. If successful, he (general) will be put upon a pedestal for his (general) clever deceit, and crowned with laurels because of his (general) lie. If Bellfield could only be successful, and achieve for himself the mastery over those forty thousand pounds, the world would forgive him (general) and place, on his (general) brow also, some not uncomfortable crown. In the mean time, his (general) stratagems were as deep and his (general) lies as profound as those of any general.

It must not be supposed that Cheesacre ever believed him (Cheesacre). In the first place, he (Cheesacre) knew that Bellfield was not a man to be believed in any way. Had he (Cheesacre) not been living on lies for the last ten years? But then a man may lie in such a way as to deceive, though no one believe him (man). Mr. Cheesacre was kept in an agony of doubt while Captain Bellfield occupied his (Cheesacre) lodgings in Norwich. He (Cheesacre) fee'd Jeannette liberally. He (Cheesacre) even fee'd Charlie Fairstairs,--Miss Fairstairs I mean,--with gloves, and chickens from Oileymead, so that he (Fairstairs) might know whether that kite fluttered about his (Fairstairs) dovecoat, and of what nature were the flutterings. He (Fairstairs) went even further than this, and fee'd the Captain himself,--binding him (Captain) down not to flutter as value given in return for such fees. He (Captain) attempted even to fee the widow,--cautioning her (widow) against the fluttering, as he (Captain) tendered to her (widow), on his (Captain) knees, a brooch as big as a breast-plate. She (widow) waved aside the breast-plate, declaring that the mourning ring which contained poor Greenow's final grey lock of hair, was the last article from a jeweller's shop which should ever find a place about her (Greenow) person. At the same time she (Greenow) declared that Captain Bellfield was nothing to her (Bellfield); Mr. Cheesacre need have no fears in that quarter. But then, she (Bellfield) added, neither was he (Cheesacre) to have any hope. Her (Bellfield) affections were all buried under the cold sod. This was harassing. Nevertheless, though no absolute satisfaction was to be attained in the wooing of Mrs. Greenow, there was a pleasantness in the occupation which ought to have reconciled her (Greenow) suitors to their destiny. With most ladies, when a gentleman has been on his (gentleman) knees before one of them in the morning, with outspoken protestations of love, with clearly defined proffers of marriage, with a minute inventory of the offerer's worldly wealth,--down even to the

``mahogany-furnitured'' (the offerer)
bed-chambers, as was the case with Mr. Cheesacre, and when all these overtures have been peremptorily declined,--a gentleman in such a case, I say, would generally feel some awkwardness in sitting down to tea with the lady at the close of such a performance. But with Mrs. Greenow there was no such awkwardness. After an hour's work of the nature above described she (Greenow) would play the hostess with a genial hospitality, that eased off all the annoyance of disappointment; and then at the end of the evening, she (Greenow) would accept a squeeze of the hand, a good, palpable, long-protracted squeeze, with that sort of
``don't;--have done now,'' (she)
by which Irish young ladies allure their lovers. Mr. Cheesacre, on such occasions, would leave the Close, swearing that she (Greenow) should be his (Cheesacre) on the next market-day,--or at any rate, on the next Saturday. Then, on the Monday, tidings would reach him (Cheesacre) that Bellfield had passed all Sunday afternoon with his (Cheesacre) lady-love,--Bellfield, to whom he (Cheesacre) had lent five pounds on purpose that he (Cheesacre) might be enabled to spend that very Sunday with some officers of the Suffolk volunteers at Ipswich. And hearing this, he (Cheesacre) would walk out among those rich heaps, at the back of his (Cheesacre) farmyard, uttering deep curses against the falsehood of men and the fickleness of women.

Driven to despair, he (Cheesacre) at last resolved to ask Bellfield to come to Oileymead for a month. That drilling at Norwich, or the part of it which was supposed to be profitable, was wearing itself out. Funds were low with the Captain,--as he (Captain) did not scruple to tell his (Captain) friend Cheesacre, and he (Captain) accepted the invitation.

``I'll mount you with the harriers, old fellow,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
Cheesacre had said;
``and give you a little shooting. Only I won't have you go out when I'm not with you.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
Bellfield agreed, Each of them understood the nature of the bargain; though Bellfield, I think, had somewhat the clearer understanding in the matter. He (Cheesacre) would not be so near the widow as he (Cheesacre) had been at Norwich, but he (Cheesacre) would not be less near than his (Cheesacre) kind host. And his (Cheesacre) host would no doubt watch him (Cheesacre) closely;--but then he (Cheesacre) also could watch his (Cheesacre) host. There was a railway station not two miles from Oileymead, and the journey thence into Norwich was one of half an hour. Mr. Cheesacre would doubtless be very jealous of such journeys, but with all his (Cheesacre) jealousy he (Cheesacre) could not prevent them. And then, in regard to this arrangement, Mr. Cheesacre paid the piper, whereas Captain Bellfield paid nothing. Would it not be sweet to him (Cheesacre) if he (Cheesacre) could carry off his (Cheesacre) friend's prize from under the very eaves of his (Cheesacre) friend's house?

And Mrs. Greenow also understood the arrangement.

``Going to Oileymead; are you?'' (she)
she (Greenow) said when Captain Bellfield came to tell her (Bellfield) of his (Captain) departure. Charlie Fairstairs was with her (Bellfield), so that the Captain could not utilize the moment in any special way.
``It's quite delightful,'' (the widow)
continued the widow,
``to see how fond you two gentlemen are of each other.'' (the widow)

``I think gentlemen always like to go best to gentlemen's houses where there are no ladies,'' (Charlie/Charlie Fairstairs)
said Charlie Fairstairs, whose career in life had not as yet been satisfactory to her (widow).

``As for that,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
said Bellfield,
``I wish with all my heart that dear old Cheesy would get a wife. He (fellow) wants a wife badly, if ever a man did, with all that house full of blankets and crockery. Why don't you set your cap at him (man), Miss Fairstairs?'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)

``What;--at a farmer!'' (Charlie/Charlie Fairstairs)
said Charlie who was particularly anxious that her (Bellfield) dear friend, Mrs. Greenow, should not marry Mr. Cheesacre, and who weakly thought to belittle him (Cheesacre) accordingly.

``Give him (farmer) my kind love,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, thereby resenting the impotent interference.
``And look here, Captain Bellfield, suppose you both dine with me next Saturday. He (Captain) always comes in on Saturday, and you might as well come too.'' (Captain)

Captain Bellfield declared that he (Captain) would only be too happy.

``And Charlie shall come to set her (Bellfield) cap at Mr. Cheesacre,'' (the widow)
said the widow, turning a soft and gracious eye on the Captain.

``I shall be happy to come,'' (Charlie/Charlie Fairstairs)
--said Charlie, quite delighted;
``but not with that object. Mr. Cheesacre is very respectable, I'm sure.'' (Charlie/Charlie Fairstairs)
Charlie's mother had been the daughter of a small squire who had let his (Charlie) land to tenants, and she (mother) was, therefore, justified by circumstances in looking down upon a farmer.

The matter was so settled,--pending the consent of Mr. Cheesacre; and Bellfield went out to Oileymead. He (Cheesacre) knew the ways of the house, and was not surprised to find himself left alone till after dusk; nor was he (Cheesacre) much surprised when he (Cheesacre) learned that he (Cheesacre) was not put into one of the mahogany-furnitured chambers, but into a back room looking over the farm-yard in which there was no fire-place. The Captain had already endured some of the evils of poverty, and could have put up with this easily had nothing been said about it. As it was, Cheesacre brought the matter forward, and apologized, and made the thing difficult.

``You see, old fellow,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) said,
``there are the rooms, and of course they're empty. But it's such a bore hauling out all the things and putting up the curtains. You'll be very snug where you are.'' (he)

``I shall do very well,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
said Bellfield rather sulkily.

``Of course you'll do very well. It's the warmest room in the house in one way.'' (He)
He (Cheesacre) did not say in what way. Perhaps the near neighbourhood of the stables may have had a warming effect.

Bellfield did not like it; but what is a poor man to do under such circumstances? So he (man) went up-stairs and washed his (man) hands before dinner in the room without a fire-place, flattering himself that he (man) would yet be even with his (man) friend Cheesacre.

They dined together not in the best humour, and after dinner they sat down to enjoy themselves with pipes and brandy and water. Bellfield, having a taste for everything that was expensive, would have preferred cigars; but his (Cheesacre) friend put none upon the table. Mr. Cheesacre, though he (Cheesacre) could spend his (Cheesacre) money liberally when occasion required such spending, knew well the value of domestic economy. He (Cheesacre) wasn't going to put himself out, as he (Cheesacre) called it, for Bellfield! What was good enough for himself was good enough for Bellfield.

``A beggar, you know; just a regular beggar!'' (he)
as he (Cheesacre) was betrayed into saying to Mrs. Greenow on some occasion just at this period.
``Poor fellow! He (fellow) only wants money to make him (fellow) almost perfect,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
Mrs. Greenow had answered;--and Mr. Cheesacre had felt that he (Cheesacre) had made a mistake.

Both the men became talkative, if not good-humoured, under the effects of the brandy and water, and the Captain then communicated Mrs. Greenow's invitation to Mr. Cheesacre. He (Cheesacre) had had his (Cheesacre) doubts as to the propriety of doing so,--thinking that perhaps it might be to his (Cheesacre) advantage to forget the message. But he (Cheesacre) reflected that he (Cheesacre) was at any rate a match for Cheesacre when they were present together, and finally came to the conclusion that the message should be delivered.

``I had to go and just wish her (You) goodbye you know,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) said apologetically, as he (Cheesacre) finished his (Cheesacre) little speech.

``I don't see that at all,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre.

``Why, my dear fellow, how foolishly jealous you are. If I were to be downright uncivil to her (You), as you would have me be, it would only call attention to the thing.'' (unknown)

``I'm not a bit jealous. A man who sits upon his (man) own ground as I do hasn't any occasion to be jealous.'' (unknown)

``I don't know what your own ground has to do with it,--but we'll let that pass.'' (unknown)

``I think it has a great deal to do with it. If a man does intend to marry he (man) ought to have things comfortable about him (man); unless he (man) wants to live on his (man) wife, which I look upon as about the meanest thing a man can do. By George, I'd sooner break stones than that.'' (any captain)

This was hard for any captain to bear,--even for Captain Bellfield; but he (Captain) did bear it,--looking forward to revenge.

``There's no pleasing you, I know,'' (he)
said he (Captain).
``But there's the fact. I went to say goodbye to her (wife), and she (wife) asked me to give you that message. Shall we go or not?'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)

Cheesacre sat for some time silent, blowing out huge clouds of smoke while he (Cheesacre) meditated a little plan.

``I'll tell you what it is, Bellfield,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) said at last.
``She (Bellfield)'s nothing to you, and if you won't mind it, I'll go. Mrs. Jones shall get you anything you like for dinner,--and,--and--I'll stand you a bottle of the '34 port!'' (Captain)

But Captain Bellfield was not going to put up with this. He (Captain) had not sold himself altogether to work Mr. Cheesacre's will.

``No, old fellow,'' (he)
said he (Cheesacre);
``that cock won't fight. She (Jones) has asked me to dine with her (Jones) on Saturday, and I mean to go. I don't intend that she (Jones) shall think that I'm afraid of her (Jones),--or of you either.'' (he)

``You don't;--don't you?'' (unknown)

``No, I don't,'' (the Captain)
said the Captain stoutly.

``I wish you'd pay me some of that money you owe me,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre.

``So I will,--when I've married the widow. Ha,--ha,--ha.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)

Cheesacre longed to turn him (Cheesacre) out of the house. Words to bid him (Cheesacre) go, were, so to say, upon his (Cheesacre) tongue. But the man would only have taken himself to Norwich, and would have gone without any embargo upon his (man) suit; all their treaties would then be at an end.

``She (widow) knows a trick worth two of that,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre at last.

``I dare say she (widow) does; and if so, why shouldn't I go and dine with her (widow) next Saturday?'' (unknown)

``I'll tell you why,--because you're in my way. The deuce is in it if I haven't made the whole thing clear enough. I've told you all my plans because I thought you were my friend, and I've paid you well to help me, too; and yet it seems to me you'd do anything in your power to throw me over,--only you can't.'' (unknown)

``What an ass you are,'' (the Captain)
said the Captain after a pause;
``just you listen to me. That scraggy young woman, Charlie Fairstairs, is to be there of course.'' (the Captain)

``How do you know?'' (unknown)

``I tell you that I do know. She (woman) was present when the whole thing was arranged, and I heard her (woman) asked, and heard her (woman) say that she (woman) would come;--and for the matter of that I heard her (woman) declare that she (woman) wouldn't set her (woman) cap at you, because you're a farmer.'' (unknown)

``Upon my word she (woman)'s kind. Upon my word she (woman) is,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre, getting very angry and very red.
``Charlie Fairstairs, indeed! I wouldn't pick her (woman) out of a gutter with a pair of tongs. She (woman) ain't good enough for my bailiff, let alone me.'' (unknown)

``But somebody must take her (woman) in hand on Saturday, if you're to do any good,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
said the crafty Bellfield.

``What the deuce does she (woman) have that nasty creature there for?'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre, who thought it very hard that everything should not be arranged exactly as he (Cheesacre) would desire.

``She (woman) wants a companion, of course. You can get rid of Charlie, you know, when you make her (woman) Mrs. Cheesacre.'' (unknown)

``Get rid of her (Cheesacre)! You don't suppose she (Cheesacre)'ll ever put her (Cheesacre) foot in this house. Not if I know it. I've detested that woman for the last ten years.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
Cheesacre could forgive no word of slight respecting his (Cheesacre) social position, and the idea of Miss Fairstairs having pretended to look down upon him (Cheesacre), galled him (Cheesacre) to the quick.

``You'll have to dine with her (woman) at any rate,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
said Bellfield,
``and I always think that four are better company than three on such occasions.'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)

Mr. Cheesacre grunted an unwilling assent, and after this it was looked upon as an arranged thing that they two should go into Norwich on the Saturday together, and that they should both dine with the widow. Indeed, Mrs. Greenow got two notes, one from each of them, accepting the invitation. Cheesacre wrote in the singular number, altogether ignoring Captain Bellfield, as he (Captain) might have ignored his (Captain) footman had he (Captain) intended to take one. The captain condescended to use the plural pronoun.

``We shall be so happy to come,'' (he)
said he (captain).
``Dear old Cheesy is out of his (Charlie) little wits with delight,'' (he)
he (captain) added,
``and has already begun to polish off the effects of the farmyard.'' (he)

``Effects of the farmyard,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow aloud, in Jeannette's hearing, when she (Greenow) received the note.
``It would be well for Captain Bellfield if he (Captain) had a few such effects himself.'' (unknown)

``You can give him (Captain) enough, ma'am,'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette,
``to make him (Captain) a better man than Mr. Cheesacre any day. And for a gentleman--of course I say nothing, but if I was a lady, I know which should be the man for me.'' (Jeannette)

CHAPTER XL.

Mrs. Greenow's Little Dinner in the Close.

How deep and cunning are the wiles of love! When that Saturday morning arrived not a word was said by Cheesacre to his (Cheesacre) rival as to his (Cheesacre) plans for the day.

``You'll take the dog-cart in?'' (Captain)
Captain Bellfield had asked overnight.
``I don't know what I shall do as yet,'' (he)
replied he (Captain) who was master of the house, of the dog-cart, and, as he (Captain) fondly thought, of the situation. But Bellfield knew that Cheesacre must take the dog-cart, and was contented. His (Cheesacre) friend would leave him (Cheesacre) behind, if it were possible, but Bellfield would take care that it should not be possible.

Before breakfast Mr. Cheesacre surreptitiously carried out into the yard a bag containing all his (Cheesacre) apparatus for dressing,--his (Cheesacre) marrow oil for his (Cheesacre) hair, his (Cheesacre) shirt with the wondrous worked front upon an under-stratum of pink to give it colour, his (Cheesacre) shiny boots, and all the rest of the paraphernalia.
