When dining in Norwich on ordinary occasions, he (Cheesacre) simply washed his (Cheesacre) hands there, trusting to the chambermaid at the inn to find him (Cheesacre) a comb; and now he (Cheesacre) came down with his (Cheesacre) bag surreptitiously, and hid it away in the back of the dog-cart with secret, but alas, not unobserved hands, hoping that Bellfield would forget his (Cheesacre) toilet. But when did such a Captain ever forget his (Captain) outward man? Cheesacre, as he (Cheesacre) returned through the kitchen from the yard into the front hall, perceived another bag lying near the door, apparently filled almost as well as his (Cheesacre) own.

``What the deuce are you going to do with all this luggage?'' (he)
said he (Cheesacre), giving the bag a kick.

``Put it where I saw you putting yours when I opened my window just now,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
said Bellfield.

``D-- the window,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
exclaimed Cheesacre, and then they sat down to breakfast.
``How you do hack that ham about,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) said.
``If you ever found hams yourself you'd be more particular in cutting them.'' (unknown)
This was very bad. Even Bellfield could not bear it with equanimity, and feeling unable to eat the ham under such circumstances, made his (ham) breakfast with a couple of fresh eggs.
``If you didn't mean to eat the meat, why the mischief did you cut it?'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre.

``Upon my word, Cheesacre, you're too bad;--upon my word you are,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
said Bellfield, almost sobbing.

``What's the matter now?'' (unknown)
said the other.

``Who wants your ham?'' (unknown)

``You do, I suppose, or you wouldn't cut it.'' (unknown)

``No I don't; nor anything else either that you've got. It isn't fair to ask a fellow into your house, and then say such things to him (fellow) as that. And it isn't what I've been accustomed to either; I can tell you that, Mr. Cheesacre.'' (unknown)

``Oh, bother!'' (unknown)

``It's all very well to say bother, but I choose to be treated like a gentleman wherever I go. You and I have known each other a long time, and I'd put up with more from you than from anyone else; but--'' (unknown)

``Can you pay me the money that you owe me, Bellfield?'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre, looking hard at him (Cheesacre).

``No, I can't,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
said Bellfield;
``not immediately.'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)

``Then eat your breakfast, and hold your tongue.'' (Captain)

After that Captain Bellfield did eat his (Captain) breakfast,--leaving the ham however untouched, and did hold his (ham) tongue, vowing vengeance in his (ham) heart. But the two men went into Norwich more amicably together than they would have done had there been no words between them. Cheesacre felt that he (Cheesacre) had trespassed a little, and therefore offered the Captain a cigar as he (Captain) seated himself in the cart. Bellfield accepted the offering, and smoked the weed of peace.

``Now,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre, as he (Cheesacre) drove into the Swan yard,
``what do you mean to do with yourself all day?'' (he)

``I shall go down to the quarters, and look the fellows up.'' (unknown)

``All right. But mind this, Bellfield;--it's an understood thing, that you're not to be in the Close before four?'' (unknown)

``I won't be in the Close before four!'' (unknown)

``Very well. That's understood. If you deceive me, I'll not drive you back to Oileymead to-night.'' (Captain)

In this instance Captain Bellfield had no intention to deceive. He (Captain) did not think it probable that he (Captain) could do himself any good by philandering about the widow early in the day. She (Bellfield) would be engaged with her (Bellfield) dinner and with an early toilet. Captain Bellfield, moreover, had learned from experience that the first comer has not always an advantage in ladies' society. The mind of a woman is greedy after novelty, and it is upon the stranger, or upon the most strange of her (woman) slaves around her (woman), that she (woman) often smiles the sweetest. The cathedral clock, therefore, had struck four before Captain Bellfield rang Mrs. Greenow's bell, and then, when he (Captain) was shown into the drawing-room, he (Captain) found Cheesacre there alone, redolent with the marrow oil, and beautiful with the pink bosom.

``Haven't you seen her (Bellfield) yet?'' (the Captain)
asked the Captain almost in a whisper.

``No,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre sulkily.

``Nor yet Charlie Fairstairs?'' (unknown)

``I've seen nobody,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre.

But at this moment he (Cheesacre) was compelled to swallow his (Cheesacre) anger, as Mrs. Greenow, accompanied by her (Greenow) lady guest, came into the room.

``Whoever would have expected two gentlemen to be so punctual,'' (she)
said she (Greenow),
``especially on market-day!'' (she)

``Market-day makes no difference when I come to see you,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre, putting his (Cheesacre) best foot forward, while Captain Bellfield contented himself with saying something civil to Charlie. He (Charlie) would bide his (Charlie) time and ride a waiting race.

The widow was almost gorgeous in her (widow) weeds. I believe that she (widow) had not sinned in her (widow) dress against any of those canons which the semi-ecclesiastical authorities on widowhood have laid down as to the outward garments fitted for gentlemen's relicts. The materials were those which are devoted to the deepest conjugal grief. As regarded every item of the written law her (widow) suttee worship was carried out to the letter. There was the widow's cap, generally so hideous, so well known to the eyes of all men, so odious to womanhood. Let us hope that such headgear may have some assuaging effect on the departed spirits of husbands. There was the dress of deep, clinging, melancholy crape,--of crape which becomes so brown and so rusty, and which makes the six months' widow seem so much more afflicted a creature than she (widow) whose husband is just gone, and whose crape is therefore new. There were the trailing weepers, and the widow's kerchief pinned close round her (widow) neck and somewhat tightly over her (widow) bosom. But there was that of genius about Mrs. Greenow, that she (Greenow) had turned every seeming disadvantage to some special profit, and had so dressed herself that though she (Greenow) had obeyed the law to the letter, she (Greenow) had thrown the spirit of it to the winds. Her (Greenow) cap sat jauntily on her (Greenow) head, and showed just so much of her (Greenow) rich brown hair as to give her (Greenow) the appearance of youth which she (Greenow) desired. Cheesacre had blamed her (Greenow) in his (Cheesacre) heart for her (Greenow) private carriage, but she (Greenow) spent more money, I think, on new crape than she (Greenow) did on her (Greenow) brougham. It never became brown and rusty with her (Greenow), or formed itself into old lumpy folds, or shaped itself round her (Greenow) like a grave cloth. The written law had not interdicted crinoline, and she (Greenow) loomed as large with weeds, which with her (Greenow) were not sombre, as she (Greenow) would do with her (Greenow) silks when the period of her (Greenow) probation should be over. Her (Greenow) weepers were bright with newness, and she (Greenow) would waft them aside from her (Greenow) shoulder with an air which turned even them into auxiliaries. Her (Greenow) kerchief was fastened close round her (Greenow) neck and close over her (Greenow) bosom; but Jeannette well knew what she (Jeannette) was doing as she (Jeannette) fastened it,--and so did Jeannette's mistress.

Mrs. Greenow would still talk much about her (Greenow) husband, declaring that her (Greenow) loss was as fresh to her (Greenow) wounded heart, as though he (husband), on whom all her (Greenow) happiness had rested, had left her (Greenow) only yesterday; but yet she (Greenow) mistook her (Greenow) dates, frequently referring to the melancholy circumstance, as having taken place fifteen months ago. In truth, however, Mr. Greenow had been alive within the last nine months,--as everybody around her (Greenow) knew. But if she (Greenow) chose to forget the exact day, why should her (Greenow) friends or dependents remind her (Greenow) of it? No friend or dependent did remind her (Greenow) of it, and Charlie Fairstairs spoke of the fifteen months with bold confidence,--false-tongued little parasite that she (Greenow) was.

``Looking well,'' (the widow)
said the widow, in answer to some outspoken compliment from Mr. Cheesacre.
``Yes, I'm well enough in health, and I suppose I ought to be thankful that it is so. But if you had buried a wife whom you had loved within the last eighteen months, you would have become as indifferent as I am to all that kind of thing.'' (unknown)

``I never was married yet,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre.

``And therefore you know nothing about it. Everything in the world is gay and fresh to you. If I were you, Mr. Cheesacre, I would not run the risk. It is hardly worth a woman's while, and I suppose not a man's. The sufferings are too great!'' (she)
Whereupon she (widow) pressed her (widow) handkerchief to her (widow) eyes.

``But I mean to try all the same,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre, looking the lover all over as he (Cheesacre) gazed into the fair one's face.

``I hope that you may be successful, Mr. Cheesacre, and that she (woman) may not be torn away from you early in life. Is dinner ready, Jeannette? That's well. Mr. Cheesacre, will you give your arm to Miss Fairstairs?'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

There was no doubt as to Mrs. Greenow's correctness. As Captain Bellfield held, or had held, her (Bellfield) Majesty's commission, he (Majesty) was clearly entitled to take the mistress of the festival down to dinner. But Cheesacre would not look at it in this light. He (Cheesacre) would only remember that he (Cheesacre) had paid for the Captain's food for some time past, that the Captain had been brought into Norwich in his (Captain) gig, that the Captain owed him (Captain) money, and ought, so to say, to be regarded as his (Captain) property on the occasion.

``I pay my way, and that ought to give a man higher station than being a beggarly captain,--which I don't believe he (captain) is, if all the truth was known.'' (he)
It was thus that he (Captain) took an occasion to express himself to Miss Fairstairs on that very evening.
``Military rank is always recognised,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
Miss Fairstairs had replied, taking Mr. Cheesacre's remarks as a direct slight upon herself. He (Cheesacre) had taken her (Cheesacre) down to dinner, and had then come to her (Cheesacre) complaining that he (Cheesacre) had been injured in being called upon to do so!
``If you were a magistrate, Mr. Cheesacre, you would have rank; but I believe you are not.'' (Charlie/Charlie Fairstairs)
Charlie Fairstairs knew well what she (Cheesacre) was about. Mr. Cheesacre had striven much to get his (Cheesacre) name put upon the commission of the peace, but had failed.
``Nasty, scraggy old cat,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
Cheesacre said to himself, as he (Cheesacre) turned away from her (Cheesacre).

But Bellfield gained little by taking the widow down. He (Cheesacre) and Cheesacre were placed at the top and bottom of the table, so that they might do the work of carving; and the ladies sat at the sides. Mrs. Greenow's hospitality was very good. The dinner was exactly what a dinner ought to be for four persons. There was soup, fish, a cutlet, a roast fowl, and some game. Jeannette waited at table nimbly, and the thing could not have been done better. Mrs. Greenow's appetite was not injured by her (Greenow) grief, and she (Greenow) so far repressed for the time all remembrance of her (Greenow) sorrow as to enable her (Greenow) to play the kind hostess to perfection. Under her (Greenow) immediate eye Cheesacre was forced into apparent cordiality with his (Cheesacre) friend Bellfield, and the Captain himself took the good things which the gods provided with thankful good-humour.

Nothing, however, was done at the dinner-table. No work got itself accomplished. The widow was so accurately fair in the adjustment of her (widow) favours, that even Jeannette could not perceive to which of the two she (Jeannette) turned with the amplest smile. She (Jeannette) talked herself and made others talk, till Cheesacre became almost comfortable, in spite of his (Cheesacre) jealousy.

``And now,'' (she)
she (Jeannette) said, as she (Jeannette) got up to leave the room, when she (Jeannette) had taken her (Jeannette) own glass of wine,
``We will allow these two gentlemen just half an hour, eh Charlie? and then we shall expect them up-stairs.'' (she)

``Ten minutes will be enough for us here,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre, who was in a hurry to utilize his (Cheesacre) time.

``Half an hour,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, not without some little tone of command in her (Greenow) voice. Ten minutes might be enough for Mr. Cheesacre, but ten minutes was not enough for her (Greenow).

Bellfield had opened the door, and it was upon him (Cheesacre) that the widow's eye glanced as she (Bellfield) left the room. Cheesacre saw it, and resolved to resent the injury.

``I'll tell you what it is, Bellfield,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) said, as he (Cheesacre) sat down moodily over the fire,
``I won't have you coming here at all, till this matter is settled.'' (he)

``Till what matter is settled?'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
said Bellfield, filling his (Cheesacre) glass.

``You know what matter I mean.'' (unknown)

``You take such a deuce of a time about it.'' (unknown)

``No, I don't. I take as little time as anybody could. That other fellow has only been dead about nine months, and I've got the thing in excellent training already.'' (unknown)

``And what harm do I do?'' (unknown)

``You disturb me, and you disturb her (you). You do it on purpose. Do you suppose I can't see? I'll tell you what, now; if you'll go clean out of Norwich for a month, I'll lend you two hundred pounds on the day she (you) becomes Mrs. Cheesacre.'' (unknown)

``And where am I to go to?'' (unknown)

``You may stay at Oileymead, if you like;--that is, on condition that you do stay there.'' (unknown)

``And be told that I hack the ham because it's not my own. Shall I tell you a piece of my mind, Cheesacre?'' (unknown)

``What do you mean?'' (unknown)

``That woman has no more idea of marrying you than she (woman) has of marrying the Bishop. Won't you fill your glass, old fellow? I know where the tap is if you want another bottle. You may as well give it up, and spend no more money in pink fronts and polished boots on her (woman) account. You're a podgy man, you see, and Mrs. Greenow doesn't like podgy men.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)

Cheesacre sat looking at him (Cheesacre) with his (Cheesacre) mouth open, dumb with surprise, and almost paralysed with impotent anger. What had happened during the last few hours to change so entirely the tone of his (Cheesacre) dependent captain? Could it be that Bellfield had been there during the morning, and that she (Bellfield) had accepted him (Cheesacre)?

``You are very podgy, Cheesacre,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
Bellfield continued,
``and then you so often smell of the farm-yard; and you talk too much of your money and your property. You'd have had a better chance if you had openly talked to her (Greenow) of hers,--as I have done. As it is, you haven't any chance at all.'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)

Bellfield, as he (Cheesacre) thus spoke to the man opposite to him (Cheesacre), went on drinking his (Cheesacre) wine comfortably, and seemed to be chuckling with glee. Cheesacre was so astounded, so lost in amazement that the creature whom he (Cheesacre) had fed,--whom he (Cheesacre) had bribed with money out of his (Cheesacre) own pocket, should thus turn against him (Cheesacre), that for a while he (Cheesacre) could not collect his (Cheesacre) thoughts or find voice wherewith to make any answer. It occurred to him (Cheesacre) immediately that Bellfield was even now, at this very time, staying at his (Cheesacre) house,--that he (Cheesacre), Cheesacre, was expected to drive him (Cheesacre), Bellfield, back to Oileymead, to his (Cheesacre) own Oileymead, on this very evening; and as he (Cheesacre) thought of this he (Cheesacre) almost fancied that he (Cheesacre) must be in a dream. He (Cheesacre) shook himself, and looked again, and there sat Bellfield, eyeing him (Cheesacre) through the bright colour of a glass of port.

``Now I've told you a bit of my mind, Cheesy, my boy,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
continued Bellfield,
``and you'll save yourself a deal of trouble and annoyance if you'll believe what I say. She (Greenow) doesn't mean to marry you. It's most probable that she (Greenow)'ll marry me; but, at any rate, she (Greenow) won't marry you.'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)

``Do you mean to pay me my money, sir?'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre, at last, finding his (Cheesacre) readiest means of attack in that quarter.

``Yes, I do.'' (unknown)

``But when?'' (unknown)

``When I've married Mrs. Greenow,--and, therefore, I expect your assistance in that little scheme. Let us drink her (Greenow) health. We shall always be delighted to see you at our house, Cheesy, my boy, and you shall be allowed to hack the hams just as much as you please.'' (unknown)

``You shall be made to pay for this,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre, gasping with anger;--gasping almost more with dismay than he (Cheesacre) did with anger.

``All right, old fellow; I'll pay for it,--with the widow's money. Come; our half-hour is nearly over; shall we go up-stairs?'' (unknown)

``I'll expose you.'' (unknown)

``Don't now;--don't be ill-natured.'' (unknown)

``Will you tell me where you mean to sleep to-night, Captain Bellfield?'' (unknown)

``If I sleep at Oileymead it will only be on condition that I have one of the mahogany-furnitured bedrooms.'' (unknown)

``You'll never put your foot in that house again. You're a rascal, sir.'' (unknown)

``Come, come, Cheesy, it won't do for us to quarrel in a lady's house. It wouldn't be the thing at all. You're not drinking your wine. You might as well take another glass, and then we'll go up-stairs.'' (unknown)

``You've left your traps at Oileymead, and not one of them you shall have till you've paid me every shilling you owe me. I don't believe you've a shirt in the world beyond what you've got there.'' (unknown)

``It's lucky I brought one in to change; wasn't it, Cheesy? I shouldn't have thought of it only for the hint you gave me. I might as well ring the bell for Jeannette to put away the wine, if you won't take any more.'' (he)
Then he (Cheesacre) rang the bell, and when Jeannette came he (Cheesacre) skipped lightly up-stairs into the drawing-room.

``Was he (it) here before to-day?'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre, nodding his (Cheesacre) head at the doorway through which Bellfield had passed.

``Who? The Captain? Oh dear no. The Captain don't come here much now;--not to say often, by no means.'' (unknown)

``He (Captain)'s a confounded rascal.'' (unknown)

``Oh, Mr. Cheesacre!'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette.

``He (Cheesacre) is;--and I ain't sure that there ain't others nearly as bad as he (Cheesacre) is.'' (unknown)

``If you mean me, Mr. Cheesacre, I do declare you're a wronging me; I do indeed.'' (unknown)

``What's the meaning of his (Cheesacre) going on in this way?'' (unknown)

``I don't know nothing of his (Cheesacre) ways, Mr. Cheesacre; but I've been as true to you, sir;--so I have;--as true as true.'' (Jeannette)
And Jeannette put her (Jeannette) handkerchief up to her (Jeannette) eyes.

He (Cheesacre) moved to the door, and then a thought occurred to him (Cheesacre). He (Cheesacre) put his (Cheesacre) hand to his (Cheesacre) trousers pocket, and turning back towards the girl, gave her (girl) half-a-crown. She (girl) curtsied as she (girl) took it, and then repeated her (girl) last words.

``Yes, Mr. Cheesacre,--as true as true.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
Mr. Cheesacre said nothing further, but followed his (Cheesacre) enemy up to the drawing-room.
``What game is up now, I wonder,'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette to herself, when she (Jeannette) was left alone.
``They two'll be cutting each other's throatses before they've done, and then my missus will take the surwiver.'' (she)
But she (Jeannette) made up her (Jeannette) mind that Cheesacre should be the one to have his (Cheesacre) throat cut fatally, and that Bellfield should be the survivor.

Cheesacre, when he (Cheesacre) reached the drawing-room, found Bellfield sitting on the same sofa with Mrs. Greenow looking at a book of photographs which they both of them were handling together. The outside rim of her (Bellfield) widow's frill on one occasion touched the Captain's whisker, and as it did so the Captain looked up with a gratified expression of triumph. If any gentleman has ever seen the same thing under similar circumstances, he (gentleman) will understand that Cheesacre must have been annoyed.

``Yes,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, waving her (Greenow) handkerchief, of which little but a two-inch-deep border seemed to be visible. Bellfield knew at once that it was not the same handkerchief which she (Bellfield) had waved before they went down to dinner.
``Yes,--there he (Cheesacre) is. It's so like him (Cheesacre).'' (she)
And then she (Bellfield) apostrophized the _carte de visite_ of the departed one.
``Dear Greenow; dear husband! When my spirit is false to thee, let thine forget to visit me softly in my dreams. Thou wast unmatched among husbands. Whose tender kindness was ever equal to thine? whose sweet temper was ever so constant? whose manly care so all-sufficient?'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
While the words fell from her (Bellfield) lips her (Bellfield) little finger was touching Bellfield's little finger, as they held the book between them. Charlie Fairstairs and Mr. Cheesacre were watching her (Bellfield) narrowly, and she (Bellfield) knew that they were watching her (Bellfield). She (Bellfield) was certainly a woman of great genius and of great courage.

-LSB-Illustration:

``Dear Greenow; dear husband!'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
-RSB-

Bellfield, moved by the eloquence of her (Bellfield) words, looked with some interest at the photograph. There was represented there before him (genius), a small, grey-looking, insignificant old man, with pig's eyes and a toothless mouth,--one who should never have been compelled to submit himself to the cruelty of the sun's portraiture! Another widow, even if she (widow) had kept in her (widow) book the photograph of such a husband, would have scrambled it over silently,--would have been ashamed to show it.

``Have you ever seen it, Mr. Cheesacre?'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
asked Mrs. Greenow.
``It's so like him (Cheesacre).'' (unknown)

``I saw it at Yarmouth,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre, very sulkily.

``That you did not,'' (the lady)
said the lady with some dignity, and not a little of rebuke in her (lady) tone;
``simply because it never was at Yarmouth. A larger one you may have seen, which I always keep, and always shall keep, close by my bedside.'' (the lady)

``Not if I know it,'' (Captain)
said Captain Bellfield to himself. Then the widow punished Mr. Cheesacre for his (Cheesacre) sullenness by whispering a few words to the Captain; and Cheesacre in his (Cheesacre) wrath turned to Charlie Fairstairs. Then it was that he (Cheesacre) spake out his (Cheesacre) mind about the Captain's rank, and was snubbed by Charlie,--as was told a page or two back.

After that, coffee was brought to them, and here again Cheesacre in his (Cheesacre) ill-humour allowed the Captain to out-manoeuvre him (Captain). It was the Captain who put the sugar into the cups and handed them round. He (Captain) even handed a cup to his (Captain) enemy.

``None for me, Captain Bellfield; many thanks for your politeness all the same,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre; and Mrs. Greenow knew from the tone of his (Cheesacre) voice that there had been a quarrel.

Cheesacre sitting then in his (Cheesacre) gloom, had resolved upon one thing,--or, I may perhaps say, upon two things. He (Cheesacre) had resolved that he (Cheesacre) would not leave the room that evening till Bellfield had left it; and that he (Cheesacre) would get a final answer from the widow, if not that night,--for he (Cheesacre) thought it very possible that they might both be sent away together,--then early after breakfast on the following morning. For the present, he (Cheesacre) had given up any idea of turning his (Cheesacre) time to good account. He (Cheesacre) was not perhaps a coward, but he (Cheesacre) had not that special courage which enables a man to fight well under adverse circumstances. He (Cheesacre) had been cowed by the unexpected impertinence of his (Cheesacre) rival,--by the insolence of a man to whom he (Cheesacre) thought that he (Cheesacre) had obtained the power of being always himself as insolent as he (Cheesacre) pleased. He (Cheesacre) could not recover his (Cheesacre) ground quickly, or carry himself before his (Cheesacre) lady's eye as though he (Cheesacre) was unconscious of the wound he (Cheesacre) had received. So he (Cheesacre) sat silent, while Bellfield was discoursing fluently. He (Cheesacre) sat in silence, comforting himself with reflections on his (Cheesacre) own wealth, and on the poverty of the other, and promising himself a rich harvest of revenge when the moment should come in which he (Cheesacre) might tell Mrs. Greenow how absolutely that man was a beggar, a swindler, and a rascal.

And he (rascal) was astonished when an opportunity for doing so came very quickly. Before the neighbouring clock had done striking seven, Bellfield rose from his (rascal) chair to go. He (rascal) first of all spoke a word of farewell to Miss Fairstairs; then he (rascal) turned to his (rascal) late host;

``Good night, Cheesacre,'' (he)
he (rascal) said, in the easiest tone in the world; after that he (rascal) pressed the widow's hand and whispered his (rascal) adieu.

``I thought you were staying at Oileymead?'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.

``I came from there this morning,'' (the Captain)
said the Captain.

``But he (Captain) isn't going back there, I can tell you,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre.

``Oh, indeed,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow;
``I hope there is nothing wrong.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

``All as right as a trivet,'' (the Captain)
said the Captain; and then he (Captain) was off.

``I promised mamma that I would be home by seven,'' (Charlie/Charlie Fairstairs)
said Charlie Fairstairs, rising from her (Greenow) chair. It cannot be supposed that she (Greenow) had any wish to oblige Mr. Cheesacre, and therefore this movement on her (Greenow) part must be regarded simply as done in kindness to Mrs. Greenow. She (Greenow) might be mistaken in supposing that Mrs. Greenow would desire to be left alone with Mr. Cheesacre; but it was clear to her (Greenow) that in this way she (Greenow) could give no offence, whereas it was quite possible that she (Greenow) might offend by remaining. A little after seven Mr. Cheesacre found himself alone with the lady.

``I'm sorry to find,'' (she)
said she (lady), gravely,
``that you two have quarrelled.'' (she)

``Mrs. Greenow,'' (he)
said he (Cheesacre), jumping up, and becoming on a sudden full of life,
``that man is a downright swindler.'' (he)

``Oh, Mr. Cheesacre.'' (unknown)

``He (Cheesacre) is. He (Cheesacre)'ll tell you that he (Cheesacre) was at Inkerman, but I believe he (Cheesacre) was in prison all the time.'' (The Captain)
The Captain had been arrested, I think twice, and thus Mr. Cheesacre justified to himself this assertion.
``I doubt whether he (Cheesacre) ever saw a shot fired,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) continued.

``He (Cheesacre)'s none the worse for that.'' (unknown)

``But he (Cheesacre) tells such lies; and then he (Cheesacre) has not a penny in the world. How much do you suppose he (Cheesacre) owes me, now?'' (unknown)

``However much it is, I'm sure you are too much of a gentleman to say.'' (unknown)

``Well;--yes, I am,'' (he)
said he (Cheesacre), trying to recover himself.
``But when I asked him (gentleman) how he (gentleman) intended to pay me, what do you think he (gentleman) said? He (gentleman) said he (gentleman)'d pay me when he (gentleman) got your money.'' (unknown)

``My money! He (gentleman) couldn't have said that!'' (unknown)

``But he (gentleman) did, Mrs. Greenow; I give you my word and honour. ``I'll pay you when I get the widow's money,

'' he (Cheesacre) said.'' (the widow)

``You gentlemen must have a nice way of talking about me when I am absent.'' (unknown)

``I never said a disrespectful word about you in my life, Mrs. Greenow,--or thought one. He (gentleman) does;--he (gentleman) says horrible things.'' (unknown)

``What horrible things, Mr. Cheesacre?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I can't tell you;--but he (Cheesacre) does. What can you expect from such a man as that, who, to my knowledge, won't have a change of clothes to-morrow, except what he (Cheesacre) brought in on his (Cheesacre) back this morning. Where he (Cheesacre)'s to get a bed to-night, I don't know, for I doubt whether he (Cheesacre)'s got half-a-crown in the world.'' (unknown)

``Poor Bellfield!'' (unknown)

``Yes; he (Cheesacre) is poor.'' (unknown)

``But how gracefully he (Cheesacre) carries his (Cheesacre) poverty.'' (unknown)

``I should call it very disgraceful, Mrs. Greenow.'' (she)
To this she (lady) made no reply, and then he (Cheesacre) thought that he (Cheesacre) might begin his (Cheesacre) work.
``Mrs. Greenow,--may I say Arabella?'' (unknown)

``Mr. Cheesacre!'' (unknown)

``But mayn't I? Come, Mrs. Greenow. You know well enough by this time what it is I mean. What's the use of shilly-shallying?'' (unknown)

``Shilly-shallying, Mr. Cheesacre! I never heard such language. If I bid you good night, now, and tell you that it is time for you to go home, shall you call that shilly-shallying?'' (He)

He (Cheesacre) had made a mistake in his (Cheesacre) word and repented it.

``I beg your pardon, Mrs. Greenow; I do indeed. I didn't mean anything offensive.'' (unknown)

``Shilly-shallying, indeed! There's very little shall in it, I can assure you.'' (The man)

The poor man was dreadfully crestfallen, so much so that the widow's heart relented, and she (widow) pardoned him (man). It was not in her (widow) nature to quarrel with people;--at any rate, not with her (widow) lovers.

``I beg your pardon, Mrs. Greenow,'' (the culprit)
said the culprit, humbly.
``It is granted,'' (the widow)
said the widow;
``but never tell a lady again that she (Greenow) is shilly-shallying. And look here, Mr. Cheesacre, if it should ever come to pass that you are making love to a lady in earnest--'' (the widow)

``I couldn't be more in earnest,'' (he)
said he (culprit).

``That you are making love to a lady in earnest, talk to her (lady) a little more about your passion and a little less about your purse. Now, good night.'' (unknown)

``But we are friends.'' (unknown)

``Oh yes;--as good friends as ever.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)

Cheesacre, as he (Cheesacre) drove himself home in the dark, tried to console himself by thinking of the miserable plight in which Bellfield would find himself at Norwich, with no possessions but what he (Cheesacre) had brought into the town that day in a small bag. But as he (Cheesacre) turned in at his (Cheesacre) own gate he (Cheesacre) met two figures emerging; one of them was laden with a portmanteau, and the other with a hat case.

``It's only me, Cheesy, my boy,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
said Bellfield. ``I've just come down by the rail to fetch my things, and I'm going back to Norwich by the 9.20.

``If you've stolen anything of mine I'll have you prosecuted,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
roared Cheesacre, as he (Cheesacre) drove his (Cheesacre) gig up to his (Cheesacre) own door.

VOLUME II.

CHAPTER XLI.

A Noble Lord Dies.

George Vavasor remained about four days beneath his (Vavasor) grandfather's roof; but he (Vavasor) was not happy there himself, nor did he (Vavasor) contribute to the happiness of any one else. He (Vavasor) remained there in great discomfort so long, being unwilling to leave till an answer had been received to the request made to Aunt Greenow, in order that he (Vavasor) might insist on Kate's performance of her (Kate) promise with reference to Alice, if that answer should be unfavourable. During these five days Kate did all in her (Kate) power to induce her (Kate) brother to be, at any rate, kind in his (brother) manner towards his (brother) grandfather, but it was in vain. The Squire would not be the first to be gracious; and George, quite as obstinate as the old man, would take no steps in that direction till encouraged to do so by graciousness from the other side. Poor Kate entreated each of them to begin, but her (Kate) entreaties were of no avail.

``He (boy) is an ill-mannered cub,'' (the man)
the old man said,
``and I was a fool to let him (boy) into the house. Don't mention his (boy) name to me again.'' (the man)
George argued the matter more at length. Kate spoke to him (George) of his (George) own interest in the matter, urging upon him (George) that he (George) might, by such conduct, drive the Squire to exclude him (Squire) altogether from the property.

``He (boy) must do as he (boy) likes,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
George said, sulkily.

``But for Alice's sake!'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Kate answered.

``Alice would be the last to expect me to submit to unreasonable ill-usage for the sake of money. As regards myself, I confess that I'm very fond of money and am not particularly squeamish. I would do anything that a man can do to secure it. But this I can't do. I never injured him (man), and I never asked him (man) to injure himself. I never attempted to borrow money from him (man). I have never cost him (man) a shilling. When I was in the wine business he (man) might have enabled me to make a large fortune simply by settling on me then the reversion of property which, when he (man) dies, ought to be my own. He (man) was so perversely ignorant that he (man) would make no inquiry, but chose to think that I was ruining myself, at the only time of my life when I was really doing well.'' (unknown)

``But he (man) had a right to act as he (man) pleased,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
urged Kate.

``Certainly he (man) had. But he (man) had no right to resent my asking such a favour at his (man) hands. He (man) was an ignorant old fool not to do it; but I should never have quarrelled with him (man) on that account. Nature made him (man) a fool, and it wasn't his (man) fault. But I can't bring myself to kneel in the dirt before him (man) simply because I asked for what was reasonable.'' (The men)

The two men said very little to each other. They were never alone together except during that half-hour after dinner in which they were supposed to drink their wine. The old Squire always took three glasses of port during this period, and expected that his (Squire) grandson would take three with him (Squire). But George would drink none at all.

``I have given up drinking wine after dinner,'' (he)
said he (George), when his (George) grandfather pushed the bottle over to him (George).
``I suppose you mean that you drink nothing but claret,'' (the Squire)
said the Squire, in a tone of voice that was certainly not conciliatory.
``I mean simply what I say,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George--
``that I have given up drinking wine after dinner.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
The old man could not openly quarrel with his (man) heir on such a point as that. Even Mr. Vavasor could not tell his (Vavasor) grandson that he (Vavasor) was going to the dogs because he (Vavasor) had become temperate. But, nevertheless, there was offence in it; and when George sat perfectly silent, looking at the fire, evidently determined to make no attempt at conversation, the offence grew, and became strong.
``What the devil's the use of your sitting there if you neither drink nor talk?'' (the man)
said the old man.
``No use in the world, that I can see,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George;
``if, however, I were to leave you, you would abuse me for it.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
``I don't care how soon you leave me,'' (the Squire)
said the Squire. From all which it may be seen that George Vavasor's visit to the hall of his (Vavasor) ancestors was not satisfactory.

On the fourth day, about noon, came Aunt Greenow's reply.

``Dearest Kate,'' (she)
she (Greenow) said,
``I am not going to do what you ask me,'' (she)
--thus rushing instantly into the middle of her (Greenow) subject.

You see, I don't know my nephew, and have no reason for being specially anxious that he (nephew) should be in Parliament. I don't care two straws about the glory of the Vavasor family. If I had never done anything for myself, the Vavasors would have done very little for me. I don't care much about what you call

``blood.'' (I)
I like those who like me, and whom I know. I am very fond of you, and because you have been good to me I would give you a thousand pounds if you wanted it for yourself; but I don't see why I am to give my money to those I don't know. If it is necessary to tell my nephew of this, pray tell him (nephew) that I mean no offence.

Your friend C. is still waiting--waiting--waiting, patiently; but his (friend) patience may be exhausted.

Your affectionate aunt,

ARABELLA GREENOW.

``Of course she (Kate) won't,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George, as he (George) threw back the letter to his (George) sister.
``Why should she (Kate)?'' (unknown)

``I had hoped she (Kate) would,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

``Why should she (Kate)? What did I ever do for her (Kate)? She (Kate) is a sensible woman. Who is your friend C., and why is he (friend) waiting patiently?'' (unknown)

``He (friend) is a man who would be glad to marry her (Kate) for her (Kate) money, if she (Kate) would take him (friend).'' (unknown)

``Then what does she (Kate) mean by his (friend) patience being exhausted?'' (unknown)

``It is her (Kate) folly. She (Kate) chooses to pretend to think that the man is a lover of mine.'' (unknown)

``Has he (man) got any money?'' (unknown)

``Yes; lots of money--or money's worth.'' (unknown)

``And what is his (man) name?'' (unknown)

``His (man) name is Cheesacre. But pray don't trouble yourself to talk about him (man).'' (unknown)

``If he (man) wants to marry you, and has plenty of money, why shouldn't you take him (man)?'' (unknown)

``Good heavens, George! In the first place he (George) does not want to marry me. In the next place all his (George) heart is in his (George) farmyard.'' (unknown)

``And a very good place to have it,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``Undoubtedly. But, really, you must not trouble yourself to talk about him (George).'' (unknown)

``Only this,--that I should be very glad to see you well married.'' (unknown)

``Should you?'' (she)
said she (Kate), thinking of her (Kate) close attachment to himself.

``And now, about the money,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.
``You must write to Alice at once.'' (unknown)
--
``Oh, George!'' (unknown)

``Of course you must; you have promised. Indeed, it would have been much wiser if you had taken me at my word, and done it at once.'' (unknown)
--
``I cannot do it.'' (sister)

Then the scar on his (George) face opened itself, and his (George) sister stood before him (George) in fear and trembling.

``Do you mean to tell me,'' (he)
said he (George),
``that you will go back from your word, and deceive me;--that after having kept me here by this promise, you will not do what you have said you would do?'' (he)

``Take my money now, and pay me out of hers as soon as you are married. I will be the first to claim it from her (you),--and from you.'' (unknown)

``That is nonsense.'' (unknown)

``Why should it be nonsense? Surely you need have no scruple with me. I should have none with you if I wanted assistance.'' (unknown)

``Look here, Kate; I won't have it, and there's an end of it. All that you have in the world would not pull me through this election, and therefore such a loan would be worse than useless.'' (unknown)

``And am I to ask her (Kate) for more than two thousand pounds?'' (unknown)

``You are to ask her (Kate) simply for one thousand. That is what I want, and must have, at present. And she (Kate) knows that I want it, and that she (Kate) is to supply it; only she (Kate) does not know that my need is so immediate. That you must explain to her (Kate).'' (unknown)

``I would sooner burn my hand, George!'' (unknown)

``But burning your hand, unfortunately, won't do any good. Look here, Kate; I insist upon your doing this for me. If you do not, I shall do it, of course, myself; but I shall regard your refusal as an unjustifiable falsehood on your part, and shall certainly not see you afterwards. I do not wish, for reasons which you may well understand, to write to Alice myself on any subject at present. I now claim your promise to do so; and if you refuse, I shall know very well what to do.'' (she)

Of course she (sister) did not persist in her (sister) refusal. With a sorrowful heart, and with fingers that could hardly form the needful letters, she (sister) did write a letter to her (sister) cousin, which explained the fact--that George Vavasor immediately wanted a thousand pounds for his (Vavasor) electioneering purposes. It was a stiff, uncomfortable letter, unnatural in its phraseology, telling its own tale of grief and shame. Alice understood very plainly all the circumstances under which it was written, but she (Alice) sent back word to Kate at once, undertaking that the money should be forthcoming; and she (Kate) wrote again before the end of January, saying that the sum named had been paid to George's credit at his (George) own bankers.

Kate had taken immense pride in the renewal of the match between her (Kate) brother and her (Kate) cousin, and had rejoiced in it greatly as being her (Kate) own work. But all that pride and joy were now over. She (Kate) could no longer write triumphant notes to Alice, speaking always of George as one who was to be their joint hero, foretelling great things of his (George) career in Parliament, and saying little soft things of his (George) enduring love. It was no longer possible to her (Kate) now to write of George at all, and it was equally impossible to Alice. Indeed, no letters passed between them, when that monetary correspondence was over, up to the end of the winter. Kate remained down in Westmoreland, wretched and ill at ease, listening to hard words spoken by her (Kate) grandfather against her (Kate) brother, and feeling herself unable to take her (Kate) brother's part as she (Kate) had been wont to do in other times.

George returned to town at the end of those four days, and found that the thousand pounds was duly placed to his (George) credit before the end of the month. It is hardly necessary to tell the reader that this money had come from the stores of Mr. Tombe, and that Mr. Tombe duly debited Mr. Grey with the amount. Alice, in accordance with her (Alice) promise, had told her (Alice) father that the money was needed, and her (Alice) father, in accordance with his (father) promise, had procured it without a word of remonstrance.

``Surely I must sign some paper,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice had said. But she (Alice) had been contented when her (Alice) father told her (Alice) that the lawyers would manage all that.

It was nearly the end of February when George Vavasor made his (Vavasor) first payment to Mr. Scruby on behalf of the coming election; and when he (Vavasor) called at Mr. Scruby's office with this object, he (Vavasor) received some intelligence which surprised him (Vavasor) not a little.

``You haven't heard the news,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Scruby.
``What news?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``The Marquis is as nearly off the hooks as a man can be.'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
Mr. Scruby, as he (George) communicated the tidings, showed clearly by his (Scruby) face and voice that they were supposed to be of very great importance; but Vavasor did not at first seem to be as much interested in the fate of
``the Marquis'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
as Scruby had intended.

``I'm very sorry for him (Marquis),'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.
``Who is the Marquis? There'll be sure to come another, so it don't much signify.'' (unknown)

``There will come another, and that's just it. It's the Marquis of Bunratty; and if he (Marquis) drops, our young Member will go into the Upper House.'' (unknown)

``What, immediately; before the end of the Session?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
George, of course, knew well enough that such would be the case, but the effect which this event would have upon himself now struck him (George) suddenly.

``To be sure,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Scruby.
``The writ would be out immediately. I should be glad enough of it, only that I know that Travers's people have heard of it before us, and that they are ready to be up with their posters directly the breath is out of the Marquis's body. We must go to work immediately; that's all.'' (unknown)

``It will only be for part of a Session,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``Just so,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby.

``And then there'll be the cost of another election.'' (unknown)

``That's true,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby;
``but in such cases we do manage to make it come a little cheaper. If you lick Travers now, it may be that you'll have a walk-over for the next.'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)

``Have you seen Grimes?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
asked George.

``Yes, I have; the blackguard! He (Grimes) is going to open his (Grimes) house on Travers's side. He (Grimes) came to me as bold as brass, and told me so, saying that he (Grimes) never liked gentlemen who kept him (Grimes) waiting for his (Grimes) odd money. What angers me is that he (Grimes) ever got it.'' (unknown)

``We have not managed it very well, certainly,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor, looking nastily at the attorney.

``We can't help those little accidents, Mr. Vavasor. There are worse accidents than that turn up almost daily in my business. You may think yourself almost lucky that I haven't gone over to Travers myself. He (Travers) is a Liberal, you know; and it hasn't been for want of an offer, I can tell you.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Vavasor was inclined to doubt the extent of his (Scruby) luck in this respect, and was almost disposed to repent of his (Scruby) Parliamentary ambition. He (Scruby) would now be called upon to spend certainly not less than three thousand pounds of his (Scruby) cousin's money on the chance of being able to sit in Parliament for a few months. And then, after what a fashion would he (Scruby) be compelled to negotiate that loan! He (Scruby) might, to be sure, allow the remainder of this Session to run, and stand, as he (Scruby) had intended, at the general election; but he (Scruby) knew that if he (Scruby) now allowed a Liberal to win the seat, the holder of the seat would be almost sure of subsequent success. He (Liberal) must either fight now, or give up the fight altogether; and he (Liberal) was a man who did not love to abandon any contest in which he (Liberal) had been engaged.

``Well, Squire,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Scruby,
``how is it to be?'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
And Vavasor felt that he (Scruby) detected in the man's voice some diminution of that respect with which he (Scruby) had hitherto been treated as a paying candidate for a metropolitan borough.

``This lord is not dead yet,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor.

``No; he (lord)'s not dead yet, that we have heard; but it won't do for us to wait. We want every minute of time that we can get. There isn't any hope for him (lord), I'm told. It's gout in the stomach, or dropsy at the heart, or some of those things that make a fellow safe to go.'' (unknown)

``It won't do to wait for the next election?'' (unknown)

``If you ask me, I should say certainly not. Indeed, I shouldn't wish to have to conduct it under such circumstances. I hate a fight when there's no chance of success. I grudge spending a man's money in such a case; I do indeed, Mr. Vavasor.'' (unknown)

``I suppose Grimes's going over won't make much difference?'' (unknown)

``The blackguard! He (Grimes)'ll take a hundred and fifty votes, I suppose; perhaps more. But that is not much in such a constituency as the Chelsea districts. You see, Travers played mean at the last election, and that will be against him (Travers).'' (unknown)

``But the Conservatives will have a candidate.'' (unknown)

``There's no knowing; but I don't think they will. They'll try one at the general, no doubt; but if the two sitting Members can pull together, they won't have much of a chance.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Vavasor found himself compelled to say that he (Scruby) would stand; and Scruby undertook to give the initiatory orders at once, not waiting even till the Marquis should be dead.

``We should have our houses open as soon as theirs,'' (he)
said he (Marquis).
``There's a deal in that.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
So George Vavasor gave his (Vavasor) orders.
``If the worst comes to the worst,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) said to himself,
``I can always cut my throat.'' (he)

As he (Vavasor) walked from the attorney's office to his (Vavasor) club he (Vavasor) bethought himself that that might not unprobably be the necessary termination of his (Vavasor) career. Everything was going wrong with him (Vavasor). His (Vavasor) grandfather, who was eighty years of age, would not die,--appeared to have no symptoms of dying;--whereas this Marquis, who was not yet much over fifty, was rushing headlong out of the world, simply because he (Marquis) was the one man whose continued life at the present moment would be serviceable to George Vavasor. As he (Vavasor) thought of his (Vavasor) grandfather he (Vavasor) almost broke his (Vavasor) umbrella by the vehemence with which he (Vavasor) struck it against the pavement. What right could an ignorant old fool like that have to live for ever, keeping the possession of a property which he (fool) could not use, and ruining those who were to come after him (fool)? If now, at this moment, that wretched place down in Westmoreland could become his (fool), he (fool) might yet ride triumphantly over his (fool) difficulties, and refrain from sullying his (fool) hands with more of his (fool) cousin's money till she (Vavasor) should become his (fool) wife.

Even that thousand pounds had not passed through his (fool) hands without giving him (fool) much bitter suffering. As is always the case in such matters, the thing done was worse than the doing of it. He (fool) had taught himself to look at it lightly whilst it was yet unaccomplished; but he (fool) could not think of it lightly now. Kate had been right. It would have been better for him (fool) to take her (Kate) money. Any money would have been better than that upon which he (fool) had laid his (fool) sacrilegious hands. If he (fool) could have cut a purse, after the old fashion, the stain of the deed would hardly have been so deep. In these days,--for more than a month, indeed, after his (fool) return from Westmoreland,--he (fool) did not go near Queen Anne Street, trying to persuade himself that he (fool) stayed away because of her (Anne) coldness to him (fool). But, in truth, he (fool) was afraid of seeing her (Anne) without speaking of her (Anne) money, and afraid to see her (Anne) if he (fool) were to speak of it.

``You have seen the _Globe_?'' (someone)
someone said to him (fool) as he (fool) entered the club.

``No, indeed; I have seen nothing.'' (unknown)

``Bunratty died in Ireland this morning. I suppose you'll be up for the Chelsea districts?'' (unknown)

CHAPTER XLII.

Parliament Meets.

Parliament opened that year on the twelfth of February, and Mr. Palliser was one of the first Members of the Lower House to take his (Palliser) seat. It had been generally asserted through the country, during the last week, that the existing Chancellor of the Exchequer had, so to say, ceased to exist as such; that though he (Chancellor) still existed to the outer world, drawing his (Chancellor) salary, and doing routine work,--if a man so big can have any routine work to do,--he (Chancellor) existed no longer in the inner world of the cabinet. He (Chancellor) had differed, men said, with his (Chancellor) friend and chief, the Prime Minister, as to the expediency of repealing what were left of the direct taxes of the country, and was prepared to launch himself into opposition with his (Minister) small bodyguard of followers, with all his (Minister) energy and with all his (Minister) venom.

There is something very pleasant in the close, bosom friendship, and bitter, uncompromising animosity, of these human gods,--of these human beings who would be gods were they not shorn so short of their divinity in that matter of immortality. If it were so arranged that the same persons were always friends, and the same persons were always enemies, as used to be the case among the dear old heathen gods and goddesses;--if Parliament were an Olympus in which Juno and Venus never kissed, the thing would not be nearly so interesting. But in this Olympus partners are changed, the divine bosom, now rabid with hatred against some opposing deity, suddenly becomes replete with love towards its late enemy, and exciting changes occur which give to the whole thing all the keen interest of a sensational novel. No doubt this is greatly lessened for those who come too near the scene of action. Members of Parliament, and the friends of Members of Parliament, are apt to teach themselves that it means nothing; that Lord This does not hate Mr. That, or think him (Mr.) a traitor to his (Mr.) country, or wish to crucify him (Mr.); and that Sir John of the Treasury is not much in earnest when he (John) speaks of his (John) noble friend at the

``Foreign Office'' (friend)
as a god to whom no other god was ever comparable in honesty, discretion, patriotism, and genius. But the outside Briton who takes a delight in politics,--and this description should include ninety-nine educated Englishmen out of every hundred,--should not be desirous of peeping behind the scenes. No beholder at any theatre should do so. It is good to believe in these friendships and these enmities, and very pleasant to watch their changes. It is delightful when Oxford embraces Manchester, finding that it cannot live without support in that quarter; and very delightful when the uncompromising assailant of all men in power receives the legitimate reward of his (assailant) energy by being taken in among the bosoms of the blessed.

But although the outer world was so sure that the existing Chancellor of the Exchequer had ceased to exist, when the House of Commons met that gentleman took his (gentleman) seat on the Treasury Bench. Mr. Palliser, who had by no means given a general support to the Ministry in the last Session, took his (Palliser) seat on the same side of the House indeed, but low down, and near to the cross benches. Mr. Bott sat close behind him (Bott), and men knew that Mr. Bott was a distinguished member of Mr. Palliser's party, whatever that party might be. Lord Cinquebars moved the Address, and I must confess that he (Cinquebars) did it very lamely. He (Cinquebars) was once accused by Mr. Maxwell, the brewer, of making a great noise in the hunting-field. The accusation could not be repeated as to his (Cinquebars) performance on this occasion, as no one could hear a word that he (Cinquebars) said. The Address was seconded by Mr. Loftus Fitzhoward, a nephew of the Duke of St. Bungay, who spoke as though he (Mr.) were resolved to trump poor Lord Cinquebars in every sentence which he (Mr.) pronounced,--as we so often hear the second clergyman from the Communion Table trumping his (Mr.) weary predecessor, who has just finished the Litany not in the clearest or most audible voice. Every word fell from Mr. Fitzhoward with the elaborate accuracy of a separate pistol-shot; and as he (Fitzhoward) became pleased with himself in his (Fitzhoward) progress, and warm with his (Fitzhoward) work, he (Fitzhoward) accented his (Fitzhoward) words sharply, made rhetorical pauses, even moved his (Fitzhoward) hands about in action, and quite disgusted his (Fitzhoward) own party, who had been very well satisfied with Lord Cinquebars. There are many rocks which a young speaker in Parliament should avoid, but no rock which requires such careful avoiding as the rock of eloquence. Whatever may be his (speaker) faults, let him (speaker) at least avoid eloquence. He (speaker) should not be inaccurate, which, however, is not much; he (speaker) should not be long-winded, which is a good deal; he (speaker) should not be ill-tempered, which is more; but none of these faults are so damnable as eloquence. All Mr. Fitzhoward's friends and all his (Fitzhoward) enemies knew that he (Fitzhoward) had had his (Fitzhoward) chance, and that he (Fitzhoward) had thrown it away.

In the Queen's Speech there had been some very lukewarm allusion to remission of direct taxation. This remission, which had already been carried so far, should be carried further if such further carrying were found practicable. So had said the Queen. Those words, it was known, could not have been approved of by the energetic and still existing Chancellor of the Exchequer. On this subject the mover of the Address said never a word, and the seconder only a word or two. What they had said had, of course, been laid down for them; though, unfortunately, the manner of saying could not be so easily prescribed. Then there arose a great enemy, a man fluent of diction, apparently with deep malice at his (man) heart, though at home,--as we used to say at school,--one of the most good-natured fellows in the world; one ambitious of that godship which a seat on the other side of the House bestowed, and greedy to grasp at the chances which this disagreement in the councils of the gods might give him (man). He (man) was quite content, he (man) said, to vote for the Address, as, he (man) believed, would be all the gentlemen on his (man) side of the House. No one could suspect them or him (man) of giving a factious opposition to Government. Had they not borne and forborne beyond all precedent known in that House? Then he (man) touched lightly, and almost with grace to his (man) opponents, on many subjects, promising support, and barely hinting that they were totally and manifestly wrong in all things. But--. Then the tone of his (man) voice changed, and the well-known look of fury was assumed upon his (man) countenance. Then great Jove on the other side pulled his (man) hat over his (man) eyes, and smiled blandly. Then members put away the papers they had been reading for a moment, and men in the gallery began to listen. But--. The long and the short of it was this; that the existing Government had come into power on the cry of a reduction of taxation, and now they were going to shirk the responsibility of their own measures. They were going to shirk the responsibility of their own election cry, although it was known that their own Chancellor of the Exchequer was prepared to carry it out to the full. He (Chancellor) was willing to carry it out to the full were he (Chancellor) not restrained by the timidity, falsehood, and treachery of his (Chancellor) colleagues, of whom, of course, the most timid, the most false, and the most treacherous was--the great god Jove, who sat blandly smiling on the other side.

-LSB-Illustration: Great Jove.-RSB-

No one should ever go near the House of Commons who wishes to enjoy all this. It was so manifestly evident that neither Jove nor any of his (Great) satellites cared twopence for what the irate gentleman was saying; nay, it became so evident that, in spite of his (Great) assumed fury, the gentleman was not irate. He (Great) intended to communicate his (Great) look of anger to the newspaper reports of his (Great) speech; and he (Great) knew from experience that he (Great) could succeed in that. And men walked about the House in the most telling moments,--enemies shaking hands with enemies,--in a way that showed an entire absence of all good, honest hatred among them. But the gentleman went on and finished his (gentleman) speech, demanding at last, in direct terms, that the Treasury Jove should state plainly to the House who was to be, and who was not to be, the bearer of the purse among the gods.

Then Treasury Jove got up smiling, and thanked his (gentleman) enemy for the cordiality of his (gentleman) support.

``He (my) had always,'' (he)
he (gentleman) said,
``done the gentleman's party justice for their clemency, and had feared no opposition from them; and he (my) was glad to find that he (my) was correct in his (my) anticipations as to the course they would pursue on the present occasion.'' (he)
He (gentleman) went on saying a good deal about home matters, and foreign matters, proving that everything was right, just as easily as his (gentleman) enemy had proved that everything was wrong. On all these points he (gentleman) was very full, and very courteous; but when he (gentleman) came to the subject of taxation, he (gentleman) simply repeated the passage from the Queen's Speech, expressing a hope that his (gentleman) right honourable friend, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, would be able to satisfy the judgement of the House, and the wishes of the people. That specially personal question which had been asked he (gentleman) did not answer at all.

But the House was still all agog, as was the crowded gallery. The energetic and still existing Chancellor of the Exchequer was then present, divided only by one little thin Secretary of State from Jove himself. Would he (Secretary) get up and declare his (Secretary) purposes? He (Secretary) was a man who almost always did get up when an opportunity offered itself,--or when it did not. Some second little gun was fired off from the Opposition benches, and then there was a pause. Would the purse-bearer of Olympus rise upon his (Secretary) wings and speak his (Secretary) mind, or would he (Secretary) sit in silence upon his (Secretary) cloud? There was a general call for the purse-bearer, but he (Secretary) floated in silence, and was inexplicable. The purse-bearer was not to be bullied into any sudden reading of the riddle. Then there came on a general debate about money matters, in which the purse-bearer did say a few words, but he (Secretary) said nothing as to the great question at issue. At last up got Mr. Palliser, towards the close of the evening, and occupied a full hour in explaining what taxes the Government might remit with safety, and what they might not,--Mr. Bott, meanwhile, prompting him (Bott) with figures from behind with an assiduity that was almost too persistent. According to Mr. Palliser, the words used in the Queen's Speech were not at all too cautious. The Members went out gradually, and the House became very thin during this oration; but the newspapers declared, next morning, that his (Palliser) speech had been the speech of the night, and that the perspicuity of Mr. Palliser pointed him (Palliser) out as the coming man.

He (Palliser) returned home to his (Palliser) house in Park Lane quite triumphant after his (Palliser) success, and found Lady Glencora, at about twelve o'clock, sitting alone. She (Glencora) had arrived in town on that day, having come up at her (Glencora) own request, instead of remaining at Matching Priory till after Easter, as he (Palliser) had proposed. He (Palliser) had wished her (Glencora) to stay, in order, as he (Palliser) had said, that there might be a home for his (Palliser) cousins. But she (Glencora) had expressed herself unwilling to remain without him (Palliser), explaining that the cousins might have the home in her (Glencora) absence, as well as they could in her (Glencora) presence; and he (Palliser) had given way. But, in truth, she (Glencora) had learned to hate her (Glencora) cousin Iphy Palliser with a hatred that was unreasonable,--seeing that she (Glencora) did not also hate Alice Vavasor, who had done as much to merit her (Glencora) hatred as had her (Glencora) cousin. Lady Glencora knew by what means her (Glencora) absence from Monkshade had been brought about. Miss Palliser had told her (Glencora) all that had passed in Alice's bedroom on the last night of Alice's stay at Matching, and had, by so doing, contrived to prevent the visit. Lady Glencora understood well all that Alice had said: and yet, though she (Alice) hated Miss Palliser for what had been done, she (Alice) entertained no anger against Alice. Of course Alice would have prevented that visit to Monkshade if it were in her (Alice) power to do so. Of course she (Alice) would save her (Alice) friend. It is hardly too much to say that Lady Glencora looked to Alice to save her (Alice). Nevertheless she (Alice) hated Iphy Palliser for engaging herself in the same business. Lady Glencora looked to Alice to save her (Alice), and yet it may be doubted whether she (Alice) did, in truth, wish to be saved.

While she (Alice) was at Matching, and before Mr. Palliser had returned from Monkshade, a letter reached her (Alice), by what means she (Alice) had never learned.

``A letter has been placed within my writing-case,'' (she)
she (Alice) said to her (Alice) maid, quite openly.
``Who put it there?'' (The maid)
The maid had declared her (maid) ignorance in a manner that had satisfied Lady Glencora of her (Glencora) truth.
``If such a thing happens again,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora,
``I shall be obliged to have the matter investigated. I cannot allow that anything should be put into my room surreptitiously.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
There, then, had been an end of that, as regarded any steps taken by Lady Glencora. The letter had been from Burgo Fitzgerald, and had contained a direct proposal that she (Glencora) should go off with him (Fitzgerald).
``I am at Matching,'' (unknown)
the letter said,
``at the Inn; but I do not dare to show myself, lest I should do you an injury. I walked round the house yesterday, at night, and I know that I saw your room. If I am wrong in thinking that you love me, I would not for worlds insult you by my presence; but if you love me still, I ask you to throw aside from you that fictitious marriage, and give yourself to the man whom, if you love him (man), you should regard as your husband.'' (unknown)
There had been more of it, but it had been to the same effect. To Lady Glencora it had seemed to convey an assurance of devoted love,--of that love which, in former days, her (Glencora) friends had told her (Glencora) was not within the compass of Burgo's nature. He (Burgo) had not asked her (Glencora) to meet him (Burgo) then, but saying that he (Burgo) would return to Matching after Parliament was met, begged her (Glencora) to let him (Burgo) have some means of knowing whether her (Glencora) heart was true to him (Burgo).

She (Glencora) told no one of the letter, but she (Glencora) kept it, and read it over and over again in the silence and solitude of her (Glencora) room. She (Glencora) felt that she (Glencora) was guilty in thus reading it,--even in keeping it from her (Glencora) husband's knowledge; but though conscious of this guilt, though resolute almost in its commission, still she (Glencora) determined not to remain at Matching after her (Glencora) husband's departure,--not to undergo the danger of remaining there while Burgo Fitzgerald should be in the vicinity. She (Glencora) could not analyse her (Glencora) own wishes. She (Glencora) often told herself, as she (Glencora) had told Alice, that it would be better for them all that she (Alice) should go away; that in throwing herself even to the dogs, if such must be the result, she (Alice) would do more of good than of harm. She (Alice) declared to herself, in the most passionate words she (Alice) could use, that she (Alice) loved this man with all her (Alice) heart. She (Alice) protested that the fault would not be hers, but theirs, who had forced her (Alice) to marry the man she (Alice) did not love. She (Alice) assured herself that her (Alice) husband had no affection for her (Alice), and that their marriage was in every respect prejudicial to him (husband). She (Alice) recurred over and over again, in her (Alice) thoughts, to her (Alice) own childlessness, and to his (husband) extreme desire for an heir.

``Though I do sacrifice myself,'' (she)
she (Alice) would say,
``I shall do more of good than harm, and I cannot be more wretched than I am now.'' (she)
But yet she (Alice) fled to London because she (Alice) feared to leave herself at Matching when Burgo Fitzgerald should be there. She (Alice) sent no answer to his (Fitzgerald) letter. She (Alice) made no preparation for going with him (Fitzgerald). She (Alice) longed to see Alice, to whom alone, since her (Alice) marriage, had she (Alice) ever spoken of her (Alice) love, and intended to tell her (Alice) the whole tale of that letter. She (Alice) was as one who, in madness, was resolute to throw herself from a precipice, but to whom some remnant of sanity remained which forced her (Alice) to seek those who would save her (Alice) from herself.

Mr. Palliser had not seen her (Alice) since her (Alice) arrival in London, and, of course, he (Palliser) took her (Alice) by the hand and kissed her (Alice). But it was the embrace of a brother rather than of a lover or a husband. Lady Glencora, with her (Glencora) full woman's nature, understood this thoroughly, and appreciated by instinct the true bearing of every touch from his (husband) hand.

``I hope you are well?'' (she)
she (Glencora) said.

``Oh, yes; quite well. And you? A little fatigued with your journey, I suppose?'' (unknown)

``No; not much.'' (unknown)

``Well, we have had a debate on the Address. Don't you want to know how it has gone?'' (unknown)

``If it has concerned you particularly, I do, of course.'' (unknown)

``Concerned me! It has concerned me certainly.'' (unknown)

``They haven't appointed you yet; have they?'' (unknown)

``No; they don't appoint people during debates, in the House of Commons. But I fear I shall never make you a politician.'' (unknown)

``I'm almost afraid you never will. But I'm not the less anxious for your success, since you wish it yourself. I don't understand why you should work so very hard; but, as you like it, I'm as anxious as anybody can be that you should triumph.'' (unknown)

``Yes; I do like it,'' (he)
he (husband) said.
``A man must like something, and I don't know what there is to like better. Some people can eat and drink all day; and some people can care about a horse. I can do neither.'' (others)

And there were others, Lady Glencora thought, who could love to lie in the sun, and could look up into the eyes of women, and seek their happiness there. She (Glencora) was sure, at any rate, that she (Glencora) knew one such. But she (Glencora) said nothing of this.

``I spoke for a moment to Lord Brock,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser. Lord Brock was the name by which the present Jove of the Treasury was known among men.

``And what did Lord Brock say?'' (unknown)

``He (Brock) didn't say much, but he (Brock) was very cordial.'' (unknown)

``But I thought, Plantagenet, that he (Brock) could appoint you if he (Brock) pleased? Doesn't he (Brock) do it all?'' (unknown)

``Well, in one sense, he (Brock) does. But I don't suppose I shall ever make you understand.'' (He)
He (Brock) endeavoured, however, to do so on the present occasion, and gave her (Glencora) a somewhat longer lecture on the working of the British Constitution, and the manner in which British politics evolved themselves, than would have been expected from most young husbands to their young wives under similar circumstances. Lady Glencora yawned, and strove lustily, but ineffectually, to hide her (Glencora) yawn in her (Glencora) handkerchief.

``But I see you don't care a bit about it,'' (he)
said he (Brock), peevishly.

``Don't be angry, Plantagenet. Indeed I do care about it, but I am so ignorant that I can't understand it all at once. I am rather tired, and I think I'll go to bed now. Shall you be late?'' (unknown)

``No, not very; that is, I shall be rather late. I've a lot of letters I want to write to-night, as I must be at work all to-morrow. By-the-by, Mr. Bott is coming to dine here. There will be no one else.'' (House/House of Commons)
The next day was a Wednesday, and the House would not sit in the evening.

``Mr. Bott!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, showing by her (Glencora) voice that she (Glencora) anticipated no pleasure from that gentleman's company.

``Yes, Mr. Bott. Have you any objection?'' (unknown)

``Oh, no. Would you like to dine alone with him (Bott)?'' (unknown)

``Why should I dine alone with him (Bott)? Why shouldn't you eat your dinner with us? I hope you are not going to become fastidious, and to turn up your nose at people. Mrs. Marsham is in town, and I dare say she (Marsham)'ll come to you if you ask her (Marsham).'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

But this was too much for Lady Glencora. She (Glencora) was disposed to be mild, but she (Glencora) could not endure to have her (Glencora) two duennas thus brought upon her (Glencora) together on the first day of her (Glencora) arrival in London. And Mrs. Marsham would be worse than Mr. Bott. Mr. Bott would be engaged with Mr. Palliser during the greater part of the evening.

``I thought,'' (she)
said she (Marsham),
``of asking my cousin, Alice Vavasor, to spend the evening with me.'' (she)

``Miss Vavasor!'' (the husband)
said the husband.
``I must say that I thought Miss Vavasor--'' (He)
He (husband) was going to make some allusion to that unfortunate hour spent among the ruins, but he (husband) stopped himself.

``I hope you have nothing to say against my cousin?'' (wife)
said his (husband) wife.
``She (Vavasor) is my only near relative that I really care for;--the only woman, I mean.'' (unknown)

``No; I don't mean to say anything against her (woman). She (woman)'s very well as a young lady, I dare say. I would sooner that you would ask Mrs. Marsham to-morrow.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

Lady Glencora was standing, waiting to go away to her (Glencora) own room, but it was absolutely necessary that this matter should be decided before she (Glencora) went. She (Glencora) felt that he (husband) was hard to her (Glencora), and unreasonable, and that he (husband) was treating her (Glencora) like a child who should not be allowed her (Glencora) own way in anything. She (Glencora) had endeavoured to please him (husband), and, having failed, was not now disposed to give way.

``As there will be no other ladies here to-morrow evening, Plantagenet, and as I have not yet seen Alice since I have been in town, I wish you would let me have my way in this. Of course I cannot have very much to say to Mrs. Marsham, who is an old woman.'' (unknown)

``I especially want Mrs. Marsham to be your friend,'' (he)
said he (husband).

``Friendships will not come by ordering, Plantagenet,'' (she)
said she (Glencora).

-LSB-Illustration:

``Friendships will not come by ordering,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.-RSB-

``Very well,'' (he)
said he (husband).
``Of course, you will do as you please. I am sorry that you have refused the first favour I have asked you this year.'' (he)
Then he (husband) left the room, and she (Glencora) went away to bed.

CHAPTER XLIII.

Mrs. Marsham.

But Lady Glencora was not brought to repentance by her (Glencora) husband's last words. It seemed to her (Glencora) to be so intolerably cruel, this demand of his (husband), that she (Glencora) should be made to pass the whole of her (Glencora) first evening in town with an old woman for whom it was impossible that she (Glencora) should entertain the slightest regard, that she (Glencora) resolved upon rebellion. Had he (husband) positively ordered Mrs. Marsham, she (Marsham) would have sent for that lady, and have contented herself with enduring her (Marsham) presence in disdainful silence; but Mr. Palliser had not given any order. He (Palliser) had made a request, and a request, from its very nature, admits of no obedience. The compliance with a request must be voluntary, and she (Marsham) would not send for Mrs. Marsham, except upon compulsion. Had not she (Marsham) also made a request to him (Palliser), and had not he (Palliser) refused it? It was his (Palliser) prerogative, undoubtedly, to command; but in that matter of requests she (Marsham) had a right to expect that her (Marsham) voice should be as potent as his (Palliser) own. She (Marsham) wrote a line, therefore, to Alice before she (Alice) went to bed, begging her (Alice) cousin to come to her (Alice) early on the following day, so that they might go out together, and then afterwards dine in company with Mr. Bott.

``I know that will be an inducement to you,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora said,
``because your generous heart will feel of what service you may be to me. Nobody else will be here,--unless, indeed, Mrs. Marsham should be asked, unknown to myself.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

Then she (Glencora) sat herself down to think,--to think especially about the cruelty of husbands. She (Glencora) had been told over and over again, in the days before her (Glencora) marriage, that Burgo would ill-use her (Glencora) if he (Burgo) became her (Glencora) husband. The Marquis of Auld Reekie had gone so far as to suggest that Burgo might probably beat her (Glencora). But what hard treatment, even what beating, could be so unendurable as this total want of sympathy, as this deadness in life, which her (Glencora) present lot entailed upon her (Glencora)? As for that matter of beating, she (Glencora) ridiculed the idea in her (Glencora) very soul. She (Glencora) sat smiling at the absurdity of the thing as she (Glencora) thought of the beauty of Burgo's eyes, of the softness of his (Burgo) touch, of the loving, almost worshipping, tones of his (Burgo) voice. Would it not even be better to be beaten by him (Burgo) than to have politics explained to her (Glencora) at one o'clock at night by such a husband as Plantagenet Palliser? The British Constitution, indeed! Had she (Glencora) married Burgo they would have been in sunny Italy, and he (Burgo) would have told her (Glencora) some other tale than that as they sat together under the pale moonlight.
