She (Glencora) had a little water-coloured drawing called Raphael and Fornarina, and she (Glencora) was infantine enough to tell herself that the so-called Raphael was like her (Glencora) Burgo--no, not her (Glencora) Burgo, but the Burgo that was not hers. At any rate, all the romance of the picture she (Glencora) might have enjoyed had they allowed her (Glencora) to dispose as she (Glencora) had wished of her (Glencora) own hand. She (Glencora) might have sat in marble balconies, while the vines clustered over her (Glencora) head, and he (Burgo) would have been at her (Glencora) knee, hardly speaking to her (Glencora), but making his (Burgo) presence felt by the halo of its divinity. He (Burgo) would have called upon her (Glencora) for no hard replies. With him (Burgo) near her (Glencora) she (Glencora) would have enjoyed the soft air, and would have sat happy, without trouble, lapped in the delight of loving. It was thus that Fornarina sat. And why should not such a lot have been hers? Her (Glencora) Raphael would have loved her (Glencora), let them say what they would about his (Raphael) cruelty.

Poor, wretched, overburthened child, to whom the commonest lessons of life had not yet been taught, and who had now fallen into the hands of one who was so ill-fitted to teach them! Who would not pity her (Glencora)? Who could say that the fault was hers? The world had laden her (Glencora) with wealth till she (Glencora) had had no limb free for its ordinary uses, and then had turned her (Glencora) loose to run her (Glencora) race!

``Have you written to your cousin?'' (husband)
her (Glencora) husband asked her (Glencora) the next morning. His (husband) voice, as he (husband) spoke, clearly showed that his (husband) anger was either over or suppressed.

``Yes; I have asked her (Marsham) to come and drive, and then to stay for dinner. I shall send the carriage for her (Marsham) if she (Marsham) can come. The man is to wait for an answer.'' (unknown)

``Very well,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, mildly. And then, after a short pause, he (Palliser) added,
``As that is settled, perhaps you would have no objection to ask Mrs. Marsham also?'' (he)

``Won't she (Marsham) probably be engaged?'' (unknown)

``No; I think not,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser. And then he (Palliser) added, being ashamed of the tinge of falsehood of which he (Palliser) would otherwise have been guilty,
``I know she (Marsham) is not engaged.'' (he)

``She (Marsham) expects to come, then?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``I have not asked her (Marsham), if you mean that, Glencora. Had I done so, I should have said so. I told her (Glencora) that I did not know what your engagements were.'' (unknown)

``I will write to her (Glencora), if you please,'' (the wife)
said the wife, who felt that she (Glencora) could hardly refuse any longer.

``Do, my dear!'' (the husband)
said the husband. So Lady Glencora did write to Mrs. Marsham, who promised to come,--as did also Alice Vavasor.

Lady Glencora would, at any rate, have Alice to herself for some hours before dinner. At first she (Glencora) took comfort in that reflection; but after a while she (Glencora) bethought herself that she (Glencora) would not know what to tell Alice, or what not to tell. Did she (Alice) mean to show that letter to her (Alice) cousin? If she (Alice) did show it, then,--so she (Alice) argued with herself,--she (Alice) must bring herself to endure the wretchedness of her (Alice) present lot, and must give up for ever all her (Alice) dreams about Raphael and Fornarina. If she (Alice) did not show it,--or, at any rate, tell of it,--then it would come to pass that she (Alice) would leave her (Alice) husband under the protection of another man, and she (Alice) would become--what she (Alice) did not dare to name even to herself. She (Alice) declared that so it must be. She (Alice) knew that she (Alice) would go with Burgo, should he (Burgo) ever come to her (Alice) with the means of going at his (Burgo) and her (Alice) instant command. But should she (Alice) bring herself to let Alice know that such a letter had been conveyed to her (Alice), Burgo would never have such power.

I remember the story of a case of abduction in which a man was tried for his (man) life, and was acquitted, because the lady had acquiesced in the carrying away while it was in progress. She (lady) had, as she (lady) herself declared, armed herself with a sure and certain charm or talisman against such dangers, which she (lady) kept suspended round her (lady) neck; but whilst she (lady) was in the post-chaise she (lady) opened the window and threw the charm from her (lady), no longer desiring, as the learned counsel for the defence efficiently alleged, to be kept under the bonds of such protection. Lady Glencora's state of mind was, in its nature, nearly the same as that of the lady in the post-chaise. Whether or no she (lady) would use her (lady) charm, she (lady) had not yet decided, but the power of doing so was still hers.

Alice came, and the greeting between the cousins was very affectionate. Lady Glencora received her (Glencora) as though they had been playmates from early childhood; and Alice, though such impulsive love was not natural to her (Alice) as to the other, could not bring herself to be cold to one who was so warm to her (Alice). Indeed, had she (Alice) not promised her (Alice) love in that meeting at Matching Priory in which her (Alice) cousin had told her (Alice) of all her (Alice) wretchedness?

``I will love you!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice had said; and though there was much in Lady Glencora that she (Glencora) could not approve,--much even that she (Glencora) could not bring herself to like,--still she (Glencora) would not allow her (Glencora) heart to contradict her (Glencora) words.

They sat so long over the fire in the drawing-room that at last they agreed that the driving should be abandoned.

``What's the use of it?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``There's nothing to see, and the wind is as cold as charity. We are much more comfortable here; are we not?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice quite acquiesced in this, having no great desire to be driven through the parks in the gloom of a February afternoon.

``If I had Dandy and Flirt up here, there would be some fun in it; but Mr. Palliser doesn't wish me to drive in London.'' (unknown)

``I suppose it would be dangerous?'' (unknown)

``Not in the least. I don't think it's that he (Palliser) minds; but he (Palliser) has an idea that it looks fast.'' (unknown)

``So it does. If I were a man, I'm sure I shouldn't like my wife to drive horses about London.'' (unknown)

``And why not? Just because you'd be a tyrant,--like other husbands? What's the harm of looking fast, if one doesn't do anything improper? Poor Dandy, and dear Flirt! I'm sure they'd like it.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps Mr. Palliser doesn't care for that?'' (unknown)

``I can tell you something else he (Palliser) doesn't care for. He (Palliser) doesn't care whether Dandy's mistress likes it.'' (unknown)

``Don't say that, Glencora.'' (unknown)

``Why not say it,--to you?'' (unknown)

``Don't teach yourself to think it. That's what I mean. I believe he (Dandy) would consent to anything that he (Dandy) didn't think wrong.'' (unknown)

``Such as lectures about the British Constitution! But never mind about that, Alice. Of course the British Constitution is everything to him (Dandy), and I wish I knew more about it;--that's all. But I haven't told you whom you are to meet at dinner.'' (unknown)

``Yes, you have--Mr. Bott.'' (unknown)

``But there's another guest, a Mrs. Marsham. I thought I'd got rid of her (Marsham) for to-day, when I wrote to you; but I hadn't. She (Marsham)'s coming.'' (unknown)

``She (Marsham) won't hurt me at all,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``She (Marsham) will hurt me very much. She (Marsham)'ll destroy the pleasure of our whole evening. I do believe that she (Marsham) hates you, and that she (Marsham) thinks you instigate me to all manner of iniquity. What fools they all are!'' (unknown)

``Who are they all, Glencora?'' (unknown)

``She (Glencora) and that man, and--. Never mind. It makes me sick when I think that they should be so blind. Alice, I hardly know how much I owe to you; I don't, indeed. Everything, I believe.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora, as she (Glencora) spoke, put her (Glencora) hand into her (Glencora) pocket, and grasped the letter which lay there.

``That's nonsense,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``No; it's not nonsense. Who do you think came to Matching when I was there?'' (unknown)

``What;--to the house?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, feeling almost certain that Mr. Fitzgerald was the person to whom Lady Glencora was alluding.

``No; not to the house.'' (unknown)

``If it is the person of whom I am thinking,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, solemnly,
``let me implore you not to speak of him (it).'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``And why should I not speak of him (it)? Did I not speak of him (it) before to you, and was it not for good? How are you to be my friend, if I may not speak to you of everything?'' (unknown)

``But you should not think of him (friend).'' (unknown)

``What nonsense you talk, Alice! Not think of him (friend)! How is one to help one's thoughts? Look here.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Her (Alice) hand was on the letter, and it would have been out in a moment, and thrown upon Alice's lap, had not the servant opened the door and announced Mrs. Marsham.

``Oh, how I do wish we had gone to drive!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, in a voice which the servant certainly heard, and which Mrs. Marsham would have heard had she (Marsham) not been a little hard of hearing,--in her (Marsham) bonnet.

``How do, my dear?'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham.
``I thought I'd just come across from Norfolk Street and see you, though I am coming to dinner in the evening. It's only just a step, you know. How d'ye do, Miss Vavasor?'' (she)
and she (Marsham) made a salutation to Alice which was nearly as cold as it could be.

Mrs. Marsham was a woman who had many good points. She (Marsham) was poor, and bore her (Marsham) poverty without complaint She (Marsham) was connected by blood and friendship with people rich and titled; but she (Marsham) paid to none of them egregious respect on account of their wealth or titles. She (Marsham) was staunch in her (Marsham) friendships, and staunch in her (Marsham) enmities. She (Marsham) was no fool, and knew well what was going on in the world. She (Marsham) could talk about the last novel, or--if need be--about the Constitution. She (Marsham) had been a true wife, though sometimes too strong-minded, and a painstaking mother, whose children, however, had never loved her (mother) as most mothers like to be loved.

The catalogue of her (mother) faults must be quite as long as that of her (mother) virtues. She (mother) was one of those women who are ambitious of power, and not very scrupulous as to the manner in which they obtain it. She (mother) was hardhearted, and capable of pursuing an object without much regard to the injury she (mother) might do. She (mother) would not flatter wealth or fawn before a title, but she (mother) was not above any artifice by which she (mother) might ingratiate herself with those whom it suited her (mother) purpose to conciliate. She (mother) thought evil rather than good. She (mother) was herself untrue in action, if not absolutely in word. I do not say that she (mother) would coin lies, but she (mother) would willingly leave false impressions. She (mother) had been the bosom friend, and in many things the guide in life, of Mr. Palliser's mother; and she (mother) took a special interest in Mr. Palliser's welfare. When he (Palliser) married, she (mother) heard the story of the loves of Burgo and Lady Glencora; and though she (Glencora) thought well of the money, she (Glencora) was not disposed to think very well of the bride. She (Glencora) made up her (Glencora) mind that the young lady would want watching, and she (Glencora) was of opinion that no one would be so well able to watch Lady Glencora as herself. She (Glencora) had not plainly opened her (Glencora) mind on this matter to Mr. Palliser; she (Glencora) had not made any distinct suggestion to him (Palliser) that she (Glencora) would act as Argus to his (Palliser) wife. Mr. Palliser would have rejected any such suggestion, and Mrs. Marsham knew that he (Palliser) would do so; but she (Marsham) had let a word or two drop, hinting that Lady Glencora was very young,--hinting that Lady Glencora's manners were charming in their childlike simplicity; but hinting also that precaution was, for that reason, the more necessary. Mr. Palliser, who suspected nothing as to Burgo or as to any other special peril, whose whole disposition was void of suspicion, whose dry nature realized neither the delights nor the dangers of love, acknowledged that Glencora was young. He (Burgo) especially wished that she (Glencora) should be discreet and matronly; he (Burgo) feared no lovers, but he (Burgo) feared that she (Glencora) might do silly things,--that she (Glencora) would catch cold,--and not know how to live a life becoming the wife of a Chancellor of the Exchequer. Therefore he (Chancellor) submitted Glencora,--and, to a certain extent, himself,--into the hands of Mrs. Marsham.

Lady Glencora had not been twenty-four hours in the house with this lady before she (Glencora) recognized in her (Glencora) a duenna. In all such matters no one could be quicker than Lady Glencora. She (Glencora) might be very ignorant about the British Constitution, and, alas! very ignorant also as to the real elements of right and wrong in a woman's conduct, but she (woman) was no fool. She (woman) had an eye that could see, and an ear that could understand, and an abundance of that feminine instinct which teaches a woman to know her (woman) friend or her (woman) enemy at a glance, at a touch, at a word. In many things Lady Glencora was much quicker, much more clever, than her (Glencora) husband, though he (husband) was to be Chancellor of the Exchequer, and though she (Glencora) did know nothing of the Constitution. She (Glencora) knew, too, that he (husband) was easily to be deceived,--that though his (husband) intelligence was keen, his (husband) instincts were dull,--that he (husband) was gifted with no fineness of touch, with no subtle appreciation of the characters of men and women; and, to a certain extent, she (Glencora) looked down upon him (husband) for his (husband) obtusity. He (husband) should have been aware that Burgo was a danger to be avoided; and he (Burgo) should have been aware also that Mrs. Marsham was a duenna not to be employed. When a woman knows that she (woman) is guarded by a watch-dog, she (woman) is bound to deceive her (woman) Cerberus, if it be possible, and is usually not ill-disposed to deceive also the owner of Cerberus. Lady Glencora felt that Mrs. Marsham was her (Glencora) Cerberus, and she (Glencora) was heartily resolved that if she (Glencora) was to be kept in the proper line at all, she (Glencora) would not be so kept by Mrs. Marsham.

Alice rose and accepted Mrs. Marsham's salutation quite as coldly as it had been given, and from that time forward those two ladies were enemies. Mrs. Marsham, groping quite in the dark, partly guessed that Alice had in some way interfered to prevent Lady Glencora's visit to Monkshade, and, though such prevention was, no doubt, good in that lady's eyes, she (lady) resented the interference. She (lady) had made up her (lady) mind that Alice was not the sort of friend that Lady Glencora should have about her (Glencora). Alice recognized and accepted the feud.

``I thought I might find you at home,'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham,
``as I know you are lazy about going out in the cold,--unless it be for a foolish midnight ramble,'' (Mrs. Marsham)
and Mrs. Marsham shook her (Marsham) head. She (Marsham) was a little woman, with sharp small eyes, with a permanent colour in her (Marsham) face, and two short, crisp, grey curls at each side of her (Marsham) face; always well dressed, always in good health, and, as Lady Glencora believed, altogether incapable of fatigue.

``The ramble you speak of was very wise, I think,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora;
``but I never could see the use of driving about in London in the middle of winter.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``One ought to go out of the house every day,'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham.

``I hate all those rules. Don't you, Alice?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice did not hate them, therefore she (Marsham) said nothing.

``My dear Glencora, one must live by rules in this life. You might as well say that you hated sitting down to dinner.'' (unknown)

``So I do, very often; almost always when there's company.'' (unknown)

``You'll get over that feeling after another season in town,'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham, pretending to suppose that Lady Glencora alluded to some remaining timidity in receiving her (Glencora) own guests.

``Upon my word I don't think I shall. It's a thing that seems always to be getting more grievous, instead of less so. Mr. Bott is coming to dine here to-night.'' (unknown)

There was no mistaking the meaning of this. There was no pretending even to mistake it. Now, Mrs. Marsham had accepted the right hand of fellowship from Mr. Bott,--not because she (Marsham) especially liked him (Bott), but in compliance with the apparent necessities of Mr. Palliser's position. Mr. Bott had made good his (Bott) ground about Mr. Palliser; and Mrs. Marsham, as she (Marsham) was not strong enough to turn him (Bott) off from it, had given him (Bott) the right hand of fellowship.

``Mr. Bott is a Member of Parliament, and a very serviceable friend of Mr. Palliser's,'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham.

``All the same; we do not like Mr. Bott--do we, Alice? He (Bott) is Doctor Fell to us; only I think we could tell why.'' (unknown)

``I certainly do not like him (Bott),'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``It can be but of small matter to you, Miss Vavasor,'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham,
``as you will not probably have to see much of him (Bott).'' (Mrs. Marsham)

``Of the very smallest moment,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``He (Bott) did annoy me once, but will never, I dare say, have an opportunity of doing so again.'' (unknown)

``I don't know what the annoyance may have been.'' (unknown)

``Of course you don't, Mrs. Marsham.'' (unknown)

``But I shouldn't have thought it likely that a person so fully employed as Mr. Bott, and employed, too, on matters of such vast importance, would have gone out of his (Bott) way to annoy a young lady whom he (Bott) chanced to meet for a day or two in a country-house.'' (unknown)

``I don't think that Alice means that he (Bott) attempted to flirt with her (Alice),'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, laughing.
``Fancy Mr. Bott's flirtation!'' (unknown)

``Perhaps he (Bott) did not attempt,'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham; and the words, the tone, and the innuendo together were more than Alice was able to bear with equanimity.

``Glencora,'' (she)
said she (Alice), rising from her (Alice) chair,
``I think I'll leave you alone with Mrs. Marsham. I'm not disposed to discuss Mr. Bott's character, and certainly not to hear his (Bott) name mentioned in disagreeable connection with my own.'' (she)

But Lady Glencora would not let her (Glencora) go.

``Nonsense, Alice,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said.
``If you and I can't fight our little battles against Mr. Bott and Mrs. Marsham without running away, it is odd. There is a warfare in which they who run away never live to fight another day.'' (unknown)

``I hope, Glencora, you do not count me as your enemy?'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham, drawing herself up.

``But I shall,--certainly, if you attack Alice. Love me, love my dog. I beg your pardon, Alice; but what I meant was this, Mrs. Marsham; Love me, love the best friend I have in the world.'' (unknown)

``I did not mean to offend Miss Vavasor,'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham, looking at her (Marsham) very grimly. Alice merely bowed her (Alice) head. She (Alice) had been offended, and she (Alice) would not deny it. After that, Mrs. Marsham took herself off, saying that she (Marsham) would be back to dinner. She (Marsham) was angry, but not unhappy. She (Marsham) thought that she (Marsham) could put down Miss Vavasor, and she (Vavasor) was prepared to bear a good deal from Lady Glencora--for Mr. Palliser's sake, as she (Glencora) said to herself, with some attempt at a sentimental remembrance of her (Glencora) old friend.

``She (Marsham)'s a nasty old cat,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, as soon as the door was closed; and she (Glencora) said these words with so droll a voice, with such a childlike shaking of her (Glencora) head, with so much comedy in her (Glencora) grimace, that Alice could not but laugh.
``She (Marsham) is,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``I know her (Marsham), and you'll have to know her (Marsham), too, before you've done with her (Marsham). It won't at all do for you to run away when she (Marsham) spits at you. You must hold your ground, and show your claws,--and make her (Marsham) know that if she (Marsham) spits, you can scratch.'' (unknown)

``But I don't want to be a cat myself.'' (unknown)

``She (Marsham)'ll find I'm of the genus, but of the tiger kind, if she (Marsham) persecutes me. Alice, there's one thing I have made up my mind about. I will not be persecuted. If my husband tells me to do anything, as long as he (husband) is my husband I'll do it; but I won't be persecuted.'' (unknown)

``You should remember that she (Alice) was a very old friend of Mr. Palliser's mother.'' (unknown)

``I do remember; and that may be a very good reason why she (Alice) should come here occasionally, or go to Matching, or to any place in which we may be living. It's a bore, of course; but it's a natural bore, and one that ought to be borne.'' (unknown)

``And that will be the beginning and the end of it.'' (unknown)

``I'm afraid not, my dear. It may perhaps be the end of it, but I fear it won't be the beginning. I won't be persecuted. If she (Alice) gives me advice, I shall tell her (Alice) to her (Alice) face that it's not wanted; and if she (Alice) insults any friend of mine, as she (Alice) did you, I shall tell her (Alice) that she (Alice) had better stay away. She (Alice)'ll go and tell him (friend), of course; but I can't help that. I've made up my mind that I won't be persecuted.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

After that, Lady Glencora felt no further inclination to show Burgo's letter to Alice on that occasion. They sat over the drawing-room fire, talking chiefly of Alice's affairs, till it was time for them to dress. But Alice, though she (Alice) spoke much of Mr. Grey, said no word as to her (Alice) engagement with George Vavasor. How could she (Alice) speak of it, inasmuch as she (Alice) had already resolved,--already almost resolved,--that that engagement also should be broken?

Alice, when she (Alice) came down to the drawing-room, before dinner, found Mr. Bott there alone. She (Alice) had dressed more quickly than her (Alice) friend, and Mr. Palliser had not yet made his (Palliser) appearance.

``I did not expect the pleasure of meeting Miss Vavasor to-day,'' (he)
he (Palliser) said, as he (Palliser) came up, offering his (Palliser) hand. She (Alice) gave him (Palliser) her (Alice) hand, and then sat down, merely muttering some word of reply.

``We spent a very pleasant month down at Matching together;--didn't you think so?'' (unknown)

``I spent a pleasant month there certainly.'' (unknown)

``You left, if I remember, the morning after that late walk out among the ruins? That was unfortunate, was it not? Poor Lady Glencora! it made her (Glencora) very ill; so much so, that she (Glencora) could not go to Monkshade, as she (Glencora) particularly wished. It was very sad. Lady Glencora is very delicate,--very delicate, indeed. We, who have the privilege of being near her (Glencora), ought always to remember that.'' (unknown)

``I don't think she (Glencora) is at all delicate.'' (unknown)

``Oh! don't you? I'm afraid that's your mistake, Miss Vavasor.'' (unknown)

``I believe she (Glencora) has very good health, which is the greatest blessing in the world. By delicate I suppose you mean weak and infirm.'' (unknown)

``Oh, dear, no,--not in the least,--not infirm certainly! I should be very sorry to be supposed to have said that Lady Glencora is infirm. What I mean is, not robust, Miss Vavasor. Her (Glencora) general organization, if you understand me, is exquisitely delicate. One can see that, I think, in every glance of her (Glencora) eye.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice was going to protest that she (Alice) had never seen it at all, when Mr. Palliser entered the room along with Mrs. Marsham.

The two gentlemen shook hands, and then Mr. Palliser turned to Alice. She (Alice) perceived at once by his (Palliser) face that she (Alice) was unwelcome, and wished herself away from his (Palliser) house. It might be all very well for Lady Glencora to fight with Mrs. Marsham,--and with her (Marsham) husband, too, in regard to the Marsham persecution,--but there could be no reason why she (Marsham) should do so. He (husband) just touched her (Marsham) hand, barely closing his (husband) thumb upon her (Marsham) fingers, and asked her (Marsham) how she (Marsham) was. Then he (husband) turned away from her (Marsham) side of the fire, and began talking to Mrs. Marsham on the other. There was that in his (husband) face and in his (husband) manner which was positively offensive to her (Marsham). He (husband) made no allusion to his (husband) former acquaintance with her (Marsham),--spoke no word about Matching, no word about his (husband) wife, as he (husband) would naturally have done to his (husband) wife's friend. Alice felt the blood mount into her (Alice) face, and regretted greatly that she (Alice) had ever come among these people. Had she (Alice) not long since made up her (Alice) mind that she (Alice) would avoid her (Alice) great relations, and did not all this prove that it would have been well for her (Alice) to have clung to that resolution? What was Lady Glencora to her (Glencora) that she (Glencora) should submit herself to be treated as though she (Glencora) were a poor companion,--a dependent, who received a salary for her (Glencora) attendance,--an indigent cousin, hanging on to the bounty of her (Glencora) rich connection? Alice was proud to a fault. She (Alice) had nursed her (Alice) pride till it was very faulty. All her (Alice) troubles and sorrows in life had come from an overfed craving for independence. Why, then, should she (Alice) submit to be treated with open want of courtesy by any man; but, of all men, why should she (Alice) submit to it from such a one as Mr. Palliser,--the heir of a ducal house, rolling in wealth, and magnificent with all the magnificence of British pomp and pride? No; she (Alice) would make Lady Glencora understand that the close intimacies of daily life were not possible to them!

``I declare I'm very much ashamed,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, as she (Glencora) entered the room.
``I shan't apologize to you, Alice, for it was you who kept me talking; but I do beg Mrs. Marsham's pardon.'' (Mrs. Marsham)

Mrs. Marsham was all smiles and forgiveness, and hoped that Lady Glencora would not make a stranger of her (Glencora). Then dinner was announced, and Alice had to walk down stairs by herself. She (Alice) did not care a doit for that, but there had been a disagreeable little contest when the moment came. Lady Glencora had wished to give up Mr. Bott to her (Glencora) cousin, but Mr. Bott had stuck manfully to Lady Glencora's side. He (Bott) hoped to take Lady Glencora down to dinner very often, and was not at all disposed to abate his (Bott) privilege.

During dinner-time Alice said very little, nor was there given to her (Alice) opportunity of saying much. She (Alice) could not but think of the day of her (Alice) first arrival at Matching Priory, when she (Alice) had sat between the Duke of St. Bungay and Jeffrey Palliser, and when everybody had been so civil to her (Alice)! She (Alice) now occupied one side of the table by herself, away from the fire, where she (Alice) felt cold and desolate in the gloom of the large half-lighted room. Mr. Palliser occupied himself with Mrs. Marsham, who talked politics to him (Palliser); and Mr. Bott never lost a moment in his (Bott) endeavours to say some civil word to Lady Glencora. Lady Glencora gave him (Bott) no encouragement; but she (Glencora) hardly dared to snub him (Bott) openly in her (Glencora) husband's immediate presence. Twenty times during dinner she (Glencora) said some little word to Alice, attempting at first to make the time pleasant, and then, when the matter was too far gone for that, attempting to give some relief. But it was of no avail. There are moments in which conversation seems to be impossible,--in which the very gods interfere to put a seal upon the lips of the unfortunate one. It was such a moment now with Alice. She (Alice) had never as yet been used to snubbing. Whatever position she (Alice) had hitherto held, in that she (Alice) had always stood foremost,--much more so than had been good for her (Alice). When she (Alice) had gone to Matching, she (Alice) had trembled for her (Alice) position; but there all had gone well with her (Alice); there Lady Glencora's kindness had at first been able to secure for her (Glencora) a reception that had been flattering, and almost better than flattering. Jeffrey Palliser had been her (Glencora) friend, and would, had she (Glencora) so willed it, have been more than her (Glencora) friend. But now she (Glencora) felt that the halls of the Pallisers were too cold for her (Glencora), and that the sooner she (Glencora) escaped from their gloom and hard discourtesy the better for her (Glencora).

Mrs. Marsham, when the three ladies had returned to the drawing-room together, was a little triumphant. She (Marsham) felt that she (Marsham) had put Alice down; and with the energetic prudence of a good general who knows that he (general) should follow up a victory, let the cost of doing so be what it may, she (Alice) determined to keep her (Alice) down. Alice had resolved that she (Alice) would come as seldom as might be to Mr. Palliser's house in Park Lane. That resolution on her (Alice) part was in close accordance with Mrs. Marsham's own views.

``Is Miss Vavasor going to walk home?'' (she)
she (Marsham) asked.

``Walk home;--all along Oxford Street! Good gracious! no. Why should she (Marsham) walk? The carriage will take her (Marsham).'' (unknown)

``Or a cab,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``I am quite used to go about London in a cab by myself.'' (unknown)

``I don't think they are nice for young ladies after dark,'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham.
``I was going to offer my servant to walk with her (Marsham). She (Marsham) is an elderly woman, and would not mind it.'' (unknown)

``I'm sure Alice is very much obliged,'' (Lady)
said Lady. Glencora;
``but she (Alice) will have the carriage.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``You are very good-natured,'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham;
``but gentlemen do so dislike having their horses out at night.'' (Mrs. Marsham)

``No gentleman's horses will be out,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, savagely;
``and as for mine, it's what they are there for.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
It was not often that Lady Glencora made any allusion to her (Glencora) own property, or allowed any one near her (Glencora) to suppose that she (Glencora) remembered the fact that her (Glencora) husband's great wealth was, in truth, her (Glencora) wealth. As to many matters her (Glencora) mind was wrong. In some things her (Glencora) taste was not delicate as should be that of a woman. But, as regarded her (Glencora) money, no woman could have behaved with greater reticence, or a purer delicacy. But now, when she (woman) was twitted by her (woman) husband's special friend with ill-usage to her (woman) husband's horses, because she (woman) chose to send her (woman) own friend home in her (woman) own carriage, she (woman) did find it hard to bear.

``I dare say it's all right,'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham.

``It is all right,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``Mr. Palliser has given me my horses for my own use, to do as I like with them; and if he (Palliser) thinks I take them out when they ought to be left at home, he (Palliser) can tell me so. Nobody else has a right to do it.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora, by this time, was almost in a passion, and showed that she (Glencora) was so.

``My dear Lady Glencora, you have mistaken me,'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham;
``I did not mean anything of that kind.'' (Mrs. Marsham)

``I am so sorry,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``And it is such a pity, as I am quite used to going about in cabs.'' (unknown)

``Of course you are,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``Why shouldn't you? I'd go home in a wheelbarrow if I couldn't walk, and had no other conveyance. That's not the question. Mrs. Marsham understands that.'' (unknown)

``Upon my word, I don't understand anything,'' (lady)
said that lady.

``I understand this,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora;
``that in all such matters as that, I intend to follow my own pleasure. Come, Alice, let us have some coffee,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
--and she (Glencora) rang the bell.
``What a fuss we have made about a stupid old carriage!'' (The gentlemen)

The gentlemen did not return to the drawing-room that evening, having, no doubt, joint work to do in arranging the great financial calculations of the nation; and, at an early hour, Alice was taken home in Lady Glencora's brougham, leaving her (Glencora) cousin still in the hands of Mrs. Marsham.

CHAPTER XLIV.

The Election for the Chelsea Districts.

March came, and still the Chancellor of the Exchequer held his (Chancellor) position. In the early days of March there was given in the House a certain parliamentary explanation on the subject, which, however, did not explain very much to any person. A statement was made which was declared by the persons making it to be altogether satisfactory, but nobody else seemed to find any satisfaction in it. The big wigs of the Cabinet had made an arrangement which, from the language used by them on this occasion, they must be supposed to have regarded as hardly less permanent than the stars; but everybody else protested that the Government was going to pieces; and Mr. Bott was heard to declare in clubs and lobbies, and wherever he (Bott) could get a semi-public, political hearing, that this kind of thing wouldn't do. Lord Brock must either blow hot or cold. If he (Brock) chose to lean upon Mr. Palliser, he (Palliser) might lean upon him (Palliser), and Mr. Palliser would not be found wanting. In such case no opposition could touch Lord Brock or the Government. That was Mr. Bott's opinion. But if Lord Brock did not so choose, why, in that case, he (Brock) must expect that Mr. Palliser, and Mr. Palliser's friends, would--. Mr. Bott did not say what they would do; but he (Bott) was supposed by those who understood the matter to hint at an Opposition lobby, and adverse divisions, and to threaten Lord Brock with the open enmity of Mr. Palliser,--and of Mr. Palliser's great follower.

``This kind of thing won't do long, you know,'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
repeated Mr. Bott for the second or third time, as he (Bott) stood upon the rug before the fire at his (Bott) club, with one or two of his (Bott) young friends around him (Bott).

``I suppose not,'' (Calder Jones/Jones)
said Calder Jones, the hunting Member of Parliament whom we once met at Roebury.
``Planty Pall won't stand it, I should say.'' (unknown)

``What can he (Marsham) do?'' (an Member)
asked another, an unfledged Member who was not as yet quite settled as to the leadership under which he (Member) intended to work.

``What can he (Marsham) do?'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Mr. Bott, who on such an occasion as this could be very great,--who, for a moment, could almost feel that he (Bott) might become a leader of a party for himself, and some day institute a Bott Ministry.
``What can he (Marsham) do? You will very shortly see what he (Marsham) can do. He (Marsham) can make himself the master of the occasion. If Lord Brock doesn't look about him (Brock), he (Brock)'ll find that Mr. Palliser will be in the Cabinet without his (Palliser) help.'' (unknown)

``You don't mean to say that the Queen will send for Planty Pall!'' (the Member)
said the young Member.

``I mean to say that the Queen will send for any one that the House of Commons may direct her (Queen) to call upon,'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Mr. Bott, who conceived himself to have gauged the very depths of our glorious Constitution.
``How hard it is to make any one understand that the Queen has really nothing to do with it!'' (unknown)

``Come, Bott, draw it mild,'' (Calder Jones/Jones)
said Calder Jones, whose loyalty was shocked by the utter Manchesterialism of his (Jones) political friend.

``Not if I know it,'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Mr. Bott, with something of grandeur in his (Bott) tone and countenance.
``I never drew it mild yet, and I shan't begin now. All our political offences against civilization have come from men drawing it mild, as you call it. Why is it that Englishmen can't read and write as Americans do? Why can't they vote as they do even in Imperial France? Why are they serfs, less free than those whose chains were broken the other day in Russia? Why is the Spaniard more happy, and the Italian more contented? Because men in power have been drawing it mild!'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
And Mr. Bott made an action with his (Bott) hand as though he (Bott) were drawing up beer from a patent tap.

``But you can't set aside Her (serfs) Majesty like that, you know,'' (the Member notions)
said the young Member, who had been presented, and whose mother's old-world notions about the throne still clung to him (Member).

``I should be very sorry,'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Mr. Bott;
``I'm no republican.'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
With all his (Bott) constitutional love, Mr. Bott did not know what the word republican meant.
``I mean no disrespect to the throne. The throne in its place is very well. But the power of governing this great nation does not rest with the throne. It is contained within the four walls of the House of Commons. That is the great truth which all young Members should learn, and take to their hearts.'' (unknown)

``And you think Planty Pall will become Prime Minister?'' (Calder Jones/Jones)
said Calder Jones.

``I haven't said that; but there are more unlikely things. Among young men I know no man more likely. But I certainly think this,--that if Lord Brock doesn't take him (Brock) into the Cabinet, Lord Brock won't long remain there himself.'' (posters)

In the meantime the election came on in the Chelsea districts, and the whole of the south-western part of the metropolis was covered with posters bearing George Vavasor's name.

``Vote for Vavasor and the River Bank.'' (he)
That was the cry with which he (Vavasor) went to the electors; and though it must be presumed that it was understood by some portion of the Chelsea electors, it was perfectly unintelligible to the majority of those who read it. His (Vavasor) special acquaintances and his (Vavasor) general enemies called him (Vavasor) Viscount Riverbank, and he (Vavasor) was pestered on all sides by questions as to Father Thames. It was Mr. Scruby who invented the legend, and who gave George Vavasor an infinity of trouble by the invention. There was a question in those days as to embanking the river from the Houses of Parliament up to the remote desolations of further Pimlico, and Mr. Scruby recommended the coming Member to pledge himself that he (Scruby) would have the work carried on even to Battersea Bridge.
``You must have a subject,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
pleaded Mr. Scruby.
``No young Member can do anything without a subject. And it should be local;--that is to say, if you have anything of a constituency. Such a subject as that, if it's well worked, may save you thousands of pounds--thousands of pounds at future elections.'' (unknown)

``It won't save me anything at this one, I take it.'' (unknown)

``But it may secure the seat, Mr. Vavasor, and afterwards make you the most popular metropolitan Member in the House; that is, with your own constituency. Only look at the money that would be spent in the districts if that were done! It would come to millions, sir!'' (unknown)

``But it never will be done.'' (unknown)

``What matters that?'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
and Mr. Scruby almost became eloquent as he (Scruby) explained the nature of a good parliamentary subject.
``You should work it up, so as to be able to discuss it at all points. Get the figures by heart, and then, as nobody else will do so, nobody can put you down. Of course it won't be done. If it were done, that would be an end of it, and your bread would be taken out of your mouth. But you can always promise it at the hustings, and can always demand it in the House. I've known men who've walked into as much as two thousand a year, permanent place, on the strength of a worse subject than that!'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)

Vavasor allowed Mr. Scruby to manage the matter for him (Scruby), and took up the subject of the River Bank.

``Vavasor and the River Bank'' (men)
was carried about by an army of men with iron shoulder-straps, and huge pasteboard placards six feet high on the top of them. You would think, as you saw the long rows, that the men were being marshalled to their several routes; but they always kept together--four-and-twenty at the heels of each other.
``One placard at a time would strike the eye,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said Mr. Vavasor, counting the expense up to himself.
``There's no doubt of it,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby in reply.
``One placard will do that, if it's big enough; but it takes four-and-twenty to touch the imagination.'' (unknown)
And then sides of houses were covered with that shibboleth--
``Vavasor and the River Bank'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
--the same words repeated in columns down the whole sides of houses. Vavasor himself declared that he (Scruby) was ashamed to walk among his (Scruby) future constituents, so conspicuous had his (Scruby) name become. Grimes saw it, and was dismayed. At first, Grimes ridiculed the cry with all his (Grimes) publican's wit.
``Unless he (I) mean to drown hisself in the Reach, it's hard to say what he (I) do mean by all that gammon about the River Bank,'' (Mr. Grimes/Grimes)
said Grimes, as he (Grimes) canvassed for the other Liberal candidate. But, after a while, Grimes was driven to confess that Mr. Scruby knew what he (Scruby) was about.
``He (I) is a sharp `un, that he (I) is,'' (Mr. Grimes/Grimes)
said Grimes in the inside bar of the
``Handsome Man;'' (Mr. Grimes/Grimes)
and he (Grimes) almost regretted that he (Grimes) had left the leadership of Mr. Scruby, although he (Scruby) knew that on this occasion he (Scruby) would not have gotten his (Scruby) odd money.

George Vavasor, with much labour, actually did get up the subject of the River Bank. He (Vavasor) got himself introduced to men belonging to the Metropolitan Board, and went manfully into the matter of pounds, shillings, and pence. He (Vavasor) was able even to work himself into an apparent heat when he (Vavasor) was told that the thing was out of the question; and soon found that he (Vavasor) had disciples who really believed in him (Vavasor). If he (Vavasor) could have brought himself to believe in the thing,--if he (Vavasor) could have been induced himself to care whether Chelsea was to be embanked or no, the work would not have been so difficult to him (Vavasor). In that case it would have done good to him (Vavasor), if to no one else. But such belief was beyond him (Vavasor). He (Vavasor) had gone too far in life to be capable of believing in, or of caring for, such things. He (Vavasor) was ambitious of having a hand in the government of his (Vavasor) country, but he (Vavasor) was not capable of caring even for that.

But he (Vavasor) worked. He (Vavasor) worked hard, and spoke vehemently, and promised the men of Chelsea, Pimlico, and Brompton that the path of London westwards had hardly commenced as yet. Sloane Street should be the new Cheapside. Squares should arise around the Chelsea barracks, with sides open to the water, for which Belgravia would be deserted. There should be palaces there for the rich, because the rich spend their riches; but no rich man's palace should interfere with the poor man's right to the River Bank. Three millions and a half should be spent on the noble street to be constructed, the grandest pathway that the world should ever yet have seen; three millions and a half to be drawn from,--to be drawn from anywhere except from Chelsea;--from the bloated money-bags of the City Corporation, Vavasor once ventured to declare, amidst the encouraging shouts of the men of Chelsea. Mr. Scruby was forced to own that his (Scruby) pupil worked the subject well.

``Upon my word, that was uncommon good,'' (he)
he (Scruby) said, almost patting Vavasor on the back, after a speech in which he (Scruby) had vehemently asserted that his (Scruby) ambition to represent the Chelsea districts had all come of his (Scruby) long-fixed idea that the glory of future London would be brought about by the embankment of the river at Chelsea.

But armies of men carrying big boards, and public-houses open at every corner, and placards in which the letters are three feet long, cost money. Those few modest hundreds which Mr. Scruby had already received before the work began, had been paid on the supposition that the election would not take place till September. Mr. Scruby made an early request, a very early request, that a further sum of fifteen hundred pounds should be placed in his (Scruby) hands; and he (Scruby) did this in a tone which clearly signified that not a man would be sent about through the streets, or a poster put upon a wall, till this request had been conceded. Mr. Scruby was in possession of two very distinct manners of address. In his (Scruby) jovial moods, when he (Scruby) was instigating his (Scruby) clients to fight their battles well, it might almost be thought that he (Scruby) was doing it really for the love of the thing; and some clients, so thinking, had believed for a few hours that Scruby, in his (Scruby) jolly, passionate eagerness, would pour out his (Scruby) own money like dust, trusting implicitly to future days for its return. But such clients had soon encountered Mr. Scruby's other manner, and had perceived that they were mistaken.

The thing had come so suddenly upon George Vavasor that there was not time for him (Vavasor) to carry on his (Vavasor) further operations through his (Vavasor) sister. Had he (Vavasor) written to Kate,--let him (Vavasor) have written in what language he (Vavasor) would,--she (Kate) would have first rejoined by a negative, and there would have been a correspondence before he (Vavasor) had induced her (Kate) to comply. He (Vavasor) thought of sending for her (Kate) by telegram, but even in that there would have been too much delay. He (Vavasor) resolved, therefore, to make his (Vavasor) application to Alice himself, and he (Vavasor) wrote to her (Alice), explaining his (Vavasor) condition. The election had come upon him (Vavasor) quite suddenly, as she (Alice) knew, he (Vavasor) said. He (Vavasor) wanted two thousand pounds instantly, and felt little scruple in asking her (Alice) for it, as he (Vavasor) was aware that the old Squire would be only too glad to saddle the property with a legacy to Alice for the repayment of this money, though he (Squire) would not have advanced a shilling himself for the purpose of the election. Then he (Squire) said a word or two as to his (Squire) prolonged absence from Queen Anne Street. He (Squire) had not been there because he (Squire) had felt, from her (Queen) manner when they last met, that she (Queen) would for a while prefer to be left free from the unavoidable excitement of such interviews. But should he (Squire) be triumphant in his (Squire) present contest, he (Squire) should go to her (Queen) to share his (Squire) triumph with her (Queen); or, should he (Squire) fail, he (Squire) should go to her (Queen) to console him (Squire) in his (Squire) failure.

Within three days he (Squire) heard from her (Queen), saying that the money would be at once placed to his (Squire) credit. She (Queen) sent him (Squire) also her (Queen) candid good wishes for success in his (Squire) enterprise, but beyond this her (Queen) letter said nothing. There was no word of love,--no word of welcome,--no expression of a desire to see him (Squire). Vavasor, as he (Squire) perceived all this in the reading of her (Queen) note, felt a triumph in the possession of her (Queen) money. She (Queen) was ill-using him (Squire) by her (Queen) coldness, and there was comfort in revenge.

``It serves her (I) right,'' (he)
he (Squire) said to himself.
``She (I) should have married me at once when she (I) said she (I) would do so, and then it would have been my own.'' (Mr. Tombe)

When Mr. Tombe had communicated with John Grey on the matter of this increased demand,--this demand which Mr. Tombe began to regard as carrying a love-affair rather too far,--Grey had telegraphed back that Vavasor's demand for money, if made through Mr. John Vavasor, was to be honoured to the extent of five thousand pounds. Mr. Tombe raised his (Tombe) eyebrows, and reflected that some men were very foolish. But John Grey's money matters were of such a nature as to make Mr. Tombe know that he (Tombe) must do as he (Tombe) was bidden; and the money was paid to George Vavasor's account.

He (Vavasor) told Kate nothing of this. Why should he (Vavasor) trouble himself to do so? Indeed, at this time he (Vavasor) wrote no letters to his (Vavasor) sister, though she (sister) twice sent to him (Vavasor), knowing what his (Vavasor) exigencies would be, and made further tenders of her (sister) own money. He (Vavasor) could not reply to these offers without telling her (sister) that money had been forthcoming from that other quarter, and so he (Vavasor) left them unanswered.

In the meantime the battle went on gloriously. Mr. Travers, the other Liberal candidate, spent his (Travers) money freely,--or else some other person did so on his (Travers) behalf. When Mr. Scruby mentioned this last alternative to George Vavasor, George cursed his (George) own luck in that he (George) had never found such backers.

``I don't call a man half a Member when he (Member)'s brought in like that,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby, comforting him (Scruby).
``He (Member) can't do what he (Member) likes with his (Member) vote. He (Member) ain't independent. You never hear of those fellows getting anything good. Pay for the article yourself, Mr. Vavasor, and then it's your own. That's what I always say.'' (Mr. Grimes/Grimes)

Mr. Grimes went to work strenuously, almost fiercely, in the opposite interest, telling all that he (Grimes) knew, and perhaps more than he (Grimes) knew, of Vavasor's circumstances. He (Grimes) was at work morning, noon, and night, not only in his (Grimes) own neighbourhood, but among those men on the river bank of whom he (Grimes) had spoken so much in his (Grimes) interview with Vavasor in Cecil Street. The entire Vavasorian army with its placards was entirely upset on more than one occasion, and was once absolutely driven ignominiously into the river mud. And all this was done under the direction of Mr. Grimes. Vavasor himself was pelted with offal from the sinking tide, so that the very name of the River Bank became odious to him (Grimes). He (Grimes) was a man who did not like to have his (Grimes) person touched, and when they hustled him (Grimes) he (Grimes) became angry.

``Lord love you, Mr. Vavasor,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Scruby,
``that's nothing! I've had a candidate so mauled,--it was in the Hamlets, I think,--that there wasn't a spot on him (Vavasor) that wasn't painted with rotten eggs. The smell was something quite awful. But I brought him (Vavasor) in, through it all.'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)

And Mr. Scruby at last did as much for George Vavasor as he (Vavasor) had done for the hero of the Hamlets. At the close of the poll Vavasor's name stood at the head by a considerable majority, and Scruby comforted him (Scruby) by saying that Travers certainly wouldn't stand the expense of a petition, as the seat was to be held only for a few months.

``And you've done it very cheap, Mr. Vavasor,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Scruby,
``considering that the seat is metropolitan. I do say that you have done it cheap. Another thousand, or twelve hundred, will cover everything--say thirteen, perhaps, at the outside. And when you shall have fought the battle once again, you'll have paid your footing, and the fellows will let you in almost for nothing after that.'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)

A further sum of thirteen hundred pounds was wanted at once, and then the whole thing was to be repeated over again in six months' time! This was not consolatory. But, nevertheless, there was a triumph in the thing itself which George Vavasor was man enough to enjoy. It would be something to have sat in the House of Commons, though it should only have been for half a session.

CHAPTER XLV.

George Vavasor Takes His (Vavasor) Seat.

George Vavasor's feeling of triumph was not unjustifiable. It is something to have sat in the House of Commons, though it has been but for one session! There is on the left-hand side of our great national hall,--on the left-hand side as one enters it, and opposite to the doors leading to the Law Courts,--a pair of gilded lamps, with a door between them, near to which a privileged old dame sells her (them) apples and her (them) oranges solely, as I presume, for the accommodation of the Members of the House and of the great policeman who guards the pass. Between those lamps is the entrance to the House of Commons, and none but Members may go that way! It is the only gate before which I have ever stood filled with envy,--sorrowing to think that my steps might never pass under it. There are many portals forbidden to me, as there are many forbidden to all men; and forbidden fruit, they say, is sweet; but my lips have watered after no other fruit but that which grows so high, within the sweep of that great policeman's truncheon.

Ah, my male friend and reader, who earnest thy bread, perhaps, as a country vicar; or sittest, may-be, at some weary desk in Somerset House; or who, perhaps, rulest the yard behind the Cheapside counter, hast thou never stood there and longed,--hast thou never confessed, when standing there, that Fate has been unkind to thee in denying thee the one thing that thou hast wanted? I have done so; and as my slow steps have led me up that more than royal staircase, to those passages and halls which require the hallowing breath of centuries to give them the glory in British eyes which they shall one day possess, I have told myself, in anger and in grief, that to die and not to have won that right of way, though but for a session,--not to have passed by the narrow entrance through those lamps,--is to die and not to have done that which it most becomes an Englishman to have achieved.

There are, doubtless, some who come out by that road, the loss of whose society is not to be regretted. England does not choose her (Englishman) six hundred and fifty-four best men. One comforts one's self, sometimes, with remembering that. The George Vavasors, the Calder Joneses, and the Botts are admitted. Dishonesty, ignorance, and vulgarity do not close the gate of that heaven against aspirants; and it is a consolation to the ambition of the poor to know that the ambition of the rich can attain that glory by the strength of its riches alone. But though England does not send thither none but her (Englishman) best men, the best of her (Englishman) Commoners do find their way there. It is the highest and most legitimate pride of an Englishman to have the letters M.P. written after his (Englishman) name. No selection from the alphabet, no doctorship, no fellowship, be it of ever so learned or royal a society, no knightship,--not though it be of the Garter,--confers so fair an honour. Mr. Bott was right when he (Bott) declared that this country is governed from between the walls of that House, though the truth was almost defiled by the lips which uttered it. He (Bott) might have added that from thence flow the waters of the world's progress,--the fullest fountain of advancing civilization.

George Vavasor, as he (Vavasor) went in by the lamps and the apple-stall, under the guardianship of Mr. Bott, felt all the pride of which I have been speaking. He (Bott) was a man quite capable of feeling such pride as it should be felt,--capable, in certain dreamy moments, of looking at the thing with pure and almost noble eyes; of understanding the ambition of serving with truth so great a nation as that which fate had made his (Bott) own. Nature, I think, had so fashioned George Vavasor, that he (Vavasor) might have been a good, and perhaps a great man; whereas Mr. Bott had been born small. Vavasor had educated himself to badness with his (Bott) eyes open. He (Bott) had known what was wrong, and had done it, having taught himself to think that bad things were best. But poor Mr. Bott had meant to do well, and thought that he (Bott) had done very well indeed. He (Bott) was a tuft-hunter and a toady, but he (Bott) did not know that he (Bott) was doing amiss in seeking to rise by tuft-hunting and toadying. He (Bott) was both mean and vain, both a bully and a coward, and in politics, I fear, quite unscrupulous in spite of his (Bott) grand dogmas; but he (Bott) believed that he (Bott) was progressing in public life by the proper and usual means, and was troubled by no idea that he (Bott) did wrong.

Vavasor, in those dreamy moments of which I have spoken, would sometimes feel tempted to cut his (Bott) throat and put an end to himself, because he (Bott) knew that he (Bott) had taught himself amiss. Again he (Bott) would sadly ask himself whether it was yet too late; always, however, answering himself that it was too late. Even now, at this moment, as he (Bott) went in between the lamps, and felt much of the honest pride of which I have spoken, he (Bott) told himself that it was too late. What could he (Bott) do now, hampered by such a debt as that which he (Bott) owed to his (Bott) cousin, and with the knowledge that it must be almost indefinitely increased, unless he (Bott) meant to give up this seat in Parliament, which had cost him (Bott) so dearly, almost before he (Bott) had begun to enjoy it? But his (Bott) courage was good, and he (Bott) was able to resolve that he (Bott) would go on with the business that he (Bott) had in hand, and play out his (Bott) game to the end. He (Bott) had achieved his (Bott) seat in the House of Commons, and was so far successful. Men who had ever been gracious to him (Bott) were now more gracious than ever, and they who had not hitherto treated him (Bott) with courtesy, now began to smile and to be very civil. It was, no doubt, a great thing to have the privilege of that entrance between the lamps.

Mr. Bott had the new Member now in hand, not because there had been any old friendship between them, but Mr. Bott was on the look-out for followers, and Vavasor was on the look-out for a party. A man gets no great thanks for attaching himself to existing power. Our friend might have enrolled himself among the general supporters of the Government without attracting much attention. He (friend) would in such case have been at the bottom of a long list. But Mr. Palliser was a rising man, round whom, almost without wish of his (Palliser) own, a party was forming itself. If he (Palliser) came into power,--as come he (Palliser) must, according to Mr. Bott and many others,--then they who had acknowledged the new light before its brightness had been declared, might expect their reward.

Vavasor, as he (Bott) passed through the lobby to the door of the House, leaning on Mr. Bott's arm, was very silent. He (Bott) had spoken but little since they had left their cab in Palace Yard, and was not very well pleased by the garrulity of his (Bott) companion. He (Bott) was going to sit among the first men of his (Bott) nation, and to take his (Bott) chance of making himself one of them. He (Bott) believed in his (Bott) own ability; he (Bott) believed thoroughly in his (Bott) own courage; but he (Bott) did not believe in his (Bott) own conduct. He (Bott) feared that he (Bott) had done,--feared still more strongly that he (Bott) would be driven to do,--that which would shut men's ears against his (Bott) words, and would banish him (Bott) from high places. No man believes in himself who knows himself to be a rascal, however great may be his (rascal) talent, or however high his (rascal) pluck.

``Of course you have heard a debate?'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Mr. Bott.

``Yes,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
answered Vavasor, who wished to remain silent.

``Many, probably?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``But you have heard debates from the gallery. Now you'll hear them from the body of the House, and you'll find how very different it is. There's no man can know what Parliament is who has never had a seat. Indeed no one can thoroughly understand the British Constitution without it. I felt, very early in life, that that should be my line; and though it's hard work and no pay, I mean to stick to it. How do, Thompson? You know Vavasor? He (Thompson)'s just returned for the Chelsea Districts, and I'm taking him (Thompson) up. We shan't divide to-night; shall we? Look! there's Farringcourt just coming out; he (Thompson)'s listened to better than any man in the House now, but he (Thompson)'ll borrow half-a-crown from you if you'll lend him (Thompson) one. How d'ye do, my lord? I hope I have the pleasure of seeing you well?'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
and Bott bowed low to a lord who was hurrying through the lobby as fast as his (Bott) shuffling feet would carry him (Bott).
``Of course you know him (Thompson)?'' (the lord)

Vavasor, however, did not know the lord in question, and was obliged to say so.

``I thought you were up to all these things?'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Bott.

``Taking the peerage generally, I am not up to it,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor, with a curl on his (Bott) lip.

``But you ought to have known him (Thompson). That was Viscount Middlesex; he (Thompson) has got something on to-night about the Irish Church. His (Thompson) father is past ninety, and he (Thompson)'s over sixty. We'll go in now; but let me give you one bit of advice, my dear fellow--don't think of speaking this session. A Member can do no good at that work till he (Member) has learned something of the forms of the House. The forms of the House are everything; upon my word they are. This is Mr. Vavasor, the new Member for the Chelsea Districts.'' (friend)

Our friend was thus introduced to the doorkeeper, who smiled familiarly, and seemed to wink his (Bott) eye. Then George Vavasor passed through into the House itself, under the wing of Mr. Bott.

Vavasor, as he (Bott) walked up the House to the Clerk's table and took the oath and then walked down again, felt himself to be almost taken aback by the little notice which was accorded to him (Bott). It was not that he (Bott) had expected to create a sensation, or that he (Bott) had for a moment thought on the subject, but the thing which he (Bott) was doing was so great to him (Bott), that the total indifference of those around him (Bott) was a surprise to him (Bott). After he (Bott) had taken his (Bott) seat, a few men came up by degrees and shook hands with him (Bott); but it seemed, as they did so, merely because they were passing that way. He (Bott) was anxious not to sit next to Mr. Bott, but he (Bott) found himself unable to avoid this contiguity. That gentleman stuck to him (gentleman) pertinaciously, giving him (gentleman) directions which, at the spur of the moment, he (gentleman) hardly knew how not to obey. So he (gentleman) found himself sitting behind Mr. Palliser, a little to the right, while Mr. Bott occupied the ear of the rising man.

There was a debate in progress, but it seemed to Vavasor, as soon as he (Bott) was able to become critical, to be but a dull affair, and yet the Chancellor of the Exchequer was on his (Chancellor) legs, and Mr. Palliser was watching him (Palliser) as a cat watches a mouse. The speaker was full of figures, as becomes a Chancellor of the Exchequer; and as every new budget of them fell from him (Chancellor), Mr. Bott, with audible whispers, poured into the ear of his (Bott) chief certain calculations of his (Bott) own, most of which went to prove that the financier in office was altogether wrong. Vavasor thought that he (financier) could see that Mr. Palliser was receiving more of his (Palliser) assistance than was palatable to him (Palliser). He (Palliser) would listen, if he (Palliser) did listen, without making any sign that he (Palliser) heard, and would occasionally shake his (Palliser) head with symptoms of impatience. But Mr. Bott was a man not to be repressed by a trifle. When Mr. Palliser shook his (Palliser) head he (Palliser) became more assiduous than ever, and when Mr. Palliser slightly moved himself to the left, he (Palliser) boldly followed him (Palliser).

No general debate arose on the subject which the Minister had in hand, and when he (Minister) sat down, Mr. Palliser would not get up, though Mr. Bott counselled him (Bott) to do so. The matter was over for the night, and the time had arrived for Lord Middlesex. That nobleman got upon his (nobleman) feet, with a roll of papers in his (nobleman) hand, and was proceeding to address the House on certain matters of church reform, with great energy; but, alas, for him (nobleman) and for his (nobleman) feelings! before his (nobleman) energy had got itself into full swing, the Members were swarming away through the doors like a flock of sheep. Mr. Palliser got up and went, and was followed at once by Mr. Bott, who succeeded in getting hold of his (Bott) arm in the lobby. Had not Mr. Palliser been an even-tempered, calculating man, with a mind and spirit well under his (Palliser) command, he (Palliser) must have learned to hate Mr. Bott before this time. Away streamed the Members, but still the noble lord went on speaking, struggling hard to keep up his (lord) fire as though no such exodus were in process. There was but little to console him (lord). He (lord) knew that the papers would not report one sentence in twenty of those he (lord) uttered. He (lord) knew that no one would listen to him (lord) willingly. He (lord) knew that he (lord) had worked for weeks and months to get up his (lord) facts, and he (lord) was beginning to know that he (lord) had worked in vain. As he (lord) summoned courage to look round, he (lord) began to fear that some enemy would count the House, and that all would be over. He (lord) had given heart and soul to this affair. His (lord) cry was not as Vavasor's cry about the River Bank. He (lord) believed in his (lord) own subject with a great faith, thinking that he (lord) could make men happier and better, and bring them nearer to their God. I said that he (God) had worked for weeks and months. I might have said that he (God) had been all his (God) life at this work. Though he (God) shuffled with his (God) feet when he (God) walked, and knocked his (God) words together when he (God) talked, he (God) was an earnest man, meaning to do well, seeking no other reward for his (God) work than the appreciation of those whom he (God) desired to serve. But this was never to be his (God). For him (God) there was in store nothing but disappointment. And yet he (God) will work on to the end, either in this House or in the other, labouring wearily, without visible wages of any kind, and, one may say, very sadly. But when he (God) has been taken to his (God) long rest, men will acknowledge that he (God) has done something, and there will be left on the minds of those who shall remember him (God) a conviction that he (God) served a good cause diligently, and not altogether inefficiently. Invisible are his (God) wages, yet in some coin are they paid. Invisible is the thing he (God) does, and yet it is done. Let us hope that some sense of this tardy appreciation may soothe his (God) spirit beyond the grave. On the present occasion there was nothing to soothe his (God) spirit. The Speaker sat, urbane and courteous, with his (Speaker) eyes turned towards the unfortunate orator; but no other ears in the House seemed to listen to him (Speaker). The corps of reporters had dwindled down to two, and they used their pens very listlessly, taking down here a sentence and there a sentence, knowing that their work was naught. Vavasor sat it out to the last, as it taught him (Speaker) a lesson in those forms of the House which Mr. Bott had truly told him (Bott) it would be well that he (Bott) should learn. And at last he (Bott) did learn the form of a

``count-out.'' (he)
Some one from a back seat muttered something, which the Speaker understood; and that high officer, having had his (Speaker) attention called to a fact of which he (Speaker) would never have taken cognizance without such calling, did count the House, and finding that it contained but twenty-three Members, he (Speaker) put an end to his (Speaker) own labours and to those of poor Lord Middlesex. With what feelings that noble lord must have taken himself home, and sat himself down in his (lord) study, vainly opening a book before his (lord) eyes, can we not all imagine? A man he (lord) was with ample means, with children who would do honour to his (lord) name; one whose wife believed in him (lord), if no one else would do so; a man, let us say, with a clear conscience, to whom all good things had been given. But of whom now was he (man) thinking with envy? Early on that same day Farringcourt had spoken in the House,--a man to whom no one would lend a shilling, whom the privilege of that House kept out of gaol, whose word no man believed; who was wifeless, childless, and unloved. But three hundred men had hung listening upon his (man) words. When he (man) laughed in his (man) speech, they laughed; when he (man) was indignant against the Minister, they sat breathless, as the Spaniard sits in the critical moment of the bull-killing. Whichever way he (Spaniard) turned himself, he (Spaniard) carried them with him (Spaniard). Crowds of Members flocked into the House from libraries and smoking-rooms when it was known that this ne'er-do-well was on his (Spaniard) legs. The Strangers' Gallery was filled to overflowing. The reporters turned their rapid pages, working their fingers wearily till the sweat drops stood upon their brows. And as the Premier was attacked with some special impetus of redoubled irony, men declared that he (Premier) would be driven to enrol the speaker among his (Premier) colleagues, in spite of dishonoured bills and evil reports. A man who could shake the thunderbolts like that must be paid to shake them on the right side. It was of this man, and of his (man) success, that Lord Middlesex was envious, as he (Middlesex) sat, wretched and respectable, in his (Middlesex) solitary study!

Mr. Bott had left the House with Mr. Palliser; and Vavasor, after the count-out, was able to walk home by himself, and think of the position which he (Bott) had achieved. He (Bott) told himself over and over again that he (Bott) had done a great thing in obtaining that which he (Bott) now possessed, and he (Bott) endeavoured to teach himself that the price he (Bott) was paying for it was not too dear. But already there had come upon him (Bott) something of that feeling,--that terribly human feeling,--which deprives every prize that is gained of half its value. The mere having it robs the diamond of its purity, and mixes vile alloy with the gold. Lord Middlesex, as he (Middlesex) had floundered on into terrible disaster, had not been a subject to envy. There had been nothing of brilliance in the debate, and the Members had loomed no larger than ordinary men at ordinary clubs. The very doorkeepers had hardly treated them with respect. The great men with whose names the papers are filled had sat silent, gloomy, and apparently idle. As soon as a fair opportunity was given them they escaped out of the House, as boys might escape from school. Everybody had rejoiced in the break-up of the evening, except that one poor old lord who had worked so hard. Vavasor had spent everything that he (lord) had to become a Member of that House, and now, as he (lord) went alone to his (lord) lodgings, he (lord) could not but ask himself whether the thing purchased was worth the purchase-money.

But his (lord) courage was still high. Though he (lord) was gloomy, and almost sad, he (lord) knew that he (lord) could trust himself to fight out the battle to the last. On the morrow he (lord) would go to Queen Anne Street, and would demand sympathy there from her (Queen) who had professed to sympathize with him (lord) so strongly in his (lord) political desires. With her (Queen), at any rate, the glory of his (lord) Membership would not be dimmed by any untoward knowledge of the realities. She (Queen) had only seen the play acted from the boxes; and to her (Queen) eyes the dresses would still be of silk velvet, and the swords of bright steel.

CHAPTER XLVI.

A Love Gift.

When Alice heard of her (Alice) cousin's success, and understood that he (cousin) was actually Member of Parliament for the Chelsea Districts, she (Districts) resolved that she (Districts) would be triumphant. She (Districts) had sacrificed nearly everything to her (Districts) desire for his (cousin) success in public life, and now that he (cousin) had achieved the first great step towards that success, it would have been madness on her (Districts) part to decline her (Districts) share in the ovation. If she (Districts) could not rejoice in that, what source of joy would then be left for her (Districts)? She (Districts) had promised to be his (cousin) wife, and at present she (Districts) was under the bonds of that promise. She (Districts) had so promised because she (Districts) had desired to identify her (Districts) interests with his (cousin),--because she (Districts) wished to share his (cousin) risks, to assist his (cousin) struggles, and to aid him (cousin) in his (cousin) public career. She (Districts) had done all this, and he (cousin) had been successful. She (Districts) strove, therefore, to be triumphant on his (cousin) behalf, but she (Districts) knew that she (Districts) was striving ineffectually. She (Districts) had made a mistake, and the days were coming in which she (Districts) would have to own to herself that she (Districts) had done so in sackcloth, and to repent with ashes.

But yet she (Districts) struggled to be triumphant. The tidings were first brought to her (Districts) by her (Districts) servant, and then she (Districts) at once sat down to write him (servant) a word or two of congratulation. But she (Districts) found the task more difficult than she (Districts) had expected, and she (Districts) gave it up. She (Districts) had written no word to him (servant) since the day on which he (servant) had left her (Districts) almost in anger, and now she (Districts) did not know how she (Districts) was to address him (servant).

``I will wait till he (Vavasor) comes,'' (she)
she (Districts) said, putting away from her (Districts) the paper and pens.
``It will be easier to speak than to write.'' (she)
But she (Districts) wrote to Kate, and contrived to put some note of triumph into her (Districts) letter. Kate had written to her (Kate) at length, filling her (Kate) sheet with a loud pæan of sincere rejoicing. To Kate, down in Westmoreland, it had seemed that her (Kate) brother had already done everything. He (brother) had already tied Fortune to his (brother) chariot wheels. He (brother) had made the great leap, and had overcome the only obstacle that Fate had placed in his (brother) way. In her (Kate) great joy she (Kate) almost forgot whence had come the money with which the contest had been won. She (Kate) was not enthusiastic in many things;--about herself she (Kate) was never so; but now she (Kate) was elated with an enthusiasm which seemed to know no bounds.
``I am proud,'' (she)
she (Kate) said, in her (Kate) letter to Alice.
``No other thing that he (Vavasor) could have done would have made me so proud of him (Vavasor). Had the Queen sent for him (Vavasor) and made him (Vavasor) an earl, it would have been as nothing to this. When I think that he (Vavasor) has forced his (Vavasor) way into Parliament without any great friend, with nothing to back him (Vavasor) but his (Vavasor) own wit'' (she)
--she (Kate) had, in truth, forgotten Alice's money as she (Alice) wrote;--
``that he (Vavasor) has achieved his (Vavasor) triumph in the metropolis, among the most wealthy and most fastidious of the richest city in the world, I do feel proud of my brother. And, Alice, I hope that you are proud of your lover.'' (she)
Poor girl! One cannot but like her (Alice) pride, nay, almost love her (Alice) for it, though it was so sorely misplaced. It must be remembered that she (Alice) had known nothing of Messrs. Grimes and Scruby, and the River Bank, and that the means had been wanting to her (Alice) of learning the principles upon which some metropolitan elections are conducted.

``And, Alice, I hope that you are proud of your lover!'' (unknown)
``He (lover) is not my lover,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice said to herself.
``He (lover) knows that he (lover) is not. He (lover) understands it, though she (Alice) may not.'' (lover Vavasor)
And if not your lover, Alice Vavasor, what is he (lover) then to you? And what are you to him (lover), if not his (lover) love? She (Alice) was beginning to understand that she (Alice) had put herself in the way of utter destruction;--that she (Alice) had walked to the brink of a precipice, and that she (Alice) must now topple over it.
``He (lover) is not my lover,'' (she)
she (Alice) said; and then she (Alice) sat silent and moody, and it took her (Alice) hours to get her (Alice) answer written to Kate.
