On the same afternoon she (Kate) saw her (Kate) father for a moment or two.

``So George has got himself returned,'' (he)
he (father) said, raising his (father) eyebrows.

``Yes, he (George) has been successful. I'm sure you must be glad, papa.'' (unknown)

``Upon my word, I'm not. He (papa) has bought a seat for three months; and with whose money has he (papa) purchased it?'' (unknown)

``Don't let us always speak of money, papa.'' (unknown)

``When you discuss the value of a thing just purchased, you must mention the price before you know whether the purchaser has done well or badly. They have let him (papa) in for his (papa) money because there are only a few months left before the general election. Two thousand pounds he (papa) has had, I believe?'' (unknown)

``And if as much more is wanted for the next election he (papa) shall have it.'' (unknown)

``Very well, my dear;--very well, If you choose to make a beggar of yourself, I cannot help it. Indeed, I shall not complain though he (beggar) should spend all your money, if you do not marry him (beggar) at last.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
In answer to this, Alice said nothing. On that point her (Alice) father's wishes were fast growing to be identical with her (Alice) own.

``I tell you fairly what are my feelings and my wishes,'' (he)
he (father) continued.
``Nothing, in my opinion, would be so deplorable and ruinous as such a marriage. You tell me that you have made up your mind to take him (beggar), and I know well that nothing that I can say will turn you. But I believe that when he (beggar) has spent all your money he (beggar) will not take you, and that thus you will be saved. Thinking as I do about him (beggar), you can hardly expect that I should triumph because he (beggar) has got himself into Parliament with your money!'' (he)

Then he (father) left her (Alice), and it seemed to Alice that he (father) had been very cruel. There had been little, she (Alice) thought, nay, nothing of a father's loving tenderness in his (father) words to her (Alice). If he (father) had spoken to her (Alice) differently, might she (Alice) not even now have confessed everything to him (father)? But herein Alice accused him (father) wrongfully. Tenderness from him (father) on this subject had, we may say, become impossible. She (Alice) had made it impossible. Nor could he (father) tell her (Alice) the extent of his (father) wishes without damaging his (father) own cause. He (father) could not let her (Alice) know that all that was done was so done with the view of driving her (Alice) into John Grey's arms.

But what words were those for a father to speak to a daughter! Had she (daughter) brought herself to such a state that her (daughter) own father desired to see her (daughter) deserted and thrown aside? And was it probable that this wish of his (father) should come to pass? As to that, Alice had already made up her (Alice) mind. She (Alice) thought that she (Alice) had made up her (Alice) mind that she (Alice) would never become her (Alice) cousin's wife. It needed not her (Alice) father's wish to accomplish her (Alice) salvation, if her (Alice) salvation lay in being separated from him (father).

On the next morning George went to her (Alice). The reader will, perhaps, remember their last interview. He (George) had come to her (Alice) after her (Alice) letter to him (George) from Westmoreland, and had asked her (Alice) to seal their reconciliation with a kiss; but she (Alice) had refused him (George). He (George) had offered to embrace her (Alice), and she (Alice) had shuddered before him (George), fearing his (George) touch, telling him (George) by signs much more clear than any words, that she (Alice) felt for him (George) none of the love of a woman. Then he (George) had turned from her (Alice) in anger, declaring to her (Alice) honestly that he (George) was angry. Since that he (George) had borrowed her (Alice) money,--had made two separate assaults upon her (Alice) purse,--and was now come to tell her (Alice) of the results. How was he (George) to address her (Alice)? I beg that it may be also remembered that he (George) was not a man to forget the treatment he (George) had received. When he (George) entered the room, Alice looked at him (George), at first, almost furtively. She (Alice) was afraid of him (George). It must be confessed that she (Alice) already feared him (George). Had there been in the man anything of lofty principle he (man) might still have made her (Alice) his (man) slave, though I doubt whether he (man) could ever again have forced her (Alice) to love him (man). She (Alice) looked at him (man) furtively, and perceived that the gash on his (man) face was nearly closed. The mark of existing anger was not there. He (man) had come to her (Alice) intending to be gentle, if it might be possible. He (man) had been careful in his (man) dress, as though he (man) wished to try once again if the rôle of lover might be within his (man) reach.

Alice was the first to speak.

``George, I am so glad that you have succeeded! I wish you joy with my whole heart.'' (unknown)

``Thanks, dearest. But before I say another word, let me acknowledge my debt. Unless you had aided me with your money, I could not have succeeded.'' (unknown)

``Oh, George! pray don't speak of that!'' (unknown)

``Let me rather speak of it at once, and have done. If you will think of it, you will know that I must speak of it sooner or later.'' (He)
He (man) smiled and looked pleasant, as he (man) used to do in those Swiss days.

``Well, then, speak and have done.'' (unknown)

``I hope you have trusted me in thus giving me the command of your fortune?'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes.'' (unknown)

``I do believe that you have. I need hardly say that I could not have stood for this last election without it; and I must try to make you understand that if I had not come forward at this vacancy, I should have stood no chance for the next; otherwise, I should not have been justified in paying so dearly for a seat for one session. You can understand that; eh, Alice?'' (unknown)

``Yes; I think so?

``Anybody, even your father, would tell you that; though, probably, he (father) regards my ambition to be a Member of Parliament as a sign of downright madness. But I was obliged to stand now, if I intended to go on with it, as that old lord died so inopportunely. Well, about the money! It is quite upon the cards that I may be forced to ask for another loan when the autumn comes.'' (unknown)

``You shall have it, George.'' (unknown)

``Thanks, Alice. And now I will tell you what I propose. You know that I have been reconciled,--with a sort of reconciliation,--to my grandfather? Well, when the next affair is over, I propose to tell him (grandfather) exactly how you and I then stand.'' (unknown)

``Do not go into that now, George. It is enough for you at present to be assured that such assistance as I can give you is at your command. I want you to feel the full joy of your success, and you will do so more thoroughly if you will banish all these money troubles from your mind for a while.'' (unknown)

``They shall, at any rate, be banished while I am with you,'' (he)
said he (man).
``There; let them go!'' (he)
And he (man) lifted up his (man) right hand, and blew at the tips of his (man) fingers.
``Let them vanish,'' (he)
said he (man).
``It is always well to be rid of such troubles for a time.'' (unknown)

It is well to be rid of them at any time, or at all times, if only they can be banished without danger. But when a man has overused his (man) liver till it will not act for him (man) any longer, it is not well for him (man) to resolve that he (man) will forget the weakness of his (man) organ just as he (man) sits down to dinner.

It was a pretty bit of acting, that of Vavasor's, when he (man) blew away his (man) cares; and, upon the whole, I do not know that he (man) could have done better. But Alice saw through it, and he (man) knew that she (Alice) did so. The whole thing was uncomfortable to him (man), except the fact that he (man) had the promise of her (Alice) further moneys. But he (man) did not intend to rest satisfied with this. He (man) must extract from her (Alice) some meed of approbation, some show of sympathy, some spark of affection, true or pretended, in order that he (man) might at least affect to be satisfied, and be enabled to speak of the future without open embarrassment. How could even he (man) take her (Alice) money from her (Alice), unless he (man) might presume that he (man) stood with her (Alice) upon some ground that belonged mutually to them both?

``I have already taken my seat,'' (he)
said he (man).

``Yes; I saw that in the newspapers. My acquaintance among Members of Parliament is very small, but I see that you were introduced, as they call it, by one of the few men that I do know. Is Mr. Bott a friend of yours?'' (unknown)

``No,--certainly not a friend. I may probably have to act with him (friend) in public.'' (unknown)

``Ah, that's just what they said of Mr. Palliser when they felt ashamed of his (Palliser) having such a man as his (Palliser) guest. I think if I were in public life I should try to act with people that I could like.'' (unknown)

``Then you dislike Mr. Bott?'' (unknown)

``I do not like him (Bott), but my feelings about him (Bott) are not violent.'' (unknown)

``He (Bott) is a vulgar ass,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George,
``with no more pretensions to rank himself a gentleman than your footman.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

``If I had one.'' (unknown)

``But he (footman) will get on in Parliament, to a certain extent.'' (unknown)

``I'm afraid I don't quite understand what are the requisites for Parliamentary success, or indeed of what it consists. Is his (footman) ambition, do you suppose, the same as yours?'' (unknown)

``His (footman) ambition, I take it, does not go beyond a desire to be Parliamentary flunkey to a big man,--with wages, if possible, but without, if the wages are impossible.'' (unknown)

``And yours?'' (unknown)

``Oh, as to mine;--there are some things, Alice, that a man does not tell to any one.'' (unknown)

``Are there? They must be very terrible things.'' (unknown)

``The schoolboy, when he (schoolboy) sits down to make his (schoolboy) rhymes, dares not say, even to his (schoolboy) sister, that he (schoolboy) hopes to rival Milton; but he (schoolboy) nurses such a hope. The preacher, when he (preacher) preaches his (preacher) sermon, does not whisper, even to his (preacher) wife, his (preacher) belief that thousands may perhaps be turned to repentance by the strength of his (preacher) words; but he (preacher) thinks that the thousand converts are possible.'' (unknown)

``And you, though you will not say so, intend to rival Chatham, and to make your thousand converts in politics.'' (unknown)

``I like to hear you laugh at me,--I do, indeed. It does me good to hear your voice again with some touch of satire in it. It brings back the old days,--the days to which I hope we may soon revert without pain. Shall it not be so, dearest?'' (her)

Her (Alice) playful manner at once deserted her (Alice). Why had he (George) made this foolish attempt to be tender?

``I do not know,'' (she)
she (Alice) said, gloomily.

For a few minutes he (George) sat silent, fingering some article belonging to her (Alice) which was lying on the table. It was a small steel paper-knife, of which the handle was cast and gilt; a thing of no great value, of which the price may have been five shillings. He (George) sat with it, passing it through his (George) fingers, while she (Alice) went on with her (Alice) work.

``Who gave you this paper-cutter?'' (he)
he (George) said, suddenly.

``Goodness me, why do you ask? and especially, why do you ask in that way?'' (unknown)

``I asked simply because if it is a present to you from any one, I will take up something else.'' (unknown)

``It was given me by Mr. Grey.'' (He)

He (George) let it drop from his (George) fingers on to the table with a noise, and then pushed it from him (George), so that it fell on the other side, near to where she (Alice) sat.

``George,'' (she)
she (Alice) said, as she (Alice) stooped and picked it up,
``your violence is unreasonable; pray do not repeat it.'' (she)

``I did not mean it,'' (he)
he (George) said,
``and I beg your pardon. I was simply unfortunate in the article I selected. And who gave you this?'' (he)
In saying which he (George) took up a little ivory foot-rule that was folded up so as to bring it within the compass of three inches.

``It so happens that no one gave me that; I bought it at a stupid bazaar.'' (unknown)

``Then this will do. You shall give it me as a present, on the renewal of our love.'' (unknown)

``It is too poor a thing to give,'' (she)
said she (Alice), speaking still more gloomily than she (Alice) had done before.

``By no means; nothing is too poor, if given in that way. Anything will do; a ribbon, a glove, a broken sixpence. Will you give me something that I may take, and, taking it, may know that your heart is given with it?'' (unknown)

``Take the rule, if you please,'' (she)
she (Alice) said.

``And about the heart?'' (he)
he (George) asked.

He (George) should have been more of a rascal or less. Seeing how very much of a rascal he (rascal) was already, I think it would have been better that he (rascal) should have been more,--that he (rascal) should have been able to content his (rascal) spirit with the simple acquisition of her (Alice) money, and that he (rascal) should have been free from all those remains of a finer feeling which made him (rascal) desire her (Alice) love also. But it was not so. It was necessary for his (rascal) comfort that she (Alice) should, at any rate, say she (Alice) loved him (rascal).

``Well, Alice, and what about the heart?'' (he)
he (rascal) asked again.

``I would so much rather talk about politics, George,'' (she)
said she (Alice).

The cicatrice began to make itself very visible in his (rascal) face, and the debonair manner was fast vanishing. He (rascal) had fixed his (rascal) eyes upon her (Alice), and had inserted his (rascal) thumbs in the armholes of his (rascal) waistcoat.

``Alice, that is not quite fair,'' (he)
he (rascal) said.

``I do not mean to be unfair.'' (unknown)

``I am not so sure of that. I almost think that you do mean it. You have told me that you intend to become my wife. If, after that, you wilfully make me miserable, will not that be unfair?'' (unknown)

``I am not making you miserable,--certainly not wilfully.'' (unknown)

``Did that letter which you wrote to me from Westmoreland mean anything?'' (unknown)

``George, do not strive to make me think that it meant too much.'' (unknown)

``If it did, you had better say so at once.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

But Alice, though she (Alice) would have said so had she (Alice) dared, made no answer to this. She (Alice) sat silent, turning her (Alice) face away from his (rascal) gaze, longing that the meeting might be over, and feeling that she (Alice) had lost her (Alice) own self-respect.

``Look here, Alice,'' (he)
he (rascal) said,
``I find it very hard to understand you. When I look back over all that has passed between us, and to that other episode in your life, summing it all up with your conduct to me at present, I find myself at a loss to read your character.'' (he)

``I fear I cannot help you in the reading of it.'' (unknown)

``When you first loved me;--for you did love me. I understood that well enough. There is no young man who in early life does not read with sufficient clearness that sweetest morsel of poetry.--And when you quarrelled with me, judging somewhat harshly of my offences, I understood that also; for it is the custom of women to be hard in their judgement on such sins. When I heard that you had accepted the offer made to you by that gentleman in Cambridgeshire, I thought that I understood you still,--knowing how natural it was that you should seek some cure for your wound. I understood it, and accused myself, not you, in that I had driven you to so fatal a remedy.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Here Alice turned round towards him (rascal) sharply, as though she (Alice) were going to interrupt him (rascal), but she (Alice) said nothing, though he (rascal) paused for her (Alice) to speak; and then he (rascal) went on.
``And I understood it well when I heard that this cure had been too much for you. By heavens, yes! there was no misunderstanding that. I meant no insult to the man when I upset his (man) little toy just now. I have not a word to say against him (man). For many women he (man) would make a model husband, but you are not one of them. And when you discovered this yourself, as you did, I understood that without difficulty. Yes, by heavens! if ever woman had been driven to a mistake, you had been driven to one there.'' (she)
Here she (Alice) looked at him (rascal) again, and met his (rascal) eyes. She (Alice) looked at him (rascal) with something of his (rascal) own fierceness in her (Alice) face, as though she (Alice) were preparing herself to fight with him (rascal); but she (Alice) said nothing at the moment, and then he (rascal) again went on.
``And, Alice, I understood it also when you again consented to be my wife. I thought that I still understood you then. I may have been vain to think so, but surely it was natural. I believed that the old love had come back upon you, and again warmed your heart. I thought that it had been cold during our separation, and I was pleased to think so. Was that unnatural? Put yourself in my place, and say if you would not have thought so. I told myself that I understood you then, and I told myself that in all that you had done you had acted as a true, and good, and loving woman. I thought of you much, and I saw that your conduct, as a whole, was intelligible and becoming.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
The last word grated on Alice's ears, and she (Alice) showed her (Alice) anger by the motion of her (Alice) foot upon the floor. Her (Alice) cousin noted it all, but went on as though he (cousin) had not noted it.
``But now your present behaviour makes all the rest a riddle. You have said that you would be my wife, declaring thereby that you had forgiven my offences, and, as I suppose, reassuring me of your love; and yet you receive me with all imaginable coldness. What am I to think of it, and in what way would you have me behave to you? When last I was here I asked you for a kiss.'' (he)
As he (cousin) said this he (cousin) looked at her (Alice) with all his (cousin) eyes, with his (cousin) mouth just open, so as to show the edges of his (cousin) white teeth, with the wound down his (cousin) face all wide and purple. The last word came with a stigmatizing hiss from his (cousin) lips. Though she (Alice) did not essay to speak, he (cousin) paused again, as if he (cousin) were desirous that she (Alice) might realize the full purport of such a request. I think that, in the energy of his (cousin) speaking, a touch of true passion had come upon him (cousin); that he (cousin) had forgotten his (cousin) rascaldom, and his (cousin) need of her (Alice) money, and that he (cousin) was punishing her (Alice) with his (cousin) whole power of his (cousin) vengeance for the treatment which he (cousin) had received from her (Alice).
``I asked you for a kiss. If you are to be my wife you can have no shame in granting me such a request. Within the last two months you have told me that you would marry me. What am I to think of such a promise if you deny me all customary signs of your affection?'' (he)
Then he (cousin) paused again, and she (Alice) found that the time had come in which she (Alice) must say something to him (cousin).

-LSB-Illustration:

``I asked you for a kiss.'' (unknown)
-RSB-

``I wonder you cannot understand,'' (she)
she (Alice) said,
``that I have suffered much.'' (she)

``And is that to be my answer?'' (unknown)

``I don't know what answer you want.'' (unknown)

``Come, Alice, do not be untrue; you do know what answer I want, and you know also whether my wanting it is unreasonable.'' (unknown)

``No one ever told me that I was untrue before,'' (she)
she (Alice) said.

``You do know what it is that I desire. I desire to learn that the woman who is to be my wife, in truth, loves me.'' (She)

She (Alice) was standing up, and so was he (cousin) also, but still she (Alice) said nothing. He (cousin) had in his (cousin) hand the little rule which she (Alice) had told him (cousin) that he (cousin) might take, but he (cousin) held it as though in doubt what he (cousin) would do with it.

``Well, Alice, am I to hear anything from you?'' (unknown)

``Not now, George; you are angry, and I will not speak to you in your anger.'' (unknown)

``Have I not cause to be angry? Do you not know that you are treating me badly?'' (unknown)

``I know that my head aches, and that I am very wretched. I wish you would leave me.'' (unknown)

``There, then, is your gift,'' (he)
said he (cousin), and he (cousin) threw the rule over on to the sofa behind her (Alice).
``And there is the trumpery trinket which I had hoped you would have worn for my sake.'' (he)
Whereupon something which he (cousin) had taken from his (cousin) waistcoat-pocket was thrown violently into the fender, beneath the fire-grate. He (cousin) then walked with quick steps to the door; but when his (cousin) hand was on the handle, he (cousin) turned.
``Alice,'' (he)
he (cousin) said,
``when I am gone, try to think honestly of your conduct to me.'' (he)
Then he (cousin) went, and she (Alice) remained still, till she (Alice) heard the front door close behind him (cousin).

When she (Alice) was sure that he (cousin) was gone, her (Alice) first movement was made in search of the trinket. I fear that this was not dignified on her (Alice) part; but I think that it was natural. It was not that she (Alice) had any desire for the jewel, or any curiosity even to see it. She (Alice) would very much have preferred that he (cousin) should have brought nothing of the kind to her (Alice). But she (Alice) had a feminine reluctance that anything of value should be destroyed without a purpose. So she (Alice) took the shovel, and poked among the ashes, and found the ring which her (Alice) cousin had thrown there. It was a valuable ring, bearing a ruby on it between two small diamonds. Such at least, she (Alice) became aware, had been its bearing; but one of the side stones had been knocked out by the violence with which the ring had been flung. She (Alice) searched even for this, scorching her (Alice) face and eyes, but in vain. Then she (Alice) made up her (Alice) mind that the diamond should be lost for ever, and that it should go out among the cinders into the huge dust-heaps of the metropolis. Better that, though it was distasteful to her (Alice) feminine economy, than the other alternative of setting the servants to search, and thereby telling them something of what had been done.

When her (Alice) search was over, she (Alice) placed the ring on the mantelpiece; but she (Alice) knew that it would not do to leave it there,--so she (Alice) folded it up carefully in a new sheet of note-paper, and put it in the drawer of her (Alice) desk. After that she (Alice) sat herself down at the table to think what she (Alice) would do; but her (Alice) head was, in truth, racked with pain, and on that occasion she (Alice) could bring her (Alice) thoughts to no conclusion.

CHAPTER XLVII.

Mr. Cheesacre's Disappointment.

When Mrs. Greenow was left alone in her (Greenow) lodgings, after the little entertainment which she (Greenow) had given to her (Greenow) two lovers, she (Greenow) sat herself down to think seriously over her (Greenow) affairs. There were three paths open before her (Greenow). She (Greenow) might take Mr. Cheesacre, or she (Greenow) might take Captain Bellfield--or she (Greenow) might decide that she (Greenow) would have nothing more to say to either of them in the way of courting. They were very persistent, no doubt; but she (Greenow) thought that she (Greenow) would know how to make them understand her (Greenow), if she (Greenow) should really make up her (Greenow) mind that she (Greenow) would have neither one nor the other. She (Greenow) was going to leave Norwich after Easter, and they knew that such was her (Greenow) purpose. Something had been said of her (Greenow) returning to Yarmouth in the summer. She (Greenow) was a just woman at heart, and justice required that each of them should know what was to be his (they) prospect if she (Greenow) did so return.

There was a good deal to be said on Mr. Cheesacre's behalf. Mahogany-furnitured bedrooms assist one's comfort in this life; and heaps of manure, though they are not brilliant in romance, are very efficacious in farming. Mrs. Greenow by no means despised these things; and as for the owner of them, though she (Greenow) saw that there was much amiss in his (owner) character, she (Greenow) thought that his (owner) little foibles were of such a nature that she (Greenow), as his (owner) wife, or any other woman of spirit, might be able to repress them, if not to cure them. But she (Greenow) had already married for money once, as she (Greenow) told herself very plainly on this occasion, and she (Greenow) thought that she (Greenow) might now venture on a little love. Her (Greenow) marriage for money had been altogether successful. The nursing of old Greenow had not been very disagreeable to her (Greenow), nor had it taken longer than she (Greenow) had anticipated. She (Greenow) had now got all the reward that she (Greenow) had ever promised herself, and she (Greenow) really did feel grateful to his (Greenow) memory. I almost think that among those plentiful tears some few drops belonged to sincerity. She (Greenow) was essentially a happy-tempered woman, blessed with a good digestion, who looked back upon her (Greenow) past life with contentment, and forward to her (Greenow) future life with confidence. She (Greenow) would not be greedy, she (Greenow) said to herself. She (Greenow) did not want more money, and therefore she (Greenow) would have none of Mr. Cheesacre. So far she (Greenow) resolved,--resolving also that, if possible, the mahogany-furnitured bedrooms should be kept in the family, and made over to her (Greenow) niece, Kate Vavasor.

But should she (Greenow) marry for love; and if so, should Captain Bellfield be the man? Strange to say, his (Captain) poverty and his (Captain) scampishness and his (Captain) lies almost recommended him (Captain) to her (Bellfield). At any rate, it was not of those things that she (Bellfield) was afraid. She (Bellfield) had a woman's true belief in her (Bellfield) own power, and thought that she (Bellfield) could cure them,--as far as they needed cure. As for his (Captain) stories about Inkerman, and his (Captain) little debts, she (Bellfield) cared nothing about that. She (Bellfield) also had her (Bellfield) Inkermans, and was quite aware that she (Bellfield) made as good use of them as the Captain did of his (Captain). And as for the debts,--what was a man to do who hadn't got any money? She (Bellfield) also had owed for her (Bellfield) gloves and corsets in the ante-Greenow days of her (Bellfield) adventures. But there was this danger,--that there might be more behind of which she (Bellfield) had never heard. Another Mrs. Bellfield was not impossible; and what, if instead of being a real captain at all, he (captain) should be a returned ticket-of-leave man! Such things had happened. Her (Bellfield) chief security was in this,--that Cheesacre had known the man for many years, and would certainly have told anything against him (Cheesacre) that he (Cheesacre) did know. Under all these circumstances, she (Bellfield) could not quite make up her (Bellfield) mind either for or against Captain Bellfield.

Between nine and ten in the evening, an hour or so after Mr. Cheesacre had left her (Bellfield), Jeannette brought to her (Jeannette) some arrowroot with a little sherry in it. She (Jeannette) usually dined early, and it was her (Jeannette) habit to take a light repast before she (Jeannette) retired for the night.

``Jeannette,'' (she)
she (Jeannette) said, as she (Jeannette) stirred the lumps of white sugar in the bowl,
``I'm afraid those two gentlemen have quarrelled.'' (she)

``Oh, laws, ma'am, in course they have! How was they to help it?'' (Jeannette)

Jeannette, on these occasions, was in the habit of standing beside the chair of her (Jeannette) mistress, and chatting with her (Jeannette); and then, if the chatting was much prolonged, she (Jeannette) would gradually sink down upon the corner of a chair herself,--and then the two women would be very comfortable together over the fire, Jeannette never forgetting that she (Jeannette) was the servant, and Mrs. Greenow never forgetting that she (Greenow) was the mistress.

``And why should they quarrel, Jeannette? It's very foolish.'' (unknown)

``I don't know about being foolish, ma'am; but it's the most natural thing in life. If I had two beaux as was a-courting me together, in course I should expect as they would punch each other's heads. There's some girls do it a purpose, because they like to see it. One at a time's what I say.'' (unknown)

``You're a young thing, Jeannette.'' (unknown)

``Well, ma'am--yes; I am young, no doubt. But I won't say but what I've had a beau, young as I look.'' (unknown)

``But you don't suppose that I want beaux, as you call them?'' (unknown)

``I don't know, ma'am, as you wants 'em exactly. That's as may be. There they are; and if they was to blow each other's brains out in the gig to-night, I shouldn't be a bit surprised for one. There's nothing won't quiet them at Oileymead to-night, if brandy-and-water don't do it.'' (she)
As she (Greenow) said this, Jeannette slipt into her (Jeannette) chair, and held up her (Jeannette) hands in token of the intensity of her (Jeannette) fears.

``Why, you silly child, they're not going home together at all. Did not the Captain go away first?'' (unknown)

``The Captain did go away first, certainly; but I thought perhaps it was to get his (Captain) pistols and fighting things ready.'' (unknown)

``They won't fight, Jeannette. Gentlemen have given over fighting.'' (unknown)

``Have they, ma'am? That makes it much easier for ladies, no doubt. Perhaps them peaceable ways will come down to such as us in time. It'd be a comfort, I know, to them as are quiet given, like me. I hate to see men knocking each other's heads about,--I do. So Mr. Cheesacre and the Captain won't fight, ma'am?'' (unknown)

``Of course they won't, you little fool, you.'' (unknown)

``Dear, dear; I was so sure we should have had the papers all full of it,--and perhaps one of them stretched upon his (Cheesacre) bloody bier! I wonder which it would have been? I always made up my mind that the Captain wouldn't be wounded in any of his (Captain) wital parts--unless it was his (Captain) heart, you know, ma'am.'' (unknown)

``But why should they quarrel at all, Jeannette? It is the most foolish thing.'' (unknown)

``Well, ma'am, I don't know about that. What else is they to do? There's some things as you can cry halves about, but there's no crying halves about this.'' (unknown)

``About what, Jeannette?'' (unknown)
--
``Why, about you, ma'am.'' (unknown)

``Jeannette, I wonder how you can say such things; as if I, in my position, had ever said a word to encourage either of them. You know it's not true, Jeannette, and you shouldn't say so.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
Whereupon Mrs. Greenow put her (Greenow) handkerchief to her (Greenow) eyes, and Jeannette, probably in token of contrition, put her (Jeannette) apron to hers.

``To be sure, ma'am, no lady could have behaved better through it than you have done, and goodness knows you have been tried hard.'' (unknown)

``Indeed I have, Jeannette.'' (unknown)

``And if gentlemen will make fools of themselves, it isn't your fault; is it, ma'am?'' (unknown)

``But I'm so sorry that they should have quarrelled. They were such dear friends, you know;--quite all in all to each other.'' (unknown)

``When you've settled which it's to be, ma'am, that'll all come right again,--seeing that gentlefolks like them have given up fighting, as you say.'' (unknown)
Then there was a little pause.
``I suppose, ma'am, it won't be Mr. Cheesacre? To be sure, he (Cheesacre)'s a man as is uncommonly well to do in the world.'' (unknown)

``What's all that to me, Jeannette? I shall ever regard Mr. Cheesacre as a dear friend who has been very good to me at a time of trouble; but he (Cheesacre)'ll never be more than that.'' (unknown)

``Then it'll be the Captain, ma'am? I'm sure, for my part, I've always thought the Captain was the nicer gentleman of the two,--and have always said so.'' (unknown)

``He (Captain)'s nothing to me, girl.'' (unknown)

``And as for money,--what's the good of having more than enough? If he (Captain) can bring love, you can bring money; can't you, ma'am?'' (unknown)

``He (Captain)'s nothing to me, girl,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
repeated Mrs. Greenow.

``But he (Captain) will be?'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette, plainly asking a question.

``Well, I'm sure! What's the world come to, I wonder, when you sit yourself down there, and cross-examine your mistress in that way! Get to bed, will you? It's near ten o'clock.'' (unknown)

``I hope I haven't said anything amiss, ma'am;'' (Jeannette)
and Jeannette rose from her (Jeannette) seat.

``It's my fault for encouraging you,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.
``Go down-stairs and finish your work, do; and then take yourself off to bed. Next week we shall have to be packing up, and there'll be all my things to see to before that.'' (Jeannette)
So Jeannette got up and departed, and after some few further thoughts about Captain Bellfield, Mrs. Greenow herself went to her (Greenow) bedroom.

Mr. Cheesacre, when he (Cheesacre) drove back to Oileymead alone from Norwich, after dining with Mrs. Greenow, had kept himself hot, and almost comfortable, with passion against Bellfield; and his (Cheesacre) heat, if not his (Cheesacre) comfort, had been sustained by his (Cheesacre) seeing the Captain, with his (Cheesacre) portmanteau, escaping just as he (Cheesacre) reached his (Cheesacre) own homestead. But early on the following morning his (Cheesacre) mind reverted to Mrs. Greenow, and he (Cheesacre) remembered, with anything but satisfaction, some of the hard things which she (Greenow) had said to him (Cheesacre). He (Cheesacre) had made mistakes in his (Cheesacre) manner of wooing. He (Cheesacre) was quite aware of that now, and was determined that they should be rectified for the future. She (Greenow) had rebuked him (Cheesacre) for having said nothing about his (Cheesacre) love. He (Cheesacre) would instantly mend that fault. And she (Greenow) had bidden him (Cheesacre) not to be so communicative about his (Cheesacre) wealth. Henceforth he (Cheesacre) would be dumb on that subject. Nevertheless, he (Cheesacre) could not but think that the knowledge of his (Cheesacre) circumstances which the lady already possessed, must be of service to him (Cheesacre).

``She (mistress) can't really like a poor beggarly wretch who hasn't got a shilling,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) said to himself. He (Cheesacre) was very far from feeling that the battle was already lost. Her (lady) last word to him (Cheesacre) had been an assurance of her (lady) friendship; and then why should she (lady) have been at so much trouble to tell him (Cheesacre) the way in which he (Cheesacre) ought to address her (lady) if she (lady) were herself indifferent as to his (Cheesacre) addresses? He (Cheesacre) was, no doubt, becoming tired of his (Cheesacre) courtship, and heartily wished that the work were over; but he (Cheesacre) was not minded to give it up. He (Cheesacre) therefore prepared himself for another attack, and took himself into Norwich without seeking counsel from any one. He (counsel) could not trust himself to think that she (lady) could really wish to refuse him (counsel) after all the encouragement she (lady) had given him (counsel). On this occasion he (counsel) put on no pink shirt or shiny boots, being deterred from doing so by a remembrance of Captain Bellfield's ridicule; but, nevertheless, he (Captain) dressed himself with considerable care. He (Captain) clothed his (Captain) nether person in knickerbockers, with tight, leathern, bright-coloured gaiters round his (Captain) legs, being conscious of certain manly graces and symmetrical proportions which might, as he (Captain) thought, stand him (Captain) in good stead. And he (Captain) put on a new shooting-coat, the buttons on which were elaborate, and a wonderful waistcoat worked over with foxes' heads. He (Captain) completed his (Captain) toilet with a round, low-crowned hat, with dog's-skin gloves, and a cutting whip. Thus armed he (Captain) went forth resolved to conquer or to die,--as far as death might result from any wound which Mrs. Greenow might be able to give him (Captain). He (Captain) waited, on this occasion, for the coming of no market-day; indeed, the journey into the city was altogether special, and he (Captain) was desirous that she (Greenow) should know that such was the case. He (Captain) drove at a great pace into the inn-yard, threw his (Captain) reins to the ostler, took just one glass of cherry-brandy at the bar, and then marched off across the market-place to the Close, with quiet and decisive steps.

``Is that you, Cheesacre?'' (unknown)
said a friendly voice, in one of the narrow streets.
``Who expected to see you in Norwich on a Thursday!'' (the son)
It was Grimsby, the son of old Grimsby of Hatherwich, a country gentleman, and one, therefore, to whom Cheesacre would generally pay much respect; but on this occasion he (Cheesacre) did not even pull up for an instant, or moderate his (Cheesacre) pace.
``A little bit of private business,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) said, and marched onwards with his (Cheesacre) head towards the Close.
``I'm not going to be afraid of a woman--not if I know it,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) said to himself; but, nevertheless, at a certain pastrycook's, of whose shop he (Cheesacre) had knowledge, he (Cheesacre) pulled up and had another glass of cherry-brandy.

``Mrs. Greenow is at home,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) said to Jeannette, not deigning to ask any question.

``Oh, yes, sir; she (Greenow) is at home,'' (Jeannette)
said Jeannette, conscious that some occasion had arrived; and in another second he (Cheesacre) was in the presence of his (Cheesacre) angel.

``Mr. Cheesacre, whoever expected to see you in Norwich on a Thursday?'' (the lady)
said the lady, as she (lady) welcomed him (Cheesacre), using almost the same words as his (Cheesacre) friend had done in the street. Why should not he (Cheesacre) come into Norwich on a Thursday, as well as any one else? Did they suppose that he (Cheesacre) was tied for ever to his (Cheesacre) ploughs and carts? He (Cheesacre) was minded to conduct himself with a little spirit on this occasion, and to improve the opinion which Mrs. Greenow had formed about him (Cheesacre). On this account he (Cheesacre) answered her (Greenow) somewhat boldly.

``There's no knowing when I may be in Norwich, Mrs. Greenow, or when I mayn't. I'm one of those men of whom nobody knows anything certain, except that I pay as I go.'' (he)
Then he (Cheesacre) remembered that he (Cheesacre) was not to make any more boasts about his (Cheesacre) money, and he (Cheesacre) endeavoured to cover the error.
``There's one other thing they may all know if they please, but we won't say what that is just at present.'' (unknown)

``Won't you sit down, Mr. Cheesacre?'' (unknown)

``Well,--thank you,--I will sit down for a few minutes if you'll let me, Mrs. Greenow. Mrs. Greenow, I'm in such a state of mind that I must put an end to it, or else I shall be going mad, and doing somebody a damage.'' (unknown)

``Dear me! what has happened to you? You're going out shooting, presently; are you not?'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
and Mrs. Greenow looked down at his (Cheesacre) garments.

``No, Mrs. Greenow, I'm not going out shooting. I put on these things because I thought I might take a shot as I came along. But I couldn't bring myself to do it, and then I wouldn't take them off again. What does it matter what a man wears?'' (unknown)

``Not in the least, so long as he (man) is decent.'' (unknown)

``I'm sure I'm always that, Mrs. Greenow.'' (unknown)

``Oh, dear, yes. More than that, I should say. I consider you to be rather gay in your attire.'' (unknown)

``I don't pretend to anything of that kind, Mrs. Greenow. I like to be nice, and all that kind of thing. There are people who think that because a man farms his (man) own land, he (man) must be always in the muck. It is the case, of course, with those who have to make their rent and living out of it.'' (he)
Then he (Cheesacre) remembered that he (Cheesacre) was again treading on forbidden ground, and stopped himself.
``But it don't matter what a man wears if his (man) heart isn't easy within him (man).'' (unknown)

``I don't know why you should speak in that way, Mr. Cheesacre; but it's what I have felt every hour since--since Greenow left me.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)

Mr. Cheesacre was rather at a loss to know how he (Cheesacre) should begin. This allusion to the departed one did not at all assist him (Cheesacre). He (Cheesacre) had so often told the widow that care killed a cat, and that a live dog was better than a dead lion; and had found so little efficacy in the proverbs, that he (Cheesacre) did not care to revert to them. He (Cheesacre) was aware that some more decided method of proceeding was now required. Little hints at love-making had been all very well in the earlier days of their acquaintance; but there must be something more than little hints before he (acquaintance) could hope to bring the matter to a favourable conclusion. The widow herself had told him (acquaintance) that he (acquaintance) ought to talk about love; and he (acquaintance) had taken two glasses of cherry-brandy, hoping that they might enable him (acquaintance) to do so. He (acquaintance) had put on a coat with brilliant buttons, and new knickerbockers, in order that he (acquaintance) might be master of the occasion. He (acquaintance) was resolved to call a spade a spade, and to speak boldly of his (acquaintance) passion; but how was he (acquaintance) to begin? There was the difficulty. He (acquaintance) was now seated in a chair, and there he (acquaintance) remained silent for a minute or two, while she (acquaintance) smoothed her (acquaintance) eyebrows with her (acquaintance) handkerchief after her (acquaintance) last slight ebullition of grief.

``Mrs. Greenow,'' (he)
he (acquaintance) exclaimed at last, jumping up before her (acquaintance);
``dearest Mrs. Greenow; darling Mrs. Greenow, will you be my wife? There! I have said it at last, and I mean it. Everything that I've got shall be yours. Of course I speak specially of my hand and heart. As for love;--oh, Arabella, if you only knew me! I don't think there's a man in Norfolk better able to love a woman than I am. Ever since I first saw you at Yarmouth, I've been in love to that extent that I've not known what I've been about. If you'll ask them at home, they'll tell you that I've not been able to look after anything about the place,--not as it should be done. I haven't really. I don't suppose I've opened the wages book half a dozen times since last July.'' (he)

``And has that been my fault, Mr. Cheesacre?'' (unknown)

``Upon my word it has. I can't move about anywhere without thinking about you. My mind's made up; I won't stay at Oileymead unless you will come and be its mistress.'' (unknown)

``Not stay at Oileymead?'' (unknown)

``No, indeed. I'll let the place, and go and travel somewheres. What's the use of my hanging on there without the woman of my heart? I couldn't do it, Mrs. Greenow; I couldn't, indeed. Of course I've got everything there that money can buy,--but it's all of no use to a man that's in love. Do you know, I've come quite to despise money and stock, and all that sort of thing. I haven't had my banker's book home these last three months. Only think of that now.'' (unknown)

``But how can I help you, Mr. Cheesacre?'' (unknown)

``Just say one word, and the thing'll be done. Say you'll be my wife? I'll be so good to you. I will, indeed. As for your fortune, I don't care that for it! I'm not like somebody else; it's yourself I want. You shall be my pet, and my poppet, and my dearest little duck all the days of your life.'' (unknown)

``No, Mr. Cheesacre; it cannot be.'' (unknown)

``And why not? Look here, Arabella!'' (he)
At these words he (acquaintance) rose from his (acquaintance) chair, and coming immediately before her (acquaintance), went down on both knees so close to her (acquaintance) as to prevent the possibility of her (acquaintance) escaping from him (acquaintance). There could be no doubt as to the efficacy of the cherry-brandy. There he (acquaintance) was, well down on his (acquaintance) knees; but he (acquaintance) had not got down so low without some little cracking and straining on the part of the gaiters with which his (acquaintance) legs were encompassed. He (acquaintance), in his (acquaintance) passion, had probably omitted to notice this; but Mrs. Greenow, who was more cool in her (Greenow) present temperament, was painfully aware that he (acquaintance) might not be able to rise with ease.

``Mr. Cheesacre, don't make a fool of yourself. Get up,'' (she)
said she (Greenow).

``Never, till you have told me that you will be mine!'' (unknown)

``Then you'll remain there for ever, which will be inconvenient. I won't have you take hold of my hand, Mr. Cheesacre. I tell you to have done.'' (unknown)
Whereupon his (acquaintance) grasp upon her (Greenow) hand was released; but he (acquaintance) made no attempt to rise.

``I never saw a man look so much like a fool in my life,'' (she)
said she (Greenow).
``If you don't get up, I'll push you over. There; don't you hear? There's somebody coming.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)

But Cheesacre, whose senses were less acute than the lady's, did not hear.

``I'll never get up,'' (he)
said he (Cheesacre),
``till you have bid me hope.'' (he)

``Bid you play the fiddle. Get away from my knees, at any rate. There;--he (man)'ll be in the room now before--'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)

-LSB-Illustration: Mr. Cheesacre disturbed.-RSB-

Cheesacre now did hear a sound of steps, and the door was opened while he (Cheesacre) made his (Cheesacre) first futile attempt to get back to a standing position. The door was opened, and Captain Bellfield entered.

``I beg ten thousand pardons,'' (he)
said he (Captain),
``but as I did not see Jeannette, I ventured to come in. May I venture to congratulate my friend Cheesacre on his (Cheesacre) success?'' (he)

In the meantime Cheesacre had risen; but he (Cheesacre) had done so slowly, and with evident difficulty.

``I'll trouble you to leave the room, Captain Bellfield,'' (he)
said he (Cheesacre).
``I'm particularly engaged with Mrs. Greenow, as any gentleman might have seen.'' (unknown)

``There wasn't the slightest difficulty in seeing it, old fellow,'' (the Captain)
said the Captain.
``Shall I wish you joy?'' (unknown)

``I'll trouble you to leave the room, sir,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre, walking up to him (Cheesacre).

``Certainly, if Mrs. Greenow will desire me to do so,'' (the Captain)
said the Captain.

Then Mrs. Greenow felt herself called upon to speak.

``Gentlemen, I must beg that you will not make my drawing-room a place for quarrelling. Captain Bellfield, lest there should be any misconception, I must beg you to understand that the position in which you found Mr. Cheesacre was one altogether of his (Cheesacre) own seeking. It was not with my consent that he (Cheesacre) was there.'' (unknown)

``I can easily believe that, Mrs. Greenow,'' (the Captain)
said the Captain.

``Who cares what you believe, sir?'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre.

``Gentlemen! gentlemen! this is really unkind. Captain Bellfield, I think I had better ask you to withdraw.'' (unknown)

``By all means,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Mr. Cheesacre.

``As it is absolutely necessary that I should give Mr. Cheesacre a definite answer after what has occurred--'' (Captain)

``Of course,'' (Captain)
said Captain Bellfield, preparing to go.
``I'll take another opportunity of paying my respects to you. Perhaps I might be allowed to come this evening?'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

To this Mrs. Greenow half assented with an uncertain nod, and then the Captain went. As soon as the door was closed behind his (Captain) back, Mr. Cheesacre again prepared to throw himself into his (Cheesacre) former position, but to this Mrs. Greenow decidedly objected. If he (Cheesacre) were allowed to go down again, there was no knowing what force might be necessary to raise him (Cheesacre).

``Mr. Cheesacre,'' (she)
she (Greenow) said,
``let there be an end to this little farce between us.'' (she)

``Farce!'' (he)
said he (Cheesacre), standing with his (Cheesacre) hand on his (Cheesacre) heart, and his (Cheesacre) legs and knickerbockers well displayed.

``It is certainly either a farce or a mistake. If the latter,--and I have been at all to blame,--I ask your pardon most sincerely.'' (unknown)

``But you'll be Mrs. Cheesacre; won't you?'' (unknown)

``No, Mr. Cheesacre; no. One husband is enough for any woman, and mine lies buried at Birmingham.'' (unknown)

``Oh, damn it!'' (he)
said he (Cheesacre), in utter disgust at this further reference to Mr. Greenow. The expression, at such a moment, militated against courtesy; but even Mrs. Greenow herself felt that the poor man had been subjected to provocation.

``Let us part friends,'' (she)
said she (Greenow), offering him (man) her (Greenow) hand.

But he (man) turned his (man) back upon her (Greenow), for there was something in his (man) eye that he (man) wanted to hide. I believe that he (man) really did love her (Greenow), and that at this moment he (man) would have taken her (Greenow), even though he (man) had learned that her (Greenow) fortune was gone.

``Will you not give me your hand,'' (she)
said she (Greenow),
``in token that there is no anger between us?'' (she)

``Do think about it again--do!'' (he)
said he (man).
``If there's anything you like to have changed, I'll change it at once. I'll give up Oileymead altogether, if you don't like being so near the farm-yard. I'll give up anything; so I will. Mrs. Greenow, if you only knew how I've set my heart upon it!'' (unknown)
And now, though his (man) back was turned, the whimpering of his (man) voice told plainly that tears were in his (man) eyes.

She (Greenow) was a little touched. No woman would feel disposed to marry a man simply because he (man) cried, and perhaps few women would be less likely to give way to such tenderness than Mrs. Greenow. She (Greenow) understood men and women too well, and had seen too much both of the world's rough side and of its smooth side to fall into such a blunder as that; but she (Greenow) was touched.

``My friend,'' (she)
she (Greenow) said, putting her (Greenow) hand upon his (man) arm,
``think no more of it.'' (she)

``But I can't help thinking of it,'' (he)
said he (man), almost blubbering in his (man) earnestness.

``No, no, no,'' (she)
said she (Greenow), still touching him (man) with her (Greenow) hand.
``Why, Mr. Cheesacre, how can you bring yourself to care for an old woman like me, when so many pretty young ladies would give their eyes to get a kind word from you?'' (unknown)

``I don't want any young lady,'' (he)
said he (man).

``There's Charlie Fairstairs, who would make as good a wife as any girl I know.'' (unknown)

``Psha! Charlie Fairstairs, indeed!'' (a bride)
The very idea of having such a bride palmed off upon him (man) did something to restore him (man) to his (man) manly courage.

``Or my niece, Kate Vavasor, who has a nice little fortune of her (Vavasor) own, and who is as accomplished as she (Vavasor) is good-looking.'' (unknown)

``She (Vavasor)'s nothing to me, Mrs. Greenow.'' (unknown)

``That's because you never asked her (Greenow) to be anything. If I get her (Greenow) to come back to Yarmouth next summer, will you think about it? You want a wife, and you couldn't do better if you searched all England over. It would be so pleasant for us to be such near friends; wouldn't it?'' (she)
And again she (Greenow) put her (Greenow) hand upon his (man) arm.

``Mrs. Greenow, just at present there's only one woman in the world that I can think of.'' (unknown)

``And that's my niece.'' (unknown)

``And that's yourself. I'm a broken-hearted man,--I am, indeed. I didn't ever think I should feel so much about a thing of the kind--I didn't, really. I hardly know what to do with myself; but I suppose I'd better go back to Oileymead.'' (He)
He (man) had become so painfully unconscious of his (man) new coat and his (man) knickerbockers that it was impossible not to pity him (man).
``I shall always hate the place now,'' (he)
he (man) said,--
``always.'' (he)

``That will pass away. You'd be as happy as a king there, if you'd take Kate for your queen.'' (unknown)

``And what'll you do, Mrs. Greenow?'' (unknown)

``What shall I do?'' (unknown)
--
``Yes; what will you do?'' (unknown)

``That is, if you marry Kate? Why, I'll come and stay with you half my time, and nurse the children, as an old grand-aunt should.'' (unknown)

``But about--.'' (he)
Then he (man) hesitated, and she (Greenow) asked him (man) of what he (man) was thinking.

``You don't mean to take that man Bellfield, do you?'' (unknown)

``Come, Mr. Cheesacre, that's rank jealousy. What right can you have to ask me whether I shall take any man or no man? The chances are that I shall remain as I am till I'm carried to my grave; but I'm not going to give any pledge about it to you or to any one.'' (unknown)

``You don't know that man, Mrs. Greenow; you don't, indeed. I tell it you as your friend. Does not it stand to reason, when he (friend) has got nothing in the world, that he (friend) must be a beggar? It's all very well saying that when a man is courting a lady, he (man) shouldn't say much about his (man) money; but you won't make me believe that any man will make a good husband who hasn't got a shilling. And for lies, there's no beating him (man)!'' (unknown)

``Why, then, has he (man) been such a friend of yours?'' (unknown)

``Well, because I've been foolish. I took up with him (man) just because he (man) looked pleasant, I suppose.'' (unknown)

``And you want to prevent me from doing the same thing.'' (unknown)

``If you were to marry him (man), Mrs. Greenow, it's my belief I should do him (man) a mischief; it is, really. I don't think I could stand it;--a mean, skulking beggar! I suppose I'd better go now?'' (unknown)

``Certainly, if that's the way you choose to talk about my friends.'' (unknown)

``Friends, indeed! Well, I won't say any more at present. I suppose if I was to talk for ever it wouldn't be any good?'' (unknown)

``Come and talk to Kate Vavasor for ever, Mr. Cheesacre.'' (he)

To this he (man) made no reply, but went forth from the house, and got his (man) gig, and drove himself home to Oileymead, thinking of his (man) disappointment with all the bitterness of a young lover.

``I didn't ever think I should ever care so much about anything,'' (he)
he (man) said, as he (man) took himself up to bed that night.

That evening Captain Bellfield did call in the Close, as he (Captain) had said he (Captain) would do, but he (Captain) was not admitted.

``Her (Vavasor) mistress was very bad with a headache,'' (Jeannette)
Jeannette said.

CHAPTER XLVIII.

Preparations for Lady Monk's Party.

Early in April, the Easter recess being all over, Lady Monk gave a grand party in London. Lady Monk's town house was in Gloucester Square. It was a large mansion, and Lady Monk's parties in London were known to be very great affairs. She (Monk) usually gave two or three in the season, and spent a large portion of her (Monk) time and energy in so arranging matters that her (Monk) parties should be successful. As this was her (Monk) special line in life, a failure would have been very distressing to her (Monk);--and we may also say very disgraceful, taking into consideration, as we should do in forming our judgement on the subject, the very large sums of Sir Cosmo's money which she (Monk) spent in this way. But she (Monk) seldom did fail. She (Monk) knew how to select her (Monk) days, so as not to fall foul of other events. It seldom happened that people could not come to her (Monk) because of a division which occupied all the Members of Parliament, or that they were drawn away by the superior magnitude of some other attraction in the world of fashion. This giving of parties was her (Monk) business, and she (Monk) had learned it thoroughly. She (Monk) worked at it harder than most men work at their trades, and let us hope that the profits were consolatory.

It was generally acknowledged to be the proper thing to go to Lady Monk's parties. There were certain people who were asked, and who went as a matter of course,--people who were by no means on intimate terms with Lady Monk, or with Sir Cosmo; but they were people to have whom was the proper thing, and they were people who understood that to go to Lady Monk's was the proper thing for them. The Duchess of St. Bungay was always there, though she (Duchess) hated Lady Monk, and Lady Monk always abused her (Monk); but a card was sent to the Duchess in the same way as the Lord Mayor invites a Cabinet Minister to dinner, even though the one man might believe the other to be a thief. And Mrs. Conway Sparkes was generally there; she (Sparkes) went everywhere. Lady Monk did not at all know why Mrs. Conway Sparkes was so favoured by the world; but there was the fact, and she (Sparkes) bowed to it. Then there were another set, the members of which were or were not invited, according to circumstances, at the time; and these were the people who were probably the most legitimate recipients of Lady Monk's hospitality. Old family friends of her (Monk) husband were among the number. Let the Tuftons come in April, and perhaps again in May; then they will not feel their exclusion from that seventh heaven of glory,--the great culminating crush in July. Scores of young ladies who really loved parties belonged to this set. The mothers and aunts knew Lady Monk's sisters and cousins. They accepted so much of Lady Monk's good things as she (Monk) vouchsafed them, and were thankful. Then there was another lot, which generally became, especially on that great July occasion, the most numerous of the three. It comprised all those who made strong interest to obtain admittance within her (Monk) ladyship's house,--who struggled and fought almost with tooth and nail to get invitations. Against these people Lady Monk carried on an internecine war. Had she (Monk) not done so she (Monk) would have been swamped by them, and her (Monk) success would have been at an end; but yet she (Monk) never dreamed of shutting her (Monk) doors against them altogether, or of saying boldly that none such should hamper her (Monk) staircases. She (Monk) knew that she (Monk) must yield, but her (Monk) effort was made to yield to as few as might be possible. When she (Monk) was first told by her (Monk) factotum in these operations that Mr. Bott wanted to come, she (Monk) positively declined to have him (Bott). When it was afterwards intimated to her (Monk) that the Duchess of St. Bungay had made a point of it, she (Duchess) sneered at the Duchess, and did not even then yield. But when at last it was brought home to her (Duchess) understanding that Mr. Palliser wished it, and that Mr. Palliser probably would not come himself unless his (Palliser) wishes were gratified, she (Duchess) gave way. She (Duchess) was especially anxious that Lady Glencora should come to her (Glencora) gathering, and she (Glencora) knew that Lady Glencora could not be had without Mr. Palliser.

It was very much desired by her (Glencora) that Lady Glencora should be there.

``Burgo,'' (she)
said she (Glencora) to her (Glencora) nephew, one morning,
``look here.'' (nephew)
Burgo was at the time staying with his (Burgo) aunt, in Gloucester Square, much to the annoyance of Sir Cosmo, who had become heartily tired of his (Cosmo) nephew. The aunt and the nephew had been closeted together more than once lately, and perhaps they understood each other better now than they had done down at Monkshade. The aunt had handed a little note to Burgo, which he (Burgo) read and then threw back to her (aunt).
``You see that she (Vavasor) is not afraid of coming,'' (Lady Monk)
said Lady Monk.

``I suppose she (Vavasor) doesn't think much about it,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo.

``If that's what you really believe, you'd better give it up. Nothing on earth would justify such a step on your part except a thorough conviction that she (Vavasor) is attached to you.'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)

Burgo looked at the fireplace, almost savagely, and his (Burgo) aunt looked at him (Burgo) very keenly.

``Well,'' (she)
she (aunt) said,
``if there's to be an end of it, let there be an end of it.'' (she)

``I think I'd better hang myself,'' (he)
he (Burgo) said.

``Burgo, I will not have you here if you talk to me in that way. I am trying to help you once again; but if you look like that, and talk like that, I will give it up.'' (unknown)

``I think you'd better give it up.'' (unknown)

``Are you becoming cowardly at last? With all your faults I never expected that of you.'' (unknown)

``No; I am not a coward. I'd go out and fight him (coward) at two paces' distance with the greatest pleasure in the world.'' (unknown)

``You know that's nonsense, Burgo. It's downright braggadocio. Men do not fight now; nor at any time would a man be called upon to fight, because you simply wanted to take his (man) wife from him (man). If you had done it, indeed!'' (unknown)

``How am I to do it? I'd do it to-morrow if it depended on me. No one can say that I'm afraid of anybody or of anything.'' (unknown)

``I suppose something in the matter depends on her (wife)?'' (unknown)

``I believe she (wife) loves me,--if you mean that?'' (unknown)

``Look here, Burgo,'' (the aunt)
and the considerate aunt gave to the impoverished and ruined nephew such counsel as she (aunt), in accordance with her (aunt) lights, was enabled to bestow.
``I think you were much wronged in that matter. After what had passed I thought that you had a right to claim Lady Glencora as your wife. Mr. Palliser, in my mind, behaved very wrongly in stepping in between you and--you and such a fortune as hers, in that way. He (Palliser) cannot expect that his (Palliser) wife should have any affection for him (Palliser). There is nobody alive who has a greater horror of anything improper in married women than I have. I have always shown it. When Lady Madeline Madtop left her (Lady) husband, I would never allow her (Lady) to come inside my doors again,--though I have no doubt he (husband) ill-used her (Lady) dreadfully, and there was nothing ever proved between her (Lady) and Colonel Graham. One can't be too particular in such matters. But here, if you,--if you can succeed, you know, I shall always regard the Palliser episode in Lady Glencora's life as a tragical accident. I shall indeed. Poor dear! It was done exactly as they make nuns of girls in Roman Catholic countries; and as I should think no harm of helping a nun out of her (nun) convent, so I should think no harm of helping her (nun) now. If you are to say anything to her (nun), I think you might have an opportunity at the party.'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)

Burgo was still looking at the fireplace; and he (Burgo) sat on, looking and still looking, but he (Burgo) said nothing.

``You can think of what I have said, Burgo,'' (aunt)
continued his (Burgo) aunt, meaning that he (Burgo) should get up and go. But he (Burgo) did not go.
``Have you anything more that you wish to say to me?'' (she)
she (aunt) asked.

``I've got no money,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo, still looking at the fireplace.

Lady Glencora's property was worth not less than fifty thousand a year. He (Burgo) was a young man ambitious of obtaining that almost incredible amount of wealth, and who once had nearly reached it, by means of her (Glencora) love. His (Burgo) present obstacle consisted in his (Burgo) want of a twenty-pound note!

``I've got no money.'' (aunt)
The words were growled out rather than spoken, and his (Burgo) eyes were never turned even for a moment towards his (Burgo) aunt's face.

``You've never got any money,'' (she)
said she (aunt), speaking almost with passion.

``How can I help it? I can't make money. If I had a couple of hundred pounds, so that I could take her (nun), I believe that she (nun) would go with me. It should not be my fault if she (nun) did not. It would have been all right if she (nun) had come to Monkshade.'' (unknown)

``I've got no money for you, Burgo. I have not five pounds belonging to me.'' (unknown)

``But you've got--?'' (unknown)

``What?'' (Lady Monk)
said Lady Monk, interrupting him (Burgo) sharply.

``Would Cosmo lend it me?'' (he)
said he (Burgo), hesitating to go on with that suggestion which he (Burgo) had been about to make. The Cosmo of whom he (Cosmo) spoke was not his (Cosmo) uncle, but his (Cosmo) cousin. No eloquence could have induced his (Cosmo) uncle, Sir Cosmo, to lend him (Cosmo) another shilling. But the son of the house was a man rich with his (man) own wealth, and Burgo had not taxed him (Burgo) for some years.

``I do not know,'' (Lady Monk)
said Lady Monk.
``I never see him (Cosmo). Probably not.'' (unknown)

``It is hard,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo.
``Fancy that a man should be ruined for two hundred pounds, just at such a moment of his (man) life as this!'' (He)
He (Burgo) was a man bold by nature, and he (Burgo) did make his (Burgo) proposition.
``You have jewels, aunt;--could you not raise it for me? I would redeem them with the very first money that I got.'' (Lady)

Lady Monk rose in a passion when the suggestion was first made, but before the interview was over she (Monk) had promised that she (Monk) would endeavour to do something in the way of raising money for him (Burgo) yet, once again. He (Burgo) was her (Monk) favourite nephew, and the same almost to her (Monk) as a child of her (Monk) own. With one of her (Monk) own children indeed she (Monk) had quarrelled, and of the other, a married daughter, she (Monk) rarely saw much. Such love as she (Monk) had to give she (Monk) gave to Burgo, and she (Monk) promised him (Burgo) the money though she (Monk) knew that she (Monk) must raise it by some villanous falsehood to her (Monk) husband.

On the same morning Lady Glencora went to Queen Anne Street with the purpose of inducing Alice to go to Lady Monk's party; but Alice would not accede to the proposition, though Lady Glencora pressed it with all her (Glencora) eloquence.

``I don't know her (aunt),'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``My dear,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora,
``that's absurd. Half the people there won't know her (aunt).'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``But they know her (aunt) set, or know her (aunt) friends,--or, at any rate, will meet their own friends at her (aunt) house. I should only bother you, and should not in the least gratify myself.'' (unknown)

``The fact is, everybody will go who can, and I should have no sort of trouble in getting a card for you. Indeed I should simply write a note and say I meant to bring you.'' (unknown)

``Pray don't do any such thing, for I certainly shall not go. I can't conceive why you should wish it.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Fitzgerald will be there,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, altering her (Glencora) voice altogether, and speaking in that low tone with which she (Glencora) used to win Alice's heart down at Matching. She (Alice) was sitting close over the fire, leaning low, holding up her (Alice) little hands as a screen to her (Alice) face, and looking at her (Alice) companion earnestly.
``I'm sure that he (Fitzgerald) will be there, though nobody has told me.'' (unknown)

``That may be a reason for your staying away,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, slowly,
``but hardly a reason for my going with you.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Lady Glencora would not condescend to tell her (Glencora) friend in so many words that she (Glencora) wanted her (Glencora) protection. She (Glencora) could not bring herself to say that, though she (Glencora) wished it to be understood.

``Ah! I thought you would have gone,'' (she)
said she (Glencora).

``It would be contrary to all my habits,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice:
``I never go to people's houses when I don't know them. It's a kind of society which I don't like. Pray do not ask me.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``Oh! very well. If it must be so, I won't press it.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora had moved the position of one of her (Glencora) hands so as to get it to her (Glencora) pocket, and there had grasped a letter, which she (Glencora) still carried; but when Alice said those last cold words,
``Pray do not ask me,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
she (Alice) released the grasp, and left the letter where it was.
``I suppose he (it) won't bite me, at any rate,'' (she)
she (Alice) said, and she (Alice) assumed that look of childish drollery which she (Alice) would sometimes put on, almost with a grimace, but still with so much prettiness that no one who saw her (Alice) would regret it.

``He (it) certainly can't bite you, if you will not let him (it).'' (unknown)

``Do you know, Alice, though they all say that Plantagenet is one of the wisest men in London, I sometimes think that he (it) is one of the greatest fools. Soon after we came to town I told him (it) that we had better not go to that woman's house. Of course he (it) understood me. He (it) simply said that he (it) wished that I should do so. ``I hate anything out of the way,'' he (Alice) said. ``There can be no reason why my wife should not go to Lady Monk's house as well as to any other.

'' There was an end of it, you know, as far as anything I could do was concerned. But there wasn't an end of it with him (Alice). He (Alice) insists that I shall go, but he (Alice) sends my duenna with me. Dear Mrs. Marsham is to be there!'' (Lady Monk)

``She (Monk)'ll do you no harm, I suppose?'' (unknown)

``I'm not so sure of that, Alice. In the first place, one doesn't like to be followed everywhere by a policeman, even though one isn't going to pick a pocket. And then, the devil is so strong within me, that I should like to dodge the policeman. I can fancy a woman being driven to do wrong simply by a desire to show her (woman) policeman that she (woman) can be too many for him (policeman).'' (unknown)

``Glencora, you make me so wretched when you talk like that.'' (unknown)

``Will you go with me, then, so that I may have a policeman of my own choosing? He (policeman) asked me if I would mind taking Mrs. Marsham with me in my carriage. So I up and spoke, very boldly, like the proud young porter, and told him (porter) I would not; and when he (porter) asked why not, I said that I preferred taking a friend of my own,--a young friend, I said, and I then named you or my cousin, Lady Jane. I told him (cousin) I should bring one or the other.'' (unknown)

``And was he (cousin) angry?'' (unknown)

``No; he (cousin) took it very quietly,--saying something, in his (cousin) calm way, about hoping that I should get over a prejudice against one of his (cousin) earliest and dearest friends. He (cousin) twits at me because I don't understand Parliament and the British Constitution, but I know more of them than he (cousin) does about a woman. You are quite sure you won't go, then?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice hesitated a moment.
``Do,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora; and there was an amount of persuasion in her (Alice) accent which should, I think, have overcome her (Alice) cousin's scruples.

``It is against the whole tenor of my life's way,'' (she)
she (Alice) said,
``And, Glencora, I am not happy myself. I am not fit for parties. I sometimes think that I shall never go into society again.'' (she)

``That's nonsense, you know.'' (unknown)

``I suppose it is, but I cannot go now. I would if I really thought--'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``Oh, very well,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, interrupting her (Glencora).
``I suppose I shall get through it. If he (tenor) asks me to dance, I shall stand up with him (tenor), just as though I had never seen him (tenor) before.'' (she)
Then she (Glencora) remembered the letter in her (Glencora) pocket,--remembered that at this moment she (Glencora) bore about with her (Glencora) a written proposition from this man to go off with him (man) and leave her (Glencora) husband's house. She (Glencora) had intended to show it to Alice on this occasion; but as Alice had refused her (Alice) request, she (Alice) was glad that she (Alice) had not done so.
``You'll come to me the morning after,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, as she (Glencora) went. This Alice promised to do; and then she (Alice) was left alone.

Alice regretted,--regretted deeply that she (Alice) had not consented to go with her (Alice) cousin. After all, of what importance had been her (Alice) objection when compared with the cause for which her (Alice) presence had been desired? Doubtless she (Alice) would have been uncomfortable at Lady Monk's house; but could she (Lady) not have borne some hour or two of discomfort on her (Lady) friend's behalf? But, in truth, it was only after Lady Glencora had left her (Glencora) that she (Glencora) began to understand the subject fully, and to feel that she (Glencora) might possibly have been of service in a great danger. But it was too late now. Then she (Glencora) strove to comfort herself with the reflection that a casual meeting at an evening party in London could not be perilous in the same degree as a prolonged sojourn together in a country house.

CHAPTER XLIX.

How Lady Glencora Went to Lady Monk's Party.

Lady Monk's house in Gloucester Square was admirably well adapted for the giving of parties. It was a large house, and seemed to the eyes of guests to be much larger than it was. The hall was spacious, and the stairs went up in the centre, facing you as you entered the inner hall. Round the top of the stairs there was a broad gallery, with an ornamented railing, and from this opened the doors into the three reception-rooms. There were two on the right, the larger of which looked out backwards, and these two were connected by an archway, as though made for folding-doors; but the doors, I believe, never were there. Fronting the top of the staircase there was a smaller room, looking out backwards, very prettily furnished, and much used by Lady Monk when alone. It was here that Burgo had held that conference with his (Burgo) aunt of which mention has been made. Below stairs there was the great dining-room, on which, on these occasions, a huge buffet was erected for refreshments,--what I may call a masculine buffet, as it was attended by butlers and men in livery,--and there was a smaller room looking out into the square, in which there was a feminine battery for the dispensing of tea and such like smaller good things, and from which female aid could be attained for the arrangement or mending of dresses in a further sanctum within it. For such purposes as that now on foot the house was most commodious. Lady Monk, on these occasions, was moved by a noble ambition to do something different from that done by her (Monk) neighbours in similar circumstances, and therefore she (Monk) never came forward to receive her (Monk) guests. She (Monk) ensconced herself, early in the evening, in that room at the head of the stairs, and there they who chose to see her (Monk) made their way up to her (Monk), and spoke their little speeches. They who thought her (Monk) to be a great woman,--and many people did think her (Monk) to be great,--were wont to declare that she (Monk) never forgot those who did come, or those who did not. And even they who desired to describe her (Monk) as little,--for even Lady Monk had enemies,--would hint that though she (Monk) never came out of the room, she (Monk) would rise from her (Monk) chair and make a step towards the door whenever any name very high in fashionable life greeted her (Monk) ears. So that a mighty Cabinet Minister, or a duchess in great repute, or any special wonder of the season, could not fail of entering her (Monk) precincts and being seen there for a few moments. It would, of course, happen that the doorway of her (Monk) chamber would become blocked; but there were precautions taken to avoid this inconvenience as far as possible, and one man in livery was employed to go backwards and forwards between his (man) mistress and the outer world, so as to keep the thread of a passage open.

But though Lady Monk was in this way enabled to rest herself during her (Monk) labours, there was much in her (Monk) night's work which was not altogether exhilarating. Ladies would come into her (Monk) small room and sit there by the hour, with whom she (Monk) had not the slightest wish to hold conversation. The Duchess of St. Bungay would always be there,--so that there was a special seat in one corner of the room which was called the Duchess' stool.

``I shouldn't care a straw about her (me),'' (Lady Monk)
Lady Monk had been heard to complain,
``if she (me) would talk to anybody. But nobody will talk to her (me), and then she (me) listens to everything.'' (Lady Monk)

There had been another word or two between Burgo Fitzgerald and his (Fitzgerald) aunt before the evening came, a word or two in the speaking of which she (aunt) had found some difficulty. She (aunt) was prepared with the money,--with that two hundred pounds for which he (Fitzgerald) had asked,--obtained with what wiles, and lies, and baseness of subterfuge I need not stop here to describe. But she (aunt) was by no means willing to give this over into her (aunt) nephew's hands without security. She (aunt) was willing to advance him (nephew) this money; she (aunt) had been willing even to go through unusual dirt to get it for him (nephew); but she (aunt) was desirous that he (nephew) should have it only for a certain purpose. How could she (aunt) bind him (nephew) down to spend it as she (aunt) would have it spent? Could she (aunt) undertake to hand it to him (nephew) as soon as Lady Glencora should be in his (nephew) power? Even though she (aunt) could have brought herself to say as much,--and I think she (aunt) might also have done so after what she (aunt) had said,--she (aunt) could not have carried out such a plan. In that case the want would be instant, and the action must be rapid. She (aunt) therefore had no alternative but to entrust him (nephew) with the bank-notes at once.

``Burgo,'' (she)
she (aunt) said,
