``if I find that you deceive me now, I will never trust you again.'' (she)
``All right,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo, as he (Burgo) barely counted the money before he (Burgo) thrust it into his (Burgo) breast-pocket.
``It is lent to you for a certain purpose, should you happen to want it,'' (she)
she (aunt) said, solemnly.
``I do happen to want it very much,'' (he)
he (Burgo) answered. She (aunt) did not dare to say more; but as her (aunt) nephew turned away from her (aunt) with a step that was quite light in its gaiety, she (aunt) almost felt that she (aunt) was already cozened. Let Burgo's troubles be as heavy as they might be, there was something to him (Burgo) ecstatic in the touch of ready money which always cured them for the moment.

-LSB-Illustration:

``All right,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo, as he (Burgo) thrust the money into his (Burgo) breast-pocket.-RSB-

On the morning of Lady Monk's party a few very uncomfortable words passed between Mr. Palliser and his (Palliser) wife.

``Your cousin is not going, then?'' (he)
said he (Palliser).

``Alice is not going.'' (unknown)

``Then you can give Mrs. Marsham a seat in your carriage?'' (unknown)

``Impossible, Plantagenet. I thought I had told you that I had promised my cousin Jane.'' (unknown)

``But you can take three.'' (unknown)

``Indeed I can't,--unless you would like me to sit out with the coachman.'' (he)

There was something in this,--a tone of loudness, a touch of what he (Palliser) called to himself vulgarity,--which made him (Palliser) very angry. So he (Palliser) turned away from her (wife), and looked as black as a thundercloud.

``You must know, Plantagenet,'' (she)
she (wife) went on,
``that it is impossible for three women dressed to go out in one carriage. I am sure you wouldn't like to see me afterwards if I had been one of them.'' (she)

``You need not have said anything to Lady Jane when Miss Vavasor refused. I had asked you before that.'' (unknown)

``And I had told you that I liked going with young women, and not with old ones. That's the long and the short of it.'' (unknown)

``Glencora, I wish you would not use such expressions.'' (unknown)

``What! not the long and the short? It's good English. Quite as good as Mr. Bott's, when he (Bott) said in the House the other night that the Government kept their accounts in a higgledy-piggledy way. You see, I have been studying the debates, and you shouldn't be angry with me.'' (unknown)

``I am not angry with you. You speak like a child to say so. Then, I suppose, the carriage must go for Mrs. Marsham after it has taken you?'' (unknown)

``It shall go before. Jane will not be in a hurry, and I am sure I shall not.'' (unknown)

``She (Jane) will think you very uncivil; that is all. I told her (Jane) that she (Jane) could go with you when I heard that Miss Vavasor was not to be there.'' (unknown)

``Then, Plantagenet, you shouldn't have told her (Jane) so, and that's the long--; but I mustn't say that. The truth is this, if you give me any orders I'll obey them,--as far as I can. If I can't I'll say so. But if I'm left to go by my own judgement, it's not fair that I should be scolded afterwards.'' (unknown)

``I have never scolded you.'' (unknown)

``Yes, you have. You have told me that I was uncivil.'' (unknown)

``I said that she (Jane) would think you so.'' (unknown)

``Then, if it's only what she (Jane) thinks, I don't care two straws about it. She (Jane) may have the carriage to herself if she (Jane) likes, but she (Jane) shan't have me in it,--not unless I'm ordered to go. I don't like her (Jane), and I won't pretend to like her (Jane). My belief is that she (Jane) follows me about to tell you if she (Jane) thinks that I do wrong.'' (unknown)

``Glencora!'' (unknown)

``And that odious baboon with the red bristles does the same thing,--only he (Jane) goes to her (Jane) because he (Jane) doesn't dare to go to you.'' (Plantagenet/Plantagenet Palliser)

Plantagenet Palliser was struck wild with dismay. He (Palliser) understood well who it was whom his (Palliser) wife intended to describe; but that she (wife) should have spoken of any man as a baboon with red bristles, was terrible to his (man) mind! He (man) was beginning to think that he (man) hardly knew how to manage his (man) wife. And the picture she (wife) had drawn was very distressing to him (man). She (wife) had no mother; neither had he (man); and he (man) had wished that Mrs. Marsham should give to her (Marsham) some of that matronly assistance and guidance which a mother does give to her (mother) young married daughter. It was true, too, as he (man) knew, that a word or two as to some socially domestic matters had filtered through to him (man) from Mr. Bott, down at Matching Priory, but only in such a way as to enable him (Bott) to see what counsel it was needful that he (Bott) should give. As for espionage over his (Bott) wife,--no man could despise it more than he (Bott) did! No man would be less willing to resort to it! And now his (man) wife was accusing him (man) of keeping spies, both male and female.

``Glencora!'' (he)
he (man) said again; and then he (man) stopped, not knowing what to say to her (wife).

``Well, my dear, it's better you should know at once what I feel about it. I don't suppose I'm very good; indeed I dare say I'm bad enough, but these people about me won't make me any better. The duennas don't make the Spanish ladies worth much.'' (unknown)

``Duennas!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
After that, Lady Glencora sat herself down, and Mr. Palliser stood for some moments looking at her (Glencora).

It ended in his (Palliser) making her (Glencora) a long speech, in which he (Palliser) said a good deal of his (Palliser) own justice and forbearance, and something also of her (Glencora) frivolity and childishness. He (Palliser) told her (Glencora) that his (Palliser) only complaint of her (Glencora) was that she (Glencora) was too young, and, as he (Palliser) did so, she (Glencora) made a little grimace,--not to him (Palliser), but to herself, as though saying to herself that that was all he (Palliser) knew about it. He (Palliser) did not notice it, or, if he (Palliser) did, his (Palliser) notice did not stop his (Palliser) eloquence. He (Palliser) assured her (Glencora) that he (Palliser) was far from keeping any watch over her (Glencora), and declared that she (Glencora) had altogether mistaken Mrs. Marsham's character. Then there was another little grimace.

``There's somebody has mistaken it worse than I have,'' (unknown)
the grimace said. Of the bristly baboon he (character) condescended to say nothing, and he (character) wound up by giving her (Glencora) a cold kiss, and saying that he (character) would meet her (Glencora) at Lady Monk's.

When the evening came,--or rather the night,--the carriage went first for Mrs. Marsham, and having deposited her (Marsham) at Lady Monk's, went back to Park Lane for Lady Glencora. Then she (Glencora) had herself driven to St. James's Square, to pick up Lady Jane, so that altogether the coachman and horses did not have a good time of it.

``I wish he (Jane)'d keep a separate carriage for her (I),'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora said to her (Glencora) cousin Jane,--having perceived that her (Glencora) servants were not in a good humour.
``That would be expensive,'' (Lady Jane/Jane)
said Lady Jane.
``Yes, it would be expensive,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora. She (Glencora) would not condescend to make any remark as to the non-importance of such expense to a man so wealthy as her (Glencora) husband, knowing that his (husband) wealth was, in fact, hers. Never to him (husband) or to any other,--not even to herself,--had she (Glencora) hinted that much was due to her (Glencora) because she (Glencora) had been magnificent as an heiress. There were many things about this woman that were not altogether what a husband might wish. She (woman) was not softly delicate in all her (woman) ways; but in disposition and temper she (woman) was altogether generous. I do not know that she (woman) was at all points a lady, but had Fate so willed it she (lady) would have been a thorough gentleman.

Mrs. Marsham was by no means satisfied with the way in which she (Marsham) was treated. She (Marsham) would not have cared to go at all to Lady Monk's party had she (Lady) supposed that she (Lady) would have to make her (Lady) entry there alone. With Lady Glencora she (Glencora) would have seemed to receive some of that homage which would certainly have been paid to her (Glencora) companion. The carriage called, moreover, before she (Glencora) was fully ready, and the footman, as he (footman) stood at the door to hand her (Glencora) in, had been very sulky. She (Glencora) understood it all. She (Glencora) knew that Lady Glencora had positively declined her (Glencora) companionship; and if she (Glencora) resolved to be revenged, such resolution on her (Glencora) part was only natural. When she (Glencora) reached Lady Monk's house, she (Monk) had to make her (Monk) way up stairs all alone. The servants called her (Monk) Mrs. Marsh, and under that name she (Monk) got passed on into the front drawing-room. There she (Monk) sat down, not having seen Lady Monk, and meditated over her (Monk) injuries.

It was past eleven before Lady Glencora arrived, and Burgo Fitzgerald had begun to think that his (Fitzgerald) evil stars intended that he (Fitzgerald) should never see her (Glencora) again. He (Fitzgerald) had been wickedly baulked at Monkshade, by what influence he (Fitzgerald) had never yet ascertained; and now he (Fitzgerald) thought that the same influence must be at work to keep her (Glencora) again away from his (Fitzgerald) aunt's house. He (Fitzgerald) had settled in his (Fitzgerald) mind no accurate plan of a campaign; he (Fitzgerald) had in his (Fitzgerald) thoughts no fixed arrangement by which he (Fitzgerald) might do the thing which he (Fitzgerald) meditated. He (Fitzgerald) had attempted to make some such plan; but, as is the case with all men to whom thinking is an unusual operation, concluded at last that he (Fitzgerald) had better leave it to the course of events. It was, however, obviously necessary that he (Fitzgerald) should see Lady Glencora before the course of events could be made to do anything for him (Fitzgerald). He (Fitzgerald) had written to her (Glencora), making his (Fitzgerald) proposition in bold terms, and he (Fitzgerald) felt that if she (Glencora) were utterly decided against him (Fitzgerald), her (Glencora) anger at his (Fitzgerald) suggestion, or at least her (Glencora) refusal, would have been made known to him (Fitzgerald) in some way. Silence did not absolutely give consent, but it seemed to show that consent was not impossible. From ten o'clock to past eleven he (Fitzgerald) stood about on the staircase of his (Fitzgerald) aunt's house, waiting for the name which he (Fitzgerald) was desirous of hearing, and which he (Fitzgerald) almost feared to hear. Men spoke to him (Fitzgerald), and women also, but he (Fitzgerald) hardly answered. His (Fitzgerald) aunt once called him (Fitzgerald) into her (aunt) room, and with a cautionary frown on her (aunt) brow, bade him (Fitzgerald) go dance.

``Don't look so dreadfully preoccupied,'' (she)
she (aunt) said to him (Fitzgerald) in a whisper. But he (Fitzgerald) shook his (Fitzgerald) head at her (aunt), almost savagely, and went away, and did not dance. Dance! How was he (Fitzgerald) to dance with such an enterprise as that upon his (Fitzgerald) mind? Even to Burgo Fitzgerald the task of running away with another man's wife had in it something which prevented dancing. Lady Monk was older, and was able to regulate her (Monk) feelings with more exactness. But Burgo, though he (Burgo) could not dance, went down into the dining-room and drank. He (Burgo) took a large beer-glass full of champagne and soon after that another. The drink did not flush his (Burgo) cheeks or make his (Burgo) forehead red, or bring out the sweat-drops on his (Burgo) brow, as it does with some men; but it added a peculiar brightness to his (Burgo) blue eyes. It was by the light of his (Burgo) eyes that men knew when Burgo had been drinking.

At last, while he (Burgo) was still in the supper room, he (Burgo) heard Lady Glencora's name announced. He (Burgo) had already seen Mr. Palliser come in and make his (Palliser) way up-stairs some quarter of an hour before; but as to that he (Palliser) was indifferent. He (Palliser) had known that the husband was to be there. When the long-expected name reached his (Palliser) ears, his (Palliser) heart seemed to jump within him (Palliser). What, on the spur of the moment, should he (Palliser) do? As he (Palliser) had resolved that he (Palliser) would be doing,--that something should be done, let it be what it might,--he (Palliser) hurried to the dining-room door, and was just in time to see and be seen as Lady Glencora was passing up the stairs. She (Glencora) was just above him (Palliser) as he (Palliser) got himself out into the hall, so that he (Palliser) could not absolutely greet her (Glencora) with his (Palliser) hand; but he (Palliser) looked up at her (Glencora), and caught her (Glencora) eye. He (Palliser) looked up, and moved his (Palliser) hand to her (Glencora) in token of salutation. She (Glencora) looked down at him (Palliser), and the expression of her (Glencora) face altered visibly as her (Glencora) glance met his (Palliser). She (Glencora) barely bowed to him (Palliser),--with her (Glencora) eyes rather than with her (Glencora) head, but he (Palliser) flattered himself that there was, at any rate, no anger in her (Glencora) countenance. How beautiful he (Palliser) was as he (Palliser) gazed up at her (Glencora), leaning against the wall as he (Palliser) stood, and watching her (Glencora) as she (Glencora) made her (Glencora) slow way up the stairs! She (Glencora) felt that his (Palliser) eyes were on her (Glencora), and where the stairs turned she (Glencora) could not restrain herself from one other glance. As her (Glencora) eyes fell on his (Palliser) again, his (Palliser) mouth opened, and she (Glencora) fancied that she (Glencora) could hear the faint sigh that he (Palliser) uttered. It was a glorious mouth, such as the old sculptors gave to their marble gods! And Burgo, if it was so that he (Burgo) had not heart enough to love truly, could look as though he (Burgo) loved. It was not in him (Burgo) deceit,--or what men call acting. The expression came to him (Burgo) naturally, though it expressed so much more than there was within; as strong words come to some men who have no knowledge that they are speaking strongly. At this moment Burgo Fitzgerald looked as though it were possible that he (Fitzgerald) might die of love.

Lady Glencora was met at the top of the stairs by Lady Monk, who came out to her (Monk), almost into the gallery, with her (Monk) sweetest smile,--so that the newly-arrived guest, of course, entered into the small room. There sat the Duchess of St. Bungay on her (Duchess) stool in the corner, and there, next to the Duchess, but at the moment engaged in no conversation, stood Mr. Bott. There was another lady there, who stood very high in the world, and whom Lady Monk was very glad to welcome--the young Marchioness of Hartletop. She (Monk) was in slight mourning; for her (Monk) father-in-law, the late Marquis, had died no t yet quite six months since. Very beautiful she (Monk) was, and one whose presence at their houses ladies and gentlemen prized alike. She (Monk) never said silly things, like the Duchess, never was troublesome as to people's conduct to her (Duchess), was always gracious, yet was never led away into intimacies, was without peer the best-dressed woman in London, and yet gave herself no airs;--and then she (woman) was so exquisitely beautiful. Her (woman) smile was loveliness itself. There were, indeed, people who said that it meant nothing; but then, what should the smile of a young married woman mean? She (woman) had not been born in the purple, like Lady Glencora, her (Glencora) father being a country clergyman who had never reached a higher grade than that of an archdeacon; but she (Glencora) knew the ways of high life, and what an exigeant husband would demand of her (Glencora), much better than poor Glencora. She (Glencora) would have spoken of no man as a baboon with a bristly beard. She (Glencora) never talked of the long and the short of it. She (Glencora) did not wander out o' nights in winter among the ruins. She (Glencora) made no fast friendship with ladies whom her (Glencora) lord did not like. She (Glencora) had once, indeed, been approached by a lover since she (Glencora) had been married,--Mr. Palliser himself having been the offender,--but she (Glencora) had turned the affair to infinite credit and profit, had gained her (Glencora) husband's closest confidence by telling him (husband) of it all, had yet not brought on any hostile collision, and had even dismissed her (Glencora) lover without annoying him (lover). But then Lady Hartletop was a miracle of a woman!

Lady Glencora was no miracle. Though born in the purple, she (Glencora) was made of ordinary flesh and blood, and as she (Glencora) entered Lady Monk's little room, hardly knew how to recover herself sufficiently for the purposes of ordinary conversation.

``Dear Lady Glencora, do come in for a moment to my den. We were so sorry not to have you at Monkshade. We heard such terrible things about your health.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora said that it was only a cold,--a bad cold.
``Oh, yes; we heard,--something about moonlight and ruins. So like you, you know. I love that sort of thing, above all people; but it doesn't do; does it? Circumstances are so exacting. I think you know Lady Hartletop;--and there's the Duchess of St. Bungay. Mr. Palliser was here five minutes since.'' (Lady)
Then Lady Monk was obliged to get to her (Monk) door again and Lady Glencora found herself standing close to Lady Hartletop.

``We saw Mr. Palliser just pass through,'' (Lady Hartletop)
said Lady Hartletop, who was able to meet and speak of the man who had dared to approach her (Hartletop) with his (man) love, without the slightest nervousness.

``Yes; he (Palliser) said he (Palliser) should be here,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``There's a great crowd,'' (Lady Hartletop)
said Lady Hartletop.
``I didn't think London was so full.'' (unknown)

``Very great.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, and then they had said to each other all that society required. Lady Glencora, as we know, could talk with imprudent vehemence by the hour together if she (Glencora) liked her (Glencora) companion; but the other lady seldom committed herself by more words than she (lady) had uttered now,--unless it was to her (lady) tirewoman.

``How very well you are looking,'' (the Duchess)
said the Duchess.
``And I heard you had been so ill.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Of that midnight escapade among the ruins it was fated that Lady Glencora should never hear the last.

``How d'ye do, Lady Glencowrer?'' (unknown)
sounded in her (Glencora) ear, and there was a great red paw stuck out for her (Glencora) to take. But after what had passed between Lady Glencora and her (Glencora) husband to-day about Mr. Bott, she (Glencora) was determined that she (Glencora) would not take Mr. Bott's hand.

``How are you, Mr. Bott?'' (she)
she (Glencora) said.
``I think I'll look for Mr. Palliser in the back room.'' (unknown)

``Dear Lady Glencora,'' (the Duchess)
whispered the Duchess, in an ecstasy of agony. Lady Glencora turned and bowed her (Glencora) head to her (Glencora) stout friend.
``Do let me go away with you. There's that woman, Mrs. Conway Sparkes, coming, and you know how I hate her (Sparkes).'' (She)
She (Glencora) had nothing to do but to take the Duchess under her (Duchess) wing, and they passed into the large room together. It is, I think, more than probable that Mrs. Conway Sparkes had been brought in by Lady Monk as the only way of removing the Duchess from her (Duchess) stool.

Just within the dancing-room Lady Glencora found her (Glencora) husband, standing in a corner, looking as though he (husband) were making calculations.

``I'm going away,'' (he)
said he (husband), coming up to her (Glencora).
``I only just came because I said I would. Shall you be late?'' (unknown)

``Oh, no; I suppose not.'' (unknown)

``Shall you dance?'' (unknown)

``Perhaps once,--just to show that I'm not an old woman.'' (unknown)

``Don't heat yourself. Good-bye.'' (he)
Then he (husband) went, and in the crush of the doorway he (husband) passed Burgo Fitzgerald, whose eye was intently fixed upon his (husband) wife. He (husband) looked at Burgo, and some thought of that young man's former hopes flashed across his (husband) mind,--some remembrance, too, of a caution that had been whispered to him (husband); but for no moment did a suspicion come to him (husband) that he (husband) ought to stop and watch by his (husband) wife.

CHAPTER L.

How Lady Glencora Came Back from Lady Monk's Party.

Burgo Fitzgerald remained for a minute or two leaning where we last saw him (Fitzgerald),--against the dining-room wall at the bottom of the staircase; and as he (Fitzgerald) did so some thoughts that were almost solemn passed across his (Fitzgerald) mind, This thing that he (Fitzgerald) was about to do, or to attempt,--was it in itself a good thing, and would it be good for her (Lady) whom he (Fitzgerald) pretended to love? What would be her (Lady) future if she (Lady) consented now to go with him (Fitzgerald), and to divide herself from her (Lady) husband? Of his (husband) own future he (husband) thought not at all. He (husband) had never done so. Even when he (husband) had first found himself attracted by the reputation of her (Lady) wealth, he (husband) cannot be said to have looked forward in any prudential way to coming years. His (husband) desire to put himself in possession of so magnificent a fortune had simply prompted him (husband), as he (husband) might have been prompted to play for a high stake at a gaming-table. But now, during these moments, he (husband) did think a little of her (Lady). Would she (Lady) be happy, simply because he (husband) loved her (Lady), when all women should cease to acknowledge her (Lady); when men would regard her (Lady) as one degraded and dishonoured; when society should be closed against her (Lady); when she (Lady) would be driven to live loudly because the softness and graces of quiet life would be denied to her (Lady)? Burgo knew well what must be the nature of such a woman's life in such circumstances. Would Glencora be happy with him (Burgo) while living such a life simply because he (Burgo) loved her (Lady)? And, under such circumstances, was it likely that he (Burgo) would continue to love her (Lady)? Did he (Burgo) not know himself to be the most inconstant of men, and the least trustworthy? Leaning thus against the wall at the bottom of the stairs he (Burgo) did ask himself all these questions with something of true feeling about his (Burgo) heart, and almost persuaded himself that he (Burgo) had better take his (Burgo) hat and wander forth anywhere into the streets. It mattered little what might become of himself. If he (Burgo) could drink himself out of the world, it might be an end of things that would be not altogether undesirable.

But then the remembrance of his (Burgo) aunt's two hundred pounds came upon him (Burgo), which money he (Burgo) even now had about him (Burgo) on his (Burgo) person, and a certain idea of honour told him (Burgo) that he (Burgo) was bound to do that for which the money had been given to him (Burgo). As to telling his (Burgo) aunt that he (Burgo) had changed his (Burgo) mind, and, therefore, refunding the money--no such thought as that was possible to him (Burgo)! To give back two hundred pounds entire,--two hundred pounds which were already within his (Burgo) clutches, was not within the compass of Burgo's generosity. Remembering the cash, he (Burgo) told himself that hesitation was no longer possible to him (Burgo). So he (Burgo) gathered himself up, stretched his (Burgo) hands over his (Burgo) head, uttered a sigh that was audible to all around him (Burgo), and took himself up-stairs.

He (Burgo) looked in at his (Burgo) aunt's room, and then he (Burgo) saw her (aunt) and was seen by her (aunt).

``Well, Burgo,'' (she)
she (aunt) said, with her (aunt) sweetest smile,
``have you been dancing?'' (she)
He (Burgo) turned away from her (aunt) without answering her (aunt), muttering something between his (Burgo) teeth about a cold-blooded Jezebel,--which, if she (aunt) had heard it, would have made her (aunt) think him (Burgo) the most ungrateful of men. But she (aunt) did not hear him (Burgo), and smiled still as he (Burgo) went away, saying something to Mrs. Conway Sparkes as to the great change for the better which had taken place in her (Sparkes) nephew's conduct.

``There's no knowing who may not reform,'' (Mrs. Sparkes/Mrs. Conway Sparkes)
said Mrs. Sparkes, with an emphasis which seemed to Lady Monk to be almost uncourteous.

Burgo made his (Burgo) way first into the front room and then into the larger room where the dancing was in progress, and there he (Burgo) saw Lady Glencora standing up in a quadrille with the Marquis of Hartletop. Lord Hartletop was a man not much more given to conversation than his (Hartletop) wife, and Lady Glencora seemed to go through her (Glencora) work with very little gratification either in the dancing or in the society of her (Glencora) partner. She (Glencora) was simply standing up to dance, because, as she (Glencora) had told Mr. Palliser, ladies of her (Glencora) age generally do stand up on such occasions. Burgo watched her (Glencora) as she (Glencora) crossed and re-crossed the room, and at last she (Glencora) was aware of his (Burgo) presence. It made no change in her (Glencora), except that she (Glencora) became even somewhat less animated than she (Glencora) had been before. She (Glencora) would not seem to see him (Burgo), nor would she (Glencora) allow herself to be driven into a pretence of a conversation with her (Glencora) partner because he (Burgo) was there.

``I will go up to her (woman) at once, and ask her (woman) to waltz,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
Burgo said to himself, as soon as the last figure of the quadrille was in action.
``Why should I not ask her (woman) as well as any other woman?'' (Lord Hartletop/Hartletop)
Then the music ceased, and after a minute's interval Lord Hartletop took away his (Hartletop) partner on his (Hartletop) arm into another room. Burgo, who had been standing near the door, followed them at once. The crowd was great, so that he (Burgo) could not get near them or even keep them in sight, but he (Burgo) was aware of the way in which they were going.

It was five minutes after this when he (Burgo) again saw her (Hartletop), and then she (Hartletop) was seated on a cane bench in the gallery, and an old woman was standing close to her (woman), talking to her (woman). It was Mrs. Marsham cautioning her (Marsham) against some petty imprudence, and Lady Glencora was telling that lady that she (Glencora) needed no such advice, in words almost as curt as those I have used. Lord Hartletop had left her (Glencora), feeling that, as far as that was concerned, he (Hartletop) had done his (Hartletop) duty for the night. Burgo knew nothing of Mrs. Marsham,--had never seen her (Marsham) before, and was quite unaware that she (Marsham) had any special connection with Mr. Palliser. It was impossible, he (Palliser) thought, to find Lady Glencora in a better position for his (Palliser) purpose, so he (Palliser) made his (Palliser) way up to her (Glencora) through the crowd, and muttering some slight inaudible word, offered her (Glencora) his (Palliser) hand.

``That will do very well thank you, Mrs. Marsham,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora said at this moment.
``Pray, do not trouble yourself,'' (she)
and then she (Glencora) gave her (Glencora) hand to Fitzgerald. Mrs. Marsham, though unknown to him (Fitzgerald), knew with quite sufficient accuracy who he (Fitzgerald) was, and all his (Fitzgerald) history, as far as it concerned her (Marsham) friend's wife. She (Marsham) had learned the whole story of the loves of Burgo and Lady Glencora. Though Mr. Palliser had never mentioned that man's name to her (Glencora), she (Glencora) was well aware that her (Glencora) duty as a duenna would make it expedient that she (Glencora) should keep a doubly wary eye upon him (Palliser) should he (Palliser) come near the sheepfold. And there he (Palliser) was, close to them, almost leaning over them, with the hand of his (Palliser) late lady love,--the hand of Mr. Palliser's wife,--within his (Palliser) own! How Lady Glencora might have carried herself at this moment had Mrs. Marsham not been there, it is bootless now to surmise; but it may be well understood that under Mrs. Marsham's immediate eye all her (Marsham) resolution would be in Burgo's favour. She (Marsham) looked at him (Palliser) softly and kindly, and though she (Marsham) uttered no articulate word, her (Marsham) countenance seemed to show that the meeting was not unpleasant to her (Marsham).

``Will you waltz?'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo,--asking it not at all as though it were a special favour,--asking it exactly as he (Burgo) might have done had they been in the habit of dancing with each other every other night for the last three months.

``I don't think Lady Glencora will waltz to-night,'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham, very stiffly. She (Marsham) certainly did not know her (Marsham) business as a duenna, or else the enormity of Burgo's proposition had struck her (Marsham) so forcibly as to take away from her (Marsham) all her (Marsham) presence of mind. Otherwise, she (Marsham) must have been aware that such an answer from her (Marsham) would surely drive her (Marsham) friend's wife into open hostility.

``And why not, Mrs. Marsham?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora rising from her (Glencora) seat.
``Why shouldn't I waltz to-night? I rather think I shall, the more especially as Mr. Fitzgerald waltzes very well.'' (she)
Thereupon she (Glencora) put her (Glencora) hand upon Burgo's arm.

Mrs. Marsham made still a little effort,--a little effort that was probably involuntary. She (Marsham) put out her (Marsham) hand, and laid it on Lady Glencora's left shoulder, looking into her (Glencora) face as she (Glencora) did so with all the severity of caution of which she (Glencora) was mistress. Lady Glencora shook her (Glencora) duenna off angrily. Whether she (Glencora) would put her (Glencora) fate into the hands of this man who was now touching her (Glencora), or whether she (Glencora) would not, she (Glencora) had not as yet decided; but of this she (Glencora) was very sure, that nothing said or done by Mrs. Marsham should have any effect in restraining her (Marsham).

What could Mrs. Marsham do? Mr. Palliser was gone. Some rumour of that proposed visit to Monkshade, and the way in which it had been prevented, had reached her (Marsham) ear. Some whispers had come to her (Marsham) that Fitzgerald still dared to love, as married, the woman whom he (Fitzgerald) had loved before she (Marsham) was married. There was a rumour about that he (Fitzgerald) still had some hope. Mrs. Marsham had never believed that Mr. Palliser's wife would really be false to her (Marsham) vows. It was not in fear of any such catastrophe as a positive elopement that she (Marsham) had taken upon herself the duty of duenna. Lady Glencora would, no doubt, require to be pressed down into that decent mould which it would become the wife of a Mr. Palliser to assume as her (wife) form; and this pressing down, and this moulding, Mrs. Marsham thought that she (Marsham) could accomplish. It had not hitherto occurred to her (Marsham) that she (Marsham) might be required to guard Mr. Palliser from positive dishonour; but now--now she (Marsham) hardly knew what to think about it. What should she (Marsham) do? To whom should she (Marsham) go? And then she (Marsham) saw Mr. Bott looming large before her (Marsham) on the top of the staircase.

-LSB-Illustration: Mr. Bott on the watch.-RSB-

In the meantime Lady Glencora went off towards the dancers, leaning on Burgo's arm.

``Who is that woman?'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo. They were the first words he (Burgo) spoke to her (Glencora), though since he (Burgo) had last seen her (Glencora) he (Burgo) had written to her (Glencora) that letter which even now she (Glencora) carried about her (Glencora). His (Burgo) voice in her (Glencora) ears sounded as it used to sound when their intimacy had been close, and questions such as that he (Burgo) had asked were common between them. And her (Glencora) answer was of the same nature.
``Oh, such an odious woman!'' (she)
she (Glencora) said.
``Her (woman) name is Mrs. Marsham; she (Marsham) is my bête noire.'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
And then they were actually dancing, whirling round the room together, before a word had been said of that which was Burgo's settled purpose, and which at some moments was her (Glencora) settled purpose also.

Burgo waltzed excellently, and in old days, before her (Glencora) marriage, Lady Glencora had been passionately fond of dancing. She (Glencora) seemed to give herself up to it now as though the old days had come back to her (Glencora). Lady Monk, creeping to the intermediate door between her (Monk) den and the dancing-room, looked in on them, and then crept back again. Mrs. Marsham and Mr. Bott standing together just inside the other door, near to the staircase, looked on also--in horror.

``He (Fitzgerald) shouldn't have gone away and left her (Marsham),'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Mr. Bott, almost hoarsely.

``But who could have thought it?'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham.
``I'm sure I didn't.'' (unknown)

``I suppose you'd better tell him (Fitzgerald)?'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Mr. Bott.

``But I don't know where to find him (Fitzgerald),'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham.

``I didn't mean now at once,'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Mr. Bott;--and then he (Bott) added,
``Do you think it is as bad as that?'' (he)

``I don't know what to think,'' (Mrs. Marsham)
said Mrs. Marsham.

The waltzers went on till they were stopped by want of breath.

``I am so much out of practice,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora;
``I didn't think--I should have been able--to dance at all.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Then she (Glencora) put up her (Glencora) face, and slightly opened her (Glencora) mouth, and stretched her (Glencora) nostrils,--as ladies do as well as horses when the running has been severe and they want air.

``You'll take another turn,'' (he)
said he (Bott).

``Presently,'' (she)
said she (Glencora), beginning to have some thought in her (Glencora) mind as to whether Mrs. Marsham was watching her (Marsham). Then there was a little pause, after which he (Bott) spoke in an altered voice.

``Does it put you in mind of old days?'' (he)
said he (Bott).

It was, of course, necessary for him (Bott) that he (Bott) should bring her (Marsham) to some thought of the truth. It was all very sweet, that dancing with her (Marsham), as they used to dance, without any question as to the reason why it was so; that sudden falling into the old habits, as though everything between this night and the former nights had been a dream; but this would not further his (Bott) views. The opportunity had come to him (Bott) which he (Bott) must use, if he (Bott) intended ever to use such opportunity. There was the two hundred pounds in his (Bott) pocket, which he (Bott) did not intend to give back.

``Does it put you in mind of `old days?''' (he)
he (Bott) said.

The words roused her (Marsham) from her (Marsham) sleep at once, and dissipated her (Marsham) dream. The facts all rushed upon her (Marsham) in an instant; the letter in her (Marsham) pocket; the request which she (Marsham) had made to Alice, that Alice might be induced to guard her (Alice) from this danger; the words which her (Alice) husband had spoken to her (Alice) in the morning, and her (Alice) anger against him (husband) in that he (husband) had subjected her (Alice) to the eyes of a Mrs. Marsham; her (Marsham) own unsettled mind--quite unsettled whether it would be best for her (Marsham) to go or to stay! It all came upon her (Marsham) now at the first word of tenderness which Burgo spoke to her (Marsham).

It has often been said of woman that she (woman) who doubts is lost,--so often that they who say it now, say it simply because others have said it before them, never thinking whether or no there be any truth in the proverb. But they who have said so, thinking of their words as they were uttered, have known but little of women. Women doubt every day, who solve their doubts at last on the right side, driven to do so, some by fear, more by conscience, but most of them by that half-prudential, half-unconscious knowledge of what is fitting, useful, and best under the cirumstances, which rarely deserts either men or women till they have brought themselves to the Burgo Fitzgerald state of recklessness. Men when they have fallen even to that, will still keep up some outward show towards the world; but women in this condition defy the world, and declare themselves to be children of perdition. Lady Glencora was doubting sorely; but, though doubting, she (Glencora) was not as yet lost.

``Does it put you in mind of old days?'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo.

She (Glencora) was driven to answer, and she (Glencora) knew that much would be decided by the way in which she (Glencora) might now speak.

``You must not talk of that,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said, very softly.

``May I not?'' (he)
And now his (Burgo) tongue was unloosed, so that he (Burgo) began to speak quickly.
``May I not? And why not? They were happy days,--so happy! Were not you happy when you thought--? Ah, dear! I suppose it is best not even to think of them?'' (unknown)

``Much the best.'' (unknown)

``Only it is impossible. I wish I knew the inside of your heart, Cora, so that I could see what it is that you really wish.'' (he)

In the old days he (Burgo) had always called her (Glencora) Cora, and now the name came from his (Burgo) lips upon her (Glencora) ears as a thing of custom, causing no surprise. They were standing back, behind the circle, almost in a corner, and Burgo knew well how to speak at such moments so that his (Burgo) words should be audible to none but her (Glencora) whom he (Burgo) addressed.

``You should not have come to me at all,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said.

``And why not? Who has a better right to come to you? Who has ever loved you as I have done? Cora, did you get my letter?'' (unknown)

``Come and dance,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said;
``I see a pair of eyes looking at us.'' (she)
The pair of eyes which Lady Glencora saw were in the possession of Mr. Bott, who was standing alone, leaning against the side of the doorway, every now and then raising his (Bott) heels from the ground, so that he (Bott) might look down upon the sinners as from a vantage ground. He (Bott) was quite alone. Mrs. Marsham had left him (Bott), and had gotten herself away in Lady Glencora's own carriage to Park Lane, in order that she (Glencora) might find Mr. Palliser there, if by chance he (Palliser) should be at home.

``Won't it be making mischief?'' (Mrs. Marsham)
Mrs. Marsham had said when Mr. Bott had suggested this line of conduct.

``There'll be worse mischief if you don't,'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
Mr. Bott had answered.
``He (Cora) can come back, and then he (Cora) can do as he (Cora) likes. I'll keep my eyes upon them.'' (he)
And so he (Bott) did keep his (Bott) eyes upon them.

Again they went round the room,--or that small portion of the room which the invading crowd had left to the dancers,--as though they were enjoying themselves thoroughly, and in all innocence. But there were others besides Mr. Bott who looked on and wondered. The Duchess of St. Bungay saw it, and shook her (Duchess) head sorrowing,--for the Duchess was good at heart. Mrs. Conway Sparkes saw it, and drank it down with keen appetite,--as a thirsty man with a longing for wine will drink champagne,--for Mrs. Conway Sparkes was not good at heart. Lady Hartletop saw it, and just raised her (Hartletop) eyebrows. It was nothing to her (Hartletop). She (Hartletop) liked to know what was going on, as such knowledge was sometimes useful; but, as for heart,--what she (Hartletop) had was, in such a matter, neither good nor bad. Her (Hartletop) blood circulated with its ordinary precision, and, in that respect, no woman ever had a better heart. Lady Monk saw it, and a frown gathered on her (Monk) brow.

``The fool!'' (she)
she (Monk) said to herself. She (Monk) knew that Burgo would not help his (Burgo) success by drawing down the eyes of all her (Monk) guests upon his (Burgo) attempt. In the meantime Mr. Bott stood there, mounting still higher on his (Bott) toes, straightening his (Bott) back against the wall.

``Did you get my letter?'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
Burgo said again, as soon as a moment's pause gave him (Burgo) breath to speak. She (Monk) did not answer him (Burgo). Perhaps her (Monk) breath did not return to her (Monk) as rapidly as his (Burgo). But, of course, he (Burgo) knew that she (Monk) had received it. She (Monk) would have quickly signified to him (Burgo) that no letter from him (Burgo) had come to her (Monk) hands had it not reached her (Monk).
``Let us go out upon the stairs,'' (he)
he (Burgo) said,
``for I must speak to you. Oh, if you could know what I suffered when you did not come to Monkshade! Why did you not come?'' (he)

``I wish I had not come here,'' (she)
she (Monk) said.

``Because you have seen me? That, at any rate, is not kind of you.'' (unknown)

They were now making their way slowly down the stairs, in the crowd, towards the supper-room. All the world was now intent on food and drink, and they were only doing as others did. Lady Glencora was not thinking where she (Glencora) went, but, glancing upwards, as she (Glencora) stood for a moment wedged upon the stairs, her (Glencora) eyes met those of Mr. Bott.

``A man that can treat me like that deserves that I should leave him (man).'' (her)
That was the thought that crossed her (Glencora) mind at the moment.

``I'll get you some champagne with water in it,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo.
``I know that is what you like.'' (unknown)

``Do not get me anything,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said. They had now got into the room, and had therefore escaped Mr. Bott's eyes for the moment.
``Mr. Fitzgerald,'' (unknown)
--and now her (Glencora) words had become a whisper in his (Bott) ear,--
``do what I ask you. For the sake of the old days of which you spoke, the dear old days which can never come again--'' (unknown)

``By G--! they can,'' (he)
said he (Bott).
``They can come back, and they shall.'' (unknown)

``Never. But you can still do me a kindness. Go away, and leave me. Go to the sideboard, and then do not come back. You are doing me an injury while you remain with me.'' (unknown)

``Cora,'' (he)
he (Bott) said,

But she (Glencora) had now recovered her (Glencora) presence of mind, and understood what was going on. She (Glencora) was no longer in a dream, but words and things bore to her (Glencora) again their proper meaning.

``I will not have it, Mr. Fitzgerald,'' (she)
she (Glencora) answered, speaking almost passionately.
``I will not have it. Do as I bid you. Go and leave me, and do not return. I tell you that we are watched.'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
This was still true, for Mr. Bott had now again got his (Bott) eyes on them, round the supper-room door. Whatever was the reward for which he (Bott) was working, private secretaryship or what else, it must be owned that he (Bott) worked hard for it. But there are labours which are labours of love.

``Who is watching us?'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo;
``and what does it matter? If you are minded to do as I have asked you--'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)

``But I am not so minded. Do you not know that you insult me by proposing it?'' (unknown)

``Yes;--it is an insult, Cora,--unless such an offer be a joy to you. If you wish to be my wife instead of his (Cora), it is no insult.'' (unknown)

``How can I be that?'' (him)
Her (Glencora) face was not turned to him (Burgo), and her (Glencora) words were half-pronounced, and in the lowest whisper, but, nevertheless, he (Burgo) heard them.

``Come with me,--abroad, and you shall yet be my wife. You got my letter? Do what I asked you, then. Come with me--to-night.'' (unknown)

The pressing instance of the suggestion, the fixing of a present hour, startled her (Glencora) back to her (Glencora) propriety.

``Mr. Fitzgerald,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said,
``I asked you to go and leave me. If you do not do so, I must get up and leave you. It will be much more difficult.'' (she)

``And is that to be all?'' (unknown)

``All;--at any rate, now.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Oh, Glencora! how could you be so weak? Why did you add that word,
``now'' (unknown)
? In truth, she (Glencora) added it then, at that moment, simply feeling that she (Glencora) could thus best secure an immediate compliance with her (Glencora) request.

``I will not go,'' (he)
he (Burgo) said, looking at her (Glencora) sternly, and leaning before her (Glencora), with earnest face, with utter indifference as to the eyes of any that might see them.
``I will not go till you tell me that you will see me again.'' (unknown)

``I will,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said in that low, all-but-unuttered whisper.

``When,--when,--when?'' (he)
he (Burgo) asked.

Looking up again towards the doorway, in fear of Mr. Bott's eyes, she (Glencora) saw the face of Mr. Palliser as he (Palliser) entered the room. Mr. Bott had also seen him (Bott), and had tried to clutch him (Bott) by the arm; but Mr. Palliser had shaken him (Palliser) off, apparently with indifference,--had got rid of him (Palliser), as it were, without noticing him (Palliser). Lady Glencora, when she (Glencora) saw her (Glencora) husband, immediately recovered her (Glencora) courage. She (Glencora) would not cower before him (husband), or show herself ashamed of what she (Glencora) had done. For the matter of that, if he (husband) pressed her (Glencora) on the subject, she (Glencora) could bring herself to tell him (husband) that she (Glencora) loved Burgo Fitzgerald much more easily than she (Glencora) could whisper such a word to Burgo himself. Mr. Bott's eyes were odious to her (Glencora) as they watched her (Glencora); but her (Glencora) husband's glance she (Glencora) could meet without quailing before it.

``Here is Mr. Palliser,'' (she)
said she (Glencora), speaking again in her (Glencora) ordinary clear-toned voice. Burgo immediately rose from his (Burgo) seat with a start, and turned quickly towards the door; but Lady Glencora kept her (Glencora) chair.

Mr. Palliser made his (Palliser) way as best he (Palliser) could through the crowd up to his (Palliser) wife. He (Palliser), too, kept his (Palliser) countenance without betraying his (Palliser) secret. There was neither anger nor dismay in his (Palliser) face, nor was there any untoward hurry in his (Palliser) movement. Burgo stood aside as he (Burgo) came up, and Lady Glencora was the first to speak.

``I thought you were gone home hours ago,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said.

``I did go home,'' (he)
he (Burgo) answered,
``but I thought I might as well come back for you.'' (he)

``What a model of a husband! Well; I am ready. Only, what shall we do about Jane? Mr. Fitzgerald, I left a scarf in your aunt's room,--a little black and yellow scarf,--would you mind getting it for me?'' (unknown)

``I will fetch it,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser;
``and I will tell your cousin that the carriage shall come back for her (aunt).'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

``If you will allow me--'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo.

``I will do it,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser; and away he (Palliser) went, making his (Palliser) slow progress up through the crowd, ordering his (Palliser) carriage as he (Palliser) passed through the hall, and leaving Mr. Bott still watching at the door.

Lady Glencora resolved that she (Glencora) would say nothing to Burgo while her (Glencora) husband was gone. There was a touch of chivalry in his (husband) leaving them again together, which so far conquered her (Glencora). He (husband) might have bade her (Glencora) leave the scarf, and come at once. She (Glencora) had seen, moreover, that he (husband) had not spoken to Mr. Bott, and was thankful to him (Bott) also for that. Burgo also seemed to have become aware that his (Burgo) chance for that time was over.

``I will say good-night,'' (he)
he (Burgo) said.
``Good-night, Mr. Fitzgerald,'' (she)
she (Glencora) answered, giving him (Burgo) her (Glencora) hand. He (Burgo) pressed it for a moment, and then turned and went. When Mr. Palliser came back he (Palliser) was no more to be seen.

Lady Glencora was at the dining-room door when her (Glencora) husband returned, standing close to Mr. Bott. Mr. Bott had spoken to her (Glencora), but she (Glencora) made no reply. He (Bott) spoke again, but her (Glencora) face remained as immovable as though she (Glencora) had been deaf.

``And what shall we do about Mrs. Marsham?'' (she)
she (Glencora) said, quite out loud, as soon as she (Glencora) put her (Glencora) hand on her (Glencora) husband's arm.
``I had forgotten her (Marsham).'' (unknown)

``Mrs. Marsham has gone home,'' (he)
he (husband) replied.

``Have you seen her (Marsham)?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``When did you see her (Marsham)?'' (unknown)

``She (Marsham) came to Park Lane.'' (unknown)

``What made her (Marsham) do that?'' (he)

These questions were asked and answered as he (husband) was putting her (Glencora) into the carriage. She (Glencora) got in just as she (Glencora) asked the last, and he (husband), as he (husband) took his (husband) seat, did not find it necessary to answer it. But that would not serve her (Glencora) turn.

``What made Mrs. Marsham go to you at Park Lane after she (Marsham) left Lady Monk's?'' (she)
she (Glencora) asked again. Mr. Palliser sat silent, not having made up his (Palliser) mind what he (Palliser) would say on the subject.
``I suppose she (Marsham) went,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
continued Lady Glencora,
``to tell you that I was dancing with Mr. Fitzgerald. Was that it?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``I think, Glencora, we had better not discuss it now.'' (unknown)

``I don't mean to discuss it now, or ever. If you did not wish me to see Mr. Fitzgerald you should not have sent me to Lady Monk's. But, Plantagenet, I hope you will forgive me if I say that no consideration shall induce me to receive again as a guest, in my own house, either Mrs. Marsham or Mr. Bott.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

Mr. Palliser absolutely declined to say anything on the subject on that occasion, and the evening of Lady Monk's party in this way came to an end.

CHAPTER LI.

Bold Speculations on Murder.

George Vavasor was not in a very happy mood when he (Vavasor) left Queen Anne Street, after having flung his (Vavasor) gift ring under the grate. Indeed there was much in his (Vavasor) condition, as connected with the house which he (Vavasor) was leaving, which could not but make him (Vavasor) unhappy. Alice was engaged to be his (Vavasor) wife, and had as yet said nothing to show that she (Alice) meditated any breach of that engagement, but she (Alice) had treated him (Vavasor) in a way which made him (Vavasor) long to throw her (Alice) promise in her (Alice) teeth. He (Vavasor) was a man to whom any personal slight from a woman was unendurable. To slights from men, unless they were of a nature to provoke offence, he (Vavasor) was indifferent. There was no man living for whose liking or disliking George Vavasor cared anything. But he (Vavasor) did care much for the good opinion, or rather for the personal favour, of any woman to whom he (Vavasor) had endeavoured to make himself agreeable.

``I will marry you,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice had said to him (Vavasor),--not in words, but in acts and looks, which were plainer than words,--
``I will marry you for certain reasons of my own, which in my present condition make it seem that that arrangement will be more convenient to me than any other that I can make; but pray understand that there is no love mixed up with this. There is another man whom I love;--only, for those reasons above hinted, I do not care to marry him (man).'' (him)
It was thus that he (Vavasor) read Alice's present treatment of him (Vavasor), and he (Vavasor) was a man who could not endure this treatment with ease.

But though he (Vavasor) could throw his (Vavasor) ring under the grate in his (Vavasor) passion, he (Vavasor) could not so dispose of her (Alice). That he (Vavasor) would have done so had his (Vavasor) hands been free, we need not doubt. And he (Vavasor) would have been clever enough to do so in some manner that would have been exquisitely painful to Alice, willing as she (Alice) might be to be released from her (Alice) engagement. But he (Vavasor) could not do this to a woman whose money he (Vavasor) had borrowed, and whose money he (Vavasor) could not repay;--to a woman, more of whose money he (Vavasor) intended to borrow immediately. As to that latter part of it, he (Vavasor) did say to himself over and over again, that he (Vavasor) would have no more of it. As he (Vavasor) left the house in Queen Anne Street, on that occasion, he (Vavasor) swore, that under no circumstances would he (Vavasor) be indebted to her (Queen) for another shilling. But before he (Vavasor) had reached Great Marlborough Street, to which his (Vavasor) steps took him (Vavasor), he (Vavasor) had reminded himself that everything depended on a further advance. He (Vavasor) was in Parliament, but Parliament would be dissolved within three months. Having sacrificed so much for his (Vavasor) position, should he (Vavasor) let it all fall from him (Vavasor) now,--now, when success seemed to be within his (Vavasor) reach? That wretched old man in Westmoreland, who seemed gifted almost with immortality,--why could he (Vavasor) not die and surrender his (Vavasor) paltry acres to one who could use them? He (Vavasor) turned away from Regent Street into Hanover Square before he (Vavasor) crossed to Great Marlborough Street, giving vent to his (Vavasor) passion rather than arranging his (Vavasor) thoughts. As he (Vavasor) walked the four sides of the square he (Vavasor) considered how good it would be if some accident should befall the old man. How he (man) would rejoice were he (man) to hear to-morrow that one of the trees of the

``accursed place,'' (he)
had fallen on the
``obstinate old idiot,'' (he)
and put an end to him (man)! I will not say that he (man) meditated the murder of his (man) grandfather. There was a firm conviction on his (man) mind, as he (man) thought of all this, that such a deed as that would never come in his (man) way. But he (man) told himself, that if he (man) chose to make the attempt, he (man) would certainly be able to carry it through without detection. Then he (man) remembered Rush and Palmer--the openly bold murderer and the secret poisoner. Both of them, in Vavasor's estimation, were great men. He (man) had often said so in company. He (man) had declared that the courage of Rush had never been surpassed.
``Think of him (idiot),'' (he)
he (man) would say with admiration,
``walking into a man's house, with pistols sufficient to shoot every one there, and doing it as though he (man) were killing rats! What was Nelson at Trafalgar to that? Nelson had nothing to fear!'' (he)
And of Palmer he (Palmer) declared that he (Palmer) was a man of genius as well as courage. He (Palmer) had
``looked the whole thing in the face,'' (He)
Vavasor would say,
``and told himself that all scruples and squeamishness are bosh,--child's tales. And so they are. Who lives as though they fear either heaven or hell? And if we do live without such fear or respect, what is the use of telling lies to ourselves? To throw it all to the dogs, as Palmer did, is more manly.'' (He)
``And be hanged,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
some hearer of George's doctrine replied.
``Yes, and be hanged,--if such is your destiny. But you hear of the one who is hanged, but hear nothing of the twenty who are not.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Vavasor walked round Hanover Square, nursing his (George) hatred against the old Squire. He (George) did not tell himself that he (George) would like to murder his (George) grandfather. But he (George) suggested to himself, that if he (George) desired to do so, he (George) would have courage enough to make his (George) way into the old man's room, and strangle him (George); and he (George) explained to himself how he (George) would be able to get down into Westmoreland without the world knowing that he (George) had been there,--how he (George) would find an entrance into the house by a window with which he (George) was acquainted,--how he (George) could cause the man to die as though, those around him (George) should think, it was apoplexy,--he (George), George Vavasor, having read something on that subject lately. All this he (Vavasor) considered very fully, walking rapidly round Hanover Square more than once or twice. If he (Vavasor) were to become an active student in the Rush or Palmer school, he (Palmer) would so study the matter that he (Palmer) would not be the one that should be hung. He (Palmer) thought that he (Palmer) could, so far, trust his (Palmer) own ingenuity. But yet he (Palmer) did not meditate murder.

``Beastly old idiot!'' (he)
he (Palmer) said to himself,
``he (idiot) must have his (idiot) chance as other men have, I suppose,'' (he)
And then he (Palmer) went across Regent Street to Mr. Scruby's office in Great Marlborough Street, not having, as yet, come to any positive conclusion as to what he (Great) would do in reference to Alice's money.

But he (Great) soon found himself talking to Mr. Scruby as though there were no doubts as to the forthcoming funds for the next elections. And Mr. Scruby talked to him (Scruby) very plainly, as though those funds must be forthcoming before long.

``A stitch in time saves nine,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby, meaning to insinuate that a pound in time might have the same effect.
``And I'll tell you what, Mr. Vavasor,--of course I've my outstanding bills for the last affair. That's no fault of yours, for the things came so sharp one on another that my fellows haven't had time to make it out. But if you'll put me in funds for what I must be out of pocket in June--'' (unknown)

``Will it be so soon as June?'' (unknown)

``They are talking of June. Why, then, I'll lump the two bills together when it's all over.'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)

In their discussion respecting money Mr. Scruby injudiciously mentioned the name of Mr. Tombe. No precise caution had been given to him (Tombe), but he (Tombe) had become aware that the matter was being managed through an agency that was not recognized by his (Tombe) client; and as that agency was simply a vehicle of money which found its way into Mr. Scruby's pocket, he (Scruby) should have held his (Scruby) tongue. But Mr. Tombe's name escaped from him (Scruby), and Vavasor immediately questioned him (Scruby). Scruby, who did not often make such blunders, readily excused himself, shaking his (Scruby) head, and declaring that the name had fallen from his (Scruby) lips instead of that of another man. Vavasor accepted the excuse without further notice, and nothing more was said about Mr. Tombe while he (Tombe) was in Mr. Scruby's office. But he (Scruby) had not heard the name in vain, and had unfortunately heard it before. Mr. Tombe was a remarkable man in his (Tombe) way. He (Tombe) wore powder to his (Tombe) hair,--was very polite in his (Tombe) bearing,--was somewhat asthmatic, and wheezed in his (Tombe) talking,--and was, moreover, the most obedient of men, though it was said of him (Tombe) that he (Tombe) managed the whole income of the Ely Chapter just as he (Tombe) pleased. Being in these ways a man of note, John Grey had spoken of him (Grey) to Alice, and his (Grey) name had filtered through Alice and her (Alice) cousin Kate to George Vavasor. George seldom forgot things or names, and when he (George) heard Mr. Tombe's name mentioned in connection with his (Tombe) own money matters, he (Tombe) remembered that Mr. Tombe was John Grey's lawyer.

As soon as he (Tombe) could escape out into the street he (Tombe) endeavoured to put all these things together, and after a while resolved that he (Tombe) would go to Mr. Tombe. What if there should be an understanding between John Grey and Alice, and Mr. Tombe should be arranging his (Tombe) money matters for him (Tombe)! Would not anything be better than this,--even that little tragedy down in Westmoreland, for which his (Tombe) ingenuity and courage would be required? He (Tombe) could endure to borrow money from Alice. He (Tombe) might even endure it still,--though that was very difficult after her (Alice) treatment of him (Tombe); but he (Tombe) could not endure to be the recipient of John Grey's money. By heavens, no! And as he (Grey) got into a cab, and had himself driven off to the neighbourhood of Doctors' Commons, he (Grey) gave himself credit for much fine manly feeling. Mr. Tombe's chambers were found without difficulty, and, as it happened, Mr. Tombe was there.

The lawyer rose from his (Tombe) chair as Vavasor entered, and bowed his (Tombe) powdered head very meekly as he (Tombe) asked his (Tombe) visitor to sit down.

``Mr. Vavasor;--oh, yes. He (Vavasor) had heard the name. Yes; he (Vavasor) was in the habit of acting for his (Vavasor) very old friend Mr. John Grey. He (Grey) had acted for Mr. John Grey, and for Mr. John Grey's father,--he (Grey) or his (Grey) partner,--he (Grey) believed he (Grey) might say, for about half a century. There could not be a nicer gentleman than Mr. John Grey;--and such a pretty child as he (Grey) used to be!'' (Mr. Tombe)
At every new sentence Mr. Tombe caught his (Tombe) poor asthmatic breath, and bowed his (Tombe) meek old head, and rubbed his (Tombe) hands together as though he (Tombe) hardly dared to keep his (Tombe) seat in Vavasor's presence without the support of some such motion; and wheezed apologetically, and seemed to ask pardon of his (Tombe) visitor for not knowing intuitively what was the nature of that visitor's business. But he (Tombe) was a sly old fox was Mr. Tombe, and was considering all this time how much it would be well that he (Tombe) should tell Mr. Vavasor, and how much it would be well that he (Vavasor) should conceal.
``The fat had got into the fire,'' (he)
as he (Vavasor) told his (Vavasor) old wife when he (Vavasor) got home that evening. He (Vavasor) told his (Vavasor) old wife everything, and I don't know that any of his (Vavasor) clients were the worse for his (Vavasor) doing so. But while he (Vavasor) was wheezing, and coughing, and apologizing, he (Vavasor) made up his (Vavasor) mind that if George Vavasor were to ask him (Vavasor) certain questions, it would be best that he (Vavasor) should answer them truly. If Vavasor did ask those questions, he (Vavasor) would probably do so upon certain knowledge, and if so, why, in that case, lying would be of no use. Lying would not put the fat back into the frying pan. And even though such questions might be asked without any absolute knowledge, they would, at any rate, show that the questioner had the means of ascertaining the truth. He (questioner) would tell as little as he (questioner) could; but he (questioner) decided during his (questioner) last wheeze, that he (questioner) could not lie in the matter with any chance of benefiting his (questioner) client.
``The prettiest child I ever saw, Mr. Vavasor!'' (Mr. Tombe)
said Mr. Tombe, and then he (Tombe) coughed violently. Some people who knew Mr. Tombe declared that he (Tombe) nursed his (Tombe) cough.

``I dare say,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``Yes, indeed,--ugh--ugh--ugh.'' (unknown)

``Can you tell me, Mr. Tombe, whether either you or he (Tombe) have anything to do with the payment of certain sums to my credit at Messrs. Hock and Block's?'' (unknown)

``Messrs. Hock and Block's, the bankers,--in Lom--bard Street?'' (Mr. Tombe)
said Mr. Tombe, taking a little more time.

``Yes; I bank there,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor, sharply.

``A most respectable house.'' (unknown)

``Has any money been paid there to my credit, by you, Mr. Tombe?'' (unknown)

``May I ask you why you put the question to me, Mr. Vavasor?'' (unknown)

``Well, I don't think you may. That is to say, my reason for asking it can have nothing to do with yours for replying to it. If you have had no hand in any such payment, there is an end of it, and I need not take up your time by saying anything more on the subject.'' (unknown)

``I am not prepared to go that length, Mr. Vavasor,--not altogether to go that length,--ugh--ugh--ugh.'' (unknown)

``Then, will you tell me what you have done in the matter?'' (unknown)

``Well,--upon my word, you've taken me a little by surprise. Let me see. Pinkle,--Pinkle.'' (Pinkle)
Pinkle was a clerk who sat in an inner room, and Mr. Tombe's effort to call him (Tombe) seemed to be most ineffectual. But Pinkle understood the sound, and came.
``Pinkle, didn't we pay some money into Hock and Block's a few weeks since, to the credit of Mr. George Vavasor?'' (unknown)

``Did we, sir?'' (Pinkle)
said Pinkle, who probably knew that his (Tombe) employer was an old fox, and who, perhaps, had caught something of the fox nature himself.

``I think we did. Just look Pinkle;--and, Pinkle,--see the date, and let me know all about it. It's fine bright weather for this time of year, Mr. Vavasor; but these easterly winds!--ugh--ugh--ugh!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Vavasor found himself sitting for an apparently interminable number of minutes in Mr. Tombe's dingy chamber, and was coughed at, and wheezed at, till he (Tombe) begun to be tired of his (Tombe) position; moreover, when tired, he (Tombe) showed his (Tombe) impatience.

``Perhaps you'll let us write you a line when we have looked into the matter?'' (Mr. Tombe)
suggested Mr. Tombe.

``I'd rather know at once,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor.
``I don't suppose it can take you very long to find out whether you have paid money to my account, by order of Mr. Grey. At any rate, I must know before I go away.'' (unknown)

``Pinkle, Pinkle!'' (the man)
screamed the old man through his (Tombe) coughing; and again Pinkle came.
``Well, Pinkle, was anything of the kind done, or is my memory deceiving me?'' (Mr. Tombe)
Mr. Tombe was, no doubt, lying shamefully, for, of course, he (Tombe) remembered all about it; and, indeed, George Vavasor had learned already quite enough for his (Vavasor) own purposes.

``I was going to look,'' (Pinkle)
said Pinkle; and Pinkle again went away.

``I'm sorry to give your clerk so much trouble,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor, in an angry voice;
``and I think it must be unnecessary. Surely you know whether Mr. Grey has commissioned you to pay money for me?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``We have so many things to do, Mr. Vavasor; and so many clients. We have, indeed. You see, it isn't only one gentleman's affairs. But I think there was something done. I do, indeed.'' (unknown)

``What is Mr. John Grey's address?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
asked Vavasor, very sharply.

``Number 5, Suffolk Street, Pall Mall East,'' (Mr. Tombe)
said Mr. Tombe. Herein Mr. Tombe somewhat committed himself. His (Tombe) client, Mr. Grey, was, in fact, in town, but Vavasor had not known or imagined that such was the case. Had Mr. Tombe given the usual address of Nethercoats, nothing further would have been demanded from him (Tombe) on that subject. But he (Tombe) had foolishly presumed that the question had been based on special information as to his (Tombe) client's visit to London, and he (Tombe) had told the plain truth in a very simple way.

``Number 5, Suffolk Street,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor, writing down the address.
``Perhaps it will be better that I should go to him (Grey), as you do not seem inclined to give me any information.'' (he)
Then he (Tombe) took up his (Tombe) hat, and hardly bowing to Mr. Tombe, left the chambers. Mr. Tombe, as he (Tombe) did so, rose from his (Tombe) chair, and bent his (Tombe) head meekly down upon the table.

``Pinkle, Pinkle,'' (Mr. Tombe)
wheezed Mr. Tombe.
``Never mind; never mind.'' (Pinkle)
Pinkle didn't mind; and we may say that he (Tombe) had not minded; for up to that moment he (Tombe) had taken no steps towards a performance of the order which had been given him (Tombe).

CHAPTER LII.

What Occurred in Suffolk Street, Pall Mall.

Mr. Tombe had gained nothing for the cause by his (Tombe) crafty silence. George Vavasor felt perfectly certain, as he (Vavasor) walked out from the little street which runs at the back of Doctors' Commons, that the money which he (Vavasor) had been using had come, in some shape, through the hands of John Grey. He (Grey) did not care much to calculate whether the payments had been made from the personal funds of his (Grey) rival, or whether that rival had been employed to dispense Alice's fortune. Under either view of the case his (Grey) position was sufficiently bitter. The truth never for a moment occurred to him (Grey). He (Grey) never dreamed that there might be a conspiracy in the matter, of which Alice was as ignorant as he (Grey) himself had been. He (Grey) never reflected that his (Grey) uncle John, together with John, the lover, whom he (John) so hated, might be the conspirators. To him (John) it seemed to be certain that Alice and Mr. Grey were in league;--and if they were in league, what must he (Grey) think of Alice, and of her (Alice) engagement with himself!

There are men who rarely think well of women,--who hardly think well of any woman. They put their mothers and sisters into the background,--as though they belonged to some sex or race apart,--and then declare to themselves and to their friends that all women are false,--that no woman can be trusted unless her (woman) ugliness protect her (woman); and that every woman may be attacked as fairly as may game in a cover, or deer on a mountain, What man does not know men who have so thought? I cannot say that such had been Vavasor's creed,--not entirely such. There had been periods of his (man) life when he (man) had believed implicitly in his (man) cousin Alice;--but then there had been other moments in which he (man) had ridiculed himself for his (man) Quixotism in believing in any woman. And as he (man) had grown older the moments of his (man) Quixotism had become more rare. There would have been no such Quixotism left with him (man) now, had not the various circumstances which I have attempted to describe, filled him (man), during the last twelve months, with a renewed desire to marry his (man) cousin. Every man tries to believe in the honesty of his (man) future wife; and, therefore, Vavasor had tried, and had in his (man) way, believed. He (man) had flattered himself, too, that Alice's heart had, in truth, been more prone to him (man) than to that other suitor. Grey, as he (Grey) thought, had been accepted by her (Alice) cold prudence; but he (Grey) thought, also, that she (Alice) had found her (Alice) prudence to be too cold, and had therefore returned where she (Alice) had truly loved. Vavasor, though he (Grey) did not love much himself, was willing enough to be the object of love.

This idea of his (Grey), however, had been greatly shaken by Alice's treatment of himself personally; but still he (Grey) had not, hitherto, believed that she (Alice) was false to him (Grey). Now, what could he (Grey) believe of her (Alice)? What was there within the compass of such a one to believe? As he (Grey) walked out into St. Paul's Churchyard he (Grey) called her (Alice) by every name which is most offensive to a woman's ears. He (Grey) hated her (Alice) at this moment with even a more bitter hatred than that which he (Grey) felt towards John Grey. She (Alice) must have deceived him (Grey) with unparalleled hypocrisy, and lied to him (Grey) and to his (Grey) sister Kate as hardly any woman had ever lied before. Or could it be that Kate, also, was lying to him (Grey)? If so, Kate also should be included in the punishment.

But why should they have conspired to feed him (Grey) with these moneys? There had been no deceit, at any rate, in reference to the pounds sterling which Scruby had already swallowed. They had been supplied, whatever had been the motives of the suppliers; and he (Scruby) had no doubt that more would be supplied if he (Scruby) would only keep himself quiet. He (Scruby) was still walking westward as he (Scruby) thought of this, down Ludgate Hill, on his (Scruby) direct line towards Suffolk Street; and he (Scruby) tried to persuade himself that it would be well that he (Scruby) should hide his (Scruby) wrath till after provision should have been made for this other election. They were his (Scruby) enemies,--Alice and Mr. Grey,--and why should he (Grey) keep any terms with his (Grey) enemies? It was still a trouble to him (Grey) to think that he (Grey) should have been in any way beholden to John Grey; but the terrible thing had been done, the evil had occurred. What would he (Grey) gain by staying his (Grey) hand now? Still, however, he (Grey) walked on quickly along Fleet Street, and along the Strand, and was already crossing under the Picture Galleries towards Pall Mall East before he (Grey) had definitely decided what steps he (Grey) would take on this very day. Exactly at the corner of Suffolk Street he (Grey) met John Grey.

``Mr. Grey,'' (he)
he (Grey) said, stopping himself suddenly,
``I was this moment going to call on you at your lodgings.'' (he)

``At my lodgings, were you? Shall I return with you?'' (unknown)

``If you please,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor, leading the way up Suffolk Street. There had been no other greeting than this between them. Mr. Grey himself, though a man very courteous in his (Grey) general demeanour, would probably have passed Vavasor in the street with no more than the barest salutation. Situated as they were towards each other there could hardly be any show of friendship between them; but when Vavasor had spoken to him (Grey), he (Grey) had dressed his (Grey) face in that guise of civility which men always use who do not intend to be offensive;--but Vavasor dressed his (Grey) as men dress theirs who do mean to be offensive; and Mr. Grey had thoroughly appreciated the dressing.

``If you will allow me, I have the key,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey. Then they both entered the house, and Vavasor followed his (Grey) host up-stairs. Mr. Grey, as he (Grey) went up, felt almost angry with himself in having admitted his (Grey) enemy into his (Grey) lodgings. He (Grey) was sure that no good could come of it, and remembered, when it was too late, that he (Grey) might easily have saved himself from giving the invitation while he (Grey) was still in the street. There they were, however, together in the sitting-room, and Grey had nothing to do but to listen.
``Will you take a chair, Mr. Vavasor?'' (he)
he (Grey) said.
``No,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor;
``I will stand up.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
And he (Grey) stood up, holding his (Grey) hat behind his (Grey) back with his (Grey) left hand, with his (Grey) right leg forward, and the thumb of his (Grey) right hand in his (Grey) waistcoat-pocket. He (Grey) looked full into Grey's face, and Grey looked full into his (Grey); and as he (Grey) looked the great cicatrice seemed to open itself and to become purple with fresh blood stains.

``I have come here from Mr. Tombe's office in the City,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor,
``to ask you of what nature has been the interference which you have taken in my money matters?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

This was a question which Mr. Grey could not answer very quickly. In the first place it was altogether unexpected; in the next place he (Grey) did not know what Mr. Tombe had told, and what he (Tombe) had not told; and then, before he (Tombe) replied, he (Tombe) must think how much of the truth he (Tombe) was bound to tell in answer to a question so put to him (Tombe).

``Do you say that you have come from Mr. Tombe?'' (he)
he (Tombe) asked.

``I think you heard me say so. I have come here direct from Mr. Tombe's chambers. He (Tombe) is your lawyer, I believe?'' (unknown)

``He (Tombe) is so.'' (unknown)

``And I have come from him (Tombe) to ask you what interference you have lately taken in my money matters. When you have answered that, I shall have other questions to ask you.'' (unknown)

``But, Mr. Vavasor, has it occurred to you that I may not be disposed to answer questions so asked?'' (unknown)

``It has not occurred to me to think that you will prevaricate. If there has been no such interference, I will ask your pardon, and go away; but if there has been such interference on your part, I have a right to demand that you shall explain to me its nature.'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)

Grey had now made up his (Grey) mind that it would be better that he (Grey) should tell the whole story,--better not only for himself, but for all the Vavasors, including this angry man himself. The angry man evidently knew something, and it would be better that he (man) should know the truth.

``There has been such interference, Mr. Vavasor, if you choose to call it so. Money, to the extent of two thousand pounds, I think, has by my directions been paid to your credit by Mr. Tombe.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor, taking his (man) right hand away from his (man) waistcoat, and tapping the round table with his (man) fingers impatiently.

``I hardly know how to explain all the circumstances under which this has been done.'' (unknown)

``I dare say not; but, nevertheless, you must explain them.'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)

Grey was a man tranquil in temperament, very little prone to quarrelling, with perhaps an exaggerated idea of the evil results of a row,--a man who would take infinite trouble to avoid any such scene as that which now seemed to be imminent; but he (man) was a man whose courage was quite as high as that of his (man) opponent. To bully or be bullied were alike contrary to his (man) nature.
