It was clear enough now that Vavasor intended to bully him (man), and he (man) made up his (man) mind at once that if the quarrel were forced upon him (man) it should find him (man) ready to take his (man) own part.

``My difficulty in explaining it comes from consideration for you,'' (he)
he (man) said.

``Then I beg that your difficulty will cease, and that you will have no consideration for me. We are so circumstanced towards each other that any consideration must be humbug and nonsense. At any rate, I intend to have none for you. Now, let me know why you have meddled with my matters.'' (unknown)

``I think I might, perhaps, better refer you to your uncle.'' (unknown)

``No, sir; Mr. Tombe is not my uncle's lawyer. My uncle never heard his (uncle) name, unless he (uncle) heard of it from you.'' (unknown)

``But it was by agreement with your uncle that I commissioned Mr. Tombe to raise for you the money you were desirous of borrowing from your cousin. We thought it better that her (uncle) fortune should not be for the moment disturbed.'' (unknown)

``But what had you to do with it? Why should you have done it? In the first place, I don't believe your story; it is altogether improbable. But why should he (Tombe) come to you of all men to raise money on his (Tombe) daughter's behalf?'' (unknown)

``Unless you can behave yourself with more discretion, Mr. Vavasor, you must leave the room,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Mr. Grey. Then, as Vavasor simply sneered at him (Grey), but spoke nothing, he (Grey) went on.
``It was I who suggested to your uncle that this arrangement should be made. I did not wish to see Miss Vavasor's fortune squandered.'' (unknown)

``And what was her (daughter) fortune to you, sir? Are you aware that she (daughter) is engaged to me as my wife? I ask you, sir, whether you are aware that Miss Vavasor is to be my wife?'' (unknown)

``I must altogether decline to discuss with you Miss Vavasor's present or future position.'' (unknown)

``By heavens, then, you shall hear me discuss it! She (wife) was engaged to you, and she (wife) has given you your dismissal. If you had understood anything of the conduct which is usual among gentlemen, or if you had had any particle of pride in you, sir, you would have left her (wife) and never mentioned her (wife) name again. I now find you meddling with her (wife) money matters, so as to get a hold upon her (wife) fortune.'' (unknown)

``I have no hold upon her (wife) fortune.'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir, you have. You do not advance two thousand pounds without knowing that you have security. She (wife) has rejected you; and in order that you may be revenged, or that you may have some further hold upon her (wife),--that she (wife) may be in some sort within your power, you have contrived this rascally pettifogging way of obtaining power over her (wife) income. The money shall be repaid at once, with any interest that can be due; and if I find you interfering again, I will expose you.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Vavasor,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey very slowly, in a low tone of voice, but with something in his (Grey) eye which would have told any bystander that he (Grey) was much in earnest,
``you have used words in your anger which I cannot allow to pass. You must recall them.'' (he)

``What were the words? I said that you were a pettifogging rascal. I now repeat them.'' (he)
As he (Grey) spoke he (Grey) put on his (Grey) hat, so as to leave both his (Grey) hands ready for action if action should be required.

Grey was much the larger man and much the stronger. It may be doubted whether he (Grey) knew himself the extent of his (Grey) own strength, but such as it was he (Grey) resolved that he (Grey) must now use it.

``There is no help for it,'' (he)
he (Grey) said, as he (Grey) also prepared for action. The first thing he (Grey) did was to open the door, and as he (Grey) did so he (Grey) became conscious that his (Grey) mouth was full of blood from a sharp blow upon his (Grey) face. Vavasor had struck him (Grey) with his (Grey) fist, and had cut his (Grey) lip against his (Grey) teeth. Then there came a scramble, and Grey was soon aware that he (Grey) had his (Grey) opponent in his (Grey) hands. I doubt whether he (Grey) had attempted to strike a blow, or whether he (Grey) had so much as clenched his (Grey) fist. Vavasor had struck him (Grey) repeatedly, but the blows had fallen on his (Grey) body or his (Grey) head, and he (Grey) was unconscious of them. He (Grey) had but one object now in his (Grey) mind, and that object was the kicking his (Grey) assailant down the stairs. Then came a scramble, as I have said, and Grey had a hold of the smaller man by the nape of his (Grey) neck. So holding him (Grey) he (Grey) forced him (Grey) back through the door on to the landing, and there succeeded in pushing him (Grey) down the first flight of steps. Grey kicked at him (Grey) as he (Grey) went, but the kick was impotent. He (Grey) had, however, been so far successful that he (Grey) had thrust his (Grey) enemy out of the room, and had the satisfaction of seeing him (Grey) sprawling on the landing-place.

Vavasor, when he (Grey) raised himself, prepared to make another rush at the room, but before he (Grey) could do so a man from below, hearing the noise, had come upon him (Grey) and interrupted him (Grey).

``Mr. Jones,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey, speaking from above,
``if that gentleman does not leave the house, I must get you to search for a policeman.'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)

Vavasor, though the lodging-house man had hold of the collar of his (man) coat, made no attempt to turn upon his (man) new enemy. When two dogs are fighting, any bystander may attempt to separate them with impunity. The brutes are so anxious to tear each other that they have no energies left for other purposes. It never occurs to them to turn their teeth upon newcomers in the quarrel. So it was with George Vavasor. Jones was sufficient to prevent his (Jones) further attack upon the foe up-stairs, and therefore he (Jones) had no alternative but to relinquish the fight.

``What's it all about, sir?'' (Calder Jones/Jones)
said Jones, who kept a tailor's establishment, and, as a tailor, was something of a fighting man himself. Of all tradesmen in London the tailors are, no doubt, the most combative,--as might be expected from the necessity which lies upon them of living down the general bad character in this respect which the world has wrongly given them.
``What's it all about, sir?'' (Calder Jones/Jones)
said Jones, still holding Vavasor by his (Jones) coat.

``That man has ill-used me, and I've punished him (man); that's all.'' (unknown)

``I don't know much about punishing,'' (the tailor)
said the tailor.
``It seems to me he (man) pitched you down pretty clean out of the room above. I think the best thing you can do now is to walk yourself off.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

It was the only thing that Vavasor could do, and he (tailor) did walk himself off. He (tailor) walked himself off, and went home to his (tailor) own lodgings in Cecil Street, that he (tailor) might smooth his (tailor) feathers after the late encounter before he (tailor) went down to Westminster to take his (tailor) seat in the House of Commons. I do not think that he (tailor) was comfortable when he (tailor) got there, or that he (tailor) felt himself very well able to fight another battle that night on behalf of the River Bank. He (tailor) had not been hurt, but he (tailor) had been worsted. Grey had probably received more personal damage than had fallen to his (Grey) share; but Grey had succeeded in expelling him (Grey) from the room, and he (Grey) knew that he (Grey) had been found prostrate on the landing-place when the tailor first saw him (tailor).

But he (tailor) might probably have got over the annoyance of this feeling had he (tailor) not been overwhelmed by a consciousness that everything was going badly with him (tailor). He (tailor) was already beginning to hate his (tailor) seat in Parliament. What good had it done for him (tailor), or was it likely to do for him (tailor)? He (tailor) found himself to be associated there with Mr. Bott, and a few others of the same class,--men whom he (Bott) despised; and even they did not admit him (Bott) among them without a certain show of superiority on their part. Who has not ascertained by his (Bott) own experience the different lights through which the same events may be seen, according to the success, or want of success, which pervades the atmosphere at the moment? At the present time everything was unsuccessful with George Vavasor; and though he (Vavasor) told himself, almost from hour to hour, that he (Vavasor) would go on with the thing which he (Vavasor) had begun,--that he (Vavasor) would persevere in Parliament till he (Vavasor) had obtained a hearing there and created for himself success, he (Vavasor) could not himself believe in the promises which he (Vavasor) had made to himself. He (Vavasor) had looked forward to his (Vavasor) entrance into that Chamber as the hour of his (Vavasor) triumph; but he (Vavasor) had entered it with Mr. Bott, and there had been no triumph to him (Bott) in doing so. He (Bott) had sworn to himself that when there he (Bott) would find men to hear him (Bott). Hitherto, indeed, he (Bott) could not accuse himself of having missed his (Bott) opportunities; his (Bott) election had been so recent that he (Bott) could hardly yet have made the attempt. But he (Bott) had been there long enough to learn to fancy that there was no glory in attempting. This art of speaking in Parliament, which had appeared to him (Bott) to be so grand, seemed already to be a humdrum, homely, dull affair. No one seemed to listen much to what was said. To such as himself,--Members without an acquired name,--men did not seem to listen at all. Mr. Palliser had once, in his (Palliser) hearing, spoken for two hours together, and all the House had treated his (Palliser) speech with respect,--had declared that it was useful, solid, conscientious, and what not; but more than half the House had been asleep more than half the time that he (Palliser) was on his (Palliser) legs. Vavasor had not as yet commenced his (Palliser) career as an orator; but night after night, as he (Palliser) sat there, the chance of commencing it with brilliance seemed to be further from him (Palliser), and still further. Two thousand pounds of his (Palliser) own money, and two thousand more of Alice's money,--or of Mr. Grey's,--he (Grey) had already spent to make his (Grey) way into that assembly. He (Grey) must spend, at any rate, two thousand more if he (Grey) intended that his (Grey) career should be prolonged beyond a three months' sitting;--and how was he (Grey) to get this further sum after what had taken place to-day?

He (Grey) would get it. That was his (Grey) resolve as he (Grey) walked in by the apple-woman's stall, under the shadow of the great policeman, and between the two august lamps. He (policeman) would get it;--as long as Alice had a pound over which he (policeman) could obtain mastery by any act or violence within his (policeman) compass. He (policeman) would get it; even though it should come through the hands of John Grey and Mr. Tombe. He (Tombe) would get it; though in doing so he (Tombe) might destroy his (Tombe) cousin Alice and ruin his (Tombe) sister Kate. He (Tombe) had gone too far to stick at any scruples. Had he (Tombe) not often declared how great had been that murderer who had been able to divest himself of all such scruples,--who had scoured his (Tombe) bosom free from all fears of the hereafter, and, as regarded the present, had dared to trust for everything to success? He (Tombe) would go to Alice and demand the money from her (Alice) with threats, and with that violence in his (Tombe) eyes which he (Tombe) knew so well how to assume. He (Tombe) believed that when he (Tombe) so demanded it, the money would be forthcoming so as to satisfy, at any rate, his (Tombe) present emergencies.

That wretched old man in Westmoreland! If he (Tombe) would but die, there might yet be a hope remaining of permanent success! Even though the estate might be entailed so as to give him (Tombe) no more than a life-interest, still money might be raised on it. His (Tombe) life-interest in it would be worth ten or twelve years' purchase. He (Tombe) had an idea that his (Tombe) grandfather had not as yet made any such will when he (Tombe) left the place in Westmoreland. What a boon it would be if death could be made to overtake the old man before he (man) did so! On this very night he (man) walked about the lobbies of the House, thinking of all this. He (man) went by himself from room to room, roaming along passages, sitting now for ten minutes in the gallery, and then again for a short space in the body of the House,--till he (man) would get up and wander again out into the lobby, impatient of the neighbourhood of Mr. Bott. Certainly just at this time he (Bott) felt no desire to bring before the House the subject of the River Embankment.

Nor was Mr. Grey much happier when he (Grey) was left alone, than was his (Grey) assailant. To give Vavasor his (Grey) due, the memory of the affray itself did not long trouble him (Grey) much. The success between the combatants had been nearly equal, and he (Grey) had, at any rate, spoken his (Grey) mind freely. His (Grey) misery had come from other sources. But the reflection that he (Grey) had been concerned in a row was in itself enough to make John Grey wretched for the time. Such a misfortune had never hitherto befallen him (Grey). In all his (Grey) dealings with men words had been sufficient, and generally words of courtesy had sufficed. To have been personally engaged in a fighting scramble with such a man as George Vavasor was to him (Vavasor) terrible. When ordering that his (Vavasor) money might be expended with the possible object of saving Alice from her (Alice) cousin, he (Vavasor) had never felt a moment's regret; he (Vavasor) had never thought that he (Vavasor) was doing more than circumstances fairly demanded of him (Vavasor). But now he (Vavasor) was almost driven to utter reproach.

``Oh, Alice! that this thing should have come upon me through thy fault!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

When Vavasor was led away down stairs by the tailor, and Grey found that no more actual fighting would be required of him (Grey), he (Grey) retired into his (Grey) bedroom, that he (Grey) might wash his (Grey) mouth and free himself from the stains of the combat. He (Grey) had heard the front door closed, and knew that the miscreant was gone,--the miscreant who had disturbed his (Grey) quiet. Then he (Grey) began to think what was the accusation with which Vavasor had charged him (Grey). He (Grey) had been told that he (Grey) had advanced money on behalf of Alice, in order that he (Grey) might obtain some power over Alice's fortune, and thus revenge himself upon Alice for her (Alice) treatment of him (Grey). Nothing could be more damnably false than this accusation. Of that he (Grey) was well aware. But were not the circumstances of a nature to make it appear that the accusation was true? Security for the money advanced by him (Grey), of course, he (Grey) had none;--of course he (Grey) had desired none;--of course the money had been given out of his (Grey) own pocket with the sole object of saving Alice, if that might be possible; but of all those who might hear of this affair, how many would know or even guess the truth?

While he (Grey) was in this wretched state of mind, washing his (Grey) mouth, and disturbing his (Grey) spirit, Mr. Jones, his (Jones) landlord, came up to him (Jones). Mr. Jones had known him (Jones) for some years, and entertained a most profound respect for his (Jones) character. A rather sporting man than otherwise was Mr. Jones. His (Jones) father had been a tradesman at Cambridge, and in this way Jones had become known to Mr. Grey. But though given to sport, by which he (Jones) meant modern prize-fighting and the Epsom course on the Derby day, Mr. Jones was a man who dearly loved respectable customers and respectable lodgers. Mr. Grey, with his (Grey) property at Nethercoats, and his (Grey) august manners, and his (Grey) reputation at Cambridge, was a most respectable lodger, and Mr. Jones could hardly understand how any one could presume to raise his (Jones) hand against such a man.

``Dear, dear, sir--this is a terrible affair!'' (he)
he (Jones) said, as he (Jones) made his (Jones) way into the room.

``It was very disagreeable, certainly,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey.

``Was the gentleman known to you?'' (the tailor)
asked the tailor.

``Yes; I know who he (gentleman) is.'' (unknown)

``Any quarrel, sir?'' (unknown)

``Well, yes. I should not have pushed him (gentleman) down stairs had he (gentleman) not quarrelled with me.'' (unknown)

``We can have the police after him (gentleman) if you wish it, sir?'' (unknown)

``I don't wish it at all.'' (unknown)

``Or we might manage to polish him (gentleman) off in any other way, you know.'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)

It was some time before Mr. Grey could get rid of the tailor, but he (Grey) did so at last without having told any part of the story to that warlike, worthy, and very anxious individual.

CHAPTER LIII.

The Last Will of the Old Squire.

In the meantime Kate Vavasor was living down in Westmoreland, with no other society than that of her (Vavasor) grandfather, and did not altogether have a very pleasant life of it. George had been apt to represent the old man to himself as being as strong as an old tower, which, though it be but a ruin, shows no sign of falling. To his (George) eyes the Squire had always seemed to be full of life and power. He (Squire) could be violent on occasions, and was hardly ever without violence in his (Squire) eyes and voice. But George's opinion was formed by his (Squire) wish, or rather by the reverses of his (Squire) wish. For years he (Squire) had been longing that his (Squire) grandfather should die,--had been accusing Fate of gross injustice in that she (Squire) did not snap the thread; and with such thoughts in his (Squire) mind he (Squire) had grudged every ounce which the Squire's vigour had been able to sustain. He (Squire) had almost taught himself to believe that it would be a good deed to squeeze what remained of life out of that violent old throat. But, indeed, the embers of life were burning low; and had George known all the truth, he (George) would hardly have inclined his (George) mind to thoughts of murder.

He (George) was, indeed, very weak with age, and tottering with unsteady steps on the brink of his (George) grave, though he (George) would still come down early from his (George) room, and would, if possible, creep out about the garden and into the farmyard. He (George) would still sit down to dinner, and would drink his (George) allotted portion of port wine, in the doctor's teeth. The doctor by no means desired to rob him (doctor) of his (doctor) last luxury, or even to stint his (doctor) quantity; but he (doctor) recommended certain changes in the mode and time of taking it. Against this, however, the old Squire indignantly rebelled, and scolded Kate almost off her (Kate) legs when she (Kate) attempted to enforce the doctor's orders.

``What the mischief does it signify,'' (the man)
the old man said to her (Kate) one evening;--
``what difference will it make whether I am dead or alive, unless it is that George would turn you out of the house directly he (George) gets it.'' (the man)

``I was not thinking of any one but yourself, sir,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, with a tear in her (Kate) eye.

``You won't be troubled to think of me much longer,'' (the Squire)
said the Squire; and then he (Squire) gulped down the remaining half of his (Squire) glass of wine.

Kate was, in truth, very good to him (Squire). Women always are good under such circumstances; and Kate Vavasor was one who would certainly stick to such duties as now fell to her (Vavasor) lot. She (Vavasor) was eminently true and loyal to her (Vavasor) friends, though she (Vavasor) could be as false on their behalf as most false people can be on their own. She (Vavasor) was very good to the old man, tending all his (man) wants, taking his (man) violence with good-humour rather than with submission, not opposing him (man) with direct contradiction when he (man) abused his (man) grandson, but saying little words to mitigate his (man) wrath, if it were possible. At such times the Squire would tell her (Vavasor) that she (Vavasor) also would learn to know her (Vavasor) brother's character some day.

``You'll live to be robbed by him (George), and turned out as naked as you were born,'' (he)
he (Squire) said to her (Vavasor) one day. Then Kate fired up and declared that she (Kate) fully trusted her (Kate) brother's love. Whatever faults he (brother) might have, he (brother) had been staunch to her (Kate), So she (Kate) said, and the old man sneered at her (Kate) for saying so.

One morning, soon after this, when she (Kate) brought him (man) up to his (man) bedroom some mixture of thin porridge, which he (man) still endeavoured to swallow for his (man) breakfast, he (man) bade her (Kate) sit down, and began to talk to her (Kate) about the property.

``I know you are a fool,'' (he)
he (man) said,
``about all matters of business;--more of a fool than even women generally are.'' (he)
To this Kate acceded with a little smile,--acknowledging that her (Kate) understanding was limited.
``I want to see Gogram,'' (he)
he (man) said.
``Do you write to him (Gogram) a line, telling him (Gogram) to come here to-day,--he (Gogram) or one of his (Gogram) men,--and send it at once by Peter.'' (Mr. Gogram/Gogram)
Gogram was an attorney who lived at Penrith, and who was never summoned to Vavasor Hall unless the Squire had something to say about his (Squire) will.
``Don't you think you'd better put it off till you are a little stronger?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate. Whereupon the Squire fired at her (Kate) such a volley of oaths that she (Kate) sprang off the chair on which she (Kate) was sitting, and darted across to a little table at which there was pen and ink, and wrote her (Kate) note to Mr. Gogram, before she (Kate) had recovered from the shaking which the battery had given her (Kate). She (Kate) wrote the note, and ran away with it to Peter, and saw Peter on the pony on his (Peter) way to Penrith, before she (Kate) dared to return to her (Kate) grandfather's bedside.

``What should you do with the estate if I left it you?'' (Squire)
the Squire said to her (Kate) the first moment she (Kate) was again back with him (Squire).

This was a question she (Kate) could not answer instantly. She (Kate) stood by his (Squire) bedside for a while thinking,--holding her (Kate) grandfather's hand and looking down upon the bed. He (Squire), with his (Squire) rough watery old eyes, was gazing up into her (Kate) face, as though he (Squire) were trying to read her (Kate) thoughts.

``I think I should give it to my brother,'' (she)
she (Kate) said.

``Then I'm d-- if I'll leave it to you,'' (he)
said he (Squire).

She (Kate) did not jump now, though he (Squire) had sworn at her (Kate). She (Kate) still stood, holding his (Squire) hand softly, and looking down upon the bed.

``If I were you, grandfather,'' (she)
she (Kate) said almost in a whisper,
``I would not trust myself to alter family arrangements whilst I was ill. I'm sure you would advise any one else against doing so.'' (she)

``And if I were to leave it to Alice, she (Alice)'d give it to him (grandfather) too,'' (he)
he (Squire) said, speaking his (Squire) thoughts out loud.
``What it is you see in him (grandfather), I never could even guess. He (grandfather)'s as ugly as a baboon, with his (grandfather) scarred face. He (grandfather) has never done anything to show himself a clever fellow. Kate, give me some of that bottle the man sent.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Kate handed him (Squire) his (Squire) medicine, and then stood again by his (Squire) bedside.

``Where did he (man) get the money to pay for his (man) election?'' (the Squire)
the Squire asked, as soon as he (Squire) had swallowed the draught.
``They wouldn't give such a one as him (man) credit a yard further than they could see him (man).'' (unknown)

``I don't know where he (man) got it,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, lying.

``He (man) has not had yours; has he (man)?'' (unknown)

``He (man) would not take it, sir.'' (unknown)

``And you offered it to him (man)?'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir.'' (unknown)

``And he (man) has not had it?'' (unknown)

``Not a penny of it, sir.'' (unknown)

``And what made you offer it to him (man) after what I said to you?'' (unknown)

``Because it was my own,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, stoutly.

``You're the biggest idiot that ever I heard of, and you'll know it yourself some day. Go away now, and let me know when Gogram comes.'' (She)

She (Kate) went away, and for a time employed herself about her (Kate) ordinary household work. Then she (Kate) sat down alone in the dingy old dining-room, to think what had better be done in her (Kate) present circumstances. The carpet of the room was worn out, as were also the covers of the old chairs and the horsehair sofa which was never moved from its accustomed place along the wall. It was not a comfortable Squire's residence, this old house at Vavasor. In the last twenty years no money had been spent on furniture or embellishments, and for the last ten years there had been no painting, either inside or out. Twenty years ago the Squire had been an embarrassed man, and had taken a turn in his (Squire) life and had lived sparingly. It could not be said that he (Squire) had become a miser. His (Squire) table was kept plentifully, and there had never been want in his (Squire) house. In some respects, too, he (Squire) had behaved liberally to Kate and to others, and he (Squire) had kept up the timber and fences on the property. But the house had become wretched in its dull, sombre, dirty darkness, and the gardens round it were as bad.

What ought she (Kate) now to do? She (Kate) believed that her (Kate) grandfather's last days were coming, and she (Kate) knew that others of the family should be with him (grandfather) besides herself. For their sakes, for his (grandfather), and for her (Kate) own, it would be proper that she (Kate) should not be alone there when he (grandfather) died. But for whom should she (Kate) send? Her (Kate) brother was the natural heir, and would be the head of the family. Her (Kate) duty to him (brother) was clear, and the more so as her (Kate) grandfather was at this moment speaking of changes in his (grandfather) will. But it was a question to her (Kate) whether George's presence at Vavasor, even if he (George) would come, would not at this moment do more harm than good to his (George) own interests. It would make some prejudicial change in the old man's will more probable instead of less so. George would not become soft and mild-spoken even by a death-bed side, and it would be likely enough that the Squire would curse his (Squire) heir with his (Squire) dying breath. She (Kate) might send for her (Kate) uncle John; but if she (Kate) did so without telling George she (Kate) would be treating George unfairly; and she (Kate) knew that it was improbable that her (Kate) uncle and her (Kate) brother should act together in anything. Her (Kate) aunt Greenow, she (Kate) thought, would come to her (Kate), and her (Kate) presence would not influence the Squire in any way with reference to the property. So she (Kate) made up her (Kate) mind at last that she (Kate) would ask her (Kate) aunt to come to Vavasor, and that she (Kate) would tell her (Kate) brother accurately all that she (Kate) could tell,--leaving him (brother) to come or stay, as he (brother) might think. Alice would, no doubt, learn all the facts from him (brother), and her (Alice) uncle John would hear them from Alice. Then they could do as they pleased. As soon as Mr. Gogram had been there she (Alice) would write her (Alice) letters, and they should be sent over to Shap early on the following morning.

Mr. Gogram came and was closeted with the Squire, and the doctor also came. The doctor saw Kate, and, shaking his (doctor) head, told her (Kate) that her (Kate) grandfather was sinking lower and lower every hour. It would be infinitely better for him (grandfather) if he (grandfather) would take that port wine at four doses in the day, or even at two, instead of taking it all together. Kate promised to try again, but stated her (Kate) conviction that the trial would be useless. The doctor, when pressed on the matter, said that his (doctor) patient might probably live a week, not improbably a fortnight,--perhaps a month, if he (doctor) would be obedient,--and so forth. Gogram went away without seeing Kate; and Kate, who looked upon a will as an awful and somewhat tedious ceremony, was in doubt whether her (Kate) grandfather would live to complete any new operation. But, in truth, the will had been made and signed and witnessed,--the parish clerk and one of the tenants having been had up into the room as witnesses. Kate knew that the men had been there, but still did not think that a new will had been perfected.

That evening when it was dusk the Squire came into the dining-room, having been shuffling about the grand sweep before the house for a quarter of an hour. The day was cold and the wind bleak, but still he (Squire) would go out, and Kate had wrapped him (Squire) up carefully in mufflers and great-coats. Now he (Squire) came in to what he (Squire) called dinner, and Kate sat down with him (Squire). He (Squire) had drank no wine that day, although she (Kate) had brought it to him (Squire) twice during the morning. Now he (Squire) attempted to swallow a little soup, but failed; and after that, while Kate was eating her (Kate) bit of chicken, had the decanter put before him (Squire).

``I can't eat, and I suppose it won't hurt you if I take my wine at once,'' (he)
he (Squire) said. It went against the grain with him (Squire), even yet, that he (Squire) could not wait till the cloth was gone from the table, but his (Squire) impatience for the only sustenance that he (Squire) could take was too much for him (Squire).

``But you should eat something, sir; will you have a bit of toast to sop in your wine?'' (unknown)

The word

``sop'' (the Squire)
was badly chosen, and made the old Squire angry.
``Sopped toast! why am I to spoil the only thing I can enjoy?'' (unknown)

``But the wine would do you more good if you would take something with it.'' (unknown)

``Good! Nothing will do me any good any more. As for eating, you know I can't eat. What's the use of bothering me?'' (he)
Then he (Squire) filled his (Squire) second glass, and paused awhile before he (Squire) put it to his (Squire) lips. He (Squire) never exceeded four glasses, but the four he (Squire) was determined that he (Squire) would have, as long as he (Squire) could lift them to his (Squire) mouth.

Kate finished, or pretended to finish, her (Kate) dinner within five minutes, in order that the table might be made to look comfortable for him (Squire). Then she (Kate) poked the fire, and brushed up the hearth, and closed the old curtains with her (Kate) own hands, moving about silently. As she (Kate) moved his (Squire) eye followed her (Kate), and when she (Kate) came behind his (Squire) chair, and pushed the decanter a little more within his (Squire) reach, he (Squire) put out his (Squire) rough, hairy hand, and laid it upon one of hers which she (Kate) had rested on the table, with a tenderness that was unusual with him (Squire).

``You are a good girl, Kate. I wish you had been a boy, that's all.'' (unknown)

``If I had, I shouldn't, perhaps, have been here to take care of you,'' (she)
she (Kate) said, smiling.

``No; you'd have been like your brother, no doubt. Not that I think there could have been two so bad as he (brother) is.'' (unknown)

``Oh, grandfather, if he (brother) has offended you, you should try to forgive him (brother).'' (unknown)

``Try to forgive him (brother)! How often have I forgiven him (brother) without any trying? Why did he (brother) come down here the other day, and insult me for the last time? Why didn't he (brother) keep away, as I had bidden him (brother)?'' (unknown)

``But you gave him (brother) leave to see you, sir.'' (unknown)

``I didn't give him (brother) leave to treat me like that. Never mind; he (brother) will find that, old as I am, I can punish an insult.'' (unknown)

``You haven't done anything, sir, to injure him (brother)?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

``I have made another will, that's all. Do you suppose I had that man here all the way from Penrith for nothing?'' (unknown)

``But it isn't done yet?'' (unknown)

``I tell you it is done. If I left him (man) the whole property it would be gone in two years' time. What's the use of doing it?'' (unknown)

``But for his (man) life, sir! You had promised him (man) that he (man) should have it for his (man) life.'' (unknown)

``How dare you tell me that? I never promised him (man). As my heir, he (man) would have had it all, if he (man) would have behaved himself with common decency. Even though I disliked him (man), as I always have done, he (man) should have had it.'' (unknown)

``And you have taken it from him (man) altogether?'' (unknown)

``I shall answer no questions about it, Kate.'' (him)
Then a fit of coughing came upon him (Squire), his (Squire) four glasses of wine having been all taken, and there was no further talk about business. During the evening Kate read a chapter of the Bible out loud. But the Squire was very impatient under the reading, and positively refused permission for a second.
``There isn't any good in so much of it, all at once,'' (he)
he (Squire) said, using almost exactly the same words which Kate had used to him (Squire) about the port wine. There may have been good produced by the small quantity to which he (Squire) listened, as there is good from the physic which children take with wry faces, most unwillingly. Who can say?

For many weeks past Kate had begged her (Kate) uncle to allow the clergyman of Vavasor to come to him (clergyman); but he (clergyman) had positively declined. The vicar was a young man to whom the living had lately been given by the Chancellor, and he (Chancellor) had commenced his (Chancellor) career by giving instant offence to the Squire. This vicar's predecessor had been an old man, almost as old as the Squire himself, and had held the living for forty years. He (Squire) had been a Westmoreland man, had read the prayers and preached his (man) one Sunday sermon in a Westmoreland dialect, getting through the whole operation rather within an hour and a quarter. He (man) had troubled none of his (man) parishioners by much advice, and had been meek and obedient to the Squire. Knowing the country well, and being used to its habits, he (Squire) had lived, and been charitable too, on the proceeds of his (Squire) living, which had never reached two hundred a year. But the new comer was a close-fisted man, with higher ideas of personal comfort, who found it necessary to make every penny go as far as possible, who made up in preaching for what he (man) could not give away in charity; who established an afternoon service, and who had rebuked the Squire for saying that the doing so was trash and nonsense. Since that the Squire had never been inside the church, except on the occasion of Christmas-day. For this, indeed, the state of his (Squire) health gave ample excuse; but he (Squire) had positively refused to see the vicar, though that gentleman had assiduously called, and had at last desired the servant to tell the clergyman not to come again unless he (clergyman) were sent for. Kate's task was, therefore, difficult, both as regarded the temporal and spiritual wants of her (Kate) grandfather.

When the reading was finished, the old man dozed in his (man) chair for half an hour. He (man) would not go up to bed before the enjoyment of that luxury. He (man) was daily implored to do so, because that sleep in the chair interfered so fatally with his (man) chance of sleeping in bed. But sleep in his (man) chair he (man) would and did. Then he (man) woke, and after a fit of coughing, was induced, with much ill-humour, to go up to his (man) room. Kate had never seen him (man) so weak. He (man) was hardly able, even with her (Kate) assistance and that of the old servant, to get up the broad stairs. But there was still some power left to him (servant) for violence of language after he (servant) got to his (servant) room, and he (servant) rated Kate and the old woman loudly, because his (servant) slippers were not in the proper place.

``Grandfather,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate,
``would you like me to stay in the room with you to-night?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
He (servant) rated her (Kate) again for this proposition, and then, with assistance from the nurse, he (servant) was gotten into bed and was left alone.

-LSB-Illustration: The last of the old squire.-RSB-

After that Kate went to her (Kate) own room and wrote her (Kate) letters. The first she (Kate) wrote was to her (Kate) aunt Greenow. That was easily enough written. To Mrs. Greenow it was not necessary that she (Greenow) should say anything about money. She (Greenow) simply stated her (Greenow) belief that her (Greenow) grandfather's last day was near at hand, and begged her (Greenow) aunt to come and pay a last visit to the old man.

``It will be a great comfort to me in my distress,'' (she)
she (Greenow) said;
``and it will be a satisfaction to you to have seen your father again.'' (she)
She (Greenow) knew that her (Greenow) aunt would come, and that task was soon done.

But her (Greenow) letter to her (Greenow) brother was much more difficult. What should she (Greenow) tell him (brother), and what should she (Greenow) not tell him (brother)? She (Greenow) began by describing her (Greenow) grandfather's state, and by saying to him (grandfather), as she (Greenow) had done to Mrs. Greenow, that she (Greenow) believed the old man's hours were well-nigh come to a close. She (Greenow) told him (man) that she (Greenow) had asked her (Greenow) aunt to come to her (Greenow);

``not,'' (aunt)
she (Greenow) said,
``that I think her (Kate) coming will be of material service, but I feel the loneliness of the house will be too much for me at such a time. I must leave it for you to decide,'' (she)
she (Greenow) said,
``whether you had better be here. If anything should happen,'' (she)
--people when writing such letters are always afraid to speak of death by its proper name,--
``I will send you a message, and no doubt you would come at once.'' (people)
Then came the question of the will. Had it not occurred to her (Greenow) that her (Greenow) own interests were involved she (Greenow) would have said nothing on the subject; but she (Greenow) feared her (Greenow) brother,--feared even his (brother) misconstruction of her (Greenow) motives, even though she (Greenow) was willing to sacrifice so much on his (brother) behalf,--and therefore she (Greenow) resolved to tell him (brother) all that she (Greenow) knew. He (brother) might turn upon her (Greenow) hereafter if she (Greenow) did not do so, and accuse her (Greenow) of a silence which had been prejudicial to him (brother).

So she (Greenow) told it all, and the letter became long in the telling.

``I write with a heavy heart,'' (she)
she (Greenow) said,
``because I know it will be a great blow to you. He (I) gave me to understand that in this will he (I) left everything away from you. I cannot declare that he (I) said so directly. Indeed I cannot remember his (I) words; but that was the impression he (I) left on me. The day before he (I) had asked me what I should do if he (I) gave me the estate; but of course I treated that as a joke. I have no idea what he (I) put into his (I) will. I have not even attempted to guess. But now I have told you all that I know.'' (she)
The letter was a very long one, and was not finished till late; but when it was completed she (Greenow) had the two taken out into the kitchen, as the boy was to start with them before daylight.

Early on the next morning she (Greenow) crept silently into her (Greenow) grandfather's room, as was her (Greenow) habit; but he (grandfather) was apparently sleeping, and then she (Greenow) crept back again. The old servant told her (Greenow) that the Squire had been awake at four, and at five, and at six, and had called for her (Greenow). Then he (Squire) had seemed to go to sleep. Four or five times in the course of the morning Kate went into the room, but her (Kate) grandfather did not notice her (Kate). At last she (Kate) feared he (grandfather) might already have passed away, and she (Kate) put her (Kate) hand upon his (grandfather) shoulder, and down his (grandfather) arm. He (grandfather) then gently touched her (Kate) hand with his (grandfather), showing her (Kate) plainly that he (grandfather) was not only alive, but conscious. She (Kate) then offered him (grandfather) food,--the thin porridge,--which he (grandfather) was wont to take, and the medicine. She (Kate) offered him (grandfather) some wine too, but he (grandfather) would take nothing.

At twelve o'clock a letter was brought to her (Kate), which had come by the post. She (Kate) saw that it was from Alice, and opening it found that it was very long. At that moment she (Alice) could not read it, but she (Alice) saw words in it that made her (Alice) wish to know its contents as quickly as possible. But she (Alice) could not leave her (Alice) grandfather then. At two o'clock the doctor came to him (doctor), and remained there till the dusk of the evening had commenced. At eight o'clock the old man was dead.

CHAPTER LIV.

Showing How Alice Was Punished.

Poor Kate's condition at the old Hall on that night was very sad. The presence of death is always a source of sorrow, even though the circumstances of the case are of a kind to create no agony of grief. The old man who had just passed away up-stairs was fully due to go. He (man) had lived his (man) span all out, and had himself known that to die was the one thing left for him (man) to do. Kate also had expected his (man) death, and had felt that the time had come in which it would be foolish even to wish that it should be arrested. But death close to one is always sad as it is solemn.

And she (Kate) was quite alone at Vavasor Hall. She (Kate) had no acquaintance within some miles of her (Kate). From the young vicar, though she (Kate) herself had not quarrelled with him (vicar), she (Kate) could receive no comfort, as she (Kate) hardly knew him (vicar); nor was she (Kate) of a temperament which would dispose her (Kate) to turn to a clergyman at such a time for comfort, unless to one who might have been an old friend. Her (Kate) aunt and brother would probably both come to her (Kate), but they could hardly be with her (Kate) for a day or two, and during that day or two it would be needful that orders should be given which it is disagreeable for a woman to have to give. The servants, moreover, in the house were hardly fit to assist her (woman) much. There was an old butler, or footman, who had lived at the Hall for more than fifty years, but he (butler) was crippled with rheumatism, and so laden with maladies, that he (butler) rarely crept out of his (butler) own room. He (butler) was simply an additional burden on the others. There was a boy who had lately done all the work which the other should have done, and ever so much more beside. There is no knowing how much work such a boy will do when properly drilled, and he (boy) was now Kate's best minister in her (Kate) distress. There was the old nurse,--but she (Kate) had been simply good for nursing, and there were two rough Westmoreland girls who called themselves cook and housemaid.

On that first evening,--the very day on which her (housemaid) grandfather had died,--Kate would have been more comfortable had she (Kate) really found something that she (Kate) could do. But there was in truth nothing. She (Kate) hovered for an hour or two in and out of the room, conscious of the letter which she (Kate) had in her (Kate) pocket, and very desirous in heart of reading it, but restrained by a feeling that at such a moment she (Kate) ought to think only of the dead. In this she (Kate) was wrong. Let the living think of the dead, when their thoughts will travel that way whether the thinker wish it or no. Grief taken up because grief is supposed to be proper, is only one degree better than pretended grief. When one sees it, one cannot but think of the lady who asked her (lady) friend, in confidence, whether hot roast fowl and bread-sauce were compatible with the earliest state of weeds; or of that other lady,--a royal lady she (lady),--who was much comforted in the tedium of her (lady) trouble when assured by one of the lords about the Court that piquet was mourning.

It was late at night, near eleven, before Kate took out her (Kate) letter and read it. As something of my story hangs upon it, I will give it at length, though it was a long letter. It had been written with great struggles, and with many tears, and Kate, as she (Kate) read it to the end, almost forgot that her (Kate) grandfather was lying dead in the room above her (Kate).

Queen Anne Street, April, 186--.

DEAREST KATE,

I hardly know how to write to you--what I have to tell, and yet I must tell it. I must tell it to you, but I shall never repeat the story to any one else. I should have written yesterday, when it occurred, but I was so ill that I felt myself unable to make the exertion. Indeed, at one time, after your brother had left me, I almost doubted whether I should ever be able to collect my thoughts again. My dismay was at first so great that my reason for a time deserted me, and I could only sit and cry like an idiot.

Dear Kate, I hope you will not be angry with me for telling you. I have endeavoured to think about it as calmly as I can, and I believe that I have no alternative. The fact that your brother has quarrelled with me cannot be concealed from you, and I must not leave him (brother) to tell you of the manner of it. He (brother) came to me yesterday in great anger. His (brother) anger then was nothing to what it became afterwards; but even when he (brother) first came in he (brother) was full of wrath. He (brother) stood up before me, and asked me how it had come to pass that I had sent him (brother) the money which he (brother) had asked of me through the hands of Mr. Grey. Of course I had not done this, and so I told him (Grey) at once. I had spoken of the matter to no one but papa, and he (papa) had managed it for me. Even now I know nothing of it, and as I have not yet spoken to papa I cannot understand it. George at once told me that he (George) disbelieved me, and when I sat quiet under this insult, he (George) used harsher words, and said that I had conspired to lower him (George) before the world.

He (George) then asked me whether I loved him (George). Oh, Kate, I must tell it you all, though it is dreadful to me that I should have to write it. You remember how it came to pass when we were in Westmoreland together at Christmas? Do not think that I am blaming you, but I was very rash then in the answers which I made to him (George). I thought that I could be useful to him (George) as his (George) wife, and I had told myself that it would be good that I should be of use in some way. When he (George) asked me that question yesterday, I sat silent. Indeed, how could I have answered it in the affirmative, when he (George) had just used such language to me,--while he (George) was standing opposite to me, looking at me in that way which he (George) has when he (George) is enraged? Then he (George) spoke again and demanded of me that I should at once send back to Mr. Grey all presents of his (Grey) which I had kept, and at the same time took up and threw across the table on to the sofa near me, a little paper knife which Mr. Grey once gave me. I could not allow myself to be so ordered by him (Grey); so I said nothing, but put the knife back upon the table. He (Grey) then took it again and threw it beneath the grate.

``I have a right to look upon you as my wife,'' (he)
he (Grey) said,
``and, as such, I will not allow you to keep that man's things about you.'' (he)
I think I told him (Grey) then that I should never become his (Grey) wife, but though I remember many of his (Grey) words, I remember none of my own. He (Grey) swore, I know, with a great oath, that if I went back a second time from my word to him (Grey) he (Grey) would leave me no peace,--that he (Grey) would punish me for my perfidy with some fearful punishment. Oh, Kate, I cannot tell you what he (Grey) looked like. He (Grey) had then come quite close to me, and I know that I trembled before him (Grey) as though he (Grey) were going to strike me. Of course I said nothing. What could I say to a man who behaved to me in such a manner? Then, as far as I can remember it, he (man) sat down and began to talk about money. I forget what he (man) said at first, but I know that I assured him (man) that he (man) might take what he (man) wanted so long as enough was left to prevent my being absolutely a burden on papa.
``That, madam, is a matter of course,'' (he)
he (papa) said. I remember those words so well. Then he (papa) explained that after what had passed between us, I had no right to ruin him (papa) by keeping back from him (papa) money which had been promised to him (papa), and which was essential to his (papa) success. In this, dear Kate, I think he (papa) was mainly right. But he (papa) could not have been right in putting it to me in that hard, cruel manner, especially as I had never refused anything that he (papa) had asked of me in respect of money. The money he (papa) may have while it lasts; but then there must be an end of it all between us, even though he (papa) should have the power of punishing me, as he (papa) says he (papa) will do. Punishing me, indeed! What punishment can be so hard as that which he (papa) has already inflicted?

He (papa) then desired me to write a letter to him (papa) which he (papa) might show to the lawyer,--to our own lawyer, I think he (papa) meant,--in order that money might be raised to pay back what Mr. Grey had advanced, and give him (Grey) what he (Grey) now required. I think he (Grey) said it was to be five thousand pounds. When he (Grey) asked this I did not move. Indeed, I was unable to move. Then he (Grey) spoke very loud, and swore at me again, and brought me pen and ink, demanding that I should write the letter. I was so frightened that I thought of running to the door to escape, and I would have done so had I not distrusted my own power. Had it been to save my life I could not have written the letter. I believe I was now crying,--at any rate I threw myself back and covered my face with my hands. Then he (Grey) came and sat by me, and took hold of my arms. Oh, Kate; I cannot tell it you all. He (Grey) put his (Grey) mouth close to my ear, and said words which were terrible, though I did not understand them. I do not know what it was he (Grey) said, but he (Grey) was threatening me with his (Grey) anger if I did not obey him (Grey). Before he (Grey) left me, I believe I found my voice to tell him (Grey) that he (Grey) should certainly have the money which he (Grey) required. And so he (Grey) shall. I will go to Mr. Round myself, and insist on its being done. My money is my own, and I may do with it as I please. But I hope,--I am obliged to hope, that I may never be made to see my cousin again.

I will not pretend to express any opinion as to the cause of all this. It is very possible that you will not believe all I say,--that you will think that I am mad and have deluded myself. Of course your heart will prompt you to accuse me rather than him (cousin). If it is so, and if there must therefore be a division between us, my grief will be greatly increased; but I do not know that I can help it. I cannot keep all this back from you. He (cousin) has cruelly ill-used me and insulted me. He (cousin) has treated me as I should have thought no man could have treated a woman. As regards money, I did all that I could do to show that I trusted him (man) thoroughly, and my confidence has only led to suspicion. I do not know whether he (man) understands that everything must be over between us; but, if not, I must ask you to tell him (man) so. And I must ask you to explain to him (man) that he (man) must not come again to Queen Anne Street. If he (man) does, nothing shall induce me to see him (man). Tell him (man) also that the money that he (man) wants shall assuredly be sent to him (man) as soon as I can make Mr. Round get it.

Dearest Kate, good-bye. I hope you will feel for me. If you do not answer me I shall presume that you think yourself bound to support his (Mr.) side, and to believe me to have been wrong. It will make me very unhappy; but I shall remember that you are his (Mr.) sister, and I shall not be angry with you.

Yours always affectionately,

ALICE VAVASOR.

Kate, as she (Kate) read her (Kate) letter through, at first quickly, and then very slowly, came by degrees almost to forget that death was in the house. Her (Kate) mind, and heart, and brain, were filled with thoughts and feelings that had exclusive reference to Alice and her (Alice) brother, and at last she (Alice) found herself walking the room with quick, impetuous steps, while her (Alice) blood was hot with indignation.

All her (Alice) sympathies in the matter were with Alice. It never occurred to her (Alice) to disbelieve a word of the statement made to her (Alice), or to suggest to herself that it had been coloured by any fears or exaggerations on the part of her (Alice) correspondent. She (Alice) knew that Alice was true. And, moreover, much as she (Alice) loved her (Alice) brother,--willing as she (Alice) had been and would still be to risk all that she (Alice) possessed, and herself also, on his (brother) behalf,--she (Alice) knew that it would be risking and not trusting. She (Alice) loved her (Alice) brother, such love having come to her (Alice) by nature, and having remained with her (Alice) from of old; and in his (brother) intellect she (Alice) still believed. But she (Alice) had ceased to have belief in his (brother) conduct. She (Alice) feared everything that he (brother) might do, and lived with a consciousness that though she (Alice) was willing to connect all her (Alice) own fortunes with his (brother), she (Alice) had much reason to expect that she (Alice) might encounter ruin in doing so. Her (Alice) sin had been in this,--that she (Alice) had been anxious to subject Alice to the same danger,--that she (Alice) had intrigued, sometimes very meanly, to bring about the object which she (Alice) had at heart,--that she (Alice) had used all her (Alice) craft to separate Alice from Mr. Grey. Perhaps it may be alleged in her (Alice) excuse that she (Alice) had thought,--had hoped rather than thought,--that the marriage which she (Alice) contemplated would change much in her (Alice) brother that was wrong, and bring him (brother) into a mode of life that would not be dangerous. Might not she (Alice) and Alice together so work upon him (brother), that he (brother) should cease to stand ever on the brink of some half-seen precipice? To risk herself for her (Alice) brother was noble. But when she (Alice) used her (Alice) cunning in inducing her (Alice) cousin to share that risk she (Alice) was ignoble. Of this she (Alice) had herself some consciousness, as she (Alice) walked up and down the old dining-room at midnight, holding her (Alice) cousin's letter in her (Alice) hand.

Her (Alice) cheeks became tinged with shame as she (Alice) thought of the scene which Alice had described,--the toy thrown beneath the grate, the loud curses, the whispered threats, which had been more terrible than curses, the demand for money, made with something worse than a cut-throat's violence, the strong man's hand placed upon the woman's arm in anger and in rage, those eyes glaring, and the gaping horror of that still raw cicatrice, as he (man) pressed his (man) face close to that of his (man) victim! Not for a moment did she (woman) think of defending him (man). She (woman) accused him (man) to herself vehemently of a sin over and above those sins which had filled Alice with dismay. He (man) had demanded money from the girl whom he (man) intended to marry! According to Kate's idea, nothing could excuse or palliate this sin. Alice had accounted it as nothing,--had expressed her (Alice) opinion that the demand was reasonable;--even now, after the ill-usage to which she (Alice) had been subjected, she (Alice) had declared that the money should be forthcoming, and given to the man who had treated her (Alice) so shamefully. It might be well that Alice should so feel and so act, but it behoved Kate to feel and act very differently. She (Kate) would tell her (Kate) brother, even in the house of death, should he (brother) come there, that his (brother) conduct was mean and unmanly. Kate was no coward. She (Kate) declared to herself that she (Kate) would do this even though he (brother) should threaten her (Kate) with all his (brother) fury,--though he (brother) should glare upon her (Kate) with all the horrors of his (brother) countenance.

One o'clock, and two o'clock, still found her (Kate) in the dark sombre parlour, every now and then pacing the floor of the room. The fire had gone out, and, though it was now the middle of April, she (Kate) began to feel the cold. But she (Kate) would not go to bed before she (Kate) had written a line to Alice. To her (Alice) brother a message by telegraph would of course be sent the next morning; as also would she (Alice) send a message to her (Alice) aunt. But to Alice she (Alice) would write, though it might be but a line. Cold as she (Alice) was, she (Alice) found her (Alice) pens and paper, and wrote her (Alice) letter that night. It was very short.

``Dear Alice, to-day I received your letter, and to-day our poor old grandfather died. Tell my uncle John, with my love, of his (John) father's death. You will understand that I cannot write much now about that other matter; but I must tell you, even at such a moment as this, that there shall be no quarrel between you and me. There shall be none at least on my side. I cannot say more till a few days shall have passed by. He (John) is lying up-stairs, a corpse. I have telegraphed to George, and I suppose he (George) will come down. I think my aunt Greenow will come also, as I had written to her (Greenow) before, seeing that I wanted the comfort of having her (Greenow) here. Uncle John will of course come or not as he (John) thinks fitting. I don't know whether I am in a position to say that I shall be glad to see him (John); but I should be very glad. He (John) and you will know that I can, as yet, tell you nothing further. The lawyer is to see the men about the funeral. Nothing, I suppose, will be done till George comes. Your own cousin and friend, KATE VAVASOR.'' (she)
And then she (Alice) added a line below,
``My own Alice,--If you will let me, you shall be my sister, and be the nearest to me and the dearest.'' (she)

Alice, when she (Alice) received this, was at the first moment so much struck, and indeed surprised, by the tidings of her (Alice) grandfather's death, that she (Alice) was forced, in spite of the still existing violence of her (Alice) own feelings, to think and act chiefly with reference to that event. Her (Alice) father had not then left his (father) room. She (Alice) therefore went to him (father), and handed him (father) Kate's letter.

``Papa,'' (she)
she (Kate) said,
``there is news from Westmoreland; bad news, which you hardly expected yet.'' (she)
``My father is dead,'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
said John Vavasor. Whereupon Alice gave him (Vavasor) Kate's letter, that he (Vavasor) might read it.
``Of course I shall go down,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) said, as he (Vavasor) came to that part in which Kate had spoken of him (Vavasor).
``Does she (sister) think I shall not follow my father to the grave, because I dislike her (sister) brother? What does she (sister) mean by saying that there shall be no quarrel between you and her (sister)?'' (unknown)
``I will explain that at another time,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice. John Vavasor asked no further questions then, but declared at first that he (Vavasor) should go to Westmoreland on the following day. Then he (Vavasor) altered his (Vavasor) purpose.
``I'll go by the mail train to-night,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) said.
``It will be very disagreeable, but I ought to be there when the will is opened.'' (Queen)
There was very little more said in Queen Anne Street on the subject till the evening,--till a few moments before Mr. Vavasor left his (Vavasor) house. He (Vavasor) indeed had thought nothing more about that quarrelling, or rather that promise that there should be no quarrelling, between the girls. He (Vavasor) still regarded his (Vavasor) nephew George as the man who, unfortunately, was to be his (Vavasor) son-in-law, and now, during this tedious sad day, in which he (Vavasor) felt himself compelled to remain at home, he (Vavasor) busied his (Vavasor) mind in thinking of George and Alice, as living together at the old Hall. At six, the father and daughter dined, and soon after dinner Mr. Vavasor went up to his (Vavasor) own room to prepare himself for his (Vavasor) journey. After a while Alice followed him (Vavasor),--but she (Alice) did not do so till she (Alice) knew that if anything was to be told before the journey no further time could be lost.
``Papa,'' (she)
she (Alice) said, as soon as she (Alice) had shut the door behind her (Alice),
``I think I ought to tell you before you go that everything is over between me and George.'' (her)

``Have you quarrelled with him (George) too?'' (father)
said her (Alice) father, with uncontrolled surprise.

``I should perhaps say that he (George) has quarrelled with me. But, dear papa, pray do not question me at present. I will tell you all when you come back, but I thought it right that you should know this before you went.'' (unknown)

``It has been his (George) doing then?'' (unknown)

``I cannot explain it to you in a hurry like this. Papa, you may understand something of the shame which I feel, and you should not question me now.'' (unknown)

``And John Grey?'' (unknown)

``There is nothing different in regard to him (Grey).'' (unknown)

``I'll be shot if I can understand you. George, you know, has had two thousand pounds of your money,--of yours or somebody else's. Well, we can't talk about it now, as I must be off. Thinking as I do of George, I'm glad of it,--that's all.'' (he)
Then he (father) went, and Alice was left alone, to comfort herself as best she (Alice) might by her (Alice) own reflections.

George Vavasor had received the message on the day previous to that on which Alice's letter had reached her (Alice), but it had not come to him (Vavasor) till late in the day. He (Vavasor) might have gone down by the mail train of that night, but there were one or two persons, his (Vavasor) own attorney especially, whom he (Vavasor) wished to see before the reading of his (Vavasor) grandfather's will. He (Vavasor) remained in town, therefore, on the following day, and went down by the same train as that which took his (Vavasor) uncle. Walking along the platform, looking for a seat, he (Vavasor) peered into a carriage and met his (Vavasor) uncle's eye. The two saw each other, but did not speak, and George passed on to another carriage. On the following morning, before the break of day, they met again in the refreshment room, at the station at Lancaster.

``So my father has gone, George,'' (the uncle)
said the uncle, speaking to the nephew. They must go to the same house, and Mr. Vavasor felt that it would be better that they should be on speaking terms when they reached it.
``Yes,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George;
``he (George) has gone at last. I wonder what we shall find to have been his (George) latest act of injustice.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
The reader will remember that he (George) had received Kate's first letter, in which she (Kate) had told him (George) of the Squire's altered will. John Vavasor turned away disgusted. His (Vavasor) finer feelings were perhaps not very strong, but he (Vavasor) had no thoughts or hopes in reference to the matter which were mean. He (Vavasor) expected nothing himself, and did not begrudge his (Vavasor) nephew the inheritance. At this moment he (Vavasor) was thinking of the old Squire as a father who had ever been kind to him (Squire). It might be natural that George should have no such old affection at his (George) heart, but it was unnatural that he (George) should express himself as he (George) had done at such a moment.

The uncle turned away, but said nothing. George followed him (George) with a little proposition of his (George) own.

``We shan't get any conveyance at Shap,'' (he)
he (George) said.
``Hadn't we better go over in a chaise from Kendal?'' (the uncle)
To this the uncle assented, and so they finished their journey together. George smoked all the time that they were in the carriage, and very few words were spoken. As they drove up to the old house, they found that another arrival had taken place before them,--Mrs. Greenow having reached the house in some vehicle from the Shap station. She (Greenow) had come across from Norwich to Manchester, where she (Greenow) had joined the train which had brought the uncle and nephew from London.

CHAPTER LV.

The Will.

The coming of Mrs. Greenow at this very moment was a great comfort to Kate. Without her (Kate) she (Kate) would hardly have known how to bear herself with her (Kate) uncle and her (Kate) brother. As it was, they were all restrained by something of the courtesy which strangers are bound to show to each other. George had never seen his (George) aunt since he (George) was a child, and some sort of introduction was necessary between them.

``So you are George,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, putting out her (Greenow) hand and smiling.

``Yes; I'm George,'' (he)
said he (George).

``And a Member of Parliament!'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.
``It's quite an honour to the family. I felt so proud when I heard it!'' (She)
She (Greenow) said this pleasantly, meaning it to be taken for truth, and then turned away to her (Greenow) brother.
``Papa's time was fully come,'' (she)
she (Greenow) said,
``though, to tell the truth, I had no idea that he (Papa) was so weak as Kate describes him (Papa) to have been.'' (she)

``Nor I, either,'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
said John Vavasor.
``He (Papa) went to church with us here on Christmas-day.'' (unknown)

``Did he (Papa), indeed? Dear, dear! He (Papa) seems at last to have gone off just like poor Greenow.'' (she)
Here she (Greenow) put her (Greenow) handkerchief up to her (Greenow) face.
``I think you didn't know Greenow, John?'' (unknown)

``I met him (John) once,'' (brother)
said her (Greenow) brother.

``Ah! he (John) wasn't to be known and understood in that way. I'm aware there was a little prejudice, because of his (John) being in trade, but we won't talk of that now. Where should I have been without him (John), tradesman or no tradesman?'' (unknown)

``I've no doubt he (John) was an excellent man.'' (unknown)

``You may say that, John. Ah, well! we can't keep everything in this life for ever.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
It may, perhaps, be as well to explain now that Mrs. Greenow had told Captain Bellfield at their last meeting before she (Greenow) left Norwich, that, under certain circumstances, if he (Captain) behaved himself well, there might possibly be ground of hope. Whereupon Captain Bellfield had immediately gone to the best tailor in that city, had told the man of his (man) coming marriage, and had given an extensive order. But the tailor had not as yet supplied the goods, waiting for more credible evidence of the Captain's good fortune.
``We're all grass of the field,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, lightly brushing a tear from her (Greenow) eye,
``and must be cut down and put into the oven in our turns.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
Her (Greenow) brother uttered a slight sympathetic groan, shaking his (brother) head in testimony of the uncertainty of human affairs, and then said that he (brother) would go out and look about the place. George, in the meantime, had asked his (George) sister to show him (George) his (George) room, and the two were already together up-stairs.

Kate had made up her (Kate) mind that she (Kate) would say nothing about Alice at the present moment,--nothing, if it could be avoided, till after the funeral. She (Kate) led the way up-stairs, almost trembling with fear, for she (Kate) knew that that other subject of the will would also give rise to trouble and sorrow,--perhaps, also, to determined quarrelling.

``What has brought that woman here?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
was the first question that George asked.

``I asked her (woman) to come,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

``And why did you ask her (woman) to come here?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George, angrily. Kate immediately felt that he (George) was speaking as though he (George) were master of the house, and also as though he (George) intended to be master of her (Kate). As regarded the former idea, she (Kate) had no objection to it. She (Kate) thoroughly and honestly wished that he (George) might be the master; and though she (Kate) feared that he (George) might find himself mistaken in his (George) assumption, she (Kate) herself was not disposed to deny any appearance of right that he (George) might take upon himself in that respect. But she (Kate) had already begun to tell herself that she (Kate) must not submit herself to his (George) masterdom. She (Kate) had gradually so taught herself since he (George) had compelled her (Kate) to write the first letter in which Alice had been asked to give her (Alice) money.

``I asked her (woman), George, before my poor grandfather's death, when I thought that he (George) would linger perhaps for weeks. My life here alone with him (George), without any other woman in the house beside the servants, was very melancholy.'' (unknown)

``Why did you not ask Alice to come to you?'' (unknown)

``Alice could not have come,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, after a short pause.

``I don't know why she (Alice) shouldn't have come. I won't have that woman about the place. She (Alice) disgraced herself by marrying a blacksmith--.'' (unknown)

``Why, George, it was you yourself who advised me to go and stay with her (Alice).'' (unknown)

``That's a very different thing. Now that he (George)'s dead, and she (Alice)'s got his (George) money, it's all very well that you should go to her (Alice) occasionally; but I won't have her (Alice) here.'' (unknown)

``It's natural that she (Alice) should come to her (Alice) father's house at her (Alice) father's death-bed.'' (unknown)

``I hate to be told that things are natural. It always means humbug. I don't suppose she (Alice) cared for the old man any more than I did,--or than she (Alice) cared for the other old man who married her (Alice). People are such intense hypocrites. There's my uncle John, pulling a long face because he (John) has come into this house, and he (John) will pull it as long as the body lies up there; and yet for the last twenty years there's nothing on earth he (John) has so much hated as going to see his (John) father. When are they going to bury him (John)?'' (unknown)

``On Saturday, the day after to-morrow.'' (unknown)

``Why couldn't they do it to-morrow, so that we could get away before Sunday?'' (unknown)

``He (John) only died on Monday, George,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, solemnly.

``Psha! Who has got the will?'' (unknown)

``Mr. Gogram. He (Gogram) was here yesterday, and told me to tell you and uncle John that he (John) would have it with him (John) when he (John) came back from the funeral.'' (unknown)

``What has my uncle John to do with it?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George, sharply.
``I shall go over to Penrith this afternoon and make Gogram give it up to me.'' (unknown)

``I don't think he (John)'ll do that, George.'' (unknown)

``What right has he (George) to keep it? What right has he (George) to it at all? How do I know that he (George) has really got the old man's last will? Where did my grandfather keep his (grandfather) papers?'' (unknown)

``In that old secretary, as he (grandfather) used to call it; the one that stands in the dining-room. It is sealed up.'' (unknown)

``Who sealed it?'' (unknown)

``Mr. Gogram did,--Mr. Gogram and I together.'' (unknown)

``What the deuce made you meddle with it?'' (unknown)

``I merely assisted him (Gogram). But I believe he (Gogram) was quite right. I think it is usual in such cases.'' (unknown)

``Balderdash! You are thinking of some old trumpery of former days. Till I know to the contrary, everything here belongs to me as heir-at-law, and I do not mean to allow of any interference till I know for certain that my rights have been taken from me. And I won't accept a death-bed will. What a man chooses to write when his (man) fingers will hardly hold the pen, goes for nothing.'' (unknown)

``You can't suppose that I wish to interfere with your rights?'' (unknown)

``I hope not.'' (unknown)

``Oh, George!'' (unknown)

``Well; I say, I hope not. But I know there are those who would. Do you think my uncle John would not interfere with me if he (John) could? By --! if he (John) does, he (John) shall find that he (John) does it to his (John) cost. I'll lead him (John) such a life through the courts, for the next two or three years, that he (John)'ll wish that he (John) had remained in Chancery Lane, and had never left it.'' (the nurse)

A message was now brought up by the nurse, saying that Mrs. Greenow and Mr. Vavasor were going into the room where the old Squire was lying,

``Would Miss Kate and Mr. George go with them?'' (Squire)

``Mr. Vavasor!'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
shouted out George, making the old woman jump. She (woman) did not understand his (George) meaning in the least.
``Yes, sir; the old Squire,'' (she)
she (woman) said.

``Will you come, George?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Kate asked.

``No; what should I go there for? Why should I pretend an interest in the dead body of a man whom I hated and who hated me;--whose very last act, as far as I know as yet, was an attempt to rob me? I won't go and see him (man).'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

Kate went, and was glad of an opportunity of getting away from her (Kate) brother. Every hour the idea was becoming stronger in her (Kate) mind that she (Kate) must in some way separate herself from him (brother). There had come upon him (brother) of late a hard ferocity which made him (brother) unendurable. And then he (brother) carried to such a pitch that hatred, as he (brother) called it, of conventional rules, that he (brother) allowed himself to be controlled by none of the ordinary bonds of society. She (Kate) had felt this heretofore, with a nervous consciousness that she (Kate) was doing wrong in endeavouring to bring about a marriage between him (brother) and Alice; but this demeanour and mode of talking had now so grown upon him (brother) that Kate began to feel herself thankful that Alice had been saved.

Kate went up with her (Kate) uncle and aunt, and saw the face of her (Kate) grandfather for the last time.

``Poor, dear old man!'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, as the easy tears ran down her (Greenow) face.
``Do you remember, John, how he (John) used to scold me, and say that I should never come to good. He (John) has said the same thing to you, Kate, I dare say?'' (unknown)

``He (John) has been very kind to me,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, standing at the foot of the bed. She (Kate) was not one of those whose tears stand near their eyes.

``He (John) was a fine old gentleman,'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
said John Vavasor;--
``belonging to days that are now gone by, but by no means the less of a gentleman on that account. I don't know that he (gentleman) ever did an unjust or ungenerous act to any one. Come, Kate, we may as well go down.'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
Mrs. Greenow lingered to say a word or two to the nurse, of the manner in which Greenow's body was treated when Greenow was lying dead, and then she (Greenow) followed her (Greenow) brother and niece.

George did not go into Penrith, nor did he (George) see Mr. Gogram till that worthy attorney came out to Vavasor Hall on the morning of the funeral. He (attorney) said nothing more on the subject, nor did he (attorney) break the seals on the old upright desk that stood in the parlour. The two days before the funeral were very wretched for all the party, except, perhaps, for Mrs. Greenow, who affected not to understand that her (Greenow) nephew was in a bad humour. She (Greenow) called him (nephew)

``poor George,'' (him)
and treated all his (nephew) incivility to herself as though it were the effect of his (nephew) grief. She (Greenow) asked him (nephew) questions about Parliament, which, of course, he (nephew) didn't answer, and told him (nephew) little stories about poor dear Greenow, not heeding his (nephew) expressions of unmistakable disgust.

The two days at last went by, and the hour of the funeral came. There was the doctor and Gogram, and the uncle and the nephew, to follow the corpse,--the nephew taking upon himself ostentatiously the foremost place, as though he (nephew) could thereby help to maintain his (nephew) pretensions as heir. The clergyman met them at the little wicket-gate of the churchyard, having, by some reasoning, which we hope was satisfactory to himself, overcome a resolution which he (nephew) at first formed, that he (nephew) would not read the burial service over an unrepentant sinner. But he (nephew) did read it, having mentioned his (nephew) scruples to none but one confidential clerical friend in the same diocese.

``I'm told that you have got my grandfather's will,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
George said to the attorney as soon as he (George) saw him (George).

``I have it in my pocket,'' (Mr. Gogram/Gogram)
said Mr. Gogram,
``and purpose to read it as soon as we return from church.'' (Mr. Gogram/Gogram)

``Is it usual to take a will away from a man's house in that way?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
George asked.

``Quite usual,'' (the attorney)
said the attorney;
``and in this case it was done at the express desire of the testator.'' (the attorney)

``I think it is the common practice,'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
said John Vavasor.

George upon this turned round at his (George) uncle as though about to attack him (George), but he (George) restrained himself and said nothing, though he (George) showed his (George) teeth.
