The funeral was very plain, and not a word was spoken by George Vavasor during the journey there and back. John Vavasor asked a few questions of the doctor as to the last weeks of his (Vavasor) father's life; and it was incidentally mentioned, both by the doctor and by the attorney, that the old Squire's intellect had remained unimpaired up to the last moment that he (Squire) had been seen by either of them. When they returned to the hall Mrs. Greenow met them with an invitation to lunch. They all went to the dining-room, and drank each a glass of sherry. George took two or three glasses. The doctor then withdrew, and drove himself back to Penrith, where he (George) lived.

``Shall we go into the other room now?'' (the attorney)
said the attorney.

The three gentlemen then rose up, and went across to the drawing-room, George leading the way. The attorney followed him (George), and John Vavasor closed the door behind them. Had any observer been there to watch them he (Vavasor) might have seen by the faces of the two latter that they expected an unpleasant meeting. Mr. Gogram, as he (Gogram) had walked across the hall, had pulled a document out of his (Gogram) pocket, and held it in his (Gogram) hand as he (Gogram) took a chair. John Vavasor stood behind one of the chairs which had been placed at the table, and leaned upon it, looking across the room, up at the ceiling. George stood on the rug before the fire, with his (George) hands in the pockets of his (George) trousers, and his (George) coat tails over his (George) arms.

``Gentlemen, will you sit down?'' (Mr. Gogram/Gogram)
said Mr. Gogram.

John Vavasor immediately sat down.

``I prefer to stand here,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

Mr. Gogram then opened the document before him (George).

``Before that paper is read,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George,
``I think it right to say a few words. I don't know what it contains, but I believe it to have been executed by my grandfather only an hour or two before his (grandfather) death.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

``On the day before he (grandfather) died,--early in the day,'' (the attorney)
said the attorney.

``Well,--the day before he (grandfather) died; it is the same thing,--while he (grandfather) was dying, in fact. He (grandfather) never got out of bed afterwards.'' (unknown)

``He (grandfather) was not in bed at the time, Mr. Vavasor. Not that it would have mattered if he (Vavasor) had been. And he (Vavasor) came down to dinner on that day. I don't understand, however, why you make these observations.'' (unknown)

``If you'll listen to me you will understand. I make them because I deny my grandfather's fitness to make a will in the last moments of his (grandfather) existence, and at such an age. I saw him (grandfather) a few weeks ago, and he (grandfather) was not fit to be trusted with the management of property then.'' (unknown)

``I do not think this is the time, George, to put forward such objections,'' (the uncle)
said the uncle.

``I think it is,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.
``I believe that that paper purports to be an instrument by which I should be villanously defrauded if it were allowed to be held as good. Therefore I protest against it now, and shall question it at law if action be taken on it. You can read it now, if you please.'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes, I shall read,'' (Mr. Gogram/Gogram)
said Mr. Gogram;
``and I say that it is as valid a will as ever a man signed.'' (Mr. Gogram/Gogram)

``And I say it's not. That's the difference between us.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

The will was read amidst sundry interjections and expressions of anger from George, which it is not necessary to repeat. Nor need I trouble my readers with the will at length. It began by expressing the testator's great desire that his (George) property might descend in his (George) own family, and that the house might be held and inhabited by some one bearing the name of Vavasor. He (George) then declared that he (George) felt himself obliged to pass over his (George) natural heir, believing that the property would not be safe in his (George) hands; he (George) therefore left it in trust to his (George) son John Vavasor, whom he (George) appointed to be sole executor of his (George) will. He (George) devised it to George's eldest son,--should George ever marry and have a son,--as soon as he (George) might reach the age of twenty-five. In the meantime the property should remain in the hands of John Vavasor for his (Vavasor) use and benefit, with a lien on it of five hundred a year to be paid annually to his (Vavasor) granddaughter Kate. In the event of George having no son, the property was to go to the eldest son of Kate, or failing that to the eldest son of his (son) other granddaughter who might take the name of Vavasor. All his (son) personal property he (son) left to his (son) son, John Vavasor.

``And, Mr. Vavasor,'' (the attorney)
said the attorney, as he (Vavasor) finished his (Vavasor) reading,
``you will, I fear, get very little by that latter clause. The estate now owes nothing; but I doubt whether the Squire had fifty pounds in his (Squire) banker's hands when he (Squire) died, and the value of the property about the place is very small. He (Squire) has been unwilling to spend anything during the last ten years, but has paid off every shilling that the property owed.'' (he)

``It is as I supposed,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George. His (George) voice was very unpleasant, and so was the fire of his (George) eyes and the ghastly rage of his (George) scarred face.
``The old man has endeavoured in his (man) anger to rob me of everything because I would not obey him (man) in his (man) wickedness when I was here with him (man) a short while before he (man) died. Such a will as that can stand nowhere.'' (unknown)

``As to that I have nothing to say at present,'' (the attorney)
said the attorney.

``Where is his (man) other will,--the one he (man) made before that?'' (unknown)

``If I remember rightly we executed two before this.'' (unknown)

``And where are they?'' (unknown)

``It is not my business to know, Mr. Vavasor. I believe that I saw him (Vavasor) destroy one, but I have no absolute knowledge. As to the other, I can say nothing.'' (unknown)

``And what do you mean to do?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George, turning to his (George) uncle.

``Do! I shall carry out the will. I have no alternative. Your sister is the person chiefly interested under it. She (sister) gets five hundred a year for her (sister) life; and if she (sister) marries and you don't, or if she (sister) has a son and you don't, her (sister) son will have the whole property.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

George stood for a few moments thinking. Might it not be possible that by means of Alice and Kate together,--by marrying the former,--perhaps, he (George) might still obtain possession of the property? But that which he (George) wanted was the command of the property at once,--the power of raising money upon it instantly. The will had been so framed as to make that impossible in any way. Kate's share in it had not been left to her (Kate) unconditionally, but was to be received even by her (Kate) through the hands of her (Kate) uncle John. Such a will shut him (John) out from all his (John) hopes.

``It is a piece of d-- roguery,'' (he)
he (John) said.

``What do you mean by that, sir?'' (Mr. Gogram/Gogram)
said Gogram, turning round towards him (Gogram).

``I mean exactly what I say. It is a piece of d-- roguery. Who was in the room when that thing was written?'' (unknown)

``The signature was witnessed by--'' (unknown)

``I don't ask as to the signature. Who was in the room when the thing was written?'' (unknown)

``I was here with your grandfather.'' (unknown)

``And no one else?'' (unknown)

``No one else. The presence of any one else at such a time would be very unusual.'' (unknown)

``Then I regard the document simply as waste paper.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
After saying this, George Vavasor left the room, and slammed the door after him (Vavasor).

``I never was insulted in such a way before,'' (the attorney)
said the attorney, almost with tears in his (attorney) eyes.

``He (grandfather) is a disappointed and I fear a ruined man,'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
said John Vavasor.
``I do not think you need regard what he (grandfather) says.'' (unknown)

``But he (grandfather) should not on that account insult me. I have only done my duty. I did not even advise his (grandfather) grandfather. It is mean on his (grandfather) part and unmanly. If he (grandfather) comes in my way again I shall tell him (grandfather) so.'' (unknown)

``He (grandfather) probably will not put himself in your way again, Mr. Gogram.'' (the attorney)

Then the attorney went, having suggested to Mr. Vavasor that he (Vavasor) should instruct his (Vavasor) attorney in London to take steps in reference to the proving of the will.

``It's as good a will as ever was made,'' (Mr. Gogram/Gogram)
said Mr. Gogram.
``If he (Gogram) can set that aside, I'll give up making wills altogether.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

Who was to tell Kate? That was John Vavasor's first thought when he (Vavasor) was left alone at the hall-door, after seeing the lawyer start away. And how was he (lawyer) to get himself back to London without further quarrelling with his (lawyer) nephew? And what was he (lawyer) to do at once with reference to the immediate duties of proprietorship which were entailed upon him (lawyer) as executor? It was by no means improbable, as he (lawyer) thought, that George might assume to himself the position of master of the house; that he (George) might demand the keys, for instance, which no doubt were in Kate's hands at present, and that he (George) would take possession with violence. What should he (George) do under such circumstances? It was clear that he (George) could not run away and get back to his (George) club by the night mail train. He (George) had duties there at the Hall, and these duties were of a nature to make him (George) almost regret the position in which his (George) father's will had placed him (George). Eventually he (George) would gain some considerable increase to his (George) means, but the immediate effect would be terribly troublesome. As he (George) looked up at the melancholy pines which were slowly waving their heads in the wind before the door he (George) declared to himself that he (George) would sell his (George) inheritance and his (George) executorship very cheaply, if such a sale were possible.

In the dining-room he (George) found his (George) sister alone.

``Well, John,'' (she)
said she (sister);
``well? How is it left?'' (she)

``Where is Kate?'' (he)
he (George) asked.

``She (Kate) has gone out with her (Kate) brother.'' (unknown)

``Did he (brother) take his (brother) hat?'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes. He (brother) asked her (Kate) to walk, and she (Kate) went with him (brother) at once.'' (unknown)

``Then, I suppose, he (brother) will tell her (Kate),'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
said John Vavasor. After that he (Vavasor) explained the circumstances of the will to Mrs. Greenow.
``Bravo,'' (the widow)
exclaimed the widow.
``I'm delighted. I love Kate dearly: and now she (Kate) can marry almost whom she (Kate) pleases.'' (unknown)

CHAPTER LVI.

Another Walk on the Fells.

George when he (George) left the room in which he (George) had insulted the lawyer, went immediately across to the parlour in which his (George) aunt and sister were sitting.

``Kate,'' (he)
said he (George),
``put on your hat and come and walk with me. That business is over.'' (he)
Kate's hat and shawl were in the room, and they were out of the house together within a minute.

They walked down the carriage-road, through the desolate, untenanted grounds, to the gate, before either of them spoke a word. Kate was waiting for George to tell her (Kate) of the will, but did not dare to ask any question. George intended to tell her (Kate) of the will, but was not disposed to do so without some preparation. It was a thing not to be spoken of open-mouthed, as a piece of ordinary news.

``Which way shall we go?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, as soon as they had passed through the old rickety gate, which swung at the entrance of the place.
``Up across the fell,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George;
``the day is fine, and I want to get away from my uncle for a time.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
She (Kate) turned round, therefore, outside the hill of firs, and led the way back to the beacon wood through which she (Kate) and Alice had walked across to Haweswater upon a memorable occasion. They had reached the top of the beacon hill, and were out upon the Fell, before George had begun his (George) story. Kate was half beside herself with curiosity, but still she (Kate) was afraid to ask.
``Well,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George, when they paused a moment as they stepped over a plank that crossed the boundary ditch of the wood:
``don't you want to know what that dear old man has done for you?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
Then he (George) looked into her (Kate) face very steadfastly.
``But perhaps you know already,'' (he)
he (George) added. He (George) had come out determined not to quarrel with his (George) sister. He (George) had resolved, in that moment of thought which had been allowed to him (George), that his (George) best hope for the present required that he (George) should keep himself on good terms with her (sister), at any rate till he (George) had settled what line of conduct he (George) would pursue. But he (George) was, in truth, so sore with anger and disappointment,--he (George) had become so nearly mad with that continued, unappeased wrath in which he (George) now indulged against all the world, that he (George) could not refrain himself from bitter words. He (George) was as one driven by the Furies, and was no longer able to control them in their driving of him (George).

``I know nothing of it,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``Had I known I should have told you. Your question is unjust to me.'' (unknown)

``I am beginning to doubt,'' (he)
said he (George),
``whether a man can be safe in trusting any one. My grandfather has done his (grandfather) best to rob me of the property altogether.'' (he)

``I told you that I feared he (grandfather) would do so.'' (unknown)

``And he (grandfather) has made you his (grandfather) heir.'' (unknown)

``Me?'' (unknown)

``Yes; you.'' (unknown)

``He (grandfather) told me distinctly that he (grandfather) would not do that.'' (unknown)

``But he (grandfather) has, I tell you.'' (unknown)

``Then, George, I shall do that which I told him (George) I should do in the event of his (George) making such a will; for he (George) asked me the question. I told him (George) I should restore the estate to you, and upon that he (George) swore that he (George) would not leave it to me.'' (unknown)

``And what a fool you were,'' (he)
said he (George), stopping her (Kate) in the pathway.
``What an ass! Why did you tell him (fool) that? You knew that he (fool) would not, on that account, do justice to me.'' (unknown)

``He (fool) asked me, George.'' (unknown)

``Psha! now you have ruined me, and you might have saved me.'' (unknown)

``But I will save you still, if he (George) has left the estate to me. I do not desire to take it from you. As God in heaven sees me, I have never ceased to endeavour to protect your interests here at Vavasor. I will sign anything necessary to make over my right in the property to you.'' (unknown)
Then they walked on over the Fell for some minutes without speaking. They were still on the same path,--that path which Kate and Alice had taken in the winter,--and now poor Kate could not but think of all that she (Kate) had said that day on George's behalf;--how had she (Kate) mingled truth and falsehood in her (Kate) efforts to raise her (Kate) brother's character in her (Kate) cousin's eyes! It had all been done in vain. At this very moment of her (Kate) own trouble Kate thought of John Grey, and repented of what she (Kate) had done. Her (Kate) hopes in that direction were altogether blasted. She (Kate) knew that her (Kate) brother had ill-treated Alice, and that she (Kate) must tell him (brother) so if Alice's name were mentioned between them. She (Alice) could no longer worship her (Alice) brother, and hold herself at his (brother) command in all things. But, as regarded the property to which he (brother) was naturally the heir, if any act of hers could give it to him (brother), that act would be done.
``If the will is as you say, George, I will make over my right to you.'' (unknown)

``You can make over nothing,'' (he)
he (brother) answered.
``The old robber has been too cunning for that; he (robber) has left it all in the hands of my uncle John. D-- him (John). D-- them both.'' (unknown)

``George! George! he (George) is dead now.'' (unknown)

``Dead; of course he (George) is dead. What of that? I wish he (George) had been dead ten years ago,--or twenty. Do you suppose I am to forgive him (George) because he (George) is dead? I'll heap his (George) grave with curses, if that can be of avail to punish him (George).'' (unknown)

``You can only punish the living that way.'' (unknown)

``And I will punish them;--but not by cursing them. My uncle John shall have such a life of it for the next year or two that he (John) shall bitterly regret the hour in which he (John) has stepped between me and my rights.'' (unknown)

``I do not believe that he (John) has done so.'' (unknown)

``Not done so! What was he (John) down here for at Christmas? Do you pretend to think that that make-believe will was concocted without his (John) knowledge?'' (unknown)

``I'm sure that he (John) knew nothing of it. I don't think my grandfather's mind was made up a week before he (John) died.'' (unknown)

``You'll have to swear that, remember, in a court. I'm not going to let the matter rest, I can tell you. You'll have to prove that. How long is it since he (John) asked you what you would do with the estate if he (John) left it to you?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

Kate thought for a moment before she (Kate) answered.

``It was only two days before he (John) died, if I remember rightly.'' (unknown)

``But you must remember rightly. You'll have to swear to it. And now tell me this honestly; do you believe, in your heart, that he (John) was in a condition fit for making a will?'' (unknown)

``I advised him (John) not to make it.'' (unknown)

``Why? why? What reason did you give?'' (unknown)

``I told him (John) that I thought no man should alter family arrangements when he (man) was so ill.'' (unknown)

``Exactly. You told him (man) that. And what did he (man) say?'' (unknown)

``He (man) was very angry, and made me send for Mr. Gogram.'' (unknown)

``Now, Kate, think a little before you answer me again. If ever you are to do me a good turn, you must do it now. And remember this, I don't at all want to take anything away from you. Whatever you think is fair you shall have.'' (He)

He (brother) was a fool not to have known her (Kate) better than that.

``I want nothing,'' (she)
she (Kate) said, stopping, and stamping with her (Kate) foot upon the crushed heather.
``George, you don't understand what it is to be honest.'' (He)

He (brother) smiled,--with a slight provoking smile that passed very rapidly from his (brother) face. The meaning of the smile was to be read, had Kate been calm enough to read it.

``I can't say that I do.'' (unknown)
That was the meaning of the smile.
``Well, never mind about that,'' (he)
said he (brother);
``you advised my grandfather not to make his (grandfather) will,--thinking, no doubt, that his (grandfather) mind was not clear enough?'' (he)

She (Kate) paused a moment again before she (Kate) answered him (brother).

``His (grandfather) mind was clear,'' (she)
she (Kate) said;
``but I thought that he (grandfather) should not trust his (grandfather) judgement while he (grandfather) was so weak.'' (she)

``Look here, Kate; I do believe that you at any rate have no mind to assist in this robbery. That it is a robbery you can't have any doubt. I said he (grandfather) had left the estate to you. That is not what he (grandfather) has done. He (grandfather) has left the estate to my uncle John.'' (unknown)

``Why tell me, then, what was untrue?'' (unknown)

``Are you disappointed?'' (unknown)

``Of course I am; uncle John won't give it you. George, I don't understand you; I don't, indeed.'' (unknown)

``Never mind about that, but listen to me. The estate is left in the hands of John Vavasor; but he (Vavasor) has left you five hundred a year out of it till somebody is twenty-five years old who is not yet born, and probably never will be born. The will itself shows the old fool to have been mad.'' (unknown)

``He (fool) was no more mad than you are, George.'' (unknown)

``Listen to me, I tell you. I don't mean that he (George) was a raging maniac. Now, you had advised him (George) not to make any new will because you thought he (George) was not in a fit condition?'' (unknown)

``Yes; I did.'' (unknown)

``You can swear to that?'' (unknown)

``I hope I may not be called on to do so. I hope there may be no swearing about it. But if I am asked the question I must swear it.'' (unknown)

``Exactly. Now listen till you understand what it is I mean. That will, if it stands, gives all the power over the estate to John Vavasor. It renders you quite powerless as regards any help or assistance that you might be disposed to give to me. But, nevertheless, your interest under the will is greater than his (Vavasor),--or than that of any one else,--for your son would inherit if I have none. Do you understand?'' (unknown)

``Yes; I think so.'' (unknown)

``And your testimony as to the invalidity of the will would be conclusive against all the world.'' (unknown)

``I would say in a court what I have told you, if that will do any good.'' (unknown)

``It will not be enough. Look here, Kate; you must be steadfast here; everything depends on you. How often have you told me that you will stick to me throughout life? Now you will be tried.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

Kate felt that her (Kate) repugnance towards him (brother),--towards all that he (brother) was doing and wished her (Kate) to do,--was growing stronger within her (Kate) at every word he (brother) spoke. She (Kate) was becoming gradually aware that he (brother) desired from her (Kate) something which she (Kate) could not and would not do, and she (Kate) was aware also that in refusing him (brother) she (Kate) would have to encounter him (brother) in all his (brother) wrath. She (Kate) set her (Kate) teeth firmly together, and clenched her (Kate) little fist. If a fight was necessary, she (Kate) would fight with him (brother). As he (brother) looked at her (Kate) closely with his (brother) sinister eyes, her (Kate) love towards him (brother) was almost turned to hatred.

``But that was what you meant when you advised him (you) not to make the will because you thought his (you) intellect was impaired!'' (unknown)

``No; not so.'' (unknown)

``Stop, Kate, stop. If you will think of it, It was so. What is the meaning of his (you) judgement being weak?'' (unknown)

``I didn't say his (you) judgement was weak.'' (unknown)

``But that was what you meant when you advised him (you) not to trust it!'' (unknown)

``Look here, George; I think I know now what you mean. If anybody asks me if his (George) mind was gone, or his (George) intellect deranged, I cannot say that there was anything of the kind.'' (unknown)

``You will not?'' (unknown)

``Certainly not. It would be untrue.'' (unknown)

``Then you are determined to throw me over and claim the property for yourself.'' (he)
Again he (brother) turned towards and looked at her (Kate) as though he (brother) were resolved to frighten her (Kate).
``And I am to count you also among my enemies? You had better take care, Kate.'' (unknown)

They were now upon the fell side, more than three miles away from the Hall; and Kate, as she (Kate) looked round, saw that they were all alone. Not a cottage,--not a sign of humanity was within sight. Kate saw that it was so, and was aware that the fact pressed itself upon her (Kate) as being of importance. Then she (Kate) thought again of her (Kate) resolution to fight with him (brother), if any fight were necessary; to tell him (brother), in so many words, that she (Kate) would separate herself from him (brother) and defy him (brother). She (Kate) would not fear him (brother), let his (brother) words and face be ever so terrible! Surely her (Kate) own brother would do her (Kate) no bodily harm. And even though he (brother) should do so,--though he (brother) should take her (Kate) roughly by the arm as he (brother) had done to Alice,--though he (brother) should do worse than that, still she (Alice) would fight him (brother). Her (Alice) blood was the same as his (brother), and he (brother) should know that her (Alice) courage was, at any rate, as high.

And, indeed, when she (Alice) looked at him (brother), she (Alice) had cause to fear. He (brother) intended that she (Alice) should fear. He (brother) intended that she (Alice) should dread what he (brother) might do to her (Alice) at that moment. As to what he (brother) would do he (brother) had no resolve made. Neither had he (brother) resolved on anything when he (brother) had gone to Alice and had shaken her (Alice) rudely as she (Alice) sat beside him (brother). He (brother) had been guided by no fixed intent when he (brother) had attacked John Grey, or when he (brother) insulted the attorney; but a Fury was driving him (brother), and he (brother) was conscious of being so driven. He (brother) almost wished to be driven to some act of frenzy. Everything in the world had gone against him (brother), and he (brother) desired to expend his (brother) rage on some one.

``Kate,'' (he)
said he (brother), stopping her (Alice),
``we will have this out here, if you please. So much, at any rate, shall be settled to-day. You have made many promises to me, and I have believed them. You can now keep them all, by simply saying what you know to be the truth,--that that old man was a drivelling idiot when he (man) made this will. Are you prepared to do me that justice? Think before you answer me, for, by G--, if I cannot have justice among you, I will have revenge.'' (her)
And he (brother) put his (brother) hand upon her (Alice) breast up near to her (Alice) throat.

``Take your hand down, George,'' (she)
said she (Alice).
``I'm not such a fool that you can frighten me in that way.'' (unknown)

``Answer me!'' (he)
he (brother) said, and shook her (Alice), having some part of her (Alice) raiment within his (brother) clutch.

``Oh, George, that I should live to be so ashamed of my brother!'' (unknown)

``Answer me,'' (he)
he (brother) said again; and again he (brother) shook her (Alice).

``I have answered you. I will say nothing of the kind that you want me to say. My grandfather, up to the latest moment that I saw him (grandfather), knew what he (grandfather) was about. He (grandfather) was not an idiot. He (grandfather) was, I believe, only carrying out a purpose fixed long before. You will not make me change what I say by looking at me like that, nor get it by shaking me. You don't know me, George, if you think you can frighten me like a child.'' (He)

He (brother) heard her (Alice) to the last word, still keeping his (brother) hand upon her (Alice), and holding her (Alice) by the cloak she (Alice) wore; but the violence of his (brother) grasp had relaxed itself, and he (brother) let her (Alice) finish her (Alice) words, as though his (brother) object had simply been to make her (Alice) speak out to him (brother) what she (Alice) had to say.

``Oh,'' (he)
said he (brother), when she (Alice) had done,
``That's to be it; is it? That's your idea of honesty. The very name of the money being your own has been too much for you. I wonder whether you and my uncle had contrived it all between you beforehand?'' (she)

``You will not dare to ask him (uncle), because he (uncle) is a man,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, her (Kate) eyes brimming with tears, not through fear, but in very vexation at the nature of the charge he (brother) had brought against her (Kate).

``Shall I not? You will see what I dare do. As for you, with all your promises--. Kate, you know that I keep my word. Say that you will do as I desire you, or I will be the death of you.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean that you will murder me?'' (she)
said she (Kate).

``Murder you! yes; why not? Treated as I have been among you, do you suppose that I shall stick at anything? Why should I not murder you--you and Alice, too, seeing how you have betrayed me?'' (unknown)

``Poor Alice!'' (she)
As she (Kate) spoke the words she (Kate) looked straight into his (brother) eyes, as though defying him (brother), as far as she (Kate) herself were concerned.

``Poor Alice, indeed! D-- hypocrite! There's a pair of you; cursed, whining, false, intriguing hypocrites. There; go down and tell your uncle and that old woman there that I threatened to murder you. Tell the judge so, when you're brought into court to swear me out of my property. You false liar!'' (he)
Then he (brother) pushed her (Kate) from him (brother) with great violence, so that she (Kate) fell heavily upon the stony ground.

He (brother) did not stop to help her (Kate) up, or even to look at her (Kate) as she (Kate) lay, but walked away across the heath, neither taking the track on towards Haweswater, nor returning by the path which had brought them thither. He (brother) went away northwards across the wild fell; and Kate, having risen up and seated herself on a small cairn of stones which stood there, watched him (brother) as he (brother) descended the slope of the hill till he (brother) was out of sight. He (brother) did not run, but he (brother) seemed to move rapidly, and he (brother) never once turned round to look at her (Kate). He (brother) went away, down the hill northwards, and presently the curving of the ground hid him (brother) from her (Kate) view.

When she (Kate) first seated herself her (Kate) thoughts had been altogether of him (brother). She (Kate) had feared no personal injury, even when she (Kate) had asked him (brother) whether he (brother) would murder her (Kate). Her (Kate) blood had been hot within her (Kate) veins, and her (Kate) heart had been full of defiance. Even yet she (Kate) feared nothing, but continued to think of him (brother) and his (brother) misery, and his (brother) disgrace. That he (brother) was gone for ever, utterly and irretrievably ruined, thrown out, as it were, beyond the pale of men, was now certain to her (Kate). And this was the brother in whom she (Kate) had believed; for whom she (Kate) had not only been willing to sacrifice herself, but for whose purposes she (Kate) had striven to sacrifice her (Kate) cousin! What would he (cousin) do now? As he (cousin) passed from out of her (Kate) sight down the hill, it seemed to her (Kate) as though he (cousin) were rushing straight into some hell from which there could be no escape.

-LSB-Illustration: Kate.-RSB-

She (Kate) knew that her (Kate) arm had been hurt in the fall, but for a while she (Kate) would not move it or feel it, being resolved to take no account of what might have happened to herself. But when he (cousin) had been gone some ten minutes, she (Kate) rose to her (Kate) feet, and finding that the movement pained her (Kate) greatly, and that her (Kate) right arm was powerless, she (Kate) put up her (Kate) left hand and became aware that the bone of her (Kate) arm was broken below the elbow. Her (Kate) first thought was given to the telling him (cousin) of this, or the not telling, when she (Kate) should meet him (cousin) below at the house. How should she (Kate) mention the accident to him (cousin)? Should she (Kate) lie, and say that she (Kate) had fallen as she (Kate) came down the hill alone? Of course he (cousin) would not believe her (Kate), but still some such excuse as that might make the matter easier for them all. It did not occur to her (Kate) that she (Kate) might not see him (cousin) again at all that day; and that, as far as he (cousin) was concerned, there might be need for no lie.

She (Kate) started off to walk down home, holding her (Kate) right arm steadily against her (Kate) body with her (Kate) left hand. Of course she (Kate) must give some account of herself when she (Kate) got to the house; but it was of the account to be given to him (cousin) that she (Kate) thought. As to the others she (Kate) cared little for them.

``Here I am; my arm is broken; and you had better send for a doctor.'' (unknown)
That would be sufficient for them.

When she (Kate) got into the wood the path was very dark. The heavens were overcast with clouds, and a few drops began to fall. Then the rain fell faster and faster, and before she (Kate) had gone a quarter of a mile down the beacon hill, the clouds had opened themselves, and the shower had become a storm of water. Suffering as she (Kate) was she (Kate) stood up for a few moments under a large tree, taking the excuse of the rain for some minutes of delay, that she (Kate) might make up her (Kate) mind as to what she (Kate) would say. Then it occurred to her (Kate) that she (Kate) might possibly meet him (Kate) again before she (Kate) reached the house; and, as she (Kate) thought of it, she (Kate) began for the first time to fear him (Kate). Would he (Kate) come out upon her (Kate) from the trees and really kill her (Kate)? Had he (Kate) made his (Kate) way round, when he (Kate) got out of her (Kate) sight, that he (Kate) might fall upon her (Kate) suddenly and do as he (Kate) had threatened? As the idea came upon her (Kate), she (Kate) made a little attempt to run, but she (Kate) found that running was impracticable from the pain the movement caused her (Kate). Then she (Kate) walked on through the hard rain, steadily holding her (Kate) arm against her (Kate) side, but still looking every moment through the trees on the side from which George might be expected to reach her (Kate). But no one came near her (Kate) on her (Kate) way homewards. Had she (Kate) been calm enough to think of the nature of the ground, she (Kate) might have known that he (George) could not have returned upon her (Kate) so quickly. He (George) must have come back up the steep hill-side which she (Kate) had seen him (George) descend. No;--he (George) had gone away altogether, across the fells towards Bampton, and was at this moment vainly buttoning his (George) coat across his (George) breast, in his (George) unconscious attempt to keep out the wet. The Fury was driving him (George) on, and he (George) himself was not aware whither he (George) was driven.

Dinner at the Hall had been ordered at five, the old hour; or rather that had been assumed to be the hour for dinner without any ordering. It was just five when Kate reached the front door. This she (Kate) opened with her (Kate) left hand, and turning at once into the dining-room, found her (Kate) uncle and her (Kate) aunt standing before the fire.

``Dinner is ready,'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
said John Vavasor;
``where is George?'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)

``You are wet, Kate,'' (aunt)
said aunt Greenow.

``Yes, I am very wet,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``I must go up-stairs. Perhaps you'll come with me, aunt?'' (unknown)

``Come with you,--of course I will.'' (Aunt)
Aunt Greenow had seen at once that something was amiss.

``Where's George?'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
said John Vavasor.
``Has he (George) come back with you, or are we to wait for him (George)?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

Kate seated herself in her (Kate) chair.

``I don't quite know where he (George) is,'' (she)
she (Kate) said. In the meantime her (Kate) aunt had hastened up to her (aunt) side just in time to catch her (aunt) as she (aunt) was falling from her (aunt) chair.
``My arm,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate, very gently;
``my arm!'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Then she (Kate) slipped down against her (Kate) aunt, and had fainted.

``He (George) has done her (aunt) a mischief,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, looking up at her (Greenow) brother.
``This is his (George) doing.'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)

John Vavasor stood confounded, wishing himself back in Queen Anne Street.

CHAPTER LVII.

Showing How the Wild Beast Got Himself Back from the Mountains.

About eleven o'clock on that night,--the night of the day on which Kate Vavasor's arm had been broken,--there came a gentle knock at Kate's bedroom door. There was nothing surprising in this, as of all the household Kate only was in bed. Her (Kate) aunt was sitting at this time by her (aunt) bedside, and the doctor, who had been summoned from Penrith and who had set her (aunt) broken arm, was still in the house, talking over the accident with John Vavasor in the dining-room, before he (Vavasor) proceeded back on his (Vavasor) journey home.

``She (aunt) will do very well,'' (the doctor)
said the doctor.
``It's only a simple fracture. I'll see her (aunt) the day after to-morrow.'' (unknown)

``Is it not odd that such an accident should come from a fall whilst walking?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
asked Mr. Vavasor.

The doctor shrugged his (Vavasor) shoulders.

``One never can say how anything may occur,'' (he)
said he (Vavasor).
``I know a young woman who broke the os femoris by just kicking her (woman) cat;--at least, she (woman) said she (woman) did.'' (unknown)

``Indeed! I suppose you didn't take any trouble to inquire?'' (unknown)

``Not much. My business was with the injury, not with the way she (woman) got it. Somebody did make inquiry, but she (woman) stuck to her (woman) story and nothing came of it. Good night, Mr. Vavasor. Don't trouble her (woman) with questions till she (woman) has had some hours' sleep, at any rate.'' (the doctor)
Then the doctor went, and John Vavasor was left alone, standing with his (Vavasor) back to the dining-room fire.

There had been so much trouble and confusion in the house since Kate had fainted, almost immediately upon her (Kate) reaching home, that Mr. Vavasor had not yet had time to make up his (Vavasor) mind as to the nature of the accident which had occurred. Mrs. Greenow had at once ascertained that the bone was broken, and the doctor had been sent for. Luckily he (doctor) had been found at home, and had reached the Hall a little before ten o'clock. In the meantime, as soon as Kate recovered her (Kate) senses, she (Kate) volunteered her (Kate) account of what had occurred.

Her (Kate) brother had quarrelled with her (Kate) about the will, she (Kate) said, and had left her (Kate) abruptly on the mountain. She (Kate) had fallen, she (Kate) went on to say, as she (Kate) turned from him (brother), and had at once found that she (Kate) had hurt herself. But she (Kate) had been too angry with him (brother) to let him (brother) know it; and, indeed, she (Kate) had not known the extent herself till he (brother) had passed out of her (Kate) sight. This was her (Kate) story; and there was nothing in it that was false by the letter, though there was much that was false in the spirit. It was certainly true that George had not known that she (Kate) was injured. It was true that she (Kate) had asked him (George) for no help. It was true, in one sense, that she (Kate) had fallen, and it was true that she (Kate) had not herself known how severe had been the injury done to her (Kate) till he (George) had gone beyond the reach of her (Kate) voice. But she (Kate) repressed all mention of his (George) violence, and when she (Kate) was pressed as to the nature of the quarrel, she (Kate) declined to speak further on that matter.

Neither her (Kate) uncle nor her (Kate) aunt believed her (Kate). That was a matter of course, and she (Kate) knew that they did not believe her (Kate). George's absence, their recent experience of his (George) moods, and the violence by which her (Kate) arm must have been broken, made them certain that Kate had more to tell if she (Kate) chose to tell it. But in her (Kate) present condition they could not question her (Kate). Mrs. Greenow did ask as to the probability of her (Greenow) nephew's return.

``I can only tell you,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate,
``that he (Vavasor) went away across the Fell in the direction of Bampton. Perhaps he (Vavasor) has gone on to Penrith. He (Vavasor) was very angry with us all; and as the house is not his (Vavasor) own, he (Vavasor) has probably resolved that he (Vavasor) will not stay another night under the roof. But, who can say? He (Vavasor) is not in his (Vavasor) senses when he (Vavasor) is angered.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

John Vavasor, as he (Vavasor) stood alone after the doctor's departure, endeavoured to ascertain the truth by thinking of it.

``I am sure,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) said to himself,
``that the doctor suspects that there has been violence. I know it from his (doctor) tone, and I can see it in his (doctor) eye. But how to prove it? and would there be good in proving it? Poor girl! Will it not be better for her (girl) to let it pass as though we believed her (girl) story?'' (he)
He (Vavasor) made up his (Vavasor) mind that it would be better. Why should he (Vavasor) take upon himself the terrible task of calling this insane relation to account for an act which he (Vavasor) could not prove? The will itself, without that trouble, would give him (Vavasor) trouble enough. Then he (Vavasor) began to long that he (Vavasor) was back at his (Vavasor) club, and to think that the signing-room in Chancery Lane was not so bad. And so he (Vavasor) went up to his (Vavasor) bed, calling at Kate's door to ask after the patient.

In the meantime there had come a messenger to Mrs. Greenow, who had stationed herself with her (Greenow) niece. One of the girls of the house brought up a scrap of paper to the door, saying that a boy had brought it over with a cart from Shap, and that it was intended for Miss Vavasor, and it was she (Greenow) who knocked at the sickroom door. The note was open and was not addressed; indeed, the words were written on a scrap of paper that was crumpled up rather than folded, and were as follows:

``Send me my clothes by the bearer. I shall not return to the house.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
Mrs. Greenow took it in to Kate, and then went away to see her (Kate) nephew's things duly put into his (nephew) portmanteau. This was sent away in the cart, and Mr. Vavasor, as he (Vavasor) went up-stairs, was told what had been done.

Neither on that night or on the following day did Mrs. Greenow ask any further questions; but on the morning after that, when the doctor had left them with a good account of the broken limb, her (Greenow) curiosity would brook no further delay. And, indeed, indignation as well as curiosity urged her (Greenow) on. In disposition she (Greenow) was less easy, and, perhaps, less selfish, than her (Greenow) brother. If it were the case that that man had ill-treated his (man) sister, she (Greenow) would have sacrificed much to bring him (man) to punishment.

``Kate,'' (she)
she (Greenow) said, when the doctor was gone,
``I expect that you will tell me the whole truth as to what occurred between you and your brother when you had this accident.'' (the doctor)

``I have told you the truth.'' (unknown)

``But not the whole truth.'' (unknown)

``All the truth I mean to tell, aunt. He (brother) has quarrelled with me, as I think, most unnecessarily, but you don't suppose that I am going to give an exact account of the quarrel? We were both wrong, probably, and so let there be an end of it.'' (unknown)

``Was he (brother) violent to you when he (brother) quarrelled with you?'' (unknown)

``When he (brother) is angry he (brother) is always violent in his (brother) language.'' (unknown)

``But, did he (brother) strike you?'' (unknown)

``Dear aunt, don't be angry with me if I say that I won't be cross-examined. I would rather answer no more questions about it. I know that questioning can do no good.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

Mrs. Greenow knew her (Greenow) niece well enough to be aware that nothing more would be told her (Greenow), but she (Greenow) was quite sure now that Kate had not broken her (Kate) arm by a simple fall. She (Kate) was certain that the injury had come from positive violence. Had it not been so, Kate would not have contented herself with refusing to answer the last question that had been asked, but would also have repelled the charge made against her (Kate) brother with indignation.

``You must have it your own way,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow;
``but let me just tell you this, that your brother George had better keep out of my way.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

``It is probable that he (George) will,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``Especially if you remain here to nurse me.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)

Kate's conduct in answering all the questions made to her (Kate) was not difficult, but she (Kate) found that there was much difficulty in planning her (Kate) own future behaviour towards her (Kate) own brother. Must she (Kate) abandon him (brother) altogether from henceforth; divide herself from him (brother), as it were; have perfectly separate interests, and interests that were indeed hostile? and must she (Kate) see him (brother) ruined and overwhelmed by want of money, while she (Kate) had been made a rich woman by her (Kate) grandfather's will? It will be remembered that her (Kate) life had hitherto been devoted to him (grandfather); that all her (Kate) schemes and plans had had his (grandfather) success as their object; that she (Kate) had taught herself to consider it to be her (Kate) duty to sacrifice everything to his (grandfather) welfare. It is very sad to abandon the only object of a life! It is very hard to tear out from one's heart and fling away from it the only love that one has cherished! What was she (Kate) to say to Alice about all this--to Alice whom she (Alice) had cheated of a husband worthy of her (Alice), that she (Alice) might allure her (Alice) into the arms of one so utterly unworthy? Luckily for Kate, her (Kate) accident was of such a nature that any writing to Alice was now out of the question.

But a blow! What woman can bear a blow from a man, and afterwards return to him (man) with love? A wife may have to bear it and to return. And she (wife) may return with that sort of love which is a thing of custom. The man is the father of her (wife) children, and earns the bread which they eat and which she (wife) eats. Habit and the ways of the world require that she (wife) should be careful in his (man) interests, and that she (wife) should live with him (man) in what amity is possible to them. But as for love,--all that we mean by love when we speak of it and write of it,--a blow given by the defender to the defenceless crushes it all! A woman may forgive deceit, treachery, desertion,--even the preference given to a rival. She (woman) may forgive them and forget them; but I do not think that a woman can forget a blow. And as for forgiveness,--it is not the blow that she (woman) cannot forgive, but the meanness of spirit that made it possible.

Kate, as she (Kate) thought of it, told herself that everything in life was over for her (Kate). She (Kate) had long feared her (Kate) brother's nature,--had feared that he (brother) was hard and heartless; but still there had been some hope with her (Kate) fear. Success, if he (brother) could be made to achieve it, would soften him (brother), and then all might be right. But now all was wrong, and she (Kate) knew that it was so. When he (brother) had compelled her (Kate) to write to Alice for money, her (Alice) faith in him (brother) had almost succumbed. That had been very mean, and the meanness had shocked her (Alice). But now he (brother) had asked her (Alice) to perjure herself that he (brother) might have his (brother) own way, and had threatened to murder her (Alice), and had raised his (brother) hand against her (Alice) because she (Alice) had refused to obey him (brother). And he (brother) had accused her (Alice) of treachery to himself,--had accused her (Alice) of premeditated deceit in obtaining this property for herself!

``But he (George) does not believe it,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate to herself.
``He (George) said that because he (George) thought it would vex me; but I know he (George) does not think it.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Kate had watched her (Kate) brother longing for money all his (brother) life,--had thoroughly understood the intensity of his (brother) wish for it,--the agony of his (brother) desire. But so far removed was she (Kate) from any such longing on her (Kate) own account, that she (Kate) could not believe that her (Kate) brother would in his (brother) heart accuse her (Kate) of it. How often had she (Kate) offered to give him (brother), on the instant, every shilling that she (Kate) had in the world! At this moment she (Kate) resolved, in her (Kate) mind, that she (Kate) never wished to see him (brother) more; but even now, had it been practicable, she (Kate) would have made over to him (brother), without any drawback, all her (Kate) interest in the Vavasor estate.

But any such making over was impossible. John Vavasor remained in Westmoreland for a week, and during that time many discussions were, of course, held about the property. Mr. Round came down from London, and met Mr. Gogram at Penrith. As to the validity of the will Mr. Round said that there was no shadow of a doubt. So an agent was appointed for receiving the rents, and it was agreed that the old Hall should be let in six months from that date. In the meantime Kate was to remain there till her (Kate) arm should become strong, and she (Kate) could make her (Kate) plans for the future. Aunt Greenow promised to remain at the Hall for the present, and offered, indeed, indefinite services for the future, as though she (Greenow) were quite forgetful of Captain Bellfield. Of Mr. Cheesacre she (Bellfield) was not forgetful, for she (Bellfield) still continued to speak of that gentleman to Kate, as though he (gentleman) were Kate's suitor. But she (Kate) did not now press upon her (Kate) niece the acceptance of Mr. Cheesacre's hand as an absolute duty. Kate was mistress of a considerable fortune, and though such a marriage might be comfortable, it was no longer necessary. Mrs. Greenow called him (Cheesacre) poor Cheesacre, pointing out how easily he (Cheesacre) might be managed, and how indubitable were his (Cheesacre) possessions; but she (Greenow) no longer spoke of Kate's chances in the marriage market as desperate, even though she (Kate) should decline the Cheesacre alliance.

``A young woman, with six hundred a year, my dear, may do pretty nearly what she (woman) pleases,'' (aunt)
said aunt Greenow.
``It's better than having ten years' grace given you.'' (unknown)

``And will last longer, certainly,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

Kate's desire was that Alice should come down to her (Kate) for a while in Westmoreland, before the six months were over, and this desire she (Kate) mentioned to her (Kate) uncle. He (uncle) promised to carry the message up to Alice, but could not be got to say more than that upon the subject. Then Mr. Vavasor went away, leaving the aunt and niece together at the Hall.

``What on earth shall we do if that wild beast shows himself suddenly among us women?'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
asked Mrs. Greenow of her (Greenow) brother.

The brother could only say,

``that he (George) hoped the wild beast would keep his (George) distance.'' (The brother)

And the wild beast did keep his (brother) distance, at any rate as long as Mrs. Greenow remained at the Hall. We will now go back to the wild beast, and tell how he (brother) walked across the mountains, in the rain, to Bampton, a little village at the foot of Haweswater. It will be remembered that after he (brother) had struck his (brother) sister, he (brother) turned away from her (sister), and walked with quick steps down the mountain-side, never turning back to look at her (sister). He (brother) had found himself to be without any power of persuasion over her (sister), as regarded her (sister) evidence to be given, if the will were questioned. The more he (brother) threatened her (sister) the steadier she (sister) had been in asserting her (sister) belief in her (sister) grandfather's capacity. She (sister) had looked into his (brother) eye and defied him (brother), and he (brother) had felt himself to be worsted. What was he (brother) to do? In truth, there was nothing for him (brother) to do. He (brother) had told her (sister) that he (brother) would murder her (sister); and in the state of mind to which his (brother) fury had driven him (brother), murder had suggested itself to him (brother) as a resource to which he (brother) might apply himself. But what could he (brother) gain by murdering her (sister),--or, at any rate, by murdering her (sister) then, out on the mountain-side? Nothing but a hanging! There would be no gratification even to his (brother) revenge. If, indeed, he (brother) had murdered that old man, who was now, unfortunately, gone beyond the reach of murder;--if he (brother) could have poisoned the old man's cup before that last will had been made--there might have been something in such a deed! But he (brother) had merely thought of it, letting

``I dare not wait upon I would'' (he)
--as he (brother) now told himself, with much self-reproach. Nothing was to be got by killing his (brother) sister. So he (brother) restrained himself in his (brother) passion, and walked away from her (sister), solitary, down the mountain.

The rain soon came on, and found him (brother) exposed on the hill-side. He (brother) thought little about it, but buttoned his (brother) coat, as I have said before, and strode on. It was a storm of rain, so that he (brother) was forced to hold his (brother) head to one side, as it hit him (brother) from the north. But with his (brother) hand to his (brother) hat, and his (brother) head bent against the wind, he (brother) went on till he (brother) had reached the valley at the foot, and found that the track by which he (brother) had been led thither had become a road. He (brother) had never known the mountains round the Hall as Kate had known them, and was not aware whither he (brother) was going. On one thing only had he (brother) made up his (brother) mind since he (brother) had left his (brother) sister, and that was that he (brother) would not return to the house. He (brother) knew that he (brother) could do nothing there to serve his (brother) purpose; his (brother) threats would be vain impotence; he (brother) had no longer any friend in the house. He (brother) could hardly tell himself what line of conduct he (brother) would pursue, but he (brother) thought that he (brother) would hurry back to London, and grasp at whatever money he (brother) could get from Alice. He (brother) was still, at this moment, a Member of Parliament; and as the rain drenched him (Member) through and through, he (Member) endeavoured to get consolation from the remembrance of that fact in his (Member) favour.

As he (Member) got near the village he (Member) overtook a shepherd boy coming down from the hills, and learned his (Member) whereabouts from him (Member).

``Baampton,'' (the boy)
said the boy, with an accent that was almost Scotch, when he (boy) was asked the name of the place. When Vavasor further asked whether a gig were kept there, the boy simply stared at him (boy), not knowing a gig by that name. At last, however, he (boy) was made to understand the nature of his (boy) companion's want, and expressed his (boy) belief that
``John Applethwaite, up at the Craigs yon, had got a mickle cart.'' (companion)
But the Craigs was a farm-house, which now came in view about a mile off, up across the valley; and Vavasor, hoping that he (boy) might still find a speedier conveyance than John Applethwaite's mickle cart, went on to the public-house in the village. But, in truth, neither there, nor yet from John Applethwaite, to whom at last an application was sent, could he (Applethwaite) get any vehicle; and between six and seven he (Applethwaite) started off again, through the rain, to make his (Applethwaite) weary way on foot to Shap. The distance was about five miles, and the little byways, lying between walls, were sticky, and almost glutinous with light-coloured, chalky mud. Before he (Applethwaite) started he (Applethwaite) took a glass of hot rum-and-water, but the effect of that soon passed away from him (Applethwaite), and then he (Applethwaite) became colder and weaker than he (Applethwaite) had been before.

Wearily and wretchedly he (Applethwaite) plodded on. A man may be very weary in such a walk as that, and yet be by no means wretched. Tired, hungry, cold, wet, and nearly penniless, I have sat me down and slept among those mountain tracks,--have slept because nature refused to allow longer wakefulness. But my heart has been as light as my purse, and there has been something in the air of the hills that made me buoyant and happy in the midst of my weariness. But George Vavasor was wretched as well as weary, and every step that he (Vavasor) took, plodding through the mud, was a new misfortune to him (Vavasor). What are five miles of a walk to a young man, even though the rain be falling and the ways be dirty? what, though they may come after some other ten that he (man) has already traversed on his (man) feet? His (man) sister Kate would have thought nothing of the distance. But George stopped on his (George) way from time to time, leaning on the loose walls, and cursing the misfortune that had brought him (George) to such a pass. He (George) cursed his (George) grandfather, his (George) uncle, his (George) sister, his (George) cousin, and himself. He (George) cursed the place in which his (George) forefathers had lived, and he (George) cursed the whole county. He (George) cursed the rain, and the wind, and his (George) town-made boots, which would not keep out the wet slush. He (George) cursed the light as it faded, and the darkness as it came. Over and over again he (George) cursed the will that had robbed him (George), and the attorney that had made it. He (George) cursed the mother that had borne him (George) and the father that had left him (George) poor. He (George) thought of Scruby, and cursed him (George), thinking how that money would be again required of him (George) by that stern agent. He (George) cursed the House of Commons, which had cost him (George) so much, and the greedy electors who would not send him (George) there without his (George) paying for it. He (George) cursed John Grey, as he (Grey) thought of those two thousand pounds, with double curses. He (Grey) cursed this world, and all worlds beyond; and thus, cursing everything, he (Grey) made his (Grey) way at last up to the inn at Shap.

It was nearly nine when he (Grey) got there. He (Grey) had wasted over an hour at Bampton in his (Grey) endeavour to get John Applethwaite's cart to carry him (Grey) on, and he (Grey) had been two hours on his (Grey) walk from Bampton to Shap,--two hours amidst his (Grey) cursing. He (Grey) ordered supper and brandy-and-water, and, as we know, sent off a Mercury for his (Grey) clothes. But the Mercuries of Westmoreland do not move on quick wings, and it was past midnight before he (Grey) got his (Grey) possessions. During all this time he (Grey) had, by no means, ceased from cursing, but continued it over his (Grey) broiled ham and while he (Grey) swallowed his (Grey) brandy-and-water. He (Grey) swore aloud, so that the red-armed servant at the inn could not but hear him (servant), that those thieves at the Hall intended to rob him (servant) of his (servant) clothes;--that they would not send him (servant) his (servant) property. He (servant) could not restrain himself, though he (servant) knew that every word he (servant) uttered would injure his (servant) cause, as regarded the property in Westmoreland, if ever he (servant) could make a cause. He (servant) knew that he (servant) had been mad to strike his (servant) sister, and cursed himself for his (servant) madness. Yet he (servant) could not restrain himself. He (servant) told himself that the battle for him (servant) was over, and he (servant) thought of poison for himself. He (servant) thought of poison, and a pistol,--of the pistols he (servant) had ever loaded at home, each with six shots, good for a life apiece. He (servant) thought of an express train, rushing along at its full career, and of the instant annihilation which it would produce. But if that was to be the end of him (servant), he (servant) would not go alone. No, indeed! why should he (servant) go alone, leaving those pistols ready loaded in his (servant) desk? Among them they had brought him (servant) to ruin and to death. Was he (servant) a man to pardon his (servant) enemies when it was within his (servant) power to take them with him (servant), down, down, down--? What were the last words upon his (servant) impious lips, as with bloodshot eyes, half drunk, and driven by the Fury, he (servant) took himself off to the bed prepared for him (servant), cursing aloud the poor red-haired girl as he (servant) went, I may not utter here.

CHAPTER LVIII.

The Pallisers at Breakfast.

Gentle reader, do you remember Lady Monk's party, and how it ended,--how it ended, at least as regards those special guests with whom we are concerned? Mr. Palliser went away early, Mrs. Marsham followed him (Palliser) to his (Palliser) house in Park Lane, caught him (Palliser) at home, and told her (Marsham) tale. He (Palliser) returned to his (Palliser) wife, found her (Marsham) sitting with Burgo in the dining-room, under the Argus eyes of the constant Bott, and bore her (Marsham) away home. Burgo disappeared utterly from the scene, and Mr. Bott, complaining inwardly that virtue was too frequently allowed to be its own reward, comforted himself with champagne, and then walked off to his (Bott) lodgings. Lady Monk, when Mr. Palliser made his (Palliser) way into her (Monk) room up-stairs, seeking his (Palliser) wife's scarf,--which little incident, also, the reader may perhaps remember,--saw that the game was up, and thought with regret of the loss of her (Monk) two hundred pounds. Such was the ending of Lady Monk's party.

Lady Glencora, on her (Glencora) journey home in the carriage with her (Glencora) husband, had openly suggested that Mrs. Marsham had gone to Park Lane to tell of her (Marsham) doings with Burgo, and had declared her (Marsham) resolution never again to see either that lady or Mr. Bott in her (Marsham) own house. This she (Marsham) said with more of defiance in her (Marsham) tone than Mr. Palliser had ever hitherto heard. He (Palliser) was by nature less ready than her (Marsham), and knowing his (Palliser) own deficiency in that respect, abstained from all answer on the subject. Indeed, during that drive home very few further words were spoken between them.

``I will breakfast with you to-morrow,'' (he)
he (Palliser) said to her (Marsham), as she (Marsham) prepared to go up-stairs.
``I have work still to do to-night, and I will not disturb you by coming to your room.'' (unknown)

``You won't want me to be very early?'' (wife)
said his (Palliser) wife.

``No,'' (he)
said he (Palliser), with more of anger in his (Palliser) voice than he (Palliser) had yet shown.
``What hour will suit you? I must say something of what has occurred to-night before I leave you to-morrow.'' (unknown)

``I don't know what you can have got to say about to-night, but I'll be down by half-past eleven, if that will do?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Mr. Palliser said that he (Palliser) would make it do, and then they parted.

Lady Glencora had played her (Glencora) part very well before her (Glencora) husband. She (Glencora) had declined to be frightened by him (husband); had been the first to mention Burgo's name, and had done so with no tremor in her (Glencora) voice, and had boldly declared her (Glencora) irreconcilable enmity to the male and female duennas who had dared to take her (Glencora) in charge. While she (Glencora) was in the carriage with her (Glencora) husband she (Glencora) felt some triumph in her (Glencora) own strength; and as she (Glencora) wished him (husband) good night on the staircase, and slowly walked up to her (Glencora) room, without having once lowered her (Glencora) eyes before his (husband), something of this consciousness of triumph still supported her (Glencora). And even while her (Glencora) maid remained with her (Glencora) she (Glencora) held herself up, as it were, inwardly, telling herself that she (Glencora) would not yield,--that she (Glencora) would not be cowed either by her (Glencora) husband or by his (husband) spies. But when she (Glencora) was left alone all her (Glencora) triumph departed from her (Glencora).

She (Glencora) bade her (Glencora) maid go while she (Glencora) was still sitting in her (Glencora) dressing-gown; and when the girl was gone she (Glencora) got close over the fire, sitting with her (Glencora) slippers on the fender, with her (Glencora) elbows on her (Glencora) knees, and her (Glencora) face resting on her (Glencora) hands. In this position she (Glencora) remained for an hour, with her (Glencora) eyes fixed on the altering shapes of the hot coals. During this hour her (Glencora) spirit was by no means defiant, and her (Glencora) thoughts of herself anything but triumphant. Mr. Bott and Mrs. Marsham she (Marsham) had forgotten altogether. After all, they were but buzzing flies, who annoyed her (Marsham) by their presence. Should she (Marsham) choose to leave her (Marsham) husband, they could not prevent her (Marsham) leaving him (husband). It was of her (Marsham) husband and of Burgo that she (Marsham) was thinking,--weighing them one against the other, and connecting her (Marsham) own existence with theirs, not as expecting joy or the comfort of love from either of them, but with an assured conviction that on either side there must be misery for her (Marsham). But of that shame before all the world which must be hers for ever, should she (Marsham) break her (Marsham) vows and consent to live with a man who was not her (Marsham) husband, she (Marsham) thought hardly at all. That which in the estimation of Alice was everything, to her (Alice), at this moment, was almost nothing. For herself, she (Alice) had been sacrificed; and,--as she (Alice) told herself with bitter denunciations against herself,--had been sacrificed through her (Alice) own weakness. But that was done. Whatever way she (Alice) might go, she (Alice) was lost. They had married her (Alice) to a man who cared nothing for a wife, nothing for any woman,--so at least she (Alice) declared to herself,--but who had wanted a wife that he (man) might have an heir. Had it been given to her (Alice) to have a child, she (Alice) thought that she (Alice) might have been happy,--sufficiently happy in sharing her (Alice) husband's joy in that respect. But everything had gone against her (Alice). There was nothing in her (Alice) home to give her (Alice) comfort.

``He (I) looks at me every time he (I) sees me as the cause of his (I) misfortune,'' (she)
she (Alice) said to herself. Of her (Alice) husband's rank, of the future possession of his (husband) title and his (husband) estates, she (Alice) thought much. But of her (Alice) own wealth she (Alice) thought nothing. It did not occur to her (Alice) that she (Alice) had given him (husband) enough in that respect to make his (husband) marriage with her (Alice) a comfort to him (husband). She (Alice) took it for granted that that marriage was now one distasteful to him (husband), as it was to herself, and that he (husband) would eventually be the gainer if she (Alice) should so conduct herself that her (Alice) marriage might be dissolved.

-LSB-Illustration: Lady Glencora.-RSB-

As to Burgo, I doubt whether she (Glencora) deceived herself much as to his (Burgo) character. She (Glencora) knew well enough that he (Burgo) was a man infinitely less worthy than her (Glencora) husband. She (Glencora) knew that he (husband) was a spendthrift, idle, given to bad courses,--that he (husband) drank, that he (husband) gambled, that he (husband) lived the life of the loosest man about the town. She (Glencora) knew also that whatever chance she (Glencora) might have had to redeem him (husband), had she (Glencora) married him (husband) honestly before all the world, there could be no such chance if she (Glencora) went to him (husband) as his (husband) mistress, abandoning her (Glencora) husband and all her (Glencora) duties, and making herself vile in the eyes of all women. Burgo Fitzgerald would not be influenced for good by such a woman as she (woman) would then be. She (woman) knew much of the world and its ways, and told herself no lies about this. But, as I have said before, she (woman) did not count herself for much. What though she (woman) were ruined? What though Burgo were false, mean, and untrustworthy? She (woman) loved him (Burgo), and he (Burgo) was the only man she (woman) ever had loved! Lower and lower she (woman) crouched before the fire; and then, when the coals were no longer red, and the shapes altered themselves no more, she (woman) crept into bed. As to what she (woman) should say to her (woman) husband on the following morning,--she (woman) had not yet begun to think of that.

Exactly at half-past eleven she (woman) entered the little breakfast parlour which looked out over the park. It was the prettiest room in the house, and now, at this springtide, when the town trees were putting out their earliest greens, and were fresh and bright almost as country trees, it might be hard to find a prettier chamber. Mr. Palliser was there already, sitting with the morning paper in his (Palliser) hand. He (Palliser) rose when she (woman) entered, and, coming up to her (woman), just touched her (woman) with his (Palliser) lips. She (woman) put her (woman) cheek up to him (Palliser), and then took her (woman) place at the breakfast table.

``Have you any headache this morning?'' (he)
he (Palliser) asked.

``Oh, no,'' (she)
she (woman) said. Then he (Palliser) took his (Palliser) tea and his (Palliser) toast, spoke some word to her (woman) about the fineness of the weather, told her (woman) some scraps of news, and soon returned to the absorbing interest of a speech made by the leader of the Opposition in the House of Lords. The speech was very interesting to Mr. Palliser, because in it the noble lord alluded to a break-up in the present Cabinet, as to which the rumours were, he (lord) said, so rife through the country as to have destroyed all that feeling of security in the existing Government which the country so much valued and desired. Mr. Palliser had as yet heard no official tidings of such a rupture; but if such rupture were to take place, it must be in his (Palliser) favour. He (Palliser) felt himself at this moment to be full of politics,--to be near the object of his (Palliser) ambition, to have affairs upon his (Palliser) hands which required all his (Palliser) attention. Was it absolutely incumbent on him (Palliser) to refer again to the incidents of last night? The doing so would be odious to him (Palliser). The remembrance of the task now immediately before him (Palliser) destroyed all his (Palliser) political satisfaction. He (Palliser) did not believe that his (Palliser) wife was in any serious danger. Might it not yet be possible for him (Palliser) to escape from the annoyance, and to wash his (Palliser) mind clean of all suspicion? He (Palliser) was not jealous; he (Palliser) was indeed incapable of jealousy. He (Palliser) knew what it would be to be dishonoured, and he (Palliser) knew that under certain circumstances the world would expect him (Palliser) to exert himself in a certain way. But the thing that he (Palliser) had now to do was a great trouble to him (Palliser). He (Palliser) would rather have to address the House of Commons with ten columns of figures than utter a word of remonstrance to his (Palliser) wife. But she (wife) had defied him (Palliser),--defied him (Palliser) by saying that she (wife) would see his (Palliser) friends no more; and it was the remembrance of this, as he (Palliser) sat behind his (Palliser) newspaper, that made him (Palliser) ultimately feel that he (Palliser) could not pass in silence over what had been done.

Nevertheless, he (Palliser) went on reading, or pretending to read, as long as the continuance of the breakfast made it certain that his (Palliser) wife would remain with him (Palliser). Every now and then he (Palliser) said some word to her (wife) of what he (Palliser) was reading, endeavouring to use the tone of voice that was customary to him (Palliser) in his (Palliser) domestic teachings of politics. But through it all there was a certain hesitation,--there were the sure signs of an attempt being made, of which he (Palliser) was himself conscious, and which she (wife) understood with the most perfect accuracy. He (Palliser) was deferring the evil moment, and vainly endeavouring to make himself believe that he (Palliser) was comfortably employed the while. She (wife) had no newspaper, and made no endeavour to deceive herself. She (wife), therefore, was the first to begin the conversation.

``Plantagenet,'' (she)
she (wife) said,
``you told me last night, as I was going to bed, that you had something to say about Lady Monk's party.'' (she)

He (Palliser) put down the newspaper slowly, and turned towards her (wife).

``Yes, my dear. After what happened, I believe that I must say something.'' (unknown)

``If you think anything, pray say it,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora.

``It is not always easy for a man to show what he (man) thinks by what he (man) says,'' (he)
he (Palliser) replied.
``My fear is that you should suppose me to think more than I do. And it was for that reason that I determined to sleep on it before I spoke to you.'' (unknown)

``If anybody is angry with me I'd much rather they should have it out with me while their anger is hot. I hate cold anger.'' (unknown)

``But I am not angry.'' (unknown)

``That's what husbands always say when they're going to scold.'' (unknown)

``But I am not going to scold. I am only going to advise you.'' (unknown)

``I'd sooner be scolded. Advice is to anger just what cold anger is to hot.'' (unknown)

``But, my dear Glencora, surely if I find it necessary to speak--'' (unknown)

``I don't want to stop you, Plantagenet. Pray, go on. Only it will be so nice to have it over.'' (He)

He (Palliser) was now more than ever averse to the task before him (Palliser). Husbands, when they give their wives a talking, should do it out of hand, uttering their words hard, sharp, and quick,--and should then go. There are some works that won't bear a preface, and this work of marital fault-finding is one of them. Mr. Palliser was already beginning to find out the truth of this.

``Glencora,'' (he)
he (Palliser) said,
``I wish you to be serious with me.'' (he)

``I am very serious,'' (she)
she (Glencora) replied, as she (Glencora) settled herself in her (Glencora) chair with an air of mockery, while her (Glencora) eyes and mouth were bright and eloquent with a spirit which her (Glencora) husband did not love to see. Poor girl! There was seriousness enough in store for her (Glencora) before she (Glencora) would be able to leave the room.

``You ought to be serious. Do you know why Mrs. Marsham came here from Lady Monk's last night?'' (unknown)

``Of course I do. She (Marsham) came to tell you that I was waltzing with Burgo Fitzgerald. You might as well ask me whether I knew why Mr. Bott was standing at all the doors, glaring at me.'' (unknown)

``I don't know anything about Mr. Bott.'' (unknown)

``I know something about him (Bott) though,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said, again moving herself in her (Glencora) chair.

``I am speaking now of Mrs. Marsham.'' (unknown)

``You should speak of them both together as they hunt in couples.'' (unknown)

``Glencora, will you listen to me, or will you not? If you say that you will not, I shall know what to do.'' (unknown)

``I don't think you would, Plantagenet.'' (she)
And she (Glencora) nodded her (Glencora) little head at him (husband), as she (Glencora) spoke.
``I'm sure I don't know what you would do. But I will listen to you. Only, as I said before, it will be very nice when it's over.'' (unknown)

``Mrs. Marsham came here, not simply to tell me that you were waltzing with Mr. Fitzgerald,--and I wish that when you mention his (Fitzgerald) name you would call him (Fitzgerald) Mr. Fitzgerald.'' (unknown)

``So I do.'' (unknown)

``You generally prefix his (Fitzgerald) Christian name, which it would be much better that you should omit.'' (unknown)

``I will try,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said, very gently;
``but it's hard to drop an old habit. Before you married me you knew that I had learned to call him (Fitzgerald) Burgo.'' (she)

``Let me go on,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

``Oh, certainly.'' (unknown)

``It was not simply to tell me that you were waltzing that Mrs. Marsham came here.'' (unknown)

``And it was not simply to see me waltzing that Mr. Bott stood in the doorways, for he (Bott) followed me about, and came down after me to the supper-room.'' (unknown)

``Glencora, will you oblige me by not speaking of Mr. Bott?'' (unknown)

``I wish you would oblige me by not speaking of Mrs. Marsham.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Mr. Palliser rose quickly from his (Palliser) chair with a gesture of anger, stood upright for half a minute, and then sat down again.
``I beg your pardon, Plantagenet,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said.
``I think I know what you want, and I'll hold my tongue till you bid me speak.'' (unknown)

``Mrs. Marsham came here because she (Marsham) saw that every one in the room was regarding you with wonder.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora twisted herself about in her (Glencora) chair, but she (Glencora) said nothing.
``She (Marsham) saw that you were not only dancing with Mr. Fitzgerald, but that you were dancing with him (Fitzgerald),--what shall I say?'' (unknown)

``Upon my word I can't tell you.'' (unknown)

``Recklessly.'' (unknown)

``Oh! recklessly, was I? What was I reckless of?'' (unknown)

``Reckless of what people might say; reckless of what I might feel about it; reckless of your own position.'' (unknown)

``Am I to speak now?'' (unknown)

``Perhaps you had better let me go on. I think she (Marsham) was right to come to me.'' (unknown)

``That's of course. What's the good of having spies, if they don't run and tell as soon as they see anything, especially anything--reckless.'' (unknown)
