``Glencora, you are determined to make me angry. I am angry now,--very angry. I have employed no spies. When rumours have reached me, not from spies, as you choose to call them, but through your dearest friends and mine--'' (unknown)

``What do you mean by rumours from my dearest friends?'' (unknown)

``Never mind. Let me go on.'' (unknown)

``No; not when you say my dear friends have spread rumours about me. Tell me who they are. I have no dear friends. Do you mean Alice Vavasor?'' (unknown)

``It does not signify. But when I was warned that you had better not go to any house in which you could meet that man, I would not listen to it. I said that you were my wife, and that as such I could trust you anywhere, everywhere, with any person. Others might distrust you, but I would not do so. When I wished you to go to Monkshade, were there to be any spies there? When I left you last night at Lady Monk's, do you believe in your heart that I trusted to Mrs. Marsham's eyes rather than to your own truth? Do you think that I have lived in fear of Mr. Fitzgerald?'' (unknown)

``No, Plantagenet; I do not think so.'' (unknown)

``Do you believe that I have commissioned Mr. Bott to watch your conduct? Answer me, Glencora.'' (She)

She (Glencora) paused a moment, thinking what actually was her (Glencora) true belief on that subject.

``He (Bott) does watch me, certainly,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said.

``That does not answer my question. Do you believe that I have commissioned him (Bott) to do so?'' (unknown)

``No; I do not.'' (unknown)

``Then it is ignoble in you to talk to me of spies. I have employed no spies. If it were ever to come to that, that I thought spies necessary, it would be all over with me.'' (he)

There was something of feeling in his (Palliser) voice as he (Palliser) said this,--something that almost approached to passion which touched his (Palliser) wife's heart. Whether or not spies would be of any avail, she (wife) knew that she (wife) had in truth done that of which he (Palliser) had declared that he (Palliser) had never suspected her (wife). She (wife) had listened to words of love from her (wife) former lover. She (wife) had received, and now carried about with her (wife) a letter from this man, in which he (man) asked her (wife) to elope with him (man). She (wife) had by no means resolved that she (wife) would not do this thing. She (wife) had been false to her (wife) husband; and as her (wife) husband spoke of his (husband) confidence in her (wife), her (wife) own spirit rebelled against the deceit which she (wife) herself was practising.

``I know that I have never made you happy,'' (she)
she (wife) said.
``I know that I never can make you happy.'' (He)

He (husband) looked at her (wife), struck by her (wife) altered tone, and saw that her (wife) whole manner and demeanour were changed.

``I do not understand what you mean,'' (he)
he (husband) said.
``I have never complained. You have not made me unhappy.'' (He)
He (husband) was one of those men to whom this was enough. If his (husband) wife caused him (husband) no uneasiness, what more was he (husband) to expect from her (wife)? No doubt she (wife) might have done much more for him (husband). She (wife) might have given him (husband) an heir. But he (husband) was a just man, and knew that the blank he (husband) had drawn was his (husband) misfortune, and not her (wife) fault.

But now her (wife) heart was loosed and she (wife) spoke out, at first slowly, but after a while with all the quietness of strong passion.

``No, Plantagenet; I shall never make you happy. You have never loved me, nor I you. We have never loved each other for a single moment. I have been wrong to talk to you about spies; I was wrong to go to Lady Monk's; I have been wrong in everything that I have done; but never so wrong as when I let them persuade me to be your wife!'' (unknown)

``Glencora!'' (unknown)

``Let me speak now, Plantagenet, It is better that I should tell you everything; and I will. I will tell you everything;--everything! I do love Burgo Fitzgerald. I do! I do! I do! How can I help loving him (Fitzgerald)? Have I not loved him (Fitzgerald) from the first,--before I had seen you? Did you not know that it was so? I do love Burgo Fitzgerald, and when I went to Lady Monk's last night, I had almost made up my mind that I must tell him (Fitzgerald) so, and that I must go away with him (Fitzgerald) and hide myself. But when he (Fitzgerald) came to speak to me--'' (unknown)

``He (Fitzgerald) has asked you to go with him (Fitzgerald), then?'' (the husband)
said the husband, in whose bosom the poison was beginning to take effect, thereby showing that he (husband) was neither above nor below humanity.

Glencora was immediately reminded that though she (Glencora) might, if she (Glencora) pleased, tell her (Glencora) own secrets, she (Glencora) ought not, in accordance with her (Glencora) ideas of honour, tell those of her (Glencora) lover.

``What need is there of asking, do you think, when people have loved each other as we have done?'' (unknown)

``You wanted to go with him (Fitzgerald), then?'' (unknown)

``Would it not have been the best for you? Plantagenet, I do not love you;--not as women love their husbands when they do love them. But, before God, my first wish is to free you from the misfortune that I have brought on you.'' (she)
As she (Glencora) made this attestation she (Glencora) started up from her (Glencora) chair, and coming close to him (lover), took him (lover) by the coat. He (lover) was startled, and stepped back a pace, but did not speak; and then stood looking at her (Glencora) as she (Glencora) went on.

-LSB-Illustration:

``Before God, my first wish is to free you from the misfortune that I have brought on you.'' (unknown)
-RSB-

``What matters it whether I drown myself, or throw myself away by going with such a one as him (God), so that you might marry again, and have a child? I'd die;--I'd die willingly. How I wish I could die! Plantagenet, I would kill myself if I dared.'' (He)

He (lover) was a tall man and she (Glencora) was short of stature, so that he (lover) stood over her (Glencora) and looked upon her (Glencora), and now she (Glencora) was looking up into his (lover) face with all her (Glencora) eyes.

``I would,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said.
``I would--I would! What is there left for me that I should wish to live?'' (he)

Softly, slowly, very gradually, as though he (lover) were afraid of what he (lover) was doing, he (lover) put his (lover) arm round her (Glencora) waist.

``You are wrong in one thing,'' (he)
he (lover) said.
``I do love you.'' (She)

She (Glencora) shook her (Glencora) head, touching his (lover) breast with her (Glencora) hair as she (Glencora) did so.

``I do love you,'' (he)
he (lover) repeated.
``If you mean that I am not apt at telling you so, it is true, I know. My mind is running on other things.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said;
``your mind is running on other things.'' (she)

``But I do love you. If you cannot love me, it is a great misfortune to us both. But we need not therefore be disgraced. As for that other thing of which you spoke,--of our having, as yet, no child'' (he)
--and in saying this he (lover) pressed her (Glencora) somewhat closer with his (lover) arm--
``you allow yourself to think too much of it;--much more of it than I do. I have made no complaints on that head, even within my own breast.'' (her)

``I know what your thoughts are, Plantagenet.'' (unknown)

``Believe me that you wrong my thoughts. Of course I have been anxious, and have, perhaps, shown my anxiety by the struggle I have made to hide it. I have never told you what is false, Glencora.'' (unknown)

``No; you are not false!'' (unknown)

``I would rather have you for my wife, childless,--if you will try to love me,--than any other woman, though another might give me an heir. Will you try to love me?'' (She)

She (Glencora) was silent. At this moment, after the confession that she (Glencora) had made, she (Glencora) could not bring herself to say that she (Glencora) would even try. Had she (Glencora) said so, she (Glencora) would have seemed to have accepted his (lover) forgiveness too easily.

``I think, dear,'' (he)
he (lover) said, still holding her (Glencora) by her (Glencora) waist,
``that we had better leave England for a while. I will give up politics for this season. Should you like to go to Switzerland for the summer, or perhaps to some of the German baths, and then on to Italy when the weather is cold enough?'' (he)
Still she (Glencora) was silent.
``Perhaps your friend, Miss Vavasor, would go with us?'' (He)

He (lover) was killing her (Glencora) by his (lover) goodness. She (Glencora) could not speak to him (lover) yet; but now, as he (lover) mentioned Alice's name, she (Alice) gently put up her (Alice) hand and rested it on the back of his (lover).

At that moment there came a knock at the door;--a sharp knock, which was quickly repeated.

``Come in,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, dropping his (Palliser) arm from his (Palliser) wife's waist, and standing away from her (wife) a few yards.

CHAPTER LIX.

The Duke of St. Bungay in Search of a Minister.

It was the butler who had knocked,--showing that the knock was of more importance than it would have been had it been struck by the knuckles of the footman in livery.

``If you please, sir, the Duke of St. Bungay is here.'' (unknown)

``The Duke of St. Bungay!'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, becoming rather red as he (Palliser) heard the announcement.

``Yes, sir, his (friend) grace is in the library. He (friend) bade me tell you that he (friend) particularly wanted to see you; so I told him (friend) that you were with my lady.'' (unknown)

``Quite right; tell his (friend) grace that I will be with him (friend) in two minutes.'' (the butler Palliser)
Then the butler retired, and Mr. Palliser was again alone with his (Palliser) wife.

``I must go now, my dear,'' (he)
he (Palliser) said;
``and perhaps I shall not see you again till the evening.'' (he)

``Don't let me put you out in any way,'' (she)
she (wife) answered.

``Oh no;--you won't put me out. You will be dressing, I suppose, about nine.'' (unknown)

``I did not mean as to that,'' (she)
she (wife) answered.
``You must not think more of Italy. He (friend) has come to tell you that you are wanted in the Cabinet.'' (he)

Again he (Palliser) turned very red.

``It may be so,'' (he)
he (Palliser) answered,
``but though I am wanted, I need not go. But I must not keep the duke waiting. Good-bye.'' (he)
And he (Palliser) turned to the door.

She (wife) followed him (Palliser) and took hold of him (Palliser) as he (Palliser) went, so that he (Palliser) was forced to turn to her (wife) once again. She (wife) managed to get hold of both his (Palliser) hands, and pressed them closely, looking up into his (Palliser) face with her (wife) eyes laden with tears. He (Palliser) smiled at her (wife) gently, returned the pressure of the hands, and then left her (wife),--without kissing her (wife). It was not that he (Palliser) was minded not to kiss her (wife). He (Palliser) would have kissed her (wife) willingly enough had he (Palliser) thought that the occasion required it.

``He (friend) says that he (friend) loves me,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora to herself,
``but he (friend) does not know what love means.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

But she (Glencora) was quite aware that he (Palliser) had behaved to her (Glencora) with genuine, true nobility. As soon as she (Glencora) was alone and certain of her (Glencora) solitude, she (Glencora) took out that letter from her (Glencora) pocket, and tearing it into very small fragments, without reading it, threw the pieces on the fire. As she (Glencora) did so, her (Glencora) mind seemed to be fixed, at any rate, to one thing,--that she (Glencora) would think no more of Burgo Fitzgerald as her (Glencora) future master. I think, however, that she (Glencora) had arrived at so much certainty as this, at that moment in which she (Glencora) had been parting with Burgo Fitzgerald, in Lady Monk's dining-room. She (Lady) had had courage enough,--or shall we rather say sin enough,--to think of going with him (Fitzgerald),--to tell herself that she (Lady) would do so; to put herself in the way of doing it; nay, she (Lady) had had enough of both to enable her (Lady) to tell her (Lady) husband that she (Lady) had resolved that it would be good for her (Lady) to do so. But she (Lady) was neither bold enough nor wicked enough to do the thing. As she (Lady) had said of her (Lady) own idea of destroying herself,--she (Lady) did not dare to take the plunge. Therefore, knowing now that it was so, she (Lady) tore up the letter that she (Lady) had carried so long, and burnt it in the fire.

She (Lady) had in truth told him (husband) everything, believing that in doing so she (Lady) was delivering her (Lady) own death-warrant as regarded her (Lady) future position in his (husband) house. She (Lady) had done this, not hoping thereby for any escape; not with any purpose as regarded herself, but simply because deceit had been grievous to her (Lady), and had become unendurable as soon as his (husband) words and manner had in them any feeling of kindness. But her (Lady) confession had no sooner been made than her (Lady) fault had been forgiven. She (Lady) had told him (husband) that she (Lady) did not love him (husband). She (Lady) had told him (husband), even, that she (Lady) had thought of leaving him (husband). She (Lady) had justified by her (Lady) own words any treatment of his (husband), however harsh, which he (husband) might choose to practise. But the result had been--the immediate result--that he (husband) had been more tender to her (Lady) than she (Lady) had ever remembered him (husband) to be before. She (Lady) knew that he (husband) had conquered her (Lady). However cold and heartless his (husband) home might be to her (Lady), it must be her (Lady) home now. There could be no further thought of leaving him (husband). She (Lady) had gone out into the tiltyard and had tilted with him (husband), and he (husband) had been the victor.

Mr. Palliser himself had not time for much thought before he (Palliser) found himself closeted with the Duke; but as he (Palliser) crossed the hall and went up the stairs, a thought or two did pass quickly across his (Palliser) mind. She (Lady) had confessed to him (Palliser), and he (Palliser) had forgiven her (Lady). He (Palliser) did not feel quite sure that he (Palliser) had been right, but he (Palliser) did feel quite sure that the thing had been done. He (Palliser) recognized it for a fact that, as regarded the past, no more was to be said. There were to be no reproaches, and there must be some tacit abandoning of Mrs. Marsham's close attendance. As to Mr. Bott;--he (Bott) had begun to hate Mr. Bott, and had felt cruelly ungrateful, when that gentleman endeavoured to whisper a word into his (gentleman) ear as he (gentleman) passed through the doorway into Lady Monk's dining-room. And he (gentleman) had offered to go abroad,--to go abroad and leave his (gentleman) politics, and his (gentleman) ambition, and his (gentleman) coming honours. He (gentleman) had persisted in his (gentleman) offer, even after his (gentleman) wife had suggested to him (gentleman) that the Duke of St. Bungay was now in the house with the object of offering him (gentleman) that very thing for which he (gentleman) had so longed! As he (gentleman) thought of this his (gentleman) heart became heavy within him (gentleman). Such chances,--so he (gentleman) told himself,--do not come twice in a man's way. When returning from a twelvemonth's residence abroad he (gentleman) would be nobody in politics. He (gentleman) would have lost everything for which he (gentleman) had been working all his (gentleman) life. But he (gentleman) was a man of his (gentleman) word, and as he (gentleman) opened the library door he (gentleman) was resolute,--he (gentleman) thought that he (gentleman) could be resolute in adhering to his (gentleman) promise.

``Duke,'' (he)
he (gentleman) said,
``I'm afraid I have kept you waiting.'' (he)
And the two political allies shook each other by the hand.

The Duke was in a glow of delight. There had been no waiting. He (gentleman) was only too glad to find his (gentleman) friend at home. He (gentleman) had been prepared to wait, even if Mr. Palliser had been out.

``And I suppose you guess why I'm come?'' (the Duke)
said the Duke.

``I would rather be told than have to guess,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, smiling for a moment. But the smile quickly passed off his (Palliser) face as he (Palliser) remembered his (Palliser) pledge to his (Palliser) wife.

``He (friend) has resigned at last. What was said in the Lords last night made it necessary that he (friend) should do so, or that Lord Brock should declare himself able to support him (Brock) through thick and thin. Of course, I can tell you everything now. He (Brock) must have gone, or I must have done so. You know that I don't like him (Brock) in the Cabinet. I admire his (Brock) character and his (Brock) genius, but I think him (Brock) the most dangerous man in England as a statesman. He (Brock) has high principles,--the very highest; but they are so high as to be out of sight to ordinary eyes. They are too exalted to be of any use for everyday purposes. He (Brock) is honest as the sun, I'm sure; but it's just like the sun's honesty,--of a kind which we men below can't quite understand or appreciate. He (Brock) has no instinct in politics, but reaches his (Brock) conclusions by philosophical deduction. Now, in politics, I would a deal sooner trust to instinct than to calculation. I think he (Brock) may probably know how England ought to be governed three centuries hence better than any man living, but of the proper way to govern it now, I think he (man) knows less. Brock half likes him (Brock) and half fears him (Brock). He (Brock) likes the support of his (Brock) eloquence, and he (Brock) likes the power of the man; but he (Brock) fears his (Brock) restless activity, and thoroughly dislikes his (Brock) philosophy. At any rate, he (Brock) has left us, and I am here to ask you to take his (Brock) place.'' (Duke)

The Duke, as he (Palliser) concluded his (Palliser) speech, was quite contented, and almost jovial. He (Palliser) was thoroughly satisfied with the new political arrangement which he (Palliser) was proposing. He (Palliser) regarded Mr. Palliser as a steady, practical man of business, luckily young, and therefore with a deal of work in him (man), belonging to the race from which English ministers ought, in his (man) opinion, to be taken, and as being, in some respects, his (man) own pupil. He (man) had been the first to declare aloud that Plantagenet Palliser was the coming Chancellor of the Exchequer; and it had been long known, though no such declaration had been made aloud, that the Duke did not sit comfortably in the same Cabinet with the gentleman who had now resigned. Everything had now gone as the Duke wished; and he (gentleman) was prepared to celebrate some little ovation with his (gentleman) young friend before he (gentleman) left the house in Park Lane.

``And who goes out with him (Brock)?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
asked Mr. Palliser, putting off the evil moment of his (Palliser) own decision; but before the Duke could answer him (Palliser), he (Palliser) had reminded himself that under his (Palliser) present circumstances he (Palliser) had no right to ask such a question. His (Palliser) own decision could not rest upon that point.
``But it does not matter,'' (he)
he (Palliser) said;
``I am afraid I must decline the offer you bring me.'' (he)

``Decline it!'' (Duke)
said the Duke, who could not have been more surprised had his (Palliser) friend talked of declining heaven.

``I fear I must.'' (Duke)
The Duke had now risen from his (Palliser) chair, and was standing, with both his (Palliser) hands upon the table. All his (Palliser) contentment, all his (Palliser) joviality, had vanished. His (Palliser) fine round face had become almost ludicrously long; his (Palliser) eyes and mouth were struggling to convey reproach, and the reproach was almost drowned in vexation. Ever since Parliament had met he (Palliser) had been whispering Mr. Palliser's name into the Prime Minister's ear, and now--. But he (Minister) could not, and would not, believe it.
``Nonsense, Palliser,'' (he)
he (Minister) said.
``You must have got some false notion into your head. There can be no possible reason why you should not join us. Finespun himself will support us, at any rate for a time.'' (Mr. Finespun)
Mr. Finespun was the gentleman whose retirement from the ministry the Duke of St. Bungay had now announced.

``It is nothing of that kind,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, who perhaps felt himself quite equal to the duties proposed to him (Palliser), even though Mr. Finespun should not support him (Finespun).
``It is nothing of that kind;--it is no fear of that sort that hinders me.'' (unknown)

``Then, for mercy's sake, what is it? My dear Palliser, I looked upon you as being as sure in this matter as myself; and I had a right to do so. You certainly intended to join us a month ago, if the opportunity offered. You certainly did.'' (unknown)

``It is true, Duke. I must ask you to listen to me now, and I must tell you what I would not willingly tell to any man.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
As Mr. Palliser said this a look of agony came over his (Palliser) face. There are men who can talk easily of all their most inmost matters, but he (Palliser) was not such a man. It went sorely against the grain with him (Palliser) to speak of the sorrow of his (Palliser) home, even to such a friend as the Duke; but it was essentially necessary to him (Palliser) that he (Palliser) should justify himself.

``Upon my word,'' (Duke)
said the Duke,
``I can't understand that there should be any reason strong enough to make you throw your party over.'' (Duke)

``I have promised to take my wife abroad.'' (unknown)

``Is that it?'' (the Duke)
said the Duke, looking at him (Palliser) with surprise, but at the same time with something of returning joviality in his (Palliser) face.
``Nobody thinks of going abroad at this time of the year. Of course, you can get away for a time when Parliament breaks up.'' (unknown)

``But I have promised to go at once.'' (unknown)

``Then, considering your position, you have made a promise which it behoves you to break. I am sure Lady Glencora will see it in that light.'' (unknown)

``You do not quite understand me, and I am afraid I must trouble you to listen to matters which, under other circumstances, it would be impertinent in me to obtrude upon you.'' (him)
A certain stiffness of demeanour, and measured propriety of voice, much at variance with his (Palliser) former manner, came upon him (Palliser) as he (Palliser) said this.

``Of course, Palliser, I don't want to interfere for a moment.'' (unknown)

``If you will allow me, Duke. My wife has told me that, this morning, which makes me feel that absence from England is requisite for her (wife) present comfort. I was with her (wife) when you came, and had just promised her (wife) that she (wife) should go.'' (unknown)

``But, Palliser, think of it. If this were a small matter, I would not press you; but a man in your position has public duties. He (man) owes his (man) services to his (man) country. He (man) has no right to go back, if it be possible that he (man) should so do.'' (unknown)

``When a man has given his (man) word, it cannot be right that he (man) should go back from that.'' (unknown)

``Of course not. But a man may be absolved from a promise. Lady Glencora--'' (unknown)

``My wife would, of course, absolve me. It is not that. Her (wife) happiness demands it, and it is partly my fault that it is so. I cannot explain to you more fully why it is that I must give up the great object for which I have striven with all my strength.'' (unknown)

``Oh, no!'' (the Duke)
said the Duke.
``If you are sure that it is imperative--'' (unknown)

``It is imperative.'' (unknown)

``I could give you twenty-four hours, you know.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Mr. Palliser did not answer at once, and the Duke thought that he (Palliser) saw some sign of hesitation.
``I suppose it would not be possible that I should speak to Lady Glencora?'' (unknown)

``It could be of no avail, Duke. She (Glencora) would only declare, at the first word, that she (Glencora) would remain in London; but it would not be the less my duty on that account to take her (Glencora) abroad.'' (unknown)

``Well; I can't say. Of course, I can't say. Such an opportunity may not come twice in a man's life. And at your age too! You are throwing away from you the finest political position that the world can offer to the ambition of any man. No one at your time of life has had such a chance within my memory. That a man under thirty should be thought fit to be Chancellor of the Exchequer, and should refuse it,--because he (Chancellor) wants to take his (Chancellor) wife abroad! Palliser, if she (wife) were dying, you should remain under such an emergency as this. She (wife) might go, but you should remain.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

Mr. Palliser remained silent for a moment or two in his (Palliser) chair; he (Palliser) then rose and walked towards the window, as he (Palliser) spoke.

``There are things worse than death,'' (he)
he (Palliser) said, when his (Palliser) back was turned. His (Palliser) voice was very low, and there was a tear in his (Palliser) eye as he (Palliser) spoke them; the words were indeed whispered, but the Duke heard them, and felt that he (Palliser) could not press him (Palliser) any more on the subject of his (Palliser) wife.

``And must this be final?'' (the Duke)
said the Duke.

``I think it must. But your visit here has come so quickly on my resolution to go abroad,--which, in truth, was only made ten minutes before your name was brought to me,--that I believe I ought to ask for a portion of those twenty-four hours which you have offered me. A small portion will be enough. Will you see me, if I come to you this evening, say at eight? If the House is up in the Lords I will go to you in St. James's Square.'' (unknown)

``We shall be sitting after eight, I think.'' (unknown)

``Then I will see you there. And, Duke, I must ask you to think of me in this matter as a friend should think, and not as though we were bound together only by party feeling.'' (unknown)

``I will,--I will.'' (unknown)

``I have told you what I shall never whisper to any one else.'' (unknown)

``I think you know that you are safe with me.'' (unknown)

``I am sure of it. And, Duke, I can tell you that the sacrifice to me will be almost more than I can bear. This thing that you have offered me to-day is the only thing that I have ever coveted. I have thought of it and worked for it, have hoped and despaired, have for moments been vain enough to think that it was within my strength, and have been wretched for weeks together because I have told myself that it was utterly beyond me.'' (unknown)

``As to that, neither Brock nor I, nor any of us, have any doubt. Finespun himself says that you are the man.'' (unknown)

``I am much obliged to them. But I say all this simply that you may understand how imperative is the duty which, as I think, requires me to refuse the offer.'' (unknown)

``But you haven't refused as yet,'' (the Duke)
said the Duke.
``I shall wait at the House for you, whether they are sitting or not. And endeavour to join us. Do the best you can. I will say nothing as to that duty of which you speak; but if it can be made compatible with your public service, pray--pray let it be done. Remember how much such a one as you owes to his (me) country.'' (the Duke)
Then the Duke went, and Mr. Palliser was alone.

He (Palliser) had not been alone before since the revelation which had been made to him (Palliser) by his (Palliser) wife, and the words she (wife) had spoken were still sounding in his (Palliser) ears.

``I do love Burgo Fitzgerald;--I do! I do! I do!'' (a husband)
They were not pleasant words for a young husband to hear. Men there are, no doubt, whose nature would make them more miserable under the infliction than it had made Plantagenet Palliser. He (husband) was calm, without strong passion, not prone to give to words a stronger significance than they should bear;--and he (husband) was essentially unsuspicious. Never for a moment had he (husband) thought, even while those words were hissing in his (husband) ears, that his (husband) wife had betrayed his (husband) honour. Nevertheless, there was that at his (husband) heart, as he (husband) remembered those words, which made him (husband) feel that the world was almost too heavy for him (husband). For the first quarter of an hour after the Duke's departure he (husband) thought more of his (husband) wife and of Burgo Fitzgerald than he (husband) did of Lord Brock and Mr. Finespun. But of this he (Finespun) was aware,--that he (Finespun) had forgiven his (Finespun) wife; that he (Finespun) had put his (Finespun) arm round her (wife) and embraced her (wife) after hearing her (wife) confession,--and that she (wife), mutely, with her (wife) eyes, had promised him (Finespun) that she (wife) would do her (wife) best for him (Finespun). Then something of an idea of love came across his (Finespun) heart, and he (Finespun) acknowledged to himself that he (Finespun) had married without loving or without requiring love. Much of all this had been his (Finespun) own fault. Indeed, had not the whole of it come from his (Finespun) own wrong-doing? He (Finespun) acknowledged that it was so. But now,--now he (Finespun) loved her (wife). He (Finespun) felt that he (Finespun) could not bear to part with her (wife), even if there were no question of public scandal, or of disgrace. He (Finespun) had been torn inwardly by that assertion that she (wife) loved another man. She (wife) had got at his (Finespun) heart-strings at last. There are men who may love their wives, though they never can have been in love before their marriage.

When the Duke had been gone about an hour, and when, under ordinary circumstances, it would have been his (Finespun) time to go down to the House, he (Finespun) took his (Finespun) hat and walked into the Park. He (Finespun) made his (Finespun) way across Hyde Park, and into Kensington Gardens, and there he (Finespun) remained for an hour, walking up and down beneath the elms. The quidnuncs of the town, who chanced to see him (Finespun), and who had heard something of the political movements of the day, thought, no doubt, that he (Finespun) was meditating his (Finespun) future ministerial career. But he (Finespun) had not been there long before he (Finespun) had resolved that no ministerial career was at present open to him (Finespun).

``It has been my own fault,'' (he)
he (Finespun) said, as he (Finespun) returned to his (Finespun) house,
``and with God's help I will mend it, if it be possible.'' (he)

But he (Finespun) was a slow man, and he (Finespun) did not go off instantly to the Duke. He (Finespun) had given himself to eight o'clock, and he (Finespun) took the full time. He (Finespun) could not go down to the House of Commons because men would make inquiries of him (Finespun) which he (Finespun) would find it difficult to answer. So he (Finespun) dined at home, alone. He (Finespun) had told his (Finespun) wife that he (Finespun) would see her (wife) at nine, and before that hour he (Finespun) would not go to her (wife). He (Finespun) sat alone till it was time for him (Finespun) to get into his (Finespun) brougham, and thought it all over. That seat in the Cabinet and Chancellorship of the Exchequer, which he (Finespun) had so infinitely desired, were already done with. There was no doubt about that. It might have been better for him (Finespun) not to have married; but now that he (Finespun) was married, and that things had brought him (Finespun) untowardly to this pass, he (Finespun) knew that his (Finespun) wife's safety was his (Finespun) first duty.

``We will go through Switzerland,'' (he)
he (Finespun) said to himself,
``to Baden, and then we will get on to Florence and to Rome. She (your) has seen nothing of all these things yet, and the new life will make a change in her (your). She (your) shall have her (your) own friend with her (your).'' (he)
Then he (Finespun) went down to the House of Lords, and saw the Duke.

``Well, Palliser,'' (Duke)
said the Duke, when he (Finespun) had listened to him (Finespun),
``of course I cannot argue it with you any more. I can only say that I am very sorry;--more sorry than perhaps you will believe. Indeed, it half breaks my heart.'' (him)
The Duke's voice was very sad, and it might almost have been thought that he (Finespun) was going to shed a tear. In truth he (Finespun) disliked Mr. Finespun with the strongest political feeling of which he (Finespun) was capable, and had attached himself to Mr. Palliser almost as strongly. It was a thousand pities! How hard had he (Palliser) not worked to bring about this arrangement, which was now to be upset because a woman had been foolish!
``I never above half liked her (your),'' (Duke)
said the Duke to himself, thinking perhaps a little of the Duchess's complaints of her (Duchess).
``I must go to Brock at once,'' (he)
he (Palliser) said aloud,
``and tell him (Brock). God knows what we must do now. Goodbye! good-bye! No; I'm not angry. There shall be no quarrel. But I am very sorry.'' (he)
In this way the two politicians parted.

We may as well follow this political movement to its end. The Duke saw Lord Brock that night, and then those two ministers sent for another minister,--another noble Lord, a man of great experience in Cabinets. These three discussed the matter together, and on the following day Lord Brock got up in the House, and made a strong speech in defence of his (Brock) colleague, Mr. Finespun. To the end of the Session, at any rate, Mr. Finespun kept his (Finespun) position, and held the seals of the Exchequer while all the quidnuncs of the nation, shaking their heads, spoke of the wonderful power of Mr. Finespun, and declared that Lord Brock did not dare to face the Opposition without him (Brock).

In the meantime Mr. Palliser had returned to his (Palliser) wife, and told her (wife) of his (Palliser) resolution with reference to their tour abroad.

``We may as well make up our minds to start at once,'' (he)
said he (Palliser).
``At any rate, there is nothing on my side to hinder us.'' (unknown)

CHAPTER LX.

Alice Vavasor's Name Gets into the Money Market.

Some ten or twelve days after George Vavasor's return to London from Westmoreland he (Vavasor) appeared at Mr. Scruby's offices with four small slips of paper in his (Vavasor) hand. Mr. Scruby, as usual, was pressing for money. The third election was coming on, and money was already being spent very freely among the men of the River Bank. So, at least, Mr. Scruby declared. Mr. Grimes, of the

``Handsome Man,'' (Mr. Grimes/Grimes)
had shown signs of returning allegiance. But Mr. Grimes could not afford to be loyal without money. He (Grimes) had his (Grimes) little family to protect. Mr. Scruby, too, had his (Scruby) little family, and was not ashamed to use it on this occasion.
``I'm a family man, Mr. Vavasor, and therefore I never run any risks. I never go a yard further than I can see my way back.'' (he)
This he (Scruby) had said in answer to a proposition that he (Scruby) should take George's note of hand for the expenses of the next election, payable in three months' time.
``It is so very hard to realize,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George,
``immediately upon a death, when all the property left is real property.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
``Very hard indeed,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby, who had heard with accuracy all the particulars of the old Squire's will. Vavasor understood the lawyer, cursed him (lawyer) inwardly, and suggested to himself that some day he (lawyer) might murder Mr. Scruby as well as John Grey,--and perhaps also a few more of his (Scruby) enemies. Two days after the interview in which his (Scruby) own note of hand had been refused, he (Scruby) again called in Great Marlborough Street. Upon this occasion he (Scruby) tendered to Mr. Scruby for his (Scruby) approval the four slips of paper which have been mentioned. Mr. Scruby regarded them with attention, looking first at one side horizontally, and then at the other side perpendicularly. But before we learn the judgement pronounced by Mr. Scruby as to these four slips of paper, we must go back to their earlier history. As they were still in their infancy, we shall not have to go back far.

One morning, at about eleven o'clock the parlour-maid came up to Alice, as she (Alice) sat alone in the drawing-room in Queen Anne Street, and told her (Queen) there was a

``gentleman'' (Anne Street/Queen Anne Street)
in the hall waiting to be seen by her (Queen). We all know the tone in which servants announce a gentleman when they know that the gentleman is not a gentleman.

``A gentleman wanting to see me! What sort of a gentleman?'' (unknown)

``Well, miss, I don't think he (gentleman)'s just of our sort; but he (gentleman)'s decent to look at.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice Vavasor had no desire to deny herself to any person but one. She (Vavasor) was well aware that the gentleman in the hall could not be her (Vavasor) cousin George, and therefore she (Vavasor) did not refuse to see him (George).

``Let him (gentleman) come up,'' (she)
she (Vavasor) said.
``But I think, Jane, you ought to ask him (gentleman) his (gentleman) name.'' (Lady Jane/Jane)
Jane did ask him (George) his (George) name, and came back immediately, announcing Mr. Levy.

This occurred immediately after the return of Mr. John Vavasor from Westmoreland. He (Vavasor) had reached home late on the preceding evening, and at the moment of Mr. Levy's call was in his (Levy) dressing-room.

Alice got up to receive her (Alice) visitor, and at once understood the tone of her (Alice) maid's voice. Mr. Levy was certainly not a gentleman of the sort to which she (Alice) had been most accustomed. He (Levy) was a little dark man, with sharp eyes, set very near to each other in his (Levy) head, with a beaked nose, thick at the bridge, and a black moustache, but no other beard. Alice did not at all like the look of Mr. Levy, but she (Alice) stood up to receive him (Levy), made him (Levy) a little bow, and asked him (Levy) to sit down.

``Is papa dressed yet?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice asked the servant.

``Well, miss, I don't think he (gentleman) is,--not to say dressed.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice had thought it might be as well that Mr. Levy should know that there was a gentleman in the house with her (Alice).

``I've called about a little bit of business, miss,'' (Mr. Levy)
said Mr. Levy, when they were alone.
``Nothing as you need disturb yourself about. You'll find it all square, I think.'' (he)
Then he (Levy) took a case out of his (Levy) breast-pocket, and produced a note, which he (Levy) handed to her (Alice). Alice took the note, and saw immediately that it was addressed to her (Alice) by her (Alice) cousin George.
``Yes, Mr. George Vavasor,'' (Mr. Levy)
said Mr. Levy.
``I dare say you never saw me before, miss?'' (unknown)

``No, sir; I think not,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``I am your cousin's clerk.'' (unknown)

``Oh, you're Mr. Vavasor's clerk. I'll read his (Vavasor) letter, if you please, sir.'' (unknown)

``If you please, miss.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

George Vavasor's letter to his (Levy) cousin was as follows:--

DEAR ALICE,

After what passed between us when I last saw you I thought that on my return from Westmoreland I should learn that you had paid in at my bankers' the money that I require. But I find that this is not so; and of course I excuse you, because women so seldom know when or how to do that which business demands of them. You have, no doubt, heard the injustice which my grandfather has done me, and will probably feel as indignant as I do. I only mention this now, because the nature of his (grandfather) will makes it more than ever incumbent on you that you should be true to your pledge to me.

Till there shall be some ground for a better understanding between us,--and this I do not doubt will come,--I think it wiser not to call, myself, at Queen Anne Street. I therefore send my confidential clerk with four bills, each of five hundred pounds, drawn at fourteen days' date, across which I will get you to write your name. Mr. Levy will show you the way in which this should be done. Your name must come under the word

``accepted,'' (unknown)
and just above the name of Messrs. Drummonds, where the money must be lying ready, at any rate, not later than Monday fortnight. Indeed, the money must be there some time on the Saturday. They know you so well at Drummonds' that you will not object to call on the Saturday afternoon, and ask if it is all right.

I have certainly been inconvenienced by not finding the money as I expected on my return to town. If these bills are not properly provided for, the result will be very disastrous to me. I feel, however, sure that this will be done, both for your own sake and for mine.

Affectionately yours,

GEORGE VAVASOR.

The unparalleled impudence of this letter had the effect which the writer had intended. It made Alice think immediately of her (Alice) own remissness,--if she (Alice) had been remiss,--rather than of the enormity of his (writer) claim upon her (Alice). The decision with which he (writer) asked for her (Alice) money, without any pretence at an excuse on his (writer) part, did for the time induce her (Alice) to believe that she (Alice) had no alternative but to give it to him (writer), and that she (Alice) had been wrong in delaying it. She (Alice) had told him (writer) that he (writer) should have it, and she (Alice) ought to have been as good as her (Alice) word. She (Alice) should not have forced upon him (writer) the necessity of demanding it.

But the idea of signing four bills was terrible to her (Alice), and she (Alice) felt sure that she (Alice) ought not to put her (Alice) name to orders for so large an amount and then intrust them to such a man as Mr. Levy. Her (Alice) father was in the house, and she (Alice) might have asked him (father). The thought that she (Alice) would do so of course occurred to her (Alice). But then it occurred to her (Alice) also that were she (Alice) to speak to her (Alice) father as to this advancing of money to her (Alice) cousin,--to this giving of money, for she (Alice) now well understood that it would be a gift;--were she (Alice) to consult her (Alice) father in any way about it, he (father) would hinder her (Alice), not only from signing the bills for Mr. Levy, but, as far as he (Levy) could do so, from keeping the promise made to her (Alice) cousin. She (Alice) was resolved that George should have the money, and she (Alice) knew that she (Alice) could give it to him (George) in spite of her (Alice) father. But her (Alice) father might probably be able to delay the gift, and thus rob it of its chief value. If she (Alice) were to sign the bills, the money must be made to be forthcoming. So much she (Alice) understood.

Mr. Levy had taken out the four bills from the same case, and had placed them on the table before him (Levy).

``Mr. Vavasor has explained, I believe, miss, what it is you have to do?'' (he)
he (Levy) said.

``Yes, sir; my cousin has explained.'' (unknown)

``And there is nothing else to trouble you with, I believe. If you will just write your name across them, here, I need not detain you by staying any longer.'' (Mr. Levy)
Mr. Levy was very anxious to make his (Levy) visit as short as possible, since he (Levy) had heard that Mr. John Vavasor was in the house.

But Alice hesitated. Two thousand pounds is a very serious sum of money. She (Alice) had heard much of sharpers, and thought that she (Alice) ought to be cautious. What if this man, of whom she (Alice) had never before heard, should steal the bills after she (Alice) had signed them? She (Alice) looked again at her (Alice) cousin's letter, chiefly with the object of gaining time.

``It's all right, miss,'' (Mr. Levy)
said Mr. Levy.

``Could you not leave them with me, sir?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Well; not very well, miss. No doubt Mr. Vavasor has explained it all; but the fact is, he (Vavasor) must have them this afternoon. He (Vavasor) has got a heavy sum to put down on the nail about this here election, and if it ain't down to-day, them on whom he (Vavasor) has to depend will be all abroad.'' (unknown)

``But, sir, the money will not be payable to-day. If I understand it, they are not cheques.'' (unknown)

``No, miss, no; they are not cheques. But your name, miss, at fourteen days, is the same as ready money;--just the same.'' (She)

She (Alice) paused, and while she (Alice) paused, he (Levy) reached a pen for her (Alice) from the writing-table, and then she (Alice) signed the four bills as he (Levy) held them before her (Alice). She (Alice) was quick enough at doing this when she (Alice) had once commenced the work. Her (Alice) object, then, was that the man should be gone from the house before her (Alice) father could meet him (father).

These were the four bits of paper which George Vavasor tendered to Mr. Scruby's notice on the occasion which we have now in hand. In doing so, he (Vavasor) made use of them after the manner of a grand capitalist, who knows that he (Vavasor) may assume certain airs as he (Vavasor) allows the odours of the sweetness of his (Vavasor) wealth to drop from him (Vavasor).

``You insisted on ready money, with your d-- suspicions,'' (he)
said he (Vavasor);
``and there it is. You're not afraid of fourteen days, I dare say.'' (he)

``Fourteen days is neither here nor there,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Mr. Scruby.
``We can let our payments stand over as long as that, without doing any harm. I'll send one of my men down to Grimes, and tell him (Grimes) I can't see him (Grimes), till,--let me see,'' (he)
and he (Scruby) looked at one of the bills,
``till the 15th.'' (he)

But this was not exactly what George Vavasor wanted. He (Vavasor) was desirous that the bills should be immediately turned into money, so that the necessity of forcing payments from Alice, should due provision for the bills not be made, might fall into other hands than his (Vavasor).

``We can wait till the 15th,'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
said Scruby, as he (Scruby) handed the bits of paper back to his (Scruby) customer.

``You will want a thousand, you say?'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.

``A thousand to begin with. Certainly not less.'' (unknown)

``Then you had better keep two of them.'' (unknown)

``Well--no! I don't see the use of that. You had better collect them through your own banker, and let me have a cheque on the 15th or 16th.'' (unknown)

``How cursed suspicious you are, Scruby.'' (unknown)

``No, I ain't. I'm not a bit suspicious. I don't deal in such articles; that's all!'' (unknown)

``What doubt can there be about such bills as those? Everybody knows that my cousin has a considerable fortune, altogether at her (You) own disposal.'' (unknown)

``The truth is, Mr. Vavasor, that bills with ladies' names on them,--ladies who are no way connected with business,--ain't just the paper that people like.'' (unknown)

``Nothing on earth can be surer.'' (unknown)

``You take them into the City for discount, and see if the bankers don't tell you the same. They may be done, of course, upon your name. I say nothing about that.'' (unknown)

``I can explain to you the nature of the family arrangement, but I can't do that to a stranger. However, I don't mind.'' (unknown)

``Of course not. The time is so short that it does not signify. Have them collected through your own bankers, and then, if it don't suit you to call, send me a cheque for a thousand pounds when the time is up.'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
Then Mr. Scruby turned to some papers on his (Scruby) right hand, as though the interview had been long enough. Vavasor looked at him (Scruby) angrily, opening his (Scruby) wound at him (Scruby) and cursing him (Scruby) inwardly. Mr. Scruby went on with his (Scruby) paper, by no means regarding either the wound or the unspoken curses. Thereupon Vavasor got up and went away without any word of farewell.

As he (Scruby) walked along Great Marlborough Street, and through those unalluring streets which surround the Soho district, and so on to the Strand and his (Scruby) own lodgings, he (Scruby) still continued to think of some wide scheme of revenge,--of some scheme in which Mr. Scruby might be included. There had appeared something latterly in Mr. Scruby's manner to him (Scruby), something of mingled impatience and familiarity, which made him (Scruby) feel that he (Scruby) had fallen in the attorney's estimation. It was not that the lawyer thought him (lawyer) to be less honourable, or less clever, than he (lawyer) had before thought him (lawyer); but that the man was like a rat, and knew a falling house by the instinct that was in him (man). So George Vavasor cursed Mr. Scruby, and calculated some method of murdering him (Vavasor) without detection.

The reader is not to suppose that the Member for the Chelsea Districts had, in truth, resolved to gratify his (Member) revenge by murder,--by murdering any of those persons whom he (Member) hated so vigorously. He (Member) did not, himself, think it probable that he (Member) would become a murderer. But he (Member) received some secret satisfaction in allowing his (Member) mind to dwell upon the subject, and in making those calculations. He (Member) reflected that it would not do to take off Scruby and John Grey at the same time, as it would be known that he (Scruby) was connected with both of them; unless, indeed, he (Scruby) was to take off a third person at the same time,--a third person, as to the expediency of ending whose career he (Scruby) made his (Scruby) calculations quite as often as he (Scruby) did in regard to any of those persons whom he (Scruby) cursed so often. It need hardly be explained to the reader that this third person was the sitting Member for the Chelsea Districts.

As he (Member) was himself in want of instant ready money Mr. Scruby's proposition that he (Scruby) should leave the four bills at his (Scruby) own bankers', to be collected when they came to maturity, did not suit him (Scruby). He (Scruby) doubted much, also, whether at the end of the fourteen days the money would be forthcoming. Alice would be driven to tell her (Alice) father, in order that the money might be procured, and John Vavasor would probably succeed in putting impediments in the way of the payment. He (Vavasor) must take the bills into the City, and do the best there that he (Vavasor) could with them. He (Vavasor) was too late for this to-day, and therefore he (Vavasor) went to his (Vavasor) lodgings, and then down to the House. In the House he (Vavasor) sat all the night with his (Vavasor) hat over his (Vavasor) eyes, making those little calculations of which I have spoken.

``You have heard the news; haven't you?'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Mr. Bott to him (Bott), whispering in his (Bott) ear.

``News; no. I haven't heard any news.'' (unknown)

``Finespun has resigned, and Palliser is at this moment with the Duke of St. Bungay in the Lords' library.'' (unknown)

``They may both be at the bottom of the Lords' fishpond, for what I care,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor.

``That's nonsense, you know,'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Bott.
``Still, you know Palliser is Chancellor of the Exchequer at this moment. What a lucky fellow you are to have such a chance come to you directly you get in. As soon as he (fellow) takes his (fellow) seat down there, of course we shall go up behind him (fellow).'' (unknown)

``We shall have another election in a month's time,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George.
``I'm safe enough,'' (Mr. Bott/Bott)
said Bott.
``It never hurts a man at elections to be closely connected with the Government.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

George Vavasor was in the City by times the next morning, but he (Vavasor) found that the City did not look with favourable eyes on his (Vavasor) four bills. The City took them up, first horizontally, and then, with a twist of its hand, perpendicularly, and looked at them with distrustful eyes. The City repeated the name, Alice Vavasor, as though it were not esteemed a good name on Change. The City suggested that as the time was so short, the holder of the bills would be wise to hold them till he (Vavasor) could collect the amount. It was very clear that the City suspected something wrong in the transaction. The City, by one of its mouths, asserted plainly that ladies' bills never meant business. George Vavasor cursed the City, and made his (Vavasor) calculation about murdering it. Might not a river of strychnine be turned on round the Exchange about luncheon time? Three of the bills he (Vavasor) left at last with his (Vavasor) own bankers for collection, and retained the fourth in his (Vavasor) breast-pocket, intending on the morrow to descend with it into those lower depths of the money market which he (Vavasor) had not as yet visited. Again, on the next day, he (Vavasor) went to work and succeeded to some extent. Among those lower depths he (Vavasor) found a capitalist who was willing to advance him (Vavasor) two hundred pounds, keeping that fourth bill in his (Vavasor) possession as security. The capitalist was to have forty pounds for the transaction, and George cursed him (George) as he (George) took his (George) cheque. George Vavasor knew quite enough of the commercial world to enable him (Vavasor) to understand that a man must be in a very bad condition when he (Vavasor) consents to pay forty pounds for the use of two hundred for fourteen days. He (Vavasor) cursed the City. He (Vavasor) cursed the House of Commons. He (Vavasor) cursed his (Vavasor) cousin Alice and his (Vavasor) sister Kate. He (Vavasor) cursed the memory of his (Vavasor) grandfather. And he (Vavasor) cursed himself.

Mr. Levy had hardly left the house in Queen Anne Street, before Alice had told her (Alice) father what she (Alice) had done.

``The money must be forthcoming,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice. To this her (Alice) father made no immediate reply, but turning himself in his (father) chair away from her (Alice) with a sudden start, sat looking at the fire and shaking his (father) head.
``The money must be made to be forthcoming,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``Papa, will you see that it is done?'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)
This was very hard upon poor John Vavasor, and so he (Vavasor) felt it to be.
``Papa, if you will not promise, I must go to Mr. Round about it myself, and must find out a broker to sell out for me. You would not wish that my name should be dishonoured.'' (unknown)

``You will be ruined,'' (he)
said he (Vavasor),
``and for such a rascal as that!'' (he)

``Never mind whether he (rascal) is a rascal or not, papa. You must acknowledge that he (rascal) has been treated harshly by his (rascal) grandfather.'' (unknown)

``I think that will was the wisest thing my father ever did. Had he (father) left the estate to George, there wouldn't have been an acre of it left in the family in six months' time.'' (unknown)

``But the life interest, papa!'' (unknown)

``He (papa) would have raised all he (papa) could upon that, and it would have done him (papa) no good.'' (unknown)

``At any rate, papa, he (papa) must have this two thousand pounds. You must promise me that.'' (unknown)

``And then he (papa) will want more.'' (unknown)

``No; I do not think he (papa) will ask for more. At any rate, I do not think that I am bound to give him (papa) all that I have.'' (unknown)

``I should think not. I should like to know how you can be bound to give him (papa) anything?'' (unknown)

``Because I promised it. I have signed the bills now, and it must be done.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
Still Mr. Vavasor made no promise.
``Papa, if you will not say that you will do it, I must go down to Mr. Round at once.'' (unknown)

``I don't know that I can do it. I don't know that Mr. Round can do it. Your money is chiefly on mortgage.'' (unknown)
Then there was a pause for a moment in the conversation.
``Upon my word, I never heard of such a thing in my life,'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said Mr. Vavasor;
``I never did. Four thousand pounds given away to such a man as that, in three months! Four thousand pounds! And you say you do not intend to marry him (man).'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

``Certainly not; all that is over.'' (unknown)

``And does he (man) know that it is over?'' (unknown)

``I suppose he (man) does.'' (unknown)

``You suppose so! Things of that sort are so often over with you!'' (unknown)
This was very cruel. Perhaps she (Alice) had deserved the reproach, but still it was very cruel. The blow struck her (Alice) with such force that she (Alice) staggered under it. Tears came into her (Alice) eyes, and she (Alice) could hardly speak lest she (Alice) should betray herself by sobbing.

``I know that I have behaved badly,'' (she)
she (Alice) said at last;
``but I am punished, and you might spare me now!'' (she)

``I didn't want to punish you,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) said, getting up from his (Vavasor) chair and walking about the room.
``I don't want to punish you. But, I don't want to see you ruined!'' (unknown)

``I must go to Mr. Round then, myself.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)

Mr. Vavasor went on walking about the room, jingling the money in his (Vavasor) trousers-pockets, and pushing the chairs about as he (Vavasor) chanced to meet them. At last, he (Vavasor) made a compromise with her (Alice). He (Vavasor) would take a day to think whether he (Vavasor) would assist her (Alice) in getting the money, and communicate his (Vavasor) decision to her (Alice) on the following morning.

CHAPTER LXI.

The Bills Are Made All Right.

Mr. Vavasor was at his (Vavasor) wits' end about his (Vavasor) daughter. She (daughter) had put her (daughter) name to four bills for five hundred pounds each, and had demanded from him (Vavasor), almost without an apology, his (Vavasor) aid in obtaining money to meet them. And she (daughter) might put her (daughter) name to any other number of bills, and for any amount! There was no knowing how a man ought to behave to such a daughter.

``I don't want her (you) money,'' (the father)
the father said to himself;
``and if she (you) had got none of her (you) own, I would make her (you) as comfortable as I could with my own income. But to see her (you) throw her (you) money away in such a fashion as this is enough to break a man's heart.'' (the father)

Mr. Vavasor went to his (Vavasor) office in Chancery Lane, but he (Vavasor) did not go to the chambers of Mr. Round, the lawyer. Instead of calling on Mr. Round he (Mr.) sent a note by a messenger to Suffolk Street, and the answer to the note came in the person of Mr. Grey. John Grey was living in town in these days, and was in the habit of seeing Mr. Vavasor frequently. Indeed, he (Vavasor) had not left London since the memorable occasion on which he (Vavasor) had pitched his (Vavasor) rival down the tailor's stairs at his (Vavasor) lodgings. He (Vavasor) had made himself pretty well conversant with George Vavasor's career, and had often shuddered as he (Vavasor) thought what might be the fate of any girl who might trust herself to marry such a man as that.

He (man) had been at home when Mr. Vavasor's note had reached his (Vavasor) lodgings, and had instantly walked off towards Chancery Lane. He (Vavasor) knew his (Vavasor) way to Mr. Vavasor's signing-office very accurately, for he (Vavasor) had acquired a habit of calling there, and of talking to the father about his (father) daughter. He (father) was a patient, persevering man, confident in himself, and apt to trust that he (father) would accomplish those things which he (father) attempted, though he (father) was hardly himself aware of any such aptitude. He (father) had never despaired as to Alice. And though he (father) had openly acknowledged to himself that she (Alice) had been very foolish,--or rather, that her (Alice) judgement had failed her (Alice),--he (father) had never in truth been angry with her (Alice). He (father) had looked upon her (Alice) rejection of himself, and her (Alice) subsequent promise to her (Alice) cousin, as the effects of a mental hallucination, very much to be lamented,--to be wept for, perhaps, through a whole life, as a source of terrible sorrow to himself and to her (Alice). But he (cousin) regarded it all as a disease, of which the cure was yet possible,--as a disease which, though it might never leave the patient as strong as she (Alice) was before, might still leave her (Alice) altogether. And as he (patient) would still have clung to his (patient) love had she (Alice) been attacked by any of those illnesses for which doctors have well-known names, so would he (patient) cling to her (Alice) now that she (Alice) was attacked by a malady for which no name was known. He (patient) had already heard from Mr. Vavasor that Alice had discovered how impossible it was that she (Alice) should marry her (Alice) cousin, and, in his (Vavasor) quiet, patient, enduring way, was beginning to feel confident that he (Vavasor) would, at last, carry his (Vavasor) mistress off with him (Vavasor) to Nethercoats.

It was certainly a melancholy place, that signing-office, in which Mr. John Vavasor was doomed to spend twelve hours a week, during every term time, of his (Vavasor) existence. Whether any man could really pass an existence of work in such a workshop, and not have gone mad,--could have endured to work there for seven hours a day, every week-day of his (Vavasor) life, I am not prepared to say. I doubt much whether any victims are so doomed. I have so often wandered through those gloomy passages without finding a sign of humanity there,--without hearing any slightest tick of the hammer of labour, that I am disposed to think that Lord Chancellors have been anxious to save their subordinates from suicide, and have mercifully decreed that the whole staff of labourers, down to the very message boys of the office, should be sent away to green fields or palatial clubs during, at any rate, a moiety of their existence.

The dismal set of chambers, in which the most dismal room had been assigned to Mr. Vavasor, was not actually in Chancery Lane. Opening off from Chancery Lane are various other small lanes, quiet, dingy nooks, some of them in the guise of streets going no whither, some being thoroughfares to other dingy streets beyond, in which sponging-houses abound, and others existing as the entrances to so-called Inns of Court,--inns of which all knowledge has for years been lost to the outer world of the laity, and, as I believe, lost almost equally to the inner world of the legal profession. Who has ever heard of Symonds' Inn? But an ancestral Symonds, celebrated, no doubt, in his (Symonds) time, did found an inn, and there it is to this day. Of Staples' Inn, who knows the purposes or use? Who are its members, and what do they do as such? And Staples' Inn is an inn with pretensions, having a chapel of its own, or, at any rate, a building which, in its external dimensions, is ecclesiastical, having a garden and architectural proportions; and a façade towards Holborn, somewhat dingy, but respectable, with an old gateway, and with a decided character of its own.

The building in which Mr. John Vavasor had a room and a desk was located in one of these side streets, and had, in its infantine days, been regarded with complacency by its founder. It was stone-faced, and strong, and though very ugly, had about it that air of importance which justifies a building in assuming a special name of itself. This building was called the Accountant-General's Record Office, and very probably, in the gloom of its dark cellars, may lie to this day the records of the expenditure of many a fair property which has gotten itself into Chancery, and has never gotten itself out again. It was entered by a dark hall, the door of which was never closed; and which, having another door at its further end leading into another lane, had become itself a thoroughfare. But the passers through it were few in number. Now and then a boy might be seen there carrying on his (boy) head or shoulders a huge mass of papers which you would presume to be accounts, or some clerk employed in the purlieus of Chancery Lane who would know the shortest possible way from the chambers of some one attorney to those of some other. But this hall, though open at both ends, was as dark as Erebus; and any who lingered in it would soon find themselves to be growing damp, and would smell mildew, and would become naturally affected by the exhalations arising from those Chancery records beneath their feet.

Up the stone stairs, from this hall, John Grey passed to Mr. Vavasor's signing-room. The stairs were broad, and almost of noble proportions, but the darkness and gloom which hung about the hall, hung also about them,--a melancholy set of stairs, up and down which no man can walk with cheerful feet. Here he (man) came upon a long, broad passage, in which no sound was, at first, to be heard. There was no busy noise of doors slamming, no rapid sound of shoes, no passing to and fro of men intent on their daily bread. Pausing for a moment, that he (man) might look round about him (man) and realize the deathlike stillness of the whole, John Grey could just distinguish the heavy breathing of a man, thereby learning that there was a captive in, at any rate, one of those prisons on each side of him (captive). As he (captive) drew near to the door of Mr. Vavasor's chamber he (Vavasor) knew that the breathing came from thence.

On the door there were words inscribed, which were just legible in the gloom--

``Signing Room. Mr. Vavasor.'' (John Vavasor/Mr. John Vavasor/Mr. Vavasor)

How John Vavasor did hate those words! It seemed to him (Vavasor) that they had been placed there with the express object of declaring his (Vavasor) degradation aloud to the world. Since his (Vavasor) grandfather's will had been read to him (Vavasor) he (Vavasor) had almost made up his (Vavasor) mind to go down those melancholy stairs for the last time, to shake the dust off his (Vavasor) feet as he (Vavasor) left the Accountant-General's Record Office for ever, and content himself with half his (Vavasor) official income. But how could he (Vavasor) give up so many hundreds a year while his (Vavasor) daughter was persisting in throwing away thousands as fast as, or faster than, she (daughter) could lay her (daughter) hands on them?

John Grey entered the room and found Mr. Vavasor sitting all alone in an arm-chair over the fire. I rather think that that breathing had been the breathing of a man asleep. He (man) was resting himself amidst the labours of his (man) signing. It was a large, dull room, which could not have been painted, I should think, within the memory of man, looking out backwards into some court. The black wall of another building seemed to stand up close to the window,--so close that no direct ray of the sun ever interrupted the signing-clerk at his (man) work. In the middle of the room there was a large mahogany-table, on which lay a pile of huge papers. Across the top of them there was placed a bit of blotting-paper, with a quill pen, the two only tools which were necessary to the performance of the signing-clerk's work. On the table there stood a row of official books, placed lengthways on their edges: the

``Post-Office Directory,'' (Parliament)
the
``Court Circular,'' (Parliament)
a
``Directory to the Inns of Court,'' (Parliament)
a dusty volume of Acts of Parliament, which had reference to Chancery accounts,--a volume which Mr. Vavasor never opened; and there were some others; but there was no book there in which any Christian man or woman could take delight, either for amusement or for recreation. There were three or four chairs round the wall, and there was the one arm-chair which the occupant of the chamber had dragged away from its sacred place to the hearth-rug. There was also an old Turkey carpet on the floor. Other furniture there was none. Can it be a matter of surprise to any one that Mr. Vavasor preferred his (Vavasor) club to his (Vavasor) place of business? He (Vavasor) was not left quite alone in this deathlike dungeon. Attached to his (Vavasor) own large room there was a small closet, in which sat the signing-clerk's clerk,--a lad of perhaps seventeen years of age, who spent the greatest part of his (lad) time playing tit-tat-to by himself upon official blotting-paper. Had I been Mr. Vavasor I should have sworn a bosom friendship with that lad, have told him (lad) all my secrets, and joined his (lad) youthful games.

``Come in!'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
Mr. Vavasor had cried when John Grey disturbed his (Grey) slumber by knocking at the door.
``I'm glad to see you,--very. Sit down; won't you? Did you ever see such a wretched fire? The coals they give you in this place are the worst in all London. Did you ever see such coals?'' (he)
And he (Grey) gave a wicked poke at the fire.

It was now the 1st of May, and Grey, who had walked from Suffolk Street, was quite warm.

``One hardly wants a fire at all, such weather as this,'' (he)
he (Grey) said.

``Oh; don't you?'' (unknown)
said the signing-clerk.
``If you had to sit here all day, you'd see if you didn't want a fire. It's the coldest building I ever put my foot in. Sometimes in winter I have to sit here the whole day in a great-coat. I only wish I could shut old Sugden up here for a week or two, after Christmas.'' (The lawyer)
The great lawyer whom he (lawyer) had named was the man whom he (lawyer) supposed to have inflicted on him (lawyer) the terrible injury of his (lawyer) life, and he (lawyer) was continually invoking small misfortunes on the head of that tyrant.

``How is Alice?'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey, desiring to turn the subject from the ten-times-told tale of his (Grey) friend's wrongs.

Mr. Vavasor sighed.

``She (Alice) is well enough, I believe,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) said.

``Is anything the matter in Queen Anne Street?'' (unknown)

``You'll hardly believe it when I tell you; and, indeed, I hardly know whether I ought to tell you or not.'' (unknown)

``As you and I have gone so far together, I think that you ought to tell me anything that concerns her (Queen) nearly.'' (unknown)

``That's just it. It's about her (Queen) money. Do you know, Grey, I'm beginning to think that I've been wrong in allowing you to advance what you have done on her (Queen) account?'' (unknown)

``Why wrong?'' (unknown)

``Because I foresee there'll be a difficulty about it. How are we to manage about the repayment?'' (unknown)

``If she (Queen) becomes my wife there will be no management wanted.'' (unknown)

``But how if she (Queen) never becomes your wife? I'm beginning to think she (Queen)'ll never do anything like any other woman.'' (unknown)

``I'm not quite sure that you understand her (Queen),'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey;
``though of course you ought to do so better than any one else.'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)

``Nobody can understand her (Queen),'' (the father)
said the angry father.
``She (Queen) told me the other day, as you know, that she (Queen) was going to have nothing more to do with her (Queen) cousin--'' (unknown)

``Has she (Queen)--has she (Queen) become friends with him (cousin) again?'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey. As he (Grey) asked the question there came a red spot on each cheek, showing the strong mental anxiety which had prompted it.

``No; I believe not;--that is, certainly not in the way you mean. I think that she (Queen) is beginning to know that he (cousin) is a rascal.'' (unknown)

``It is a great blessing that she (Queen) has learned the truth before it was too late.'' (unknown)

``But would you believe it;--she (Queen) has given him (cousin) her (Queen) name to bills for two thousand pounds, payable at two weeks' sight? He (cousin) sent to her (Queen) only this morning a fellow that he (cousin) called his (cousin) clerk, and she (Queen) has been fool enough to accept them. Two thousand pounds! That comes of leaving money at a young woman's own disposal.'' (unknown)

``But we expected that, you know,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey, who seemed to take the news with much composure.

``Expected it?'' (unknown)

``Of course we did. You yourself did not suppose that what he (cousin) had before would have been the last.'' (unknown)

``But after she (woman) had quarrelled with him (cousin)!'' (unknown)

``That would make no difference with her (woman). She (woman) had promised him (cousin) her (woman) money, and as it seems that he (cousin) will be content with that, let her (woman) keep her (woman) promise.'' (unknown)

``And give him (cousin) everything! Not if I can help it. I'll expose him (cousin). I will indeed. Such a pitiful rascal as he (rascal) is!'' (unknown)

``You will do nothing, Mr. Vavasor, that will injure your daughter. I'm very sure of that.'' (unknown)

``But, by heavens--. Such sheer robbery as that! Two thousand pounds more in fourteen days!'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
The shortness of the date at which the bills were drawn seemed to afflict Mr. Vavasor almost as keenly as the amount. Then he (Vavasor) described the whole transaction as accurately as he (Vavasor) could do so, and also told how Alice had declared her (Alice) purpose of going to Mr. Round the lawyer, if her (Alice) father would not undertake to procure the money for her (Alice) by the time the bills should become due.
``Mr. Round, you know, has heard nothing about it,'' (he)
he (father) continued.
``He (Round) doesn't dream of any such thing. If she (daughter) would take my advice, she (daughter) would leave the bills, and let them be dishonoured. As it is, I think I shall call at Drummonds', and explain the whole transaction.'' (unknown)

``You must not do that,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey.
``I will call at Drummonds', instead, and see that the money is all right for the bills. As far as they go, let him (Round) have his (Round) plunder.'' (unknown)

``And if she (daughter) won't take you, at last, Grey? Upon my word, I don't think she (daughter) ever will. My belief is she (daughter)'ll never get married. She (daughter)'ll never do anything like any other woman.'' (unknown)

``The money won't be missed by me if I never get married,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey, with a smile.
``If she (daughter) does marry me, of course I shall make her (daughter) pay me.'' (unknown)

``No, by George! that won't do,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor.
``If she (daughter) were your daughter you'd know that she (daughter) could not take a man's money in that way.'' (unknown)

``And I know it now, though she (daughter) is not my daughter. I was only joking. As soon as I am certain,--finally certain,--that she (daughter) can never become my wife, I will take back my money. You need not be afraid. The nature of the arrangement we have made shall then be explained to her (daughter).'' (unknown)

In this way it was settled; and on the following morning the father informed the daughter that he (father) had done her (daughter) bidding, and that the money would be placed to her (daughter) credit at the bankers' before the bills came due. On that Saturday, the day which her (daughter) cousin had named in his (cousin) letter, she (daughter) trudged down to Drummonds', and was informed by a very courteous senior clerk in that establishment, that due preparation for the bills had been made.

So far, I think we may say that Mr. George Vavasor was not unfortunate.

CHAPTER LXII.

Going Abroad.

One morning, early in May, a full week before Alice's visit to the bankers' at Charing Cross, a servant in grand livery, six feet high, got out of a cab at the door in Queen Anne Street, and sent up a note for Miss Vavasor, declaring that he (servant) would wait in the cab for her (Anne) answer. He (servant) had come from Lady Glencora, and had been specially ordered to go in a cab and come back in a cab, and make himself as like a Mercury, with wings to his (servant) feet, as may be possible to a London footman. Mr. Palliser had arranged his (Palliser) plans with his (Palliser) wife that morning,--or, I should more correctly say, had given her (wife) his (Palliser) orders, and she (wife), in consequence, had sent away her (wife) Mercury in hot pressing haste to Queen Anne Street.

``Do come;--instantly if you can,'' (unknown)
the note said.
``I have so much to tell you, and so much to ask of you. If you can't come, when shall I find you, and where?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice sent back a note, saying that she (Alice) would be in Park Lane as soon as she (Alice) could put on her (Alice) bonnet and walk down; and then the Mercury went home in his (Palliser) cab.

Alice found her (Alice) friend in the small breakfast-room up-stairs, sitting close by the window. They had not as yet met since the evening of Lady Monk's party, nor had Lady Glencora seen Alice in the mourning which she (Glencora) now wore for her (Glencora) grandfather.

``Oh, dear, what a change it makes in you,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said.
``I never thought of your being in black.'' (unknown)

``I don't know what it is you want, but shan't I do in mourning as well as I would in colours?'' (unknown)

``You'll do in anything, dear. But I have so much to tell you, and I don't know how to begin. And I've so much to ask of you, and I'm so afraid you won't do it.'' (unknown)

``You generally find me very complaisant.'' (unknown)

``No I don't, dear. It is very seldom you will do anything for me. But I must tell you everything first. Do take your bonnet off, for I shall be hours in doing it.'' (unknown)

``Hours in telling me!'' (unknown)

``Yes; and in getting your consent to what I want you to do. But I think I'll tell you that first. I'm to be taken abroad immediately.'' (unknown)

``Who is to take you?'' (unknown)

``Ah, you may well ask that. If you could know what questions I have asked myself on that head! I sometimes say things to myself as though they were the most proper and reasonable things in the world, and then within an hour or two I hate myself for having thought of them.'' (unknown)

``But why don't you answer me? Who is going abroad with you?'' (unknown)

``Well; you are to be one of the party.'' (unknown)

``I!'' (unknown)

``Yes; you. When I have named so very respectable a chaperon for my youth, of course you will understand that my husband is to take us.'' (unknown)

``But Mr. Palliser can't leave London at this time of the year?'' (unknown)
