``I'll indict you for slander, my friend,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
said Bellfield.

``Pay me the money you owe me,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre.
``You're a swindler!'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

Mrs. Greenow cared little as to her (Greenow) lover being a swindler in Mr. Cheesacre's estimation. Such accusations from him (Cheesacre) she (Greenow) had heard before. But she (Greenow) did care very much as to this mission of the police against her (Greenow) Captain. If that were true, the Captain could be her (Greenow) Captain no longer.

``What is this I hear, Captain Bellfield?'' (she)
she (Greenow) said.

``It's a lie and a slander. He (Captain) merely wants to make a quarrel between us. What police are after me, Mr. Cheesacre?'' (unknown)

``It's the police, or the sheriff's officer, or something of the kind,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre.

``Oh, the sheriff's officers!'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
exclaimed Mrs. Greenow, in a tone of voice which showed how great had been her (Greenow) relief.
``Mr. Cheesacre, you shouldn't come and say such things;--you shouldn't, indeed. Sheriff's officers can be paid, and there's an end of them.'' (unknown)

``I'll indict him (Sheriff) for the libel--I will, as sure as I'm alive,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
said Bellfield.

``Nonsense,'' (the widow)
said the widow.
``Don't you make a fool of yourself. When men can't pay their way they must put up with having things like that said of them. Mr. Cheesacre, where were you going?'' (unknown)

``I was going to Vavasor Hall, on purpose to caution you.'' (unknown)

``It's too late,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow, sinking behind her (Greenow) veil.

``Why, you haven't been and married him (Cheesacre) since yesterday? He (Cheesacre) only had twenty-four hours' start of me, I know. Or, perhaps, you had it done clandestine in Norwich? Oh, Mrs. Greenow!'' (He)

He (Cheesacre) got out of the gig, and the three walked back towards the Hall together, while the boy drove on with Mr. Cheesacre's carpetbag.

``I hardly know,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow,
``whether we can welcome you. There are other visitors, and the house is full.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

``I'm not one to intrude where I'm not wanted. You may be sure of that. If I can't get my supper for love, I can get at for money. That's more than some people can say. I wonder when you're going to pay me what you owe me, Lieutenant Bellfield?'' (unknown)

-LSB-Illustration:

``I wonder when you're going to pay me what you owe me, Lieutenant Bellfield?'' (the widow)
-RSB-

Nevertheless, the widow had contrived to reconcile the two men before she (Greenow) reached the Hall. They had actually shaken hands, and the lamb Cheesacre had agreed to lie down with the wolf Bellfield. Cheesacre, moreover, had contrived to whisper into the widow's ears the true extent of his (Cheesacre) errand into Westmoreland. This, however, he (Cheesacre) did not do altogether in Bellfield's hearing. When Mrs. Greenow ascertained that there was something to be said, she (Greenow) made no scruple in sending her (Greenow) betrothed away from her (Greenow)

``You won't throw a fellow over, will you, now?'' (she)
whispered Bellfield into her (Bellfield) ear as he (Cheesacre) went. She (Bellfield) merely frowned at him (Cheesacre), and bade him (Cheesacre) begone, so that the walk which Mrs. Greenow began with one lover she (Greenow) ended in company with the other.

Bellfield, who was sent on to the house, found Alice and Kate surveying the newly arrived carpet bag.

``He (Lieutenant) knows `un,'' (the boy)
said the boy who had driven the gig, pointing to the Captain.

``It belongs to your old friend, Mr. Cheesacre,'' (Bellfield/Mrs. Bellfield)
said Bellfield to Kate.

``And has he (Cheesacre) come too?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.

The Captain shrugged his (Captain) shoulders, and admitted that it was hard.

``And it's not the slightest use,'' (he)
said he (Captain),
``not the least in the world. He (Cheesacre) never had a chance in that quarter.'' (he)

``Not enough of the rocks and valleys about him (Cheesacre), was there, Captain Bellfield?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate. But Captain Bellfield understood nothing about the rocks and valleys, though he (Captain) was regarded by certain eyes as being both a rock and a valley himself.

In the meantime Cheesacre was telling his (Cheesacre) story. He (Cheesacre) first asked, in a melancholy tone, whether it was really necessary that he (Cheesacre) must abandon all his (Cheesacre) hopes.

``He (Captain) wasn't going to say anything against the Captain,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) said,
``if things were really fixed. He (Captain) never begrudged any man his (Captain) chance.'' (he)

``Things are really fixed,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.

He (Cheesacre) could, however, not keep himself from hinting that Oileymead was a substantial home, and that Bellfield had not as much as a straw mattress to lie upon. In answer to this Mrs. Greenow told him (Cheesacre) that there was so much more reason why some one should provide the poor man with a mattress.

``If you look at it in that light, of course it's true,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre. Mrs. Greenow told him (Cheesacre) that she (Greenow) did look at it in that light.
``Then I've done about that,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre;
``and as to the little bit of money he (Captain) owes me, I must give him (Captain) his (Captain) time about it, I suppose.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
Mrs. Greenow assured him (Cheesacre) that it should be paid as soon as possible after the nuptial benediction had been said over them. She (Greenow) offered, indeed, to pay it at once if he (Cheesacre) was in distress for it, but he (Cheesacre) answered contemptuously that he (Cheesacre) never was in distress for money. He (Cheesacre) liked to have his (Cheesacre) own,--that was all.

After this he (Cheesacre) did not get away to his (Cheesacre) next subject quite so easily as he (Cheesacre) wished; and it must be admitted that there was a difficulty. As he (Cheesacre) could not have Mrs. Greenow he (Cheesacre) would be content to put up with Kate for his (Cheesacre) wife. That was his (Cheesacre) next subject. Rumours as to the old Squire's will had no doubt reached him (Squire), and he (Squire) was now willing to take advantage of that assistance which Mrs. Greenow had before offered him (Squire) in this matter. The time had come in which he (Squire) ought to marry; of that he (Squire) was aware. He (Squire) had told many of his (Squire) friends in Norfolk that Kate Vavasor had thrown herself at his (Squire) head, and very probably he (Squire) had thought it true. In answer to all his (Squire) love speeches to herself, the aunt had always told him (Squire) what an excellent wife her (wife) niece would make him (Squire). So now he (Squire) had come to Westmoreland with this second string to his (Squire) bow.

``You know you put it into my head your own self,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
pleaded Mr. Cheesacre.
``Didn't you, now?'' (unknown)

``But things are so different since that,'' (the widow)
said the widow.

``How different? I ain't different. There's Oileymead just where it always was, and the owner of it don't owe a shilling to any man. How are things different?'' (unknown)

``My niece has inherited property.'' (unknown)

``And is that to make a change? Oh! Mrs. Greenow, who would have thought to find you mercenary like that? Inherited property! Is she (Greenow) going to fling a man over because of that?'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

Mrs. Greenow endeavoured to explain to him (Cheesacre) that her (Greenow) niece could hardly be said to have flung him (Cheesacre) over, and at last pretended to become angry when he (Cheesacre) attempted to assert his (Cheesacre) position.

``Why, Mr. Cheesacre, I am quite sure she (Greenow) never gave you a word of encouragement in her (Greenow) life.'' (unknown)

``But you always told me I might have her (Greenow) for the asking.'' (unknown)

``And now I tell you that you mayn't. It's of no use your going on there to ask her (Greenow), for she (Greenow) will only send you away with an answer you won't like. Look here, Mr. Cheesacre; you want to get married, and it's quite time you should. There's my dear friend Charlie Fairstairs. How could you get a better wife than Charlie?'' (unknown)

``Charlie Fairstairs!'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre, turning up his (Cheesacre) nose in disgust.
``She (wife) hasn't got a penny, nor any one belonging to her (wife). The man who marries her (wife) will have to find the money for the smock she (wife) stands up in.'' (unknown)

``Who's mercenary now, Mr. Cheesacre? Do you go home and think of it; and if you'll marry Charlie, I'll go to your wedding. You shan't be ashamed of her (wife) clothing. I'll see to that.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)

They were now close to the gate, and Cheesacre paused before he (Cheesacre) entered.

``Do you think there's no chance at all for me, then?'' (he)
said he (Cheesacre).

``I know there's none. I've heard her (wife) speak about it.'' (unknown)

``Somebody else, perhaps, is the happy man?'' (unknown)

``I can't say anything about that, but I know that she (wife) wouldn't take you. I like farming, you know, but she (wife) doesn't.'' (unknown)

``I might give that up,'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)
said Cheesacre readily,--
``at any rate, for a time.'' (Mr. Cheesacre/Cheesacre)

``No, no, no; it would do no good. Believe me, my friend, that it is of no use.'' (He)

He (Cheesacre) still paused at the gate.

``I don't see what's the use of my going in,'' (he)
said he (Cheesacre). To this she (Greenow) made him (Cheesacre) no answer.
``There's a pride about me,'' (he)
he (Cheesacre) continued,
``that I don't choose to go where I'm not wanted.'' (he)

``I can't tell you, Mr. Cheesacre, that you are wanted in that light, certainly.'' (unknown)

``Then I'll go. Perhaps you'll be so good as to tell the boy with the gig to come after me? That's six pound ten it will have cost me to come here and go back. Bellfield did it cheaper, of course; he (boy) travelled second class. I heard of him (boy) as I came along.'' (unknown)

``The expense does not matter to you, Mr. Cheesacre.'' (he)

To this he (Cheesacre) assented, and then took his (Cheesacre) leave, at first offering his (Cheesacre) hand to Mrs. Greenow with an air of offended dignity, but falling back almost into humility during the performance of his (Cheesacre) adieu. Before he (Cheesacre) was gone he (Cheesacre) had invited her (Greenow) to bring the Captain to Oileymead when she (Greenow) was married, and had begged her (Greenow) to tell Miss Vavasor how happy he (Cheesacre) should be to receive her (Greenow).

``And Mr. Cheesacre,'' (the widow)
said the widow, as he (Cheesacre) walked back along the road,
``don't forget dear Charlie Fairstairs.'' (he)

They were all standing at the front door of the house when Mrs. Greenow re-appeared,--Alice, Kate, Captain Bellfield, the Shap boy, and the Shap horse and gig.

``Where is he (Cheesacre)?'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Kate asked in a low voice, and everyone there felt how important was the question.
``He (Cheesacre) has gone,'' (the widow)
said the widow. Bellfield was so relieved that he (Captain) could not restrain his (Captain) joy, but took off his (Captain) little straw hat and threw it up into the air. Kate's satisfaction was almost as intense.
``I am so glad,'' (she)
said she (Kate).
``What on earth should we have done with him (Cheesacre)?'' (unknown)
``I never was so disappointed in my life,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``I have heard so much of Mr. Cheesacre, but have never seen him (Cheesacre).'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
Kate suggested that she (Kate) should get into the gig and drive after him (Captain).
``He (Cheesacre) ain't a been and took hisself off?'' (the boy)
suggested the boy, whose face became very dismal as the terrible idea struck him (Captain). But, with juvenile craft, he (Captain) put his (Captain) hand on the carpet-bag, and finding that it did not contain stones, was comforted.
``You drive after him (Cheesacre), young gentleman, and you'll find him (gentleman) on the road to Shap,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow.
``Mind you give him (gentleman) my love,'' (the Captain)
said the Captain in his (Captain) glee,
``and say I hope he (gentleman)'ll get his (gentleman) turnips in well.'' (the Captain)

This little episode went far to break the day, and did more than anything else could have done to put Captain Bellfield at his (Captain) ease. It created a little joint-stock fund of merriment between the whole party, which was very much needed. The absence of such joint-stock fund is always felt when a small party is thrown together without such assistance. Some bond is necessary on these occasions, and no other bond is so easy or so pleasant. Now, when the Captain found himself alone for a quarter of an hour with Alice, he (Captain) had plenty of subjects for small-talk.

``Yes, indeed. Old Cheesacre, in spite of his (gentleman) absurdities, is not a bad sort of fellow at bottom;--awfully fond of his (gentleman) money, you know, Miss Vavasor, and always boasting about it.'' (unknown)
``That's not pleasant,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``No, the most unpleasant thing in the world. There's nothing I hate so much, Miss Vavasor, as that kind of talking. My idea is this,--when a man has lots of money, let him (man) make the best use he (man) can of it, and say nothing about it. Nobody ever heard me talking about my money.'' (He)
He (Captain) knew that Alice knew that he (Captain) was a pauper; but, nevertheless, he (Captain) had the satisfaction of speaking of himself as though he (Captain) were not a pauper.

In this way the afternoon went very pleasantly. For an hour before dinner Captain Bellfield was had into the drawing-room and was talked to by his (Captain) widow on matters of business; but he (Captain) had of course known that this was necessary. She (widow) scolded him (Captain) soundly about those sheriff's officers. Why had he (Captain) not told her (widow)?

``As long as there's anything kept back, I won't have you,'' (she)
said she (widow).
``I won't become your wife till I'm quite sure there's not a penny owing that is not shown in the list.'' (I)
Then I think he (Captain) did tell her (widow) all,--or nearly all. When all was counted it was not so very much. Three or four hundred pounds would make him (Captain) a new man, and what was such a sum as that to his (Captain) wealthy widow! Indeed, for a woman wanting a husband of that sort, Captain Bellfield was a safer venture than would be a man of a higher standing among his (man) creditors. It is true Bellfield might have been a forger, or a thief, or a returned convict,--but then his (thief) debts could not be large. Let him (thief) have done his (thief) best, he (thief) could not have obtained credit for a thousand pounds; whereas, no one could tell the liabilities of a gentleman of high standing. Burgo Fitzgerald was a gentleman of high standing, and his (Fitzgerald) creditors would have swallowed up every shilling that Mrs. Greenow possessed; but with Captain Bellfield she (Bellfield) was comparatively safe.

Upon the whole I think that she (Bellfield) was lucky in her (Bellfield) choice; or, perhaps, I might more truly say, that she (Bellfield) had chosen with prudence. He (Captain) was no forger, or thief--in the ordinary sense of the word; nor was he (Captain) a returned convict. He (Captain) was simply an idle scamp, who had hung about the world for forty years, doing nothing, without principle, shameless, accustomed to eat dirty puddings, and to be kicked--morally kicked--by such men as Cheesacre. But he (Cheesacre) was moderate in his (Cheesacre) greediness, and possessed of a certain appreciation of the comfort of a daily dinner, which might possibly suffice to keep him (Cheesacre) from straying very wide as long as his (Cheesacre) intended wife should be able to keep the purse-strings altogether in her (wife) own hands. Therefore, I say that Mrs. Greenow had been lucky in her (Greenow) choice, and not altogether without prudence.

``I think of taking this house,'' (she)
said she (Greenow),
``and of living here.'' (she)

``What, in Westmoreland!'' (the Captain)
said the Captain, with something of dismay in his (Captain) tone. What on earth would he (Captain) do with himself all his (Captain) life in that gloomy place!

``Yes, in Westmoreland. Why not in Westmoreland as well as anywhere else? If you don't like Westmoreland, it's not too late yet, you know.'' (the Captain)
In answer to this the poor Captain was obliged to declare that he (Captain) had no objection whatever to Westmoreland.

``I've been talking to my niece about it,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
continued Mrs. Greenow,
``and I find that such an arrangement can be made very conveniently. The property is left between her (niece) and her (niece) uncle,--the father of my other niece, and neither of them want to live here.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)

``But won't you be rather dull, my dear?'' (unknown)

``We could go to Yarmouth, you know, in the autumn.'' (the Captain)
Then the Captain's visage became somewhat bright again.
``And perhaps, if you are not extravagant, we could manage a month or so in London during the winter, just to see the plays and do a little shopping.'' (the Captain)
Then the Captain's face became very bright.
``That will be delightful,'' (he)
said he (Captain).
``And as for being dull,'' (the widow)
said the widow,
``when people grow old they must be dull. Dancing can't go on for ever.'' (the widow)
In answer to this the widow's Captain assured the widow that she (widow) was not at all old; and now, on this occasion, that ceremony came off successfully which had been interrupted on the Shap road by the noise of Mr. Cheesacre's wheels.
``There goes my cap,'' (she)
said she (widow).
``What a goose you are! What will Jeannette say?'' (unknown)
``Bother Jeannette,'' (the Captain)
said the Captain in his (Captain) bliss.
``She (Jeannette) can do another cap, and many more won't be wanted.'' (I)
Then I think the ceremony was repeated.

Upon the whole the Captain's visit was satisfactory--at any rate to the Captain. Everything was settled. He (Captain) was to go away on Saturday morning, and remain in lodgings at Penrith till the wedding, which they agreed to have celebrated at Vavasor Church. Kate promised to be the solitary bridesmaid. There was some talk of sending for Charlie Fairstairs, but the idea was abandoned.

``We'll have her (Jeannette) afterwards,'' (the widow)
said the widow to Kate,
``when you are gone, and we shall want her (Jeannette) more. And I'll get Cheesacre here, and make him (Jeannette) marry her (Jeannette). There's no good in paying for two journeys.'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
The Captain was to be allowed to come over from Penrith twice a week previous to his (Captain) marriage; or perhaps, I might more fairly say, that he (Captain) was commanded to do so. I wonder how he (Captain) felt when Mrs. Greenow gave him (Captain) his (Captain) first five-pound note, and told him (Captain) that he (Captain) must make it do for a fortnight?--whether it was all joy, or whether there was about his (Captain) heart any touch of manly regret?

``Captain Bellfield, of Vavasor Hall, Westmoreland. It don't sound badly,'' (he)
he (Captain) said to himself, as he (Captain) travelled away on his (Captain) first journey to Penrith.

CHAPTER LXVI.

Lady Monk's Plan.

On the night of Lady Monk's party, Burgo Fitzgerald disappeared; and when the guests were gone and the rooms were empty, his (Fitzgerald) aunt inquired for him (Fitzgerald) in vain. The old butler and factotum of the house, who was employed by Sir Cosmo to put out the lamps and to see that he (Cosmo) was not robbed beyond a certain point on these occasions of his (Cosmo) wife's triumphs, was interrogated by his (Cosmo) mistress, and said that he (Cosmo) thought Mr. Burgo had left the house. Lady Monk herself knocked at her (Monk) nephew's door, when she (Monk) went up-stairs, ascending an additional flight of stairs with her (Monk) weary old limbs in order that she (Monk) might do so; she (Monk) even opened the door and saw the careless debris of his (Burgo) toilet about the room. But he (Burgo) was gone.

``Perhaps, after all, he (Captain) has arranged it,'' (she)
she (Monk) said to herself, as she (Monk) went down to her (Monk) own room.

But Burgo, as we know, had not

``arranged it.'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
It may be remembered that when Mr. Palliser came back to his (Palliser) wife in the supper-room at Lady Monk's, bringing with him (Palliser) the scarf which Lady Glencora had left up-stairs, Burgo was no longer with her (Glencora). He (Burgo) had become well aware that he (Burgo) had no chance left, at any rate for that night. The poor fool, acting upon his (fool) aunt's implied advice rather than his (fool) own hopes, had secured a post-chaise, and stationed it in Bruton Street, some five minutes' walk from his (fool) aunt's house. And he (fool) had purchased feminine wrappings, cloaks, &c.--things that he (fool) thought might be necessary for his (fool) companion. He (fool) had, too, ordered rooms at the new hotel near the Dover Station,--the London Bridge Station,--from whence was to start on the following morning a train to catch the tidal boat for Boulogne. There was a dressing-bag there for which he (fool) had paid twenty-five guineas out of his (fool) aunt's money, not having been able to induce the tradesman to grant it to him (fool) on credit; and there were other things,--slippers, collars, stockings, handkerchiefs, and what else might, as he (fool) thought, under such circumstances be most necessary. Poor thoughtful, thoughtless fool!

The butler was right. He (butler) did leave the house. He (butler) saw Lady Glencora taken to her (Glencora) carriage from some back hiding-place in the hall, and then slipped out, unmindful of his (butler) shining boots, and dress coat and jewelled studs. He (butler) took a Gibus hat,--his (butler) own, or that of some other unfortunate,--and slowly made his (butler) way down to the place in Bruton Street. There was the carriage and pair of horses, all in readiness; and the driver, when he (driver) had placed himself by the door of the vehicle, was not long in emerging from the neighbouring public-house.

``All ready, your honour,'' (the man)
said the man.
``I shan't want you to-night,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo, hoarsely;--
``go away.'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
``And about the things, your honour?'' (unknown)
``Take them to the devil. No; stop. Take them back with you, and ask somebody to keep them till I send for them. I shall want them and another carriage in a day or two.'' (he)
Then he (Burgo) gave the man half a sovereign, and went away, not looking at the little treasures which he (Burgo) had spent so much of his (Burgo) money in selecting for his (Burgo) love. When he (Burgo) was gone, the waterman and the driver turned them over with careful hands and gloating eyes.
``It's a `eiress, I'll go bail,'' (the waterman)
said the waterman.
``Pretty dear! I suppose her (somebody) parints was too many for her (somebody),'' (the driver)
said the driver. But neither of them imagined the enormity which the hirer of the chaise had in truth contemplated.

Burgo from thence took his (Burgo) way back into Grosvenor Square, and from thence down Park Street, and through a narrow passage and a mews which there are in those parts, into Park Lane. He (Burgo) had now passed the position of Mr. Palliser's house, having come out on Park Lane at a spot nearer to Piccadilly; but he (Palliser) retraced his (Palliser) steps, walking along by the rails of the Park, till he (Palliser) found himself opposite to the house. Then he (Palliser) stood there, leaning back upon the railings, and looking up at Lady Glencora's windows. What did he (Palliser) expect to see? Or was he (Palliser), in truth, moved by love of that kind which can take joy in watching the slightest shadow that is made by the one loved object,--that may be made by her (Glencora), or, by some violent conjecture of the mind, may be supposed to have been so made? Such love as that is, I think, always innocent. Burgo Fitzgerald did not love like that. I almost doubt whether he (Fitzgerald) can be said to have loved at all. There was in his (Fitzgerald) breast a mixed, feverish desire, which he (Fitzgerald) took no trouble to analyse. He (Fitzgerald) wanted money. He (Fitzgerald) wanted the thing of which this Palliser had robbed him (Fitzgerald). He (Fitzgerald) wanted revenge,--though his (Fitzgerald) desire for that was not a burning desire. And among other things, he (Fitzgerald) wanted the woman's beauty of the woman whom he (Fitzgerald) coveted. He (Fitzgerald) wanted to kiss her (woman) again as he (Fitzgerald) had once kissed her (woman), and to feel that she (woman) was soft, and lovely, and loving for him (Fitzgerald). But as for seeing her (woman) shadow, unless its movement indicated some purpose in his (Fitzgerald) favour,--I do not think that he (Fitzgerald) cared much about that.

And why then was he (Fitzgerald) there? Because in his (Fitzgerald) unreasoning folly he (Fitzgerald) did not know what step to take, or what step not to take. There are men whose energies hardly ever carry them beyond looking for the thing they want. She (woman) might see him (Fitzgerald) from the window, and come to him (Fitzgerald). I do not say that he (Fitzgerald) thought that it would be so. I fancy that he (Fitzgerald) never thought at all about that or about anything. If you lie under a tree, and open your mouth, a plum may fall into it. It was probably an undefined idea of some such chance as this which brought him (Fitzgerald) against the railings in the front of Mr. Palliser's house; that, and a feeling made up partly of despair and partly of lingering romance that he (Palliser) was better there, out in the night air, under the gas-lamps, than he (Palliser) could be elsewhere. There he (Palliser) stood and looked, and cursed his (Palliser) ill-luck. But his (Palliser) curses had none of the bitterness of those which George Vavasor was always uttering. Through it all there remained about Burgo one honest feeling,--one conviction that was true,--a feeling that it all served him (Burgo) right, and that he (Burgo) had better, perhaps, go to the devil at once, and give nobody any more trouble. If he (devil) loved no one sincerely, neither did he (devil) hate any one; and whenever he (devil) made any self-inquiry into his (devil) own circumstances, he (devil) always told himself that it was all his (devil) own fault. When he (devil) cursed his (devil) fate, he (devil) only did so because cursing is so easy. George Vavasor would have ground his (Vavasor) victims up to powder if he (Vavasor) knew how; but Burgo Fitzgerald desired to hurt no one.

There he (Fitzgerald) stood till he (Fitzgerald) was cold, and then, as the plum did not drop into his (Fitzgerald) mouth, he (Fitzgerald) moved on. He (Fitzgerald) went up into Oxford Street, and walked along it the whole distance to the corner of Bond Street, passing by Grosvenor Square, to which he (Bond) intended to return. At the corner of Bond Street, a girl took hold of him (Bond), and looked up into his (Bond) face.

``Ah!'' (she)
she (girl) said,
``I saw you once before.'' (she)
--
``Then you saw the most miserable devil alive,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo.
``You can't be miserable,'' (the girl)
said the girl.
``What makes you miserable? You've plenty of money.'' (unknown)
--
``I wish I had,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo.
``And plenty to eat and drink,'' (the girl)
exclaimed the girl;
``and you are so handsome! I remember you. You gave me supper one night when I was starving. I ain't hungry now. Will you give me a kiss?'' (the girl)
--
``I'll give you a shilling, and that's better,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo.
``But give me a kiss too,'' (the girl)
said the girl. He (Burgo) gave her (girl) first the kiss, and then the shilling, and after that he (Burgo) left her (girl) and passed on.
``I'm d--d if I wouldn't change with her (you)!'' (he)
he (Burgo) said to himself.
``I wonder whether anything really ails him (I)?'' (the girl)
thought the girl.
``He (I) said he (I) was wretched before. Shouldn't I like to be good to such a one as him (I)!'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)

Burgo went on, and made his (Burgo) way into the house in Grosvenor Square, by some means probably unknown to his (Burgo) aunt, and certainly unknown to his (Burgo) uncle. He (Burgo) emptied his (Burgo) pockets as he (Burgo) got into bed, and counted a roll of notes which he (Burgo) had kept in one of them. There were still a hundred and thirty pounds left. Lady Glencora had promised that she (Glencora) would see him (Burgo) again. She (Glencora) had said as much as that quite distinctly. But what use would there be in that if all his (Burgo) money should then be gone? He (Burgo) knew that the keeping of money in his (Burgo) pocket was to him (Burgo) quite an impossibility. Then he (Burgo) thought of his (Burgo) aunt. What should he (Burgo) say to his (Burgo) aunt if he (Burgo) saw her (aunt) in the course of the coming day? Might it not be as well for him (Burgo) to avoid his (Burgo) aunt altogether?

He (Burgo) breakfasted up-stairs in his (Burgo) bedroom,--in the bed, indeed, eating a small paté de foie gras from the supper-table, as he (Burgo) read a French novel. There he (Burgo) was still reading his (Burgo) French novel in bed when his (Burgo) aunt's maid came to him (Burgo), saying that his (Burgo) aunt wished to see him (Burgo) before she (aunt) went out.

``Tell me, Lucy,'' (he)
said he (Burgo),
``how is the old girl?'' (he)

``She (girl)'s as cross as cross, Mr. Burgo. Indeed, I shan't;--not a minute longer. Don't, now; will you? I tell you she (girl)'s waiting for me.'' (Lucy)
From which it may be seen that Lucy shared the general feminine feeling in favour of poor Burgo.

Thus summoned Burgo applied himself to his (Burgo) toilet; but as he (Burgo) did so, he (Burgo) recruited his (Burgo) energies from time to time by a few pages of the French novel, and also by small doses from a bottle of curaçoa which he (Burgo) had in his (Burgo) bedroom. He (Burgo) was utterly a pauper. There was no pauper poorer than he (Burgo) in London that day. But, nevertheless, he (Burgo) breakfasted on paté de foie gras and curaçoa, and regarded those dainties very much as other men regard bread and cheese and beer.

But though he (Burgo) was dressing at the summons of his (Burgo) aunt, he (Burgo) had by no means made up his (Burgo) mind that he (Burgo) would go to her (aunt). Why should he (Burgo) go to her (aunt)? What good would it do him (Burgo)? She (aunt) would not give him (Burgo) more money. She (aunt) would only scold him (Burgo) for his (Burgo) misconduct. She (aunt) might, perhaps, turn him (Burgo) out of the house if he (Burgo) did not obey her (aunt),--or attempt to do so; but she (aunt) would be much more likely to do this when he (Burgo) had made her (aunt) angry by contradicting her (aunt). In neither case would he (Burgo) leave the house, even though its further use were positively forbidden him (Burgo), because his (Burgo) remaining there was convenient; but as he (Burgo) could gain nothing by seeing

``the old girl,'' (he)
as he (Burgo) had called her (aunt), he (Burgo) resolved to escape to his (Burgo) club without attending to her (aunt) summons.

But his (Burgo) aunt, who was a better general than he (Burgo), out-manoeuvred him (Burgo). He (Burgo) crept down the back stairs; but as he (Burgo) could not quite condescend to escape through the area, he (Burgo) was forced to emerge upon the hall, and here his (Burgo) aunt pounced upon him (Burgo), coming out of the breakfast-parlour.

``Did not Lucy tell you that I wanted to see you?'' (Lady)
Lady Monk asked, with severity in her (Monk) voice.

Burgo replied, with perfect ease, that he (Burgo) was going out just to have his (Burgo) hair washed and brushed. He (Burgo) would have been back in twenty minutes. There was no energy about the poor fellow, unless, perhaps, when he (fellow) was hunting; but he (fellow) possessed a readiness which enabled him (fellow) to lie at a moment's notice with the most perfect ease. Lady Monk did not believe him (fellow); but she (Monk) could not confute him (fellow), and therefore she (Monk) let the lie pass.

``Never mind your hair now,'' (she)
she (Monk) said.
``I want to speak to you. Come in here for a few minutes.'' (him)

As there was no way of escape left to him (fellow), he (fellow) followed his (fellow) aunt into the breakfast-parlour.

``Burgo,'' (she)
she (aunt) said, when she (aunt) had seated herself, and had made him (fellow) sit in a chair opposite to her (aunt),
``I don't think you will ever do any good.'' (her)

``I don't much think I shall, aunt.'' (unknown)

``What do you mean, then, to do with yourself?'' (unknown)

``Oh,--I don't know. I haven't thought much about it.'' (unknown)

``You can't stay here in this house. Sir Cosmo was speaking to me about you only yesterday morning.'' (unknown)

``I shall be quite willing to go down to Monkshade, if Sir Cosmo likes it better;--that is, when the season is a little more through.'' (unknown)

``He (Cosmo) won't have you at Monkshade. He (Cosmo) won't let you go there again. And he (Cosmo) won't have you here. You know that you are turning what I say into joke.'' (unknown)

``No, indeed, aunt,'' (unknown)

``Yes, you are;--you know you are. You are the most ungrateful, heartless creature I ever met. You must make up your mind to leave this house at once.'' (unknown)

``Where does Sir Cosmo mean that I should go, then?'' (unknown)

``To the workhouse, if you like. He (Cosmo) doesn't care.'' (unknown)

``I don't suppose he (Cosmo) does;--the least in the world,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo, opening his (Burgo) eyes, and stretching his (Burgo) nostrils, and looking into his (Burgo) aunt's face as though he (Burgo) had great ground for indignation.

But the turning of Burgo out of the house was not Lady Monk's immediate purpose. She (Monk) knew that he (Burgo) would hang on there till the season was over. After that he (Burgo) must not be allowed to return again, unless he (Burgo) should have succeeded in a certain enterprise. She (Monk) had now caught him (Burgo) in order that she (Monk) might learn whether there was any possible remaining chance of success as to that enterprise. So she (Monk) received his (Burgo) indignation in silence, and began upon another subject.

``What a fool you made of yourself last night, Burgo!'' (unknown)

``Did I;--more of a fool than usual?'' (unknown)

``I believe that you will never be serious about anything. Why did you go on waltzing in that way when every pair of eyes in the room was watching you?'' (unknown)

``I couldn't help going on, if she (Cosmo) liked it.'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes,--say it was her (Cosmo) fault. That's so like a man!'' (unknown)

``Look here, aunt, I'm not going to sit here and be abused. I couldn't take her (aunt) in my arms, and fly away with her (aunt) out of a crowd.'' (unknown)

``Who wants you to fly away with her (aunt)?'' (unknown)

``For the matter of that, I suppose that you do.'' (unknown)

``No, I don't.'' (unknown)

``Well, then, I do.'' (unknown)

``You! you haven't spirit to do that, or anything else. You are like a child that is just able to amuse itself for the moment, and never can think of anything further. You simply disgraced yourself last night, and me too,--and her (aunt); but, of course, you care nothing about that.'' (unknown)

``I had a plan all ready;--only he (you) came back.'' (unknown)

``Of course he (you) came back. Of course he (you) came back, when they sent him (you) word how you and she (aunt) were going on. And now he (you) will have forgiven her (aunt), and after that, of course, the thing will be all over.'' (unknown)

``I tell you what, aunt; she (aunt) would go if she (aunt) knew how. When I was forced to leave her (aunt) last night, she (aunt) promised to see me again. And as for being idle, and not doing anything;--why, I was out in Park Lane last night, after you were in bed.'' (unknown)

``What good did that do?'' (unknown)

``It didn't do any good, as it happened. But a fellow can only try. I believe, after all, it would be easier down in the country,--especially now that he (fellow) has taken it into his (fellow) head to look after her (aunt).'' (Lady Monk)

Lady Monk sat silent for a few moments, and then she (Monk) said in a low voice,

``What did she (aunt) say to you when you were parting? What were her (aunt) exact words?'' (she)
She (Monk), at any rate, was not deficient in energy. She (Monk) was anxious enough to see her (Monk) purpose accomplished. She (Monk) would have conducted the matter with discretion, if the running away with Mr. Palliser's wife could, in very fact, have been done by herself.

``She (aunt) said she (aunt) would see me again. She (aunt) promised it twice.'' (unknown)

``And was that all?'' (unknown)

``What could she (aunt) say more, when she (aunt) was forced to go away?'' (unknown)

``Had she (aunt) said that she (aunt) would go with you?'' (unknown)

``I had asked her (aunt),--half a dozen times, and she (aunt) did not once refuse. I know she (aunt) means it, if she (aunt) knew how to get away. She (aunt) hates him (aunt);--I'm sure of it. A woman, you know, wouldn't absolutely say that she (woman) would go, till she (woman) was gone.'' (unknown)

``If she (woman) really meant it, she (woman) would tell you.'' (unknown)

``I don't think she (woman) could have told me plainer. She (woman) said she (woman) would see me again. She (woman) said that twice over.'' (Lady)

Again Lady Monk sat silent. She (Monk) had a plan in her (Monk) head,--a plan that might, as she (Monk) thought, give to her (Monk) nephew one more chance. But she (Monk) hesitated before she (Monk) could bring herself to explain it in detail. At first she (Monk) had lent a little aid to this desired abduction of Mr. Palliser's wife, but in lending it had said no word upon the subject. During the last season she (wife) had succeeded in getting Lady Glencora to her (wife) house in London, and had taken care that Burgo should meet her (wife) there. Then a hint or two had been spoken, and Lady Glencora had been asked to Monkshade. Lady Glencora, as we know, did not go to Monkshade, and Lady Monk had then been baffled. But she (Monk) did not therefore give up the game. Having now thought of it so much, she (Monk) began to speak of it more boldly, and had procured money for her (Monk) nephew that he (nephew) might thereby be enabled to carry off the woman. But though this had been well understood between them, though words had been spoken which were sufficiently explicit, the plan had not been openly discussed. Lady Monk had known nothing of the mode in which Lady Glencora was to have been carried off after her (Glencora) party, nor whither she (Glencora) was to have been taken. But now,--now she (Glencora) must arrange it herself, and have a scheme of her (Glencora) own, or else the thing must fail absolutely. Even she (Glencora) was almost reluctant to speak out plainly to her (Glencora) nephew on such a subject. What if he (nephew) should be false to her (Glencora), and tell of her (Glencora)? But when a woman has made such schemes, nothing distresses her (Glencora) so sadly as their failure. She (Glencora) would risk all rather than that Mr. Palliser should keep his (Palliser) wife.

``I will try and help you,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said at last, speaking hoarsely, almost in a whisper,
``if you have courage to make an attempt yourself.'' (she)

``Courage!'' (he)
said he (Palliser)
``What is it you think I am afraid of? Mr. Palliser? I'd fight him (Palliser),--or all the Pallisers, one after another, if it would do any good.'' (he)

``Fighting! There's no fighting wanted, as you know well enough. Men don't fight nowadays. Look here! If you can get her (woman) to call here some day,--say on Thursday, at three o'clock,--I will be here to receive her (woman); and instead of going back into her (woman) carriage, you can have a cab for her (woman) somewhere near. She (woman) can come, as it were, to make a morning call.'' (unknown)

``A cab!'' (unknown)

``Yes; a cab won't kill her (woman), and it is less easily followed than a carriage.'' (unknown)

``And where shall we go?'' (unknown)

``There is a train to Southampton at four, and the boat sails for Jersey at half-past six; you will be in Jersey the next morning, and there is a boat goes on to St. Malo, almost at once. You can go direct from one boat to the other,--that is, if she (woman) has strength and courage.'' (Lady Monk)
After that, who will say that Lady Monk was not a devoted aunt?

``That would do excellently well,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said the enraptured Burgo.

``She (woman) will have difficulty in getting away from me, out of the house. Of course I shall say nothing about it, and shall know nothing about it. She (woman) had better tell her (woman) coachman to drive somewhere to pick some one up, and to return;--out somewhere to Tyburnia, or down to Pimlico. Then she (woman) can leave me, and go out on foot, to where you have the cab. She (woman) can tell the hall-porter that she (woman) will walk to her (woman) carriage. Do you understand?'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
Burgo declared that he (Burgo) did understand.

``You must call on her (woman), and make your way in, and see her (woman), and arrange all this. It must be a Thursday, because of the boats.'' (she)
Then she (Monk) made inquiry about his (Burgo) money, and took from him (Burgo) the notes which he (Burgo) had, promising to return them, with something added, on the Thursday morning; but he (Burgo) asked, with a little whine, for a five-pound note, and got it. Burgo then told her (Monk) about the travelling-bags and the stockings, and they were quite pleasant and confidential.
``Bid her (woman) come in a stout travelling-dress,'' (Lady Monk)
said Lady Monk.
``She (woman) can wear some lace or something over it, so that the servants won't observe it. I will take no notice of it.'' (an aunt)
Was there ever such an aunt?

After this, Burgo left his (Burgo) aunt, and went away to his (Burgo) club, in a state of most happy excitement.

CHAPTER LXVII.

The Last Kiss.

Alice, on her (Alice) return from Westmoreland, went direct to Park Lane, whither Lady Glencora and Mr. Palliser had also returned before her (Glencora). She (Glencora) was to remain with them in London one entire day, and on the morning after that they were to start for Paris. She (Glencora) found Mr. Palliser in close attendance upon his (Palliser) wife. Not that there was anything in his (Palliser) manner which at all implied that he (Palliser) was keeping watch over her (Glencora), or that he (Palliser) was more with her (Glencora), or closer to her (Glencora) than a loving husband might wish to be with a young wife; but the mode of life was very different from that which Alice had seen at Matching Priory!

On her (Alice) arrival Mr. Palliser himself received her (Alice) in the hall, and took her (Alice) up to his (Palliser) wife before she (Alice) had taken off her (Alice) travelling hat.

``We are so much obliged to you, Miss Vavasor,'' (he)
he (Palliser) said.
``I feel it quite as deeply as Glencora.'' (unknown)

``Oh, no,'' (she)
she (Alice) said;
``it is I that am under obligation to you for taking me.'' (she)

He (Palliser) merely smiled, and shook his (Palliser) head, and then took her (Alice) up-stairs. On the stairs he (Palliser) said one other word to her (Alice):

``You must forgive me if I was cross to you that night she (Glencora) went out among the ruins.'' (he)
Alice muttered something,--some little fib of courtesy as to the matter having been forgotten, or never borne in mind; and then they went on to Lady Glencora's room. It seemed to Alice that he (Palliser) was not so big or so much to be dreaded as when she (Alice) had seen him (Palliser) at Matching. His (Palliser) descent from an expectant, or more than an expectant, Chancellor of the Exchequer, down to a simple, attentive husband, seemed to affect his (Chancellor) gait, his (Chancellor) voice, and all his (Chancellor) demeanour. When he (Chancellor) received Alice at the Priory he (Chancellor) certainly loomed before her (Alice) as something great, whereas now his (Chancellor) greatness seemed to have fallen from him (Chancellor). We must own that this was hard upon him (Chancellor), seeing that the deed by which he (Chancellor) had divested himself of his (Chancellor) greatness had been so pure and good!

``Dear Alice, this is so good of you! I am all in the midst of packing, and Plantagenet is helping me.'' (Plantagenet/Plantagenet Palliser)
Plantagenet winced a little under this, as the hero of old must have winced when he (hero) was found with the distaff. Mr. Palliser had relinquished his (Palliser) sword of state for the distaff which he (Palliser) had assumed, and could take no glory in the change. There was, too, in his (Palliser) wife's voice the slightest hint of mockery, which, slight as it was, he (Palliser) perhaps thought she (wife) might have spared.
``You have nothing left to pack,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
continued Glencora,
``and I don't know what you can do to amuse yourself.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``I will help you,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``But we have so very nearly done. I think we shall have to pull all the things out, and put them up again, or we shall never get through to-morrow. We couldn't start to-morrow;--could we, Plantagenet?'' (unknown)

``Not very well, as your rooms are ordered in Paris for the next day.'' (unknown)

``As if we couldn't find rooms at every inn on the road. Men are so particular. Now in travelling I should like never to order rooms,--never to know where I was going or when I was going, and to carry everything I wanted in a market-basket.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice, who by this time had followed her (Alice) friend along the passage to her (Alice) bedroom, and had seen how widely the packages were spread about, bethought herself that the market-basket should be a large one.
``And I would never travel among Christians. Christians are so slow, and they wear chimney-pot hats everywhere. The further one goes from London among Christians, the more they wear chimney-pot hats. I want Plantagenet to take us to see the Kurds, but he (they) won't.'' (unknown)

``I don't think that would be fair to Miss Vavasor,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, who had followed them.

``Don't put the blame on her (I) head,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``Women have always pluck for anything. Wouldn't you like to see a live Kurd, Alice?'' (unknown)

``I don't exactly know where they live,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Nor I. I have not the remotest idea of the way to the Kurds. You see my joke, don't you, though Plantagenet doesn't? But one knows that they are Eastern, and the East is such a grand idea!'' (unknown)

``I think we'll content ourselves with Rome, or perhaps Naples, on this occasion,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

The notion of Lady Glencora packing anything for herself was as good a joke as that other one of the Kurds and whey. But she (Alice) went flitting about from room to room, declaring that this thing must be taken, and that other, till the market-basket would have become very large indeed. Alice was astonished at the extent of the preparations, and the sort of equipage with which they were about to travel. Lady Glencora was taking her (Glencora) own carriage.

``Not that I shall ever use it,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said to Alice,
``but he (Kurd) insists upon it, to show that I am not supposed to be taken away in disgrace. He (Kurd) is so good;--isn't he (Kurd)?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``Very good,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``I know no one better.'' (unknown)

``And so dull!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``But I fancy that all husbands are dull from the nature of their position. If I were a young woman's husband, I shouldn't know what to say to her (woman) that wasn't dull.'' (women servants)

Two women and two men servants were to be taken. Alice had received permission to bring her (Alice) own maid--

``or a dozen, if you want them,'' (maid)
Lady Glencora had said.
``Mr. Palliser in his (Palliser) present mood would think nothing too much to do for you. If you were to ask him (Palliser) to go among the Kurds, he (Palliser)'d go at once;--or on to Crim Tartary, if you made a point of it.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
But as both Lady Glencora's servants spoke French, and as her (Glencora) own did not, Alice trusted herself in that respect to her (Alice) cousin.
``You shall have one all to yourself,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``I only take two for the same reason that I take the carriage,--just as you let a child go out in her (Palliser) best frock, for a treat, after you've scolded her (Palliser).'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

When Alice asked why it was supposed that Mr. Palliser was so specially devoted to her (Alice), the thing was explained to her (Alice).

``You see, my dear, I have told him (Palliser) everything. I always do tell everything. Nobody can say I am not candid. He (Palliser) knows about your not letting me come to your house in the old days. Oh, Alice!--you were wrong then; I shall always say that. But it's done and gone; and things that are done and gone shall be done and gone for me. And I told him (Palliser) all that you said,--about you know what. I have had nothing else to do but make confessions for the last ten days, and when a woman once begins, the more she (woman) confesses the better. And I told him (Palliser) that you refused Jeffrey.'' (unknown)

``You didn't?'' (unknown)

``I did indeed, and he (Jeffrey) likes you the better for that. I think he (Jeffrey)'d let Jeffrey marry you now if you both wished it;--and then, oh dear!--supposing that you had a son and that we adopted it?'' (unknown)

``Cora, if you go on in that way I will not remain with you.'' (unknown)

``But you must, my dear. You can't escape now. At any rate, you can't when we once get to Paris. Oh dear! you shouldn't grudge me my little naughtinesses. I have been so proper for the last ten days. Do you know I got into a way of driving Dandy and Flirt at the rate of six miles an hour, till I'm sure the poor beasts thought they were always going to a funeral. Poor Dandy and poor Flirt! I shan't see them now for another year.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

On the following morning they breakfasted early, because Mr. Palliser had got into an early habit. He (Palliser) had said that early hours would be good for them.

``But he (Dandy) never tells me why,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``I think it is pleasant when people are travelling,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``It isn't that,'' (cousin)
her (Alice) cousin answered;
``but we are all to be such particularly good children. It's hardly fair, because he (Dandy) went to sleep last night after dinner while you and I kept ourselves awake: but we needn't do that another night, to be sure.'' (cousin)
After breakfast they all three went to work to do nothing. It was ludicrous and almost painful to see Mr. Palliser wandering about and counting the boxes, as though he (Palliser) could do any good by that. At this special crisis of his (Palliser) life he (Palliser) hated his (Palliser) papers and figures and statistics, and could not apply himself to them. He (Palliser), whose application had been so unremitting, could apply himself now to nothing. His (Palliser) world had been brought to an abrupt end, and he (Palliser) was awkward at making a new beginning. I believe that they all three were reading novels before one o'clock. Lady Glencora and Alice had determined that they would not leave the house throughout the day.
``Nothing has been said about it, but I regard it as part of the bond that I'm not to go out anywhere. Who knows but what I might be found in Gloucester Square?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
There was, however, no absolute necessity that Mr. Palliser should remain with them; and, at about three, he (Palliser) prepared himself for a solitary walk. He (Palliser) would not go down to the House. All interest in the House was over with him (Palliser) for the present. He (Palliser) had the Speaker's leave to absent himself for the season. Nor would he (Palliser) call on anyone. All his (Palliser) friends knew, or believed they knew, that he (Palliser) had left town. His (Palliser) death and burial had been already chronicled, and were he (Palliser) now to reappear, he (Palliser) could reappear only as a ghost. He (Palliser) was being talked of as the departed one;--or rather, such talk on all sides had now come nearly to an end. The poor Duke of St. Bungay still thought of him (Palliser) with regret when more than ordinarily annoyed by some special grievance coming to him (Palliser) from Mr. Finespun; but even the Duke had become almost reconciled to the present order of things. Mr. Palliser knew better than to disturb all this by showing himself again in public; and prepared himself, therefore, to take another walk under the elms in Kensington Gardens.

He (Palliser) had his (Palliser) hat on his (Palliser) head in the hall, and was in the act of putting on his (Palliser) gloves, when there came a knock at the front door. The hall-porter was there, a stout, plethoric personage, not given to many words, who was at this moment standing with his (Palliser) master's umbrella in his (Palliser) hand, looking as though he (Palliser) would fain be of some use to somebody, if any such utility were compatible with the purposes of his (Palliser) existence. Now had come this knock at the door, while the umbrella was still in his (Palliser) hand, and the nature of his (Palliser) visage changed, and it was easy to see that he (Palliser) was oppressed by the temporary multiplicity of his (Palliser) duties.

``Give me the umbrella, John,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser. John gave up the umbrella, and opening the door disclosed Burgo Fitzgerald standing upon the door-step.
``Is Lady Glencora at home?'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
asked Burgo, before he (Burgo) had seen the husband. John turned a dismayed face upon his (John) master, as though he (John) knew that the comer ought not to be making a morning call at that house,--as no doubt he (John) did know very well,--and made no instant reply.
``I am not sure,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, making his (Palliser) way out as he (Palliser) had originally purposed.
``The servant will find out for you.'' (he)
Then he (Palliser) went on his (Palliser) way across Park Lane and into the Park, never once turning back his (Palliser) face to see whether Burgo had effected an entrance into the house. Nor did he (Burgo) return a minute earlier than he (Burgo) would otherwise have done. After all, there was something chivalrous about the man.

``Yes; Lady Glencora was at home,'' (the porter)
said the porter, not stirring to make any further inquiry. It was no business of his (porter) if Mr. Palliser chose to receive such a guest. He (Palliser) had not been desired to say that her (porter) ladyship was not at home. Burgo was therefore admitted and shown direct up into the room in which Lady Glencora was sitting. As chance would have it, she (Glencora) was alone. Alice had left her (Alice) and was in her (Alice) own chamber, and Lady Glencora was sitting at the window of the small room up-stairs that overlooked the Park. She (Glencora) was seated on a footstool with her (Glencora) face between her (Glencora) hands when Burgo was admitted, thinking of him (Burgo), and of what the world might have been to her (Glencora) had
``they left her (Glencora) alone,'' (him)
as she (Glencora) was in the habit of saying to Alice and to herself.

She (Alice) rose quickly, so that he (Burgo) saw her (Alice) only as she (Alice) was rising.

``Ask Miss Vavasor to come to me,'' (she)
she (Alice) said, as the servant left the room; and then she (Alice) came forward to greet her (Alice) lover.

``Cora,'' (he)
he (lover) said, dashing at once into his (lover) subject--hopelessly, but still with a resolve to do as he (lover) had said that he (lover) would do.
``Cora, I have come to you, to ask you to go with me.'' (unknown)

``I will not go with you,'' (she)
said she (Alice).

``Do not answer me in that way, without a moment's thought. Everything is arranged--'' (she)

``Yes, everything is arranged,'' (she)
she (Alice) said.
``Mr. Fitzgerald, let me ask you to leave me alone, and to behave to me with generosity. Everything is arranged. You can see that my boxes are all prepared for going. Mr. Palliser and I, and my friend, are starting to-morrow. Wish me God-speed and go, and be generous.'' (unknown)

``And is this to be the end of everything?'' (He)
He (lover) was standing close to her (Alice), but hitherto he (lover) had only touched her (Alice) hand at greeting her (Alice).
``Give me your hand, Cora,'' (he)
he (lover) said.

``No;--I will never give you my hand again. You should be generous to me and go. This is to be the end of everything,--of everything that is common to you and to me. Go, when I ask you.'' (unknown)

``Cora; did you ever love me?'' (unknown)

``Yes; I did love you. But we were separated, and there was no room for love left between us.'' (unknown)

``You are as dear to me now,--dearer than ever you were. Do not look at me like that. Did you not tell me when we last parted that I might come to you again? Are we children, that others should come between us and separate us like that?'' (unknown)

``Yes, Burgo; we are children. Here is my cousin coming. You must leave me now.'' (she)
As she (Alice) spoke the door was opened and Alice entered the room.
``Miss Vavasor, Mr. Fitzgerald,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``I have told him (Fitzgerald) to go and leave me. Now that you have come, Alice, he (Fitzgerald) will perhaps obey me.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice was dumbfounded, and knew not how to speak either to him (lover) or to her (Alice); but she (Alice) stood with her (Alice) eyes riveted on the face of the man of whom she (Alice) had heard so much. Yes; certainly he (man) was very beautiful. She (Alice) had never before seen man's beauty such as that. She (Alice) found it quite impossible to speak a word to him (man) then--at the spur of the moment, but she (Alice) acknowledged the introduction with a slight inclination of the head, and then stood silent, as though she (Alice) were waiting for him (man) to go.

``Mr. Fitzgerald, why do you not leave me and go?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

Poor Burgo also found it difficult enough to speak. What could he (Burgo) say? His (Burgo) cause was one which certainly did not admit of being pleaded in the presence of a strange lady; and he (Burgo) might have known from the moment in which he (Burgo) heard Glencora's request that a third person should be summoned to their meeting--and probably did know, that there was no longer any hope for him (Burgo). It was not on the cards that he (Burgo) should win. But there remained one thing that he (Burgo) must do. He (Burgo) must get himself out of that room; and how was he (Burgo) to effect that?

``I had hoped,'' (he)
said he (Burgo), looking at Alice, though he (Burgo) addressed Lady Glencora--
``I had hoped to be allowed to speak to you alone for a few minutes.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``No, Mr. Fitzgerald; it cannot be so. Alice do not go. I sent for my cousin when I saw you, because I did not choose to be alone with you. I have asked you to go--'' (unknown)

``You perhaps have not understood me?'' (unknown)

``I understand you well enough.'' (unknown)

``Then, Mr. Fitzgerald,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice,
``why do you not do as Lady Glencora has asked you? You know--you must know, that you ought not to be here.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``I know nothing of the kind,'' (he)
said he (Burgo), still standing his (Burgo) ground.

``Alice,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora,
``we will leave Mr. Fitzgerald here, since he (Fitzgerald) drives us from the room.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

In such contests, a woman has ever the best of it at all points. The man plays with a button to his (man) foil, while the woman uses a weapon that can really wound. Burgo knew that he (Burgo) must go,--felt that he (Burgo) must skulk away as best he (Burgo) might, and perhaps hear a low titter of half-suppressed laughter as he (Burgo) went. Even that might be possible.

``No, Lady Glencora,'' (he)
he (Burgo) said,
``I will not drive you from the room. As one must be driven out, it shall be I. I own I did think that you would at any rate have been--less hard to me.'' (he)
He (Burgo) then turned to go, bowing again very slightly to Miss Vavasor.

He (Burgo) was on the threshold of the door before Glencora's voice recalled him (Burgo).

``Oh my God!'' (she)
she (Glencora) said,
``I am hard,--harder than flint. I am cruel. Burgo!'' (she)
And he (Burgo) was back with her (Glencora) in a moment, and had taken her (Glencora) by the hand.

``Glencora,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice,
``pray,--pray let him (God) go. Mr. Fitzgerald, if you are a man, do not take advantage of her (Glencora) folly.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``I will speak to him (Fitzgerald),'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``I will speak to him (Fitzgerald), and then he (Fitzgerald) shall leave me.'' (She)
She (Glencora) was holding him (Burgo) by the hand now and turning to him (Burgo), away from Alice, who had taken her (Alice) by the arm.
``Burgo,'' (she)
she (Alice) said, repeating his (Burgo) name twice again, with all the passion that she (Alice) could throw into the word,--
``Burgo, no good can come of this. Now, you must leave me. You must go. I shall stay with my husband as I am bound to do. Because I have wronged you, I will not wrong him (husband) also. I loved you;--you know I loved you.'' (she)
She (Alice) still held him (Burgo) by the hand, and was now gazing up into his (Burgo) face, while the tears were streaming from her (Alice) eyes.

``Sir,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice,
``you have heard from her (Glencora) all that you can care to hear. If you have any feeling of honour in you, you will leave her (Glencora).'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``I will never leave her (Glencora), while she (Glencora) tells me that she (Glencora) loves me!'' (unknown)

``Yes, Burgo, you will;--you must! I shall never tell you that again, never. Do as she (Glencora) bids you. Go, and leave us;--but I could not bear that you should tell me that I was hard.'' (unknown)

``You are hard;--hard and cruel, as you said, yourself.'' (unknown)

``Am I? May God forgive you for saying that of me!'' (unknown)

``Then why do you send me away?'' (unknown)

``Because I am a man's wife, and because I care for his (man) honour, if not for my own. Alice, let us go.'' (He)

He (Burgo) still held her (Alice), but she (Alice) would have been gone from him (Burgo) had he (Burgo) not stooped over her (Alice), and put his (Burgo) arm round her (Alice) waist. In doing this, I doubt whether he (Burgo) was quicker than she (Alice) would have been had she (Alice) chosen to resist him (Burgo). As it was, he (Burgo) pressed her (Alice) to his (Burgo) bosom, and, stooping over her (Alice), kissed her (Alice) lips. Then he (Burgo) left her (Alice), and making his (Burgo) way out of the room, and down the stairs, got himself out into the street.

``Thank God, that he (God) is gone!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``You may say so,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora,
``for you have lost nothing!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``And you have gained everything!'' (unknown)

``Have I? I did not know that I had ever gained anything, as yet. The only human being to whom I have ever yet given my whole heart,--the only thing that I have ever really loved, has just gone from me for ever, and you bid me thank God that I have lost him (God). There is no room for thankfulness in any of it;--either in the love or in the loss. It is all wretchedness from first to last!'' (unknown)

``At any rate, he (God) understands now that you meant it when you told him (God) to leave you.'' (unknown)

``Of course I meant it. I am beginning to know myself by degrees. As for running away with him (God), I have not the courage to do it. I can think of it, scheme for it, wish for it;--but as for doing it, that is beyond me. Mr. Palliser is quite safe. He (Palliser) need not try to coax me to remain.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice knew that it was useless to argue with her (Alice), so she (Alice) came and sat over her (Alice),--for Lady Glencora had again placed herself on the stool by the window,--and tried to sooth her (Glencora) by smoothing her (Glencora) hair, and nursing her (Glencora) like a child.

``Of course I know that I ought to stay where I am,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said, breaking out, almost with rage, and speaking with quick, eager voice.
``I am not such a fool as to mistake what I should be if I left my husband, and went to live with that man as his (man) mistress. You don't suppose that I should think that sort of life very blessed. But why have I been brought to such a pass as this? And, as for female purity! Ah! What was their idea of purity when they forced me, like ogres, to marry a man for whom they knew I never cared? Had I gone with him (man),--had I now eloped with that man who ought to have been my husband,--whom would a just God have punished worst,--me, or those two old women and my uncle, who tortured me into this marriage?'' (unknown)

``Come, Cora,--be silent.'' (unknown)

``I won't be silent! You have had the making of your own lot. You have done what you liked, and no one has interfered with you. You have suffered, too; but you, at any rate, can respect yourself.'' (unknown)

``And so can you, Cora,--thoroughly, now.'' (unknown)

``How;--when he (Cora) kissed me, and I could hardly restrain myself from giving him (Cora) back his (Cora) kiss tenfold, could I respect myself? But it is all sin. I sin towards my husband, feigning that I love him (husband); and I sin in loving that other man, who should have been my husband. There;--I hear Mr. Palliser at the door. Come away with me; or rather, stay, for he (Palliser) will come up here, and you can keep him (Palliser) in talk while I try to recover myself.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

Mr. Palliser did at once as his (Palliser) wife had said, and came up-stairs to the little front room, as soon as he (Palliser) had deposited his (Palliser) hat in the hall. Alice was, in fact, in doubt what she (Alice) should do, as to mentioning, or omitting to mention, Mr. Fitzgerald's name. In an ordinary way, it would be natural that she (Alice) should name any visitor who had called, and she (Alice) specially disliked the idea of remaining silent because that visitor had come as the lover of her (Alice) host's wife. But, on the other hand, she (Alice) owed much to Lady Glencora; and there was no imperative reason, as things had gone, why she (Alice) should make mischief. There was no further danger to be apprehended. But Mr. Palliser at once put an end to her (Alice) doubts.

``You have had a visitor here?'' (he)
said he (Palliser).

``Yes,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``I saw him (visitor) as I went out,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.
``Indeed, I met him (visitor) at the hall door. He (visitor), of course, was wrong to come here;--so wrong, that he (visitor) deserves punishment, if there were any punishment for such offences.'' (unknown)

``He (visitor) has been punished, I think,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``But as for Glencora,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
continued Mr. Palliser, without any apparent notice of what Alice had said,
``I thought it better that she (Glencora) should see him (visitor) or not, as she (Glencora) should herself decide.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``She (Glencora) had no choice in the matter. As it turned out, he (visitor) was shown up here at once. She (Glencora) sent for me, and I think she (Glencora) was right to do that.'' (unknown)

``Glencora was alone when he (visitor) came in?'' (unknown)

``For a minute or two,--till I could get to her (Glencora).'' (unknown)

``I have no questions to ask about it,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, after waiting for a few moments. He (Palliser) had probably thought that Alice would say something further.
``I am very glad that you were within reach of her (Glencora), as otherwise her (Glencora) position might have been painful. For her (Glencora), and for me perhaps, it may be as well that he (visitor) has been here. As for him (visitor), I can only say, that I am forced to suppose him (visitor) to be a villain. What a man does when driven by passion, I can forgive; but that he (man) should deliberately plan schemes to ruin both her (Glencora) and me, is what I can hardly understand.'' (he)
As he (Palliser) made this little speech I wonder whether his (Palliser) conscience said anything to him (Palliser) about Lady Dumbello, and a certain evening in his (Palliser) own life, on which he (Palliser) had ventured to call that lady, Griselda.

The little party of three dined together very quietly, and after dinner they all went to work with their novels. Before long Alice saw that Mr. Palliser was yawning, and she (Alice) began to understand how much he (Palliser) had given up in order that his (Palliser) wife might be secure. It was then, when he (Palliser) had left the room for a few minutes, in order that he (Palliser) might wake himself by walking about the house, that Glencora told Alice of his (Palliser) yawning down at Matching.

``I used to think that he (man) would fall in pieces. What are we to do about it?'' (unknown)

``Don't seem to notice it,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``That's all very well,'' (unknown)
said the other;
``but he (man)'ll set us off yawning as bad as himself, and then he (man)'ll notice it. He (man) has given himself up to politics, till nothing else has any salt in it left for him (man). I cannot think why such a man as that wanted a wife at all.'' (unknown)

``You are very hard upon him (man), Cora.'' (unknown)

``I wish you were his (Cora) wife, with all my heart. But, of course, I know why he (Cora) got married. And I ought to feel for him (Cora) as he (Cora) has been so grievously disappointed.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Then Mr. Palliser having walked off his (Palliser) sleep, returned to the room, and the remainder of the evening was passed in absolute tranquillity.

Burgo Fitzgerald, when he (Fitzgerald) left the house, turned back into Grosvenor Square, not knowing, at first, whither he (Fitzgerald) was going. He (Fitzgerald) took himself as far as his (Fitzgerald) uncle's door, and then, having paused there for a moment, hurried on. For half an hour, or thereabouts, something like true feeling was at work within his (Fitzgerald) heart. He (Fitzgerald) had once more pressed to his (Fitzgerald) bosom the woman he (Fitzgerald) had, at any rate, thought that he (Fitzgerald) had loved. He (Fitzgerald) had had his (Fitzgerald) arm round her (woman), and had kissed her (woman), and the tone with which she (woman) had called him (Fitzgerald) by his (Fitzgerald) name was still ringing in his (Fitzgerald) ears,

``Burgo!'' (him)
He (Fitzgerald) repeated his (Fitzgerald) own name audibly to himself, as though in this way he (Fitzgerald) could recall her (woman) voice. He (Fitzgerald) comforted himself for a minute with the conviction that she (woman) loved him (Fitzgerald). He (Fitzgerald) felt,--for a moment,--that he (Fitzgerald) could live on such consolation as that! But among mortals there could, in truth, hardly be one with whom such consolation would go a shorter way. He (Fitzgerald) was a man who required to have such comfort backed by patés and curaçoa to a very large extent, and now it might be doubted whether the amount of patés and curaçoa at his (Fitzgerald) command would last him (Fitzgerald) much longer.

He (Fitzgerald) would not go in and tell his (Fitzgerald) aunt at once of his (Fitzgerald) failure, as he (Fitzgerald) could gain nothing by doing so. Indeed, he (Fitzgerald) thought that he (Fitzgerald) would not tell his (Fitzgerald) aunt at all. So he (Fitzgerald) turned back from Grosvenor Square, and went down to his (Fitzgerald) club in St. James's Street, feeling that billiards and brandy-and-water might, for the present, be the best restorative. But, as he (Fitzgerald) went back, he (Fitzgerald) blamed himself very greatly in the matter of those bank-notes which he (Fitzgerald) had allowed Lady Monk to take from him (Fitzgerald). How had it come to pass that he (Fitzgerald) had been such a dupe in her (Monk) hands? When he (Fitzgerald) entered his (Fitzgerald) club in St. James's Street his (Fitzgerald) mind had left Lady Glencora, and was hard at work considering how he (Fitzgerald) might best contrive to get that spoil out of his (Fitzgerald) aunt's possession.

CHAPTER LXVIII.

From London to Baden.

On the following morning everybody was stirring by times at Mr. Palliser's house in Park Lane, and the master of that house yawned no more. There is some life in starting for a long journey, and the life is the stronger and the fuller if the things and people to be carried are numerous and troublesome. Lady Glencora was a little troublesome, and would not come down to breakfast in time. When rebuked on account of this manifest breach of engagement, she (Glencora) asserted that the next train would do just as well; and when Mr. Palliser proved to her (Glencora), with much trouble, that the next train could not enable them to reach Paris on that day, she (Glencora) declared that it would be much more comfortable to take a week in going than to hurry over the ground in one day. There was nothing she (Glencora) wanted so much as to see Folkestone.

``If that is the case, why did not you tell me so before?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, in his (Palliser) gravest voice.
``Richard and the carriage went down yesterday, and are already on board the packet.'' (unknown)

``If Richard and the carriage are already on board the packet,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora,
``of course we must follow them, and we must put off the glories of Folkestone till we come back. Alice, haven't you observed that, in travelling, you are always driven on by some Richard or some carriage, till you feel that you are a slave?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

All this was trying to Mr. Palliser; but I think that he (Palliser) enjoyed it, nevertheless, and that he (Palliser) was happy when he (Palliser) found that he (Palliser) did get his (Palliser) freight off from the Pimlico Station in the proper train.

Of course Lady Glencora and Alice were very ill crossing the Channel; of course the two maids were worse than their mistresses; of course the men kept out of their master's way when they were wanted, and drank brandy-and-water with the steward down-stairs; and of course Lady Glencora declared that she (Glencora) would not allow herself to be carried beyond Boulogne that day;--but, nevertheless, they did get on to Paris. Had Mr. Palliser become Chancellor of the Exchequer, as he (Palliser) had once hoped, he (Palliser) could hardly have worked harder than he (Palliser) did work. It was he (Palliser) who found out which carriage had been taken for them, and who put, with his (Palliser) own hands, the ladies' dressing-cases and cloaks on to the seats,--who laid out the novels, which, of course, were not read by the road,--and made preparations as though this stage of their journey was to take them a week, instead of five hours and a half.

``Oh, dear! how I have slept!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, as they came near to Paris.

``I think you've been tolerably comfortable,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, joyfully.

``Since we got out of that horrid boat I have done pretty well. Why do they make the boats so nasty? I'm sure they do it on purpose.'' (unknown)

``It would be difficult to make them nice, I suppose?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``It is the sea that makes them uncomfortable,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

``Never mind; we shan't have any more of it for twelve months, at any rate. We can get to the Kurds, Alice, without getting into a packet again. That, to my way of thinking, is the great comfort of the Continent. One can go everywhere without being seasick.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

Mr. Palliser said nothing, but he (Palliser) sighed as he (Palliser) thought of being absent for a whole year. He (Palliser) had said that such was his (Palliser) intention, and would not at once go back from what he (Palliser) himself had said. But how was he (Palliser) to live for twelve months out of the House of Commons? What was he (Palliser) to do with himself, with his (Palliser) intellect and his (Palliser) energy, during all these coming dreary days? And then,--he (Palliser) might have been Chancellor of the Exchequer! He (Chancellor) might even now, at this very moment, have been upon his (Chancellor) legs, making a financial statement of six hours' duration, to the delight of one-half of the House, and bewilderment of the other, instead of dragging cloaks across that dingy, dull, dirty waiting-room at the Paris Station, in which British subjects are kept in prison while their boxes are being tumbled out of the carriages.

``But we are not to stop here;--are we?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, mournfully.

``No, dear;--I have given the keys to Richard. We will go on at once.'' (unknown)

``But can't we have our things?'' (unknown)

``In about half an hour,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
pleaded Mr. Palliser.

``I suppose we must bear it, Alice?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora as she (Glencora) got into the carriage that was waiting for her (Glencora).
