Alice thought of the last time in which she (Alice) had been in that room,--when George and Kate had been with her (Kate),--and the two girls had been quite content to wait patiently while their trunks were being examined. But Alice was now travelling with great people,--with people who never spoke of their wealth, or seemed ever to think of it, but who showed their consciousness of it at every turn of their lives.

``After all,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice had said to herself more than once,
``I doubt whether the burden is not greater than the pleasure.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

They stayed in Paris for a week, and during that time Alice found that she (Alice) became very intimate with Mr. Palliser. At Matching she (Alice) had, in truth, seen but little of him (Palliser), and had known nothing. Now she (Alice) began to understand his (Palliser) character, and learned how to talk to him (Palliser), She (Alice) allowed him (Palliser) to tell her (Alice) of things in which Lady Glencora resolutely persisted in taking no interest. She (Glencora) delighted him (Palliser) by writing down in a little pocket-book the number of eggs that were consumed in Paris every day, whereas Glencora protested that the information was worth nothing unless her (Glencora) husband could tell her (Glencora) how many of the eggs were good, and how many bad. And Alice was glad to find that a hundred and fifty thousand female operatives were employed in Paris, while Lady Glencora said it was a great shame, and that they ought all to have husbands. When Mr. Palliser explained that that was impossible, because of the redundancy of the female population, she (Glencora) angered him (Palliser) very much by asserting that she (Glencora) saw a great many men walking about who, she (Glencora) was quite sure, had not wives of their own.

``I do so wish you had married him (Richard)!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Glencora said to Alice that evening.
``You would always have had a pocket-book ready to write down the figures, and you would have pretended to care about the eggs, and the bottles of wine, and the rest of it. As for me, I can't do it. If I see an hungry woman, I can give her (woman) my money; or if she (woman) be a sick woman, I can nurse her (woman); or if I hear of a very wicked man, I can hate him (man);--but I cannot take up poverty and crime in the lump. I never believe it all. My mind isn't big enough.'' (unknown)

They went into no society at Paris, and at the end of a week were all glad to leave it.

``I don't know that Baden will be any better,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora said;
``but, you know, we can leave that again after a bit,--and so we shall go on getting nearer to the Kurds.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

To this, Mr. Palliser demurred.

``I think we had better make up our mind to stay a month at Baden.'' (unknown)

``But why should we make up our minds at all?'' (wife)
his (Palliser) wife pleaded.

``I like to have a plan,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

``And so do I,'' (wife)
said his (Palliser) wife,--
``if only for the sake of not keeping it.'' (wife)

``There's nothing I hate so much as not carrying out my intentions,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

Upon this, Lady Glencora shrugged her (Glencora) shoulders, and made a mock grimace to her (Glencora) cousin. All this her (Glencora) husband bore for a while meekly, and it must be acknowledged that he (husband) behaved very well. But, then, he (husband) had his (husband) own way in everything. Lady Glencora did not behave very well,--contradicting her (Glencora) husband, and not considering, as, perhaps, she (Glencora) ought to have done, the sacrifice he (husband) was making on her (Glencora) behalf. But, then, she (Glencora) had her (Glencora) own way in nothing.

She (Glencora) had her (Glencora) own way in almost nothing; but on one point she (Glencora) did conquer her (Glencora) husband. He (husband) was minded to go from Paris back to Cologne, and so down the Rhine to Baden. Lady Glencora declared that she (Glencora) hated the Rhine,--that, of all rivers, it was the most distasteful to her (Glencora); that, of all scenery, the scenery of the Rhine was the most over-praised; and that she (Glencora) would be wretched all the time if she (Glencora) were carried that way. Upon this, Mr. Palliser referred the matter to Alice; and she (Alice), who had last been upon the Rhine with her (Alice) cousins Kate and George Vavasor, voted for going to Baden by way of Strasbourg.

``We will go by Strasbourg, then,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, gallantly.

``Not that I want to see that horrid church again,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora.

``Everything is alike horrid to you, I think,'' (husband)
said her (Glencora) husband.
``You are determined not to be contented, so that it matters very little which way we go.'' (unknown)

``That's the truth,'' (wife)
said his (husband) wife.
``It does matter very little.'' (Baden)

They got on to Baden,--with very little delay at Strasbourg, and found half an hotel prepared for their reception. Here the carriage was brought into use for the first time, and the mistress of the carriage talked of sending home for Dandy and Flirt. Mr. Palliser, when he (Palliser) heard the proposition, calmly assured his (Palliser) wife that the horses would not bear the journey.

``They would be so out of condition,'' (he)
he (Palliser) said,
``as not to be worth anything for two or three months.'' (he)

``I only meant to ask for them if they could come in a balloon,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

This angered Mr. Palliser, who had really, for a few minutes, thought of pacifying his (Palliser) wife by sending for the horses.

``Alice,'' (she)
she (wife) asked, one morning,
``how many eggs are eaten in Baden every morning before ten o'clock?'' (she)

Mr. Palliser, who at the moment was in the act of eating one, threw down his (Palliser) spoon, and pushed his (Palliser) plate from him (Palliser).

``What's the matter, Plantagenet?'' (she)
she (wife) asked.

``The matter!'' (he)
he (Palliser) said.
``But never mind; I am a fool to care for it.'' (unknown)

``I declare I didn't know that I had done anything wrong,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``Alice, do you understand what it is?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice said that she (Alice) did understand very well.

``Of course she (Alice) understands,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.
``How can she (Alice) help it? And, indeed, Miss Vavasor, I am more unhappy than I can express myself, to think that your comfort should be disturbed in this way.'' (unknown)

``Upon my word I think Alice is doing very well,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``What is there to hurt her (Alice) comfort? Nobody scolds her (Alice). Nobody tells her (Alice) that she (Alice) is a fool. She (Alice) never jokes, or does anything wicked, and, of course, she (Alice) isn't punished.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

Mr. Palliser, as he (Palliser) wandered that day alone through the gambling-rooms at the great Assembly House, thought that, after all, it might have been better for him (Palliser) to have remained in London, to have become Chancellor of the Exchequer, and to have run all risks.

``I wonder whether it would be any harm if I were to put a few pieces of money on the table, just once?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora said to her (Glencora) cousin, on the evening of the same day, in one of those gambling salons. There had been some music on that evening in one side of the building, and the Pallisers had gone to the rooms. But as neither of the two ladies would dance, they had strayed away into the other apartments.

``The greatest harm in the world!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice;
``and what on earth could you gain by it? You don't really want any of those horrid people's money?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``I'll tell you what I want,--something to live for,--some excitement. Is it not a shame that I see around me so many people getting amusement, and that I can get none? I'd go and sit out there, and drink beer and hear the music, only Plantagenet wouldn't let me. I think I'll throw one piece on to the table to see what becomes of it.'' (unknown)

``I shall leave you if you do,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``You are such a prude! It seems to me as if it must have been my special fate,--my good fate, I mean,--that has thrown me so much with you. You look after me quite as carefully as Mr. Bott and Mrs. Marsham ever did; but as I chose you myself, I can't very well complain, and I can't very well get rid of you.'' (unknown)

``Do you want to get rid of me, Cora?'' (unknown)

``Sometimes. Do you know, there are moments when I almost make up my mind to go headlong to the devil,--when I think it is the best thing to be done. It's a hard thing for a woman to do, because she (woman) has to undergo so much obloquy before she (woman) gets used to it. A man can take to drinking, and gambling and all the rest of it, and nobody despises him (man) a bit. The domestic old fogies give him (man) lectures if they can catch him (man), but he (man) isn't fool enough for that. All he (man) wants is money, and he (man) goes away and has his (man) fling. Now I have plenty of money,--or, at any rate, I had,--and I never got my fling yet. I do feel so tempted to rebel, and go ahead, and care for nothing.'' (unknown)

``Throwing one piece on to the table wouldn't satisfy that longing.'' (unknown)

``You think I should be like the wild beast that has tasted blood, and can't be controlled. Look at all these people here. There are husbands gambling, and their wives don't know it; and wives gambling, and their husbands don't know it. I wonder whether Plantagenet ever has a fling? What a joke it would be to come and catch him (I)!'' (unknown)

``I don't think you need be afraid.'' (unknown)

``Afraid! I should like him (I) all the better for it. If he (I) came to me, some morning, and told me that he (I) had lost a hundred thousand pounds, I should be so much more at my ease with him (I).'' (unknown)

``You have no chance in that direction, I'm quite sure.'' (unknown)

``None the least. He (I)'d make a calculation that the chances were nine to seven against him (I), and then the speculation would seem to him (I) to be madness.'' (unknown)

``I don't suppose he (I)'d wish to try, even though he (I) were sure of winning.'' (unknown)

``Of course not. It would be a very vulgar kind of thing then. Look,--there's an opening there. I'll just put on one napoleon.'' (unknown)

``You shall not. If you do, I'll leave you at once. Look at the women who are playing. Is there one there whom it would not disgrace you to touch? Look what they are. Look at their cheeks, and their eyes, and their hands. Those men who rake about the money are bad enough, but the women look like fiends.'' (unknown)

``You're not going to frighten me in that hobgoblin sort of way, you know. I don't see anything the matter with any of the people.'' (unknown)

``What do you think of that young woman who has just got a handful of money from the man next to her (woman)?'' (unknown)

``I think she (woman) is very happy. I never get money given to me by handfuls, and the man to whom I belong gives me no encouragement when I want to amuse myself.'' (unknown)
They were now standing near to one end of the table, and suddenly there came to be an opening through the crowd up to the table itself. Lady Glencora, leaving Alice's side, at once stepped up and deposited a piece of gold on one of the marked compartments. As soon as she (Alice) placed it she (Alice) retreated again with flushed face, and took hold of Alice's arm.
``There,'' (she)
she (Alice) said,
``I have done it.'' (she)
Alice, in her (Alice) dismay, did not know what step to take. She (Alice) could not scold her (Alice) friend now, as the eyes of many were turned upon them, nor could she (Alice), of course, leave her (Alice), as she (Alice) had threatened. Lady Glencora laughed with her (Glencora) peculiar little low laughter, and stood her (Glencora) ground.
``I was determined you shouldn't frighten me out of it,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said.

-LSB-Illustration: Lady Glencora at Baden.-RSB-

One of the ministers at the table had in the meantime gone on with the cards, and had called the game; and another minister had gently pushed three or four more pieces of gold up to that which Lady Glencora had flung down, and had then cunningly caught her (Glencora) eye, and, with all the courtesy of which he (minister) was master, had pushed them further on towards her (Glencora). She (Glencora) had supposed herself to be unknown there in the salon, but no doubt all the croupiers and half the company knew well enough who was the new customer at the table. There was still the space open, near to which she (Glencora) stood, and then someone motioned to her (Glencora) to come and take up the money which she (Glencora) had won. She (Glencora) hesitated, and then the croupier asked her (Glencora), in that low, indifferent voice which these men always use, whether she (Glencora) desired that her (Glencora) money should remain. She (Glencora) nodded her (Glencora) head to him (customer), and he (customer) at once drew the money back again to the spot on which she (Glencora) had placed the first napoleon. Again the cards were turned up softly, again the game was called, and again she (Glencora) won. The money was dealt out to her (Glencora),--on this occasion with a full hand. There were lying there between twenty and thirty napoleons, of which she (Glencora) was the mistress. Her (Glencora) face had flushed before, but now it became very red. She (Glencora) caught hold of Alice, who was literally trembling beside her (Alice), and tried to laugh again. But there was that in her (Alice) eye which told Alice that she (Alice) was really frightened. Some one then placed a chair for her (Alice) at the table, and in her (Alice) confusion, not knowing what she (Alice) was to do, she (Alice) seated herself.

``Come away,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, taking hold of her (Alice), and disregarding everything but her (Alice) own purpose, in the agony of the moment.
``You must come away! You shall not sit there!'' (unknown)
``I must get rid of that money,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora, trying to whisper her (Glencora) words,
``and then I will come away.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
The croupier again asked her (Glencora) if the money was to remain, and she (Glencora) again nodded her (Glencora) head. Everybody at the table was now looking at her (Glencora). The women especially were staring at her (Glencora),--those horrid women with vermilion cheeks, and loud bonnets half off their heads, and hard, shameless eyes, and white gloves, which, when taken off in the ardour of the game, disclosed dirty hands. They stared at her (Glencora) with that fixed stare which such women have, and Alice saw it all, and trembled.

Again she (Alice) won.

``Leave it,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice,
``and come away.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
``I can't leave it,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora.
``If I do, there'll be a fuss. I'll go the next time.'' (she)
What she (Glencora) said was, of course, in English, and was probably understood by no one near her (Glencora); but it was easy to be seen that she (Glencora) was troubled, and, of course, those around her (Glencora) looked at her (Glencora) the more because of her (Glencora) trouble. Again that little question and answer went on between her (Glencora) and the croupier, and on this occasion the money was piled up on the compartment--a heap of gold which made envious the hearts of many who stood around there. Alice had now both her (Alice) hands on the back of the chair, needing support. If the devil should persist, and increase that stock of gold again, she (Alice) must go and seek for Mr. Palliser. She (Alice) knew not what else to do. She (Alice) understood nothing of the table, or of its laws; but she (Alice) supposed all those ministers of the game to be thieves, and believed that all villainous contrivances were within their capacity. She (Alice) thought that they might go on adding to that heap so long as Lady Glencora would sit there, presuming that they might thus get her (Glencora) into their clutches. Of course, she (Glencora) did not sift her (Glencora) suspicions. Who does at such moments?
``Come away at once, and leave it,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said,
``or I shall go.'' (she)
At that moment the croupier raked it all up, and carried it all away; but Alice did not see that this had been done. A hand had been placed on her (Alice) shoulder, and as she (Alice) turned round her (Alice) face her (Alice) eyes met those of Mr. Palliser.
``It is all gone,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora, laughing. And now she (Glencora), turning round, also saw her (Glencora) husband.
``I am so glad that you are come,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``Why did you bring her (you) here?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser. There was anger in his (Palliser) tone, and anger in his (Palliser) eye. He (Palliser) took his (Palliser) wife's arm upon his (Palliser) own, and walked away quickly, while Alice followed them alone. He (Palliser) went off at once, down the front steps of the building, towards the hotel. What he (Palliser) said to his (Palliser) wife, Alice did not hear; but her (Alice) heart was swelling with the ill-usage to which she (Alice) herself was subjected. Though she (Alice) might have to go back alone to England, she (Alice) would tell him (Palliser) that he (Palliser) was ill-treating her (Alice). She (Alice) followed him (Palliser) on, up into their drawing-room, and there he (Palliser) stood with the door open in his (Palliser) hand for her (Alice), while Lady Glencora threw herself upon a sofa, and burst out into affected laughter.
``Here's a piece of work,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said,
``about a little accident.'' (she)

``An accident!'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

``Yes, an accident. You don't suppose that I sat down there meaning to win all that money?'' (he)
Whereupon he (Palliser) looked at her (Glencora) with scorn.

``Mr. Palliser,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice,
``you have treated me this evening in a manner I did not expect from you. It is clear that you blame me.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``I have not said a word, Miss Vavasor.'' (unknown)

``No; you have not said a word. You know well how to show your anger without speaking. As I do not choose to undergo your displeasure, I will return to England by myself.'' (unknown)

``Alice! Alice!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora, jumping up,
``that is nonsense! What is all this trumpery thing about? Leave me, because he (I) chooses to be angry about nothing?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

``Is it nothing that I find my wife playing at a common gambling-table, surrounded by all that is wretched and vile,--established there, seated, with heaps of gold before her (wife)?'' (unknown)

``You wrong me, Plantagenet,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora.
``There was only one heap, and that did not remain long. Did it, Alice?'' (unknown)

``It is impossible to make you ashamed of anything,'' (he)
he (Palliser) said.

``I certainly don't like being ashamed,'' (she)
she (Glencora) answered;
``and don't feel any necessity on this occasion.'' (she)

``If you don't object, Mr. Palliser,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice,
``I will go to bed. You can think over all this at night,--and so can I. Good night, Glencora.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Then Alice took her (Alice) candle, and marched off to her (Alice) own room, with all the dignity of which she (Alice) was mistress.

CHAPTER LXIX.

From Baden to Lucerne.

The second week in July saw Mr. Palliser's party, carriage and all, established at Lucerne, in Switzerland, safe beyond the reach of the German gambling tables. Alice Vavasor was still with them; and the reader will therefore understand that that quarrel about Lady Glencora's wickedness had been settled without any rupture. It had been settled amicably, and by the time that they had reached Lucerne, Alice was inclined to acknowledge that the whole thing was not worth notice; but for many days her (Alice) anger against Mr. Palliser had not been removed, and her (Alice) intimacy with him (Palliser) had been much checked. It was now a month since the occurrence of that little scene in the salon at Baden, which was described in the last chapter,--since Mr. Palliser had marched off with his (Palliser) wife, leaving Alice to follow as she (Alice) best could by herself. After that, as the reader may remember, he (reader) had almost told her (Alice) that she (Alice) was to be blamed because of his (reader) wife's indiscretion; and when she (Alice) had declared her (Alice) intention of leaving him (reader), and making her (Alice) way home to England by herself, he (reader) had answered her (Alice) not at all, and had allowed her (Alice) to go off to her (Alice) own room under the full ban of his (reader) displeasure. Since that he (reader) had made no apology to her (Alice); he (reader) had not, in so many words, acknowledged that he (reader) had wronged her (Alice); but Alice had become aware that he (reader) intended to apologize by his (reader) conduct, and she (Alice) had been content so far to indulge his (reader) obstinacy as to accept this conduct on his (reader) part in lieu of any outspoken petition for pardon. The acknowledgement of a mistake and the asking for grace is almost too much for any woman to expect from such a man as Mr. Palliser.

Early on the morning after the scene in question, Lady Glencora had gone into Alice's bedroom, and had found her (Alice) cousin in her (Alice) dressing-gown, packing up her (Alice) things, or looking as though she (Alice) intended to do so.

``You are not such a fool,'' (she)
she (Alice) said,
``as to think anything of what occurred yesterday?'' (she)
Alice assured her (Alice) that, whether fool or not, she (Alice) did think a great deal of it.
``In point of fact,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice,
``I can't stand it. He (fool) expects me to take care of you, and chooses to show himself offended if you don't do just what he (fool) thinks proper; whereas, as you know well enough, I have not the slightest influence over you.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
All these positions Lady Glencora contradicted vigorously. Of course, Mr. Palliser had been wrong in walking out of the Assembly Rooms as he (Palliser) had done, leaving Alice behind him (Palliser). So much Lady Glencora admitted. But this had come of his (Palliser) intense anxiety.
``And you know what a man he (man) is,'' (wife)
said his (Palliser) wife--
``how stiff, and hard, and unpleasant he (man) can be without meaning it.'' (wife)
--
``There is no reason why I should bear his (man) unpleasantness,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``Yes, there is,--great reason. You are to do it for the sake of friendship. And as for my not doing what you tell me, you know that's not true.'' (unknown)

``Did I not beg you to keep away from the table?'' (unknown)

``Of course you did, and of course I was naughty; but that was only once. Alice, I want you more than I ever wanted you before. I cannot tell you more now, but you must stay with me.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice consented to come down to breakfast without any immediate continuance of her (Alice) active preparations for going, and at last, of course, she (Alice) stayed. When she (Alice) entered the breakfast-room Mr. Palliser came up to her (Alice), and offered her (Alice) his (Palliser) hand. She (Alice) had no alternative but to take it, and then seated herself. That there was an intended apology in the manner in which he (Palliser) offered her (Alice) toast and butter, she (Alice) was convinced; and the special courtesy with which he (Palliser) handed her (Alice) to the carriage, when she (Alice) and Lady Glencora went out for their drive, after dinner, was almost as good as a petition for pardon. So the thing went on, and by degrees Mr. Palliser and Miss Vavasor were again friends.

But Alice never knew in what way the matter was settled between Mr. Palliser and his (Palliser) wife, or whether there was any such settling. Probably there was none.

``Of course, he (I) understands that it didn't mean anything,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora had said.
``He (I) knows that I don't want to gamble.'' (the party)
But let that be as it might, their sojourn at Baden was curtailed, and none of the party went up again to the Assembly Rooms before their departure.

Before establishing themselves at Lucerne they made a little tour round by the Falls of the Rhine and Zurich. In their preparations for this journey, Alice made a struggle, but a struggle in vain, to avoid a passage through Basle. It was only too clear to her (Alice) that Mr. Palliser was determined to go by Basle. She (Alice) could not bring herself to say that she (Alice) had recollections connected with that place which would make a return to it unpleasant to her (Alice). If she (Alice) could have said as much, even to Glencora, Mr. Palliser would no doubt have gone round,--round by any more distant route that might have been necessary to avoid that eternal gateway into Switzerland. But she (Alice) could not say it. She (Alice) was very averse to talking about herself and her (Alice) own affairs, even with her (Alice) cousin. Of course Lady Glencora knew the whole story of Mr. John Grey and his (Grey) rejection,--and knew much also of that other story of Mr. George Vavasor. And, of course, like all Alice's friends, she (Alice) hated George Vavasor, and was prepared to receive Mr. John Grey with open arms, if there were any possibility that her (Alice) cousin would open her (Alice) arms to him (cousin) also. But Alice was so stubborn about her (Alice) own affairs that her (Alice) friend found it almost impossible to speak of them.

``It is not that you trouble me,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice once said,
``but that you trouble yourself about that which is of no use. It is all done and over; and though I know that I have behaved badly,--very badly,--yet I believe that everything has been done for the best. I am inclined to think that I can live alone, or perhaps with my cousin Kate, more happily than I could with any husband.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``That is such nonsense.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps so; but, at any rate, I mean to try. We Vavasors don't seem to be good at marrying.'' (unknown)

``You want some one to break your heart for you; that's what you want,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora. In saying this she (Glencora) knew but little of the state of her (Glencora) friend's heart, and perhaps was hardly capable of understanding it. With all the fuss that Lady Glencora made to herself,--with all the tears that she (Glencora) had shed about her (Glencora) lost lover, and was so often shedding,--with all her (Glencora) continual thinking of the matter, she (Glencora) had never loved Burgo Fitzgerald as Alice Vavasor had loved Mr. Grey. But her (Vavasor) nature was altogether different to that of Alice. Love with her (Alice) had in it a gleam of poetry, a spice of fun, a touch of self-devotion, something even of hero-worship; but with it all there was a dash of devilry, and an aptitude almost for wickedness. She (Alice) knew Burgo Fitzgerald to be a scapegrace, and she (Alice) liked him (Fitzgerald) the better on that account. She (Alice) despised her (Alice) husband because he (husband) had no vices. She (Alice) would have given everything she (Alice) had to Burgo,--pouring her (Alice) wealth upon him (Burgo) with a total disregard of herself, had she (Alice) been allowed to do so. She (Alice) would have forgiven him (Burgo) sin after sin, and might perhaps have brought him (Burgo) round, at last, to some life not absolutely reckless and wretched. But in all that she (Alice) might have done, there would have been no thoughtfulness,--no true care either for him (Burgo) or for herself. And now that she (Alice) was married there was no thoughtfulness, or care either for herself or for her (Alice) husband. She (Alice) was ready to sacrifice herself for him (husband), if any sacrifice might be required of her (Alice). She (Alice) believed herself to be unfit for him (husband), and would have submitted to be divorced,--or smothered out of the way, for the matter of that,--if the laws of the land would have permitted it. But she (Alice) had never for a moment given to herself the task of thinking what conduct on her (Alice) part might be the best for his (husband) welfare.

But Alice's love had been altogether of another kind,--and I am by no means sure that it was better suited for the work of this work-a-day world than that of her (Alice) cousin. It was too thoughtful. I will not say that there was no poetry in it, but I will say that it lacked romance. Its poetry was too hard for romance. There was certainly in it neither fun nor wickedness; nor was there, I fear, so large a proportion of hero-worship as there always should be in a girl's heart when she (girl) gives it away. But there was in it an amount of self-devotion which none of those near to her (girl) had hitherto understood,--unless it were that one to whom the understanding of it was of the most importance. In all the troubles of her (girl) love, of her (girl) engagements, and her (girl) broken promises, she (girl) had thought more of others than of herself,--and, indeed, those troubles had chiefly come from that self-devotion. She (girl) had left John Grey because she (girl) feared that she (girl) would do him (Grey) no good as his (Grey) wife,--that she (girl) would not make him (Grey) happy; and she (girl) had afterwards betrothed herself for a second time to her (girl) cousin, because she (girl) believed that she (girl) could serve him (cousin) by marrying him (cousin). Of course she (girl) had been wrong. She (girl) had been very wrong to give up the man she (girl) did love, and more wrong again in suggesting to herself the possibility of marrying the man she (girl) did not love. She (girl) knew that she (girl) had been wrong in both, and was undergoing repentance with very bitter inward sackcloth. But she (girl) said little of all this even to her (girl) cousin.

They went to Lucerne by Basle, and put up at the big hotel with the balcony over the Rhine, which Alice remembered so well. On the first evening of her (Alice) arrival she (Alice) found herself again looking down upon the river, as though it might have been from the same spot which she (Alice) had occupied together with George and Kate. But, in truth, that house is very large, and has many bedrooms over the water. Who has ever been through Basle, and not stood in one of them, looking down upon the father of waters? Here, on this very spot, in one of these balconies, was brought to her (Kate) a letter from her (Kate) cousin Kate, which was filled with tidings respecting her (Kate) cousin George. Mr. Palliser brought it to her (Kate) with his (Palliser) own hands, and she (Kate) had no other alternative but to read it in his (Palliser) presence.

``George has lost his (George) election,'' (unknown)
the letter began. For one moment Alice thought of her (Alice) money, and the vain struggle in which it had been wasted. For one moment, something like regret for the futility of the effort she (Alice) had made came upon her (Alice). But it passed away at once.
``It was worth our while to try it,'' (she)
she (Alice) said to herself, and then went on with her (Alice) letter.
``I and Aunt Greenow are up in London,'' (unknown)
the letter went on to say, ``and have just heard the news. Though I have been here for three days, and have twice sent word to him (George) to say so, he (George) has not been near me. Perhaps it is best that he (George) should stay away, as I do not know how any words could pass between us that would be pleasant. The poll was finished this afternoon, and he (George) lost his (George) election by a large majority. There were five candidates altogether for the two seats--three Liberals, and two Conservatives. The other two Liberals were seated, and he (George) was the last of the five. I continue to hear tidings about him (George) from day to day,--or rather, my aunt hears them and tells them to me, which fill me full of fears as to his (George) future career. I believe that he (George) has abandoned his (George) business, and that he (George) has now no source of income. I would willingly share what I have with him (George); or I would do more than that. After keeping back enough to repay you gradually what he (George) owes you, I would give him (George) all my share of the income out of the estate. But I cannot do this while we are presumed to be enemies. I am up here to see a lawyer as to some steps which he (lawyer) is taking to upset grandpapa's will. The lawyer says that it is all nonsense, and that George's lawyer is not really in earnest; but I cannot do anything till the matter is settled. Dear Alice, though so much of your money is for a time gone, I am bound to congratulate you on your safety,--on what I may more truly call your escape. You will understand what my own feelings must be in writing this, after all that I did to bring you and him (lawyer) together,--after all my hopes and ambition respecting him (lawyer). As for the money, it shall be repaid. I do not think I shall ever dare to indulge in any strong desire again. I think you will forgive me the injury I have done you;--and I know that you will pity me.

``I am here to see the London lawyer,--but not only for that. Aunt Greenow is buying her (Greenow) wedding clothes, and Captain Bellfield is in lodgings near to us, also buying his (Captain) trousseau; or, as I should more properly say, having it bought for him (Captain). I am hardly in a mood for much mirth, but it is impossible not to laugh inwardly when she (Bellfield) discusses before me the state of his (Captain) wardrobe, and proposes economical arrangements--greatly to his (Captain) disgust. At present, she (Bellfield) holds him (Captain) very tightly in hand, and makes him (Captain) account for all his (Captain) hours as well as all his (Captain) money. ``Of course, he (Captain)'ll run wild directly he (Captain)'s married,

'' she (Alice) said to me, yesterday; `and, of course, there'll always be a fight about it; but the more I do to tame him (Alice) now, the less wild he (Alice)'ll be by-and-by. And though I dare say, I shall scold him (Alice) sometimes, I shall never quarrel with him (Alice).'' (he)
I have no doubt all that is true; but what a fool she (Alice) is to trouble herself with such a man. She (Alice) says she (Alice) does it for an occupation. I took courage to tell her (Alice) once that a caged tiger would give her (Alice) as much to do, and be less dangerous. She (Alice) was angry at this, and answered me very sharply. I had tried my hand on a tiger, she (Alice) said, and had felt his (man) claws. She (Alice) chose to sacrifice herself,--if a sacrifice it were to be,--when some good result might be possible. I had nothing further to say; and from that time to this we have been on the pleasantest terms possible as to the Captain. They have settled with your father to take Vavasor Hall for three years, and I suppose I shall stay with them till your return. What I may do then will depend entirely upon your doings. I feel myself to be a desolate, solitary being, without any tie to any person, or to any place. I never thought that I should feel the death of my grandfather to be such a loss to me as it has been. Except you, I have nothing left to me; and, as regards you, I have the unpleasant feeling that I have for years been endeavouring to do you the worst possible injury, and that you must regard me as an enemy from whom you have escaped indeed, but not without terrible wounds.''

Alice was always angered by any assumption that her (Alice) conduct to Mr. Grey had been affected by the advice or influence of her (Alice) cousin Kate. But this very feeling seemed to preserve Kate from the worse anger, which might have been aroused against her (Kate), had Alice acknowledged the injury which her (Alice) cousin had in truth done to her (Alice). It was undoubtedly true that had Alice neither seen nor heard from Kate during the progress of John Grey's courtship, John Grey would not have lost his (Grey) wife. But against this truth Alice was always protesting within her (Alice) own breast. She (Alice) had been weak, foolish, irresolute,--and had finally acted with false judgement. So much she (Alice) now admitted to herself. But she (Alice) would not admit that any other woman had persuaded her (woman) to such weakness.

``She (Bellfield) mistakes me,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice thought, as she (Alice) put up her (Alice) letter.
``She (Bellfield) is not the enemy who has wounded me.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

Mr. Palliser, who had brought her (Alice) the letter, was seated in the same balcony, and while Alice had been reading, had almost buried himself in newspapers which conveyed intelligence as to the general elections then in progress. He (Palliser) was now seated with a sheet of _The Times_ in his (Palliser) hand, opened to its full extent,--for he (Palliser) had been too impatient to cut the paper,--and as he (Palliser) held it up in his (Palliser) hands before his (Palliser) eyes, was completely hidden beneath it. Five or six other open papers were around him (Palliser), and he (Palliser) had not spoken a word since he (Palliser) had commenced his (Palliser) present occupation. Lady Glencora was standing on the other side of him (Palliser), and she (Glencora) also had received letters.

``Sophy tells me that you are returned for Silverbridge,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said at last.

``Who? I! yes; I'm returned,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, speaking with something like disdain in his (Palliser) voice as to the possibility of anybody having stood with a chance of success against him (Palliser) in his (Palliser) own family borough. For a full appreciation of the advantages of a private seat in the House of Commons let us always go to those great Whig families who were mainly instrumental in carrying the Reform Bill. The house of Omnium had been very great on that occasion. It had given up much, and had retained for family use simply the single seat at Silverbridge. But that that seat should be seriously disputed hardly suggested itself as possible to the mind of any Palliser. The Pallisers and the other great Whig families have been right in this. They have kept in their hands, as rewards for their own services to the country, no more than the country is manifestly willing to give them.
``Yes; I have been returned,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.
``I'm sorry to see, Miss Vavasor, that your cousin has not been so fortunate.'' (unknown)

``So I find,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``It will be a great misfortune to him (cousin).'' (unknown)

``Ah! I suppose so. Those Metropolitan elections cost so much trouble and so much money, and under the most favourable circumstances, are so doubtful. A man is never sure there till he (man) has fought for his (man) seat three or four times.'' (unknown)

``This has been the third time with him (man),'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice,
``and he (man) is a poor man.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``Dear, dear,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, who himself knew nothing of such misfortunes.
``I have always thought that those seats should be left to rich commercial men who can afford to spend money upon them. Instead of that, they are generally contested by men of moderate means. Another of my friends in the House has been thrown out.'' (unknown)

``Who is that unfortunate?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
asked Lady Glencora.

``Mr. Bott,'' (the husband)
said the unthinking husband.

``Mr. Bott out!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
exclaimed Lady Glencora.
``Mr. Bott thrown out! I am so glad. Alice, are you not glad? The red-haired man, that used to stand about, you know, at Matching;--he (man) has lost his (man) seat in Parliament. I suppose he (man)'ll go and stand about somewhere in Lancashire, now.'' (A woman)

A very indiscreet woman was poor Lady Glencora. Mr. Palliser's face became black beneath _The Times_ newspaper.

``I did not know,'' (he)
said he (Palliser),
``that my friend Mr. Bott and Miss Vavasor were enemies.'' (he)

``Enemies! I don't suppose they were enemies,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora.
``But he (Bott) was a man whom no one could help observing,--and disliking.'' (unknown)

``He (Bott) was a man I specially disliked,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, with great courage.
``He (Bott) may be very well in Parliament; but I never met a man who could make himself so disagreeable in society. I really did feel myself constrained to be his (man) enemy.'' (unknown)

``Bravo, Alice!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``I hope he (man) did nothing at Matching, to--to--to--,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
began Mr. Palliser, apologetically.

``Nothing especially to offend me, Mr. Palliser,--except that he (Palliser) had a way that I especially dislike of trying to make little secret confidences.'' (unknown)

``And then he (Palliser) was so ugly,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``I felt certain that he (Palliser) endeavoured to do mischief,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Of course he (Palliser) did,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora;
``and he (Palliser) had a habit of rubbing his (Palliser) head against the papers in the rooms, and leaving a mark behind him (Palliser) that was quite unpardonable.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

Mr. Palliser was effectually talked down, and felt himself constrained to abandon his (Palliser) political ally. Perhaps he (Palliser) did this the easier as the loss which Mr. Bott had just suffered would materially interfere with his (Bott) political utility.

``I suppose he (Palliser) will remain now among his (Palliser) own people,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

``Let us hope he (Palliser) will,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora,--
``and that his (Palliser) own people will appreciate the advantage of his (Palliser) presence.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Then there was nothing more said about Mr. Bott.

It was evening, and while they were still sitting among their letters and newspapers, there came a shout along the water, and the noise of many voices from the bridge. Suddenly, there shot down before them in the swift running stream the heads of many swimmers in the river, and with the swimmers came boats carrying their clothes. They went by almost like a glance of light upon the waters, so rapid was the course of the current. There was the shout of voices,--the quick passage of the boats,--the uprising, some half a dozen times, of the men's hands above the surface; and then they were gone down the river, out of sight,--like morsels of wood thrown into a cataract, which are borne away instantly.

``Oh, how I wish I could do that!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``It seems to be very dangerous,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.
``I don't know how they can stop themselves.'' (unknown)

``Why should they want to stop themselves?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``Think how cool the water must be, and how beautiful to be carried along so quickly, and to go on, and on, and on! I suppose we couldn't try it?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

As no encouragement was given to this proposition, Lady Glencora did not repeat it; but stood leaning on the rail of the balcony, and looking enviously down upon the water. Alice was, of course, thinking of that other evening, when perhaps the same swimmers had come down under the bridge and before the balcony, and where George Vavasor was sitting in her (Alice) presence. It was, I think, on that evening, that she (Alice) made up her (Alice) mind to separate herself from Mr. Grey.

On the day after that, Mr. Palliser and his (Palliser) party went on to Lucerne, making that journey, as I have said, by slow stages; taking Schaffhausen and Zurich in their way. At Lucerne, they established themselves for some time, occupying nearly a dozen rooms in the great hotel which overlooks the lake. Here there came to them a visitor, of whose arrival I will speak in the next chapter.

CHAPTER LXX.

At Lucerne.

I am inclined to think that Mr. Palliser did not much enjoy this part of his (Palliser) tour abroad. When he (Palliser) first reached Lucerne there was no one there with whom he (Palliser) could associate pleasantly, nor had he (Palliser) any occupation capable of making his (Palliser) time run easily. He (Palliser) did not care for scenery. Close at his (Palliser) elbow was the finest to be had in Europe; but it was nothing to him (Palliser). Had he (Palliser) been simply journeying through Lucerne at the proper time of the year for such a journey, when the business of the Session was over, and a little change of air needed, he (Palliser) could have enjoyed the thing in a moderate way, looking about him (Palliser), passing on, and knowing that it was good for him (Palliser) to be there at that moment. But he (Palliser) had none of that passion for mountains and lakes, none of that positive joy in the heather, which would have compensated many another man for the loss of all that Mr. Palliser was losing. His (Palliser) mind was ever at home in the House of Commons, or in that august assembly which men call the Cabinet, and of the meetings of which he (Palliser) read from week to week the simple records. Therein were mentioned the names of those heroes to whom Fortune had been so much kinder than she (Palliser) had been to him (Palliser); and he (Palliser) envied them. He (Palliser) took short, solitary walks, about the town, over the bridges, and along the rivers, making to himself the speeches which he (Palliser) would have made to full houses, had not his (Palliser) wife brought ruin upon all his (Palliser) hopes. And as he (Palliser) pictured to himself the glorious successes which probably never would have been his (Palliser) had he (Palliser) remained in London, so did he (Palliser) prophesy to himself an absolute and irremediable downfall from all political power as the result of his (Palliser) absence,--having, in truth, no sufficient cause for such despair. As yet, he (Palliser) was barely thirty, and had he (Palliser) been able to judge his (Palliser) own case as keenly as he (Palliser) could have judged the case of another, he (Palliser) would have known that a short absence might probably raise his (Palliser) value in the estimation of others rather than lower it. But his (Palliser) personal annoyance was too great to allow of his (Palliser) making such calculations aright. So he (Palliser) became fretful and unhappy; and though he (Palliser) spoke no word of rebuke to his (Palliser) wife, though he (Palliser) never hinted that she (wife) had robbed him (Palliser) of his (Palliser) glories, he (Palliser) made her (wife) conscious by his (Palliser) manner that she (wife) had brought him (Palliser) to this miserable condition.

Lady Glencora herself had a love for the mountains and lakes, but it was a love of that kind which requires to be stimulated by society, and which is keenest among cold chickens, picnic-pies, and the flying of champagne corks. When they first entered Switzerland she (Glencora) was very enthusiastic, and declared her (Glencora) intention of climbing up all the mountains, and going through all the passes. She (Glencora) endeavoured to induce her (Glencora) husband to promise that she (Glencora) should be taken up Mont Blanc. And I think she (Glencora) would have carried this on, and would have been taken up Mont Blanc, had Mr. Palliser's aspirations been congenial. But they were not congenial, and Lady Glencora soon lost all her (Glencora) enthusiasm. By the time that they were settled at Lucerne she (Glencora) had voted the mountains to be bores, and had almost learned to hate the lake, which she (Glencora) declared always made her (Glencora) wet through when she (Glencora) got into a small boat, and sea-sick when she (Glencora) put her (Glencora) foot in a large one. At Lucerne they made no acquaintances, Mr. Palliser being a man not apt to new friendships. They did not even dine at the public table, though Lady Glencora had expressed a wish to do so. Mr. Palliser did not like it, and of course Lady Glencora gave way. There were, moreover, some marital passages which were not pleasant to a third person. They did not scold each other; but Lady Glencora would make little speeches of which her (Glencora) husband disapproved. She (Glencora) would purposely irritate him (husband) by continuing her (Glencora) tone of badinage, and then Mr. Palliser would become fretful, and would look as though the cares of the world were too many for him (Palliser). I cannot, therefore, say that Alice had much to make the first period of her (Alice) sojourn at Lucerne a period of enjoyment.

But when they had been there about a fortnight, a stranger arrived, whose coming at any rate lent the grace of some excitement to their lives. Their custom was to breakfast at nine,--or as near nine as Lady Glencora could be induced to appear,--and then Mr. Palliser would read till three. At that hour he (Palliser) would walk forth by himself, after having handed the two ladies into their carriage, and they would be driven about for two hours.

``How I do hate this carriage,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora said one day.
``I do so wish it would come to grief, and be broken to pieces. I wonder whether the Swiss people think that we are going to be driven about here for ever.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
There were moments, however, which seemed to indicate that Lady Glencora had something to tell her (Glencora) cousin, which, if told, would alter the monotony of their lives. Alice, however, would not press her (Alice) for her (Alice) secret.

``If you have anything to tell, why don't you tell it?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice once said.

``You are so hard,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``So you tell me very often,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice replied;
``and it is not complimentary. But hard or soft, I won't make a petition for your confidence.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Then Lady Glencora said something savage, and the subject was dropped for a while.

But we must go back to the stranger. Mr. Palliser had put the ladies into their carriage, and was standing between the front door of the hotel and the lake on a certain day, doubting whether he (Palliser) would walk up the hill to the left or turn into the town on the right, when he (Palliser) was accosted by an English gentleman, who, raising his (Palliser) hat, said that he (Palliser) believed that he (Palliser) spoke to Mr. Palliser.

``I am Mr. Palliser,'' (friend)
said our friend, very courteously, returning the salute, and smiling as he (Palliser) spoke. But though he (Palliser) smiled, and though he (Palliser) was courteous, and though he (Palliser) raised his (Palliser) hat, there was something in his (Palliser) look and voice which would not have encouraged any ordinary stranger to persevere. Mr. Palliser was not a man with whom it was easy to open an acquaintance.

``My name is John Grey,'' (the stranger)
said the stranger.

Then the smile was dropped, the look of extreme courtesy disappeared, the tone of Mr. Palliser's voice was altered, and he (Palliser) put out his (Palliser) hand. He (Palliser) knew enough of Mr. John Grey's history to be aware that Mr. John Grey was a man with whom he (Grey) might permit himself to become acquainted. After the interchange of a very few words, the two men started off for a walk together.

``Perhaps you don't wish to meet the carriage?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.
``If so, we had better go through the town and up the river.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

They went through the town, and up the river, and when Mr. Palliser, on his (Palliser) return, was seen by Alice and Lady Glencora, he (Palliser) was alone. They dined together, and nothing was said. Together they sauntered out in the evening, and together came in and drank their tea; but still nothing was said. At last, Alice and her (Alice) cousin took their candles from Mr. Palliser's hands and left the sitting-room for the night.

``Alice,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, as soon as they were in the passage together,
``I have been dying for this time to come. I could not speak before, or I should have made blunders, and so would you. Let us go into your room at once. Who do you think is here, at Lucerne, in this house, at this very moment?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

Alice knew at once who it was. She (Alice) knew, immediately, that Mr. Grey had followed her (Alice), though no word had been written to her (Alice) or spoken to her (Alice) on the subject since that day on which he (Grey) himself had told her (Alice) that they would meet abroad. But though she (Alice) was quite sure, she (Alice) did not mention his (Grey) name.

``Who is it, Glencora?'' (she)
she (Alice) asked, very calmly.

``Whom in all the world would you best like to see?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora.

``My cousin Kate, certainly,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Then it is not your cousin Kate. And I don't believe you;--or else you're a fool.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice was accustomed to Lady Glencora's mode of talking, and therefore did not think much of this.

``Perhaps I am a fool,'' (she)
she (Alice) said.

``Only I know you are not. But I am not at all so sure as to your being no hypocrite. The person I mean is a gentleman, of course. Why don't you show a little excitement, at any rate? When Plantagenet told me, just before dinner, I almost jumped out of my shoes. He (gentleman) was going to tell you himself after dinner, in the politest way in the world, no doubt, and just as the servants were carrying away the apples. I thought it best to save you from that; but, I declare, I believe I might have left him (gentleman) to do it; it would have had no effect upon you. Who is it that has come, do you suppose?'' (unknown)

``Of course I know now,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, very calmly,
``that Mr. John Grey has come.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``Yes, Mr. John Grey has come. He (Grey) is here in this house at this minute;--or, more probably, waiting outside by the lake till he (Grey) shall see a light in your bedroom.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Then Lady Glencora paused for a moment, waiting that Alice might say something. But Alice said nothing.
``Well?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, rising up from her (Glencora) chair.
``Well?'' (unknown)

``Well?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Have you nothing to say? Is it the same to you as though Mr. Smith had come?'' (unknown)

``No; not exactly the same. I am quite alive to the importance of Mr. Grey's arrival, and shall probably lie awake all night thinking about it,--if it will do you any good to know that; but I don't feel that I have much to say about it.'' (unknown)

``I wish I had let Mr. Palliser tell you, in an ordinary way, before all the servants. I do indeed.'' (unknown)

``It would not have made much difference.'' (unknown)

``Not the least, I believe. I wonder whether you ever did care for anybody in your life,--for him (Palliser), or for that other one, or for anybody. For nobody, I believe;--except your cousin Kate. Still waters, they say, run deep; and sometimes I think your waters run too deep for me to fathom. I suppose I may go now, if you have got nothing more to say?'' (unknown)

``What do you want me to say? Of course I know why he (cousin) has come here. He (cousin) told me he (cousin) should come.'' (unknown)

``And you have never said a word about it.'' (unknown)

``He (cousin) told me he (cousin) should come, and I thought it better not to say a word about it. He (cousin) might change his (cousin) mind, or anything might happen. I told him (cousin) not to come; and it would have been much better that he (cousin) should have remained away.'' (unknown)

``Why;--why;--why would it be better?'' (unknown)

``Because his (cousin) being here will do no good to any one.'' (unknown)

``No good! It seems to me impossible but that it should do all the good in the world. Look here, Alice. If you do not altogether make it up with him (cousin) before to-morrow evening, I shall believe you to be utterly heartless. Had I been you I should have been in his (cousin) arms before this. I'll go now, and leave you to lie awake, as you say you will.'' (she)
Then she (Alice) left the room, but returned in a moment to ask another question.
``What is Plantagenet to say to him (cousin) about seeing you to-morrow? Of course he (cousin) has asked permission to come and call.'' (unknown)

``He (cousin) may come if he (cousin) pleases. You don't think I have quarrelled with him (cousin), or would refuse to see him (cousin)!'' (unknown)

``And may we ask him (cousin) to dine with us?'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes.'' (unknown)

``And make up a picnic, and all the rest of it. In fact, he (cousin) is to be regarded as only an ordinary person. Well;--good night. I don't understand you, that's all.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

It may be doubted whether Alice understood herself. As soon as her (Alice) friend was gone, she (Alice) put out her (Alice) candle and seated herself at the open window of her (Alice) room, looking out upon the moonlight as it played upon the lake. Would he (friend) be there, thinking of her (Alice), looking up, perhaps, as Glencora had hinted, to see if he (friend) could distinguish her (Glencora) light among the hundred that would be flickering across the long front of the house. If it were so, at any rate he (friend) should not see her (Glencora), so she (Glencora) drew the curtain, and sat there watching the lake. It was a pity that he (friend) should have come, and yet she (Glencora) loved him (friend) dearly for coming. It was a pity that he (friend) should have come, as his (friend) coming could lead to no good result. Of this she (Glencora) assured herself over and over again, and yet she (Glencora) hardly knew why she (Glencora) was so sure of it. Glencora had called her (Glencora) hard; but her (Glencora) conviction on that matter had not come from hardness. Now that she (Glencora) was alone, her (Glencora) heart was full of love, of the soft romance of love towards this man; and yet she (Glencora) felt that she (Glencora) ought not to marry him (man), even though he (man) might still be willing to take her (Glencora). That he (man) was still willing to take her (Glencora), that he (man) desired to have her (Glencora) for his (man) wife in spite of all the injury she (Glencora) had done him (man), there could be no doubt. Why else had he (man) followed her (Glencora) to Switzerland? And she (Glencora) remembered, now at this moment, how he (man) had told her (Glencora) at Cheltenham that he (man) would never consider her (Glencora) to be lost to him (man), unless she (Glencora) should, in truth, become the wife of another man. Why, then, should it not be as he (man) wished it?

-LSB-Illustration: Alice.-RSB-

She (Alice) asked herself the question, and did not answer it; but still she (Alice) felt that it might not be so. She (Alice) had no right to such happiness after the evil that she (Alice) had done. She (Alice) had been driven by a frenzy to do that which she (Alice) herself could not pardon; and having done it, she (Alice) could not bring herself to accept the position which should have been the reward of good conduct. She (Alice) could not analyse the causes which made her (Alice) feel that she (Alice) must still refuse the love that was proffered to her (Alice); she (Alice) could not clearly read her (Alice) own thoughts; but the causes were as I have said, and such was the true reading of her (Alice) thoughts. Had she (Alice) simply refused his (Alice) hand after she (Alice) had once accepted it,--had she (Alice) refused it, and then again changed her (Alice) mind, she (Alice) could have brought herself to ask him (Alice) to forgive her (Alice). But she (Alice) had done so much more than this, and so much worse! She (Alice) had affianced herself to another man since she (Alice) had belonged to him (man),--since she (Alice) had been his (man), as his (man) future wife. What must he (man) not think of her (Alice), and what not suspect? Then she (Alice) remembered those interviews which she (Alice) had had with her (Alice) cousin since she (Alice) had written to him (cousin), accepting his (cousin) offer. When he (cousin) had been with her (Alice) in Queen Anne Street she (Alice) had shrunk from all outward signs of a love which she (Alice) did not feel. There had been no caress between them. She (Alice) had not allowed him (cousin) to touch her (Alice) with his (cousin) lips. But it was impossible that the nature of that mad engagement between her (Alice) and her (Alice) cousin George should ever be made known to Mr. Grey. She (Alice) sat there wiping the tears from her (Alice) eyes as she (Alice) looked for his (George) figure among the figures by the lake-side; but, as she (Alice) sat there, she (Alice) promised herself no happiness from his (George) coming. Oh! reader, can you forgive her (Alice) in that she (Alice) had sinned against the softness of her (Alice) feminine nature? I think that she (Alice) may be forgiven, in that she (Alice) had never brought herself to think lightly of her (Alice) own fault.

If he (George) were there, by the lake-side, she (Alice) did not see him (George). I think we may say that John Grey was not a man to console himself in his (Grey) love by looking up at his (Grey) lady's candle. He (Grey) was one who was capable of doing as much as most men in the pursuit of his (Grey) love,--as he (Grey) proved to be the case when he (Grey) followed Alice to Cheltenham, and again to London, and now again to Lucerne; but I doubt whether a glimmer from her (Alice) bedroom-window, had it been unmistakably her (Alice) own glimmer, and not that of some ugly old French woman who might chance to sleep next to her (Alice), would have done him (Grey) much good. He (Grey) had come to Lucerne with a purpose, which purpose, if it might be possible, he (Grey) meant to carry out; but I think he (Grey) was already in bed, being tired with long travel, before Lady Glencora had left Alice's room.

At breakfast the next morning nothing was said for a while about the new arrival. At last Mr. Palliser ventured to speak.

``Glencora has told you, I think, that Mr. Grey is here? Mr. Grey is an old friend of yours, I believe?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice, keeping her (Alice) countenance as well as she (Alice) was able, said Mr. Grey had been, and, indeed, was, a very dear friend of hers. Mr. Palliser knew the whole story, and what was the use of any little attempt at dissimulation?

``I shall be glad to see him (Grey),--if you will allow me?'' (she)
she (Alice) went on to say.

``Glencora suggests that we should ask him (Grey) to dinner,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser; and then that matter was settled.

But Mr. Grey did not wait till dinner-time to see Alice. Early in the morning his (Grey) card was brought up, and Lady Glencora, as soon as she (Glencora) saw the name, immediately ran away.

``Indeed you need not go,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Indeed I shall go,'' (ladyship)
said her (Alice) ladyship.
``I know what's proper on these occasions, if you don't.'' (she)

So she (Alice) went, whisking herself along the passages with a little run; and Mr. Grey, as he (Grey) was shown into her (Alice) ladyship's usual sitting-room, saw the skirt of her (Alice) ladyship's dress as she (Alice) whisked herself off towards her (Alice) husband.

``I told you I should come,'' (he)
he (husband) said, with his (husband) ordinary sweet smile.
``I told you that I should follow you, and here I am.'' (He)

He (husband) took her (Alice) hand, and held it, pressing it warmly. She (Alice) hardly knew with what words first to address him (husband), or how to get her (Alice) hand back from him (husband).

``I am very glad to see you,--as an old friend,'' (she)
she (Alice) said;
``but I hope--'' (she)

``Well;--you hope what?'' (she)

``I hope you have had some better cause for travelling than a desire to see me?'' (unknown)

``No, dearest; no. I have had no better cause, and, indeed, none other. I have come on purpose to see you; and had Mr. Palliser taken you off to Asia or Africa, I think I should have felt myself compelled to follow him (Palliser). You know why I follow you?'' (unknown)

``Hardly,'' (she)
said she (Alice),--not finding at the moment any other word that she (Alice) could say.

``Because I love you. You see what a plain-spoken John Bull I am, and how I come to the point at once. I want you to be my wife; and they say that perseverance is the best way when a man has such a want as that.'' (unknown)

``You ought not to want it,'' (she)
she (Alice) said, whispering the words as though she (Alice) were unable to speak them out loud.

``But I do, you see. And why should I not want it?'' (unknown)

``I am not fit to be your wife.'' (unknown)

``I am the best judge of that, Alice. You have to make up your mind whether I am fit to be your husband.'' (unknown)

``You would be disgraced if you were to take me, after all that has passed;--after what I have done. What would other men say of you when they knew the story?'' (unknown)

``Other men, I hope, would be just enough to say, that when I had made up my mind, I was tolerably constant in keeping to it. I do not think they could say much worse of me than that.'' (unknown)

``They would say that you had been jilted, and had forgiven the jilt.'' (unknown)

``As far as the forgiveness goes, they would tell the truth. But, indeed, Alice, I don't very much care what men do say of me.'' (unknown)

``But I care, Mr. Grey;--and though you may forgive me, I cannot forgive myself. Indeed I know now, as I have known all along, that I am not fit to be your wife. I am not good enough. And I have done that which makes me feel that I have no right to marry anyone.'' (she)
These words she (Alice) said, jerking out the different sentences almost in convulsions; and when she (Alice) had come to the end of them, the tears were streaming down her (Alice) cheeks.
``I have thought about it, and I will not. I will not. After what has passed, I know that it will be better,--more seemly, that I should remain as I am.'' (she)

Soon after that she (Alice) left him (husband), not, however, till she (Alice) had told him (husband) that she (Alice) would meet him (husband) again at dinner, and had begged him (husband) to treat her (Alice) simply as a friend.

``In spite of everything, I hope that we may always be friends,--dear friends,'' (she)
she (Alice) said.

``I hope we may,'' (he)
he (husband) answered;--
``the very dearest.'' (he)
And then he (husband) left her (Alice).

In the afternoon he (husband) again encountered Mr. Palliser, and having thought over the matter since his (husband) interview with Alice, he (husband) resolved to tell his (husband) whole story to his (husband) new acquaintance,--not in order that he (husband) might ask for counsel from him (husband), for in this matter he (husband) wanted no man's advice,--but that he (husband) might get some assistance. So the two men walked off together, up the banks of the clear-flowing Reuss, and Mr. Palliser felt the comfort of having a companion.

``I have always liked her (I),'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser,
``though, to tell the truth, I have twice been very angry with her (I).'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

``I have never been angry with her (I),'' (the lover)
said the lover.

``And my anger was in both instances unjust. You may imagine how great is my confidence in her (I), when I have thought she (I) was the best companion my wife could have for a long journey, taken under circumstances that were--that were--; but I need not trouble you with that.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

So great had been the desolation of Mr. Palliser's life since his (Palliser) banishment from London that he (Palliser) almost felt tempted to tell the story of his (Palliser) troubles to this absolute stranger. But he (Palliser) bethought himself of the blood of the Pallisers, and refrained. There are comforts which royalty may never enjoy, and luxuries in which such men as Plantagenet Palliser may not permit themselves to indulge.

``About her (wife) and her (wife) character I have no doubt in the world,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey.
``In all that she (wife) has done I think that I have seen her (wife) motives; and though I have not approved of them, I have always known them to be pure and unselfish. She (wife) has done nothing that I did not forgive as soon as it was done. Had she (wife) married that man, I should have forgiven her (wife) even that,--though I should have known that all her (wife) future life was destroyed, and much of mine also. I think I can make her (wife) happy if she (wife) will marry me, but she (wife) must first be taught to forgive herself. Living as she (wife) is with you, and with your wife, she (wife) may, perhaps, just now be more under your influence and your wife's than she (wife) can possibly be under mine.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Whereupon, Mr. Palliser promised that he (Palliser) would do what he (Palliser) could.
``I think she (wife) loves me,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Mr. Grey.

Mr. Palliser said that he (Palliser) was sure she (Palliser) did, though what ground he (Palliser) had for such assurance I am quite unable to surmise. He (Palliser) was probably desirous of saying the most civil thing which occurred to him (Palliser).

The little dinner-party that evening was pleasant enough, and nothing more was said about love. Lady Glencora talked nonsense to Mr. Grey, and Mr. Palliser contradicted all the nonsense which his (Palliser) wife talked. But this was all done in such a way that the evening passed away pleasantly. It was tacitly admitted among them that Mr. Grey was to be allowed to come among them as a friend, and Lady Glencora managed to say one word to him (Grey) aside, in which she (Glencora) promised to give him (Grey) her (Glencora) most cordial cooperation.

CHAPTER LXXI.

Showing How George Vavasor Received a Visit.

We must go back for a few pages to scenes which happened in London during this summer, so that the reader may understand Mr. Grey's position when he (Grey) reached Lucerne. He (Grey) had undergone another quarrel with George Vavasor, and something of the circumstances of that quarrel must be told.

It has been already said that George Vavasor lost his (Vavasor) election for the Chelsea Districts, after all the money which he (Vavasor) had spent,--money which he (Vavasor) had been so ill able to spend, and on which he (Vavasor) had laid his (Vavasor) hands in a manner so disreputable! He (Vavasor) had received two thousand pounds from the bills which Alice had executed on his (Vavasor) behalf,--or rather, had received the full value of three out of the four bills, and a part of the value of the fourth, on which he (Vavasor) had been driven to raise what immediate money he (Vavasor) had wanted by means of a Jew bill-discounter. One thousand pounds he (Vavasor) had paid over at once into the hands of Mr. Scruby, his (Scruby) Parliamentary election agent, towards the expenses of his (Scruby) election; and when the day of polling arrived had exactly in his (Scruby) hands the sum of five hundred pounds. Where he (Scruby) was to get more when this was gone he (Scruby) did not know. If he (Scruby) were successful,--if the enlightened constituents of the Chelsea Districts, contented with his (Scruby) efforts on behalf of the River Bank, should again send him (Scruby) to Parliament, he (Scruby) thought that he (Scruby) might still carry on the war. A sum of ready money he (Scruby) would have in hand; and, as to his (Scruby) debts, he (Scruby) would be grandly indifferent to any consideration of them. Then there might be pickings in the way of a Member of Parliament of his (Member) calibre. Companies,--mercantile companies,--would be glad to have him (Member) as a director, paying him (Member) a guinea a day, or perhaps more, for his (Member) hour's attendance. Railways in want of vice-chairmen might bid for his (Member) services; and in the City he (Member) might turn that

``M.P.'' (he)
which belonged to him (Member) to good account in various ways. With such a knowledge of the City world as he (Member) possessed, he (Member) thought that he (Member) could pick up a living in London, if only he (Member) could retain his (Member) seat in Parliament.

But what was he (Member) to do if he (Member) could not retain it? No sooner had Mr. Scruby got the thousand pounds into his (Scruby) clutches than he (Scruby) pressed for still more money. George Vavasor, with some show of justice on his (Vavasor) side, pointed out to this all-devouring agent that the sum demanded had already been paid. This Mr. Scruby admitted, declaring that he (Scruby) was quite prepared to go on without any further immediate remittance, although by doing so might subject himself to considerable risk. But another five hundred pounds, paid at once, would add greatly to the safety of the seat; whereas eight hundred judiciously thrown in at the present moment would make the thing quite secure. But Vavasor swore to himself that he (Scruby) would not part with another shilling. Never had he (Scruby) felt such love for money as he (Scruby) did for that five hundred pounds which he (Scruby) now held in his (Scruby) pocket.

``It's no use,'' (he)
he (Scruby) said to Mr. Scruby.
``I have done what you asked, and would have done more had you asked for more at that time. As it is, I cannot make another payment before the election.'' (Mr. Scruby/Scruby)
Mr. Scruby shrugged his (Scruby) shoulders, and said that he (Scruby) would do his (Scruby) best. But George Vavasor soon knew that the man was not doing his (Vavasor) best,--that the man had, in truth, abandoned his (Vavasor) cause. The landlord of the
``Handsome Man'' (him)
jeered him (Vavasor) when he (Vavasor) went there canvassing.
``Laws, Mr. Vavasor!'' (unknown)
said the landlord of the
``Handsome Man,'' (unknown)
``you're not at all the fellow for us chaps along the river,--you ain't. You're afraid to come down with the stumpy,--that's what you are.'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
George put his (George) hand upon his (George) purse, and acknowledged to himself that he (George) had been afraid to come down with the stumpy.

For the last five days of the affair George Vavasor knew that his (Vavasor) chance was gone. Mr. Scruby's face, manner, and words, told the result of the election as plainly as any subsequent figures could do. He (Scruby) would be absent when Vavasor called, or the clerk would say that he (Scruby) was absent. He (Scruby) would answer in very few words, constantly shrugging his (Scruby) shoulders. He (Scruby) would even go away and leave the anxious candidate while he (Scruby) was in the middle of some discussion as to his (Scruby) plans. It was easy to see that Mr. Scruby no longer regarded him (Scruby) as a successful man, and the day of the poll showed very plainly how right Mr. Scruby had been.

George Vavasor was rejected, but he (Vavasor) still had his (Vavasor) five hundred pounds in his (Vavasor) pocket. Of course he (Vavasor) was subject to that mortification which a man feels when he (man) reflects that some little additional outlay would have secured his (man) object. Whether it might have been so, or not, who can say? But there he (man) was, with the gateway between the lamps barred against him (man), ex-Member of Parliament for the Chelsea Districts, with five hundred pounds in his (man) pocket, and little or nothing else that he (man) could call his (man) own. What was he (man) to do with himself?

After trying to make himself heard upon the hustings when he (man) was rejected, and pledging himself to stand again at the next election, he (man) went home to his (man) lodgings in Cecil Street, and endeavoured to consider calmly his (man) position in the world. He (man) had lost his (man) inheritance. He (man) had abandoned one profession after another, and was now beyond the pale of another chance in that direction. His (man) ambition had betrayed him (man), and there were no longer possible to him (man) any hopes of political activity. He (man) had estranged from himself every friend that he (man) had ever possessed. He (man) had driven from him (man) with violence the devotion even of his (man) sister. He (man) had robbed the girl whom he (man) intended to marry of her (girl) money, and had so insulted her (girl) that no feeling of amity between them was any longer possible. He (man) had nothing now but himself and that five hundred pounds, which he (man) still held in his (man) pocket. What should he (man) do with himself and his (man) money? He (man) thought over it all with outer calmness for awhile, as he (man) sat there in his (man) arm-chair.

From the moment in which he (man) had first become convinced that the election would go against him (man), and that he (man) was therefore ruined on all sides, he (man) had resolved that he (man) would be calm amidst his (man) ruin. Sometimes he (man) assumed a little smile, as though he (man) were laughing at his (man) own position. Mr. Bott's day of rejection had come before his (man) own, and he (man) had written to Mr. Bott a drolling note of consolation and mock sympathy.
