He (Bott) had shaken hands with Mr. Scruby, and had poked his (Scruby) fun at the agent, bidding him (Scruby) be sure to send in his (Scruby) little bill soon. To all who accosted him (Scruby), he (Scruby) replied in a subrisive tone; and he (Scruby) bantered Calder Jones, whose seat was quite sure, till Calder Jones began to have fears that were quite unnecessary. And now, as he (Jones) sat himself down, intending to come to some final decision as to what he (Jones) would do, he (Jones) maintained the same calmness. He (Jones) smiled in the same way, though there was no one there to see the smile. He (Jones) laughed even audibly once or twice, as he (Jones) vainly endeavoured to persuade himself that he (Jones) was able to regard the world and all that belonged to it as a bubble.

There came to him (Jones) a moment in which he (Jones) laughed out very audibly.

``Ha! ha!'' (he)
he (Jones) shouted, rising up from his (Jones) chair, and he (Jones) walked about the room, holding a large paper-knife in his (Jones) hand.
``Ha! ha!'' (he)
Then he (Jones) threw the knife away from him (Jones), and thrusting his (Jones) hands into his (Jones) trousers-pockets, laughed again--
``Ha! ha!'' (him)
He (Jones) stood still in the centre of the room, and the laughter was very plainly visible on his (Jones) face, had there been anybody there to see it.

But suddenly there was a change upon his (Jones) face, as he (Jones) stood there all alone, and his (Jones) eyes became fierce, and the cicatrice that marred his (Jones) countenance grew to be red and ghastly, and he (Jones) grinned with his (Jones) teeth, and he (Jones) clenched his (Jones) fists as he (Jones) still held them within his (Jones) pockets.

``Curse him (fellow)!'' (he)
he (Jones) said out loud.
``Curse him (fellow), now and for ever!'' (He)
He (Jones) had broken down in his (Jones) calmness, when he (Jones) thought of that old man who had opposed him (Jones) during his (Jones) life, and had ruined him (Jones) at his (Jones) death.
``May all the evils which the dead can feel cling to him (fellow) for ever and ever!'' (him)
His (Jones) laughter was all gone, and his (Jones) assumed tranquillity had deserted him (Jones). Walking across the room, he (Jones) struck his (Jones) foot against a chair; upon this, he (Jones) took the chair in his (Jones) hands, and threw it across the room. But he (Jones) hardly arrested the torrent of his (Jones) maledictions as he (Jones) did so. What good was it that he (Jones) should lie to himself by that mock tranquillity, or that false laughter? He (Jones) lied to himself no longer, but uttered a song of despair that was true enough. What should he (Jones) do? Where should he (Jones) go? From what fountain should he (Jones) attempt to draw such small draughts of the water of comfort as might support him (Jones) at the present moment? Unless a man have some such fountain to which he (man) can turn, the burden of life cannot be borne. For the moment, Vavasor tried to find such fountain in a bottle of brandy which stood near him (man). He (man) half filled a tumbler, and then, dashing some water on it, swallowed it greedily.
``By --!'' (he)
he (man) said,
``I believe it is the best thing a man can do.'' (he)

But where was he (man) to go? to whom was he (man) to turn himself? He (man) went to a high desk which stood in one corner of the room, and unlocking it, took out a revolving pistol, and for a while carried it about with him (man) in his (man) hand. He (man) turned it up, and looked at it, and tried the lock, and snapped it without caps, to see that the barrel went round fairly.

``It's a beggarly thing to do,'' (he)
he (man) said, and then he (man) turned the pistol down again;
``and if I do do it, I'll use it first for another purpose.'' (he)
Then he (man) poured out for himself more brandy-and-water, and having drunk it, he (man) threw himself upon the sofa, and seemed to sleep.

But he (man) did not sleep, and by-and-by there came a slight single knock at the door, which he (man) instantly answered. But he (man) did not answer it in the usual way by bidding the comer to come in.

``Who's there?'' (he)
he (man) said. Then the comer attempted to enter, turning the handle of the door. But the door had been locked, and the key was on Vavasor's side.
``Who's there?'' (he)
he (man) asked again, speaking out loudly, but in an angry voice.
``It is I,'' (a woman)
said a woman's voice.
``D--ation!'' (George/Mr. Vavasor/George Vavasor)
said George Vavasor.

The woman heard him (Vavasor), but she (woman) made no sign of having heard him (Vavasor). She (woman) simply remained standing where she (woman) was till something further should be done within. She (woman) knew the man well, and knew that she (woman) must bide his (man) time. She (woman) was very patient,--and for the time was meek, though it might be that there would come an end to her (woman) meekness. Vavasor, when he (man) had heard her (Vavasor) voice, and knew who was there, had again thrown himself on the sofa. There flashed across his (man) mind another thought or two as to his (man) future career,--another idea about the pistol, which still lay upon the table. Why should he (man) let the intruder in, and undergo the nuisance of a disagreeable interview, if the end of all things might come in time to save him (man) from such trouble? There he (man) lay for ten minutes thinking, and then the low single knock was heard again. He (man) jumped upon his (man) feet, and his (man) eyes were full of fire. He (man) knew that it was useless to bid her (man) go and leave him (man). She (man) would sit there, if it were through the whole night. Should he (man) open the door and strangle her (man), and pass out over her (man) with the pistol in his (man) hand, so that he (man) might make that other reckoning which he (man) desired to accomplish, and then never come back any more?

He (man) took a turn through the room, and then walked gently up to the door, and undid the lock. He (man) did not open the door, nor did he (man) bid his (man) visitor enter, but having made the way easy for her (man) if she (man) chose to come in, he (man) walked back to the sofa and threw himself on it again. As he (man) did so, he (man) passed his (man) hand across the table so as to bring the pistol near to himself at the place where he (man) would be lying. She (man) paused a moment after she (man) had heard the sound of the key, and then she (man) made her (man) way into the room. He (man) did not at first speak to her (man). She (man) closed the door very gently, and then, looking around, came up to the foot of the sofa. She (man) paused a moment, waiting for him (man) to address her (man); but as he (man) said nothing, but lay there looking at her (man), she (man) was the first to speak.

``George,'' (she)
she (man) said,
``what am I to do?'' (she)

She (man) was a woman of about thirty years of age, dressed poorly, in old garments, but still with decency, and with some attempt at feminine prettiness. There were flowers in the bonnet on her (man) head, though the bonnet had that unmistakable look of age which is quite as distressing to bonnets as it is to women, and the flowers themselves were battered and faded. She (man) had long black ringlets on each cheek, hanging down much below her (man) face, and brought forward so as to hide in some degree the hollowness of her (man) jaws. Her (man) eyes had a peculiar brightness, but now they left on those who looked at her (man) cursorily no special impression as to their colour. They had been blue,--that dark violet blue, which is so rare, but is sometimes so lovely. Her (man) forehead was narrow, her (man) mouth was small, and her (man) lips were thin; but her (man) nose was perfect in its shape, and, by the delicacy of its modelling, had given a peculiar grace to her (man) face in the days when things had gone well with her (man), when her (man) cheeks had been full with youth and good living, and had been dimpled by the softness of love and mirth. There were no dimples there now, and all the softness which still remained was that softness which sorrow and continual melancholy give to suffering women. On her (man) shoulders she (man) wore a light shawl, which was fastened to her (man) bosom with a large clasp brooch. Her (man) faded dress was supported by a wide crinoline, but the under garment had lost all the grace of its ancient shape, and now told that woman's tale of poverty and taste for dress which is to be read in the outward garb of so many of Eve's daughters. The whole story was told so that those who ran might read it. When she (woman) had left her (woman) home this afternoon, she (woman) had struggled hard to dress herself so that something of the charm of apparel might be left to her (woman); but she (woman) had known of her (woman) own failure at every twist that she (woman) had given to her (woman) gown, and at every jerk with which she (woman) had settled her (woman) shawl. She (woman) had despaired at every push she (woman) had given to her (woman) old flowers, vainly striving to bring them back to their old forms; but still she (woman) had persevered. With long tedious care she (woman) had mended the old gloves which would hardly hold her (woman) fingers. She (woman) had carefully hidden the rags of her (woman) sleeves. She (woman) had washed her (woman) little shrivelled collar, and had smoothed it out painfully. It had been a separate grief to her (woman) that she (woman) could find no cuffs to put round her (woman) wrists;--and yet she (woman) knew that no cuffs could have availed her (woman) anything. Nothing could avail her (woman) now. She (woman) expected nothing from her (woman) visit; yet she (woman) had come forth anxiously, and would have waited there throughout the whole night had access to his (woman) room been debarred to her (woman).

``George,'' (she)
she (woman) said, standing at the bottom of the sofa,
``what am I to do?'' (she)

As he (woman) lay there with his (woman) face turned towards her (woman), the windows were at her (woman) back, and he (woman) could see her (woman) very plainly. He (woman) saw and appreciated the little struggles she (woman) had made to create by her (woman) appearance some reminiscence of her (woman) former self. He (woman) saw the shining coarseness of the long ringlets which had once been softer than silk. He (woman) saw the sixpenny brooch on her (woman) bosom where he (woman) had once placed a jewel, the price of which would now have been important to him (woman). He (woman) saw it all, and lay there for a while, silently reading it.

``Don't let me stand here,'' (she)
she (woman) said,
``without speaking a word to me.'' (she)

``I don't want you to stand there,'' (he)
he (woman) said.

``That's all very well, George. I know you don't want me to stand here. I know you don't want to see me ever again.'' (unknown)

``Never.'' (unknown)

``I know it. Of course I know it. But what am I to do? Where am I to go for money? Even you would not wish that I should starve?'' (unknown)

``That's true, too. I certainly would not wish it. I should be delighted to hear that you had plenty to eat and plenty to drink, and plenty of clothes to wear. I believe that's what you care for the most, after all.'' (unknown)

``It was only for your sake,--because you liked it.'' (unknown)

``Well;--I did like it; but that has come to an end, as have all my other likings. You know very well that I can do nothing more for you. What good do you do yourself by coming here to annoy me? Have I not told you over and over again that you were never to look for me here? Is it likely that I should give you money now, simply because you have disobeyed me!'' (unknown)

``Where else was I to find you?'' (unknown)

``Why should you have found me at all? I don't want you to find me. I shall give you nothing;--not a penny. You know very well that we've had all that out before. When I put you into business I told you that we were to see no more of each other.'' (unknown)

``Business!'' (she)
she (woman) said.
``I never could make enough out of the shop to feed a bird.'' (unknown)

``That wasn't my fault. Putting you there cost me over a hundred pounds, and you consented to take the place.'' (unknown)

``I didn't consent. I was obliged to go there because you took my other home away from me.'' (unknown)

``Have it as you like, my dear. That was all I could do for you;--and more than most men would have done, when all things are considered.'' (he)
Then he (woman) got up from the sofa, and stood himself on the hearthrug, with his (woman) back to the fireplace.
``At any rate, you may be sure of this, Jane;--that I shall do nothing more. You have come here to torment me, but you shall get nothing by it.'' (unknown)

``I have come here because I am starving.'' (unknown)

``I have nothing for you. Now go;'' (he)
and he (woman) pointed to the door. Nevertheless, for more than three years of his (woman) life this woman had been his (woman) closest companion, his (woman) nearest friend, the being with whom he (woman) was most familiar. He (woman) had loved her (woman) according to his (woman) fashion of loving, and certainly she (woman) had loved him (woman).
``Go,'' (he)
he (woman) said repeating the word very angrily.
``Do as I bid you, or it will be the worse for you.'' (unknown)

``Will you give me a sovereign?'' (unknown)

``No;--I will give you nothing. I have desired you not to come to me here, and I will not pay for you coming.'' (unknown)

``Then I will not go;'' (the woman)
and the woman sat down upon a chair at the foot of the table.
``I will not go till you have given me something to buy food. You may put me out of the room if you can, but I will lie at the door of the stairs. And if you get me out of the house, I will sit upon the door-step.'' (unknown)

``If you play that game, my poor girl, the police will take you.'' (unknown)

``Let them. It has come to that with me, that I care for nothing. Out of this I will not go till you give me money--unless I am put out.'' (she)

And for this she (woman) had dressed herself with so much care, mending her (woman) gloves, and darning her (woman) little fragments of finery! He (woman) stood looking at her (woman), with his (woman) hands thrust deep into his (woman) pockets,--looking at her (woman) and thinking what he (woman) had better do to rid himself of her (woman) presence. If he (woman) even quite resolved to take that little final journey of which we have spoken, with the pistol in his (woman) hand, why should he (woman) not go and leave her (woman) there? Or, for the matter of that, why should he (woman) not make her (woman) his (woman) heir to all remainder of his (woman) wealth? What he (woman) still had left was sufficient to place her (woman) in a seventh heaven of the earth. He (woman) cared but little for her (woman), and was at this moment angry with her (woman); but there was no one for whom he (woman) cared more, and no friend with whom he (woman) was less angry. But then his (woman) mind was not quite made up as to that final journey. Therefore he (woman) desired to rid himself and his (woman) room of the nuisance of her (woman) presence.

``Jane,'' (he)
he (woman) said, looking at her (woman) again with that assumed tranquillity of which I have spoken,
``you talk of starving and of being ruined,--'' (I)

``I am starving. I have not a shilling in the world.'' (I)

``Perhaps it may be a comfort to you in your troubles to know that I am, at any rate, as badly off as you are? I won't say that I am starving, because I could get food to eat at this moment if I wanted it; but I am utterly ruined. My property,--what should have been mine,--has been left away from me. I have lost the trumpery seat in Parliament for which I have paid so much. All my relations have turned their backs upon me--'' (she)

``Are you not going to be married?'' (she)
she (woman) said, rising quickly from her (woman) chair and coming close to him (woman).

``Married! No;--but I am going to blow my brains out. Look at that pistol, my girl. Of course you won't think that I am in earnest,--but I am.'' (She)

She (woman) looked up into his (woman) face piteously.

``Oh! George,'' (she)
she (woman) said,
``you won't do that?'' (she)

-LSB-Illustration:

``Oh! George,'' (she)
she (woman) said,
``you won't do that?'' (she)
-RSB-

``But I shall do that. There is nothing else left for me to do. You talk to me about starving. I tell you that I should have no objection to be starved, and so be put an end to in that way. It's not so bad as some other ways when it comes gradually. You and I, Jane, have not played our cards very well. We have staked all that we had, and we've been beaten. It's no good whimpering after what's lost. We'd better go somewhere else and begin a new game.'' (unknown)

``Go where?'' (she)
said she (woman).

``Ah!--that's just what I can't tell you.'' (unknown)

``George,'' (she)
she (woman) said,
``I'll go anywhere with you. If what you say is true,--if you're not going to be married, and will let me come to you, I will work for you like a slave. I will indeed. I know I'm poorly looking now--'' (she)

``My girl, where I'm going, I shall not want any slave; and as for your looks--when you go there too,--they'll be of no matter, as far as I am able to judge.'' (unknown)

``But, George, where are you going?'' (unknown)

``Wherever people do go when their brains are knocked out of them; or, rather, when they have knocked out their own brains,--if that makes any difference.'' (unknown)

``George,'' (she)
--she (woman) came up to him (woman) now, and took hold of him (woman) by the front of his (woman) coat, and for the moment he (woman) allowed her (woman) to do so,--
``George, you frighten me. Do not do that. Say that you will not do that!'' (her)

``But I am just saying that I shall.'' (unknown)

``Are you not afraid of God's anger? You and I have been very wicked.'' (unknown)

``I have, my poor girl. I don't know much about your wickedness. I've been like Topsy;--indeed I am a kind of second Topsy myself. But what's the good of whimpering when it's over?'' (unknown)

``It isn't over; it isn't over,--at any rate for you.'' (unknown)

``I wish I knew how I could begin again. But all this is nonsense, Jane, and you must go.'' (unknown)

``You must tell me, first, that you are not going to--kill yourself.'' (unknown)

``I don't suppose I shall do it to-night,--or, perhaps, not to-morrow. Very probably I may allow myself a week, so that your staying here can do no good. I merely wanted to make you understand that you are not the only person who has come to grief.'' (unknown)

``And you are not going to be married?'' (unknown)

``No; I'm not going to be married, certainly.'' (unknown)

``And I must go now?'' (unknown)

``Yes; I think you'd better go now.'' (she)
Then she (woman) rose and went, and he (woman) let her (woman) leave the room without giving her (woman) a shilling! His (woman) bantering tone, in speaking of his (woman) own position, had been successful. It had caused her (woman) to take herself off quietly. She (woman) knew enough of his (woman) usual manner to be aware that his (woman) threats of self destruction were probably unreal; but, nevertheless, what he (woman) had said had created some feeling in her (woman) heart which had induced her (woman) to yield to him (woman), and go away in peace.

CHAPTER LXXII.

Showing How George Vavasor Paid a Visit.

It was nearly seven o'clock in the evening,--a hot, July evening,--when the woman went from Vavasor's room, and left him (Vavasor) there alone. It was necessary that he (Vavasor) should immediately do something. In the first place he (Vavasor) must dine, unless he (Vavasor) meant to carry out his (Vavasor) threat, and shoot himself at once. But he (Vavasor) had no such intention as that, although he (Vavasor) stood for some minutes with the pistol in his (Vavasor) hand. He (Vavasor) was thinking then of shooting some one else. But he (Vavasor) resolved that, if he (Vavasor) did so at all, he (Vavasor) would not do it on that evening, and he (Vavasor) locked up the pistol again in the standing desk. After that, he (Vavasor) took up some papers, referring to steam packets, which were lying on his (Vavasor) table. They contained the programmes of different companies, and showed how one vessel went on one day to New York, and another on another day would take out a load of emigrants for New Zealand and Australia.

``That's a good line,'' (he)
said he (Vavasor), as he (Vavasor) read a certain prospectus.
``They generally go to the bottom, and save a man from any further trouble on his (man) own account.'' (he)
Then he (Vavasor) dressed himself, putting on his (Vavasor) boots and coat, and went out to his (Vavasor) club for his (Vavasor) dinner.

London was still fairly full,--that is to say, the West End was not deserted, although Parliament had been broken up two months earlier than usual, in preparation for the new elections. Many men who had gone down into the country were now back again in town, and the dining-room at the club was crowded. Men came up to him (Vavasor) condoling with him (Vavasor), telling him (Vavasor) that he (Vavasor) was well rid of a great nuisance, that the present Members for the Chelsea Districts would not sit long, or that there would be another general election in a year or two. To all these little speeches he (Vavasor) made cheerful replies, and was declared by his (Vavasor) acquaintance to bear his (Vavasor) disappointment well. Calder Jones came to him (Jones) and talked hunting talk, and Vavasor expressed his (Jones) intention of being at Roebury in November.

``You had better join our club,'' (Calder Jones/Jones)
said Calder Jones. In answer to which Vavasor said that he (Jones) thought he (Jones) would join the club. He (Jones) remained in the smoking-room till nearly eleven; then he (Jones) took himself home, and remained up half the night destroying papers. Every written document on which he (Jones) could lay his (Jones) hands he (Jones) destroyed. All the pigeon-holes of his (Jones) desk were emptied out, and their contents thrown into the flames. At first he (Jones) looked at the papers before he (Jones) burned them; but the trouble of doing so soon tired him (Jones), and he (Jones) condemned them all, as he (Jones) came to them, without examination. Then he (Jones) selected a considerable amount of his (Jones) clothes, and packed up two portmanteaus, folding his (Jones) coats with care, and inspecting his (Jones) boots narrowly, so that he (Jones) might see which, out of the large number before him (Jones), it might be best worth his (Jones) while to take with him (Jones). When that was done, he (Jones) took from his (Jones) desk a bag of sovereigns, and, pouring them out upon the table, he (Jones) counted them out into parcels of twenty-five each, and made them up carefully into rouleaus with paper. These, when complete, he (Jones) divided among the two portmanteaus and a dressing-bag which he (Jones) also packed and a travelling desk, which he (Jones) filled with papers, pens, and the like. But he (Jones) put into it no written document. He (Jones) carefully looked through his (Jones) linen, and anything that had been marked with more than his (Jones) initials he (Jones) rejected. Then he (Jones) took out a bundle of printed cards, and furnished a card-case with them. On these cards was inscribed the name of Gregory Vance. When all was finished, he (Vance) stood for awhile with his (Vance) back to the fireplace contemplating his (Vance) work.
``After all,'' (he)
he (Vance) said to himself,
``I know that I shall never start; and, if I do, nobody can hinder me, and my own name would be as good as any other. As for a man with such a face as mine not being known, that is out of the question.'' (he)
But still he (Vance) liked the arrangements which he (Vance) had made, and when he (Vance) had looked at them for awhile he (Vance) went to bed.

He (Vance) was up early the next morning, and had some coffee brought to him (Vance) by the servant of the house, and as he (Vance) drank it he (Vance) had an interview with his (Vance) landlady.

``He (man) was going,'' (he)
he (Vance) said;--
``going that very day.'' (he)
It might be possible that he (Vance) would change his (Vance) mind; but as he (Vance) would desire to start without delay, if he (Vance) did go, he (Vance) would pay her (landlady) then what he (Vance) owed her (landlady), and what would be due for her (landlady) lodgings under a week's notice. The woman stared, and curtseyed, and took her (woman) money. Vavasor, though he (Vance) had lately been much pressed for money, had never been so foolish as to owe debts where he (Vance) lived.
``There will be some things left about, Mrs. Bunsby,'' (he)
he (Vance) said,
``and I will get you to keep them till I call or send.'' (he)
Mrs. Bunsby said that she (Bunsby) would, and then looked her (Bunsby) last at him (Vance). After that interview she (Bunsby) never saw him (Vance) again.

When he (Vance) was left alone he (Vance) put on a rough morning coat, and taking up the pistol, placed it carefully in his (Vance) pocket, and sallied forth. It was manifest enough that he (Vance) had some decided scheme in his (Vance) head, for he (Vance) turned quickly towards the West when he (Vance) reached the Strand, went across Trafalgar Square to Pall Mall East, and then turned up Suffolk Street. Just as he (Vance) reached the club-house at the corner he (Vance) paused and looked back, facing first one way and then the other.

``The chances are that I shall never see anything of it again,'' (he)
he (Vance) said to himself. Then he (Vance) laughed in his (Vance) own silent way, shook his (Vance) head slightly, and turning again quickly on his (Vance) heel, walked up the street till he (Vance) reached the house of Mr. Jones, the pugilistic tailor. The reader, no doubt, has forgotten all he (reader) ever knew of Mr. Jones, the pugilistic tailor. It can soon be told again. At Mr. Jones's house John Grey lodged when he (Grey) was in London, and he (Grey) was in London at this moment.

Vavasor rang the bell, and as soon as the servant came he (servant) went quickly into the house, and passed her (reader) in the passage.

``Mr. Grey is at home,'' (he)
he (servant) said.
``I will go up to him (Grey).'' (The girl)
The girl said that Mr. Grey was at home, but suggested that she (girl) had better announce the gentleman. But Vavasor was already halfway up the stairs, and before the girl had reached the first landing place, he (Grey) had entered Mr. Grey's room and closed the door behind him (Grey).

Grey was sitting near the open window, in a dressing-gown, and was reading. The breakfast things were on the table, but he (Grey) had not as yet breakfasted. As soon as he (Grey) saw George Vavasor, he (Vavasor) rose from his (Vavasor) chair quickly, and put down his (Vavasor) book.

``Mr. Vavasor,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) said,
``I hardly expected to see you in my lodgings again!'' (he)

``I dare say not,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor;
``but, nevertheless, here I am.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
He (Vavasor) kept his (Vavasor) right hand in the pocket which held the pistol, and held his (Vavasor) left hand under his (Vavasor) waistcoat.

``May I ask why you have come?'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey.

``I intend to tell you, at any rate, whether you ask me or not. I have come to declare in your own hearing,--as I am in the habit of doing occasionally behind your back,--that you are a blackguard,--to spit in your face, and defy you.'' (he)
As he (Grey) said this he (Grey) suited his (Grey) action to his (Grey) words, but without any serious result.
``I have come here to see if you are man enough to resent any insult that I can offer you; but I doubt whether you are.'' (unknown)

``Nothing that you can say to me, Mr. Vavasor, will have any effect upon me;--except that you can, of course, annoy me.'' (unknown)

``And I mean to annoy you, too, before I have done with you. Will you fight me?'' (unknown)

``Fight a duel with you,--with pistols? Certainly not.'' (unknown)

``Then you are a coward, as I supposed.'' (unknown)

``I should be a fool if I were to do such a thing as that.'' (unknown)

``Look here, Mr. Grey. You managed to worm yourself into an intimacy with my cousin, Miss Vavasor, and to become engaged to her (Vavasor). When she (Vavasor) found out what you were, how paltry, and mean, and vile, she (Vavasor) changed her (Vavasor) mind, and bade you leave her (Vavasor).'' (unknown)

``Are you here at her (Vavasor) request?'' (unknown)

``I am here as her (Vavasor) representative.'' (unknown)

``Self-appointed, I think.'' (unknown)

``Then, sir, you think wrong. I am at this moment her (Vavasor) affianced husband; and I find that, in spite of all that she (Vavasor) has said to you,--which was enough, I should have thought, to keep any man of spirit out of her (Vavasor) presence,--you still persecute her (Vavasor) by going to her (Vavasor) house, and forcing yourself upon her (Vavasor) presence. Now, I give you two alternatives. You shall either give me your written promise never to go near her (Vavasor) again, or you shall fight me.'' (unknown)

``I shall do neither one nor the other,--as you know very well yourself.'' (unknown)

``Stop till I have done, sir. If you have courage enough to fight me, I will meet you in any country. I will fight you here in London, or, if you are afraid of that, I will go over to France, or to America, if that will suit you better.'' (unknown)

``Nothing of the kind will suit me at all. I don't want to have anything to do with you.'' (unknown)

``Then you are a coward.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps I am;--but your saying so will not make me one.'' (unknown)

``You are a coward, and a liar, and a blackguard. I have given you the option of behaving like a gentleman, and you have refused it. Now, look here. I have come here with arms, and I do not intend to leave this room without using them, unless you will promise to give me the meeting that I have proposed.'' (he)
And he (Grey) took the pistol out of his (Grey) pocket.

``Do you mean that you are going to murder me?'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
Grey asked. There were two windows in the room, and he (Grey) had been sitting near to that which was furthest removed from the fireplace, and consequently furthest removed from the bell, and his (Grey) visitor was now standing immediately between him (Grey) and the door. He (Grey) had to think what steps he (Grey) might best take, and to act upon his (Grey) decision instantly. He (Grey) was by no means a timid man, and was one, moreover, very little prone to believe in extravagant action. He (Grey) did not think, even now, that this disappointed, ruined man had come there with any intention of killing him (man). But he (man) knew that a pistol in the hands of an angry man is dangerous, and that it behoved him (man) to do his (man) best to rid himself of the nuisance which now encumbered him (man).
``Do you mean that you are going to murder me?'' (he)
he (man) had said.

``I mean that you shall not leave this room alive unless you promise to meet me, and fight it out.'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
Upon hearing this, Grey turned himself towards the bell.
``If you move a step, I will fire at you,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor. Grey paused a moment, and looked him (Grey) full in the face.
``I will,'' (unknown)
said Vavasor again.

``That would be murder,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey.

``Don't think that you will frighten me by ugly words,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Vavasor.
``I am beyond that.'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)

Grey had stopped for a moment to fix his (Grey) eyes on the other man's face; but it was only for a moment, and then he (Grey) went on to the bell. He (Grey) had seen that the pistol was pointed at himself, and had once thought of rushing across the room at his (Grey) adversary, calculating that a shot fired at him (Grey) as he (Grey) did so might miss him (Grey), and that he (Grey) would then have a fair chance of disarming the madman. But his (Grey) chief object was to avoid any personal conflict, to escape the indignity of a scramble for the pistol,--and especially to escape the necessity of a consequent appearance at some police-office, where he (Grey) would have to justify himself, and answer the questions of a lawyer hired to cross-question him (lawyer). He (lawyer) made, therefore, towards the bell, trusting that Vavasor would not fire at him (lawyer), but having some little thought also as to the danger of the moment. It might be that everything was over for him (lawyer) now,--that the fatal hour had come, and that eternity was close upon him (lawyer). Something of the spirit of a prayer flashed across his (lawyer) mind as he (lawyer) moved. Then he (lawyer) heard the click of the pistol's hammer as it fell, and was aware that his (lawyer) eyes were dazzled, though he (lawyer) was unconscious of seeing any flame. He (lawyer) felt something in the air, and knew that the pistol had been fired;--but he (lawyer) did not know whether the shot had struck him (lawyer) or had missed him (lawyer). His (lawyer) hand was out for the bell-handle, and he (lawyer) had pulled it, before he (lawyer) was sure that he (lawyer) was unhurt.

``D--ation!'' (the murderer)
exclaimed the murderer. But he (lawyer) did not pull the trigger again. Though the weapon had of late been so often in his (lawyer) hands, he (lawyer) forgot, in the agitation of the moment, that his (lawyer) missing once was but of small matter if he (lawyer) chose to go on with his (lawyer) purpose. Were there not five other barrels for him (lawyer), each making itself ready by the discharge of the other? But he (lawyer) had paused, forgetting, in his (lawyer) excitement, the use of his (lawyer) weapon, and before he (lawyer) had bethought himself that the man was still in his (man) power, he (man) heard the sound of the bell.
``D--ation!'' (he)
he (man) exclaimed. Then he (man) turned round, left the room, hurried down the stairs, and made his (man) way out into the street, having again passed the girl on his (man) way.

Grey, when he (Grey) perceived that his (Grey) enemy was gone, turned round to look for the bullet or its mark. He (Grey) soon found the little hole in the window-shutter, and probing it with the point of his (Grey) pencil, came upon the morsel of lead which might now just as readily have been within his (Grey) own brain. There he (Grey) left it for the time, and then made some not inaccurate calculation as to the narrowness of his (Grey) own escape. He (Grey) had been standing directly between Vavasor and the shutter, and he (Grey) found, from the height of the hole, that the shot must have passed close beneath his (Grey) ear. He (Grey) remembered to have heard the click of the hammer, but he (Grey) could not remember the sound of the report, and when the girl entered the room, he (Grey) perceived at once from her (girl) manner that she (girl) was unaware that firearms had been used.

``Has that gentleman left the house?'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
Grey asked. The girl said that he (Grey) had left the house.
``Don't admit him (gentleman) again,'' (he)
said he (Grey);--
``that is, if you can avoid it. I believe he (gentleman) is not in his (gentleman) right senses.'' (he)
Then he (Grey) asked for Mr. Jones, his (Grey) landlord, and in a few minutes the pugilistic tailor was with him (Grey).

During those few minutes he (Grey) had been called upon to resolve what he (Grey) would do now. Would he (Grey) put the police at once upon the track of the murderer, who was, as he (Grey) remembered too well, the first cousin of the woman whom he (Grey) still desired to make his (Grey) wife? That cross-examination which he (Grey) would have to undergo at the police-office, and again probably in an assize court, in which all his (Grey) relations with the Vavasor family would be made public, was very vivid to his (Grey) imagination. That he (Grey) was called upon by duty to do something he (Grey) felt almost assured. The man who had been allowed to make such an attempt once with impunity, might probably make it again. But he (man) resolved that he (man) need not now say anything about the pistol to the pugilistic tailor, unless the tailor said something to him (tailor).

``Mr. Jones,'' (he)
he (tailor) said,
``that man whom I had to put out of the room once before, has been here again.'' (he)

``Has there been another tussle, sir?'' (unknown)

``No;--nothing of that kind. But we must take some steps to prevent his (Jones) getting in again, if we can help it.'' (Calder Jones/Jones)

Jones promised his (Jones) aid, and offered to go at once to the police. To this, however, Mr. Grey demurred, saying that he (Grey) should himself seek assistance from some magistrate. Jones promised to be very vigilant as to watching the door; and then John Grey sat down to his (Grey) breakfast. Of course he (Grey) thought much of what had occurred. It was impossible that he (Grey) should not think much of so narrow an escape. He (Grey) had probably been as near death as a man may well be without receiving any injury; and the more he (Grey) thought of it, the more strongly he (Grey) was convinced that he (Grey) could not allow the thing to pass by without some notice, or some precaution as to the future.

At eleven o'clock he (Grey) went to Scotland Yard, and saw some officer great in power over policemen, and told him (officer) all the circumstances,--confidentially. The powerful officer recommended an equally confidential reference to a magistrate; and towards evening a very confidential policeman in plain clothes paid a visit to Vavasor's lodgings in Cecil Street. But Vavasor lodged there no longer. Mrs. Bunsby, who was also very confidential,--and at her (Vavasor) wits' end because she (Vavasor) could not learn the special business of the stranger who called,--stated that Mr. George Vavasor left her (Vavasor) house in a cab at ten o'clock that morning, having taken with him (Vavasor) such luggage as he (Vavasor) had packed, and having gone,

``she (gentleman) was afraid, for good,'' (he)
as Mrs. Bunsby expressed it.

He (Vavasor) had gone for good, and at the moment in which the policeman was making the inquiry in Cecil Street, was leaning over the side of an American steamer which had just got up her (Bunsby) steam and weighed her (Bunsby) anchor in the Mersey. He (Cecil) was on board at six o'clock, and it was not till the next day that the cabman was traced who had carried him (Cecil) to Euston Square Station. Of course, it was soon known that he (Cecil) had gone to America, but it was not thought worth while to take any further steps towards arresting him (Cecil). Mr. Grey himself was decidedly opposed to any such attempt, declaring his (Grey) opinion that his (Grey) own evidence would be insufficient to obtain a conviction. The big men in Scotland Yard were loth to let the matter drop. Their mouths watered after the job, and they had very numerous and very confidential interviews with John Grey. But it was decided that nothing should be done.

``Pity!'' (superintendent)
said one enterprising superintendent, in answer to the condolings of a brother superintendent.
``Pity's no name for it. It's the greatest shame as ever I knew since I joined the force. A man as was a Member of Parliament only last Session,--as belongs to no end of swell clubs, a gent as well known in London as any gent about the town! And I'd have had him (gent) back in three months, as sure as my name's Walker.'' (that superintendent)
And that superintendent felt that his (superintendent) profession and his (superintendent) country were alike disgraced.

And now George Vavasor vanishes from our pages, and will be heard of no more. Roebury knew him (Vavasor) no longer, nor Pall Mall, nor the Chelsea Districts. His (Vavasor) disappearance was a nine days' wonder, but the world at large knew nothing of the circumstances of that attempt in Suffolk Street. Mr. Grey himself told the story to no one, till he (Grey) told it to Mr. Palliser at Lucerne. Mr. Scruby complained bitterly of the way in which Vavasor had robbed him (Scruby); but I doubt whether Scruby, in truth, lost much by the transaction. To Kate, down in Westmoreland, no tidings came of her (Kate) brother, and her (Kate) sojourn in London with her (Kate) aunt had nearly come to an end before she (Kate) knew that he (brother) was gone. Even then the rumour reached her (Kate) through Captain Bellfield, and she (Kate) learned what few facts she (Kate) knew from Mrs. Bunsby in Cecil Street.

``He (gent) was always mysterious,'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
said Mrs. Greenow,
``and now he (gent) has vanished. I hate mysteries, and, as for myself, I think it will be much better that he (gent) should not come back again.'' (Mrs. Greenow/Greenow)
Perhaps Kate was of the same opinion, but, if so, she (Kate) kept it to herself.

CHAPTER LXXIII.

In Which Come Tidings of Great Moment to All Pallisers.

It was not till they had been for a day or two together at Lucerne that Mr. Grey told Mr. Palliser the story of George Vavasor's visit to him (Grey) in Suffolk Street. Having begun the history of his (Grey) connection with Alice, he (Grey) found himself obliged to go with it to the end, and as he (Grey) described the way in which the man had vanished from the sight of all who had known him (man),--that he (man) had in truth gone, so as no longer to be a cause of dread, he (man) could not without dissimulation, keep back the story of that last scene.

``And he (gent) tried to murder you!'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.
``He (gent) should be caught and,--and--'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Mr. Palliser hesitated, not liking to say boldly that the first cousin of the lady who was now living with him (Palliser) ought to be hung.

``It is better as it is,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey.

``He (gent) actually walked into your rooms in the day time, and fired a pistol at you as you were sitting at your breakfast! He (gent) did that in London, and then walked off and went abroad, as though he (gent) had nothing to fear!'' (unknown)

``That was just it,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey.

Mr. Palliser began to think that something ought to be done to make life more secure in the metropolis of the world. Had he (Palliser) not known Mr. Grey, or been accustomed to see the other man in Parliament, he (Grey) would not have thought so much about it. But it was almost too much for him (Grey) when he (Grey) reflected that one man whom he (man) now called his (man) friend, had been nearly murdered in daylight, in the heart of his (man) own part of London, by another man whom he (man) had reckoned among his (man) Parliamentary supporters.

``And he (gent) has got your money too!'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Palliser, putting all the circumstances of the case together. In answer to this Mr. Grey said that he (Grey) hoped the loss might eventually be his (Grey) own; but that he (Grey) was bound to regard the money which had been taken as part of Miss Vavasor's fortune.
``He (gent) is simply the greatest miscreant of whom I ever heard in my life,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.
``The wonder is that Miss Vavasor should ever have brought herself to--to like him (gent).'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
Then Mr. Grey apologized for Alice, explaining that her (Alice) love for her (Alice) cousin had come from her (Alice) early years; that the man himself was clever and capable of assuming pleasant ways, and that he (man) had not been wholly bad till ruin had come upon him (man).
``He (gent) attempted public life and made himself miserable by failing, as most men do who make that attempt,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey. This was a statement which Mr. Palliser could not allow to pass without notice. Whereupon the two men got away from George Vavasor and their own individual interests, and went on seriously discussing the merits and demerits of public life.
``The end of it all is,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey at last,
``that public men in England should be rich like you, and not poor like that miserable wretch, who has now lost everything that the Fates had given him (gent).'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)

They continued to live at Lucerne in this way for a fortnight. Mr. Grey, though he (Grey) was not unfrequently alone with Alice, did not plead his (Grey) suit in direct words; but continued to live with her (Alice) on terms of close and easy friendship. He (Grey) had told her (Alice) that her (Alice) cousin had left England,--that he (cousin) had gone to America immediately after his (cousin) disappointment in regard to the seat in Parliament, and that he (cousin) would probably not return.

``Poor George!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice had said;
``he (George) is a man very much to be pitied.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
``He (George) is a man very much to be pitied,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
Grey had replied. After that, nothing more was said between them about George Vavasor. From Lady Glencora Alice did hear something; but Lady Glencora herself had not heard the whole story.
``I believe he (George) misbehaved himself, my dear,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora said;
``but then, you know, he (George) always does that. I believe that he (George) saw Mr. Grey and insulted him (Grey). Perhaps you had better not ask anything about it till by-and-by. You'll be able to get anything out of him (Grey) then.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
In answer to this Alice made her (Alice) usual protest, and Lady Glencora, as was customary, told her (Glencora) that she (Glencora) was a fool.

I am inclined to think that Mr. Grey knew what he (Grey) was about. Lady Glencora once scolded him (Grey) very vehemently for not bringing the affair to an end.

``We shall be going on to Italy before it's settled,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said;
``and I don't suppose you can go with us, unless it is settled.'' (she)
Mr. Grey protested that he (Grey) had no intention of going to Italy in either case.

``Then it will be put off for another year or two, and you are both of you as old as Adam and Eve already.'' (unknown)

``We ancient people are never impatient,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey, laughing.

``If I were you I would go to her (you) and tell her (you), roundly, that she (you) should marry me, and then I would shake her (you). If you were to scold her (you), till she (you) did not know whether she (you) stood on her (you) head or her (you) heels, she (you) would come to reason.'' (unknown)

``Suppose you try that, Lady Glencora!'' (unknown)

``I can't. It's she (Glencora) that always scolds me,--as you will her (Glencora), when she (Glencora)'s your wife. You and Mr. Palliser are very much alike. You're both of you so very virtuous that no woman would have a chance of picking a hole in your coats.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

But Lady Glencora was wrong. Alice would, no doubt, have submitted herself patiently to her (Alice) lover's rebukes, and would have confessed her (Alice) own sins towards him (Grey) with any amount of self-accusation that he (Grey) might have required; but she (Alice) would not, on that account, have been more willing to obey him (Grey) in that one point, as to which he (Grey) now required present obedience. He (Grey) understood that she (Alice) must be taught to forgive herself for the evil she (Alice) had done,--to forgive herself, at any rate in part,--before she (Alice) could be induced to return to her (Alice) old allegiance to him (Grey). Thus they went on together at Lucerne, passing quiet, idle days,--with some pretence of reading, with a considerable amount of letter-writing, with boat excursions and pony excursions,--till the pony excursions came to a sudden end by means of a violent edict, as to which, and the cause of it, a word or two must be said just now. During these days of the boats and the ponies, the carriage which Lady Glencora hated so vehemently was shut up in limbo, and things went very pleasantly with her (Glencora). Mr. Palliser received political letters from England, which made his (Palliser) mouth water sadly, and was often very fidgety. Parliament was not now sitting, and the Government would, of course, remain intact till next February. Might it not be possible that when the rent came in the Cabinet, he (Palliser) might yet be present at the darning? He (Palliser) was a constant man, and had once declared his (Palliser) intention of being absent for a year. He (Palliser) continued to speak to Grey of his (Grey) coming travels, as though it was impossible that they should be over until after the next Easter. But he (Grey) was sighing for Westminster, and regretting the blue books which were accumulating themselves at Matching;--till on a sudden, there came to him (Grey) tidings which upset all his (Grey) plans, which routed the ponies, which made everything impossible, which made the Alps impassable and the railways dangerous, which drove Burgo Fitzgerald out of Mr. Palliser's head, and so confused him (Palliser) that he (Palliser) could no longer calculate the blunders of the present Chancellor of the Exchequer. All the Palliser world was about to be moved from its lowest depths, to the summits of its highest mountains. Lady Glencora had whispered into her (Glencora) husband's ear that she (Glencora) thought it probable--; she (Glencora) wasn't sure;--she (Glencora) didn't know. And then she (Glencora) burst out into tears on his (husband) bosom as he (husband) sat by her (Glencora) on her (Glencora) bedside.

He (husband) was beside himself when he (husband) left her (Glencora), which he (husband) did with the primary intention of telegraphing to London for half a dozen leading physicians. He (husband) went out by the lake side, and walked there alone for ten minutes in a state of almost unconscious exaltation. He (husband) did not quite remember where he (husband) was, or what he (husband) was doing. The one thing in the world which he (husband) had lacked; the one joy which he (husband) had wanted so much, and which is so common among men, was coming to him (husband) also. In a few minutes it was to him (husband) as though each hand already rested on the fair head of a little male Palliser, of whom one should rule in the halls at Gatherum, and the other be eloquent among the Commons of England. Hitherto,--for the last eight or nine months, since his (husband) first hopes had begun to fade,--he (husband) had been a man degraded in his (husband) own sight amidst all his (husband) honours. What good was all the world to him (husband) if he (husband) had nothing of his (husband) own to come after him (husband)? We must give him (husband) his (husband) due, too, when we speak of this. He (husband) had not had wit enough to hide his (husband) grief from his (husband) wife; his (husband) knowledge of women and of men in social life had not been sufficient to teach him (husband) how this should be done; but he (husband) had wished to do it. He (husband) had never willingly rebuked her (wife) for his (husband) disappointment, either by a glance of his (husband) eye, or a tone of his (husband) voice; and now he (husband) had already forgiven everything. Burgo Fitzgerald was a myth. Mrs. Marsham should never again come near her (Marsham). Mr. Bott was, of course, a thing abolished;--he (Bott) had not even had the sense to keep his (Bott) seat in Parliament. Dandy and Flirt should feed on gilded corn, and there should be an artificial moon always ready in the ruins. If only those d--able saddle-ponies of Lucerne had not come across his (Dandy) wife's path! He (Dandy) went at once into the yard and ordered that the ponies should be abolished;--sent away, one and all, to the furthest confines of the canton; and then he (Dandy) himself inspected the cushions of the carriage. Were they dry? As it was August in those days, and August in Lucerne is a warm month, it may be presumed that they were dry.

He (Dandy) then remembered that he (Dandy) had promised to send Alice up to his (Dandy) wife, and he (Dandy) hurried back into the house. She (wife) was alone in the breakfast-room, waiting for him (Dandy) and for his (Dandy) wife. In these days, Mr. Grey would usually join them at dinner; but he (Grey) seldom saw them before eleven or twelve o'clock in the day. Then he (Grey) would saunter in and join Mr. Palliser, and they would all be together till the evening. When the expectant father of embryo dukes entered the room, Alice perceived at once that some matter was astir. His (father) manner was altogether changed, and he (father) showed by his (father) eye that he (father) was eager and moved beyond his (father) wont.

``Alice,'' (he)
he (father) said,
``would you mind going up to Glencora's room? She (Alice) wishes to speak to you.'' (he)
He (father) had never called her (Alice) Alice before, and as soon as the word was spoken, he (father) remembered himself and blushed.

``She (Alice) isn't ill, I hope?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``No;--she (Alice) isn't ill. At least I think she (Alice) had better not get up quite yet. Don't let her (Alice) excite herself, if you can help it.'' (unknown)

``I'll go to her (Alice) at once,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice rising.

``I'm so much obliged to you;--but, Miss Vavasor--'' (He)

``You called me Alice just now, Mr. Palliser, and I took it as a great compliment.'' (He)

He (father) blushed again.

``Did I? Very well. Then I'll do it again--if you'll let me. But, if you please, do be as calm with her (Alice) as you can. She (Alice) is so easily excited, you know. Of course, if there's anything she (Alice) fancies, we'll take care to get it for her (Alice); but she (Alice) must be kept quiet.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Upon this Alice left him (father), having had no moment of time to guess what had happened, or was about to happen; and he (father) was again alone, contemplating the future glories of his (father) house. Had he (father) a thought for his (father) poor cousin Jeffrey, whose nose was now so terribly out of joint? No, indeed. His (father) thoughts were all of himself, and the good things that were coming to him (father),--of the new world of interest that was being opened for him (father). It would be better to him (father), this, than being Chancellor of the Exchequer. He (Chancellor) would rather have it in store for him (Chancellor) to be father of the next Duke of Omnium, than make half a dozen consecutive annual speeches in Parliament as to the ways and means, and expenditure of the British nation! Could it be possible that this foreign tour had produced for him (Chancellor) this good fortune? If so, how luckily had things turned out! He (Chancellor) would remember even that ball at Lady Monk's with gratitude. Perhaps a residence abroad would be best for Lady Glencora at this particular period of her (Glencora) life. If so, abroad she (Glencora) should certainly live. Before resolving, however, on anything permanently on this head, he (Chancellor) thought that he (Chancellor) might judiciously consult those six first-rate London physicians, whom, in the first moment of his (Chancellor) excitement, he (Chancellor) had been desirous of summoning to Lucerne.

In the meantime Alice had gone up to the bedroom of the lady who was now to be the subject of so much anxious thought. When she (Alice) entered the room, her (Alice) friend was up and in her (Alice) dressing-gown, lying on a sofa which stood at the foot of the bed.

``Oh, Alice, I'm so glad you've come,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``I do so want to hear your voice.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Then Alice knelt beside her (Alice), and asked her (Alice) if she (Alice) were ill.

``He (you) hasn't told you? But of course he (you) wouldn't. How could he (you)? But, Alice, how did he (you) look? Did you observe anything about him (you)? Was he (you) pleased?'' (unknown)

``I did observe something, and I think he (you) was pleased. But what is it? He (you) called me Alice. And seemed to be quite unlike himself. But what is it? He (you) told me that I was to come to you instantly.'' (unknown)

``Oh, Alice, can't you guess?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Then suddenly Alice did guess the secret, and whispered her (Alice) guess into Lady Glencora's ear.
``I suppose it is so,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``I know what they'll do. They'll kill me by fussing over me. If I could go about my work like a washerwoman, I should be all right.'' (unknown)

``I am so happy,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said, some two or three hours afterwards.
``I won't deny that I am very happy. It seemed as though I were destined to bring nothing but misery to everybody, and I used to wish myself dead so often. I shan't wish myself dead now.'' (unknown)

``We shall all have to go home, I suppose?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``He (washerwoman) says so;--but he (washerwoman) seems to think that I oughtn't to travel above a mile and a half a day. When I talked of going down the Rhine in one of the steamers, I thought he (washerwoman) would have gone into a fit. When I asked him (washerwoman) why, he (washerwoman) gave me such a look. I know he (washerwoman)'ll make a goose of himself;--and he (washerwoman)'ll make geese of us, too; which is worse.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

On that afternoon, as they were walking together, Mr. Palliser told the important secret to his (Palliser) new friend, Mr. Grey. He (Palliser) could not deny himself the pleasure of talking about this great event.

``It is a matter, you see, of such immense importance to me,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Mr. Palliser said.

``Indeed, it is,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey.
``Every man feels that when a child is about to be born to him (man).'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
But this did not at all satisfy Mr. Palliser.

``Yes,'' (he)
said he (Palliser).
``That's of course. It is an important thing to everybody;--very important, no doubt. But, when a man--. You see, Grey, I don't think a man is a bit better because he (Grey) is rich, or because he (Grey) has a title; nor do I think he (Grey) is likely to be in any degree the happier. I am quite sure that he (Grey) has no right to be in the slightest degree proud of that which he (Grey) has had no hand in doing for himself.'' (unknown)

``Men usually are very proud of such advantages,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey.

``I don't think that I am; I don't, indeed. I am proud of some things. Whenever I can manage to carry a point in the House, I feel very proud of it. I don't think I ever knocked under to any one, and I am proud of that.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Perhaps, Mr. Palliser was thinking of a certain time when his (Palliser) uncle the Duke had threatened him (Palliser), and he (Palliser) had not given way to the Duke's threats.
``But I don't think I'm proud because chance has made me my uncle's heir.'' (unknown)

``Not in the least, I should say.'' (unknown)

``But I do feel that a son to me is of more importance than it is to most men. A strong anxiety on the subject, is, I think, more excusable in me than it might be in another. I don't know whether I quite make myself understood?'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes! When there's a dukedom and heaven knows how many thousands a year to be disposed of, the question of their future ownership does become important.'' (unknown)

``This property is so much more interesting to one, if one feels that all one does to it is done for one's own son.'' (unknown)

``And yet,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey,
``of all the great plunderers of property throughout Europe, the Popes have been the most greedy.'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)

``Perhaps it's different, when a man can't have a wife,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

From all this it may be seen that Mr. Palliser and Mr. Grey had become very intimate. Had chance brought them together in London they might have met a score of times before Mr. Palliser would have thought of doing more than bowing to such an acquaintance. Mr. Grey might have spent weeks at Matching, without having achieved anything like intimacy with its noble owner. But things of that kind progress more quickly abroad than they do at home. The deck of an ocean steamer is perhaps the most prolific hotbed of the growth of sudden friendships; but an hotel by the side of a Swiss lake does almost as well.

For some time after this Lady Glencora's conduct was frequently so indiscreet as to drive her (Glencora) husband almost to frenzy. On the very day after the news had been communicated to him (husband), she (Glencora) proposed a picnic, and made the proposition not only in the presence of Alice, but in that of Mr. Grey also! Mr. Palliser, on such an occasion, could not express all that he (Palliser) thought; but he (Palliser) looked it.

``What is the matter, now, Plantagenet?'' (wife)
said his (Palliser) wife.

``Nothing,'' (he)
said he (Palliser);--
``nothing. Never mind.'' (he)

``And shall we make this party up to the chapel?'' (unknown)

The chapel in question was Tell's chapel--ever so far up the lake. A journey in a steam-boat would have been necessary.

``No!'' (he)
said he (Palliser), shouting out his (Palliser) refusal at her (wife).
``We will not.'' (unknown)

``You needn't be angry about it,'' (she)
said she (wife);--as though he (Palliser) could have failed to be stirred by such a proposition at such a time. On another occasion she (wife) returned from an evening walk, showing on her (wife) face some sign of the exercise she (wife) had taken.

``Good G--! Glencora,'' (he)
said he (Palliser),
``do you mean to kill yourself?'' (he)

He (Palliser) wanted her (wife) to eat six or seven times a day; and always told her (wife) that she (wife) was eating too much, remembering some ancient proverb about little and often. He (Palliser) watched her (wife) now as closely as Mrs. Marsham and Mr. Bott had watched her (Marsham) before; and she (Marsham) always knew that he (Bott) was doing so. She (Marsham) made the matter worse by continually proposing to do things which she (Marsham) knew he (Bott) would not permit, in order that she (Marsham) might enjoy the fun of seeing his (Bott) agony and amazement. But this, though it was fun to her (Marsham) at the moment, produced anything but fun, as its general result.

``Upon my word, Alice, I think this will kill me,'' (she)
she (Marsham) said.
``I am not to stir out of the house now, unless I go in the carriage, or he (Alice) is with me.'' (unknown)

``It won't last long.'' (unknown)

``I don't know what you call long. As for walking with him (Alice), it's out of the question. He (Alice) goes about a mile an hour. And then he (Alice) makes me look so much like a fool. I had no idea that he (Alice) would be such an old coddle.'' (unknown)

``The coddling will all be given to some one else, very soon.'' (unknown)

``No baby could possibly live through it, if you mean that. If there is a baby--'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

``I suppose there will be one, by-and-by,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``Don't be a fool! But, if there is, I shall take that matter into my own hands. He (fool) can do what he (fool) pleases with me, and I can't help myself; but I shan't let him (fool) or anybody do what they please with my baby. I know what I'm about in such matters a great deal better than he (fool) does. I've no doubt he (fool)'s a very clever man in Parliament; but he (fool) doesn't seem to me to understand anything else.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice was making some very wise speech in answer to this, when Lady Glencora interrupted her (Glencora).

``Mr. Grey wouldn't make himself so troublesome, I'm quite sure.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Then Alice held her (Alice) tongue.

When the first consternation arising from the news had somewhat subsided,--say in a fortnight from the day in which Mr. Palliser was made so triumphant,--and when tidings had been duly sent to the Duke, and an answer from his (Palliser) Grace had come, arrangements were made for the return of the party to England. The Duke's reply was very short:--

MY DEAR PLANTAGENET,--Give my kind love to Glencora. If it's a boy, of course I will be one of the godfathers. The Prince, who is very kind, will perhaps oblige me by being the other. I should advise you to return as soon as convenient.

Your affectionate uncle,

OMNIUM.

That was the letter; and short as it was, it was probably the longest that Mr. Palliser had ever received from the Duke.

There was great trouble about the mode of their return.

``Oh, what nonsense,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora.
``Let us get into an express train, and go right through to London.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Mr. Palliser looked at her (Glencora) with a countenance full of rebuke and sorrow. He (Palliser) was always so looking at her (Glencora) now.
``If you mean, Plantagenet, that we are to be dragged all across the Continent in that horrible carriage, and be a thousand days on the road, I for one won't submit to it.'' (unknown)
``I wish I had never told him (Grey) a word about it,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said afterwards to Alice.
``He (Grey) would never have found it out himself, till this thing was all over.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

Mr. Palliser did at last consent to take the joint opinion of a Swiss doctor and an English one who was settled at Berne; and who, on the occasion, was summoned to Lucerne. They suggested the railway; and as letters arrived for Mr. Palliser,--medical letters,--in which the same opinion was broached, it was agreed, at last, that they should return by railway; but they were to make various halts on the road, stopping at each halting-place for a day. The first was, of course, Basle, and from Basle they were to go on to Baden.

``I particularly want to see Baden again,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora said;
``and perhaps I may be able to get back my napoleon.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)

CHAPTER LXXIV.

Showing What Happened in the Churchyard.

These arrangements as to the return of Mr. Palliser's party to London did not, of course, include Mr. Grey. They were generally discussed in Mr. Grey's absence, and communicated to him (Grey) by Mr. Palliser.

``I suppose we shall see you in England before long?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.
``I shall be able to tell you that before you go,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey.
``Not but that in any event I shall return to England before the winter.'' (unknown)

``Then come to us at Matching,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.
``We shall be most happy to have you. Say that you'll come for the first fortnight in December. After that we always go to the Duke, in Barsetshire. Though, by-the-by, I don't suppose we shall go anywhere this year,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Mr. Palliser added, interrupting the warmth of his (Palliser) invitation, and reflecting that, under the present circumstances, perhaps, it might be improper to have any guests at Matching in December. But he (Palliser) had become very fond of Mr. Grey, and on this occasion, as he (Grey) had done on some others, pressed him (Grey) warmly to make an attempt at Parliament.
``It isn't nearly so difficult as you think,'' (he)
said he (Grey), when Grey declared that he (Grey) would not know where to look for a seat.
``See the men that get in. There was Mr. Vavasor. Even he (Vavasor) got a seat.'' (unknown)

``But he (Vavasor) had to pay for it very dearly.'' (unknown)

``You might easily find some quiet little borough.'' (unknown)

``Quiet little boroughs have usually got their own quiet little Members,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey.

``They're fond of change; and if you like to spend a thousand pounds, the thing isn't difficult. I'll put you in the way of it.'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
But Mr. Grey still declined. He (Grey) was not a man prone to be talked out of his (Grey) own way of life, and the very fact that George Vavasor had been in Parliament would of itself have gone far towards preventing any attempt on his (Vavasor) part in that direction. Alice had also wanted him (Vavasor) to go into public life, but he (Vavasor) had put aside her (Alice) request as though the thing were quite out of the question,--never giving a moment to its consideration. Had she (Alice) asked him (Vavasor) to settle himself and her (Alice) in Central Africa, his (Vavasor) manner and mode of refusal would have been the same. It was this immobility on his (Vavasor) part,--this absolute want of any of the weakness of indecision, which had frightened her (Alice), and driven her (Alice) away from him (Vavasor). He (Vavasor) was partly aware of this; but that which he (Vavasor) had declined to do at her (Alice) solicitation, he (Vavasor) certainly would not do at the advice of any one else. So it was that he (Vavasor) argued the matter with himself. Had he (Vavasor) now allowed himself to be so counselled, with what terrible acknowledgements of his (Vavasor) own faults must he (Vavasor) not have presented himself before Alice?

``I suppose books, then, will be your object in life?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

``I hope they will be my aids,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
Grey answered.
``I almost doubt whether any object such as that you mean is necessary for life, or even expedient. It seems to me that if a man can so train himself that he (man) may live honestly and die fearlessly, he (man) has done about as much as is necessary.'' (unknown)

``He (man) has done a great deal, certainly,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, who was not ready enough to carry on the argument as he (Palliser) might have done had more time been given to him (Palliser) to consider it. He (Palliser) knew very well that he (Palliser) himself was working for others, and not for himself; and he (Palliser) was aware, though he (Palliser) had not analysed his (Palliser) own convictions on the matter, that good men struggle as they do in order that others, besides themselves, may live honestly, and, if possible, die fearlessly. The recluse of Nethercoats had thought much more about all this than the rising star of the House of Commons; but the philosophy of the rising star was the better philosophy of the two, though he (recluse) was by far the less brilliant man.
``I don't see why a man should not live honestly and be a Member of Parliament as well,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
continued Mr. Palliser, when he (Palliser) had been silent for a few minutes.

``Nor I either,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Grey.
``I am sure that there are such men, and that the country is under great obligation to them. But they are subject to temptations which a prudent man like myself may perhaps do well to avoid.'' (he)
But though he (Grey) spoke with an assured tone, he (Grey) was shaken, and almost regretted that he (Grey) did not accept the aid which was offered to him (Grey). It is astonishing how strong a man may be to those around him (man),--how impregnable may be his (man) exterior, while within he (man) feels himself to be as weak as water, and as unstable as chaff.

But the object which he (man) had now in view was a renewal of his (man) engagement with Alice, and he (man) felt that he (man) must obtain an answer from her (Alice) before they left Lucerne. If she (Alice) still persisted in refusing to give him (man) her (Alice) hand, it would not be consistent with his (man) dignity as a man to continue his (man) immediate pursuit of her (Alice) any longer. In such case he (man) must leave her (Alice), and see what future time might bring forth. He (man) believed himself to be aware that he (man) would never offer his (man) love to another woman; and if Alice were to remain single, he (man) might try again, after the lapse of a year or two. But if he (man) failed now,--then, for that year or two, he (man) would see her (Alice) no more. Having so resolved, and being averse to anything like a surprise, he (man) asked her (Alice), as he (man) left her (Alice) one evening, whether she (Alice) would walk with him (man) on the following morning. That morning would be the morning of her (Alice) last day at Lucerne; and as she (Alice) assented she (Alice) knew well what was to come. She (Alice) said nothing to Lady Glencora on the subject, but allowed the coming prospects of the Palliser family to form the sole subject of their conversation that night, as it had done on every night since the great news had become known. They were always together for an hour every evening before Alice was allowed to go to bed, and during this hour the anxieties of the future father and mother were always discussed till Alice Vavasor was almost tired of them. But she (Vavasor) was patient with her (Vavasor) friend, and on this special night she (Vavasor) was patient as ever. But when she (Vavasor) was released and was alone, she (Vavasor) made a great endeavour to come to some fixed resolution as to what she (Vavasor) would do on the morrow,--some resolution which should be absolutely resolute, and from which no eloquence on the part of any one should move her (Vavasor). But such resolutions are not easily reached, and Alice laboured through half the night almost in vain. She (Alice) knew that she (Alice) loved the man. She (Alice) knew that he (man) was as true to her (Alice) as the sun is true to the earth. She (Alice) knew that she (Alice) would be, in all respects, safe in his (man) hands. She (Alice) knew that Lady Glencora would be delighted, and her (Glencora) father gratified. She (Glencora) knew that the countesses would open their arms to her (Glencora),--though I doubt whether this knowledge was in itself very persuasive. She (Glencora) knew that by such a marriage she (Glencora) would gain all that women generally look to gain when they give themselves away. But, nevertheless, as far as she (Glencora) could decide at all, she (Glencora) decided against her (Glencora) lover. She (Glencora) had no right of her (Glencora) own to be taken back after the evil that she (Glencora) had done, and she (Glencora) did not choose to be taken back as an object of pity and forgiveness.

``Where are you going?'' (cousin)
said her (Glencora) cousin, when she (Glencora) came in with her (Glencora) hat on, soon after breakfast.

``I am going to walk,--with Mr. Grey.'' (unknown)

``By appointment?'' (unknown)

``Yes, by appointment. He (Grey) asked me yesterday.'' (unknown)

``Then it's all settled, and you haven't told me!'' (unknown)

``All that is settled I have told you very often. He (Grey) asked me yesterday to walk with him (Grey) this morning, and I could not well refuse him (Grey).'' (unknown)

``Why should you have wished to refuse him (Grey)?'' (unknown)

``I haven't said that I did wish it. But I hate scenes, and I think it would have been pleasanter for us to have parted without any occasion for special words.'' (unknown)

``Alice, you are such a fool!'' (unknown)

``So you tell me very often.'' (unknown)

``Of course he (fool) is now going to say the very thing that he (fool) has come all this way for the purpose of saying. He (fool) has been wonderfully slow about it; but then slow as he (fool) is, you are slower. If you don't make it up with him (fool) now, I really shall think you are very wicked. I am becoming like Lady Midlothian;--I can't understand it. I know you want to be his (fool) wife, and I know he (fool) wants to be your husband, and the only thing that keeps you apart is your obstinacy,--just because you have said you wouldn't have him (fool). My belief is that if Lady Midlothian and the rest of us were to pat you on the back, and tell you how right you were, you'd ask him (fool) to take you, out of defiance. You may be sure of this, Alice; if you refuse him (fool) now, it'll be for the last time.'' (she)

This, and much more of the same kind, she (Glencora) bore before Mr. Grey came to take her (Glencora), and she (Glencora) answered to it all as little as she (Glencora) could.

``You are making me very unhappy, Glencora,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said once.
``I wish I could break you down with unhappiness,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora answered,
``so that he (fool) might find you less stiff, and hard, and unmanageable.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Directly upon that he (Grey) came in, looking as though he (Grey) had no business on hand more exciting than his (Grey) ordinary morning's tranquil employments. Alice at once got up to start with him (Grey).
``So you and Alice are going to make your adieux,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``It must be done sooner or later,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Mr. Grey; and then they went off.

Those who know Lucerne,--and almost everybody now does know Lucerne,--will remember the big hotel which has been built close to the landing-pier of the steamers, and will remember also the church that stands upon a little hill or rising ground, to the left of you, as you come out of the inn upon the lake. The church is immediately over the lake, and round the church there is a burying-ground, and skirting the burying-ground there are cloisters, through the arches and apertures of which they who walk and sit there look down immediately upon the blue water, and across the water upon the frowning menaces of Mount Pilate. It is one of the prettiest spots in that land of beauty; and its charm is to my feeling enhanced by the sepulchral monuments over which I walk, and by which I am surrounded, as I stand there. Up here, into these cloisters, Alice and John Grey went together. I doubt whether he (Grey) had formed any purpose of doing so. She (Alice) certainly would have gone without question in any direction that he (Grey) might have led her (Alice). The distance from the inn up to the church-gate did not take them ten minutes, and when they were there their walk was over. But the place was solitary, and they were alone; and it might be as well for Mr. Grey to speak what words he (Grey) had to say there as elsewhere. They had often been together in those cloisters before, but on such occasions either Mr. Palliser or Lady Glencora had been with them. On their slow passage up the hill very little was spoken, and that little was of no moment.

``We will go in here for a few minutes,'' (he)
he (Palliser) said.
``It is the prettiest spot about Lucerne, and we don't know when we may see it again.'' (unknown)
So they went in, and sat down on one of the embrasures that open from the cloisters over the lake.

``Probably never again,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.
``And yet I have been here now two years running.'' (She)

She (Alice) shuddered as she (Alice) remembered that in that former year George Vavasor had been with her (Alice). As she (Alice) thought of it all she (Alice) hated herself.
