Over and over again she (Alice) had told herself that she (Alice) had so mismanaged the latter years of her (Alice) life that it was impossible for her (Alice) not to hate herself. No woman had a clearer idea of feminine constancy than she (woman) had, and no woman had sinned against that idea more deeply. He (Vavasor) gave her (woman) time to think of all this as he (Vavasor) sat there looking down upon the water.

``And yet I would sooner live in Cambridgeshire,'' (he)
were the first words he (Vavasor) spoke.

``Why so?'' (unknown)

``Partly because all beauty is best enjoyed when it is sought for with some trouble and difficulty, and partly because such beauty, and the romance which is attached to it, should not make up the staple of one's life. Romance, if it is to come at all, should always come by fits and starts.'' (unknown)

``I should like to live in a pretty country.'' (unknown)

``And would like to live a romantic life,--no doubt; but all those things lose their charm if they are made common. When a man has to go to Vienna or St. Petersburg two or three times a month, you don't suppose he (man) enjoys travelling?'' (unknown)

``All the same, I should like to live in a pretty country,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``And I want you to come and live in a very ugly country.'' (he)
Then he (Vavasor) paused for a minute or two, not looking at her (Alice), but gazing still on the mountain opposite. She (Alice) did not speak a word, but looked as he (Vavasor) was looking. She (Alice) knew that the request was coming, and had been thinking about it all night; but now that it had come she (Alice) did not know how to bear herself.
``I don't think,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) went on to say,
``that you would let that consideration stand in your way, if on other grounds you were willing to become my wife.'' (he)

``What consideration?'' (unknown)

``Because Nethercoats is not so pretty as Lucerne.'' (unknown)

``It would have nothing to do with it,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``It should have nothing to do with it.'' (unknown)

``Nothing; nothing at all,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
repeated Alice.

``Will you come, then? Will you come and be my wife, and help me to be happy amidst all that ugliness? Will you come and be my one beautiful thing, my treasure, my joy, my comfort, my counsellor?'' (unknown)

``You want no counsellor, Mr. Grey.'' (unknown)

``No man ever wanted one more. Alice, this has been a bad year to me, and I do not think that it has been a happy one for you.'' (unknown)

``Indeed, no.'' (unknown)

``Let us forget it,--or rather, let us treat it as though it were forgotten. Twelve months ago you were mine. You were, at any rate, so much mine that I had a right to boast of my possession among my friends.'' (unknown)

``It was a poor boast.'' (unknown)

``They did not seem to think so. I had but one or two to whom I could speak of you, but they told me that I was going to be a happy man. As to myself, I was sure that I was to be so. No man was ever better contented with his (man) bargain than I was with mine. Let us go back to it, and the last twelve months shall be as though they had never been.'' (unknown)

``That cannot be, Mr. Grey. If it could, I should be worse even than I am.'' (unknown)

``Why cannot it be?'' (unknown)

``Because I cannot forgive myself what I have done, and because you ought not to forgive me.'' (unknown)

``But I do. There has never been an hour with me in which there has been an offence of yours rankling in my bosom unforgiven. I think you have been foolish, misguided,--led away by a vain ambition, and that in the difficulty to which these things brought you, you endeavoured to constrain yourself to do an act, which, when it came near to you,--when the doing of it had to be more closely considered, you found to be contrary to your nature.'' (he)
Now, as he (Vavasor) spoke thus, she (Alice) turned her (Alice) eyes upon him (Vavasor), and looked at him (Vavasor), wondering that he (Vavasor) should have had power to read her (Alice) heart so accurately.
``I never believed that you would marry your cousin. When I was told of it, I knew that trouble had blinded you for awhile. You had driven yourself to revolt against me, and upon that your heart misgave you, and you said to yourself that it did not matter then how you might throw away all your sweetness. You see that I speak of your old love for me with the frank conceit of a happy lover.'' (unknown)

``No;--no, no!'' (she)
she (Alice) ejaculated.

``But the storm passes over the tree and does not tear it up by the roots or spoil it of all its symmetry. When we hear the winds blowing, and see how the poor thing is shaken, we think that its days are numbered and its destruction at hand. Alice, when the winds were shaking you, and you were torn and buffeted, I never thought so. There may be some who will forgive you slowly. Your own self-forgiveness will be slow. But I, who have known you better than any one,--yes, better than any one,--I have forgiven you everything, have forgiven you instantly. Come to me, Alice, and comfort me. Come to me, for I want you sorely.'' (She)
She (Alice) sat quite still, looking at the lake and the mountain beyond, but she (Alice) said nothing. What could she (Alice) say to him (Vavasor)?
``My need of you is much greater now,'' (he)
he (Vavasor) went on to say,
``than when I first asked you to share the world with me. Then I could have borne to lose you, as I had never boasted to myself that you were my own,--had never pictured to myself the life that might be mine if you were always to be with me. But since that day I have had no other hope,--no other hope but this for which I plead now. Am I to plead in vain?'' (he)

``You do not know me,'' (she)
she (Alice) said;
``how vile I have been! You do not think what it is,--for a woman to have promised herself to one man while she (woman) loved another.'' (she)

``But it was me you loved. Ah! Alice, I can forgive that. Do I not tell you that I did forgive it the moment that I heard it? Do you not hear me say that I never for a moment thought that you would marry him (man)? Alice, you should scold me for my vanity, for I have believed all through that you loved me, and me only. Come to me, dear, and tell me that it is so, and the past shall be only as a dream.'' (unknown)

``I am dreaming it always,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``They will cease to be bitter dreams if your head be upon my shoulder. You will cease to reproach yourself when you know that you have made me happy.'' (unknown)

``I shall never cease to reproach myself. I have done that which no woman can do and honour herself afterwards. I have been--a jilt.'' (unknown)

``The noblest jilt that ever yet halted between two minds! There has been no touch of selfishness in your fickleness. I think I could be hard enough upon a woman who had left me for greater wealth, for a higher rank,--who had left me even that she (woman) might be gay and merry. It has not been so with you.'' (unknown)

``Yes, it has. I thought you were too firm in your own will, and--'' (unknown)

``And you think so still. Is that it?'' (unknown)

``It does not matter what I think now. I am a fallen creature, and have no longer a right to such thoughts. It will be better for us both that you should leave me,--and forget me. There are things which, if a woman does them, should never be forgotten;--which she (woman) should never permit herself to forget.'' (unknown)

``And am I to be punished, then, because of your fault? Is that your sense of justice?'' (He)
He (Vavasor) got up, and standing before her (Alice), looked down upon her (Alice).
``Alice, if you will tell me that you do not love me, I will believe you, and will trouble you no more. I know that you will say nothing to me that is false. Through it all you have spoken no word of falsehood. If you love me, after what has passed, I have a right to demand your hand. My happiness requires it, and I have a right to expect your compliance. I do demand it. If you love me, Alice, I tell you that you dare not refuse me. If you do so, you will fail hereafter to reconcile it to your conscience before God.'' (he)

Then he (Vavasor) stopped his (Vavasor) speech, and waited for a reply; but Alice sat silent beneath his (Vavasor) gaze, with her (Alice) eyes turned upon the tombstones beneath her (Alice) feet. Of course she (Alice) had no choice but to yield. He (Vavasor), possessed of power and force infinitely greater than hers, had left her (Alice) no alternative but to be happy. But there still clung to her (Alice) what I fear we must call a perverseness of obstinacy, a desire to maintain the resolution she (Alice) had made,--a wish that she (Alice) might be allowed to undergo the punishment she (Alice) had deserved. She (Alice) was as a prisoner who would fain cling to his (prisoner) prison after pardon has reached him (prisoner), because he (prisoner) is conscious that the pardon is undeserved. And it may be that there was still left within her (Alice) bosom some remnant of that feeling of rebellion which his (prisoner) masterful spirit had ever produced in her (Alice). He (prisoner) was so imperious in his (prisoner) tranquillity, he (prisoner) argued his (prisoner) question of love with such a manifest preponderance of right on his (prisoner) side, that she (Alice) had always felt that to yield to him (prisoner) would be to confess the omnipotence of his (prisoner) power. She (Alice) knew now that she (Alice) must yield to him (prisoner),--that his (prisoner) power over her (Alice) was omnipotent. She (Alice) was pressed by him (prisoner) as in some countries the prisoner is pressed by the judge,--so pressed that she (Alice) acknowledged to herself silently that any further antagonism to him (prisoner) was impossible. Nevertheless, the word which she (Alice) had to speak still remained unspoken, and he (prisoner) stood over her (Alice), waiting for her (Alice) answer. Then slowly he (prisoner) sat down beside her (Alice), and gradually he (prisoner) put his (prisoner) arm round her (Alice) waist. She (Alice) shrank from him (prisoner), back against the stonework of the embrasure, but she (Alice) could not shrink away from his (prisoner) grasp. She (Alice) put up her (Alice) hand to impede his (prisoner), but his (prisoner) hand, like his (prisoner) character and his (prisoner) words, was full of power. It would not be impeded.

``Alice,'' (he)
he (prisoner) said, as he (prisoner) pressed her (Alice) close with his (prisoner) arm,
``the battle is over now, and I have won it.'' (he)

``You win everything,--always,'' (she)
she (Alice) said, whispering to him (prisoner), as she (Alice) still shrank from his (prisoner) embrace.

``In winning you I have won everything.'' (he)
Then he (prisoner) put his (prisoner) face over her (Alice) and pressed his (prisoner) lips to hers. I wonder whether he (prisoner) was made happier when he (prisoner) knew that no other touch had profaned those lips since last he (prisoner) had pressed them?

CHAPTER LXXV.

Rouge et Noir.

Alice insisted on being left up in the churchyard, urging that she (Alice) wanted to

``think about it all,'' (she)
but, in truth, fearing that she (Alice) might not be able to carry herself well, if she (Alice) were to walk down with her (Alice) lover to the hotel. To this he (lover) made no objection, and, on reaching the inn, met Mr. Palliser in the hall. Mr. Palliser was already inspecting the arrangement of certain large trunks which had been brought down-stairs, and was preparing for their departure. He (Palliser) was going about the house, with a nervous solicitude to do something, and was flattering himself that he (Palliser) was of use. As he (Palliser) could not be Chancellor of the Exchequer, and as, by the nature of his (Chancellor) disposition, some employment was necessary to him (Chancellor), he (Chancellor) was looking to the cording of the boxes.
``Good morning! good morning!'' (he)
he (Chancellor) said to Grey, hardly looking at him (Chancellor), as though time were too precious with him (Chancellor) to allow of his (Chancellor) turning his (Chancellor) eyes upon his (Chancellor) friend.
``I am going up to the station to see after a carriage for to-morrow. Perhaps you'll come with me.'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
To this proposition Mr. Grey assented.
``Sometimes, you know,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
continued Mr. Palliser,
``the springs of the carriages are so very rough.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Then, in a very few words, Mr. Grey told him (Grey) what had been his (Grey) own morning's work. He (Grey) hated secrets and secrecy, and as the Pallisers knew well what had brought him (Grey) upon their track, it was, he (Grey) thought, well that they should know that he (Grey) had been successful. Mr. Palliser congratulated him (Palliser) very cordially, and then, running up-stairs for his (Palliser) gloves or his (Palliser) stick, or, more probably, that he (Palliser) might give his (Palliser) wife one other caution as to her (wife) care of herself, he (Palliser) told her (wife) also that Alice had yielded at last.
``Of course she (Alice) has,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``I really didn't think she (Alice) would,'' (he)
said he (Palliser).

``That's because you don't understand things of that sort,'' (wife)
said his (Palliser) wife. Then the caution was repeated, the mother of the future duke was kissed, and Mr. Palliser went off on his (Palliser) mission about the carriage, its cushions, and its springs. In the course of their walk Mr. Palliser suggested that, as things were settled so pleasantly, Mr. Grey might as well return with them to England, and to this suggestion Mr. Grey assented.

Alice remained alone for nearly an hour, looking out upon the rough sides and gloomy top of Mount Pilate. No one disturbed her (Alice) in the churchyard,--no steps were heard along the tombstones,--no voice sounded through the cloisters. She (Alice) was left in perfect solitude to think of the past, and form her (Alice) plans of the future. Was she (Alice) happy, now that the manner of her (Alice) life to come was thus settled for her (Alice); that all further question as to the disposal of herself was taken out of her (Alice) hands, and that her (Alice) marriage with a man she (Alice) loved was so firmly arranged that no further folly of her (Alice) own could disarrange it? She (Alice) was happy, though she (Alice) was slow to confess her (Alice) happiness to herself. She (Alice) was happy, and she (Alice) was resolute in this,--that she (Alice) would now do all she (Alice) could to make him (man) happy also. And there must now, she (Alice) acknowledged, be an end to her (Alice) pride,--to that pride which had hitherto taught her (Alice) to think that she (Alice) could more wisely follow her (Alice) own guidance than that of any other who might claim to guide her (Alice). She (Alice) knew now that she (Alice) must follow his (man) guidance. She (Alice) had found her (Alice) master, as we sometimes say, and laughed to herself with a little inward laughter as she (Alice) confessed that it was so. She (Alice) was from henceforth altogether in his (man) hands. If he (man) chose to tell her (Alice) that they were to be married at Michaelmas, or at Christmas, or on Lady Day, they would, of course, be married accordingly. She (Lady) had taken her (Lady) fling at having her (Lady) own will, and she (Lady) and all her (Lady) friends had seen what had come of it. She (Lady) had assumed the command of the ship, and had thrown it upon the rocks, and she (Lady) felt that she (Lady) never ought to take the captain's place again. It was well for her (Lady) that he (captain) who was to be captain was one whom she (Lady) respected as thoroughly as she (Lady) loved him (captain).

She (Lady) would write to her (Lady) father at once,--to her (Lady) father and Lady Macleod,--and would confess everything. She (Lady) felt that she (Lady) owed it to them that they should be told by herself that they had been right and that she (Lady) had been wrong. Hitherto she (Lady) had not mentioned to either of them the fact that Mr. Grey was with them in Switzerland. And, then, what must she (Lady) do as to Lady Midlothian? As to Lady Midlothian, she (Lady) would do nothing. Lady Midlothian, of course, would triumph;--would jump upon her (Lady), as Lady Glencora had once expressed it, with very triumphant heels,--would try to patronize her (Glencora), or, which would be almost worse, would make a parade of her (Glencora) forgiveness. But she (Glencora) would have nothing to do with Lady Midlothian, unless, indeed, Mr. Grey should order it. Then she (Midlothian) laughed at herself again with that inward laughter, and, rising from her (Midlothian) seat, proceeded to walk down the hill to the hotel.

``Vanquished at last!'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, as Alice entered the room.

``Yes, vanquished; if you like to call it so,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice.

``It is not what I call it, but what you feel it,'' (unknown)
said the other.
``Do you think that I don't know you well enough to be sure that you regard yourself now as an unfortunate prisoner,--as a captive taken in war, to be led away in triumph, without any hope of a ransom? I know that it is quite a misery to you that you should be made a happy woman of at last. I understand it all, my dear, and my heart bleeds for you.'' (unknown)

``Of course; I knew that was the way you would treat me.'' (unknown)

``In what way would you have me treat you? If I were to hug you with joy, and tell you how good he (my) is, and how fortunate you are,--if I were to praise him (my), and bid you triumph in your success, as might be expected on such an occasion,--you would put on a long face at once, and tell me that though the thing is to be, it would be much better that the thing shouldn't be. Don't I know you, Alice?'' (unknown)

``I shouldn't have said that;--not now.'' (unknown)

``I believe in my heart you would;--that, or something like it. But I do wish you joy all the same, and you may say what you please. He (you) has got you in his (you) power now, and I don't think even you can go back.'' (unknown)

``No; I shall not go back again.'' (unknown)

``I would join with Lady Midlothian in putting you into a madhouse, if you did. But I am so glad; I am, indeed. I was afraid to the last,--terribly afraid; you are so hard and so proud. I don't mean hard to me, dear. You have never been half hard enough to me. But you are hard to yourself, and, upon my word, you have been hard to him (I). What a deal you will have to make up to him (I)!'' (unknown)

``I feel that I ought to stand before him (I) always as a penitent,--in a white sheet.'' (unknown)

``He (I) will like it better, I dare say, if you will sit upon his (I) knee. Some penitents do, you know. And how happy you will be! He (I)'ll never explain the sugar-duties to you, and there'll be no Mr. Bott at Nethercoats.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
They sat together the whole morning,--while Mr. Palliser was seeing to the springs and cushions,--and by degrees Alice began to enjoy her (Alice) happiness. As she (Alice) did so her (Alice) friend enjoyed it with her (Alice), and at last they had something of the comfort and excitement which such an occasion should give.
``I'll tell you what, Alice; you shall come and be married at Matching, in August, or perhaps September. That's the only way in which I can be present; and if we can bespeak some sun, we'll have the breakfast out in the ruins.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

On the following morning they all started together, a first-class compartment having been taken for the Palliser family, and a second-class compartment close to them for the Palliser servants. Mr. Palliser, as he (Palliser) slowly handed his (Palliser) wife in, was a triumphant man; as was also Mr. Grey, as he (Grey) handed in his (Grey) lady-love, though, in a manner, much less manifest. We may say that both the gentlemen had been very fortunate while at Lucerne. Mr. Palliser had come abroad with a feeling that all the world had been cut from under his (Palliser) feet. A great change was needed for his (Palliser) wife, and he (Palliser) had acknowledged at once that everything must be made to yield to that necessity. He (Palliser) certainly had his (Palliser) reward,--now in his (Palliser) triumphant return. Terrible troubles had afflicted him (Palliser) as he (Palliser) went, which seemed now to have dissipated themselves altogether. When he (Palliser) thought of Burgo Fitzgerald he (Palliser) remembered him (Palliser) only as a poor, unfortunate fellow, for whom he (Palliser) should be glad to do something, if the doing of anything were only in his (Palliser) power; and he (Palliser) had in his (Palliser) pocket a letter which he (Palliser) had that morning received from the Duke of St. Bungay, marked private and confidential, which was in its nature very private and confidential, and in which he (Palliser) was told that Lord Brock and Mr. Finespun were totally at variance about French wines. Mr. Finespun wanted to do something, now in the recess,--to send some political agent over to France,--to which Lord Brock would not agree; and no one knew what would be the consequence of this disagreement. Here might be another chance,--if only Mr. Palliser could give up his (Palliser) winter in Italy! Mr. Palliser, as he (Palliser) took his (Palliser) place opposite his (Palliser) wife, was very triumphant.

And Mr. Grey was triumphant, as he (Grey) placed himself gently in his (Grey) seat opposite to Alice. He (Grey) seemed to assume no right, as he (Grey) took that position apparently because it was the one which came naturally to his (Grey) lot. No one would have been made aware that Alice was his (Grey) own simply by seeing his (Grey) arrangements for her (Alice) comfort. He (Grey) made no loud assertion as to his (Grey) property and his (Grey) rights, as some men do. He (Grey) was quiet and subdued in his (Grey) joy, but not the less was he (Grey) triumphant. From the day on which Alice had accepted his (Grey) first offer,--nay, from an earlier day than that; from the day on which he (Grey) had first resolved to make it, down to the present hour, he (Grey) had never been stirred from his (Grey) purpose. By every word that he (Grey) had said, and by every act that he (Grey) had done, he (Grey) had shown himself to be unmoved by that episode in their joint lives, which Alice's other friends had regarded as so fatal. When she (Alice) first rejected him (Grey), he (Grey) would not take his (Grey) rejection. When she (Alice) told him (Grey) that she (Alice) intended to marry her (Alice) cousin, he (Grey) silently declined to believe that such marriage would ever take place. He (Grey) had never given her (Alice) up for a day, and now the event proved that he (Grey) had been right. Alice was happy, very happy; but she (Alice) was still disposed to regard her (Alice) lover as Fate, and her (Alice) happiness as an enforced necessity.

They stopped a night at Basle, and again she (Alice) stood upon the balcony. He (lover) was close to her (Alice) as she (Alice) stood there,--so close that, putting out her (Alice) hand for his (lover), she (Alice) was able to take it and press it closely.

``You are thinking of something, Alice,'' (he)
he (lover) said.
``What is it?'' (unknown)

``It was here,'' (she)
she (Alice) said--
``here, on this very balcony, that I first rebelled against you, and now you have brought me here that I should confess and submit on the same spot. I do confess. How am I to thank you for forgiving me?'' (she)

-LSB-Illustration:

``How am I to thank you for forgiving me?'' (a couple)
-RSB-

On the following morning they went on to Baden-Baden, and there they stopped for a couple of days. Lady Glencora had positively refused to stop a day at Basle, making so many objections to the place that her (Glencora) husband had at last yielded.

``I could go from Vienna to London without feeling it,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said, with indignation;
``and to tell me that I can't do two easy days' journey running!'' (she)
Mr. Palliser had been afraid to be imperious, and therefore, immediately on his (Palliser) arrival at one of the stations in Basle, he (Palliser) had posted across the town, in the heat and the dust, to look after the cushions and the springs at the other.

``I've a particular favour to ask of you,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Lady Glencora said to her (Glencora) husband, as soon as they were alone together in their rooms at Baden. Mr. Palliser declared that he (Palliser) would grant her (Glencora) any particular favour,--only premising that he (Palliser) was not to be supposed to have thereby committed himself to any engagement under which his (Palliser) wife should have authority to take any exertion upon herself.
``I wish I were a milkmaid,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``But you are not a milkmaid, my dear. You haven't been brought up like a milkmaid.'' (unknown)

But what was the favour? If she (Glencora) would only ask for jewels,--though they were the Grand Duchess's diamond eardrops, he (Palliser) would endeavour to get them for her (Duchess). If she (Duchess) would have quaffed molten pearls, like Cleopatra, he (Palliser) would have procured the beverage,--having first fortified himself with a medical opinion as to the fitness of the drink for a lady in her (lady) condition. There was no expenditure that he (Palliser) would not willingly incur for her (lady), nothing costly that he (Palliser) would grudge. But when she (lady) asked for a favour, he (Palliser) was always afraid of an imprudence. Very possibly she (lady) might want to drink beer in an open garden.

And her (lady) request was, at last, of this nature:

``I want you to take me up to the gambling-rooms!'' (she)
said she (lady).

``The gambling-rooms!'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser in dismay.

``Yes, Plantagenet; the gambling-rooms. If you had been with me before, I should not have made a fool of myself by putting my piece of money on the table. I want to see the place; but then I saw nothing, because I was so frightened when I found that I was winning.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

Mr. Palliser was aware that all the world of Baden,--or rather the world of the strangers at Baden,--assembles itself in those salons. It may be also that he (Palliser) himself was curious to see how men looked when they lost their own money, or won that of others. He (Palliser) knew how a Minister looked when he (Minister) lost or gained a tax. He (Minister) was familiar with millions and tens of millions in a committee of the whole House. He (Minister) knew the excitement of a near division upon the estimates. But he (Minister) had never yet seen a poor man stake his (Minister) last napoleon, and rake back from off the table a small hatful of gold. A little exercise after an early dinner was, he (Minister) had been told, good for his (Minister) wife; and he (Minister) agreed therefore that, on their second evening at Baden, they would all walk up and see the play.

``Perhaps I shall get back my napoleon,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora to Alice.

``And perhaps I shall be forgiven when somebody sees how difficult it is to manage you,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, looking at Mr. Palliser.

``She (my) isn't in earnest,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, almost fearing the result of the experiment.

``I don't know that,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

They started together, Mr. Palliser with his (Palliser) wife, and Mr. Grey with Alice on his (Palliser) arm, and found all the tables at work. They at first walked through the different rooms, whispering to each other their comments on the people that they saw, and listening to the quick, low, monotonous words of the croupiers as they arranged and presided over the games. Each table was closely surrounded by its own crowd, made up of players, embryo players, and simple lookers-on, so that they could not see much as they walked. But this was not enough for Lady Glencora. She (Glencora) was anxious to know what these men and women were doing,--to see whether the croupiers wore horns on their heads and were devils indeed,--to behold the faces of those who were wretched and of those who were triumphant,--to know how the thing was done, and to learn something of that lesson in life.

``Let us stand here a moment,'' (she)
she (Glencora) said to her (Glencora) husband, arresting him (husband) at one corner of the table which had the greatest crowd.
``We shall be able to see in a few minutes.'' (he)
So he (husband) stood with her (Glencora) there, giving way to Alice, who went in front with his (husband) wife; and in a minute or two an aperture was made, so that they could all see the marked cloth, and the money lying about, and the rakes on the table, and the croupier skilfully dealing his (husband) cards, and,--more interesting than all the rest, the faces of those who were playing. Grey looked on, over Alice's shoulder, very attentively,--as did Palliser also,--but both of them kept their eyes upon the ministers of the work. Alice and Glencora did the same at first, but as they gained courage they glanced round upon the gamblers.

It was a long table, having, of course, four corners, and at the corner appropriated by them they were partly opposite to the man who dealt the cards. The corner answering to theirs at the other end was the part of the table most removed from their sight, and that on which their eyes fell last. As Lady Glencora stood she (Glencora) could hardly see,--indeed, at first she (Glencora) could not see,--one or two who were congregated at this spot. Mr. Palliser, who was behind her (Glencora), could not see them at all. But to Alice,--and to Mr. Grey, had he (Grey) cared about it,--every face at the table was visible except the faces of those who were immediately close to them. Before long Alice's attention was riveted on the action and countenance of one young man who sat at that other corner. He (man) was leaning, at first listlessly, over the table, dressed in a velveteen jacket, and with his (man) round-topped hat brought far over his (man) eyes, so that she (Alice) could not fully see his (man) face. But she (Alice) had hardly begun to observe him (man) before he (man) threw back his (man) hat, and taking some pieces of gold from under his (man) left hand, which lay upon the table, pushed three or four of them on to one of the divisions marked on the cloth. He (man) seemed to show no care, as others did, as to the special spot which they should occupy. Many were very particular in this respect, placing their ventures on the lines, so as to share the fortunes of two compartments, or sometimes of four; or they divided their coins, taking three or four numbers, selecting the numbers with almost grotesque attention to some imagined rule of their own. But this man let his (man) gold go all together, and left it where his (man) half-stretched rake deposited it by chance. Alice could not but look at his (man) face. His (man) eyes she (Alice) could see were bloodshot, and his (man) hair, when he (man) pushed back his (man) hat, was rough and dishevelled; but still there was that in his (man) face which no woman could see and not regard. It was a face which at once prepossessed her (woman) in his (man) favour,--as it had always prepossessed all others. On this occasion he (man) had won his (man) money, and Alice saw him (man) drag it in as lazily as he (man) had pushed it out.

``Do you see that little Frenchman?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``He (Frenchman) has just made half a napoleon, and has walked off with it. Isn't it interesting? I could stay here all the night.'' (she)
Then she (Glencora) turned round to whisper something to her (Glencora) husband, and Alice's eyes again fell on the face of the man at the other end of the table. After he (man) had won his (man) money, he (man) had allowed the game to go on for a turn without any action on his (man) part. The gold again went under his (man) hand, and he (man) lounged forward with his (man) hat over his (man) eyes. One of the croupiers had said a word, as though calling his (man) attention to the game, but he (man) had merely shaken his (man) head. But when the fate of the next turn had been decided, he (man) again roused himself, and on this occasion, as far as Alice could see, pushed his (man) whole stock forward with the rake. There was a little mass of gold, and, from his (man) manner of placing it, all might see that he (man) left its position to chance. One piece had got beyond its boundary, and the croupier pushed it back with some half-expressed inquiry as to his (man) correctness.
``All right,'' (unknown)
said a voice in English. Then Lady Glencora started and clutched Alice's arm with her (Alice) hand. Mr. Palliser was explaining to Mr. Grey, behind them, something about German finance as connected with gambling-tables, and did not hear the voice, or see his (Palliser) wife's motion. I need hardly tell the reader that the gambler was Burgo Fitzgerald.

But Lady Glencora said not a word,--not as yet. She (Glencora) looked forward very gently, but still with eager eyes, till she (Glencora) could just see the face she (Glencora) knew so well. His (Fitzgerald) hat was now pushed back, and his (Fitzgerald) countenance had lost its listlessness. He (Fitzgerald) watched narrowly the face of the man as he (Fitzgerald) told out the amount of the cards as they were dealt. He (Fitzgerald) did not try to hide his (Fitzgerald) anxiety, and when, after the telling of some six or seven cards, he (Fitzgerald) heard a certain number named, and a certain colour called, he (Fitzgerald) made some exclamation which even Glencora could not hear. And then another croupier put down, close to Burgo's money, certain rolls of gold done up in paper, and also certain loose napoleons.

``Why doesn't he (Frenchman) take it?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

``He (Frenchman) is taking it,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, not at all knowing the cause of her (Alice) cousin's anxiety.

Burgo had paused a moment, and then prepared to rake the money to him (Burgo); but as he (Burgo) did so, he (Burgo) changed his (Burgo) mind, and pushed it all back again,--now, on this occasion, being very careful to place it on its former spot. Both Alice and Glencora could see that a man at his (man) elbow was dissuading him (man),--had even attempted to stop the arm which held the rake. But Burgo shook him (Burgo) off, speaking to him (Burgo) some word roughly, and then again he (Burgo) steadied the rolls upon their appointed place. The croupier who had paused for a moment now went on quickly with his (Burgo) cards, and in two minutes the fate of Burgo's wealth was decided. It was all drawn back by the croupier's unimpassioned rake, and the rolls of gold were restored to the tray from whence they had been taken.

Burgo looked up and smiled at them all round the table. By this time most of those who stood around were looking at him (Burgo). He (Burgo) was a man who gathered eyes upon him (Burgo) wherever he (Burgo) might be, or whatever he (Burgo) was doing; and it had been clear that he (Burgo) was very intent upon his (Burgo) fortune, and on the last occasion the amount staked had been considerable. He (Burgo) knew that men and women were looking at him (Burgo), and therefore he (Burgo) smiled faintly as he (Burgo) turned his (Burgo) eyes round the table. Then he (Burgo) got up, and, putting his (Burgo) hands in his (Burgo) trousers pockets, whistled as he (Burgo) walked away. His (Burgo) companion followed him (Burgo), and laid a hand upon his (Burgo) shoulder; but Burgo shook him (Burgo) off, and would not turn round. He (Burgo) shook him (Burgo) off, and walked on whistling, the length of the whole salon.

``Alice,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora,
``it is Burgo Fitzgerald.'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
Mr. Palliser had gone so deep into that question of German finance that he (Palliser) had not at all noticed the gambler.
``Alice, what can we do for him (Fitzgerald)? It is Burgo,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

Many eyes were now watching him (Palliser). Used as he (Palliser) was to the world and to misfortune, he (Palliser) was not successful in his (Palliser) attempt to bear his (Palliser) loss with a show of indifference. The motion of his (Palliser) head, the position of his (Palliser) hands, the tone of his (Palliser) whistling, all told the tale. Even the unimpassioned croupiers furtively cast an eye after him (Palliser), and a very big Guard, in a cocked hat, and uniform, and sword, who hitherto had hardly been awake, seemed evidently to be interested by his (Palliser) movements. If there is to be a tragedy at these places,--and tragedies will sometimes occur,--it is always as well that the tragic scene should be as far removed as possible from the salons, in order that the public eye should not suffer.

Lady Glencora and Alice had left their places, and had shrunk back, almost behind a pillar.

``Is it he (Burgo), in truth?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice asked.

``In very truth,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora.
``What can I do? Can I do anything? Look at him (Burgo), Alice. If he (Burgo) were to destroy himself, what should I do then?'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)

Burgo, conscious that he (Burgo) was the regarded of all eyes, turned round upon his (Burgo) heel and again walked the length of the salon. He (Burgo) knew well that he (Burgo) had not a franc left in his (Burgo) possession, but still he (Burgo) laughed and still he (Burgo) whistled. His (Burgo) companion, whoever he (Burgo) might be, had slunk away from him (Burgo), not caring to share the notoriety which now attended him (Burgo).

``What shall I do, Alice?'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora, with her (Glencora) eyes still fixed on him (Burgo) who had been her (Glencora) lover.

``Tell Mr. Palliser,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
whispered Alice.

Lady Glencora immediately ran up to her (Glencora) husband, and took him (husband) away from Mr. Grey. Rapidly she (Glencora) told her (Glencora) story,--with such rapidity that Mr. Palliser could hardly get in a word.

``Do something for him (Palliser);--do, do. Unless I know that something is done, I shall die. You needn't be afraid.'' (unknown)

``I'm not afraid,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

Lady Glencora, as she (Glencora) went on quickly, got hold of her (Glencora) husband's hand, and caressed it.

``You are so good,'' (she)
said she (Glencora).
``Don't let him (Palliser) out of your sight. There; he (Palliser) is going. I will go home with Mr. Grey. I will be ever so good; I will, indeed. You know what he (Grey)'ll want, and for my sake you'll let him (Grey) have it. But don't let him (Grey) gamble. If you could only get him (Grey) home to England, and then do something. You owe him (Grey) something, Plantagenet; do you not?'' (unknown)

``If money can do anything, he (Grey) shall have it.'' (unknown)

``God bless you, dearest! I shall never see him (God) again; but if you could save him (God)! There;--he (God) is going now. Go;--go.'' (She)
She (Glencora) pushed him (Palliser) forward, and then retreating, put her (Glencora) arm within Mr. Grey's, still keeping her (Glencora) eye upon her (Glencora) husband.

Burgo, when he (Burgo) first got to the door leading out of the salon, had paused a moment, and, turning round, had encountered the big gendarme close to him (Burgo).

``Well, old Buffer, what do you want?'' (he)
said he (Burgo), accosting the man in English. The big gendarme simply walked on through the door, and said nothing. Then Burgo also passed out, and Mr. Palliser quickly went after him (Palliser). They were now in the large front salon, from whence the chief door of the building opened out upon the steps. Through this door Burgo went without pausing, and Mr. Palliser went after him (Palliser). They both walked to the end of the row of buildings, and then Burgo, leaving the broad way, turned into a little path which led up through the trees to the hills. That hillside among the trees is a popular resort at Baden, during the day; but now, at nine in the evening, it was deserted. Palliser did not press on the other man, but followed him (Palliser), and did not accost Burgo till he (Burgo) had thrown himself on the grass beneath a tree.

``You are in trouble, I fear, Mr. Fitzgerald,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, as soon as he (Palliser) was close at Burgo's feet.

``We will go home. Mr. Palliser has something to do,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora to Mr. Grey, as soon as the two men had disappeared from her (Glencora) sight.

``Is that a friend of Mr. Palliser?'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Mr. Grey.

``Yes;--that is, he (Palliser) knows him (Palliser), and is interested about him (Palliser). Alice, shall we go home? Oh! Mr. Grey, you must not ask any questions. He (Grey),--Mr. Palliser, will tell you everything when he (Palliser) sees you,--that is, if there is anything to be told.'' (unknown)
Then they all went home, and soon separated for the night.
``Of course I shall sit up for him (Palliser),'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora to Alice,
``but I will do it in my own room. You can tell Mr. Grey, if you like.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
But Alice told nothing to Mr. Grey, nor did Mr. Grey ask any questions.

CHAPTER LXXVI.

The Landlord's Bill.

``You are in trouble, Mr. Fitzgerald, I fear,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, standing over Burgo as he (Palliser) lay upon the ground. They were now altogether beyond the gas-lights, and the evening was dark. Burgo, too, was lying with his (Burgo) face to the ground, expecting that the footsteps which he (Burgo) had heard would pass by him (Burgo).

``Who is that?'' (he)
said he (Burgo), turning round suddenly; but still he (Burgo) was not at once able to recognize Mr. Palliser, whose voice was hardly known to him (Palliser).

``Perhaps I have been wrong in following you,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser,
``but I thought you were in distress, and that probably I might help you. My name is Palliser.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

``Plantagenet Palliser?'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo, jumping up on to his (Palliser) legs and looking close into the other's face.
``By heavens! it is Plantagenet Palliser! Well, Mr. Palliser, what do you want of me?'' (unknown)

``I want to be of some use to you, if I can. I and my wife saw you leave the gaming-table just now.'' (unknown)

``Is she (wife) here too?'' (unknown)

``Yes;--she (wife) is here. We are going home, but chance brought us up to the salon. She (wife) seemed to think that you are in distress, and that I could help you. I will, if you will let me.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

Mr. Palliser, during the whole interview, felt that he (Palliser) could afford to be generous. He (Palliser) knew that he (Palliser) had no further cause for fear. He (Palliser) had no lingering dread of this poor creature who stood before him (Palliser). All that feeling was over, though it was as yet hardly four months since he (Palliser) had been sent back by Mrs. Marsham to Lady Monk's house to save his (Palliser) wife, if saving her (wife) were yet possible.

``So she (wife) is here, is she (wife);--and saw me there when I staked my last chance? I should have had over twenty thousand francs now, if the cards had stood to me.'' (unknown)

``The cards never do stand to any one, Mr. Fitzgerald.'' (unknown)

``Never;--never,--never!'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo.
``At any rate, they never did to me. Nothing ever does stand to me.'' (unknown)

``If you want twenty thousand francs,--that's eight hundred pounds, I think--I can let you have it without any trouble.'' (unknown)

``The devil you can!'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes. As I am travelling with my family--'' (I)
I wonder whether Mr. Palliser considered himself to be better entitled to talk of his (Palliser) family than he (Palliser) had been some three or four weeks back--
``As I am travelling with my family, I have been obliged to carry large bills with me, and I can accommodate you without any trouble.'' (he)

There was something pleasant in this, which made Burgo Fitzgerald laugh. Mr. Palliser, the husband of Lady Glencora M``Cluskie, and the heir of the Duke of Omnium happening to have money with him (heir)! As if Mr. Palliser could not bring down showers of money in any quarter of the globe by simply holding up his (Palliser) hand. And then to talk of accommodating him (Palliser),--Burgo Fitzgerald, as though it were simply a little matter of convenience,--as though Mr. Palliser would of course find the money at his (Palliser) bankers' when he (Palliser) next examined his (Palliser) book! Burgo could not but laugh.

``I was not in the least doubting your ability to raise the money,'' (he)
said he (Palliser);
``but how would you propose to get it back again?'' (he)

``That would be at your convenience,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, who hardly knew how to put himself on a proper footing with his (Palliser) companion, so that he (Palliser) might offer to do something effectual for the man's aid.

``I never have any such convenience,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo.
``Who were those women whose tubs always had holes at the bottom of them? My tub always has such a hole.'' (unknown)

``You mean the daughters of Danaus,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

``I don't know whose daughters they were, but you might just as well lend them all eight hundred pounds apiece.'' (unknown)

``There were so many of them,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, trying a little joke.
``But as you are only one I shall be most happy, as I said before, to be of service.'' (unknown)

They were now walking slowly together up towards the hills, and near to them they heard a step. Upon this, Burgo turned round.

``Do you see that fellow?'' (he)
said he (Burgo). Mr. Palliser, who was somewhat short-sighted, said that he (Palliser) did not see him (Palliser).
``I do, though. I don't know his (fellow) name, but they have sent him (fellow) out from the hotel with me, to see what I do with myself. I owe them six or seven hundred francs, and they want to turn me out of the house and not let me take my things with me.'' (unknown)

``That would be very uncomfortable,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

``It would be uncomfortable, but I shall be too many for them. If they keep my traps they shall keep me. They think I'm going to blow my brains out. That's what they think. The man lets me go far enough off to do that,--so long as it's nowhere about the house.'' (unknown)

``I hope you're not thinking of such a thing?'' (unknown)

``As long as I can help it, Mr. Palliser, I never think of anything.'' (The stranger)
The stranger was now standing near to them,--almost so near that he (Palliser) might hear their words. Burgo, perceiving this, walked up to him (Burgo), and, speaking in bad French, desired him (Burgo) to leave them.
``Don't you see that I have a friend with me?'' (unknown)

``Oh! a friend,'' (the man answering)
said the man, answering in bad English.
``Perhaps de friend can advance moneys?'' (unknown)

``Never mind what he (friend) can do,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo.
``You do as you are bid, and leave me.'' (the gentleman)

Then the gentleman from the hotel retreated down the hill, but Mr. Palliser, during the rest of the interview, frequently fancied that he (Palliser) heard the man's footfall at no great distance.

They continued to walk on up the hill very slowly, and it was some time before Mr. Palliser knew how to repeat his (Palliser) offer.

``So Lady Glencora is here?'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
Burgo said again.

``Yes, she (Glencora) is here. It was she (Glencora) who asked me to come to you,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Mr. Palliser answered. Then they both walked on a few steps in silence, for neither of them knew how to address the other.

``By George!--isn't it odd,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo, at last,
``that you and I, of all men in the world, should be walking together here at Baden? It's not only that you're the richest man in London, and that I'm the poorest, but--; there are other things, you know, which make it so funny.'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)

``There have been things which make me and my wife very anxious to give you aid.'' (unknown)

``And have you considered, Mr. Palliser, that those things make you the very man in the world,--indeed, for the matter of that, the only man in the world,--from whom I can't take aid. I would have taken it all if I could have got it,--and I tried hard.'' (unknown)

``I know you have been disappointed, Mr. Fitzgerald.'' (unknown)

``Disappointed! By G--! yes. Did you ever know any man who had so much right to be disappointed as I have? I did love her (you), Mr. Palliser. Nay, by heavens! I do love her (you). Out here I will dare to say as much even to you. I shall never try to see her (you) again. All that is over, of course. I've been a fool about her (you) as I have been about everything. But I did love her (you).'' (unknown)

``I believe it, Mr. Fitzgerald.'' (unknown)

``It was not altogether her (you) money. But think what it would have been to me, Mr. Palliser. Think what a chance I had, and what a chance I lost. I should have been at the top of everything,--as now I am at the bottom. I should not have spent that. There would have been enough of it to have saved me. And then I might have done something good instead of crawling about almost in fear of that beast who is watching us.'' (unknown)

``It has been ordered otherwise,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, not knowing what to say.

``Yes; it has been ordered, with a vengeance! It seems to have been ordered that I'm to go to the devil; but I don't know who gave the orders, and I don't know why.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

Mr. Palliser had not time to explain to his (Palliser) friend that the orders had been given, in a very peremptory way, by himself, as he (Palliser) was anxious to bring back the conversation to his (Palliser) own point. He (Palliser) wished to give some serviceable, and, if possible, permanent aid to the poor ne'er-do-well; but he (Palliser) did not wish to talk more than could be helped about his (Palliser) own wife.

``There is an old saying, which you will remember well,'' (he)
said he (Palliser),
``that the way to good manners is never too late.'' (he)

``That's nonsense,'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo.
``It's too late when the man feels the knot round his (man) neck at the Old Bailey.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps not, even then. Indeed, we may say, certainly not, if the man be still able to take the right way. But I don't want to preach to you.'' (unknown)

``It wouldn't do any good, you know.'' (unknown)

``But I do want to be of service to you. There is something of truth in what you say. You have been disappointed; and I, perhaps, of all men am the most bound to come to your assistance now that you are in need.'' (unknown)

``How can I take it from you?'' (Burgo/Burgo Fitzgerald/Fitzgerald)
said Burgo, almost crying.

``You shall take it from her (I)!'' (unknown)

``No;--that would be worse; twenty times worse. What! take her (I) money, when she (I) would not give me herself!'' (unknown)

``I do not see why you should not borrow her (I) money,--or mine. You shall call it which you will.'' (unknown)

``No; I won't have it.'' (unknown)

``And what will you do then?'' (unknown)

``What will I do? Ah! That's the question. I don't know what I will do. I have the key of my bedroom in my pocket, and I will go to bed to-night. It's not very often that I look forward much beyond that.'' (unknown)

``Will you let me call on you, to-morrow?'' (unknown)

``I don't see what good it will do? I shan't get up till late, for fear they should shut the room against me. I might as well have as much out of them as I can. I think I shall say I'm ill, and keep my bed.'' (unknown)

``Will you take a few napoleons?'' (unknown)

``No; not a rap. Not from you. You are the first man from whom I ever refused to borrow money, and I should say that you'll be about the last to offer to lend it me.'' (unknown)

``I don't know what else I can offer?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

``You can offer nothing. If you will say to your wife from me that I bade her (wife) adieu;--that is all you can do for me. Good night, Mr. Palliser; good night.'' (unknown)

-LSB-Illustration:

``Good night, Mr. Palliser.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
-RSB-

Mr. Palliser left him (Palliser) and went his (Palliser) way, feeling that he (Palliser) had no further eloquence at his (Palliser) command. He (Palliser) shook Burgo's hand, and then walked quickly down the hill. As he (Palliser) did so he (Palliser) passed, or would have passed the man who had been dodging them.

``Misther, Misther!'' (the man)
said the man in a whisper.

``What do you want of me?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
asked Mr. Palliser, in French.

Then the man spoke in French, also.

``Has he (Palliser) got any money? Have you given him (Palliser) any money?'' (unknown)

``I have not given him (Palliser) any money,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser, not quite knowing what he (Palliser) had better do or say under such circumstances.

``Then he (Palliser) will have a bad time with it,'' (the man)
said the man.
``And he (Palliser) might have carried away two thousand francs just now! Dear, dear, dear! Has he (Palliser) got any friends, sir?'' (unknown)

``Yes, he (Palliser) has friends. I do not know that I can assist him (Palliser), or you.'' (unknown)

``Fitzgerald;--his (Fitzgerald) name is Fitzgerald?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser;
``his (Fitzgerald) name is Fitzgerald.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)

``Ah! There are so many Fitzgeralds in England. Mr. Fitzgerald, London;--he (Fitzgerald) has no other address?'' (unknown)

``If he (Fitzgerald) had, and I knew it, I should not give it you without his (Fitzgerald) sanction.'' (unknown)

``But what shall we do? How shall we act? Perhaps with his (Fitzgerald) own hand he (Fitzgerald) will himself kill. For five weeks his (Fitzgerald) pension he (Fitzgerald) owes; yes, for five weeks. And for wine, oh so much! There came through Baden a my lord, and then, I think he (Baden) got money. But he (Baden) went and played. That was of course. But; oh my G--! he (Baden) might have carried away this night two thousand francs; yes, two thousand francs!'' (unknown)

``Are you the hotelkeeper?'' (unknown)

``His (Baden) friend, sir; only his (Baden) friend. That is, I am the head Commissionaire. I look after the gentlemen who sometimes are not all--not all--'' (the commissioner)
exactly what they should be, the commissioner intended to explain; and Mr. Palliser understood him (Palliser) although the words were not quite spoken. The interview was ended by Mr. Palliser taking the name of the hotel, and promising to call before Mr. Fitzgerald should be up in the morning--a purposed visit, which we need not regard as requiring any very early energy on Mr. Palliser's part, when we remember Burgo's own programme for the following day.

Lady Glencora received her (Glencora) husband that night with infinite anxiety, and was by no means satisfied with what had been done. He (husband) described to her (Glencora) as accurately as he (husband) could the nature of his (husband) interview with Burgo, and he (husband) described to her (Glencora) also his (husband) other interview with the head commissioner.

``He (Baden) will; he (Baden) will,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora; when she (Glencora) heard from her (Glencora) husband the man's surmise that perhaps he (man) might destroy himself.
``He (Baden) will; he (Baden) will; and if he (Baden) does, how can you expect that I shall bear it?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Mr. Palliser tried to soothe her (Glencora) by telling her (Glencora) of his (Palliser) promised visit to the landlord; and Lady Glencora, accepting this as something, strove to instigate her (Glencora) husband to some lavish expenditure on Burgo's behalf.
``There can be no reason why he (Baden) should not take it,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Glencora.
``None the least. Had it not been promised to him (Baden)? Had he (Baden) not a right to it?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
The subject was one which Mr. Palliser found it very hard to discuss. He (Palliser) could not tell his (Palliser) wife that Fitzgerald ought to accept his (Fitzgerald) bounty; but he (Fitzgerald) assured her (wife) that his (Fitzgerald) money should be forthcoming, almost to any extent, if it could be made available.

On the following morning he (Fitzgerald) went down to the hotel, and saw the real landlord. He (Fitzgerald) found him (Fitzgerald) to be a reasonable, tranquil, and very good-natured man,--who was possessed by a not irrational desire that his (Fitzgerald) customers' bills should be paid; but who seemed to be much less eager on the subject than are English landlords in general. His (Fitzgerald) chief anxiety seemed to arise from the great difficulty of doing anything with the gentleman who was now lying in his (gentleman) bed up-stairs.

``Has he (Baden) had any breakfast?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Mr. Palliser asked.

``Breakfast! Oh yes;'' (He)
and the landlord laughed. He (Palliser) had been very particular in the orders he (Palliser) had given. He (Palliser) had desired his (Palliser) cutlets to be dressed in a particular way,--with a great deal of cayenne pepper, and they had been so dressed. He (Palliser) had ordered a bottle of Sauterne; but the landlord had thought, or the head-waiter acting for him (Palliser) had thought, that a bottle of ordinary wine of the country would do as well. The bottle of ordinary wine of the country had just that moment been sent up-stairs.

Then Mr. Palliser sat down in the landlord's little room, and had Burgo Fitzgerald's bill brought to him (Fitzgerald).

``I think I might venture to pay it,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

``That was as monsieur pleased,'' (unknown)
said the landlord, with something like a sparkle in his (Palliser) eye.

What was Mr. Palliser to do? He (Palliser) did not know whether, in accordance with the rules of the world in which he (Palliser) lived, he (Palliser) ought to pay it, or ought to leave it; and certainly the landlord could not tell him (Palliser). Then he (Palliser) thought of his (Palliser) wife. He (Palliser) could not go back to his (Palliser) wife without having done something; so, as a first measure, he (Palliser) paid the bill. The landlord's eyes glittered, and he (Palliser) receipted it in the most becoming manner.

``Should he (Baden) now send up the bottle of Sauterne?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
--but to this Mr. Palliser demurred.

``And to whom should the receipted bill be given?'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
Mr. Palliser thought that the landlord had better keep it himself for a while.

``Perhaps there is some little difficulty?'' (unknown)
suggested the landlord.

Mr. Palliser acknowledged that there was a little difficulty. He (Palliser) knew that he (Palliser) must do something more. He (Palliser) could not simply pay the bill and go away. That would not satisfy his (Palliser) wife. He (Palliser) knew that he (Palliser) must do something more; but how was he (Palliser) to do it? So at last he (Palliser) let the landlord into his (Palliser) confidence. He (Palliser) did not tell the whole of Burgo's past history. He (Burgo) did not tell that little episode in Burgo's life which referred to Lady Glencora. But he (Burgo) did make the landlord understand that he (Burgo) was willing to administer money to Mr. Fitzgerald, if only it could only be administered judiciously.

``You can't keep him (Baden) out of the gambling salon, you know, sir; that is, not if he (Baden) has a franc in his (Baden) pocket.'' (unknown)
As to that the landlord was very confident.

It was at last arranged, that the landlord was to tell Burgo that his (Burgo) bill did not signify at present, and that the use of the hotel was to be at Burgo's command for the next three months. At the end of that time he (Burgo) was to have notice to quit. No money was to be advanced to him (Burgo);--but the landlord, even in this respect, had a discretion.

``When I get home, I will see what can be done with his (Baden) relations there,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser. Then he (Palliser) went home and told his (Palliser) wife.

``But he (Baden)'ll have no clothes,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.

Mr. Palliser said that the judicious landlord would manage that also; and in that way Lady Glencora was appeased,--appeased, till something final could be done for the young man, on Mr. Palliser's return home.

Poor Burgo! He (Palliser) must now be made to end his (Palliser) career as far as these pages are concerned. He (Palliser) soon found that something had been done for him (Palliser) at the hotel, and no doubt he (Palliser) must have made some guess near the truth. The discreet landlord told him (Palliser) nothing,--would tell him (Palliser) nothing; but that his (Palliser) bill did not signify as yet. Burgo, thinking about it, resolved to write about it in an indignant strain to Mr. Palliser; but the letter did not get itself written. When in England, Mr. Palliser saw Sir Cosmo Monk, and with many apologies, told him (Palliser) what he (Palliser) had done.

``I regret it,'' (Cosmo/Cosmo Monk)
said Sir Cosmo, in anger.
``I regret it; not for the money's sake, but I regret it.'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
The amount expended, was however repaid to Mr. Palliser, and an arrangement was made for remitting a weekly sum of fifteen pounds to Burgo, through a member of the diplomatic corps, as long as he (Burgo) should remain at a certain small German town which was indicated, and in which there was no public gambling-table. Lady Glencora expressed herself satisfied for the present; but I must doubt whether poor Burgo lived long in comfort on the allowance made to him (Burgo).

Here we must say farewell to Burgo Fitzgerald.

CHAPTER LXXVII.

The Travellers Return Home.

Mr. Palliser did not remain long in Baden after the payment of Burgo's bill. Perhaps I shall not throw any undeserved discredit on his (Burgo) courage if I say that he (Burgo) was afraid to do so. What would he (Burgo) have said,--what would he (Burgo) have been able to say, if that young man had come to him (man) demanding an explanation? So he (man) hurried away to Strasbourg the same day, much to his (man) wife's satisfaction.

The journey home from thence was not marked by any incidents. Gradually Mr. Palliser became a little more lenient to his (Palliser) wife and slightly less oppressive in his (Palliser) caution. If he (Palliser) still inquired about the springs of the carriages, he (Palliser) did so in silence, and he (Palliser) ceased to enjoin the necessity of a day's rest after each day's journey. By the time that they reached Dover he (Palliser) had become so used to his (Palliser) wife's condition that he (Palliser) made but little fluttering as she (wife) walked out of the boat by that narrow gangway which is so contrived as to make an arrival there a serious inconvenience to a lady, and a nuisance even to a man. He (man) was somewhat staggered when a big man, in the middle of the night, insisted on opening the little basket which his (man) wife carried, and was uncomfortable when obliged to stop her (wife) on the plank while he (man) gave up the tickets which he (man) thought had been already surrendered; but he (man) was becoming used to his (man) position, and bore himself like a man.

During their journey home Mr. Palliser had by no means kept his (Palliser) seat opposite to Lady Glencora with constancy. He (Palliser) had soon found that it was easier to talk to Mr. Grey than to his (Grey) wife, and, consequently, the two ladies had been much together, as had also the two gentlemen. What the ladies discussed may be imagined. One was about to become a wife and the other a mother, and that was to be their fate after each had made up her (wife) mind that no such lot was to be hers. It may, however, be presumed that for every one word that Alice spoke Lady Glencora spoke ten. The two men, throughout these days of close intimacy, were intent upon politics. Mr. Palliser, who may be regarded as the fox who had lost his (Palliser) tail,--the tail being, in this instance, the comfort of domestic privacy,--was eager in recommending his (Palliser) new friend to cut off his (Palliser) tail also.

``Your argument would be very well,'' (he)
said he (Palliser),
``if men were to be contented to live for themselves only.'' (he)

``Your argument would be very well,'' (unknown)
said the other,
``if it were used to a man who felt that he (man) could do good to others by going into public life. But it is wholly inefficacious if it recommends public life simply or chiefly because a man may gratify his (man) own ambition by public services.'' (unknown)

``Of course there is personal gratification, and of course there is good done,'' (Mr. Palliser/Jeffrey/Jeffrey Palliser)
said Mr. Palliser.

``Is,--or should be,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Mr. Grey.

``Exactly; and the two things must go together. The chief gratification comes from the feeling that you are of use.'' (unknown)

``But if you feel that you would not be of use?'' (unknown)

We need not follow the argument any further. We all know its nature, and what between two such men would be said on both sides. We all know that neither of them would put the matter altogether in a true light. Men never can do so in words, let the light within themselves be ever so clear. I do not think that any man yet ever had such a gift of words as to make them a perfect exponent of all the wisdom within him (man). But the effect was partly that which the weaker man of the two desired,--the weaker in the gifts of nature, though art had in some respects made him (man) stronger. Mr. Grey was shaken in his (Grey) quiescent philosophy, and startled Alice,--startled her (Alice) as much as he (Grey) delighted her (Alice),--by a word or two he (Grey) said as he (Grey) walked with her (Alice) in the courts of the Louvre.

``It's all hollow here,'' (he)
he (Grey) said, speaking of French politics.

``Very hollow,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, who had no love for the French mode of carrying on public affairs.

``Of all modes of governing this seems to me to be the surest of coming to a downfall. Men are told that they are wise enough to talk, but not wise enough to have any power of action. It is as though men were cautioned that they were walking through gunpowder, and that no fire could be allowed them, but were at the same time enjoined to carry lucifer matches in their pockets. I don't believe in the gunpowder, and I think there should be fire, and plenty of it; but if I didn't want the fire I wouldn't have the matches.'' (unknown)

``It's so odd to hear you talk politics,'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice, laughing.

After this he (Grey) dropped the subject for a while, as though he (Grey) were ashamed of it, but in a very few minutes he (Grey) returned to it manfully.

``Mr. Palliser wants me to go into Parliament.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Upon hearing this Alice said nothing. She (Alice) was afraid to speak. After all that had passed she (Alice) felt that it would not become her (Alice) to show much outward joy on hearing such a proposition, so spoken by him (Grey), and yet she (Alice) could say nothing without some sign of exultation in her (Alice) voice. So she (Alice) walked on without speaking, and was conscious that her (Alice) fingers trembled on his (Grey) arm.
``What do you say about it?'' (he)
he (Grey) asked.

``What do I say? Oh, John, what right can I have to say anything?'' (unknown)

``No one else can have so much right,--putting aside of course myself, who must be responsible for my own actions. He (John) asked me whether I could afford it, and he (John) seems to think that a smaller income suffices for such work now than it did a few years since. I believe that I could afford it, if I could get a seat that was not very expensive at the first outset. He (John) could help me there.'' (unknown)

``On that point, of course, I can have no opinion.'' (unknown)

``No; not on that point. I believe we may take that for granted. Living in London for four or five months in the year might be managed. But as to the mode of life!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Then Alice was unable to hold her (Alice) tongue longer, and spoke out her (Alice) thoughts with more vehemence than discretion. No doubt he (Grey) combated them with some amount of opposition. He (Grey) seldom allowed out-spoken enthusiasm to pass by him (Grey) without some amount of hostility. But he (Grey) was not so perverse as to be driven from his (Grey) new views by the fact that Alice approved them, and she (Alice), as she (Alice) drew near home, was able to think that the only flaw in his (Grey) character was in process of being cured.

When they reached London they all separated. It was Mr. Palliser's purpose to take his (Palliser) wife down to Matching with as little delay as possible. London was at this time nearly empty, and all the doings of the season were over. It was now the first week of August, and as Parliament had not been sitting for nearly two months, the town looked as it usually looks in September. Lady Glencora was to stay but one day in Park Lane, and it had been understood between her (Glencora) and Alice that they were not to see each other.

``How odd it is parting in this way, when people have been together so long,'' (Lady Glencora/Glencora/Lady Glencora M `` Cluskie)
said Lady Glencora.
``It always seems as though there had been a separate little life of its own which was now to be brought to a close. I suppose, Mr. Grey, you and I, when we next meet, will be far too distant to fight with each other.'' (unknown)

``I hope that may never be the case,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Mr. Grey.

``I suppose nothing would prevent his (Grey) fighting; would it Alice? But, remember, there must be no fighting when we do meet next, and that must be in September.'' (unknown)

``With all my heart,'' (Mr. Grey/John Grey/Grey)
said Mr. Grey. But Alice said nothing.

Then Mr. Palliser made his (Palliser) little speech.

``Alice,'' (he)
he (Palliser) said, as he (Palliser) gave his (Palliser) hand to Miss Vavasor,
``give my compliments to your father, and tell him (father) that I shall take the liberty of asking him (father) to come down to Matching for the early shooting in September, and that I shall expect him (father) to bring you with him (father). You may tell him (father) also that he (father) will have to stay to see you off, but that he (father) will not be allowed to take you away.'' (Miss Vavasor)
Lady Glencora thought that this was very pretty as coming from her (Glencora) husband, and so she (Glencora) told him (husband) on their way home.

Alice insisted on going to Queen Anne Street in a cab by herself. Mr. Palliser had offered a carriage, and Mr. Grey, of course, offered himself as a protector; but she (Alice) would have neither the one nor the other. If he (Grey) had gone with her (Alice) he (Grey) might by chance have met her (Alice) father, and she (Alice) was most anxious that she (Alice) should not be encumbered by her (Alice) lover's presence when she (Alice) first received her (Alice) father's congratulations. They had slept at Dover, and had come up by a mid-day train. When she (Alice) reached Queen Anne Street, the house was desolate, and she (Alice) might therefore have allowed Mr. Grey to attend her (Alice). But she (Alice) found a letter waiting for her (Alice) which made her (Alice) for the moment forget both him (Grey) and her (Alice) father. Lady Macleod, at Cheltenham, was very ill, and wished to see her (Alice) niece, as she (Alice) said, before she (Alice) died.

``I have got your letter,'' (the kind woman)
said the kind old woman,
``and am now quite happy. It only wanted that to reconcile me to my departure. I thought through it all that my girl would be happy at last. Will she (girl) forgive me if I say that I have forgiven her (girl)?'' (the kind woman)
The letter then went on to beg Alice to come to Cheltenham at once.
``It is not that I am dying now,'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)
said Lady Macleod,
``though you will find me much altered and keeping my bed. But the doctor says he (doctor) fears the first cold weather. I know what that means, my dear; and if I don't see you now, before your marriage, I shall never see you again. Pray get married as soon as you can. I want to know that you are Mrs. Grey before I go. If I were to hear that it was postponed because of my illness, I think it would kill me at once.'' (Lady Macleod/Macleod/LADY MACLEOD)

There was another letter for her (Macleod) from Kate, full, of course, of congratulations, and promising to be at the wedding;

``that is,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate,
``unless it takes place at the house of some one of your very grand friends;'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
and telling her (Kate) that aunt Greenow was to be married in a fortnight;--telling her (Greenow) of this, and begging her (Greenow) to attend that wedding.
``You should stand by your family,'' (Kate/Kate Vavasor/KATE VAVASOR)
said Kate.
``And only think what my condition will be if I have no one here to support me. Do come. Journeys are nothing nowadays. Don't you know I would go seven times the distance for you? Mr. Cheesacre and Captain Bellfield are friends after all, and Mr. Cheesacre is to be best man. Is it not beautiful? As for poor me, I'm told I haven't a chance left of becoming mistress of Oileymead and all its wealth.'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Alice began to think that her (Alice) hands were almost too full. If she (Alice) herself were to be married in September, even by the end of September, her (Alice) hands were very full indeed. Yet she (Alice) did not know how to refuse any of the requests made to her (Alice). As to Lady Macleod, her (Macleod) visit to her (Macleod) was a duty which must of course be performed at once. She (Macleod) would stay but one day in London, and then go down to Cheltenham. Having resolved upon this she (Macleod) at once wrote to her (Macleod) aunt to that effect. As to that other affair down in Westmoreland, she (Macleod) sighed as she (Macleod) thought of it, but she (Macleod) feared that she (Macleod) must go there also. Kate had suffered too much on her (Kate) behalf to allow of her (Kate) feeling indifferent to such a request.

Then her (Kate) father came in.

``I didn't in the least know when you might arrive,'' (he)
said he (father), beginning with an apology for his (father) absence.
``How could I, my dear?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
Alice scorned to remind him (father) that she (Alice) herself had named the precise hour of the train by which they had arrived.
``It's all right, papa,'' (she)
said she (Alice).
``I was very glad to have an hour to write a letter or two. Poor Lady Macleod is very ill. I must go to her (Macleod) the day after to-morrow.'' (unknown)

``Dear, dear, dear! I had heard that she (Macleod) was poorly. She (Macleod) is very old, you know. So, Alice, you've made it all square with Mr. Grey at last?'' (unknown)

``Yes, papa;--if you call that square.'' (unknown)

``Well; I do call it square. It has all come round to the proper thing.'' (unknown)

``I hope he (papa) thinks so.'' (unknown)

``What do you think yourself, my dear?'' (unknown)

``I've no doubt it's the proper thing for me, papa.'' (unknown)

``Of course not; of course not; and I can tell you this, Alice, he (papa) is a man in a thousand. You've heard about the money?'' (unknown)

``What money, papa?'' (unknown)

``The money that George had.'' (the reader)
As the reader is aware, Alice had heard nothing special about this money. She (Alice) only knew, or supposed she (Alice) knew, that she (Alice) had given three thousand pounds to her (Alice) cousin. But now her (Alice) father explained to her (Alice) the whole transaction.
``We couldn't have realized your money for months, perhaps,'' (he)
said he (father);
``but Grey knew that some men must have rope enough before they can hang themselves.'' (he)

Alice was unable to say anything on this subject to her (Alice) father, but to herself she (Alice) did declare that not in that way or with that hope had John Grey produced his (Grey) money.

``He (Grey) must be paid, papa,'' (she)
she (Alice) said.
``Paid!'' (he)
he (Grey) answered;
``he (Grey) can pay himself now. It may make some difference in the settlements, perhaps, but he (Grey) and the lawyers may arrange that. I shan't think of interfering with such a man as Grey. If you could only know, my dear, what I've suffered!'' (he)
Alice in a penitential tone expressed her (Alice) sorrow, and then he (Grey) too assured her (Alice) that he (Grey) had forgiven her (Alice).
``Bless you, my child!'' (he)
he (Grey) said,
``and make you happy, and good, and--and--and very comfortable.'' (he)
After that he (Grey) went back to his (Grey) club.

Alice made her (Alice) journey down to Cheltenham without any adventure, and was received by Lady Macleod with open arms.

``Dearest Alice, it is so good of you.'' (unknown)
``Good!'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)
said Alice,
``would I not have gone a thousand miles to you?'' (Alice/Vavasor/Alice Vavasor)

Lady Macleod was very eager to know all about the coming marriage.

``I can tell you now, my dear, though I couldn't do it before, that I knew he (Grey)'d persist for ever. He (Grey) told me so himself in confidence.'' (unknown)

``He (Grey) has persisted, aunt; that is certain.'' (unknown)

``And I hope you'll reward him (Grey). A beautiful woman without discretion is like a pearl in a swine's snout; but a good wife is a crown of glory to her (wife) husband. Remember that, my dear, and choose your part for his (husband) sake.'' (unknown)
